headline: Familiar Rivals in Final Four
text: DENVER — In one semifinal at the N.C.A.A. women’s Final Four, Baylor and Stanford will duel for the fourth time in their histories. In the other semifinal, Notre Dame and Connecticut will double that — in just the last two years.

headline: The Nourse Auditorium
text: Despite street signs that point out the Nourse Auditorium, few walking past the hulking building at Hayes and Franklin Streets know about the opulent 1,800-seat theater inside. Built in 1927 for the High School of Commerce, it has served as a stage for poets, rock stars, lawyers and, for the last 30 years, as storage space for the San Francisco Unified School District.

headline: Wildcats Are Winners in Battle for Kentucky
text: NEW ORLEANS — The faithful flocked from the Commonwealth of Kentucky for their sporting version of a religious experience. The fans of Louisville and Kentucky practically filled the Superdome, with its capacity for 74,000 people, and created an atmosphere that made the stadium feel like a high school bandbox in Paducah or Owensboro.

headline: Surprise in Florida Clouds Favorite’s Path to the Kentucky Derby
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Union Rags was relegated to the role of spectator in Saturday’s 63rd running of the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park as Take Charge Indy led from the start and pulled off the upset.

headline: 40-0 in Sight, Baylor Turns Focus to Stanford
text: DENVER — Undefeated seasons in women’s basketball have been the exclusive property of Connecticut this century; the Huskies’ 39-0 seasons of 2001-2, 2009-10 and 2010-11 are the only perfect runs since Pat Summitt’s Tennessee Volunteers went unblemished in winning the 1998 national championship.

headline: The Secret Owners Behind a Prostitution Website
text: My Sunday column tries to pull back the veil on the owners of Village Voice Media, the company that owns (besides the Village Voice newspaper) the website Backpage.com, which is generally regarded as the leading site for trafficking of women and girls in the United States. The big surprise: Goldman Sachs turned out to be a 16 percent owner.

headline: A Study in Contrasts
text: DENVER — The coaches in the N.C.A.A. men’s and women’s Final Fours have similar issues as part of their jobs: waging recruiting battles, balancing players’ practice time with academics and fighting a culture that emphasizes results in March at the expense of games from November to February.

headline: Keith Olbermann: Machine Gun for Hire
text: Given Keith Olbermann’s abrupt removal at Current and his typically temperate response — “Current’s statement are untrue and will be proved so in the legal actions I will be filing against them presently” — it seems as if his next stop will be a puppet show shot from a basement somewhere. He’ll never work in this town, or any other, again, right?

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Replay: March 31
text: Kentucky roared past Louisville, 69-61, and Kansas pulled off a comeback victory over Ohio State, 64-62, to advance to the national title game.

headline: Romney Predicts a Victory in Wisconsin Primary
text: FITCHBURG, Wis. — At a drop-by stop to help a phone bank for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, Mitt Romney predicted a victory in Wisconsin on Tuesday.

headline: Kansas Tops Ohio State in Tense Stretch Run
text: NEW ORLEANS — Kansas won the “other game” Saturday, the second N.C.A.A. tournament national semifinal, a contest most notable on the surface for what it lacked: even one team from the Bluegrass State.

headline: Knee Surgery for Lin, a Title for Marbury
text: HONG KONG — He’s Linjured. There, we’ve said it.

headline: Pasty-gate and a Series of ‘Own Goals’ Hit Cameron
text: LONDON — It has been one of those weeks for David Cameron, the British prime minister.

headline: Insurgents’ Bombs in Thailand: Bigger and Deadlier
text: HONG KONG — A string of orchestrated explosions rocked southern Thailand during the weekend, killing 14 people, wounding 340 and raising fears of larger and deadlier bombs being used by Muslim insurgents.

headline: From Prisoner to Parliament in Myanmar
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy advocate silenced for two decades by Myanmar’s generals with house arrests and overturned elections, assumed a new role in her country’s political transition on Sunday, apparently winning a seat in Parliament to make the remarkable shift from dissident to lawmaker.

headline: Giants and Jets, the Same Dynamic
text: From the Fifth Down in 2009:

headline: Opening Day? Meh.
text: As the editor of The Meh List, I’m tasked with making sure that any given submission isn’t too cool or too lame but just, well, meh. It’s harder than it sounds.

headline: U.S. Joins Effort to Equip and Pay Rebels in Syria
text: ISTANBUL — The United States and dozens of other countries moved closer on Sunday to direct intervention in the fighting in Syria, with Arab nations pledging $100 million to pay opposition fighters and the Obama administration agreeing to send communications equipment to help rebels organize and evade Syria’s military, according to participants gathered here.

headline: Schrödinger’s Candidate
text: David Javerbaum’s quantum theory of Mitt Romney has to be one of the funniest things I’ve ever read. Check it out.

headline: DirecTV and Tribune Fail to Reach Deal
text: Some DirecTV customers woke up on Sunday without Fox or the CW networks on their television sets, the result of a failed negotiation with Tribune Broadcasting, which owns or operates 23 television stations across the United States.

headline: From Relais & Châteaux, a Chef-apalooza
text: Relais & Châteaux, a network of more than 500 luxury hotels and restaurants around the world, will host its second annual Grands Chefs Dinner on April 16 at Gotham Hall in New York City.

headline: Why I’m O.K. with ‘Pink Slime’ in Ground Beef
text: This is not an April Fool’s Day joke. I agree with Texas Gov. Rick Perry on something — the nutritional merits of derided “pink slime” — the processed last scrapings of meat and connective tissue after cattle are butchered. Dude, it is indeed beef — a source of low-fat nutrition.

headline: Disruptions: Top 10 Lists Lead to Less Choice on the Web
text: The digital age has us living in a perpetual and pervasive popularity contest.

headline: Iraqi Leader Visits Qatar in Defiance of Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s fugitive Sunni vice president left the country on Sunday for a diplomatic trip to the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar, his office announced, a development that threatened to stir new tensions just days after officials in Baghdad hosted a lavish meeting to repair ties with other Arab nations.

headline: Senator Johnson Backs Romney as Santorum Vows Fight
text: Senator Ron Johnson, a freshman Republican from Wisconsin, endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Sunday, adding to the list of prominent elected officials who are coalescing around the former Massachusetts governor.

headline: Myanmar Elections
text: The party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident, declared that she had won a seat in Myanmar’s Parliament on Sunday.

headline: Another Big Weekend for ‘The Hunger Games’
text: “The Hunger Games” continued to dominate movie theaters over the weekend, leaving the big-budget sequel “Wrath of the Titans” and “Mirror Mirror” with Julia Roberts to make do with box-office scraps. Propelled by strong word of mouth, “The Hunger Games” (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America, taking in an estimated $61.1 million for a two-week total of over $251 million, according to Hollywood.com, which complies box-office data.

headline: Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico in 1980s, Dies at 77
text: Miguel de la Madrid, a former president of Mexico whose derided handling of the earthquake that devastated Mexico City in 1985 was the beginning of the end for the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, died Sunday morning in Mexico City. He was 77 .

headline: On Amnesty Day, Somber Owners Surrender Pythons and a Snapping Turtle
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — There was Buck, all 12 green, iridescent feet of him, stretched across the sky. His reptilian tongue lapped the raw air, and a light mist clung to his thick body before a team of handlers managed to coil and stuff him into a small plastic bin. Buck was ready for transport, and, whether or not he or his owners liked it, he was starting a new, possibly healthier life.

headline: Santana Will Start for Mets on Opening Day
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets on Sunday made the announcement they had been itching to make since the middle of February: Johan Santana will be their starter on opening day.

headline: As Foreclosure Problems Persist, Fed Seeks More Fines
text: Federal regulators are poised to crack down on eight financial firms that are not part of the recent government settlement over home foreclosure practices involving sloppy, inaccurate or forged documents.

headline: Original Review: ‘The Best Man’
text: Brooks Atkinson’s original 1960 review in The New York Times of Gore Vidal’s play “The Best Man.”

headline: Response by Big Men in Physical Game Factors Into Kansas’ Victory
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Final Four game between Ohio State and Kansas was breathtakingly physical; a game of inches as the big men cleared out space inside the key. That physicality was particularly challenging for the game’s best players: Ohio State’s Jared Sullinger and Kansas’ Thomas Robinson.

headline: Complacency a Threat to Romney in Wisconsin
text: Throughout the nomination process, Mitt Romney’s campaign has applied a sledgehammer approach to the delicate art of managing expectations. If campaign officials think Mr. Romney is going to win a state, they will find a way to broadcast that to the news media — even when it might not seem to their advantage to do so. If they think Mr. Romney will lose, then they won’t.

headline: Lifting Voices and Ambitions in a Soaring Sacred Space
text: Kent Tritle established his enviable reputation as a choral conductor during the 22 years he led Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, the magnificent series he founded at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in 1989. These days he is about as busy as a conductor can be, having added to his portfolio the directorships of Musica Sacra and the venerable Oratorio Society of New York as well as teaching commitments at the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music, and organist posts at the New York Philharmonic and the American Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Out of Sight in Wartime
text: The backwoods North Carolina cove where Laurel Shelton lives was cursed long before the Sheltons got there. The Cherokee knew to stay away. The first white family to settle there died of smallpox. Laurel’s mother spoke of this setting as a shadow land and “claimed there wasn’t a gloamier place in the whole Blue Ridge.” She died young, as if to prove it.

headline: Something Borrowed, Something Kentucky Blue
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Everyone has one: a story of a wedding they attended that conflicted with a major sporting event. The scene of people looking for a bar with a TV at the reception or listening to a game on the radio in the coat check room, or sneaking peeks at a score on a phone.

headline: Unleashing Playful Music
text: The composer David Del Tredici walked to his seat in Zankel Hall on Thursday evening accompanied by a tall, neatly dressed man wearing a leather dog collar bristling with sharp studs. It was a reminder that the spirit of San Francisco — provocative, playful, a little weird — had arrived in the cool, corporate New York of 2012.

headline: Private Needs, Public Displays
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — It’s no secret why people want to be famous. They want to be loved. They want to live forever.

headline: A Sure Blend of Noise and Melody Imported From Wales
text: Ritzy Bryan, the lead singer and guitarist of the Joy Formidable, derives a lot of her power from an artful dissonance of style. On one level she’s the picture of angularity, lurching fast across the stage, her strumming hand visible only as a blur: a dust devil in a platinum bob. She’s also the keeper of a high, sweet-tart voice, which communicates girlish softness along with its shiver of hauteur. That contrast isn’t really unusual in her chosen field, but Ms. Bryan invests so eagerly in it that she makes it work.

headline: As Viewing Habits Change, Political Ads Switch Screens
text: MILWAUKEE — Just because you own a D.V.R. or watch television online does not mean political commercials are not coming soon to a screen near you.

headline: When Mom Makes Lunch, the Food Is Secondary
text: Nina Levy is putting mothers everywhere to shame with what she makes for her sons’ lunches: their napkins.

text: Ah. I see that Nick Rowe has made the same mistake I made a few days ago, that of trying to engage the monetary mystics in a rational discussion, and is already regretting it.

headline: Billion Price Update
text: For some reason I seem to be seeing a resurgence of inflation scare stories, despite the fact that — gas prices aside — inflation remains quiescent. And along with the scare stories come assertions that the inflation numbers are faked, that the government is hiding the true rate.

headline: Rebellious Tinkerers Dress Up the iPhone’s Uniform
text: For some, fashion means a wardrobe makeover for spring. Then there are those for whom it means an elaborate neck tattoo.

headline: Customized iPhones

headline: Ranks of Working Poor Grow in Europe
text: PARIS — When Melissa Dos Santos leaves her job at the end of each day, she goes home to an unlikely place: a tiny trailer in a campground 30 miles north of Paris, where scores of people who can barely make ends meet are living on a sprawling lot originally designed as a bucolic retreat for vacationers.

headline: Romney Target of April Fool’s Joke
text: MILWAUKEE, Wis. — Aides to Mitt Romney love to talk about his underappreciated sense of humor, and his career as a prankster (juvenile and adult) is storied — there was the time as a teenager he put flashing lights on his car and pretended to pull over two friends who were out with dates, and when as governor he used to short-sheet his state troopers’ beds.

headline: Booking Battle at the Morning Shows
text: Set your alarm clocks for 6:59 a.m., America.

headline: In Kentucky-Louisville, Coaching Differences Were on Display
text: NEW ORLEANS — With two and a half minutes left and Kentucky leading Louisville by 60-53, the Wildcats faced a crucial possession. Coach John Calipari, sensing the urgency of the situation, stood on the edge of the court and screamed for Anthony Davis to go get the ball. Davis obliged, flashing to the elbow, then dumping a pass to a cutting Doron Lamb. Lamb missed the layup, but Davis had drawn so much attention on the play that Terrance Jones had time for not one, but two putback attempts. Jones stuffed the second through the basket for a momentum-changing dunk.

headline: Clarinet Quintets, From Centuries Old to Brand New
text: The clarinet has inspired chamber music composers ever since Mozart wrote his ethereal Clarinet Quintet in A (K. 581), one of several works resulting from his friendship with the clarinetist Anton Stadler.

headline: We’ll Sing and We’ll Spiel, but No Sex Till War Ends
text: Before Saturday evening’s performance of Schubert’s one-act opera “Die Verschworenen” (“The Conspirators”) at the Manhattan School of Music Dona Vaughn, the artistic director of the school’s opera programs, announced that the performers would be dancing in addition to singing, acting and providing their own costumes.

headline: The End of an Affair: Movement Marathon
text: Danspace Project’s black dance series Platform 2012: Parallels came to a close on Saturday. Near the end of the final program, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones, who had served as curator for this series and its predecessor in 1982, listed what he could remember from the previous two months of Parallels performances. It was a conventional wrap-up, except that he did his reminiscing while lying sealed in a garbage bag.

headline: Do Not Feed or Annoy the Dancers
text: Reputations are hard to keep up, especially when you’re still referred to as the bad boy of British dance. It’s something of a weakness then that the choreographer Michael Clark, included as part of the Whitney Biennial 2012, cannot fully separate from his brash, younger self. Despite his attraction to provocative, sexual costumes and rock music, he built dances based on structure and form. The fashionable edge he worked so hard to cultivate is tempered by classical training at the Royal Ballet School.

headline: In Arizona, Censoring Questions About Race
text: In recent weeks, the state of Arizona has intensified its attack in its schools on an entire branch of study — critical race theory. Books and literature that, in the state’s view, meet that definition have been said to violate a provision in the state’s law that prohibits lessons “promoting racial resentment.” Officials are currently bringing to bear all their influence in the public school curriculum, going so far as to enter classrooms to confiscate books and other materials and to oversee what can be taught.  After decades of debate over whether we might be able to curtail ever so slightly the proliferation of violent pornography, the censors have managed a quick and thorough coup over educational materials in ethnic studies.

headline: Stepping Out of the Shadows With a Sunnier Sound
text: When M. Ward released his previous album, “Hold Time,” three years ago, he did much of his recording in his Portland, Ore., home with retro equipment and was so shy onstage that he pulled his ball cap over his eyes. People regarded him as an underground folk-rocker who seemed more comfortable as a sideman than fronting a band.

headline: Excerpt: 'Gore Vidal's The Best Man'
text: Eric McCormack in a scene from the Broadway revival of the play at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Setback Rebounds at Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams
text: The winners of the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams in Memphis last month were Barbara Sonsini of Woodside, Calif.; Judi Radin of New York City; Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y.; Beth Palmer of Chevy Chase, Md.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.

headline: Cherry Blossoms and a Fan Telling Tales
text: Virginia Woolf titled one essay “On Not Knowing Greek,” which she began, “For it is vain and foolish to talk of knowing Greek.” In the world of the performing arts the same disclaimer should be applied by Westerners to the Japanese traditional forms of Kabuki and Noh. Though these styles have been repeatedly seen in the West for decades, familiarization does not erode their strangeness. Last week’s performance of Kabuki dance at Japan Society, featuring Bando Kotoji with live music, was not more difficult than several other performances of Kabuki I have seen; its finest passages were picturesque, eloquent and remarkable. Yet challenges remain.

headline: An Indie-Rock Memoir From Carrie Brownstein
text: Riverhead Books has acquired a book that is sure to thrill indie-rock fans: the memoir of Carrie Brownstein, a singer, songwriter and guitarist in Sleater-Kinney, a beloved all-female band from Olympia, Wash. Ms. Brownstein, who is on tour with a new band, Wild Flag, will write a book about her life in music, Riverhead said Sunday. She is also a creator and star of “Portlandia,” the IFC show that satirizes hipster culture. Jynne Martin, a spokeswoman for Riverhead, part of Penguin Group (USA), said no title or publication date had been decided.

headline: A Shooting, and Instant Polarization
text: What seemed like a single shooting incident in a midsize Florida city — the killing in February of Trayvon Martin — now threatens to divide a country. How did that happen?

headline: Footnote
text: The playwright Yussef El Guindi has won the 2012 Harold and Mimi Steinberg/American Theater Critics Association New Play Award for “Pilgrims Musa and Sheri in the New World.” The announcement came Saturday during the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky. The honor, which recognizes a playwright for work that had its premiere outside New York City in the previous year, includes a prize of $25,000. Citations and $7,500 prizes were also awarded to Ken LaZebnik for “On the Spectrum” and A. Rey Pamatmat for “Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them.”

headline: Whitney Houston Items Are Sold at Auction
text: Thirteen items related to the career of Whitney Houston drew a total of more than $80,000 on Saturday as part of a Julien’s “Hollywood Legends” auction in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Associated Press reported that a bustier, below, worn onstage by Ms. Houston, who died in February, garnered the highest winning bid, at $18,750, while a velvet gown from a pre-Grammy party in 1996 brought in $11,250. Other items included a vest and pearl-drop earrings from Ms. Houston’s wardrobe for the 1992 film “The Bodyguard.” Most of the items were provided by her friends and family. Another auction, which is to include 30 more dresses worn by Ms. Houston, is planned for June.

headline: Encore at the Met Pleases the Audience
text: The tenor sang a number and the audience loved it, so he sang it again. Such encores at the Metropolitan Opera have become such a rarity in recent decades that aficionados — and press offices — take special note. The repeat performance took place on Saturday, when Juan Diego Flórez was appearing in Donizetti’s “Elisir d’Amore.” At the end of the aria “Una furtiva lagrima” the audience responded with so much enthusiasm that Mr. Flórez repeated it. The encore was also heard by millions of listeners because the performance, the last show of the run, was broadcast on radio. Within hours the Met sent out a news release pointing out the encore and mentioning that Mr. Flórez was the last Met performer to offer one (in 2008) and that Luciano Pavarotti was the previous singer to do so (in 1994). The Met had banned encores in recent decades amid a more serious performance atmosphere. But the current general manager, Peter Gelb, has loosened the reins in what he has called an effort to make opera more exciting and entertaining. Encores were common in the 19th century and the early 20th.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Filmmaker Chases an Israeli Spy Story
text: LOS ANGELES — You don’t want an Israeli Air Force pilot on your tail, especially not the kind who has turned documentary filmmaker.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the I.S.M. manufacturing index for March and construction spending for February (Monday); factory orders for February (Tuesday); ADP employment for March and I.S.M. nonmanufacturing for March; weekly jobless claims and unemployment for March and consumer credit for February (Friday).

headline: Giorgio Chinaglia, Cosmos and Lazio Star, Dies at 65
text: Giorgio Chinaglia, the Italian striker who found a way to overshadow even the soccer greats Pele and Franz Beckenbauer on some of the famed Cosmos teams of the 1970s and ’80s, died Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 65.

headline: Kentucky-Kansas: A Look at the Numbers
text: While the nation has been enamored with Kentucky and its eye-popping talent, a statistical analysis for The Quad maintained throughout the past month that Kansas was also one of the teams most likely to win the men’s college basketball championship — identifying the Jayhawks as an impressive No. 2 seed before the N.C.A.A. tournament began and primed to advance through their region after North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall was injured in the first week.

headline: Coast Guard Rescues Sailors Whose Yacht Was Overtaken by Wave
text: Updated | 10:12 p.m. For a sailor on the ocean, there is perhaps nothing more bone-chilling than the sight of a skyscraper-size wave gathering to engulf your boat.

headline: Anticipation High for Rangers-Bruins, but Tortorella Doesn’t Let On
text: Ahead of Sunday’s Rangers-Bruins game at Madison Square Garden, in which the Rangers can clinch the No. 1 seed in the Eastern Conference and home ice through at least the first three rounds of the playoffs, Coach John Tortorella was in extreme business-only mode. He was eager to end the mandatory pregame news conference, which occurred around 5 p.m. This is the transcript in its entirety:

headline: Mets and Niese Are Said to Be Discussing Long-Term Deal
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets have been in discussions about a long-term contract extension with the left-handed starter Jon Niese, according to a person with knowledge of the talks.

headline: Pension Funds Have Mixed Results With Alternative Investments
text: Pension funds have had mixed results with alternative investments.

headline: Pensions Find Riskier Funds Fail to Pay Off
text: Searching for higher returns to bridge looming shortfalls, public workers’ pension funds across the country are increasingly turning to riskier investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds.

headline: Israel Frees Palestinian Detainee After Hunger Strike of Weeks
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian woman who spent more than 40 days on a hunger strike to protest her detention by Israel without charge or trial was released from an Israeli prison on Sunday and sent into temporary exile in Gaza under a deal reached with the Israeli authorities.

headline: On Leaving, and Not Leaving, the Church
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mayoral Hopeful’s Slow Start Has Some Asking if His Heart Is in It
text: William C. Thompson Jr. has heard all the questions. Is he really running for mayor next year? Can he raise enough money to compete in a crowded primary? Does he have the burning desire that it takes to mount an aggressive campaign?

headline: Talk Radio Face-Off Approaches
text: “The Mike Huckabee Show,” the radio show featuring the former Arkansas governor and onetime presidential hopeful that starts next Monday, is not merely another shot at liberal media elites. Conceived by Cumulus Media, the program is a shot at Clear Channel, the radio giant that distributes Rush Limbaugh’s show at the same time of day.

headline: An Eighth-Grade Sports Encyclopedia Finds Himself Without a High School
text: When Omri Shefet started at East Side Middle School two years ago, as a sixth grader, he felt quite small. He had learning problems and needed special education services, including speech and physical therapy, as well as extra support in math and English.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Planning for Parking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Magazine Guidelines for Tablets
text: Magazine publishers may have embraced the tablet phenomenon by preparing digital editions, apps and multimedia offerings, but learning about the reader on the other side of the screen has proved more difficult. Terms used to describe content are inconsistent, and the type of data that can be collected on users varies by device.

headline: To Enroll More Minority Students, Colleges Work Around the Courts
text: With its decision to take up racial preferences in admissions at public colleges, the Supreme Court has touched off a national guessing game about how far it might move against affirmative action and how profoundly colleges might change as a result.

headline: Stars of Hollywood and Madison Avenue
text: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual Transformation conference of the Four A’s, which took place last week in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Can Privatization Kill?
text: ON Oct. 12, 2010, Jimmy Mubenga was deported from Britain. The 46-year-old Angolan had come to the country as a refugee 16 years earlier. But after his involvement in a pub brawl and a subsequent criminal conviction, the government ordered his deportation. Three private security guards escorted him through Heathrow Airport and onto British Airways Flight 77 to Luanda, Angola. The exact details of what followed are still unclear and currently subject to criminal investigation.

headline: At the University of Texas, Admissions as a Mystery
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Even after 20 years of legal wrangling, admission to the University of Texas — and what role race plays — still has its mysteries.

headline: As Smartphones Become Health Aids, Ads May Follow
text: With smartphones changing the culture in so many ways, more and more young people are using their mobile devices to keep track of their health, and the trend is not going unnoticed by advertisers.

headline: Your Choice for World Bank President?
text: The nominations for the new president of the World Bank are closed. For the next several weeks the board of directors will be considering three candidates:· Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, a Nigerian, has a doctorate in regional economics and development from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was the managing director of the World Bank from 2007 to 2011 and is currently the finance minister of Nigeria. Many think she’s the natural choice for the next president. Her appointment would mean that a woman would lead the World Bank at the same time that a woman heads the International Monetary Fund· José Antonio Ocampo, a Colombian, has been the United Nations under-secretary general for Economics & Social Affairs and the finance minister of Colombia. He has a doctorate in economics from Yale University and is currently a professor at Columbia University’s School of International & Public Affairs in New York. He is known for leading Colombia through Latin America’s financial crisis.· Jim Yong Kim, a Korean-American, is a medical doctor and also has a Ph.D. in anthropology from Harvard University. He was a founder of Partners in Health, a nonprofit agency that developed a successful, replicable model to provide health care to the poor. He is president of Dartmouth College and is President Barack Obama’s choice for president of the World Bank.

headline: Painstakingly Reimagining City’s Cabs, Down to the Floor Mats
text: LA JOLLA, Calif. — The goateed French designer and the bespectacled New York City bureaucrat had been at it for about 20 minutes now, politely arguing about the pros and cons of a particular style of plastic sheet.

headline: Britain Sees Chechen Plot to Kill Exile
text: LONDON — The British government and intelligence services have accused “a henchman” of President Ramzan A. Kadyrov of Chechnya of seeking to assassinate a prominent exiled Chechen politician in London, according to court documents revealed here on Sunday.

headline: 2 Channels, and Anchor Who Set Liberal Tone
text: Current TV was co-founded by a former Democratic vice president, but it took Keith Olbermann to give the cable channel its liberal identity.

headline: Naked, With Children
text: I walk around my house naked. My partner often does, too. Not gratuitously, just often. We don’t bother covering up when walking from bathroom to bedroom. We leave the door open when we get dressed. So far, my 8- and 12-year-old sons remain unfazed. If I’m standing nude in the door of the bathroom telling my oldest to clean up the basement, the only thing he finds audacious is the request.

headline: Pink Slime Economics
text: The big bad event of last week was, of course, the Supreme Court hearing on health reform. In the course of that hearing it became clear that several of the justices, and possibly a majority, are political creatures pure and simple, willing to embrace any argument, no matter how absurd, that serves the interests of Team Republican.

headline: A Die-Hard Conservative, but Not on Immigrants
text: SALT LAKE CITY — He is a Republican and a Mormon. He opposes abortion. Mark L. Shurtleff, the attorney general of Utah, also rejects President Obama’s health care law as an assault on states’ rights and he went to Washington last week to urge the Supreme Court to throw it out.

headline: Newly in Business, and Finding a Lifeline
text: Erica Molina was standing where she usually stands at lunchtime, in the middle of her 116 square feet — an irregularly shaped booth in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. She was talking about the $5,000 loan that had allowed her to buy the counter she was leaning on and the used refrigerator behind her when a delivery arrived.

headline: For Some New York Shoppers, No More State Sales Tax
text: Many shoppers got a pleasant surprise on Sunday as New York State reinstated its sales-tax exemption on clothing and footwear items costing less than $110.

headline: Notre Dame Wins a Taut Game and Returns to the Final
text: DENVER — Eight times they have played in the past two seasons, a Big East women’s rivalry so familiar that Connecticut and Notre Dame can finish each other’s plays, the way a husband and wife finish each other’s sentences.

headline: A Report for the Web, on TV
text: When Stone Phillips, formerly of “Dateline NBC,” learned of a first-of-its-kind study in 2011 at Virginia Tech about the magnitude of head impacts on youth football players, his journalistic instincts kicked in.

headline: Apple’s Chief Puts Stamp on Labor Issues
text: A day after Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, toured a Chinese factory where the company’s products are made, an audit commissioned by Apple criticized the long hours and dangerous working conditions at plants run by Foxconn, the operator of the factory Mr. Cook visited last week.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 1, 2012

headline: Tyler and Trayvon
text: IN 2009 President Obama signed a federal bias crimes law named for the victims of two gruesome 1998 atrocities: the young gay man who was tortured, lashed to a fence and left to die; and the black man chained to the back of a pickup by white supremacists and dragged until he was dismembered. The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act joined a 40-year accumulation of statutes declaring that crimes committed with a mind full of racial spite or anti-Semitism or homophobic hatred should be punished more severely than identical crimes committed for greed or vengeance.

headline: Clients Raise Questions About MF Global Checks
text: MF Global customers who closed their accounts in the brokerage firm’s final days have been fuming for months about how the firm mailed checks to them, instead of promptly transferring the money electronically as usual. Many of those checks arrived after the bankruptcy filing, and subsequently bounced.

headline: Judo Legends Don’t Retire
text: William C. Rhoden talks with Yoshihiro Uchida, judo coach at San Jose State for 66 years and of the first United States Olympic judo team, who has no plans to retire.

headline: For 66 Years, a Force for Judo in the United States
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.

headline: In Egyptian Hard-Liner’s Surge, New Worries for the Muslim Brotherhood
text: CAIRO — Hazem Salah Abu Ismail is an old-school Islamist.

headline: Race, Tragedy and Outrage Collide After a Shot in Florida
text: SANFORD, Fla. — Once again, a river of protest raged through Sanford this weekend to demand justice in the name of an unarmed black teenager shot dead. It gathered strength in front of the historic Crooms Academy, the first high school for black students in Seminole County; surged through the streets; and formed a flood of grief and outrage just outside the Sanford Police Department.

headline: A Ballerina Who Wasn’t and Other Reader Tales
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Loan Gone Sour Clouds the Future of a Media Activists’ Haven in TriBeCa
text: In the second-floor room with the green walls, Lenny Charles Labanco pointed to where the news desk sat, and the television cameras once stood. Nearly 10 years ago, he started an organization called International News Net World Report, which from that room produced hundreds of 30-minute programs, which were broadcast on satellite television.

headline: Their Contributors’ Bidding
text: Don’t they ever learn? Large bipartisan majorities in the House and Senate have now passed the deeply flawed JOBS Act and President Obama is expected to sign it soon. The full name is equally seductive: Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act. What it is is an invitation to a fresh round of financial malfeasance. It rolls back important investor safeguards from the post-Enron Sarbanes-Oxley law and the post-financial crisis Dodd-Frank law.

headline: Myanmar Elections
text: The party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident, declared that she had won a seat in Myanmar’s Parliament on Sunday.

headline: A Monsignor Goes on Trial
text: A long overdue step of accountability in the sex abuse of children by wayward Catholic priests — the first-ever trial of a diocesan supervisor for allegedly covering up the scandal — has opened in Philadelphia. The issue of hierarchal responsibility is finally front and center.

headline: Encyclopaedia Britannica’s Last Print Edition Has a Sales Boom
text: When Encyclopaedia Britannica announced last month that it was discontinuing its print editions after 244 years, company executives noted that there were 4,000 sets of the final 32-volume 2010 edition left in a warehouse, the remnants of an old tradition.

headline: The Puzzle of More Autism Cases
text: The latest federal survey suggests that more than 1 percent of all children in the country have been identified as having autism or two related disorders by the age of 8, a far higher percentage than found in previous surveys. But no one knows whether the increase shows that the disorders are more common or whether it simply reflects better detection of cases that would previously have been missed. Either way, the survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggests that more children and parents may need help in coping with these disorders in their schools and communities.

headline: Mr. Chairman, the Great State of Nostalgia ...
text: Yards and yards of patriotic bunting stun the senses as you enter the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, where a revival of “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man” opened on Sunday night. Television monitors displaying black-and-white footage hang from boxes that frame the stage, and the usher handing you your program wears a festive boater with red, white and blue trim. The aim is to give the audience a sense of being present at a presidential nominating convention in Philadelphia in 1960, where the play is set.

headline: Census Numbers for City Won’t Change, Bureau Says
text: The United States Census Bureau, rebuffing a challenge by the Bloomberg administration, will not change its 2010 population total for New York City, a city official said on Sunday night.

headline: Examining Marijuana Arrests
text: The New York State Legislature showed good sense when it exempted people convicted of low-level marijuana possession from having to submit DNA to the state database, unless they have been convicted of a previous crime. Still, the state must do more to curb the arrests of tens of thousands of people each year in New York City for minor possession of marijuana, despite a 1977 state law that decriminalized it.

headline: For Santorum, Hope That Voters See Message as Pins Go Flying
text: CHILTON, Wis. — Struggling to match Mitt Romney in momentum in the polls and endorsements from Republican luminaries, Rick Santorum has turned, for at least part of his day, from contrasting political records to playing up cultural differences.

headline: Master Runner
text: Kathy Martin, 60, is going after a new set of running records for her age bracket. She is breaking them one by one.

headline: After Late Start, Runner Is Speeding Through Records
text: The crowd, small but noisy, fixed eyes on Kathy Martin, the woman in last place. Early on, she was fifth in a pack of 11 runners, calmly moving in heavy traffic. She ran not only efficiently but also beautifully, her classic strides in perfect rhythm, a fluid parting of the empty air, almost balletic.

headline: Ryan Seacrest Is Said to Be Close to New Deal With Comcast
text: Ryan Seacrest is on the verge of completing a new contract with NBCUniversal, the company that owns the E! channel, where he is a host and a producer; Bravo, where he is a supplier of programming; and NBC, where he will soon appear sometimes on the “Today” show.

headline: Aides With Candidate’s Ear, if Not Title or Paycheck
text: WASHINGTON — It is the season of the “informal adviser.”

headline: Rethinking How We Teach Economics
text: What have we learned in the last five years that should be imparted upon future generations of economists?

headline: The Events Leading to the Shooting of Trayvon Martin
text: What may have happened on the night George Zimmerman shot and killed Trayvon Martin in Sanford, Fla.

headline: Nobody Minds Dyeing the Egg, but the Chicken Is Another Story
text: Cute as they are, they are not made of marshmallow.

headline: The Politics of Going to College
text: An unexpected issue in the 2012 election is whether or not rank-and-file Americans should aspire to a college degree. Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum have both made comments about higher education that could come back to haunt them in a general election.

headline: Washington Is First State to Take On Escort Sites
text: SEATTLE — For more than three months, she was sold online for sex. She had run away at 15, gone back home, then run away again. Finally, an undercover police officer caught her, and her pimp. This time she went home and stayed, but she was not the same.

headline: After a Data Breach, Visa Removes a Service Provider
text: Visa removed Global Payments, an Atlanta company that helps the payment giant process transactions for merchants, from its list of “compliant service providers.”

text: NATIONAL

headline: Baylor’s Depth and Defense Subdue Stanford
text: DENVER — Brittney Griner may be the best player in women’s college basketball, but Baylor also has what is so far the best and most complete team.

headline: Land Rover Time-Lapse
text: Beneath the High Line, Land Rover builds an off-road jungle gym in this time-lapse video.

headline: Citizen Journalist in Syria Is Captured and Tortured, Activists Say
text: A citizen journalist in Syria who has been instrumental in assisting those covering the conflict in Homs, helping evacuate wounded journalists from inside the city’s neighborhood of Baba Amr, has been seized and perhaps tortured by the Syrian government, an activist told CNN on Saturday.

headline: Can Bicycling Affect a Woman’s Sexual Health?
text: Spending time on a bicycle seat, which has been linked to erectile dysfunction in men, may also be a hazard to a woman’s sexual health, a new study shows.

headline: Word of the Day | prognosis
text: prognosis •\präg-ˈno-səs\• noun

headline: Paul and Brenda Babits, 51
text: Most pole-vaulters do not stick with the sport after their youthful heyday. The spirit may be willing, but the humility is weak. “They don’t want to jump at heights three or four feet less than they used to,” Paul Babits said. He is different. An athlete who twice qualified for the United States Olympic trials, he not only has kept up with the sport, he has also turned it into a business, coaching vaulters at a custom-built facility in Fort Wayne, Ind. Among his students was his previously nonathletic wife, Brenda, a graphic artist. “She couldn’t even run around the block,” Paul said. Brenda, pole-vaulting now for five years, has a best of 8 ½ feet. “The feeling you get flying over the bar, nothing is better than that,” she said.

headline: Jeanne Daprano, 75
text: Daprano grew up on a farm in Iowa, played a little basketball in high school and later moved to Long Beach, Calif., where she taught third grade for nearly 40 years. She jogged in the sand to keep fit but did not enter a masters track meet until her late 40s. Now she is quite a serious competitor, coupling her running workouts with weight lifting, lunges, squats and time on the rowing machine. “I don’t do it for longevity,” said Daprano, who resides in Atlanta. “I do it to be the best at being alive right now.” Five years ago, she became the first woman to run a seven-minute mile (6:47.91) after 70. And last month, running in the 75-79 age bracket, she set world records in the 400 meters (1:21.28), the 800 (3:18.48) and the mile (7:13.51). Though pleased with her performances, she insisted: “The only record I want is to be in the Book of Life for eternity.”

headline: Nolan Shaheed, 62
text: As a high school student in Pasadena, Calif., Shaheed ran track and played the trumpet until his parents decided he should focus on music. It was a prudent choice. Shaheed went on to a fine career playing the horn with many of the greats, among them Duke Ellington, Aretha Franklin, Stevie Wonder and Natalie Cole. But he also kept up with the running, working out on his own. It was good for his wind. “Air to a trumpet player is like gas to a car,” he said. He sometimes bet his bandmates he could beat them in the mile, running the distance himself while six or seven of them used a relay. “I took a lot of their money,” he boasted. Shaheed has been running masters events for three decades. In 2010, he became the first 60-year-old to break five minutes in the indoor mile (4:57.06). In February, he broke the world indoor record for the 60-64 age group with a 4:35.07 in the 1,500 meters.

headline: Phil McConkey, 55
text: McConkey recalls the butterflies he felt competing in sports in the second grade, and he certainly remembers them from the 1986 Super Bowl season when he caught passes and returned kicks for the Giants. He missed that sensation of excitement, and, with his hair now gray, he wanted to feel it once again. “When you’re younger, you live to compete, and now, at this age, you compete to live,” said McConkey, who works in financial services in San Diego. “You can’t just get off the couch and compete in masters track; you’ve got to work out.” Last month, he ran at the indoor national championships in Bloomington, Ind. “I couldn’t sleep, too nervous,” he said. He went home with two third-place finishes in the 55-59 age group, running the 60 meters in 7.79 seconds and the 200 in 25.98.

headline: Philippa Raschker, 65
text: Raschker had her bone density tested seven years ago, and “they told me I was still like a 20-year-old,” she said. Surely, her powers of recuperation are extraordinary. Though Phil, as she is widely known, has had three knee operations and recently sustained an ankle injury, she broke the world indoor record in the pentathlon in her new age group, 65-69, last month. The sprints and the hurdles are her best events. She has won more than 70 gold medals in masters world championships and is the best-known competitor in masters track. Raschker has twice been a finalist for the Sullivan Award, which honors America’s top amateur athlete, losing out in 2003 to Michael Phelps and in 2007 to Tim Tebow. These days, she trains only two or three times a week, as she is busy working as an accountant in Marietta, Ga., and traveling to Germany to care for her ailing mother.

headline: Bob Lida, 75
text: Lida was the Big Eight champion in the indoor 440-yard dash in 1959. Then a problem with his sciatic nerve forced him to quit track; he thought he was washed up at 22 and turned his attention to a career in advertising. At 40, he decided to start sprinting again. This time, it was a pulled hamstring that spoiled things, so he restricted himself to slower road races. But there is something special about the full-throttle locomotion of the sprints. And at 60, he returned to the dashes, and though his knees lock up every now and again, he is back to being the champion he was at Kansas. In January, he set two indoor world records in the 75-79 age bracket, running the 60 meters in 8.49 seconds and the 200 in 27.03. He credits recent advice from an observant track coach. “It turns out all these years I’ve been overstriding,” Lida said.

headline: North Korea Party Calls for Leadership Meeting
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s ruling Workers’ Party will convene a representatives’ conference on April 11, the country’s state-ran news agency, K.C.N.A., reported on Monday. Analysts said the rare meeting was expected to anoint the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, as the official head of the party.

headline: Too Many Small Fish Are Caught, Report Says
text: An international group of marine scientists is calling for cuts in commercial fishing for sardines, herring and other so-called forage fish whose use as food for fish farms is soaring. The catch should be cut in half for some fisheries, the scientists say, to protect populations of both the fish and the natural predators that depend on them.

headline: Paul S. Boyer, 76, Dies; Historian Studied A-Bomb and Witches
text: Paul S. Boyer, an intellectual historian who wrote groundbreaking studies of the Salem witch trials, the history of apocalyptic movements and the response of the American public to the nuclear annihilation of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, died on March 17 in Madison, Wis. He was 76.

headline: Now, Will She Kick the Hornet’s Nest?
text: HONG KONG — The joy in the streets and at polling stations was unmistakable as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her political party swept to victory on Sunday in Myanmar. Mother Suu, she carried the day.

headline: Bruins Prevent Rangers From Clinching Conference and Top Seeding
text: Rangers fans went to Madison Square Garden on Sunday night ready for a party. Their team needed only a point against the Boston Bruins to clinch the Eastern Conference title and the first seed in the playoffs after Pittsburgh lost earlier Sunday.

headline: A Land Rover Obstacle Course
text: As part of its silver-anniversary festivities, Land Rover built an obstacle course, an off-road "urban-jungle adventure," in west Chelsea through Tuesday.

headline: Little Cheering Accompanies Bruins’ Division Title
text: Tim Thomas wore a baseball cap with a Bruins logo stitched underneath the words “2012 Division Champs.” Otherwise, you would never know Boston had just clinched the Northeast Division with a 2-1 win over the Rangers on Sunday night.

headline: Murray, in Loss to Djokovic, Is His Own Worst Enemy
text: Andy Murray lost the final of the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla., on Sunday to the one opponent that gives him the most trouble in a match — himself.

headline: Charles Lockwood, Who Wrote the Row-House Bible, Dies at 63
text: Charles Lockwood, whose 1972 book, “Bricks and Brownstone: The New York Row House, 1783-1929,” both chronicled and furthered the row-house revival that transformed many New York neighborhoods, died on Wednesday at his home in Topanga, Calif. He was 63.

headline: Knicks Have Returned to Point of Disarray
text: The room filled, the cameras rolled and the shutters clicked, rapid-fire — one last multimedia salute to Jeremy Lin, one noisy farewell to Linsanity. It was not supposed to end this way.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: Gloom for Betty and Roger
text: Season 5, Episode 2

headline: Meanwhile, Starring in China ....
text: With point guard Jeremy Lin out for the remainder of the regular season (and maybe the playoffs) with a torn meniscus in his left knee, the Knicks once again find themselves thin at point guard. Baron Davis has been slowed by a strained hamstring, and Mike Bibby and Toney Douglas are not inspiring much confidence. Halfway around the globe, a former Knicks point guard, Stephon Marbury, is faring far better.

headline: Newswallah: A Brief History of Corruption in the Ministry of Defense
text: Corruption in India’s Ministry of Defense runs deep and wide, judging by the accusations made by defense officials in the past few months. Maybe that shouldn’t be a surprise. In the frequent cases of corruption that have surfaced in the ministry over the years, incidents of graft have implicated everyone from from petty officers to the highest ranks in the department.

headline: The One Who Stayed Holds Kentucky Together
text: NEW ORLEANS — Darius Miller had a “senior moment” on Sunday.

headline: No Easy Path to the Rim for Either Tourney Finalist
text: NEW ORLEANS — Kansas, one of college basketball’s most storied programs, has improbably been cast as an underdog for the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament championship game Monday night. Its opponent, Kentucky, has had a season so dominant that its march to an eighth national title has been perceived as inevitable.

headline: Rodriguez Is Feeling at Home in Miami
text: MIAMI — Much has changed in Alex Rodriguez’s life, and in Miami, since he was a boy growing up here. So returning to play in a meaningless spring training tuneup actually did have some meaning for him.

headline: L.P.G.A.’s First Major Ends in Playoff After Stunning Miss on Final Hole
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — That was not another 40-mile-per-hour gust that sent shivers up and down the 18th hole at Mission Hills Country Club on Sunday. It was the crowd’s collective gasp when I. K. Kim, the leader by one stroke at the Kraft Nabisco Championship, missed a one-foot par putt on the par-5 finishing hole to fall out of the lead and into a playoff with her South Korean compatriot Sun Young Yoo.

headline: Vonn Unruffled by Prospect of Knee Surgery
text: VAIL, Colo. — Lindsey Vonn, the newly crowned overall World Cup champion, could have arthroscopic surgery to repair meniscus cartilage damage in her left knee this week, although she said she did not think the injury would significantly alter her off-season training or affect next winter’s race season.

headline: India’s Industry Helps Open a Door to the World
text: “On the day the Indian trade delegation came across the border, Pakistan was having another political crisis,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times from Lahore, Pakistan.

headline: In Tug of War Over San Jose, A’s and the Giants Remain at a Standoff
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — To some outsiders, the Bay Area can look like one big patchouli party united by high technology, good food and liberal politics. But when it comes to baseball, relations between the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants have become positively nasty.

headline: Photo Replay: April 1
text: The day in sports, including a rodeo in Atlantic City, N.C.A.A. women’s basketball in Denver and the Kraft Nabisco Championship in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

headline: News Quiz | April 2, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: April 2, 1917 | Woodrow Wilson Asks For Declaration of War Against Germany
text: On April 2, 1917, President Woodrow Wilson asked Congress to declare war against Germany, saying, “The world must be made safe for democracy.” Four days later, Congress voted overwhelmingly in favor of a war declaration.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 2, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “No Dribbling and No Passing, but Free Throws Are Nonstop.”

headline: Britons Protest Proposal to Widen Surveillance
text: LONDON — British lawmakers and rights activists joined a chorus of protest Monday against plans by the government to give the intelligence and security services the ability to monitor the phone calls, e-mails, text messages and Internet use of every person in the country.

headline: Beats, Rhymes and Hard Work
text: When Jared Soares decided to document the hip-hop scene in Roanoke, Va., he had a bumpy start. After failing to connect with several local musicians, he was finally invited to the studio of Terrence Palmer, a graphic artist who designed the covers for many of the do-it-yourself CDs sold at corner stores.

headline: Saris and Chuppahs for the B’nei Israel Jews of India
text: Two days before Yamit Talker-Shefer’s wedding to her husband Elad, in traditional Indian custom her family donned colorful saris and gathered together for the henna ceremony, in which her ring finger was painted red in preparation for the wedding ring to come. Forty-eight hours later, in traditional Jewish custom, she and Elad stood under the chuppah – the Jewish wedding canopy – and recited ancient Hebrew vows before an Israeli rabbi.

headline: ‘Vogue of the Veiled’ Has a Following, and Critics
text: HOW is Ala like other fashion magazines?HOW is it different?HOW many subscriptions has Ala sold?

headline: Russian Crash After Takeoff Kills 31
text: MOSCOW — At least 31 people died in a plane crash in Siberia early Monday, Russian officials said, the latest in a string of deadly crashes that have eroded confidence in Russia’s commitment to air safety.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | April Checklist for Seniors
text: In March, The Choice introduced an occasional series called Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track as they go through the admissions process.

headline: Easy Does It
text: There may be no better barometer of a designer’s commercial success than retailers and consumers clamoring for those interim collections known as resort and prefall. So after four seasons of challenging pieces like patterned pajama sets and over-the-top quilted coats, the Northern Irish designer J. W. Anderson (left) has come down to earth — at least a little — for his first prefall collection. Alongside straight-leg pants, pleated skirts and jewel-tone turtlenecks (including one in blue with bright green sleeves), Anderson still offers plenty of quilting: a white A-line skirt, a red-and-white checkerboard print jacket and two puffy bombers, one in black patent leather and another in brown with white sleeves and a shearling collar. “I like the idea of storytelling, and for me this collection was the prequel to my fall collection,” the designer says. “Both collections are for the same woman and for me all the pieces work together, but I definitely aimed to design clothes that were easier and more relatable.” That doesn’t mean Anderson has lost touch with the avant-garde. For fall expect vinyl suiting, pillow-top apron skirts and a curious take on the deerstalker cap.

headline: A March for Those Whose Lives Were Taken, and Others Yet to Be Taken
text: It was Palm Sunday, a celebration of what the Gospels say was Jesus’s triumphal entry into Jerusalem. On this Palm Sunday, though, there was no feeling of triumph in a march that wound through three city-run housing complexes in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. If anything, the path followed by this procession could have qualified as a latter-day Via Dolorosa, the sorrowful road that Jesus walked on his way to the cross.

headline: A Middle-School Student Overlooked by the High School Draft

In his On Education column in The New York Times this Monday morning, Michael Winerip reminds us of the many young lives in the city's hands, and puts the focus on one of them.

headline: Taylor Swift Retains Crown as Entertainer of the Year
text: Taylor Swift, Miranda Lambert and Jason Aldean were the big winners at the 47th annual Academy of Country Music Awards in Las Vegas on Sunday night in a show that provided few surprises. Ms. Swift, who at 22 has become one of the highest-earning singers in any genre, was named entertainer of the year for the second year in a row, beating out Mr. Aldean, Kenny Chesney and Brad Paisley. The award was not unexpected. Her last album, “Speak Now,” was the second-best-selling LP of 2011, and Billboard recently named her its top moneymaker last year with an estimated $35 million earned. She also won two Grammys earlier this year.

headline: Think Very Different: Ashton Kutcher to Play Steve Jobs
text: In his best-known roles, Ashton Kutcher has played a young man who came of age in the 1970s and a self-made technology gazillionaire, so why shouldn’t his latest gig combine them both? Mr. Kutcher, the sitcom star of “That ’70s Show” and “Two and a Half Men,” is set to portray Steve Jobs in an independent film about that Apple co-founder, Variety reported. The film, called “Jobs,” is to be directed by Joshua Michael Stern (“Swing Vote”) and written by Matt Whiteley, and is expected to chronicle Jobs’s life from his relatively wayward youth to his involvement in the creation of Apple. Variety said the film is expected to start production in May while Mr. Kutcher is on a hiatus from “Two and a Half Men,” on which he plays Walden Schmidt, a wealthy Internet entrepreneur.

headline: Sephardic Dishes for the Passover Table
text: When I am planning a Passover menu I look to the Sephardic traditions of the Mediterranean. The Sephardim were the Jews of the Iberian Peninsula; they had a rich culture and lived in harmony with Christians and Muslims until the Spanish and Portuguese Inquisitions at the end of the 15th century, when all non-Christians were expelled from Spain and Portugal. The Sephardim were welcomed in Turkey, and many went to Greece, North Africa and the Middle East as well. I’ve chosen an assortment of vegetarian dishes from all of these places for this week’s Recipes for Health. Throughout the Mediterranean, springtime is the season for spinach and other greens, artichokes and fava beans, and these vegetables make delicious appearances at Passover meals. There’s much in the way of healthy produce to choose from, and olive oil is the only fat you’ll find.

headline: A Burden Too Heavy to Bear
text: In late December 1861 Northern newspapers buzzed with rumors about a high-ranking Confederate officer who had committed suicide. Within days the victim was identified as Philip St. George Cocke, one of Virginia’s wealthiest and largest planters. Cocke, a West Point graduate, had been appointed commander of Virginia’s state forces by Governor John Letcher in the earliest days of hostilities. He lost his coveted rank of brigadier general, however, when Southern state militias were folded into the Confederate Army.

headline: Oh My, Steve Keen Edition
text: Update update: Ah, so Keen didn’t mean DSGE — a term that refers only to New Keynesian models — when he said DSGE; he meant New Classical, which he somehow regards as the underlying principles for models that aren’t New Classical at all. OK. Anyway, enough of that. I’m all for listening to heretics when they offer insights I can use, but I’m not finding that at all in this conversation, just word games and continual insistence that the members of the sect have insights denied to us lesser mortals. Time to move on.

headline: Growth Industry | Williams-Sonoma Goes Agrarian
text: Williams-Sonoma, the company that has lured every amateur Thomas Keller and Alice Waters into the kitchen with the promise of gleaming, chef-grade pots and pans and all manner of specialized countertop appliances, not only wants you to prepare your own food but also to grow it. On Thursday, it will introduce Agrarian, a collection offering just about everything one might possibly need to make the leap from seed to table, including cedar garden beds and window boxes, organic soil and fertilizer, heirloom seeds, copper gardening tools, even a chic dark denim gardening apron. For the more adventurous (or for anyone who doesn’t live in Manhattan) there is even a backyard beehive (beehive starter kit sold separately) and portable chicken coops (above). Or, for those who don’t want to get their hands dirty, there are kits for making cheese and kombucha and all the accouterments for “putting up” the fruits and vegetables you “picked” at your local farmers market. Shipping costs aside, in keeping with the locavore spirit, the emphasis is on small producers like Brooklyn Slate, which provides Agrarian’s slate garden markers, and Fire Escape Farms, a company in Northern California whose leafy greens and rainbow beets seed packets are also part of the Agrarian mix. “It’s about building community through food,” says Daron Joffe (affectionately known as Farmer D), an organic farmer and advocate who produces the raised beds from sustainably harvested cedar in Atlanta. “There is a lot of opportunity for growth.”

headline: The ABC’s of the Health Care Law and Its Future

The justices will decide whether the so-called individual mandate is constitutional, and if not, whether the entire law must be overturned.

text: 3:48 p.m. | Updated with comments from Coty’s chairman

headline: In Syria, Some Assad Loyalists Waver
text: A young writer living in Syria’s capital city has agreed to share some observations of the uprisings and subsequent crackdowns happening across the country. We have withheld the writer’s name for security reasons.

headline: Understanding the Dip in Class-Action Securities Settlements
text: Cornerstone Research recently found that the number of court-approved settlements of securities class-action suits fell 25 percent in 2011, to 65 — the lowest level in more than a decade. Below, two lawyers, Daniel Tyukody and Gerald Silk, discuss the significance of the most recent annual study:

headline: Digital Notes: ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic Sues Sony for $5 million
text: Adding to the recent wave of artists suing record companies over online royalties, “Weird Al” Yankovic has sued Sony Music Entertainment, saying he is owed more than $5 million. In the suit, filed Friday at United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Yankovic says the company underpaid him for videos and other expenses, and also incorrectly counted downloads of his music as “sales” rather than as “licenses,” which pay a higher royalty rate.

headline: Parole Denied Again for Killer No Longer Considered Dangerous
text: The State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision, for the eighth time, has denied parole to Dempsey Hawkins, a 52-year-old inmate who killed his girlfriend when he was a teenager on Staten Island 36 years ago.

headline: Romney Bats Away Mormon Question, Then Engages
text: HOWARD, Wis. — Before the young voter in Mitt Romney‘s town hall meeting here was even able to get his question out on Monday, Mr. Romney suspected where the conversation was headed.

headline: Sparring to the End
text: April 2, 2012 - Rick Santorum continues to criticize Mitt Romney ahead of Tuesday's primaries.

headline: Turkey Steps Up Demands for Antiquities in U.S. Museums
text: The government of Turkey appears to be joining the list of countries making more concerted demands of the United States for the return of antiquities believed to have been looted and exported illegally, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: New Estimate Raises Civil War Death Toll
text: For 110 years, the numbers stood as gospel: 618,222 men died in the Civil War, 360,222 from the North and 258,000 from the South — by far the greatest toll of any war in American history.

headline: A Favored Son Returns to Uphill Battle in Nebraska
text: LINCOLN, Neb. — Bob Kerrey, the former governor and two-term senator from Nebraska, has returned to his native state after a decade in New York City to try to reclaim his Senate seat.

headline: Tweet, Tweet, Go the Kindergartners
text: Three days a week, as the school day draws to a close, Jennifer Aaron's kindergarten class at P.S. 150 in Manhattan sits down to compose a message about what they have been doing all day. Then they send it out to their parents and relatives through Twitter, the stomping grounds of celebrities and politicians, where few kindergartners have been known to venture.

headline: TimesCast | From Dissident to Lawmaker
text: April 2, 2012 — After two decades as a political dissident under house arrest in Myanmar, Aung Sun Suu Kyi appears to have now made the transition to political representative.

headline: Obama Remains Confident That Court Will Uphold Health Care Law
text: President Obama declared on Monday that he was confident that the Supreme Court would uphold his health care law, saying it would be an “unprecedented, extraordinary” step to overturn legislation passed by a “strong majority of a democratically elected Congress.”

headline: TimesCast: Sparring to the End
text: Rick Santorum continues to battle Mitt Romney despite Republican calls to coalesce around one candidate to defeat President Obama. Jeff Zeleny reports.

headline: Less Outdoor Playtime for Preschool Girls
text: American parents aren’t taking our preschoolers, and in particular our preschool girls, out to play. According to a study published online Monday in the Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, about half of the parents of preschoolers in a national sample said they did not take their children outside daily — a result that the researchers say suggests the children aren’t getting the level of physical activity they need.

headline: Santorum Says Contested Convention Could Benefit G.O.P.
text: APPLETON, Wis. — Refusing to concede the inevitability of Mitt Romney‘s candidacy, Rick Santorum said a contested Republican convention in August would be “energizing” for the party.

headline: Trayvon Martin and the Smoking Gun
text: It should be clear to everyone by now that our ability to know exactly what led to the death of Trayvon Martin expired when he did. But that’s no excuse for not even making the effort, for taking the killer at his word and calling it a day.

headline: Asked & Answered | Tilt
text: The stately hôtel particulier Au Vieux Panier sits on one of the many labyrinthine cobblestone streets in the hillside district of Le Panier, Marseille’s oldest neighborhood and home to a thriving art scene. Formerly a Corsican grocer, this 17th-century building was converted into a boutique hotel in 2010 by the Franco-British entrepreneur Jessica Venediger with a unique focus. “Sleep in a work of art” is the experience promised there, and because the hotel doubles as an installation art gallery, it delivers exactly that.

headline: Vocal Responses on the Issue of Grunting
text: Saturday’s story about the Women’s Tennis Association cracking down on what it calls excessive grunting elicited a handful of pointed responses from readers.

headline: In Turbocharged Porsches, Artist Richard Phillips Finds a New Muse
text: On a balmy March afternoon in Manhattan, the artist Richard Phillips was breaking in the refurbished engine on his 1992 Porsche 965. Mr. Phillips, who is 6-foot-5, just missed scraping his head on the roofline of the white sports car.

headline: Projecting Anthony Davis’s Career in the N.B.A.
text: NEW ORLEANS — Over the past 20 years there have been 10 clear franchise players taken with the first pick in the N.B.A. draft. The list includes LeBron James and Allen Iverson, Blake Griffin and Dwight Howard — players who immediately became the cornerstones of their franchise, were good pros from Day 1 and gave their team a legitimate chance to win a championship.

headline: Good Weekend for CBS
text: A combination of college basketball and country music translated into strong ratings for CBS over the weekend. The network’s coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s Final Four on Saturday earned its highest preliminary rating since 2005, according to Nielsen estimates, and averaged 14.9 million total viewers.

headline: The Billionaire Family Backing the Avon Bid
text: Behind Coty’s $10 billion unsolicited offer for Avon Products is one of Europe’s wealthiest and most private families: the Reimanns.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Adventure Time’
text: The return of “The Killing” on Sunday night may have drawn the attention of adult viewers, but their children are likely to be waiting for the resolution of a different cliffhanger: Will 14-year-old Finn the Human hook up with the Flame Princess? The answer comes at 7:30 p.m. on Monday night, when Cartoon Network’s popular animated series “Adventure Time” begins its fourth season. (The Season 3 finale will be shown at 7.)

headline: Santorum Bowls a Spare
text: Rick Santorum picked up a spare at a campaign event at Sabre Lanes in Appleton, Wis.

headline: Hazards: Mild Sleep Disorders Tied to Depression
text: Snorting and stopping breathing during sleep are associated with depression, even in people whose symptoms do not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea, a new study has found.

headline: In a Fight Between the Flyers and Penguins, Even the Coaches Get Involved
text: This wasn’t an April Fool’s prank or an attempt by Philadelphia Flyers Coach Peter Laviolette to add some dark comedy to the waning moments of Sunday’s third period. The Flyers were playing the Penguins in Pittsburgh, with the game being NBC’s N.H.L. broadcast of the week, when a fight-fueled frenzy broke out.

headline: Really? A Longer Allergy Season as Climate Warms
text: THE FACTS

headline: Video of Aung San Suu Kyi’s Remarks After Elections in Myanmar
text: As my colleague Thomas Fuller reports, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy advocate and Nobel Peace laureate who was kept under house arrest for 15 years by Myanmar’s generals, spoke to supporters on Monday, after a resounding triumph in dozens of parliamentary by-elections.

headline: Patterns: Alcohol May Help Heart Attack Survivors
text: It’s well established that moderate alcohol consumption may ward off heart disease. But even after a heart attack, an alcoholic drink a day may be good for a man’s health, a new study has found.

headline: Mets’ Closer to Have M.R.I. Test on Knee
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Closer Frank Francisco said he planned to have a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left knee Monday night.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Affirmative Action Ban in California
text: A federal appeals court panel has upheld California’s ban on using affirmative action during the admissions process of public colleges and universities, The Associated Press reports.

headline: The View from Kansas: A Team Built on Trust
text: The Quad asked writers at newspapers at the University of Kansas and the University of Kentucky for reports on what to expect on Monday night.

headline: Selling America Abroad
text: Time was when just the mention of the Grand Canyon, the Pacific Coast Highway or the New York skyline was enough to entice tourists from around the world. But that was before 9/11 and the rise of security barriers on entering the United States. And it was before Asia’s economic renaissance drew travelers there.

headline: For a Bronx Student, Home Is Poetry
text: What is it like for a young girl to be uprooted from her home and sent to a new country? A poem by a Bronx high school student evokes sadness, loss and yearning. We publish it here because of its powerful reflection on an experience shared by so many students in New York City.

headline: At a Bronx Middle School, Reflections on Trayvon and Lost Dreams
text: Laura Klein, who teaches at a Bronx middle school, says she has had a tough time getting her students interested in current events. But the Trayvon Martin case practically walked into her classroom. When she gave her students an assignment related to the case, she writes: "They got right to work, quiet and focused, only pausing to discuss the issue with their peers.  This was an issue with which they clearly connected."

headline: Reading Material at the Strand Does Not Include a Contract
text: The Strand Bookstore has long stood as a beacon in the city for book lovers, tourists and those on lunch break who just want to lose themselves in a foreign world before returning to another corporate meeting.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading
text: Guess and Gucci pick up where Christian Louboutin and Yves Saint Laurent left off in the latest designer trademark infringement case.

headline: From Strife-Marked Vineyards
text: IN his 72 years, Serge Hochar has produced 53 vintages of Château Musar, a wine that has enthralled several generations only partly because of its unusual provenance, the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon.

headline: The Joys of “Old” Potatoes
text: Clotilde Hryshko runs a farm and CSA in a beautiful valley in Brookfield, Vt. She has written some lovely pieces that have appeared on www.markbittman.com.

headline: Nokia’s Lumia Ads Say Your Phone Is No Good
text: Nokia’s strategy to sell its new Lumia smartphone is to make you feel dumb about what you already have. New video ads from Nokia, the Finnish phone maker, suggest that iPhones and Android phones are flawed, unfinished “beta” devices, which makes you a sucker for having one.

headline: No Misbehaving for This Heiress
text: UNDER the storied stone atrium of the Hearst Building in Midtown, a small pale figure emerged from the elevator the other day. Thin and casually chic with blond hair and young-Mariel Hemingway eyebrows, she could have been any glossy fashion editor in the building preoccupied with getting a byline, boyfriend, bikini wax or blowout.

headline: First the Mandate, Then All Tax Incentives
text: Last week the Supreme Court heard a case about whether the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance mandate is constitutional. But striking down the mandate could suggest that all sorts of tax incentives are similarly unconstitutional, an economist says.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Women and Tablet Ratings
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Regulator Accuses R.B.C. of ‘Massive’ Trading Scheme
text: Regulators on Monday accused the Royal Bank of Canada of orchestrating an elaborate trading scheme and booking bogus trades to generate lucrative tax benefits.

headline: Gunman Opens Fire at University in Oakland
text: The Times will post updates as they become available.

headline: Talking Baseball With Times Reporters
text: Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh discuss the upcoming season with Times readers.

headline: Talking Baseball With Times Reporters
text: The Times’s sports department started experimenting with Google-plus video hangouts last month, and with opening day coming this week, we thought it was time to get our baseball reporters in front of webcams. So, Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh joined a handful Times readers to discuss the 2012 season, with topics ranging from Albert Pujols and Prince Fielder to the new playoff format to whether Mets fans have any hope of enjoying the summer, even if that means rooting for Bobby Valentine against the Yankees.

headline: A River Crossing
text: Even after 20 years of studying in the country, Brian L. Fisher, an entomologist, was surprised by the ability of a cyclone to derail an expedition.

headline: Wearing Waist-Length Hair, and a Sense of Humor
text: I’M a bass player in a jam band, and we do a lot of concert tours. So I fly a lot. Flying is so far removed from anything that I would really want to do that I just endure it. But once I’m up in the air, I suppose I do like it a little bit better, since I’m going someplace to do something that I enjoy.

headline: A Brief Therapy Heals Trauma in Children
text: Every year millions of children from all walks of life become victims of, or witnesses to, abusive or violent events that can result in long-lasting symptoms of distress. The events can range from sexual and physical abuse to involvement in a natural disaster, fire or serious motor vehicle accident.

headline: Micronutrient Insurance
text: Q. A doctor told me that you don’t need daily vitamin supplements if you eat right, and that they don’t dissolve anyway. Is he correct?
