text: John McCain already tried that.

headline: A Virus May Make Mosquitoes Even Thirstier for Human Blood
text: The dengue virus may actually make mosquitoes thirstier for human blood, new research has found.

headline: AMC Sunday Dramas Suffer Ratings Falloff
text: AMC is trying back-to-back dramas on Sunday night and so far the results are a bit underwhelming.

headline: The Right to Strip
text: I’m not a constitutional lawyer, or actually a lawyer of any kind. But there are days when I read a Supreme Court opinion and I just wonder, what on earth are these people thinking? Like today, for example.

headline: How to Cultivate Eureka Moments
text: What makes the cartoon light bulb of creativity go off over someone’s head? What is the catalyst for groundbreaking inventions and innovative breakthroughs? In his illuminating new book, the journalist Jonah Lehrer explicates some now classic case studies. As he tells it:

headline: Learning on the Road to Nowhere in Madagascar
text: Brian L. Fisher, an entomologist at the California Academy of Sciences, has been studying the ants of Madagascar for more than 15 years.

headline: Glass Slipper as Fetish
text: Sex is a hard sell.

headline: Traveling the World,  Bottles Full of Miracles
text: Serge Hochar, the guiding spirit of Château Musar, is 72 years old. It only seems as if he’s been spreading the gospel of Musar for that long. In fact, Musar, made in Beirut from grapes grown in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon, is a singular wine that is almost as remarkable as Mr. Hochar himself.

headline: Numberplay delayed this week
text: Numberplay is delayed, and will appear later this week. Please check the permanent Numberplay link for the post later in the week. Thank you for your patience.

headline: Gunman Kills 7 in a Rampage at a Northern California University
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A former student opened fire on students and staff at a religious college here on Monday morning, killing seven people and wounding at least three more, the authorities said.

headline: Does RIM’s Enterprise Plan Herald More Shrinking?
text: During his first quarterly financial results conference call as chief executive last week, Thorsten Heins of Research In Motion said that he was taking the company back to its roots. RIM, he said, would again focus its attention on customers who use BlackBerrys for work.

headline: Goldman Announces Changes to Its Board
text: Goldman Sachs announced changes to its board late Monday, appointing a lead director and losing one of its three female board members.

headline: A Push for Relocation After Mold Found at Brooklyn School
text: After finding black mold in several classrooms at a Williamsburg middle school, education officials say the building is now safe. Some parents and students, however, aren't so sure, and will bring their concerns to a meeting Monday night.

headline: Evidence Against Moon as Meteoroid’s Offspring
text: Astronomers have long theorized that the Moon was formed when an object the size of Mars slammed into Earth, sending a huge mass of rock into orbit around it. “According to the prevailing model prediction, approximately half of the Moon-forming material should come from the Mars-size impactor,” said Junjun Zhang, an isotope geochemist at the University of Chicago and the study’s first author.

headline: Augusta’s Flowers Are Wilting, but Bloom Is Still On for Simpson
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Images of bright, verdant blooms and shimmering pastels have forever been associated with Augusta National and the Masters, but this year’s tournament may have a little less color than usual.

headline: Amy Brenneman to Star in New Gina Gionfriddo Play
text: The actress Amy Brenneman will star in the premiere production of Gina Gionfriddo’s new play “Rapture, Blister, Burn” at Playwrights Horizons this spring, the theater announced on Monday. Ms. Brenneman, a five-time Emmy Award nominee known for her television roles in “Private Practice,” “Judging Amy” and “NYPD Blue,” will be joined in the cast by Kellie Overbey, Lee Tergesen, Beth Dixon and Virginia Kull.

headline: Fred Rubino, a Popular Brooklyn Superintendent, Dies
text: Fortunato "Fred" Rubino, a popular former principal who was recently appointed the superintendent of District 14 in Brooklyn, died Monday morning.

headline: Keeping Score: Comparing Kentucky and Kansas on the Stat Sheet
text: In a previous post on The Quad, Jack Styczynski analyzed the championship matchup between Kentucky and Kansas using statistics that show a strong correlation with success.

headline: Family War Stories, Both Lived and Told
text: When you have a famous last name, a lot of obligations come with it.

headline: The gender gap in computer science; recounting the Civil War dead; and it turns out you are what you wear.
text: The gender gap in computer science; recounting the Civil War dead; and it turns out you are what you wear.

headline: JetBlue Fracas Highlights Need for Alert Passengers
text: ABOUT 1.7 million people board about 28,000 commercial flights each day in the United States. Occasionally, something unexpected is bound to happen.

headline: Willets Point Development Makes Gain With Highway Administration’s Approval
text: The Federal Highway Administration has removed a major obstacle to the Bloomberg administration’s plan to turn a waterlogged enclave of crumbling shops and sheds near Citi Field into a major development site.

headline: How Immersion Helps to Learn a Language
text: Learning a foreign language is never easy, but contrary to common wisdom, it is possible for adults to process a language the same way a native speaker does. And over time, the processing improves even when the skill goes unused, researchers are reporting.

headline: Watergate Reporting, the Second Draft
text: Rarely does reality intersect with role playing the way it did two Sundays ago in Bob Woodward’s living room.

headline: City Withdraws Plans to Close Seven Schools
text: New York City's Department of Education withdrew its plans on Monday to close seven schools and reopen them this summer, but officials said they would proceed with plans to close 26 others. The proposed closings have been strongly opposed by the schools, various elected officials and the city's teachers' union.

headline: The Risks and Rewards of a More Intimate Space
text: The life of a singer perpetually involves vast, sudden shifts of scale. The ability to negotiate them — as well as to choose halls and repertory carefully and match them wisely — is as much a quality of a successful career as singing in key. Two budding stars of the Metropolitan Opera (3,800 seats) were put to this test when they sang on Sunday afternoon in Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum (250 seats).

headline: At Some Recitals, It’s All About the Encore
text: After his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon the young Iranian-American harpsichordist Mahan Esfahani said it was an honor to perform on the same stage where, in 1954, the acclaimed harpsichordist Wanda Landowska gave her final public recital.

headline: Singing Pageant of Pop, With a Circus Atmosphere
text: NEWARK — The spirit of Michael Jackson may not hover over “Michael Jackson The Immortal World Tour,” a spectacular that played the Prudential Center here last weekend and heads to Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, but the Jackson estate sure does. It collaborated with Cirque du Soleil, which conceived the Beatles “Love” show in Las Vegas, to create this galumphing sensory assault, presumably a substitute for the Jackson “This Is It” run of shows that never was.

headline: Excerpt: '4000 Miles'
text: Gabriel Ebert and Mary Louise Wilson in a scene from Amy Herzog’s play at Lincoln Center Theater.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Israel, Bahrain, Syria and Pakistan.

headline: Giving Women the Access Code
text: CLAREMONT, Calif. — When Maria Klawe became president of Harvey Mudd College in 2006, she was dismayed — but not surprised — at how few women were majoring in computer science.

headline: Solar Energy Inspiration From Butterflies
text: Butterfly wings are not just beautiful. They are also sophisticated collectors of solar energy that help butterflies stay warm, and researchers say that their shinglelike structure could provide valuable clues into developing better solar technology.

headline: ‘Pipeline’ to Programming Jobs Has Leaks
text: When educators speak of women in computer science, they often refer to the “pipeline,” which tends to start in high school and wind its way through graduate studies. Along the way, the pipeline becomes increasingly porous, losing women at a discouraging rate.

headline: Footnote
text: Neil Patrick Harris will return as host of the Tony Awards telecast on June 10, the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing announced. Mr. Harris hosted the awards ceremony last year and in 2009. It will again be at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan and will be broadcast by CBS.

headline: City Revokes Testing Word Ban
text:
Why should pressure groups who won battles a generation ago in other states and regions determine what appears on the tests of New York City?

New York City Department of Education officials said late Monday that they were pulling back on a clause in contracts for testing companies that list 50 words and topics that they should avoid in creating new tests.

headline: Australian Golfers Hope for End to Masters Drought
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — A year ago, Jason Day and Adam Scott each came close to becoming the first Australian winner of the Masters, a drought they say inevitably gains attention in their home country this time of year.

headline: Push for the Right to Die Grows in the Netherlands
text: AMSTERDAM — It was 1989, and Dr. Petra de Jong, a Dutch pulmonologist, was asked for help by a terminally ill patient, a man in great pain with a large cancerous tumor in his trachea. He wanted to end his life.

headline: Path Improves Security in Mobile App
text: Path, the mobile social network, announced on Monday that it had added a privacy feature to its mobile application. The update comes two months after it was discovered that some app makers, including Path, were copying people’s address book data without permission. In some instances the data was stored unencrypted on company servers.

headline: Why José Antonio Ocampo Wants to Run the World Bank
text: Last week, I spoke with two candidates for the presidency of the World Bank for an article on the contested election, the first in the history of the Washington-based development institution. (The White House has nominated Dr. Jim Yong Kim, a global health expert and the president of Dartmouth College.) Both candidates gave detailed answers on how they would lead the bank and why they are running for the presidency.

headline: How China Steals Our Secrets
text: Washington

headline: Panel Rejects Proposal to Allow Election-Related Trading
text: Wall Street, which buys and sells all types of exotic securities, has found a limit to its financial innovation. It can’t trade derivatives tied to the 2012 election.

headline: $178,000 Is a Lot for a Pig, but This Pig Is Paying for College
text: HOUSTON — Here in the largest city in Texas, $200,000 still goes a long way. It can buy you a four-bedroom 3,000-square-foot home, a used red 2010 Ferrari or a short tubby pig.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Merger of 2 of the Biggest Pharmacy Benefit Managers
text: Despite potential antitrust concerns and vocal opposition by some lawmakers and consumer groups, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, two of the nation’s largest pharmacy benefit managers, said Monday that federal regulators had approved their $29 billion merger.

headline: System, Not Judge, Is Blamed for Nepotism in Court Hiring
text: A state oversight commission has dismissed allegations that the top judge in Manhattan’s appellate court gave jobs to friends and family members, including a former city councilwoman; lied about where he lived; and improperly allowed his assistant to practice law.

headline: Agency Administrator Fires Deputies, Then Resigns, Amid Spending Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The administrator of the General Services Administration fired her two top deputies, then resigned Monday ahead of an investigation into a conference the agency held in Las Vegas that included commemorative coins, lavish meals, a mind reader and a $75,000 team-building exercise assembling bicycles.

headline: Obama Campaign’s New Ad Attacks Romney and the Oil Industry
text: 9:49 p.m. | Updated The Obama campaign released a new commercial on Monday that tries to link Mitt Romney to the oil industry, painting them both as hostile to the president’s efforts to raise automobile mileage standards and produce more renewable energy.

headline: The Straw That Stirred the Cosmos
text: Giorgio Chinaglia was a goal scorer, period. Watching him as he prowled the penalty area — lanky, hunch-shouldered, barrel-chested — fans saw no feints, no tricks, no shimmies or shakes. There was nothing fancy about his play. It was bullish and direct, like the man himself.

headline: Quakers Say Contractors Desecrated a Historic Queens Graveyard
text: The wood-shingled meetinghouse, preserved under a bower of trees on a commercial strip in Flushing, Queens, was once the most influential seat of American Quakerism, a place of worship for those who wrote one of the country’s first declarations of religious freedom in the 1600s.

headline: Iran: Hyundai Motor Ends Operations
text: The Hyundai Motor Company, the automaking subsidiary of Hyundai, the South Korean conglomerate, has quietly ended its business dealings with Iran, where it had extensive operations, including a joint venture to make cars. United Against Nuclear Iran, an American group that has advocated economic sanctions to pressure Iran over its disputed nuclear program, has reclassified Hyundai Motor, putting it in the “withdrawn” category on a list the group has compiled of foreign businesses that deal with Iran. Hyundai Motor officials did not respond to requests for comment. A strict new American law is putting pressure on foreign companies to reduce or eliminate their operations in Iran or risk penalties in the United States market. Hyundai is the second big foreign automaker in a week to pull back from Iran. Last week, General Motors said its French partner, PSA Peugeot Citroën, had suspended shipments of components to the Iran Khodro Industrial Group, an Iranian vehicle maker, to comply with American restraints on Iran trade.

headline: A Little Device That’s Trying to Read Your Thoughts
text: SAN DIEGO — Already surrounded by machines that allow him, painstakingly, to communicate, the physicist Stephen Hawking last summer donned what looked like a rakish black headband that held a feather-light  device the size of a small matchbox.

headline: Suggestions by Union in Bounty Case Are Unlikely
text: Representatives of the N.F.L. and the players union met Monday for the first time to discuss the New Orleans Saints’ bounty system and the 22 to 27 players the league said its investigation showed were involved.

headline: Small Banks Shift Charters to Avoid U.S. as Regulator
text: A small community bank in New Hampshire found a demand from its regulator last month just too much.

headline: France: Deportations of ‘Radicals’ Begin
text: French authorities on Monday deported two foreign citizens they identified as “Islamist radicals” and said three others would soon be expelled, in keeping with a pledge by President Nicolas Sarkozy to quash Muslim extremism after a series of killings in the Toulouse region by a man who claimed to be a member of Al Qaeda. An Algerian man previously convicted for terrorist ties was deported, the Interior Ministry said, along with a Malian imam accused of preaching anti-Semitism. Imams from Saudi Arabia and Turkey and Tunisia were also expected to be expelled. Last week, the authorities arrested 19 people suspected of ties to Muslim groups calling for violence; 16 remain in custody.

headline: Mind Games: Sometimes a White Coat Isn’t Just a White Coat
text: If you wear a white coat that you believe belongs to a doctor, your ability to pay attention increases sharply. But if you wear the same white coat believing it belongs to a painter, you will show no such improvement.

headline: China: Nobel Winners Urge Tibet Talks
text: Twelve Nobel Peace laureates have written an open letter to President Hu Jintao of China, urging him to engage in “meaningful dialogue” with the Dalai Lama to ease Tibetans’ frustrations over Chinese policies. At least 32 people in Tibet have set themselves on fire since March 2011 to protest Chinese policies. The laureates, including Desmond M. Tutu, Jody Williams and Lech Walesa, expressed concern over “the drastic expressions of resentment by the people of Tibet.” The letter, to be sent Tuesday, calls for Mr. Hu to open up Tibet to journalists and diplomats, stop the arbitrary detention of Tibetans and respect religious freedom.

headline: President Confident Health Law Will Stand
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared Monday that he was confident the Supreme Court would uphold his health care law, saying it would be an “unprecedented, extraordinary” step to overturn legislation passed by the “strong majority of a democratically elected Congress.”

headline: Alive, Dead or Otherwise (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pay for Women’s Basketball Coaches Lags Far Behind That of Men’s Coaches
text: Women’s college sports have changed enormously since the adoption of Title IX in 1972. More teams are being fielded and more athletes are participating, and overall visibility and popularity have increased exponentially.

headline: Only Connect (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why People Hate the Banks
text: A few months ago, I was standing in a crowded elevator when Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, stepped in. When he saw me, he said in a voice loud enough for everyone to hear: “Why does The New York Times hate the banks?”

headline: U.S. Davis Cup Team Adds Harrison to Replace Fish
text: A teenager until next month, Ryan Harrison is unexpectedly a key member of the United States Davis Cup team that will face France in a quarterfinal beginning Friday at Monte Carlo Country Club.

headline: Another Hole in the Safety Net
text: Georgia is vying with Florida for the title of stingiest state, when it comes to jobless residents. The Republican-controlled State Legislature passed a bill last week to cut the duration of unemployment benefits from a current maximum of 26 weeks to a range from 14 weeks to 20 weeks, depending on the state unemployment rate. Florida cut its 26-week maximum last year, to a range of 12 weeks to 23 weeks.

headline: Senior Season Awaits, but at Potential Cost
text: DENVER

headline: Live Updates: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Final
text: Kentucky is playing Kansas for the men’s basketball national championship. Zach Hillesland, a former player at Notre Dame and frequent contributor to The Quad, will provide live updates and analysis with the help of Stephen Danley, another frequent contributor who played basketball at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Desperately Seeking Synonyms
text: This is the second in a series of writing lessons by the author.

headline: As Riots Boil Over, These Guards Don’t Budge
text: ATHENS — It is not easy being a member of Greece’s Presidential Guard, the soldiers who, resplendent in old-world uniforms, must stand stock-still at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier here. Frozen feet, sweaty brows and the curiosity of the very young, who poke and kick the guards to see if they are really alive, are just some of the hazards.

headline: Where Housing Once Boomed, Recovery Lags
text: CLINTON, Md. — Half a decade has passed since crowds of lunchtime workers regularly packed the Fish Market restaurant, a popular fixture of this southern Maryland crossroads known by the lighthouse on its roof.

headline: JOBS Act Jeopardizes Safety Net for Investors
text: Maybe President Obama should have bought shares in Groupon’s I.P.O.

headline: Weighing When Slim Hopes Become G.O.P. Problem
text: OSHKOSH, Wis. — With big-name Republicans and even many Democrats coming to agree that Mitt Romney is destined to be the Republican nominee, there is just one hitch: Someone forgot to tell Rick Santorum.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 2, 2012

headline: A Judge Turns on the Light
text: A federal judge took an important step toward ending secret donations to big-spending political groups, striking down regulations that permitted some groups to hide their donors. Unfortunately, the ruling probably came too late to flush this corrupting practice from this year’s elections — though there is still time for Congress to do so.

headline: Treasure of Golf’s Sad Past, Black Caddies Vanish in Era of Riches
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For decades, the black caddies at Augusta National Golf Club — required by the club’s rules and treasured for their nuanced knowledge of the course’s topography — stood as a striking symbol of the sport’s segregated state.

headline: Divide and Discriminate
text: When a light is shined into the dark corners of American politics, it’s never pleasant to see what scurries away. Last week, a federal judge in Maine unsealed memos from the National Organization for Marriage, one of the most prominent groups fighting against same-sex marriage.

headline: Regulator Orders Hospitals to Undo a Merger in Ohio
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission has blocked an Ohio hospital merger in a closely watched case that could slow the consolidation of health care providers around the country.

headline: At Advocates’ Offices, Confronting an Anti-Liberal Scheme
text: Young, bearded, a bit scruffy, a young man walked into a community organizing office in East Harlem, lugging a heavy bag. A little nervous, he said that his name was Melvin Howting, and that he worked for an environmental company in New Jersey and had a few questions about how to organize a union.

headline: A Network Popular With Hispanics Reaches Out to Them
text: IT’S been redone nearly 400 times over the last 17 years, but one thing has stayed the same about ESPN’s “This is SportsCenter” advertisement: It’s always been in English.

headline: Stop and Frisk, Continued
text: The Bloomberg administration and its police commissioner, Raymond Kelly, have been disturbingly dismissive of complaints about the city’s program of stops, frisks and arrests that is ensnaring hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers each year.

headline: State Public Workers Rushed to Join Pensions Before Cutbacks
text: ALBANY — Thousands of public employees across New York State rushed to sign up for pensions over the last several weeks, seeking to lock in generous retirement benefits before cuts approved by the State Legislature took effect on Sunday.

headline: Manhattan State Senator Says He’ll Challenge Rangel
text: Adriano Espaillat, a Democratic state senator who represents Washington Heights, announced on Monday that he would run against Representative Charles B. Rangel, ending months of speculation over his potential candidacy and setting the stage for a campaign that could test the strength of Latino influence in the district.

headline: Ahead of Passover, Strict Standards Transform a Brooklyn Neighborhood
text: On any ordinary day, yellow school buses with the Hebrew names of yeshivas dominate the ultra-Orthodox landscape of Borough Park, Brooklyn. But in the days before Passover, large trucks parked along many of the sidewalks are far more striking, particularly those bearing signs with a Hebrew word obscure even to most Jews: Sheimos.

headline: Swiss Seek Arrest of 3 German Tax Officials Over Stolen Banking Data
text: BERLIN — A long-simmering dispute between Germany and Switzerland over a CD containing stolen data about possible tax evaders has escalated after Swiss authorities issued arrest warrants for three German tax inspectors who paid $3.3 million for the information.

headline: ‘End of the Rainbow’
text: Scenes from the new Broadway show starring Tracie Bennett as Judy Garland.

headline: Small Border City Wins an Israeli Title
text: Hapoel Ironi Kiryat Shmona secured its first Israeli league title Monday after battling out a 0-0 draw against its second-place rival, Hapoel Tel Aviv.

headline: The Beauty and the Bluster of Chinaglia
text: Lawrie Mifflin, who covered the Cosmos and soccer from 1977 to 1984 for the Daily News and The Times, wrote an appraisal of Giorgio Chinaglia’s career for Tuesday’s editions, but you can read it here now. The former Times sports columnist George Vecsey, who now blogs at georgevecsey.com, offered his take there.

headline: A Star Who Was Born, Sparkled and Fell
text: As befits a play about Judy Garland, a woman known for liberally mixing her pills, Peter Quilter’s “End of the Rainbow” is a jolting upper and downer at the same time. After watching Tracie Bennett’s electrifying interpretation of Garland in the intense production that opened on Monday night at the Belasco Theater, you feel exhilarated and exhausted, equally ready to dance down the street and crawl under a rock.

headline: Generations Collide, Gently, in a Grandmother’s Village Apartment
text: Plays as truthful and touching and fine as Amy Herzog’s “4000 Miles” come along once or maybe twice a season, if we’re lucky. So let us be grateful that Lincoln Center Theater, which first presented this gently comic drama at the tail end of last season under the auspices of its LCT3 program, has moved the same production uptown to the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, where it opened on Monday with all its virtues intact.

headline: Moving Parts of an Engine
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — A nice, fresh grid from Paula Gamache, and just a hair tougher than I would expect on a Tuesday. Not that there’s anything wrong with that.

headline: Redrawn Districts Present a Hurdle for Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — As Democrats try to orchestrate a state-by-state drive to retake control of the House of Representatives, an unexpected hurdle has arisen in New York, an overwhelmingly Democratic state that should have been friendly terrain.

headline: The Muslim Swing Vote
text: As the 2012 presidential election picks up steam, Republican candidates find it tempting and beneficial to bash Muslims as a way to attract voters. In the wake of the 2010 midterm elections, “Americans are learning what Europeans have known for years: Islam-bashing wins votes,” the journalist Michael Scott Moore wrote that November. At the time, many of the 85 new Republican House members buoyed by the surging Tea Party movement found the political virtues of anti-Muslim rhetoric an easy way to prove their mettle to the surging conservative base.

headline: Mayoral Elections Give Russian Opposition a Boost
text: YAROSLAVL, Russia — Just weeks before Vladimir V. Putin again assumes the presidency in Russia, scattered political insurgencies against local governments have begun to expose cracks in his near monopoly on power.

headline: And Now, the Veepstakes
text: I have two words for you: Dick Cheney.

headline: Although Still Ailing, Davis Thinks He Is Able
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Baron Davis has the résumé of a former All-Star and the bravado to go with it. But sometimes he still has to convince himself, like Stuart Smalley speaking mantras into the mirror.

headline: Respect the Future
text: Last fall I asked readers over 70 to send me “Life Reports” — essays evaluating their own lives. Charles Darwin Snelling responded with a remarkable 5,000-word reflection.

headline: Sampling the Easter Markets of Prague
text: Frisky young lovers, barbecued pork and rows upon rows of colorful hand-painted eggs are all part of Prague’s pastel-hued Easter markets. The old tradition of men playfully swatting their paramours with artfully decorated willow sticks in exchange for plum brandy and painted eggs is a beloved part of the seasonal fun. These Easter “whips” (or “pomlazka”), along with numerous other unique souvenirs, can be bought from little wooden booths that will line many of the city’s public squares through April 15.

headline: One Star Torn Between Two Tours
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — In front of a hotel mirror with his father by his side, 17-year-old Ryo Ishikawa rehearsed the lines that would open his first news conference on the PGA Tour: “Hello, America. I am Ryo Ishikawa from Japan.”

headline: Half of Irish Homeowners Join Boycott of New Property Tax
text: DUBLIN — Anti-austerity protesters are claiming victory after the government acknowledged that around 50 percent of Ireland’s estimated 1.6 million homeowners failed to pay a new, flat-rate $133 property tax by the March 31 deadline.

headline: Are the Olympics More Trouble Than They’re Worth?
text: London and Rio de Janeiro saw the Games as an opportunity. But will the cities change for the better, and at what cost?

headline: Law Could Hamper Drug Tourism in the Netherlands
text: AMSTERDAM — The scene at the 420 Cafe on a recent Friday was typical of what many travelers have come to associate with Amsterdam. Behind the bar, Janne Svensson, 34, a self-described “cannabis refugee” from Norway, weighed out small quantities of marijuana and hashish for her customers, many from foreign countries. They sat quietly, smoking and sipping coffee, as familiar strains of Jimi Hendrix drifted softly from the stereo and giant manta rays cavorted in a nature video on a big-screen television.

headline: White House and the F.D.A. Often at Odds
text: Nancy-Ann DeParle, the whip-smart and sometimes caustic White House deputy chief of staff, picked up The Wall Street Journal one summer day in 2010 and got an unwelcome shock. The Food and Drug Administration was proposing as part of the new health care law to require that movie theaters post calorie counts for popcorn — and this was the first she had heard of it.

headline: Professors’ Salaries Are Graded on the Global Curve
text: How much is a professor worth?

headline: Areas of Disagreement
text: Senior officials in the Obama administration and the Food and Drug Administration have quietly disagreed over a range of issues.

headline: Colombian Rebels Free 10, Raising Hopes of Peace Talks With Government
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Colombia’s main rebel group on Monday released four soldiers and six police officers it had held hostage for as long as 14 years. The 10 men were thought to be the last remaining noncivilian captives held by the group, which has used kidnapping and drug trafficking to help finance its nearly five-decade war against the Colombian government.

headline: Yankees and Mets Resuming Rivalry Down South
text: MIAMI — The Yankees will take a sparse lineup to Port St. Lucie on Tuesday for the first of two spring training games against the Mets in 16 years. Stars like Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Mariano Rivera will not make the trip.

headline: In Libya, Militias Become a Political Force
text: The militias that have turned Libya into a patchwork of semiautonomous fiefdoms are now plunging into politics, raising fears that they could undermine elections.

headline: Libyan Militias Turn to Politics, a Volatile Mix
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The militia leaders who have turned post-Qaddafi Libya into a patchwork of semiautonomous fiefs are now plunging into politics, raising fears that their armed brigades could undermine elections intended to lay the foundation of a new democracy.

headline: Noncitizens Sue Over U.S. Gay Marriage Ban
text: Five legally married same-sex couples filed a lawsuit on Monday to challenge the 1996 law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages, arguing that its impact is particularly harsh on couples that include an American citizen and a foreigner.

headline: Romney Faults Obama on Energy Costs, but Has Cited Benefits of Rising Prices
text: WASHINGTON — For several weeks, Mitt Romney has seized on the rising cost of gasoline to attack President Obama and his environmental aides for what Mr. Romney calls their misguided desire to see higher energy prices.

headline: Immigration Officials Arrest More Than 3,100
text: In a six-day nationwide sweep, federal immigration agents arrested 3,168 immigrants who had been convicted of crimes or had repeatedly violated immigration laws, officials said Monday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 2
text: Jewelery industry workers protest new taxes in Mumbai.

headline: Ex-Treasurer of Massachusetts Accused of Misusing Lottery Ads
text: BOSTON — A former treasurer of Massachusetts, Timothy P. Cahill, was indicted Monday, accused of misusing advertising for the State Lottery to benefit his campaign for governor in 2010.

headline: Coronation for Kentucky, and for Its Coach
text: NEW ORLEANS — Kentucky Coach John Calipari finally found the right team and the right setting to outrace his tortured N.C.A.A. tournament history. For all the drama, all the investigations and all the late-season heartbreak Calipari has endured, the game that delivered him his first national title came against a program nearly as iconic as his own and in almost anticlimactic fashion.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,906 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Girardi Eludes Ejection in Yankees’ Win
text: MIAMI – Manager Joe Girardi was able to stick around for all of the Yankees’ 5-2 victory over the Miami Marlins on Monday night, despite a heated argument with the home plate umpire Laz Diaz in the first inning.

headline: Longevity Up in U.S., but Education Creates Disparity, Study Says
text: Americans are living longer, but the gains in life span are accruing disproportionately among the better educated, according to a new report by researchers from the University of Wisconsin.

headline: Bidding Wars Amid Flat Property Prices in Manhattan
text: Prices for Manhattan real estate were relatively flat in the first three months of the year, but brokers anticipate a much stronger spring sales season, saying that many properties had recently prompted bidding wars, indicating a new level of buyer confidence.

headline: Wildcats’ Davis Dominates the Title Game With His Swats, Not His Shots
text: NEW ORLEANS — Early in the second half, Kansas threw the ball inside, to the part of the court the Jayhawks avoided most on Monday night. Thomas Robinson, star forward, all-American, likely N.B.A. draft lottery pick, received the pass. Anthony Davis of Kentucky stood waiting for him.

headline: Giorgio Chinaglia, Italian Star and the Cosmos’ Leader, Dies at 65
text: Giorgio Chinaglia, who came to the New York Cosmos professional soccer team as one of Europe’s greatest and most charismatic goal scorers, then attracted almost as much attention for his impenitent candor — he even criticized his revered teammate Pelé — died on Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 65.

headline: 10-Year-Old Boy Shot by Stray Bullet in Brooklyn
text: A 10-year-old boy was shot by a stray bullet fired during a shootout in Brooklyn on Monday night, the police said.

headline: John Arden, British Playwright, Dies at 81
text: John Arden, a major British playwright of the 1950s and 1960s, whose politically engaged, theatrically inventive and conscience-provoking works were often compared to Brecht’s but have been only intermittently revived and rarely performed in the United States, died on Wednesday. He was 81.

headline: Cricket’s Juggernaut Returns to Action

text: In theory, Barcelona will be up against it when it faces A.C. Milan on Tuesday in the second leg of its Champions League quarterfinal, having played a scoreless tie at the San Siro last week. But Champions League games are not played in theory.

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Championship Final
text: Kentucky defeated Kansas, 67-59, to win the N.C.A.A. championship.

headline: News Quiz | April 3, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Billionaire Brothers and Bad Blood
text: HONG KONG — The Independent Commission Against Corruption, originally formed to bust crooked cops and greedy bureaucrats, has arrested two of the world’s wealthiest men in an alleged bribery case.

headline: April 3, 1948 | Truman Signs Marshall Plan, Providing Aid to Europe
text: On April 3, 1948, President Truman signed the Marshall Plan, which allocated more than $5 billion in aid to 16 European countries. In signing the plan, officially called the Economic Recovery Program, Truman declared, “This measure is America’s answer to the challenge facing the free world.”

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 3, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the dance review “Accentuating the Improvisational.”

headline: What’s the Easiest Way to Cheat on Your Taxes?
text: If economists ran the tax system, there would be virtually no exemptions or loopholes. But economists don’t run the tax system! Instead, businesses, rich people, Congressmen and attorneys spend a shockingly large amount of time lobbying for tax breaks or exploiting the ones that exist. When the modern income tax was created in 1913, the code was 27 pages long. Last year, it was 5,296 pages. What in the world does it say? After surveying 20 accountants, tax lawyers and policy wonks, we’ve boiled down their arcane knowledge to this short list of things you might want to know.

headline: Simple Portraits, Complex Camera
text: On Friday, Lens featured a series of portraits from Mary Ellen Mark’s new book, “Prom,” with a clip from the accompanying film by Martin Bell. The portraits also appeared in the Sunday Review over the weekend.

headline: Do You Want to Write a Book?
text: In the past few years, it’s gotten easier to put out a book – not with an established publishing house, but to do what’s known as self-publishing. And students have gotten in on it, putting out self-published books, often with their parents’ help. Do you want to write a book?

headline: Syrian Leader Accused of Escalating Attacks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s political opposition accused President Bashar al-Assad of escalating military assaults on four major urban centers on Tuesday. Such assaults would directly contradict the Syrian government’s promise, announced on Monday, that it would immediately begin pulling armed forces back from population centers, in accordance with a special envoy’s cease-fire plan.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | April Checklist for Juniors
text: In March, The Choice introduced Counselor’s Calendar, an occasional series intended to keep students on track throughout the college admissions process.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Reflections of a Big Draft Weekend
text: Sixteen of my 17 drafts are in the books — just my home league remains, all the way on April 9. Saturday was the National Fantasy Baseball Championship Main Event live in Las Vegas, and as always, I gained solid insight into the drafting trends heading into the season. Here are a few.

headline: N.F.C. South Team Needs

headline: A Mammal’s Evolution, Documented in Chrome
text: The impala, a gentle, fleet-hoofed grazing animal from eastern Africa, has historically been associated with Chevrolet’s large, upper-level models. In the pantheon of instantly recognizable mammalian automotive badges, it sits with Ford’s Mustang and Jaguar’s leapers and growlers.

headline: Beware of Budget Gimmickry
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Solazyme and Bunge Plan Factory to Make Oil From Algae
text: The promise of using algae to make biofuels — a dream scientists have chased for decades — might seem particularly welcome in a time of stubbornly high gasoline prices. But the path to commercial-scale production has been circuitous.

headline: U.S. Offers $10 Million Reward for Pakistani Militant Tied to Mumbai Attacks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The United States has announced a $10 million reward for information leading to the capture of Hafiz Saeed, a Pakistani militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 Mumbai attacks, who in recent months has emerged at the vanguard of a prominent anti-American lobbying group.

headline: As Myanmar Changes, So Does Its Leader
text: KYONKU, Myanmar — He is sometimes called the Mikhail Gorbachev of Myanmar, a once-loyal apparatchik of one of the world’s most brutal military dictatorships who is chipping away at some of its worst legacies — freeing political prisoners, partially unshackling the press and allowing the long-persecuted opposition to run for election last Sunday.

headline: 5 Visions of How to Solve the Euro Crisis
text: LONDON — How much will it cost to find a solution to the crisis in the euro zone? If a British businessman has his way, £250,000, or about $400,000, might do the trick.

headline: S.L.R. Video Cameras for the Pros
text: For the last few months, I’ve been crisscrossing the country filming two projects for PBS’s long-running science series Nova. One of those projects is a two-hour special called “Hunting the Elements” (as in the periodic table, not extreme weather). It will be broadcast at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday on PBS. (Local broadcast times vary.)

headline: A Top London Banker at JPMorgan Chase Resigns
text: LONDON — One of the top bankers at JPMorgan Chase in London resigned on Tuesday.

headline: James Cameron Is Ready for the Apocalypse
text: You recently made news for taking an incredibly tiny submarine seven miles deep into the Pacific Ocean. Was there a moment inside that thing when you thought, This totally sucks?  Oh, yeah. There are moments when you say, “Wow, I really wish I could stretch my legs out. If only I had made this three inches bigger.” But I worked hard for years and spent a lot of money to put myself in that situation, so I can’t exactly complain.

headline: Tech Audit: Two Owners, Two Companies, Lots of I.T. Headaches
text: Scott Lowe had been living in Tokyo with his wife, Rio Miura, for a few years when in 1996 they started selling coffee and tea by catalog. “We really wanted to open a coffee shop and then expand, like Starbucks, but we didn’t have the money for it,” he said. But the catalog started pulling in sales, and then in 1998 they moved back to the United States and started selling here as well, settling in San Francisco.

headline: Europe’s Economy Is Eating Its Young, and It’s About to Get Worse
text: LONDON — Almost 40,000 Spaniards joined the ranks of the unemployed last month, according to figures released Tuesday, in a country where more young people are now out of work than have jobs.

headline: Foundations Made for the High-Definition Era
text: BEFORE a photo shoot with Katy Perry for the March issue of Interview magazine, Gucci Westman, Revlon’s global artistic director, who was prepping the 27-year-old Ms. Perry, was surprised at one request. “The first thing she told me was, ‘I like my foundation,’ ” Ms. Westman recalled.

headline: On Facebook, Some Friendly Energy Rivalry
text: So, would you stop washing your clothes in warm water if your best friend tried doing it in cold and said her jeans were coming out clean? Would you be more likely to weatherize your house if your college roommate said that it had cut her heating bill by 30 percent? And if your mom got one of those power strips that turn off devices that suck electricity in the middle of the night, would you do the same?

headline: Roche Answers Illumina’s Jibe at Revised Offer

headline: How That Sausage of Happiness Is Made
text: The quest for happiness has been the direct or indirect subject of a huge chunk of intellectual endeavor: philosophy, theology, psychology, economics and, of course, literature, which has tended to cast a jaundiced eye on the matter. “To be stupid and selfish and to have good health are the three requirements for happiness,” Flaubert wrote, “though if stupidity is lacking, the others are useless.”

headline: Europe Opens Patent Investigations Into Motorola Mobility
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s competition office on Tuesday opened two antitrust cases against Motorola Mobility for possibly abusing its patents following complaints by two rivals, Microsoft and Apple.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Buys Out RBC Dexia
text: LONDON — Royal Bank of Canada agreed on Tuesday to buy the 50 percent stake in RBC Dexia Investor Services it did not already own for 837.5 million euros, or $1.1 billion.

headline: Screw Your Analysis to the Sticky Point
text: Via Mark Thoma, a new paper from the San Francisco Fed offers stunning evidence on downward nominal wage rigidity, a topic I’ve written about before.

headline: A Turnaround on Turnaround for Seven Schools
text: Like a roller coaster on its final descent, the city's "turnaround" push for 33  "struggling schools" seemed to be picking up speed and heading toward an inevitable conclusion. But in an unexpected twist, the Education Department decided to give seven schools a reprieve, acknowledging that they were on the ascent and should be given more time to continue to improve.

headline: Troubled History Emerges for Suspect in Fatal Oakland Attack
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the tightly knit Korean-American community here, bound by membership at churches and a striving for academic excellence, One L. Goh had long found himself on the periphery. After leaving an apartment in Virginia without paying his rent two years ago, he returned to the Bay Area, where he had lived earlier and where his ailing father still resided.

headline: Dress for Success
text: What’s the secret to a great dress? Sunhee Hwang, a South Korean-born designer whose second collection won her an Ecco Domani prize this year, has this tip: “Before thoughts of fine fabrics, look for beautiful colors,” she says. “That’s what gets us into the dressing rooms in the hopes of finding winsome silhouettes and flattering lines.” Hwang certainly has a way with a frock herself: at the 1995 Fashion Institute of Technology graduation show, her tangerine gown attracted the attention of the Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz, then at Geoffrey Beene. “He said to me, ‘Your dresses are very beautiful. Why don’t you work for me?’ ” recalls Hwang, now 38. After stints at Beene, Anna Sui, Elie Tahari and Anne Klein, Hwang is back in the limelight with knockout Sunhee dresses, like an airy silk confection in maize yellow (above right; $825 at sunheeny.com) and a flirty salsa number in rich cobalt ($395 at sunheeny.com). “When you look at beautiful clothes, it doesn’t matter who the designer is,” she says, citing Narciso Rodriguez’s color-blocked sheaths and Jonathan Saunders’s vibrant shifts as examples of smart fits in smashing colors. “As long as you look gorgeous and feel special, you will buy it. I’m just hoping it’s my dress.”

headline: Daily Report: A Device to Read Your Thoughts
text: The physicist Stephen Hawking is trying out a device the size of a matchbox that is designed to allow him to communicate by merely thinking, David Ewing Duncan reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: James Murdoch Steps Down From British Broadcaster
text: LONDON — BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster partly owned by the News Corporation, said on Tuesday that James Murdoch had resigned as chairman to shield the company from the phone hacking scandal engulfing his family’s British newspaper group.

headline: U.S. Car Sales Keep Up Their Firm Growth
text: DETROIT —  Automakers on Tuesday reported strong sales across the board in March, pushing the industry to its best quarter since before the recession, even though gasoline prices climbed to more than $4 a gallon in many states.

text: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, claims to have won his latest corporate rumble.

headline: Tuesday Reading: High Court Allows Strip Searches for Any Offense
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: U.S. Offers $10 Million Reward for Pakistani Militant
text: The United States has announced a $10 million reward for information leading to the capture of Hafiz Saeed, a Pakistani militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 Mumbai attacks, and who in recent months has emerged at the vanguard of a prominent anti-American political movement, Declan Walsh writes in The New York Times.

headline: Scouting the Draft: Marshall’s Vinny Curry
text: Jonathan Bales is the founder of TheDCTimes.com and will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

headline: What’s Next in Myanmar?
text: It seemed unthinkable only a few months ago. On Sunday, people danced in the streets of Yangon, celebrating that Nobel Peace laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi had won a seat in Myanmar’s Parliament. Her party, the National League for Democracy, has picked up  almost every seat contested in the elections. As she spoke of the “beginning of a new era,” observers around the world were wondering what comes next for Myanmar.

headline: A Mecca in London
text: LONDON — As a frequent visitor to the British Museum, I can attest that its vast Great Court has never been as full of Muslims — declaring themselves through headscarves, skull caps and prayer beads — as it is these days. They are swarming the museum to visit “Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam,’’ the first-ever exhibit about the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. More than 80,000 people visited the exhibit in its first seven weeks. Moreover, it has fueled a much-needed dialogue about Islam in Britain, and demonstrated that cultural venues are well suited to host the difficult debate about multiculturalism.

headline: In Paris, Degas and the Nude
text: Edgar Degas’s reputation largely rests on his paintings of horse racing and dancers, portraits and genre scenes. Far less celebrated but equally compelling are his nudes, a subject he returned to throughout his career. In collaboration with Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts, the Musée d’Orsay (1, rue de la Légion d’Honneur) sets out to rectify this oversight with the remarkable exhibition “Degas and the Nude,” which will be held through July 1, and includes important loans from the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, among others.

headline: A Critics’ Conversation: Modern Dance Madness
text: ALASTAIR MACAULAY These last few years, hard-pressed critics have spoken of “Modern-Dance March Madness.” This year was no exception. March 2012 proved to be one of the busiest and richest times for dance lovers in New York. The Paul Taylor Dance Company’s three-week season, featuring 22 works at the Koch Theater, ended on Sunday. Meanwhile, we have also seen a multitude of performances from other classic companies, like the Martha Graham Dance Company, and contemporary artists like Sarah Michelson and Ishmael Houston-Jones, who organized the Parallels series at Danspace, which also ended this weekend.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
text: The long history of newspapers in the City of Brotherly Love took another turn Monday with the sale of parent company of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News to a group of politically connected investors. The price was $55 million, less than half of what the papers sold for just two years earlier. One investor who did not follow through with the deal, writes Amy Chozick, was Ed Rendell, the former Philadelphia mayor and Pennsylvania governor whose participation drew a lot of criticism from inside and outside the papers. “There was enough blowback from reporters and editorial people, because I’m active politically and support candidates and the president, that I decided to step back,” he said, adding the current owners “might ask me my opinion every once in a while.”

For the first time the director Jason Reitman will bring his popular “Live Read” series, in which famous movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors, to New York with a reading of “The Apartment” to be presented on April 27 at the TimesCenter in Manhattan, it was announced on Tuesday.

I’ll ignore the readers who think I’m not entitled to an opinion on this because I am not black, Jewish or gay, and try to address a few of the substantive comments.

headline: A New Pop Music Festival in Delaware
text: The Killers, the Black Keys and Jack White will headline a new music festival in Dover, Del., this summer. The three-day event, the Firefly Music Festival, is scheduled for July 20 to 22 at the Woodlands of Dover International Speedway. Organizers say more than 40 bands and solo artists will play, ranging from the R&B singer John Legend to the indie band Death Cab for Cutie. The rappers Tinie Tempah and Lupe Fiasco are also expected to perform.

headline: Life, Interrupted: A Video Portrait of Cancer in Young Adulthood
text: “Cancer doesn’t just put your life on hold,” says Suleika Jaouad, Well columnist, in a new video that documents her experiences as a 23-year-old woman with cancer. “It’s not like you get to skip back a few months and pick up exactly where you left off. I wasn’t going to get my old life back.”

headline: Computer Glitch Dashed High School Hopes for Five Queens Girls

It turns out Deanna was one of five girls from a small Catholic school in Queens who were locked out of public high school admissions. The problem: a computer glitch that their teacher failed to resolve.

headline: The True Cost of Breast-feeding — This Milk Isn’t Free
text: One of the most powerful myths surrounding breast milk is that it’s not only the “best” food for baby, but that it’s free. Nursing mothers have long known that “free” in this context requires that we place zero value on our own sleep, time and even dignity. (Remember the study showing that breast-feeding women are viewed as less competent?)

headline: The Fighting Second
text: The creation of army corps during the early winter of 1862 represents one of the greatest, if lesser known, organizational accomplishments of the Union Army. The sheer numbers were staggering. By the end of March, the Army of the Potomac, the premier Union military force in the Eastern Theater, alone had swelled to 120,000 men. By comparison, the American army that had captured Mexico City during the Mexican War — the nation’s last major conflict — had numbered only about 14,000 soldiers.

headline: Bookshelf | Will Oldham Speaks
text: Will Oldham does not care for interviews. They’re often confounding and pointless, he finds, and the media does not seem to think he is good at giving them. What’s more, he does not want to get better. “It just feels so wrong most of the time,” the singer-songwriter and actor tells his friend Alan Licht, in a new book-length interview. “It’s just a waste of time, because it doesn’t have anything to do with anything, and it demands a lot of time and a lot of thought, and the thought has nothing to do with anything.” The book, “Will Oldham on Bonnie ‘Prince’ Billy,” which will be published in Britain by Faber & Faber on Thursday and in the United States by Norton this fall, is one very long interview — an interview to end all interviews, the hope seems to be. And it just might work, for within the book’s 382 pages Oldham answers nearly every question one might wish to ask about his prolific output, which he has recorded and performed variously as Will Oldham, Palace Brothers, Palace Music, Palace Songs, Palace, Bonnie (Prince) Billy, Bonnie Billy, and Bonnie (Prince) Billy and the Cairo Gang. Longtime fans will appreciate the book’s generous portion of inside baseball. He wrote the song “I Am a Cinematographer,” for instance, after reading Robert Bresson’s “Notes on the Cinematographer,” and initially agreed to play piano on Johnny Cash’s cover of his song “I See a Darkness” despite not knowing how to play piano. (He later fessed up and instead conducted Cash and sang back-up vocals, in a recording session he recalls as surreal: “I remember it was as if I was a Colorform or paper doll that had just been pasted into that situation.”) Readers may also be amused to learn that he once passed up a possible part on “Doogie Howser, M.D.”; took classes in the waltz, the cha-cha-cha and scuba diving; and admires the comic timing of Foghorn Leghorn and Bugs Bunny, whom he cites as an influence. Though Oldham declined to be interviewed about the interview, The Moment was delighted to mine an advance copy for some of its choicest quotations.

headline: How Bolivia Lost Its Hat
text: In 1867, the British ambassador to Bolivia fell afoul of its dictator, Mariano Melgarejo, by refusing a glass of chicha, a cloudy drink based on fermented maize. Opting for cocoa instead, the ambassador got more than he asked for: Melgarejo, incensed, forced him to drink an entire bowl of liquid chocolate. He then paraded him three times around La Paz’s main square, tied up and seated back to front on a donkey [1], before shipping him back to London.

headline: Kensington Palace Reopens After Extensive Renovations
text: A palace that was built to keep the commoners out is now an estate open to all. Last week, Kensington Palace reopened after a £12 million  renovation that created the space for several new exhibits and revamped nearly every part of the building and grounds — from gardens first created in the 1730s to the interior State Rooms, where royal family members such as Queen Victoria and Princess Margaret once lived. Prince William and Princess Kate plan to continue the royal tradition and make this their home once they leave Wales.  (Their quarters won’t be open to the public, however.)The new exhibits include an in-depth look at two former residents: Queen Victoria in an exhibit called Victoria Revealed and Princess Diana in a timeline of her evolution as a fashion icon. A small collection of her dresses are on display, some of which have never been exhibited before in the United Kingdom.

This summer, however, Ms. Adams will have a shot at a star turn on stage when she makes her New York debut playing the baker’s wife in the musical “Into the Woods,” which will run July 23 to Aug. 25 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, the show’s producers at the Public Theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Link Between Income Inequality and Teen Pregnancy
text: At the Economix blog, they’re talking about a study showing a strong correlation between teenage births and income inequality: teenagers in the states with the highest income inequality (with little hope of upward mobility) are roughly 5 percentage points more likely to give birth as teenagers than those in states with the lowest inequality. Are policies promoting economic opportunity as important as sex ed?

headline: The Micro-Multinational: Our Experience With Bribery in Foreign Markets
text: As I mentioned in my last post, I am going to be writing a series of posts about our expansion into foreign markets. Ever since we began this expansion, I have been asked how often we are solicited for bribes in foreign countries. The funny thing is that while bribery is perceived to be relatively commonplace in international business, it may be more common in this country than people like to think. At least that’s what a former TerraCycle employee who used to work for a major American consumer products company told me.

headline: Research Cut Short in Indian Tiger Preserves
text: Anindya Sinha knows the Bandipur Tiger Reserve’s 900 bonnet macaques by face. Since 2000 he has worked among the monkey troops in the reserve, trying to understand how individual identity informs behavior and group dynamics, and how tourism is affecting the primates’ intricate society. But his research, meant to last 20 years, recently came to a grinding halt. Along with those of around 40 other scientists, Dr. Sinha’s permit to conduct work within the reserve was revoked by the wildlife manager of Karnataka State.

headline: Digital Notes: A Boss for ‘Six Strikes’ Copyright Enforcement

headline: Theatrical Parody of Harry Potter Books to Open in New York
text: “Potted Potter,” the 70-minute unauthorized parody of the seven Harry Potter books, will make its United States debut with an Off Broadway production starting preview performances on May 19 at the Little Shubert Theater, a group of Canadian and British producers announced on Tuesday. As previously reported, the producers plan to hold 10 performances a week at the 499-seat Little Shubert – more than the typical New York performance schedule of eight a week – in hopes of making more money off the relatively brief running time of “Potted Potter” and the popularity of the Potter characters and stories.

headline: Gwynnett St.
text: Sophisticated food in simple surroundings at a new restaurant in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: In a Simple Room, Surprises Await
text: THE one-story exterior facing Graham Avenue, in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was totally unornamented except for a cryptic pair of stone lions up on the cornice. The dining room was plain, too, harking back to the days when nothing said hip, contemporary and urban better than exposed brick. At the end of the bar was what looked like, and under the previous ownership was, a pizza oven. Now it was baking miniature loaves of whiskey bread. They cost $5, tasted sweet and old-fashioned, and brought me back to those sprawling family restaurants that serve turkey with hot gravy on Sunday afternoons.

headline: 100 Years Later: Ways to Teach About the Titanic With The Times
text: April 15 is the centennial anniversary of the Titanic disaster, which took the lives of more than 1,500 people and left just over 700 survivors.

headline: Budget Plan’s Defeat Shows Hurdles to Compromise
text: WASHINGTON — As the House moved toward a vote last week on a bipartisan budget plan modeled on the deficit reduction blueprint of a White House commission, Washington’s conservative and liberal influence machines swung into action.

headline: Three Dishes at Gwynnett St.
text: Welcome to the weekly blog feature formerly known as Five Dishes. We took a week off, and in that time two of the dishes dropped away. Cynics will note that we are delivering less content just as The Times is shutting the window a bit on how many articles readers can see each month without subscribing. The more charitable might say that Diner’s Journal still gives good value when the three dishes contain as many components as the ones Justin Hilbert prepares at Gwynnett St., which I’m reviewing this week.

headline: Obama Ad Buy Totals $1.4 Million in Six States
text: The Obama campaign is putting nearly $1.4 million behind its newest commercial, getting the president’s message on the air in some of the nation’s largest television markets, according to figures provided by a Republican strategist who tracks media purchases.

headline: In Somalia’s Capital, Hope and Reconstruction
text: Mogadishu had been reduced to rubble over 21 years of civil war, but the city is going through a transition.

headline: For Shumpert, an Opportunity Down the Stretch
text: The recent loss of Jeremy Lin (knee) and Amar’e Stoudemire (back) to potentially season-ending injuries has been viewed as a potential death knell for the Knicks. Facing the N.B.A.’s second toughest home-stretch schedule, the Knicks have turned to Baron Davis, who has not exactly inspired confidence of late.

headline: Much to Savor With the Cherry Blossoms
text: The blooms may be off the branches, but there is still plenty left of the monthlong National Cherry Blossom Festival, including a kite-flying extravaganza on Saturday on the grounds of the Washington Monument. Where to eat when you are taking it all in? For those who do not mind more walking, or an inexpensive taxi ride, here are suggestions for meals, snacks or cocktails in the National Mall neighborhood:

headline: A Fleeting Beauty, Shared With the Multitudes

headline: Republicans Brace for Repeal
text: April 3, 2012 - As the Supreme Court considers repealing all or part of President Obama's health care law, Republican lawmakers are dusting off their own proposals.

headline: TimesCast: Republicans Brace for Repeal
text: As the Supreme Court considers repealing all or part of President Obama’s health care law, Republican lawmakers are dusting off their own proposals. Jonathan Weisman reports.

headline: The President Fumbles the Court Issue
text: I’m sure President Obama knows how important the Supreme Court’s decision on health care will be to his re-election, not to mention the future of the country. And I’m equally sure he knows that the issue of Supreme Court appointments should figure highly in his campaign. If he loses, the nation faces what could be the most right-wing court in history, driven by a highly politicized agenda.

headline: In Mogadishu, a Glimpse of Daily Life
text: Sven Torfinn, a Dutch photographer based in Nairobi, Kenya, and I just spent a week in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital. It was incredible how much the city has changed in the past year. Not so long ago, so much of “Mog,” as it’s called, was off-limits, either Shabab territory or a full-fledged conflict zone. Gunshots rang out every night. Bodies were literally lying in the streets.

headline: In Poll, Jewish Voters Overwhelmingly Support Obama
text: A poll of American Jewish voters shows that they overwhelmingly support Barack Obama for president, just as they did four years ago, and that Israel and Iran rank low on their list of priority issues in the presidential election.

headline: Fire Kills 17 in Moscow Workers’ Dormitory
text: MOSCOW — A makeshift workers’ dormitory here that was cited for fire code violations a month ago caught fire early on Tuesday, killing at least 17 people, officials said, and highlighting Russia’s worsening problem with the enforcement of basic safety standards.

headline: MJ’s Egg Casserole
text: 4 tablespoons butter, plus extra for buttering pan

headline: Straight From the Home Coop
text: FOR newly hatched chicken enthusiasts, the first egg from your own hens is a small miracle. “You want to dip it in gold,” said the writer Susan Orlean, who keeps nine hens at her home in Columbia County, N.Y.

headline: Thinking of Keeping Chickens in Your Yard?
text: A theme quickly emerged as I interviewed home cooks for my article this week: once you get the hang of keeping chickens, the challenge is keeping up with them. Many hatcheries have a minimum order of 25 day-old chicks (they need to huddle together for warmth during shipping), so it’s not unusual to end up with more than a dozen laying hens by summer. Jennifer Trainer Thompson, who has recently published “The Fresh Egg Cookbook,” was a hobbyist gardener (with a day job at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art) before branching out into poultry and bees at her Williamstown home. Her dozen hens produce about five dozen eggs a week.

headline: The Get | Miu Miu’s Starfish Sandals
text: With straps that form sparkly starfish, the latest glitterific Miu Miu shoes are beach sandals at their best. Conical crystals mimic the ocean creatures’ rough, pumice-y texture; a thick layer of gold glitter beneath them reads like pyrite sand; and the leather piping is the perfect seaside color — coral. Every detail has been meticulously applied and assembled by hand (so walk away from the salt water).

headline: In Virginia, Kaine Jumps to Substantial Fund-Raising Lead
text: In the closely watched Senate race in Virginia, former Gov. Tim Kaine, the Democratic candidate, has jumped out to an early and substantial lead.

headline: James Joyce and Tendrils of ’30s Swing
text: The composer Victoria Bond has never been afraid to experiment with unusual combinations, musical and otherwise, in her Cutting Edge Concerts. The series, now in its 15th season, used to bring together musicians and representatives of other disciplines — chefs or architects, for example — in the hope of finding some sort of philosophical common ground. These days, Ms. Bond’s goals are strictly musical, and she has expanded the name of the series to Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival.

headline: Peter Kareiva, an Inconvenient Environmentalist
text: I encourage you to watch the provocative and important lecture above by Peter Kareiva, the much-lauded chief scientist of the world’s biggest environmental group, the Nature Conservancy. The title is “Failed Metaphors and A New Environmentalism for the 21st Century.” It’s a refreshing call for new approaches from a community stuck on what I’ve called a “woe is me, shame on you” tune for far too long

headline: Chicken and Egg
text: Once you get the hang of keeping chickens, the challenge is keeping up with them.

headline: From Congress, a Law Befitting a Sausage Factory
text: Whether the Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act will create jobs or only encourage fraud is open to debate, but one thing is clear: this piece of legislation is a reminder that Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, is completely inept at regulating our financial system.

headline: In New Zealand, a Man, a Van, a Plan
text: Early on a chilly March morning, my iPhone alarm clock sounded. I extracted myself from deep within a navy blue comforter, sat up and opened the door. I had momentarily forgotten where I was.

headline: Mayor Defends Withholding Report on 911 System
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration came under attack on Tuesday for keeping secret what is said to be a sharply critical report on New York City’s much-delayed, wildly over-budget 911 emergency dispatch system, as elected officials accused it of trying to portray a technological debacle in the rosiest possible terms.

headline: Bronx Assistant Principal Charged With Sexual Abuse of Students
text: An assistant principal at a Bronx elementary school was arrested on Tuesday on charges of sexually abusing two girls, the police said.

headline: Obama at the Associated Press Luncheon
text: President Obama attacked the Republican budget in a speech at the Associated Press luncheon in Washington.

headline: 3 American Women in Their Parisian Moments
text: Alice Kaplan’s “Dreaming in French” is an easy book to admire but a hard one to muster much enthusiasm for. It makes a half bang, like a wet firework that flickers colorfully but never rises from the ground.

headline: The Simple Analytics of Soaking the Rich (Wonkish)
text: Update: I see that some people are saying, “But taxes discourage work!” Um, that’s what the supply curve in the figure measures; if taxes didn’t have any effect on work, it would be a vertical line.

headline: Griner Joins the Greats of the Game
text: DENVER — At the buzzer, Brittney Griner threw a towel in the air, ran to midcourt and held up a finger signaling that Baylor was finally No. 1. With another dominant performance, she made good on a pledge to lift a national championship trophy and to hoist her coach to cut down the nets.

headline: The Big Bang
text: In 1990, Japan was at the peak of its prosperity. It seemed an unstoppable force. But the boom turned out to be a bubble. Remember MITI, Japan’s economic planning agency? It’s now defunct, but then it was the envy of “competitiveness” gurus the world over. MITI, plus public-private cooperation, plus thrifty citizens and dedicated workers, plus demanding schools and diligent students, plus a sheltered domestic economy, plus ferociously competitive exporters — all worked together to create a new variety of capitalism, one destined to eat America’s lunch. Or so it seemed.

headline: Updates From Wisconsin, Maryland and D.C. Primaries

headline: Wen Calls China Banks Too Powerful
text: SHANGHAI — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said on Tuesday that the nation’s biggest state-run banks have too much power and ought to be broken up because they earn far too much money.

headline: A Shakespeare Play Set Where the Buffalo Roam
text: The Wild West makes a suitable setting for the brawling romance at the center of “The Taming of the Shrew” in the Theater for a New Audience production at the Duke on 42nd Street. Transplanting Shakespeare comedies to the land of gunslingers and tumbleweeds has become something of a commonplace, it’s true, but this lively production, directed by Arin Arbus (who directed the excellent renditions of “Othello” and “Macbeth” for the same company), treads lightly on conceptual gimmickry and features a frisky dustup between Maggie Siff and Andy Grotelueschen as the pecking lovebirds Kate and Petruchio.

headline: ABC Has Couric, but NBC Gets a Ratings Win
text: 10:30 p.m. | Updated On the first of five days of an epic morning television duel, the normally top-rated “Today” show on NBC stayed on top.

headline: Happiness May Be Here, but Desperation Is Often Close
text: Existential musings waft up from guitar figures in the songs of Ben Howard, the English musician who performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night. He’s an avowed descendant of a late-1960s school of (mostly) British musicians whose songs were inseparable from their guitar textures: tolling drones and intricate fingerpicking, syncopated strumming and skeins of countermelody, damped or snapped strings, tight little trills and the high ping of plucked harmonics.

headline: James Murdoch Steps Down
text: April 3, 2012 - James Murdoch steps down as chairman of the British satellite broadcaster BSkyB, which is partly owned by the Murdoch family.

headline: RIM Software Opens Up to Competing Devices
text: Research In Motion, the struggling BlackBerry maker, on Tuesday released an expanded version of its server software that supports not only its own phones but also those made by its competitors.

headline: Staying Connected, One Shoe at a Time
text: Platform shoe enthusiasts can rejoice at the latest Jeffrey Campbell collaboration. Black Milk Clothing, the three-year-old brand known for colorful, and sometimes outrageous, printed leggings, has teamed up with Jeffrey Campbell to design a shoe line sold exclusively on Solestruck.com. For some, this three-way marriage is overdue.

headline: Relish: An M.V.P. Now Sidelined
text: IN the world of condiments, as in major league baseball, there are heavy favorites and underdogs. Ketchup and mustard are the division leaders, of course. But my allegiance is to pickle relish. Not commonly used by chefs and often relegated to the bottom shelf in supermarkets, relish is like a small-market team that is overlooked and always out of contention — say, the Pittsburgh Pirates of condiments.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wisconsin and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Wisconsin, Israel, Spain and Scotland.

headline: Exit Bad Obama, Enter Good Obama
text: President Obama’s comments yesterday on the Supreme Court and health care reform were utterly inept, but he recovered today. The president’s speech on the economy was a powerful argument against the calculated cruelty of the Republicans’ failed economic policies.

headline: Union Sues City Education Department to Obtain E-mails
text: The teachers' union claims the Department of Education is violating state Freedom of Information Law by declining to release e-mails between former Chancellor Joel I. Klein, other officials and education groups. The e-mails date back to May 2010, the same year the city was blocked by the union from closing more than 20 low-performing schools.

headline: Prismatic Hopes to Create a New Category of Social News
text: For many, Twitter and other social sites have become a central repository for news. Online, people follow mainstream news outlets, journalists, bloggers, friends and family, who all individually stand on their digital soapboxes and share the topics and stories they find interesting.

headline: Assad’s Forces Record Brutal Crackdown as They Carry It Out
text: Syrian activists working to show what the government crackdown on dissent looks like in graphic detail have found a rich, if unexpected, source of material: video clips apparently shot as souvenirs by members of President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces.

headline: Tornadoes Tear Through Dallas-Fort Worth Area
text: Updated | 10:21 p.m. At least two huge tornadoes churned through the densely populated Dallas-Fort Worth area on Tuesday afternoon, leveling homes, snapping power lines and hurling tractor-trailers into the air.

headline: Balanchine Disciple Chosen to Lead Miami City Ballet

headline: Call and Response: Outsider Artist With Shades, Glove and Bukowski
text: Willis Earl Beal — part soul singer, part outsider-art curiosity — is not about deception or deliberate sleights of behavior, but the constructedness of Mr. Beal’s world, whether by design or happenstance, is extremely tough to ignore. For now when you watch Mr. Beal, as you could have on Sunday night at Mercury Lounge, you are watching a back story as much as a performance, especially because the back story is so much louder.

headline: A Man of Many Roles (Most Canceled)

Things weren’t coming together for him professionally and so Mr. Walton, a Boston native, began plotting a move to New York for a career change to banking. When NBC ordered a pilot called “Heist,” he landed a role playing a thief, and the show made it to the airwaves.

headline: When an Atrocity Lacks Documentation, and Truth Is Hard to Prove

So Dee Pelletier’s frightening monologue as Brenda Goodsen in “The Soap Myth,” now at the Black Box Theater at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center, was a revelation. That’s the sort of thing these people say?

headline: Impact of Iran Sanctions Widens
text: The Iran sanctions effort led by the United States appeared to be causing new fractures in the Iranian economy on Tuesday, with leading oil companies in South Africa and Greece suspending imports of Iran’s crude oil, further signs of emergency self-reliance emerging in Iran, and an influential former Iranian president publicly challenging his country’s anti-American stoicism.

headline: The Child of a Lost War Who Gave Comics an R Rating
text: To nonaficionados, Japanese comic books, or manga, typically celebrate vampire-hunting beauties or feisty schoolgirls, tentacled monsters or technology-crazed teenagers. But to the graphic artist Yoshihiro Tatsumi and his peers in the late 1950s, they offered an opportunity to explore darker, more sophisticated stories about postwar Japan — stories so adult that they required a brand-new name: gekiga.
