text: MIAMI — After years of planning, political wrangling and begrudging compromise, a new era in baseball began Wednesday night in Miami.

text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The mysteries that make Augusta National hard for the uninitiated golfer to solve are less puzzling when the greens are spongy from rain, as they were in this week’s practice rounds.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York City
text: Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Council Reluctantly Agrees to State’s Oversight of Detroit’s Fiscal Decisions
text: DETROIT — Hours before Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan was to start the process of assigning an emergency manager to take control of financially ailing Detroit, a divided City Council agreed on Wednesday night to a deal that gives an advisory board, partly appointed by the state, oversight of its financial decisions, budgets and union contracts.

headline: DirecTV and Tribune Agree to Deal
text: Tribune Broadcasting and DirecTV announced an agreement Wednesday night to end a dispute over retransmission fees, returning programming to subscribers after a blackout that began early Sunday.

headline: Plan to Let Poultry Plants Inspect Birds Is Criticized
text: WASHINGTON — Federal food safety inspectors said a proposal by the Agriculture Department to expand a pilot program that allows private companies to take over the inspections at poultry plants could pose a health risk by allowing contaminated meat to reach customers.

headline: A Piece of the Masters, Its Oldest Chronicler, Is Missing
text: As the sun set on the 75th Masters a year ago Sunday, the fertile brain inside Furman Bisher’s head, partly hidden under a signature bucket hat, sent these words through his fingers to the keyboard:

headline: Turkey: Aging Generals Face Trial for Violent 1980 Military Coup
text: Two former generals stood trial in Ankara on Wednesday for their roles in Turkey’s violent 1980 military coup. Kenan Evren, 94, the former head of the army, and Tahsin Sahinkaya, 86, the former air force commander, who were absent because of poor health, face charges of staging a coup to overthrow the civilian government, punishable by life imprisonment. The coup was the most violent of the three military interventions in modern Turkey: 50 people were executed, 300 were killed in prisons and more than half a million were arrested, according to human rights groups. The generals are unlikely to be jailed because of their age and health.

headline: Laich Guarantees a Berth for Capitals
text: So maybe it wasn’t Mark Messier, guaranteeing victory for the Rangers over the Devils in 1994. But Brooks Laich, a respected veteran grinder for the Washington Capitals, became surprisingly brash about his team’s hopes of clinching a playoff berth with two games left in the regular season.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Investigation Under Way at Howard
text: Howard University announced that it had temporarily suspended some of its athletes from competition while the university investigates possible N.C.A.A. rules violations. Kerry-Ann Hamilton, a spokeswoman for Howard, a historically black university in Washington, said she could not divulge the names of the athletes or their sports. She said, however, that most of the university’s teams would continue competing as usual. Howard has 7 men’s sports and 10 for women.

headline: Population Growth in New York City Is Outpacing 2010 Census, 2011 Estimates Show
text: New York City gained nearly 70,000 residents in the 15 months ended July 1, 2011, almost matching the growth of the 1990s, when an influx of foreigners set annual records, according to census estimates released on Wednesday.

text: The Challenge: Can you solve the case of a young woman with an odd gait and slowly progressive weakness in her hips and legs?

headline: U.S. Marine Deployment Won’t Put China At Ease
text: HONG KONG — The new deployment of U.S. marines to Australia is part of the much-discussed “pivot” by the United States toward the Asia-Pacific region, a series of muscular military and diplomatic initiatives intended to balance the rise of China.

headline: India’s Leaders Dispute Report of Rift With Military
text: “India’s top leaders on Wednesday denied a rift between the country’s civilian government and its military brass after an article in a leading national newspaper described a tense episode in January, in which civilian leaders became deeply unnerved when two army units advanced on the capital in an unannounced nighttime drill,” Jim Yardley and Hari Kumar write in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | April 5, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: New Clashes Fuel U.N. Skepticism of Promises by Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Spasms of fighting convulsed parts of Syria on Thursday, with clashes reported only miles from the capital. The leader of the United Nations said the conflict was getting worse — contradicting the Syrian government’s assurances to a special envoy that it was complying with his cease-fire plan.

headline: Kerala’s Cochini Jews Meld Into Israel
text: On Moshav Nevatim, a dust-blown, palm-tree studded community on the northern edge of Israel’s Negev desert stands a humble little synagogue with an enormous past. The Kerala Synagogue, as it is called, was built in the style of the synagogues of India’s Cochini Jews, a hardy handful of whom settled Nevatim in the 1950s after emigrating from the Indian state of Kerala.

headline: April 5, 1951 | Judge Sentences Julius and Ethel Rosenberg to Death for Espionage
text: On April 5, 1951, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were sentenced to death for conspiring to commit espionage for the Soviet Union. They were executed by electric chair in 1953, becoming the only two American civilians to be executed for cold war espionage.

text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Coronation for Kentucky, and for Its Coach.”

headline: 97% of Investors Agree to Greek Debt Swap
text: Greek government officials said on Thursday that 97 percent of the investors holding its private sector bonds had agreed to the terms of a debt swap in which they would take a 75 percent loss in return for a new package of debt securities.

headline: Chile’s Youth in Revolt
text: Camila Vallejo leads Chile back into the streets.

headline: Camila Vallejo, the World’s Most Glamorous Revolutionary
text: The hotel had a musty, Pinochet-era atmosphere — dark bar, heavy furniture, bartenders in white shirts and black ties — and drew mostly businessmen. But when the bartenders found out that my friends and I were going to the student march, they cut lemons for us and put them into plastic bags with salt. In case of tear gas, you were supposed to bite into the lemons to lessen the effect. With guarded smiles, they let us know they supported the Chilean student movement and especially its most prominent leader, Camila Vallejo. A bartender said, “La Camila es valiente”; he laughed and added, “Está bien buena la mina” — “She’s hot.”

headline: Standing Between the Police and Protesters
text: As the full extent of Greece’s financial crisis has unfolded over the last three years, the Greek government has been forced to impose one austerity measure after another: salaries and pensions have been cut. Taxes raised.

headline: Is There a Fiscal Crisis in the United States?
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Do You Spend Too Much Time on Smartphones Playing ‘Stupid Games’?
text: Angry Birds, Fruit Ninja, Draw Something, Words With Friends: All these games are available right at your fingertips, wherever a smart phone, tablet or similar device is available. Are you addicted? When are you most likely to play games like this? Do you think they’re a waste of time — or do you see some value in them?

headline: Rocket From Sinai Lands in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — At least one rocket fired from the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt struck the southern Israeli resort city of Eilat overnight, causing alarm but no injuries, police officials said on Thursday.

headline: In the End, My Gut Decided Which College to Choose
text: I confirmed my admission to the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities for the fall of 2012 while watching Iowa State lose to Kentucky in a basketball game. As I sat with my family in my living room, my gut twisting with nerves, I knew I was ready to make my decision final.

text: In order to win your fantasy league, you need the players you acquire to out-earn their draft slots or auction prices; in other words, you must make a sizable collective net profit on your roster. Assuming you’re not playing with absolute novices, there are four ways to do this:

headline: The Taxi of Tomorrow
text: James Barron and John McDonagh, a New York City taxi driver, step into Nissan’s new taxi cab, which is expected to appear on the streets at the end of next year.

headline: Rothschilds to Combine French and British Assets
text: LONDON — One of Europe’s oldest banking dynasties is changing to maintain its grip on an institution dating back to the 18th century.

headline: Pope Rebukes Priests Who Advocate Ordaining Women and Ending Celibacy
text: ROME — Striking the tone that once earned him the nickname “God’s Rottweiler,” Pope Benedict XVI in a stern Holy Thursday homily denounced “disobedience” in the Roman Catholic Church, chastising priests who sought the ordination of women and the abolition of priestly celibacy.

headline: Indexes Up as China Acts to Lure Foreign Investors
text: HONG KONG — Stocks in China rallied on Thursday, helped by the country’s newly announced decision to open its markets to more foreign investment and expectations that Beijing might soon take additional steps to bolster flagging economic growth.

headline: Spinach Is a Dish Best Served Cooked
text: If spinach has the reputation of being the homework of vegetables, it was not helped by its ’70s “revival” in the form of raw spinach salads. Spinach has many charms — truly singular flavor, the ability to be transformed by cooking in myriad ways, its famous health benefits — but salad is probably the least convincing.

headline: Jack Outside the Box
text: In an industrial section of south-central Nashville, stuck between a homeless shelter and some railroad tracks, sits a little primary-colored Lego-block of a building with a Tesla tower on top. The inside holds all manner of curiosities and wonders — secret passageways, trompe l’oeil floors, the mounted heads of various exotic ungulates (a bison, a giraffe, a Himalayan tahr) as well as a sign on the wall that says photography is prohibited. This is the home of Third Man Records: the headquarters of Jack White’s various musical enterprises, and the center of his carefully curated world.

headline: The Verdict on Business Huddles
text: Several weeks ago, during a meeting of our business group, Susan Parker raved about huddles — short, daily meetings that help keep employees moving toward a common goal (here’s a guide to holding productive huddles). She and her sister, who own Bari Jay, started huddling at the suggestion of their business coach. Ms. Parker said the practice kept the entire team clearer about what needed to be done and helped the two owners focus on big-picture goals.

headline: Doubts Surround Syrian Cease-Fire Plan
text: LONDON — If all goes according to plan — a big “if” — up to 250 United Nations military observers could soon be sent to Syria to monitor a proposed cease-fire between the forces of President Bashar al-Assad and those trying to overthrow him.

headline: A Small Pill, With Positive Side Effects
text: On a cool February morning in north Delhi, “35 third graders sat at small desks in a spartan but tidy classroom,”Amy Yee writes in The New York Times. “They wore blue school uniforms and listened as their teacher asked in Hindi if they had had intestinal worms.”

headline: British Central Bank Keeps Rate Steady
text: LONDON — The Bank of England kept its main interest rate at a record low on Thursday because of concerns about higher energy prices and the continuing economic crisis in Europe.

headline: Daily Report: Old Money, New Tech
text: Fresh from college and graduate schools, the children of some prominent dynasties are taking a different career path, spurning their legacies in retailing, real estate and finance for a future in technology, Evelyn M. Rusli reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: On Our Radar: Missteps in Colorado Fire
text: Forest Service records show that a crew carrying out a controlled burn last month in the forested foothills southwest of Denver failed to ask for a spot forecast of weather conditions. That would have predicted the swirling winds that led to a six-square-mile blaze. [Associated Press]

headline: Violet, Lily and Other Flowers of Youth
text: Most of the characters in Whit Stillman’s “Damsels in Distress”— the principal damsels, for sure, and also some of the lads identified in the opening titles as “their distress” — speak in complete sentences and express complex, sometimes startlingly original ideas. This, friends, is news: a movie populated by young people who do not mumble, swear, punctuate their utterances with “like” or think that an incredulous “really?” represents the apogee of wit. Even if it did not have other charms, this peculiar, uneven campus comedy would be worth seeing for the delightful felicity of its dialogue.

headline: N.F.C. East Team Needs
text: We round out our N.F.C. pre-draft hidden needs series with a look at the television companies’ favorite division.

headline: Delhi Doctor Couple Denies Charges of Maid Abuse
text: The Vermas, the doctor couple who allegedly left their under-age maid locked in their Delhi home while vacationing in Thailand are innocent, their lawyer, Shailendra Bhardwaj, said on Thursday.

text: Wall Street Examines Fine Print in a Bill for Start-Ups  |  Wall Street is examining whether it will benefit from a little-known section of a broad new law that President Obama is expected to sign on Thursday.

headline: After Stenson Capsizes, Westwood Grabs Lead
text: The first round of the Masters started uneventfully enough, with pleasant weather and a seemingly attackable course softened by the week’s rain. By late afternoon, it had taken a turn for the weird.

headline: France Rules Out Sending Troops to Mali as Rebels Proclaim Ceasefire
text: West Africa’s regional trade bloc began drawing up plans for military action to tackle the twin crises of a coup and a rebellion in Mali, as Tuareg rebels who have seized control over much of the north of the country declared a cease-fire in their drive to create an independent homeland.

headline: The Early Word: Definition

Mark Landler writes that while Mitt Romney embraces Mr. Ryan and his budget on the campaign trail, President Obama is trying to portray the alliance between the two Republicans as a dangerous partnership that would deepen America’s fiscal woes.

headline: Why Is It Ethical to Eat Meat? Ethicist Contest Closes April 8
text: Two weeks ago, The Ethicist asked readers to send in 600-word essays on a divisive topic: Why is it ethical to eat meat? Vegetarians and vegans have long discussed why being an omnivore is unethical. Now omnivores (or carnivores) have a chance to respond.

headline: Vain Glorious | A New Day (Spa) in Myanmar
text: Who: Inya Day Spa, Yangon (Rangoon), Myanmar.

headline: Yellow and Green Nail Shades for Spring
text: Wild manicures are all the rage for spring, and in today’s Thursday Styles, Ruth La Ferla covers the booming business of sparkle, neon and zebra stripes. Meanwhile, I wrote about the cult of yellow and green polish— a trend that’s only growing hotter despite alienating many a man and manicurist.

headline: No More Mr. Nice Guy
text: ISTANBUL — For much of the Cold War, Turkey was NATO’s lonely sentinel, patrolling Europe’s southern flank. It’s not surprising that the thawing of that conflict left Turkey feeling somewhat abandoned. Its principal function — a strategic importance to its Western allies — had been devalued by the removal of the Soviet threat.

headline: Mixing Religion and Baseball on a Day of Renewal for All
text: This is the season of renewal and redemption, embodied for many New Yorkers by three events that symbolize those concepts and happen to converge this weekend: Easter, Passover and, yes, the start of the baseball season. All three embody an optimism that is the essence of spring, and rings true for nearly everyone but the most dispirited in our midst, sometimes known as Mets fans.

headline: Voters’ Anger May Hinder, Not Help, Republicans This Year

headline: Thursday Reading: Gene Mutations Linked to Autism Risk
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Markets Mixed on Fears About Europe
text: Stocks were mostly lower on Thursday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to its biggest weekly loss of the year as renewed concern about Europe’s debt crisis overshadowed a decline in jobless claims to a four-year low.

headline: From a Green Corner of the Auto Show, SRT Viper Earns an Unlikely Fan
text: The fire-breathing Dodge Viper, theoretically good for a combined 16 miles per gallon in its 2009 incarnation, was never going to be a Greenpeace poster car. And that’s why it was somewhat astonishing to see Jim Kliesch, the research director for the clean vehicles program at the Union of Concerned Scientists, standing front and center when the 2013 SRT Viper was unveiled here Wednesday.

headline: Champions League: And Then There Were Four
text: It says something about the Champions League semifinals that Chelsea, a billion-dollar club with a roster stocked full of internationals, is the weak link. But after the Blues slipped past Benfica on Wednesday, there’s no denying it.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 5: A Soccer Field on the Pier
text: Good morning. It will remain sunny throughout the day, with temperatures rising to the high 50s.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bloomberg Businessweek: The aftermath of the Euro crisis: the long spud lines in Greece. In a nation with no economy, no jobs and fading hopes, young couples, families and pensioners queue for the basic food group: red-mesh 20-kilo sacks of potatoes. A new “potato movement” is linking farmers to consumers in the interest of mutual survival. — Glenn Collins

headline: Ferris Bueller’s Nights Onstage
text: MATTHEW BRODERICK spent the evening of his 50th birthday late last month at the Imperial Theater, where he will open on April 24 in the new musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It.” After some cake and a brief celebration he returned to his chores, which seemed like an illustration of the show’s title. He was required over and over again to dance with a bevy of beautiful chorus girls who hoisted him off the floor and carried him across the stage before starting to undress him. Not just nice work, it seemed, but hardly work at all.

headline: (Vegan) Brunch Options Abound in East Berlin
text: Germany’s traditional gastronomic portfolio is as meat-centric as they come, but Berlin’s contemporary food-culture has started shrugging off its carnivorous past in favor of, well, plants. An enduring bohemian spirit and newfound cosmopolitanism have cultivated fertile culinary ground for the city’s emergence as the continent’s vegetarian capital. Here, cruelty-free cuisine holds special sway for weekend brunchgoers — in Berlin, where you dine for Sunday morning das Frühstuck carries as much social import as where you partied on Saturday night. Three East Berlin establishments offering vegan brunch options rise to the occasion.

headline: Spring, in the Air and on the Racks, Helps Retailers
text: Retailers’ sales continued to hum in March, particularly in the trendy apparel sector, suggesting that shoppers are snapping up spring fashions.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Easter Wings’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches George Herbert’s “Easter Wings” with a recent “Lives” column from the Sunday Magazine, “Easter Among Strangers.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Collected $10.5 Million for 2011
text: James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley‘s chief executive, took home a $10.5 million pay package in 2011, a year in which his firm’s stock price dropped about 44 percent.

headline: Finding Her Own Path Back to Broadway
text: LINDA LAVIN surprised the New York theater world last summer when she passed up roles in not one but two hotly anticipated Broadway shows in favor of an Off Broadway play called “The Lyons.” It was hard to see what was so special about the project: Ms. Lavin’s character was the matriarch of yet another dysfunctional family; the play’s author, Nicky Silver, had an uneven track record; and the production was at a 125-seat theater downtown.

headline: Romney Has 2-to-1 Lead Among Republican Voters in New York
text: With three weeks to go before New York’s presidential primary, Mitt Romney holds a more than two-to-one lead among likely Republican voters, according to a new poll released on Thursday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Betting On Deadmau5 and Arianna Takes More Control
text: After a decade, money is circling around the concert business again, but this time the interest isn’t in Madonna or The Eagles, writes Ben Sisario. Electronic dance music has moved from dance clubs and semi-legal warehouse parties into concert halls and stadiums and private equity is showing interest. “If you’re 15 to 25 years old now, this is your rock ‘n’ roll,” said Michael Rapino, the chief executive of Live Nation Entertainment, the world’s largest concert promoter. The problem for investors? The business is run by independent investors who have credibility with customers and a roster of star D.J.’s but little else.

headline: Built to Last
text: If there’s anything perennial in fashion, it’s a pair of black boots, and Robert Clergerie’s are as enduring as any out there. Roland Mouret, the French-born, London-based designer known for his sculptural clothes, is now the creative director of the comfort-meetsbourgeois- chic brand. In addition to statuesque heels and brogues, he’s done several variations on the boot theme: Parisian motorcyclists, sinuous thigh-highs, sturdy jodhpurs (above; $795 at Robert Clergerie’s New York and Los Angeles stores, and at barneys.com). ‘‘Women like Catherine Deneuve knew how to wear a really sexy yet practical shoe,’’ Mouret says. ‘‘And I think today’s women are ready for that again.’’

headline: Theater Talkback: Second Helpings
text: Often, it really is better the second time around. Occasionally, the thrill is gone. And then there are those instances – and they are the rarest — when it all seems exactly the same.

headline: Ai Weiwei Says He Pulled the Plug on Webcams, on Police Orders
text: Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and outspoken government critic, said Thursday that he and his colleagues had “disconnected” a live Web camera operation from a Japanese server the previous day. Mr. Ai said in a brief text message that he took the action after having been “told by police to shut down.” Mr. Ai was unable to be reached by telephone late Wednesday, when word of the shutdown of his new webcam operation began spreading, and he sent the text message on Thursday in response to a text message question left by this reporter.

headline: The Big Three Tee Off
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. – At 7:40 a.m. Thursday, golf’s Big Three – Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Gary Player – teed off together for the first time as honorary starters at the Masters. All three of their drives found the center of the fairway, although they had to take everyone else’s word for it.

headline: Refunds for Wedding Gifts After the Couple Splits Up
text: Admit it. You’ve sometimes grumbled after buying a nice wedding gift, only to see the couple split up a year or two later.

headline: Jack White’s Blue Period
text: For this week’s magazine, Josh Eells has written the definitive profile of Jack White, the former White Stripes frontman who is releasing his first solo record, ‘‘Blunderbuss,’’ this month. Eells spent close to 14 months on the story, traveling back and forth to Nashville, and it turned out to be a pretty eventful period: White Stripes break up; White and Karen Elson announce their divorce; White quickly bangs out a solo record. And crucially, Eells discovered, the color scheme has shifted. White’s rose period (the inviolable red and white of the White Stripes) is gone. Jack’s in a blue period now.

headline: Pro’s Perspective: Before Playing, Workouts and Waffle Houses
text: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 PGA Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters, but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia, in his third season on the Champions Tour, will provide a daily Masters blog, as well as in-round analysis, for The New York Times:

text: Discover vineyards, mountains and a sandwich called the lomo in this northern region of the country.

headline: Three-Alarm Party for Alber
text: There are risks to having a work party in your own home, as the Barneys New York chief executive Mark Lee discovered on Wednesday night when he invited a small crowd of editors to toast Alber Elbaz, once again, on the occasion of his 10th anniversary at Lanvin.

headline: 36 Hours in Mendoza, Argentina
text: ARGENTINA’S financial crash in 2002 was actually a boon for the local wine industry. The devaluation of the peso meant that winemakers in this northern region of the country could deliver high-quality vintages to the export market at very low prices, even while the cost of making wine was dropping. Real estate prices also fell, and investors rushed in to snap up prime wine acreage at a fraction of the cost in other regions. Ten years later the result is a vibrant wine scene with a great array of bottles for different budgets and palates, cutting-edge eco-sustainable cantinas and a new generation of innovative winemakers. The city of Mendoza itself makes a good base for a visit, with new hotels, restaurants and bars in the historic center, and a mix of architecture that showcases Art Deco alongside ’60s modern (the vintage pickup trucks are also a throwback to another era). Just a short drive away are vineyards, adventure sports and resorts under the shadow of the Andes with wine lists that feature the best of the region.

headline: Catholic Fund Cuts Off Aid Over Groups’ Affiliations
text: DENVER — For three years now, Compañeros, a small nonprofit organization in rural southwestern Colorado, has received thousands of dollars from the Roman Catholic Church to help poor Hispanic immigrants with basic needs including access to health care and guidance on local laws.

headline: We Need to Talk About Guns
text: How many students have to be shot to death in their schools before this country has a serious discussion about guns? Are the 10 who have been gunned down just since Feb. 27 enough?

headline: Walcott: In Sync With City Hall
text: As city schools head into spring vacation, starting on Friday, Dennis M. Walcott is marking a personal day of celebration: his one-year anniversary as city schools chancellor. To mark the occasion, he has been granting a series of interviews to news organizations, and The Daily News's report on Thursday focuses on the air of calm and steadiness Mr. Walcott has brought to the job.

headline: Video-Game Companies Agree to Close Sex Offenders’ Online Accounts
text: In an effort to cut off another avenue used by online predators, several video-game companies have agreed to close the accounts of more than 3,500 registered sex offenders in New York State following an agreement with the attorney general’s office.

headline: Airline Introduces Option For Short-Hauls
text: Travelers who want to shave time off a four-hour car drive don’t have many options. Amtrak’s Acela Express has just a single route. And given airport procedures, flying isn’t such a shortcut. Surf Air, an airline starting this summer, has designs on that short-haul sweet spot.

headline: Face Time | Mena Suvari
text: I chatted with Mena Suvari in New York, before she had to jet off for her press tour for her new movie, “American Pie: Reunion,” opening tomorrow. I don’t want to miss out on the special brand of humor this movie holds. And I didn’t want to miss out on what beauty brands Mena will be taking with her on the road.

headline: Happy Opening Day! (Take 3)
text: DETROIT – “Happy opening day,” Bobby Valentine says, and then he pauses to reconsider. “Third opening day. Yesterday, Japan and today. Happy third opening day.”

text: Once known for paint and stamps, the Temescal District is now studded with hip shops.

headline: ‘Face to Face With the Rebels’
text: Gen. George B. McClellan, the former commander of the entire Union force, now commander of the Army of the Potomac alone, started the Peninsula campaign on April 4, 1862, the first step toward fulfilling the promise made to him by Secretary of War Edwin Stanton the previous November: “Now we two will save the country.” Having landed tens of thousands of soldiers near the tip of the Virginia Peninsula in the preceding weeks, his plan was to push inexorably northwest toward the Confederate capital at Richmond — and victory in the Civil War.

headline: Sexual Misconduct Complaints Are Up, Investigator Says
text: The number of complaints involving school employees accused of sexual misconduct went up 35 percent in the first three months of 2012 compared to the same period last year, Richard J. Condon, the Special Commissioner of Investigation for the New York City Schools, said in an interview with WNYC's Beth Fertig.

headline: Lauren Oliver to Write First Adult Book
text: Lauren Oliver, the 29-year-old author of best-selling teenage novels, will write her first novel for an adult audience, her publisher said on Thursday. Ecco, part of HarperCollins, has acquired “Rooms,” which will be released in fall 2014. Lee Boudreaux, who will edit the book, said it was “as instantly gripping as it was elegantly written, filled with characters and predicaments I still can’t get out of my head a week later.”

headline: Funny or Die Expands Into Commercial Production
text: A company that specializes in nontraditional advertising is expanding into the traditional kind.

headline: Cheryl Strayed Talks About ‘Wild,’ a Memoir of Hiking and Grief
text: In her memoir “Wild,” Cheryl Strayed recounts her solo trip hiking the Pacific Crest Trail in 1995, when she was 26 years old and in a state of crisis, separated from her husband and grieving for her mother, who had recently died of cancer at 45. Reviewing “Wild,” Dwight Garner wrote: “This book is as loose and sexy and dark as an early Lucinda Williams song. It’s got a punk spirit and makes an earthy and American sound.” I recently spoke with Ms. Strayed about the book via e-mail. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

headline: Romney Says Santorum Should Win His Home State
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Greeting voters on a rooftop here, Mitt Romney handicapped his Pennsylvania prospects, which sound a lot like those of Barack Obama four years ago: losing the primary, but winning the general election.

headline: J.C. Penney Cuts 14% of Headquarters Staff
text: J. C. Penney laid off 600 employees from its corporate headquarters on Thursday, about 14 percent of the staff there, and said it would close one of its three call centers later this year, eliminating another 300 jobs.

headline: Tax Haven Crackdown Creates Opportunities for Bankers
text: LONDON — The world’s tax havens are being forced to clean up their acts.

headline: Watch the Mayor’s ‘Late Night’ Appearance
text: “It’s the best job in the world,” chimed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during his appearance on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on Wednesday, his first in about three years. He boasted about kissing Lady Gaga, but remained pretty quiet as a photo of him posing with Snooki and The Situation of “Jersey Shore” was displayed.

headline: British Broadcaster With Murdoch Link Admits to Hacking
text: LONDON — Sky News, a British satellite news broadcaster whose parent company is part-owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, admitted Thursday that one of its reporters had hacked into e-mails on two occasions while pursuing news stories, the first time that Britain’s hacking scandal has spilled into television news.

headline: Smaller Navy Ship Has a Rocky Past and Key Support
text: MOBILE, Ala. — The Navy’s newest ship is designed to battle Iranian attack boats, clear mines from the Strait of Hormuz, chase down Somali pirates and keep watch on China’s warships. The ones built here even look menacing, like Darth Vader on the sea.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: Abolition in Connecticut
text: It looks like Connecticut is about to join modern civilization: On Thursday morning, state senators voted 20-16 in favor of repealing the death penalty. The abolition bill now goes to the state House, where it’s likely to pass, and then to Democratic Governor Dannel P. Malloy, who said he’ll sign it.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “India: One, Two, Three” (March 25), I truly think that the author misses the point of visiting India by recommending overpriced, fancy hotels and driving everywhere by car. This guarantees that one remains in a bubble and contributes to traffic gridlock and pollution.

headline: Monaco Adds Art to Its Seaside Allure
text: ACROSS from the grand entrance at Monaco’s Oceanographic Museum is a monumental cabinet of curiosities. Filled with items ranging from marine specimens to a polar bear to a replica of the world’s first diving suit, the 33-by-60-foot wood, glass and steel structure seems at home in this stunning building that houses an aquarium once overseen by Jacques Cousteau. The cabinet, though, is not part of the museum’s scientific exhibitions. It is a permanent installation by the American artist Mark Dion.

headline: Hotel Review: Nun Assisi Relais in Assisi, Italy
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: A Taos Field Evokes the Extraordinary
text: MY favorite place is a field — an ordinary farmer’s field on the edge of Taos. It’s easy enough to find, but equally easy to miss. If you’re driving north through town on the Paseo del Pueblo, you’ll see it on the right, not far after Cid’s Food Market, a four- or five-acre field edged with cottonwoods on one side, a dirt track along another, and a row of unassuming houses that separate it from the Taos Pueblo’s land beyond. In the background looms Taos Mountain.

headline: At Citi Field, a Campaign for New Owners
text: Hope springs eternal on opening day, they say, unless you’re a Mets fan disgruntled with the team’s owners, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz.

headline: High in Lombardy, Italy, a Less Crowded Pilgrimage
text: THE spring presents Italy at its best. The lively and colorful celebrations of saints, ancient folkloric customs and traditional feasts build to a peak as the weather warms after Palm Sunday. But the inevitable corollary is that the season can also show the peninsula at its worst: thousands of tourists flock to the classic Venice-Florence-Rome triangle, Italians on vacation flood beaches and mountains, pilgrims swarm to Vatican City for papal Masses in St. Peter’s Square.

headline: Deborah Dickson-Smith’s Tips for Family Travel
text: AS an editor and travel writer for LittleNomads.com, a Web site about traveling with children, and a contributor to publications like Holidays With Kids, Deborah Dickson-Smith has traversed the world researching family vacations. But her real education began when she and her partner, Simon Mallender, combined their families and began traveling with five of the most severe critics: their children.

headline: Graphic: The Billionaires’ Club
text: Regardless of who wins the 2012 presidential election, billionaires will come out on top.

headline: Restaurant Review: Sotto in Los Angeles
text: On the western side of Los Angeles, where Pico Boulevard transects Beverly Hills to the north and Cheviot Hills to the south, is a kind of no man’s land. There is a palpable sense of stasis there, accentuated by the area’s most striking landmark, a carpet showroom with an immaculate 1950s facade. But since opening last year, a southern Italian restaurant has been transforming this lonely stretch into a site of culinary pilgrimage.

headline: Tunisia After the Revolution
text: BELOW the watchtower of the ancient fortress known as the Ribat, a panoramic view of the Tunisian city of Sousse unfolds. To the east lies the Mediterranean coast, where the Carthaginians moored their navy during epic battles with the Roman Empire. To the south and west, the labyrinthine passageways of the medina, the city’s old walled quarter, extend to the vanishing point amid a sea of tightly packed houses and minarets.

headline: Profit and Proliferation: A Special Report on Belgian Arms in the Arab Uprising, Part I
text: The uprisings in Libya and Syria have cast the Belgian small arms industry as a case study of the difficult balances within a Western arms-manufacturing community that seeks exports to preserve revenue and local jobs, but risks compromising European policies and human rights values.

headline: In AMG’s Go-Fast Machines, Start-Stop Gains Ground
text: Mercedes-Benz is bullish on relatively low-cost stop-start systems, which deactivate the engine at idle to save fuel, but the German brand’s partiality is manifesting itself in an unlikely place.

headline: Germans and Swiss Reach Stricter Deal on Tax Cheats
text: PARIS — Switzerland agreed Thursday to a revised tax deal with Germany under which it would pay billions of dollars on funds hidden in its banks by German tax dodgers, the latest step in an international charm offensive that is meant to salvage at least some of the country’s famous banking secrecy.

headline: Haunted by Life, Haunted by Wife
text: In the course of her long career, Anne Tyler has done more with a limited number of premises and story lines than perhaps any other novelist working today. Not only do most of her novels take place in the by now recognizable environs of a pleasant, middle-class Baltimore, but they also tend to work inventive variations on a slender handful of themes and character types.

headline: Does Your Pet Watch the Hawk Cam?
text: Updated, April 9Last year, we learned that cats couldn’t turn away from the Hawk Cam. Readers from all over the country submitted photos of their cats focused on the screen.

headline: Eurofile | Paris Bed Check
text: Proof that the French are great hotel connoisseurs is a term they coined to describe a certain category of them — hôtel de charme, connoting a one-of-a-kind place with a big but casually chic personality. Until recently, cabbage-rose wallpaper and shrewd flea-market finds have tended to define the quirky look at this Parisian species, but a fresh crop of properties is adding a major dose of design and creature comforts.

headline: Free Help for People Filing Their Income Taxes
text: This deadline for filing federal taxes this year is Tuesday, April 17. The deadline was extended because April 15, the traditional filing date, falls on a Sunday, and Monday, April 16, is a holiday in Washington.

text: When the new Yankee Stadium opened in 2009, not even the loudest of Yankee fanatics could drown out the outraged howls over its costly tickets, its tax-exempt financing and, of course, its construction atop two city parks.

headline: Magic Coach Says Howard Wants Him Fired

headline: Sarkozy and His Rivals Trade Attacks as Vote Nears

headline: Twitter and Me
text: I have succumbed. You can follow me at DouthatNYT, for what I hope will mostly be a mix of links to my own pieces, occasional links to other items of interest, and (for the next month or so) near-constant book promotion. But yes, it will probably devolve into a mix of self-congratulatory snark, celebrity retweets, and 140-character demagoguery soon enough.

headline: Russian Church Admits Photo Was Altered to Hide Patriarch’s Watch
text: Updated | 5:22 p.m. MOSCOW — The Russian Orthodox Church admitted on Thursday to altering an image on its Web site to remove a watch worn by its leader. The alteration was discovered this week by Russian bloggers who suggested that the deleted watch was an expensive timepiece Patriarch Kirill has admitted he owns but claims to never wear.

headline: Appeals Court Revives Viacom Suit Against YouTube
text: A federal appeals court on Thursday reversed a lower court’s decision to throw out a $1 billion lawsuit filed against YouTube by Viacom and other media companies five years ago.

headline: Collector Sues William Eggleston Over New Prints of Old Photos

headline: Spec Obsession Disorder: The Incurable Techie Malady
text: In my Times column Thursday, I reviewed the Nokia Lumia 900 phone. Plenty of people (including Nokia) consider it Nokia’s last best effort to make some headway in the American smartphone market. Microsoft also has a lot riding on this phone, which runs its Windows Phone 7 software. Like Nokia, it’s currently flopping.

headline: New York Public Library to Digitize Washington, Thoreau and Twain
text: Letters written by George Washington, Henry David Thoreau’s pencil-drawn map of Walden Pond and Mark Twain’s manuscript of “A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court” are among the items from the New York Public Library’s American collections that will soon be digitized and made available to the public online, the library announced on Thursday.

headline: Philosophers Versus Breeders
text: In last week’s New Yorker, Elizabeth Kolbert reviewed two books that examine the moral case for having children — and find it seriously wanting. Here’s Kolbert’s summary of one of the objections to procreation, from the philosopher David Benatar:

headline: About.me Releases Mobile Application
text: About.me, an online profile Web service of AOL that enables people to create public profiles of themselves, announced the release of its first mobile application on Thursday.

headline: Who (Else) Wants to Be a Billionaire?
text: To answer some of the most-asked questions I’ve received about my article on living like a billionaire for a day: yes, my editors are very cool for approving my pitch; no, I didn’t bankrupt The Times when I filed my expenses; and yes, I did get to keep the suit. (I paid for it myself, because I needed a new one anyway. Now I just have to find other, less rarefied places to wear it.)

headline: Pentagon Pushes Crowdsourced Manufacturing
text: Designing and building things for the United States military is a notoriously slow-moving and costly endeavor. The time from idea to manufacturing for a new armored personnel carrier or a tank is typically 10 to 20 years.

headline: Yonkers Finances in Serious Trouble, Panel Says
text: Yonkers, the fourth-largest city in New York State, could be the next municipality headed for a control board.

headline: When a Violinist and a Violin Stop Making Music
text: Sure, sure. Ars longa, vita brevis, and all that. But what happens when ars also begins to show its age?

headline: Administration Concedes Courts’ Review Power
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration stipulated the incontestable to a disgruntled federal court on Thursday, formally declaring that “the power of the courts to review the constitutionality of legislation is beyond dispute.”

headline: And Now a Word From Charles Dickens’s Sponsor…
text: Globe-trotting admirers of Charles Dickens can celebrate this year’s bicentennial of his birth by brushing shoulders with chimney sweeps at a Dickens World theme park in England, taking in lectures and amateur theatricals at a scholarly “Dickens camp” in California, or attending any of the festivities being held from Bologna, Italy, to Colorado Springs.

headline: In Time for the Playoffs, Red Wings Find Some Confidence
text: The Detroit Red Wings, who have been mired in a slump brought on by injuries to key players, may be showing some signs of life as the playoffs draw near. The Wings jumped over the Predators for fourth place in the Western Conference, thanks to a 3-2 win over the Central-leading Blues, to temporarily gain home-ice advantage for a looming first-round series against Nashville. The Predators and Wings both have two games left in the season.

headline: Actor Is Said to Be Kicked Out of Co-op. He Says Otherwise.

headline: A Mouse Problem Closes Little Owl
text: The Little Owl, a famously unpretentious 28-seat restaurant at 90 Bedford Street that was called “a vest-pocket Greenwich Village gem” in an article by Sam Sifton, a former restaurant critic of The New York Times, was closed Wednesday evening after a health inspector found evidence of mouse droppings in its basement and in a customer-seating area, the New York City Department of Health said.

headline: C’mon, Get Happy. Or Not.
text: SEEING Tracie Bennett in “End of the Rainbow” isn’t the only way to encounter the spirit and legacy of Judy Garland in the New York region. Garland and her daughter Liza Minnelli have always been ripe for impersonation, and several performers continue that tradition. “Judy Garland & Liza Minnelli Live at Mama’s!,” a long-running show on select weekends at the cabaret Don’t Tell Mama, is a night of songs and banter featuring the performers Tommy Femia as Garland and Rick Skye as Ms. Minnelli. (212-757-0788, donttellmamanyc.com.) Phyl Craig plays Ms. Minnelli in “Believe: Divas in a Man’s World,” a female impersonator show at Resorts Atlantic City (resortsac.com).

headline: The Road Gets Rougher for Judyism’s Faithful
text: LAST Saturday I invited my friend Brodie, a 30ish gay man like myself, to a preview performance of “End of the Rainbow,” Peter Quilter’s play about the final days of Judy Garland. In the course of that invitation, I asked him if he was a Judy fan, and he said, “No, but she was good in ‘The Wizard of Oz.’ ”

headline: Cigarette Started Macy’s Fire, Investigators Find

headline: The Big Bang
text: Last fall, television stations carried a 60-second ad for Audi’s A6 car. The opening images showed a pitted, potholed American road while the voice-over gloomily intoned, “Across the nation, over 100,000 miles of highways and bridges are in disrepair.” Fear not, said the voice; Audi’s smart gizmos would help. The spot’s message was clear: Roads in the United States are now so bad, you need a foreign car to negotiate them.

Back on Dec. 26, 1995, he played his first N.H.L. game, across the street at the old Igloo. He was an 18-year-old rookie for the Buffalo Sabres then, called up from the Beauport Harfangs of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League to face the great Mario Lemieux and the Penguins.

headline: Where Death Shaped the Beats

It was here 68 years ago, on a slope descending to the moonlit Hudson River, that Lucien Carr, 19, the Beat Generation’s charismatic, callow swami, buried a knife in the heart of David Kammerer, 33, his besotted, dauntless hometown stalker.

text: Concentrated poverty has a concentrated impact. This is not news, and it’s a very difficult story to make “new” — another, less amusing way that writing about family can feel, as Lisa Belkin put it in a recent column, like “Groundhog Day.”

headline: Pensioner’s Suicide Continues to Shake Greece
text: ATHENS — The death of a 77-year-old Greek pensioner who shot himself in the head outside Parliament in despair over his financial problems has shaken this austerity-weary country and a crumbling political system struggling to assert its relevance amid an economic and social meltdown.

headline: Up Front
text: “Language first came to fascinate me when I was 5 and heard a Jewish friend suddenly start speaking Hebrew with her parents,” John McWhorter, who this week reviews “Language: The Cultural Tool,” by Daniel L. Everett, said via e-mail. “As my mother drove me home, I was actually in tears at the idea that some people could talk in two ways and I could only talk in one.”

headline: At One-Year Mark, Walcott Sees Improvement in Education Debate's Tone
text: Reflecting on his first year as chancellor of the city's schools, one marked by protests over school closings and the public release of teacher rankings, Dennis M. Walcott said that, in some ways, the tone of the citywide education debate has improved under his leadership.

headline: Hang Loose
text: My wonderful mother is in her mid-60s. Since retiring, she has tried to become healthier and lose weight. She has lost 30 pounds so far. But she still has 25 to go, and has hit a plateau. Plus, it’s hard to tell she’s lost weight because she has a lot of excess skin around her chin and neck. I want to suggest a neck lift. I think if more people noticed her weight loss, she would be happier, and it would encourage her to work harder toward her goal. Is there any way to do this tactfully?

headline: For Some Artworks, Life Begins at the Dustbin
text: From the department of unsolicited advice for aspiring artists: avoid dust, dirt, ashes, soot, smoke, sand, mud and lint, especially if you want to make a statement about life, death, history and the ephemerality of it all. The dangers are well illustrated by “Swept Away: Dust, Ashes and Dirt in Contemporary Art and Design,” at the Museum of Arts and Design.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Spain, Israel, Syria and Thailand.

headline: Whit Stillman on ‘Damsels in Distress’

headline: A New Traveling Show of Lichtenstein Works
text: The world has changed since the last traveling Roy Lichtenstein retrospective, which opened nearly 20 years ago at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York. Pop Art has not only continued to capture the imagination of the public, but it has also flourished, helped in part by social networking, global connectivity and a universal fascination with the media.

headline: Finding Outfits That Sing
text: The singer and songwriter Carnie Wilson, 43, is part of the pop trio Wilson Phillips, which released a new album, “Dedicated,” last week and will have the first episode of its reality show, “Wilson Phillips: Still Holding On,” on the TV Guide Network this Sunday. Ms. Wilson, a Los Angeles native, is married to the producer and musician Rob Bonfiglio. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

text: In an appearance on CBS, David Axelrod says that Mitt Romney "hasn't been able to make the sale to his own party."

headline: Russian Weapons Trafficker Avoids Getting Life in Prison
text: Viktor Bout, a Russian man known and feared for his leadership role in international weapons trafficking, was sentenced on Thursday to 25 years in prison, sparing him the life sentence that federal prosecutors in Manhattan had sought.

headline: Taking Cues From Rodin, Who Took Some From Others
text: There is a longstanding tradition of artists reading other artists’ work against the grain: viewing or interpreting it in a way that was clearly not intended. A famous example is Auguste Rodin, the French sculptor, who was inspired by Michelangelo’s unfinished works, specifically sculptural fragments of torsos and limbs and the “Slaves” originally planned for the tomb of Pope Julius II. Working in the same era as the Impressionists, whose canvases were often criticized as looking like unfinished sketches, Rodin took the idea of figures still partly encased in stone and translated it into sculpture that looked distinctly modern.

headline: Stalking the Most Elusive Prey in Tasmania’s Wilds
text: “The Hunter,” filmed in Tasmania, has the faintly surreal look peculiar to Australian movies in which nature pulses with a mysterious, primordial shimmer. Adapted from Julia Leigh’s novel and directed by Daniel Nettheim from a screenplay by Alice Addison, the film tells the story of a lone hunter from another continent searching for a creature that may not exist in an old-growth forest largely untouched by humans.

headline: At Spring Nationals, ‘Right’ Play in Wrong Deal
text: There are some defensive deals in which many make what appear to be textbook plays, not realizing that they are erring.

headline: Family of Iraqi Woman Killed in California Was in Crisis, Records Show
text: EL CAJON, Calif. — When Shaima Alawadi, an Iraqi-born mother of five, was found bludgeoned to death in her home last month with a threatening note beside her, many members of the large Middle Eastern immigrant population here feared a hate crime.

headline: You Can Almost Hear Him Sigh
text: This year the joys of spring in New York include the visit of a large, magnificently plainspoken self-portrait by Rembrandt to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Never before exhibited in this country, it comes from the collection of Kenwood House in North London, which is closed for repairs; it will subsequently join other Kenwood paintings at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, for an exhibition that will open in June and then travel to three other American museums.

headline: Album Might Have a Presidential Tie
text: Ian Brabner, an Americana dealer in Delaware, is bringing an 1870s photo album that he says has a presidential connection to the New York Antiquarian Book Fair, opening Thursday at the Park Avenue Armory. Last year at a Maryland estate auction, Mr. Brabner said, he unwittingly bought images of maternal ancestors of Stanley Ann Dunham, President Obama’s mother, in Kansas and Ohio.

headline: America’s Sex-Trafficking Victims
text: I was born in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia, to two professors. Lisa, a woman my age from a poor neighborhood in Washington, was born to a rapist and an alcoholic. I was my parents’ first and only child. Lisa was one of 12.  I’m now working at The New York Times, while Lisa is recovering from brutal mistreatment at the hands of pimps and johns.

headline: A French Church Nears Its End, but Not Without a Contretemps
text: Tossing a gauntlet as he delivered an Easter sermon in 1841 to the people of New York, Charles Auguste Marie Joseph, the bishop of Nancy and Toul in France, demanded:

text: Introduced on Thursday, April 5: 2013 Cadillac SRX.

headline: Grown Up and Married, Certainly, but Mature? Not by a Long Shot
text: Believe it or not, there are teenagers in this great country who respond to intrinsically hilarious phrases like “band camp,” “Stifler’s Mom” and “Eugene Levy” with blank, uncomprehending stares. The arrival of “American Reunion” is no doubt partly intended to remedy this alarming cultural deficit and also to remind former teenagers of jokes that used to make them laugh.

headline: Texas Chain to Reincarnate a Landmark Theater
text: Alamo Drafthouse Cinema, the Texas-based movie theater chain famed for its no-tolerance policy on cell phone use — and for making a viral hit out of the irate rant of a customer who got booted for violating it — is coming to New York.

headline: Merritt Parkway Trail Faces Opposition
text: DRIVERS on Fairfield County’s scenic Merritt Parkway are known to complain to the state Department of Transportation that too many houses are visible through the trees lining the highway’s periphery.

headline: Mixed Signals for Builders
text: THERE was plenty of room to move up and down the sparsely populated carpeted aisles of the recent 63rd Annual Atlantic Builders Convention in Atlantic City. The organizers were anticipating a better turnout than last year’s 7,000 visitors, but if the first day was any indication, the slogan stripped across the cover of the official show guide — “Building is Back in Business!” — may not tell the whole story.

headline: Parting With the Parsonage
text: A GENERATION or so ago, a parsonage was the accepted way to provide members of the clergy with housing, typically in lieu of a higher salary. Particularly for younger pastors on Long Island, the parsonage was often nicer than what they could have otherwise afforded.

headline: Deal Preserves Red Hook Port’s Customs Inspections
text: Beer and bananas will continue to flow into Brooklyn’s Red Hook Container Terminal, a result of a last-minute agreement between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and federal customs officials that will keep inspectors at the port for the next five years.

headline: For International Students, a College Admissions Checklist for April
text: In March, The Choice introduced Counselor’s Calendar, an occasional series intended to keep students on track throughout the college admissions process.

headline: Illinois Representative Will Drop Re-election Bid
text: Representative Timothy V. Johnson of Illinois will not continue his re-election bid, despite winning the Republican Party nomination in a primary last month.

headline: For the Dearest Departed, Nothing Is Too Good
text: HONG KONG — Hong Kong people like to shop — and they don’t stint when it comes to shopping for their departed loved ones.

headline: Matt Lauer to Stay With NBC’s ‘Today’ Show
text: NBC News has signed Matt Lauer to a new multiyear contract to remain as the co-host of the “Today” show, addressing one of the division’s most pressing issues.

headline: Q & A
text: A False Impression at a Co-op Building

headline: Apollo May Again Face an Unwanted Battle
text: Despite its best efforts, Apollo Global Management may find itself once again in a battle to acquire an amusement park company.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cloud Competition, and ‘Silicon Valley,’ the TV Show
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

headline: Happy Meal Lawsuit Dismissed
text: The lawsuit brought by the Center for Science in the Public Interest and a California mother of two that sought to stop McDonald’s from including toys in its Happy Meals has been dismissed by California judge Richard Kramer. No legal analysis was provided, but the lawsuit had been widely criticized as frivolous: more about rhetoric than legal issues. Is offering a toy with your junk food predatory marketing? For now, it’s up to the consumer to decide.

headline: Locking In Peace of Mind
text: WITH mortgage rates inching higher, some borrowers might want to consider a lock-in agreement, which freezes the terms of a loan while it is being processed, potentially saving borrowers thousands of dollars over the life of the mortgage.

headline: A Gangster Named Ulysses Goes Home and Homeric
text: The muscle and the molls are in the parlor, hunkered down and waiting for the cops. There are ghosts upstairs, rattling their chains. But “Keyhole” is not really a gangster picture nor a horror movie, though it traffics in some of the visual and verbal conventions of both genres: tough talk, murky shadows, darkened hallways. The simplest way to describe it is as a Guy Maddin film, which is really just a way of gesturing toward its puzzles and complications.

headline: Karzai Orders Prosecutor and Tribunal in Scandal Over Kabul Bank’s Losses
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With Afghanistan’s foreign backers set to meet next month in Chicago, President Hamid Karzai ordered the appointment of a special prosecutor and the creation of a special tribunal to try those involved in the near collapse of Kabul Bank, a scandal that laid bare the crony capitalism and corruption that has thrived here in the past decade.

headline: Pakistani Lawmakers Criticize U.S. Reward for Militant Leader
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government and opposition on Thursday united in criticism of a newly announced $10 million American bounty for Hafiz Saeed, a militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, during a heated session of Parliament in which lawmakers demanded that Washington provide proof of Mr. Saeed’s terrorist credentials.

headline: When Human Advancement Backfires
text: No one carries a placard scrawled with “The end is near” in the nonfiction movie “Surviving Progress,” as people sometimes do in New Yorker cartoons. Its assembly of experts is far too smart and savvy, too heavily armed with facts, figures and the legacy of the Enlightenment to be dismissed as random kooks, well, except by their political and ideological critics. Even so, this 86-minute breeze through civilization, its history and self-made discontents from the Canadian filmmakers Mathieu Roy and Harold Crooks — which concentrates on the present and future costs of familiar environmental and economic catastrophes — is very much a doomsday documentary.

headline: Answers About Bobby and Rosie, Part 2
text: As we wait hopefully for baby hawks in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park, the executive director of New York City Audubon, Glenn Phillips, responds to readers’ questions about behavioral clues that signal the eggs are hatching; the parenting instincts of raptors; and hawk attacks and territories in New York City.

headline: Vice President Biden on CBS
text: In an interview, Vice President Joe Biden offers a variety of critiques of Mr. Romney.

headline: Quandary Considered: Telling My Daughter About My Abusive Mother
text: Years ago, E. chose not to have any more contact with her verbally abusive mother. Now, as she described for last week’s quandary, her young daughter is approaching the age when she’s bound to ask questions. How, E. asked, should I tell my child — at 3, and as she grows older — why she has two grandparents on her father’s side, while her mother has no parents to share at all?

headline: ‘Upstairs, Downstairs,’ Apartment-Style
text: HAVE you heard enough about the $55 million for-sale sign on Huguette Clark’s apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue yet? Me, too. But this is about something different, about 907 itself, built in 1916 as a new kind of gentry housing, where the truly rich could feel truly comfortable under a common roof — even if the servants did not.

headline: Devils’ Top Line Regains an Important Piece
text: NEWARK — After tearing his left Achilles’ tendon last summer, then having surgery, then returning for eight games only to be sore and weak, then sitting out more than two months while waiting for the injury to heal, Travis Zajac is finally the Devils’ top-line center again.

headline: Healthier Eating Starts on the Roof
text: WHEN Yarittzi Estevez and her 8-year-old daughter, Aaliyah Rivers, planted collard greens, zucchini, lettuce and strawberries in their Brooklyn garden last year, they did not quite know what to expect. But one thing they never anticipated was competition from the native fauna.

text: To the Editor:
