headline: Good Friday Food Links
text: Shocking: The F.D.A., citing lack of evidence, declined to ban the chemical bisphenol A (BPA) from food and drink packaging. It’ll be more shocking if the agency, which has a long, rich history of inaction when it comes to animal antibiotics, decides to ban the practice of routinely feeding antibiotics to healthy farm animals, a decision that it’s being forced to make.

headline: India’s Tax Plan Troubles Foreign Investors
text: MUMBAI, India — Just two months ago, worried about their slowing economy, Indian officials were promising to promote policies to make the country more hospitable to foreign investment.

headline: Poetry Between Shifts
text: During National Poetry Month at the Gramercy Tavern, employees recite poetry before every lunch and dinner shift.

headline: NBC’s ‘Today’ Show Wins Ratings Showdown
text: The “Today” show removed any doubt that it will win its weeklong showdown against “Good Morning America” by scoring its biggest ratings win of the week on Thursday morning.

headline: Isiah Thomas Fired By Florida International
text: Isiah Thomas has been fired as the men’s basketball coach at Florida International University after three seasons. His record was 26-65.

headline: Ryan in Two Numbers
text: Last year, when Paul Ryan first made a big splash with his budget proposal, many commentators — some of them pretending to be moderates or at any rate only moderate conservatives — lavished praise on its fiscal responsibility. Then people who actually know how to read budget numbers weighed in, revealing it as a piece of mean-spirited junk.

headline: And Lincoln Had a Secretary Named Deadmau5…

headline: In Defense of Superstition
text: SUPERSTITION is typically a pejorative term. Belief in things like magic and miracles is thought to be irrational and scientifically retrograde. But as studies have repeatedly shown, some level of belief in the supernatural — often a subtle and unconscious belief — appears to be unavoidable, even among skeptics. One study found that a group of seemingly rational Princeton students nonetheless believed that they had influenced the Super Bowl just by watching it on TV. We are all mystics, to a degree.

headline: After Appearing on TV, Two Subway Protesters Are Arrested
text: As cracking cases go, this one did not require detectives to open too many phone books or wear out the soles of their shoes climbing tenement steps. No mug shots were needed either.

headline: When a Book Lover’s Son Won’t Read
text: I’m not raising a reader. My 9-year-old, Daniel, reads more or less at grade level, but he doesn’t love it. How do I know? Because he says, “I don’t love reading.” Our nightly book sessions are a chore, and it’s getting worse.

headline: In Spain, Women Enslaved by a Boom in Brothel Tourism

headline: And on the Special Staff Menu, Poetry
text: “Enlightened hospitality,” the restaurateur Danny Meyer’s catchphrase for success, takes on new meaning during National Poetry Month. All April long, before each lunch and dinner shift at Gramercy Tavern, his three-star Flatiron district restaurant, the employees take turns reciting poems for one another before they hit the floor.

headline: Jaguar F-Type Revealed, Vaguely, in New York

headline: A Difficult Choice on Water
text: Arizona’s two senators, John McCain and Jon Kyl, traveled to the Navajo reservation this week to meet with Navajo and Hopi tribal leaders about a proposed water rights accord that would settle the two tribes’ claims to the Little Colorado River system.

headline: Turkey Raises Alarm to U.N. Over Worsening Violence in Syria
text: Turkey’s foreign minister on Friday reported increased Syrian military attacks near the border and a relentless influx of refugees from Syria, saying he had telephoned the United Nations secretary general to express his alarm about the situation in the prelude to a proposed cease-fire in the Syrian conflict that is scheduled to start in less than a week.

headline: Don’t Expect Many New Factory Jobs
text: Even if every manufactured product we bought was made in America, a professor argues, manufacturing employment here would lag.

headline: Why Shiloh Matters
text: The Battle of Shiloh began at sunrise on April 6, 1862 — the Sabbath — as 45,000 Confederate soldiers swooped down on an unsuspecting Union army encamped at Pittsburg Landing, a nondescript hog-and-cotton steamboat dock on the Tennessee River. What followed were two of the bloodiest days of the Civil War, leaving 24,000 men on both sides dead, dying and wounded.

headline: In Camila Vallejo’s Footsteps
text: “I had heard a lot about the joyful, carnival madness of the marches: hundreds of thousands of people roiling the streets of Santiago, with bands and costumes and colorful signs and floats and shouts,” Francisco Goldman writes in his piece on Camila Vallejo, the Chilean student leader. Goldman goes on to describe a march in which protestors dressed as zombies and danced to “Thriller.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: America and the Balance of Global Power

headline: A Village Embraces Its Haunted Legacy
text: LAHARDANE, Ireland — For decades, abandoned stone cottages were the only mark of the Addergoole Fourteen, young emigrants who had fled the dark bogs of County Mayo with dreams of fortune in America and steerage tickets aboard the Titanic steamer setting sail from its last port of call: Queenstown, Ireland.

headline: A Storm Over the Montana Football Program
text: Montana’s football program continues to churn in choppy waters, with the newly designated interim coach, Mick Delaney, telling The Billings Gazette on Thursday that he will not be stepping down any time soon.

headline: Confronting a Different Kind of Loss
text: STANLEY ROSENZWEIG stands in his shiny kitchen in Manhattan, reflective surfaces all around, by the stainless-steel island that friends refer to as looking like “an autopsy table.” Mr. Rosenzweig, an easygoing, upbeat man who once went online to rent a Moses costume to jazz up a Passover Seder, is telling a joke, which he does frequently.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Game of Thrones’ and the Avengers
text: There are two new hardcovers on the list this week. At No. 1 is “A Game of Thrones,” an adaptation of George R. R. Martin’s fantasy novel, written by Daniel Abraham and illustrated by Tommy Patterson. It’s a great week to be a fan of the series. The new season of the HBO version had its premiere on Sunday to high ratings. It was the most-watched scripted show on cable last week.

headline: Parent of Outback Steakhouse Plans to Go Public
text: The parent company of the Outback Steakhouse chain of restaurants, Bloomin’ Brands, filed to go public on Friday, becoming the latest company owned by private equity firms to seek a stock market listing.

headline: How to Make Fresh Ricotta
text: It’s easy and economical and tastes amazing. Melissa Clark shows how to make ricotta cheese at home.

headline: Figuring Out the Market for Fine Watches
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week is about the booming market for high-end vintage watches, even with the economy still showing signs of weakness. But driving some of the demand is a whole new group of collectors in Asia.

headline: Table Talk | Frère Jacques
text: Jacques Pépin: more French than American, or more American than French? Let’s review the particulars. He learned to cook as a teenager in his parents’ restaurant in Lyon and, by the age of 20, was commanding the kitchen of Charles de Gaulle. (French!) At 23, he moved to the United States and took a job flipping burgers at a Howard Johnson’s on Queens Boulevard, then spent a decade at the Howard Johnson Company, mastering the art of mass food production. (American!) Several television shows and 27 cookbooks later, he holds a daytime Emmy and both a Chevalier de L’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres and Chevalier de L’Ordre du Mérite Agricole, two of France’s highest honors. (American?)

headline: Photo Replay: April 6

headline: Displaying British Reserve, but Ready to Play in Dirt
text: DID America really need — or want — a luxury sport utility? That was the question confronting Tony Gilroy, managing director of Land Rover, as the company began exploring ways to bring its Range Rover brand to the United States in the mid-1980s.

headline: The Ever-Evolving Impala Badge
text: THE impala, a gentle, fleet-hoofed grazing animal from eastern Africa, has long been associated with Chevrolet’s large upper-level models. In the pantheon of instantly recognizable mammalian automotive badges, it ranks with Ford’s mustang and Jaguar’s leapers and growlers.

headline: New York, Without the Dazzle
text: This year’s auto show is notably light on fantasies and flashy niche models, and heavy on mass-market appeal. Here is a look at some of the show’s highlights.

headline: Touring Cabaret Capitals With a Polyglot Chanteuse
text: With the first song that the German cabaret artist Ute Lemper performed on Thursday night at Zankel Hall, in a program called “Berlin Nights/Paris Days: The Art of Chanson,” she gave her audience an evening’s worth of intensely expressive singing and riveting drama. The song, “Elle Fréquentait la Rue Pigalle” (“Her Beat Was the Rue Pigalle”), composed in 1939 by Louis Maitrier, with words by Raymond Asso, was made famous by Édith Piaf. It tells of an ashen-faced young prostitute with a hint of radiance, “like blue skies,” in her eyes. She works the Rue Pigalle in Paris but is taken away by a smitten man to Montparnasse. For a while.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 6
text: Subjects include the arrival of a newly designed taxi, a crane collapse in Manhattan and new ball fields on the site of the old Yankee Stadium.

headline: Portraits of Harlem’s Clergy
text: Ozier Muhammad has lived in Harlem for the last 22 years, exploring the area and hunting for stories during long walks in the neighborhood.

headline: Pink Tea Cup to Return to the Village
text: The Pink Tea Cup, once an iconic soul food spot in Greenwich Village, is about to enter another phase in its fragile history.

headline: Former Franklin Bank Executives Accused of Fraud

text: Adapted from “Zuppe,” by Mona Talbott

headline: Quiet Nourishment as Spring Settles In
text: MY friend Mona Talbott, one of the best cooks I know, has just published a book about soup. Its title is “Zuppe,” which means “soups” in Italian, though as she points out, there are many names for soup in that language: aquacotta, brodo, crema, minestrone, minestrina, minestra, passata, ribollita, vellutata and pappa, each with its own personality.

headline: How to Make Fresh Ricotta
text: Why make homemade ricotta? Because you can. And because the results are so much better than most of the packaged stuff you can buy, especially at the supermarket. Making it yourself is also less expensive than buying fresh ricotta at a fancy gourmet market. You can watch this week’s video for some of the nuances of the process, but here’s the basic recipe, which is pretty straightforward.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 6
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Remixing Some Catnip to Attract a New Audience
text: It’s not hard to understand the logic behind “Flamenco Sketches,” the new Blue Note release by the Andalusian pianist Chano Domínguez. As the title suggests, however indirectly, it’s a cultural reimagining of “Kind of Blue,” the landmark 1959 Miles Davis album, which featured a weightless ballad called “Flamenco Sketches” as its fifth and final track. On some level, perhaps, it’s an act of reciprocity, a circling back of flamenco’s modal improvising tradition after its borrowed time in Davis’s hands. That would be the generous interpretation.

headline: Tortorella, Fined for Comments About Penguins, Turns Focus to Capitals
text: GREENBURGH, N. Y. — The day after John Tortorella called the Penguins “one of the most arrogant organizations in the league,” the Rangers did not want to talk about Pittsburgh. If the Rangers win the regular-season finale Saturday night at Madison Square Garden against Washington, they will beat out Vancouver for the Presidents’ Trophy, as the team with the best record in the league. They would have home-ice advantage through the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: AutoSlash, AwardWallet, MileWise and the Travel Bullies
text: In this weekend’s column, I look at a couple of instances of big players in the travel industry beating up on start-ups that make them look bad and, in some instances, maybe crossing the line in doing so.

headline: Swatting Down Start-Ups That Help Consumers
text: Back in February, I dived deeply into the workings of AutoSlash, a little company making big waves in the world of car rentals.

headline: An Existential Way Station With No Chance of Escape
text: CHICAGO — “This place is confusing to me,” says Kilroy, the permanently punch-drunk ex-prizefighter hero of Tennessee Williams’s “Camino Real,” who has landed in a Latin American town from which he cannot seem to escape. “I think it must be the after-effects of fever.”

headline: Chic in Review | Follow Beyoncé!
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 6
text: More Photographs

headline: A Rock Star May Steal the Show
text: It’s been a week since the premiere of the British choreographer Michael Clark’s new work at the Whitney Biennial, but that hasn’t been enough time to turn “Who’s Zoo?” into a dance of substance. Though changes have been made, it’s still a patchwork job in the style of Merce Cunningham — but it must be granted that Mr. Clark knows how to amp it up.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at Spring Nationals
text: There are many deals in which declarer would make his contract if he could peek at an opponent’s hand. In those deals, the defenders must try to be as deceptive as possible, forcing declarer to guess what to do.

headline: Talented, Eye-Catching, Unapologetic
text: MAHLER and Coco Chanel are unusual bedfellows, but the pianist Yuja Wang, on her Twitter feed, quotes both: from Mahler, “Tradition is tending the flame, it’s not worshiping the ashes”; and from Chanel, “A girl should always be two things: classy and fabulous.”

headline: Homemade Soup Needs Homemade Broth
text: This week’s City Kitchen column celebrates the publication of a wonderful new cookbook called “Zuppe” by Mona Talbott, a longtime chef at the American Academy in Rome. It is a gorgeous collection of 50 seasonal Italian soups, inspired by the cooks and gardeners of the Rome Sustainable Food Project. Made from organic garden vegetables, grains and legumes, these soups are nurturing and healthy. Some are hearty enough for a meal, while others could make a light first course. All are beautiful, but none are fancy.

headline: Cinderella Treatment for Unvarnished Soul
text: UNTIL just seven months ago the singer, songwriter and guitarist Brittany Howard used to get up at dawn for her day job: delivering mail. “I just assumed I was going to work like my parents did till I got old,” she said by telephone from her home in the small town of Athens, Ala.

headline: Off-Road Class
text: Land Rover’s success in the United States was based on a counterintuitive premise: that affluent buyers would be willing to pay a premium for a down-and-dirty sport utility vehicle.

headline: The Case for Shakespeare: Words, Words, Words
text: Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, the defense calls Simon Callow.

headline: Digital Notes: After Springsteen Flap, Ticketmaster Settles in Canada
text: As part of a settlement in a class-action in Canada suit over ticket scalping, Ticketmaster has agreed to limitations on one of its subsidiaries there.

headline: April 8 — 14
text: ARE alarm bells going off at the 59E59 Theaters? They should be, since the playwright David Harrower has left a man and a woman alone on a stage there. The last time Mr. Harrower did this, in his Olivier Award-winning “Blackbird” (staged by the Manhattan Theater Club in 2007), the chemistry between his characters was so toxic that many of us who saw it still feel the burn. His current offering, opening on Thursday, has the ominous title “A SLOW AIR.” It is ostensibly a portrait of a relationship between a long-estranged brother and sister, played by Lewis Howden and Susan Vidler. But the play’s scope turns out to range far beyond matters domestic. (The 2007 terrorist attack on the Glasgow Airport is a fulcrum of the plot.)

headline: Still Tripping Far and Wide
text: A skull sat alongside votive candles on the grand piano when Dr. John performed on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, midway through a three-week residency titled “Insides Out.” Physical and spiritual, earthly and supernatural, a memento mori and a promise of transcendence — all were aspects of Dr. John’s music for the night.

headline: Health, Politics and the Supreme Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: For These Couples, Power Isn’t Just His
text: Today’s prototypical Hollywood wife is not the dinner-party-hosting, Rodeo-Drive-shopping, thinly disguised character from a Jackie Collins novel. Many have careers of their own, some of which nearly rival the ones of the powerful men they are married to. A sampling:

headline: Don’t Call Her a Trophy Wife
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

headline: Eye-Baffling (and Fatal) Contortions
text: LONDON — In England, on Maundy Thursday various customs still pertain. (The monarch still distributes “Maundy money” to deserving pensioners.) It immediately precedes Good Friday, a public holiday, on which theaters are traditionally closed.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Book of Right On
text: More Sarah Jarosz.

headline: Blurring of Two Worlds, One Suspended in Time
text: In the work of zoe | juniper, the Seattle-based husband-and-wife team of the choreographer Zoe Scofield and the video artist Juniper Shuey, dance design and video design are on unusually intimate terms. The sophisticated layering that can result is especially evident in “A Crack in Everything,” which had its local debut at New York Live Arts on Wednesday. But piling on layers doesn’t guarantee depth.

headline: Democrats Ready to Pressure G.O.P. on ‘Buffett Rule’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Senate Democrats will kick off a coordinated pressure campaign on Republicans next week ahead of a tax day vote on legislation to enact the president’s “Buffett Rule,” which would ensure that the rich pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the arrival of a newly designed taxi, a crane collapse in Manhattan and new ball fields on the site of the old Yankee Stadium.

headline: Syrian Activists Report Intense Gunfire in Hama
text: Amid reports of escalating violence in Syria, three days before a cease-fire plan calls for the Syrian military to withdraw from cities and towns, bloggers in the city of Hama posted audio and video online that appeared to document an intense gun battle on Friday night.

headline: Hotel’s Free Wi-Fi Comes With Hidden Extras
text: Justin Watt, a Web engineer, was browsing the Web in his room at the Courtyard Marriott in Midtown Manhattan this week when he saw something strange. On his personal blog, a mysterious gap was appearing at the top of the page.

headline: Little Owl Reopens After Passing Inspection
text: The Little Owl took flight again on Friday night.

headline: Independence of the F.D.A.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rock Throwing by Arabs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Strip-Search Decision
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond Affirmative Action
text: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Patent Wars and Tagging People
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Tapas That Make Entrees an Afterthought
text: ONE wonders where Rafael Palomino finds the time. This noted chef, a Bedford resident, has produced several cookbooks, runs a catering business and oversees a clutch of restaurants (each with a discrete menu) scattered from New Haven to Pennsylvania’s Lehigh Valley. Sonora in Port Chester has long been a stop for diners who enjoy Mr. Palomino’s Nuevo Latino touch, and Bistro Latino in Tuckahoe, his newest venture in Westchester, is very much in the informal café tradition — serviceable without frills, with bare heavy table tops, tight seating and quick, knowledgeable service.

headline: NBC Fires Producer of Misleading Zimmerman Tape
text: NBC News has fired a producer who was involved in the production of a misleading segment about the Trayvon Martin case in Florida.

headline: Jury Awards Damages in Fruit Fight
text: A six-member jury in Manhattan ruled on Friday that Del Monte Foods, the preserved food and pet food company, had misled consumers with the labeling on some of its cut, refrigerated fruit products and violated the terms of licensing agreements it has with Fresh Del Monte, the fresh fruit and vegetable company that was split off in 1989.

headline: Yankees’ Game 1 Looks a Lot Like Game 162
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For the second straight regular-season game over two seasons, the Tampa Bay Rays celebrated a game-ending victory over the Yankees. But this time, it really mattered to the Yankees.

headline: AT&T Will Unlock Out-of-Contract iPhones
text: Starting Sunday, AT&T will allow iPhone customers whose contracts have expired to unlock their phones, or remove the restrictions that bind them to the carrier.

headline: Giant-Size Flagship of a Growing Empire
text: RICHARD ROSENTHAL is Connecticut’s Danny Meyer, a restaurateur-Midas who rules an ever-expanding empire of trattorias and seafood emporia, taverns and luxury burger joints. With his Max Food Group celebrating its 25th anniversary, the time seemed ripe to revisit the flagship, situated on the ground floor of Cityplace I, Hartford’s prime power building and the tallest in the state.

headline: For Rebels in Mali, Odds of Establishing a Nation Are Slim
text: JOHANNESBURG — Lines etched in sand are playthings of the wind. So it is no wonder that the nomadic Tuareg people of West Africa, who have for centuries plied caravan routes that crisscross the Sahara with little regard for national borders, have long believed in their right to their own state. And on Friday, by their lights, they got one: rebel fighters in the ancient crossroads of Timbuktu, Mali, announced the birth of a nation called Azawad.

headline: The Dust Kicked Up by ‘Bully’ Still Flies
text: LOS ANGELES — “Bully” is now safe for viewers under 17. But is the movie ratings system safe from Harvey Weinstein?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Hop to It
text: Dashes of color, an eclectic mix of styles, silk scarves catching a spring breeze: vivid harbingers on Fifth Avenue last week for the Easter Parade.

headline: Widespread Virus Proves Macs Are No Longer Safe From Hackers
text: 9:22 a.m. | Updated with site that has simpler instructions for identifying virus.

headline: What Could Be More Realistic Than a Commercial?
text: Do you enjoy being manipulated? Of course not. So why would you enjoy watching people as they make plans to manipulate you?

headline: Idle Hands in Need of Work
text: Since “The Client List” is being advertised with billboards on which each of Jennifer Love Hewitt’s breasts appears to be the size of a studio apartment, let’s say this up front: It’s hard to imagine a less sexy show about prostitution. Based on its first two episodes, Lifetime’s “Client List” makes even a dead fish like HBO’s “Hung” look steamy.

headline: Some Dreary Forecasts From Recovery Skeptics
text: WASHINGTON — When a lackluster jobs report came in on Friday morning, some economists, investors and forecasters were hardly surprised.

headline: The Shots Sounded Like Fireworks, So Nobody in the Cafe Reacted
text: They always say it sounded like fireworks.

headline: Seattle: Leave Our Amazon Alone!
text: It was Amazon week at The Seattle Times, as the retailer’s hometown paper examined at length various aspects of the company, including its approach to warehouse labor,  tough negotiating tactics with publishers and bare-bones approach to corporate giving. The questions underlying these stories are increasingly being asked not only about Amazon, but also Apple and other leading tech companies: As their reach and ambition grow, do these firms have any special responsibilities to their workers? How about to the local community? How about the larger community?

headline: A Festive Setting, Indoors and Out
text: AS restaurant transformations go, it was a quick one: After Two Steak and Sushi Den, an expensive, well-regarded steakhouse in New Hyde Park, closed its doors on Jan. 1, the establishment reopened on Feb. 10 as K. Pacho, a rustic, casual Mexican spot with lower prices. The owners — Jay Grossman, John Guirguis and Ray Sidhom, who also run Four Food Studio in Melville — are the same, as is the executive chef, James McDevitt.

headline: In Food and Form, Back to the Future
text: WHEN Joe San Philip and his partners took over a two-story restaurant space in Millburn with noisy acoustics, they moved the bar into the storefront next door to quiet things down. Drinkers, they hoped, would mosey from the bar into the dining room and back again. Their next move was to concoct a cocktail list with a mixture of updated classics, like a ginger sidecar, and newer creations like Cynars and Saints, a bittersweet potion of artichoke and elderflower liqueurs topped with prosecco.

headline: Caring, Romantic American Boys
text: Amherst, Mass.

headline: California College Postpones Plan to Charge Much More for Some Popular Courses
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Following a week of student protests and a request from the chancellor of the California community college system to hold off, Santa Monica College has canceled its plan to offer certain popular courses at higher prices this summer.

headline: Reviewing the Fiat 500 Abarth
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett reviews the 500 Abarth, a hotted-up version of Fiat’s minicar from the Italian automaker’s performance tuning division:

headline: Katherine Russell Rich, Who Wrote of Battle With Cancer, Dies at 56
text: Katherine Russell Rich, whose gritty, darkly comic memoir of her protracted battle with breast cancer became a beacon for other patients, died of the disease on Tuesday. She was 56, and against all predictions had lived with cancer for nearly a quarter-century.

headline: Palm Trees Part of Frozen Four’s Novel Backdrop
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With palm trees swaying and boats meandering through a sun-kissed marina, Christian Miller could barely contain his grin. Proudly wearing a sleeveless Ferris State University T-shirt, sunglasses and flip-flops, he looked like a typical college student on spring break.

headline: Godfathers, Caterpillars and Golf
text: Republican to-do checklist:

headline: Girl Model
text: Embedd only trailer

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Investors are buying up homes to turn into rentals, Google gave a preview of its Internet-connected glasses and the government released a disappointing jobs report for March.

headline: Starting the Day, and Ending It, at Romney’s Side
text: MILWAUKEE — Garrett Jackson and Mitt Romney are stuck together like the peanut butter and honey sandwiches they both love.

headline: ‘On the Beach’
text: At the Baryshnikov Arts Center, teams of artists and performers play around with Philip Glass’s “Einstein on the Beach.”

headline: On the Odder End of the Space-Time Continuum
text: When “Einstein on the Beach” had its premiere in 1976 at the Metropolitan Opera House, it changed everything, on both sides of the footlights. It redefined what opera could be: forget about narrative, dramatic conflict, arias and conventional orchestration; this was a work about ideas, both quirky and elevated, explored in microscopic detail over five hours.

headline: Reliving the Day the Unsinkable Sank
text: AS the Titanic sailed toward its destiny on a Sunday afternoon a century ago this month, passengers in first class listened to the band play fox trots and waltzes as they lunched on egg à l’Argenteuil, prepared with asparagus.

headline: For Braun and the Brewers, a Warm Reception at Home, if Little Else
text: MILWAUKEE — Ryan Braun says he has something to prove, but he is not concerned about detractors who think he used a banned substance that led to a positive test for elevated levels of testosterone during the 2011 playoffs.

headline: Radical to Mundane, and to Radical Again
text: In the catalog foreword for “John Constable: Oil Sketches From the Victoria and Albert Museum,” an unnamed 19th-century commentator is quoted describing the landscape sketches of Constable as “Nature caught in the very act.” In the very act of what? That is the kind of remark that turns benign-looking clouds, trees and seascapes into ... well, something else. You wonder if you’re missing something.

headline: Pressed From All Sides, Toys ‘R’ Us Fights to Reinvent Itself
text: For nearly two years, Toys “R” Us has waited for the right moment to take itself public.

headline: From O.J. to Trayvon
text: The case of Trayvon Martin is producing another O.J. Simpson moment for America.

headline: The Glamour, and the Intrigue, of the Cocktail
text: Oyster Bay, N.Y.

headline: Skyscapes
text: In my last essay, about choosing precise nouns and adjectives, I challenged readers to write a distinct description of the sky. Many thanks to those of you who answered the call. We were given hundreds of skyscapes, in Paris; New York City; Vancouver, Canada; Perth, Australia; and Quepos, Costa Rica — as well as sentences describing the sky above tornado country and across the American Southwest.

headline: How to Expand the Voter Rolls
text: A country that should be encouraging more people to vote is still using an archaic voter registration system that creates barriers to getting a ballot. In 2008, 75 million eligible people did not vote in the presidential election, and 80 percent of them were not registered.

headline: Scandal Involving Petrino Goes Beyond X’s and O’s
text: Arkansas Coach Bobby Petrino is widely considered one of the brightest offensive minds in college football. He guided Louisville to the Orange Bowl during the 2006 season, and after a one-year stint as coach of the Atlanta Falcons in 2007, he came to Arkansas and turned the Razorbacks into a national power.

headline: Troubling Flaws in a Heart Device Shake Implant Makers
text: Last October, a high school football coach named Greg Jessee was standing on the sidelines watching his son play when he felt a jolt to his chest. The heart defibrillator implanted in him five years earlier was firing wildly. The next jolt made him double up. The one after that knocked him unconscious.

headline: Judicial Conduct Unbecoming
text: It does not take a law degree or special knowledge of judicial ethics to know that handing out courthouse jobs to favored friends and relatives is wrong.

headline: Celebrating the Day With Musical Variety
text: FOR all the joy associated with Easter, its concerts are sometimes less-than-joyful affairs, heavy on extended works that, for the uninitiated, can be demanding. But this year’s Easter concert at the Cathedral of St. Joseph in Hartford will favor brevity and material from a multiplicity of sources, broadening the appeal of the concert and, presumably, instilling in more people the spirit of the day.

headline: Sustainably Feeding a Changing World
text: One of the biggest challenges facing this planet isn’t simply feeding a growing population — perhaps as many as 10 billion by the year 2100. The challenge is feeding all those people as the climate changes in ways we can barely project. A new report called “Achieving Food Security in the Face of Climate Change” illustrates the complexity of the problem and makes clear that action must be taken soon to address it.

headline: From Brother to Brother, a Kidney, and a Life
text: When restaurant customers learned that the waiter they called Angel was in the hospital with kidney failure, they stuffed bills into a collection jar to help support his family. His brother offered something more precious: a healthy kidney to restore his life.

headline: Court Upends 9-Year Fight on Housing Mentally Ill
text: A federal appeals court, ruling on procedural grounds, struck down on Friday a judge’s order that New York State transfer thousands of mentally ill adults in New York City from institutional group homes into their own homes and apartments. In doing so, the court brought a nine-year legal battle to an abrupt end without resolving the underlying issues of how the state cares for such patients.

headline: Mainstay for Music, Trying Not to Leave
text: SET well back from the highway, a nondescript two-lane stretch in exurban Pawling, the Towne Crier has a modest, multihued exterior gussied up with faux-Southwestern frills. Inside, though, the club’s pedigree is readily apparent. On a Saturday night last month, a coterie of fans sang and swayed to the finely wrought tunes of the troubadour Steve Forbert. After the set Mr. Forbert found solitude, as he had dozens of times before, in a dressing room plastered with posters of the famous acts that had played the club — including one of the British rocker Ian Hunter, who had dropped in earlier for a plate of shrimp tostadas and some camaraderie.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 6, 2012

headline: A Populist’s Downfall Exposes Ideological Divisions in China’s Ruling Party
text: BEIJING — Some Chinese leaders clearly hope that this year will mark another milestone in China’s rise under authoritarian rule: the first time that a whole new slate of leaders is chosen largely by consensus among the political elite, not handpicked by a powerful strongman.

headline: At the Garden, Spending Passover With Springsteen
text: For those of the Jewish faith, the central question of Passover is familiar: Why is this night different from all other nights?

headline: Actor Rushes to Aid of Damsel in Pink Wig
text: WHEN a New Yorker stops a fellow wayfarer from wandering into traffic, he is lucky to earn a thank you.

headline: Tied for Lead, Couples Feels Young Again at Augusta
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — If the side-hill lies and Delphian greens of Augusta National Golf Club do not age a player overnight, the capricious winds that ventilate the course will. Patrick Cantlay, a sophomore at U.C.L.A., sounded weary beyond his 20 years Friday when he spoke about adding seven strokes to the score he posted in the first round.

headline: New York Economics, Inquisitions and Immigrants
text: Near the end of his new survey of the New York City economy over the last half-century, the business journalist Greg David offers some hope, as well as a dire warning. “Wall Street may save the city again,” he writes.

headline: A Win-Win Deal on Natural Gas
text: With the Republicans hammering away at higher gas prices, President Obama has gone out of his way in recent weeks to show that he is friendly to the idea of oil and gas exploration on federal lands. This is a sound part of any broad energy strategy as long as it balances energy needs with environmental protection. The administration has done a better job on this score than the Bush administration, which took a “drill now, drill everywhere” approach.

headline: Corrections: April 7
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Voters Speak: Yes to Bathrooms
text: THE bathrooms won.

headline: The Right Flames the Volt
text: It was Thursday morning and several dozen owners of the new Chevrolet Volt had gathered at a restaurant overlooking the East River. Across town, the New York International Auto Show was in full swing. The Volt, of course, is the innovative electric car from General Motors, and G.M. was using the occasion of the auto show to meet with Volt owners.

headline: In Successful Fight to Keep Job, Music Teacher Cited Double Standard by City
text: The New York City Education Department wanted to fire Michael Dalton, a music teacher in Washington Heights, after its investigators said that he had placed three third-grade boys on his lap in what they considered an inappropriate manner.

headline: Joe Avezzano, a Cowboys Coach for 3 Titles, Dies at 68
text: Joe Avezzano, who helped the Dallas Cowboys win their last three Super Bowl titles as the colorful and acclaimed coach of their kicking and kick-return teams, died on Thursday in Milan, where he was the coach of the Milano Seamen of the Italian Football League. He was 68.

headline: Provider of Up-to-the-Minute Info
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — A toughie for me, with those five 15-letter entries stretched across the grid, and I didn’t get any of them right off the bat. Maybe you did better.

headline: After Firing, It’s 2008 for Knicks
text: In a matter of hours on Friday, Isiah Thomas lost his job and Donnie Walsh began seeking a new one. These events were unrelated, but still intertwined — two dangling threads in the Knicks’ tangled universe.

headline: Mass, Egg Sandwich and Play Dates
text: Brian d’Arcy James, who played the misanthropic ogre Shrek on Broadway, is now Frank Houston, the long-suffering husband of an emotionally volatile writer (played by Debra Messing) on NBC’s new show “Smash.” Twice a Tony nominee, and a star of the play “Next to Normal,” Mr. James is delighted to have matinee-free weekends for the first time in years. Another plus: “Smash” is shot in the city, which he deems “a miracle.” He spends Sundays with his wife, Jennifer Prescott, an actress and green design consultant, and their daughter, Grace, 10. They share an Upper West Side apartment with a cat named Jam; the family also has a country house in Sherman, Conn.

headline: Oosthuizen Cold, Then Hot
text: Louis Oosthuizen was in the fifth group on the course, and when he arrived at the first tee he could have been forgiven for thinking he was back at St. Andrews, the site of his 2010 British Open victory. Fans were buying green stocking caps from the merchandise stores to ward off the chill. The sky was pewter and it was 53 degrees, but a raw wind made it feel 10 degrees colder.

headline: In Queens, Redefining ‘Mechanic’
text: IT is a men-only club, these auto-repair hawkers who battle for your business as you bump your way down the pothole-pocked streets of Willets Point in Corona, Queens.

headline: Mitt Romney’s Aide is Always Nearby
text: Garrett Jackson spends more time with the candidate than even Mr. Romney’s wife, Ann, does.

headline: Elan Steinberg Dies at 59; Led World Jewish Congress
text: Elan Steinberg, who brought what he called a new, “American style” assertiveness to the World Jewish Congress as its top executive, winning more than $1 billion from Swiss banks for Holocaust victims and challenging Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations secretary general, over his Nazi past, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 59.

headline: Giuseppi Logan’s Second Chance
text: ON a springlike morning in Tompkins Square Park, the old man with the battered saxophone blew a fractured chorus of “Over the Rainbow,” then held up a CD with his name and face on it.

headline: A Parish Without Borders
text: A LINE of priests, chanting choir members, and altar girls and boys, all dressed in red and white robes, streamed down Duffield Street in Downtown Brooklyn last weekend, leading the Palm Sunday street procession at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface.

headline: A Transplant Years in the Making
text: An illegal immigrant whose quest for a kidney was chronicled in The New York Times received one from his brother.

headline: Two Swings, Two Hits to Celebrate for Pena
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — It is not often that a ballplayer must choose between these two moments and decide which is bigger — a grand slam against C. C. Sabathia, or a game-ending hit against Mariano Rivera.

headline: Ruling on Bounty Appeals Will Be Signal to the Public
text: On Monday, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell will probably announce his decision on the discipline appeals by the New Orleans Saints. That leaves an entire weekend for the Gregg Williams audiotape to ring in the ears of football fans, an obscenity-laced, injury-detailing diatribe that has pulled back the curtain on a part of the football culture Goodell wants to eliminate.

headline: A Vision of a Grim Past and a Hopeful Future
text: On a bright morning last week, the East New York Community Health Center celebrated its gleaming expansion, something made possible largely by a $541,000 federal grant of the kind intended to flourish under the imperiled Affordable Care Act.

headline: Limits on Lobbyists as Hosts? Simply Unworkable, They Say
text: WASHINGTON — Tough new limits proposed on the way special interests could court executive branch officials have prompted a fierce counterattack from lobbyists who fear they will end a cherished Washington ritual: hosting federal workers at events like conferences, cocktail parties, galas and movie screenings.

headline: For Masters Dads, Balancing Divots and Diaper Duty
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — This is Bubba Watson’s fourth Masters, so his routine is well established. Every year he likes to arrive here on Saturday so he can play one practice round Sunday, without any fans (or many of the other players) around to bother him. Then he falls into the usual Monday-Tuesday-Wednesday preparation sequence before the tournament begins Thursday.

headline: Obama Embraces National Security as Campaign Issue
text: WASHINGTON — With a Republican opponent all but chosen and the general election campaign about to start, President Obama is preparing to emphasize an issue that few Democratic candidates have embraced in the past: national security, long the domain of the Republican Party.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: M.L.S. Discusses Arena at West Side’s Pier 40
text: Eager to find a home for a new team in New York, officials from Major League Soccer met officials from the Hudson River Park Trust on Thursday to discuss a potential stadium on Pier 40 on the West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Alabama May Revise New Policies on Migrants
text: ATLANTA — Nearly a year after enacting an immigration law that supporters describe as the toughest in the country, Alabama is considering major revisions to its immigration policies.

headline: Mixed Reviews on Program for Immigrants With Records
text: Senior Obama administration officials created major confusion for state and local authorities by providing inconsistent information about a high-profile federal program to identify illegal immigrants who committed crimes, according to a stinging report published Friday by the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Greek Statistician Under Scrutiny for Budget Estimates Before Euro Crisis
text: ATHENS — Andreas Georgiou was not particularly alarmed when he was asked to testify in a judicial investigation into one of the most contentious issues in Greece today: whether the 2009 budget deficit — which precipitated not only Greece’s crash but the broader euro zone crisis — had been badly overstated.

headline: Amateur Cantlay Survives Round Two
text: After following his opening-round 71 with a six-over-par 78, Patrick Cantlay talked about his first Masters experience in the past tense. “Just the whole experience I’ll remember, for sure, nothing in particular,” he said. “Staying in the Crow’s Nest was fun.”

headline: DiPietro, an Invisible Islander, Determined to Play On
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Far away from a flock of fans collecting autographs before the Islanders’ last home game of the season on Thursday, a bearded man wearing a flat cap and a backpack on his shoulder walked out a side entrance at Nassau Coliseum, alone.

headline: Jet Crashes Into Virginia Beach Apartment Complex
text: Clouds of ominous black smoke were sent billowing into the air over Virginia Beach, Va., after a Navy fighter jet fell from the sky and crashed into an apartment complex on Friday afternoon. At least seven people were injured, officials said, but as of 11:00 p.m., no fatalities had been reported.

headline: Storm Continues After German Writer’s Poem Against Israel
text: BERLIN — Günter Grass, Germany’s most famous living writer, tried Friday to quell the growing controversy over a poem critical of Israel that he published this week, saying that he did not mean to attack the country wholesale but only the policies of the current government.

headline: As Nuclear Talks Near, Iran Softens Criticism of Turkey
text: Iran’s leaders on Friday backpedaled from their recent criticism of Turkey, the host of coming talks on the disputed Iranian nuclear program, in a possible indication of their concern about alienating the Turks at a time when Iran is facing increased isolation.

headline: Colt’s Preparation for Kentucky Derby Includes Plenty of Rest
text: When Alpha won the Withers Stakes on Feb. 4 at Aqueduct, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin had a number of options, all of them enticing. He had a hot horse, and there was a lot of money on the table in a number of rich Kentucky Derby prep races like the $400,000 Gotham and the $400,000 Fountain of Youth. Just when it seemed it was time to strike, McLaughlin sat back.

headline: Once-Shunned Washington Legislator Is Embraced in Budget Vote
text: SEATTLE — State Senator Pam Roach has a volatile temper and a vital vote.

headline: Defying an Image With a Tilt to the Left
text: PETAH TIKVAH, Israel

headline: The Early Word: National Security
text: Today’s Times

headline: Report by the Inspector General on Secure Communities
text: An audit of and recommendations for the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Secure Communities program.

headline: Dodgers Look to Turn Over Team by End of Month
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers, who filed for bankruptcy last June, filed documents Friday looking to get out for good by the end of the month. But almost no specifics are revealed in the paperwork about the purchase of the team and Dodger Stadium for $2 billion by a group led by Magic Johnson but financed primarily by Guggenheim Partners, a private financial services firm.

headline: When Twosome Plays Through, Nobody Grumbles
text: While a fast group of golfers playing through a slower group is a regular occurrence on public courses, it is unusual — if not downright rare — to see it take place in a professional event.

headline: Architecture’s Ugly Ducklings May Not Get Time to Be Swans
text: GOSHEN, N.Y. — As Modernist buildings reach middle age, many of the stark structures that once represented the architectural vanguard are showing signs of wear, setting off debates around the country between preservationists, who see them as historic landmarks, and the many people who just see them as eyesores.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,912 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: A Boy or Girl? Cut the Cake
text: THE house was filled with balloons and confetti, the chips and artichoke spinach dip were ready, and the guests, about 25 of them, were decked out in team colors, ready to cheer. Minutes before the party kicked off, they eagerly cast votes on the outcome.

headline: Jewelers in India End 21-Day Strike
text: Jewelers in India, “the biggest bullion buyer,” suspended a nationwide strike Friday, after the government assured them that “it would consider their concerns about a tax on non-branded gold ornaments,” Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A grenade attack was carried out by suspected militants on Thursday night on the road leading up to the Srinagar airport, Kashmir Live reported. The police headquarters and the state vigilance organization are located close to the area that was targeted, but no casualties were reported, the newspaper said.

headline: In Mourning, Malawi Swears In a New President
text: JOHANNESBURG — Malawi’s vice president, Joyce Banda, was sworn in as president on Saturday, ending a tense 36 hours of speculation and confusion about the future of one of central Africa’s most enduring democracies after the death of President Bingu wa Mutharika on Thursday.

headline: Making Crime Pay
text: LARRY LEVINE, heavyset and bald, runs a thriving business out of a gated apartment complex in Ventura County, Calif., a setting that’s not at all bad for a home office considering some of the prison cells he’s lived in. But as he drops into his plush beige and white sectional couch to talk business, something is nagging at him.

headline: Chris Polk, Fifth-Ranked Running Back in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis that is available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping the Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: India’s Tax Plan Troubles Foreign Investors
text: “Just two months ago, worried about their slowing economy, Indian officials were promising to promote policies to make the country more hospitable to foreign investment,” Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times. “Instead, the government has done the opposite — proposed a budget festooned with new taxes that would make it more difficult and expensive for outsiders to invest here.”

headline: In Close French Election, Anniversaries on Path to Algerian Independence a Minefield
text: LONDON — Fifty years after the French people voted overwhelming to endorse independence for Algeria, the legacy of a traumatic eight-year colonial war continues to resonate on both sides of the Mediterranean.

headline: One Weekend Left to Argue the Ethics of Meat Eating
text: This is it, your last chance to enter The Ethicist’s essay contest. The subject — if you’ve managed to duck our multiplatform P.R. assault so far — is why eating meat is ethical. To date, vegetarians and vegans have made many powerful arguments about why it’s not ethical to eat our fellow members of the animal kingdom. Meat eaters, on the other hand, have said a lot about why meat is delicious and why it’s their right to eat it, but they have done little to articulate the ethics of their position.

headline: Rare for Northwestern: A Five-Star Transfer
text: EVANSTON, Ill. – It was been a week of ups and downs for Kyle Prater.

headline: Amid Highs and Lows, Bryant Stays Enigmatic
text: LOS ANGELES — At 22, Kobe Bryant, who had won an N.B.A. title and had started in three All-Star Games, leaving an entire career ahead of him to realize even dreams as heady as his, said of marrying, “I do everything young.”

headline: Japan’s New Ace? The Search Is On
text: NAGO, Japan — On the side of the Nippon Ham Fighters’ spring training bullpen reserved for fan viewing, onlookers clutching cellphones, video cameras and even children jockeyed to capture a glimpse of the pitcher who had started throwing. The center of attention was not Yu Darvish this time, for he had signed a six-year contract with the Texas Rangers.

headline: On Ryan Apologists
text: In my next life I want to be a conservative policy scammer. Think of how much nicer it would be. Instead of constantly being accused of having evil motives, I’d be presumed to have noble intentions no matter how much the actual content of my policy proposals was at odds with such claims. Instead of being accused of saying bad things I never said, I’d be given credit for supporting good things I’ve never supported. Life would be great!

headline: As Gold Medalist Found Out, More Coverage Is Mixed Blessing for Sailing
text: Ben Ainslie of Britain is on the cusp of becoming among the most decorated Olympic sailors ever. A victory in his Finn dinghy on his home waters of Weymouth at this summer’s Olympics would give him four consecutive gold medals, tying the sailing record of Paul Elvstrom of Denmark. So successful was Ainslie that there was speculation he could lead the British delegation at the opening ceremony in London.

headline: Variety: A Talkative Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Some people just aren’t talkers. There are people who express themselves better through the visual arts, and the author of today’s quote speaks quite eloquently about just such an artist.

headline: Pondering Curses at Chavez Ravine
text: Can a baseball curse have a delayed reaction, like a pharmaceutical capsule that kicks in hours (or decades) later?

headline: China Buys Inroads in the Caribbean, Catching U.S. Notice
text: NASSAU, the Bahamas — A brand new $35 million stadium opened here in the Bahamas a few weeks ago, a gift from the Chinese government.

headline: Reactions and Overreactions
text: Hmm. I see that some people are accusing me of overreacting to one bad month of job news. Um, no. What has actually been happening is that conventional wisdom overreacted to four months of good(ish) news, and the March numbers were a useful corrective.

headline: For Players at Augusta National, the Practice Range Is Perfect
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The most important place for players in the Masters at Augusta National Golf Club has not been Amen Corner and may not be the back nine on Sunday. Rather, it has been a wide-open field behind the media center that fans stream past every day as they enter from the parking lots.

headline: Rangers Prefer to Keep Goals Unstated
text: The Rangers play their season finale on Saturday, but lost in all the ruckus over Coach John Tortorella’s tirade against the Penguins organization and its “two whining superstars” is a matter of somewhat greater dignity: the Presidents’ Trophy.

headline: Packing Up, Moving On and Selling the Town
text: DENVER — For years, Don Sammons was the biggest shot in Buford. He owned everything. The gas station, the trading post, the cafe. Needed anything while passing through town? Mr. Sammons was the man to talk to.

headline: Rivera Shrugs Off Loss in Season Opener
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. – If Mariano Rivera has excelled at anything in his career besides saving a record number of games, it is handling the rare blown save. Obviously, those things are closely related. Rivera’s ability to deal with that unexpected failure has enabled him to rebound and succeed time and time again.

headline: Fang Lizhi, Chinese Physicist and Seminal Dissident, Dies at 76
text: BEIJING — Fang Lizhi, whose advocacy of economic and democratic freedoms shaped China’s brief era of student dissent that ended with the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and his exile, died on Friday in Tucson, Ariz., his son, Fang Ke, said Saturday.

headline: Numberplay: Logic Postponed
text: Life imitates Art. This Numberplay blog post was postponed and the day of its actual appearance left open-ended. This was not intentional, but it so resembles a classic logical paradox on postponement, that I can’t resist making that the subject of this post.

headline: Long Bench Has Served Bulls Well
text: It has been said that if you cut off the head, the body will die. At this point, most Eastern Conference teams are probably wondering just what part of the Chicago Bulls qualifies as the head.

headline: Looking for Four Good Rounds in a Row
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At 5 feet 10 inches and 180 pounds, Jason Dufner doesn’t look like a sprinter. And yet he is golf’s equivalent of a runner who goes out fast and hangs on for dear life. On the PGA Tour, Dufner ranks in the top 30 in scoring average in the first and second rounds, and outside the top 75 in the third and fourth.

headline: China Said to Detain Returning Tibetan Pilgrims
text: DHARAMSALA, India — Hundreds of Tibetans who attended an important Buddhist ceremony in January in India have been detained without charge by Chinese security officers on their return to Tibet, according to family members and friends living in exile in India, international human rights groups and officials with the Tibetan exile government.

headline: Lundqvist Focused on the Cup
text: Less than two hours before they were to play the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers could not find Henrik Lundqvist. They called his cellphone, but it had been turned off. They called his wife, Therese, who said he had left their Midtown apartment.

headline: Trying to Find a Measure for How Well Colleges Do
text: How well does a college teach, and what do its students learn? Rankings based on the credentials of entering freshmen are not hard to find, but how can students, parents and policy makers assess how well a college builds on that foundation?

headline: Hamas Executes 3 Palestinians in Gaza
text: GAZA — The Islamic group Hamas that controls Gaza executed three Palestinians on Saturday, one who was convicted of collaborating with Israel and two others who had been found guilty of murder, according to a statement from the Hamas Interior Ministry.

headline: China Flexes Its Economic Prowess in the Caribbean
text: China’s economic might has rolled up to America’s doorstep in the Caribbean, with loans from state banks, investments by companies and outright gifts from the government in the form of stadiums, roads, official buildings, ports and resorts.

headline: The Autism Wars
text: THE report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that one in 88 American children have an autism spectrum disorder has stoked a debate about why the condition’s prevalence continues to rise. The C.D.C. said it was possible that the increase could be entirely attributed to better detection by teachers and doctors, while holding out the possibility of unknown environmental factors.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist Rises to the Top
text: Henrik Lundqvist was selected by the Rangers with the 205th pick in the 2000 draft. But he has led the Rangers to the playoffs in six of his seven seasons.

headline: Rural District Is Struggling to Make Improvements
text: PREMONT — The hallways at this rural town’s only high school were deserted on a Tuesday afternoon in January, much to Enrique Ruiz’s delight. It meant everyone who had shown up for school that day was in class — a sight that Mr. Ruiz, the school’s principal, has learned not to take for granted.

headline: Boston College Internalizes a SEAL’s Message
text: Slap Shot will feature reports from writers at the colleges and universities playing in the N.C.A.A. Frozen Four tournament this week.

headline: A Japanese Prodigy Makes an Impression
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — One amateur, 54-year-old Randal Lewis, drew attention last week for being, it is believed, the oldest first-time participant in Masters history. Another amateur, Patrick Cantlay, took a piece of the spotlight because he is the world’s top-ranked amateur and has inspired raves from veteran players.

headline: Wary of Heights (and the Future)
text: SEEING is supposed to be believing, but a second consecutive quarter of eye-popping gains for stocks has left many investors still unconvinced that the long-term trend is up.

headline: On Lenten Fridays in New Orleans, the Catfish Are Making the Sacrifices
text: NEW ORLEANS — New Orleans is the land of Antoine’s and Galatoire’s, of trout amandine and oysters Rockefeller, of rémoulades and beurre blanc — a bastion of Old World fine dining in the United States.

headline: Here Come the Zombies, but Not the Cash
text: ZOMBIES chased me. It happened during a recent morning run, and it was great. It gave me new insights into making money and how — as always — I’m doing it wrong.

headline: Rebels Who Changed a Sport Reunite
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In a farmhouse in the village of Durham Lead outside Melbourne, Australia, a single American dollar bill is framed and proudly displayed. Judy Tegart Dalton has kept that dollar for nearly 42 years, one small memento in the great battle for women’s rights.

headline: In Target-Date Funds, a Hodgepodge of Styles
text: CHOOSING among the often-confusing lineup of mutual funds offered in 401(k) retirement accounts can be an unwelcome chore. Increasingly, employees have been embracing a simpler choice: all-in-one mutual funds known as target-date retirement funds, or T.D.F.’s.

headline: Balancing Act Helps Giants Spread Wealth
text: One reason the San Francisco Giants sell out every game, said their chief executive, Larry Baer, is that fans relate to the different personalities on the roster. The eccentric ones stand out most: Brian Wilson is the raging, bearded closer; Pablo Sandoval is the jovial panda of a third baseman; Tim Lincecum is the little, long-haired ace.

headline: Another Rally, but a New Cast of Characters
text: THE strong first quarter for equity mutual funds — up 12 percent — is reminiscent of their hot start last year, just before stocks ran headlong into a major pullback in the spring and summer.

headline: Latin American Markets Aim for a New Decade of Gains
text: STOCK markets in much of the world may have suffered a lost decade, but there was much to gain by investing in Latin America.

headline: Emerging-Market Bonds Quench a Yield Thirst
text: MUTUAL funds investing in emerging-market bonds have lately captured a frothy river of new customer cash.

headline: Finding Big Profits Along the Roads Less Traveled
text: MANAGERS of three of the better-performing mutual funds in the first quarter do not mind zigging while others zag. The captains of the Ivy Cundill Global Value fund and the John Hancock Global Opportunities fund seek stocks that others are shunning, while the steward at Fidelity Convertible Securities hangs onto investments far longer than his peers.

headline: Ballpark Upbringing Creates Lifelong Fan
text: People are forever asking me, “Are you a baseball fan?”

headline: Two Ways to Invest: Think Hard, or Hardly at All
text: WHICH kind of investor are you? (This is a question about style, not proficiency, by the way.)

headline: Hockey, at Any Age
text: The Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley cup in 2010 and suddenly the city had hockey fever. Even adult novices started taking classes to learn to play the fast sport.

headline: In Chicago, the Boys (and Girls) of Winter
text: CHICAGO — So much for shuffleboard, bridge and Ping-Pong.

headline: Mickelson Soars into Contention but Hanson Leads
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The stately oak between the clubhouse and the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club, planted in the 1850s, has survived strong winds, savage storms and searing sun, making it the perfect symbol for success at the Masters.

headline: Honoring Sarajevo’s Victims and Its Survivors
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The power of a simple idea packed the emotional punch this weekend in Sarajevo, 20 years after war erupted in Bosnia-Herzegovina.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: As Wallets Reopen, Consumer Stocks Look More Tempting
text: LAST fall, amid widespread fears that the economy would fall back into recession, shares of hotels, retailers and other stocks that wax and wane with the consumer cycle sold off sharply.

headline: Pro’s Perspective: The Fun of Moving Day
text: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 P.G.A. Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters, but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia, in his third season on the Champions Tour, will provide a daily Masters blog, as well as in-round analysis, for The New York Times.

headline: New Rules Seek to Prevent Invasive Stowaways
text: Nearly a quarter-century has passed since an oceangoing ship from Europe docked somewhere in the Great Lakes and discharged ballast water carrying tiny but tenacious zebra mussel larvae from Europe.

headline: Thomas Kinkade, Artist to Mass Market, Dies at 54
text: Thomas Kinkade, the prolific painter of bucolic and idealized scenes who estimated that his mass-produced works hung in one out of 20 American homes, died on Friday at his home in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 54.

headline: Affectionate Scorn for ’62 Mets
text: Jimmy Breslin assessed the Mets one recent afternoon, dressed in blue pajamas, red-and-green robe and black slippers.

headline: Saving Lives in a Time of Cholera
text: Cholera is on the rise around the world. Last year, according to Unicef, West and Central Africa had “one of the worst ever” cholera outbreaks. An outbreak in Haiti sickened 1 in 20 Haitians and killed more than 7,000 people. The World Health Organization estimates that there are between three million and five million cases of cholera each year, and between 100,000 and 120,000 deaths. New and more virulent strains are emerging in Asia and Africa, and the W.H.O. says that global warming creates even more hospitable conditions for the disease.

headline: 30 Seconds: Talking Pitching, but Not Looking to Coach It
text: David Cone pitched for six major league teams from 1986 to 2003, posting a 194-126 record, with a 3.46 earned run average and 2,668 strikeouts.

headline: A Man. A Woman. Just Friends?
text: CAN men and women be friends? We have been asking ourselves that question for a long time, and the answer is usually no. The movie “When Harry Met Sally...” provides the locus classicus. The problem, Harry famously explains, is that “the sex part always gets in the way.” Heterosexual people of the opposite sex may claim to be just friends, the message goes, but count on it — wink, wink, nudge, nudge — something more’s going on. Popular culture enforces the notion relentlessly. In movie after movie, show after show, the narrative arc is the same. What starts as friendship (Ross and Rachel, Monica and Chandler) ends up in bed.

headline: Teen Essay Contest on Bullying
text: Earlier this year I reported on Lady Gaga’s campaign against bullying, and learned that learned that increasingly the Department of Education sees bullying as a serious problem. So I’d like to consult the real experts — American teenagers – by holding an essay contest for young adults aged 14 through 19 about bullying.

headline: Accentuating the Positive to Angry Customers
text: Q. You receive an angry call or visit from an irate customer. How should you respond?

headline: High in Chilean Desert, a Huge Astronomy Project
text: In one of the most remote spots on earth, looking for clues to the origins of the universe.

headline: At the End of the Earth, Seeking Clues to the Universe
text: LLANO DE CHAJNANTOR, Chile — Trucks stall on the road to this plateau 16,597 feet up in the Atacama Desert, where scientists are installing one of the world’s largest ground-based astronomical projects. Heads ache. Noses bleed. Dizziness overcomes the researchers toiling in the shadow of the Licancabur volcano.

headline: The Army as a Cornerstone
text: MY early years growing up in Allentown, Pa., gave no hint that I would have a 32-year career in the Army. I came from a middle-class family, played trumpet in the high school band, ran track and joined the football team. I had a newspaper route, and in the summer I washed dishes at a country club.

headline: 135 Missing as Avalanche Hits Pakistan Base
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The military faced a looming disaster on Saturday after an avalanche crashed through a remote mountain base containing 135 people, setting off a high-altitude rescue scramble that after 18 hours had yielded no survivors.

headline: Democratize Wall Street, for Social Good
text: MANY finance students and members of the Occupy Wall Street movement have a great deal in common: a deep interest in democratizing Wall Street.

headline: Penny Wise, or 2.4 Cents Foolish?
text: THE news from north of the border is both trivial and unsettling: they won’t be making shiny new pennies in Canada anymore.

headline: An F.D.A. for Finance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fact or Fiction
text: To the Editor:

headline: To Stop Cellphone Cramming, Don’t Let It Start
text: THE Haggler’s last column apparently caused a lot of readers to take a close look at their cellphone bills, and many made a disturbing discovery: they had been crammed.

headline: Malaysian Expatriates Seek Overseas Voting Rights
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Nurul Syaheedah Jes Izman, 27, a graduate of New York University, lives in New Jersey and works on Wall Street as a financial analyst. Though she has spent her college years and all of her working life in the United States, she closely follows political developments in her native Malaysia, reading Malaysian news Web sites every day and talking with friends and family back home about the issues.

headline: Taking a Chance on Love, and Algorithms
text: THE invitation from Yoke.me, a new online dating start-up, seemed innocuous enough. It suggested that I meet some of the single pals of one of my friends.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Changing Our Car Culture
text: Readers debate how best to reduce our use of cars and gas.

headline: Paul Clement
text: Paul Clement is a former United States solicitor general and current partner with the Washington law firm Bancroft P.L.L.C. He recently received widespread praise even from opponents for his nimble oral arguments before the Supreme Court against the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act, a law that if left intact would extend health care coverage to more than 30 million uninsured Americans.

headline: The Non-Joie of Parenting
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

headline: America’s Place in the New World
text: Washington

headline: Hope for the Blue Jays This Season
text: Over time, a player who struggles to reach base does not help his team. Too many years with a .282 on-base percentage, as Toronto Blue Jays catcher J. P. Arencibia posted as a rookie last season, and the player will not last long.

headline: What 23 Years of E-Mail May Say About You
text: MOST of us accumulate huge amounts of data in our lives — including e-mails, telephone calls and spikes of writing activity, as measured by daily keystrokes.

headline: Cultural Liberalism Is Not Enough
text: As White House aides and Congressional leaders flood the media with dueling leaks about just how far President Obama was willing to go last summer to meet the budget-cutting demands of House Speaker John A. Boehner, many liberals have reacted with shock and horror at how much of their historic achievement the president appears to have been ready to bargain away. If a Democratic president could consider cutting America’s shredded safety net further when unemployment remained stiffly high and the country was undergoing an explosion of inequality, was the “liberal moment” of American politics finally over?

headline: Wright and Duda Power Mets Past Braves
text: Last season, a ball like the one Lucas Duda, the Mets’ fledgling slugger, pummeled during the fourth inning of Saturday’s game at Citi Field would have bounced cruelly off the center-field wall.

headline: Monetary Mandate Mischief
text: One of the remarkable things about the ongoing economic crisis is the way so many people have responded to events by adopting doctrines that would magnify our problems. The woes of Spain and Ireland demonstrate that balanced budgets and low debt in good times offer no protection against crisis, so European leaders make tougher fiscal rules the core of their agenda. The broader euro crisis demonstrates the downside of fixed exchange rates and inflexible monetary policy, so the right doubles down on the gold standard. The financial meltdown demonstrates the need for effective bank regulation; the right demands even less government intervention.

headline: The Phones Are Out, but the Robot Is In
text: This interview with Phil Libin, chief executive of Evernote, a provider of note-taking and archiving technology, based in Mountain View, Calif., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Passenger’s Lot Then . . . And Now
text: The Titanic may have been grand, but today’s cruise ships offer a great deal more.

headline: Crossing the Ocean, 1912 vs. 2012
text: THE 100th anniversary of the Titanic tragedy is being widely observed on both sides of the Atlantic, at museum openings, special exhibits and lectures, theatrical performances, concerts, readings and walking and graveyard tours. Guests at some events are invited to dress in fashions of the era, and Titanic-themed cocktails and re-creations of the elaborate first-class meal from the storied liner’s last dinner will be served. Two Titanic Memorial Cruises to the site of the sinking are planned, and the ships are scheduled to be there on the anniversary, April 15.

headline: At Speed on the Breakneck Ocean
text: The best time to check in on the Volvo Ocean Race is when you’re feeling warm and comfortable. Then you can really appreciate the thrill and high-speed misery — howling winds, topographical waves sweeping the decks, and an unceasing effort to keep the sailboats from flying apart.

headline: That Campaign Promise About Campaigning
text: As a candidate for the White House, President Obama left no doubt about his determination to reform the Federal Election Commission, widely seen as dysfunctional in its role as the referee of campaign politics. “What the F.E.C. needs most is strong, impartial leadership that will promote integrity in our election system,” Mr. Obama said in reply to a voter questionnaire in 2007.

headline: Still Crawling Out of a Very Deep Hole
text: The employment report for March, released Friday, was a big disappointment. After three straight months of job gains above 200,000, only 120,000 new jobs were added last month.

headline: Disclosure to Student Borrowers
text: The federal government must do a lot more to protect college students and their families from falling into crippling debt. At the very top of that list is improving oversight of private student lenders. Too often, these lenders rush families into taking on risky, high-priced loans — even when students are eligible for safer, more affordable federal loans. Colleges must also be pressed to do a lot more to fully inform and protect their students. They often fail to explain the costs of loans and the dangers of choosing the wrong ones. Some colleges actively harm their students by packaging high-cost loans with their student-aid offers, to make the school appear more affordable than it really is.

headline: Violence Intensifies in Syria as a Planned Truce Nears
text: ISTANBUL — Violence rocked a wide portion of Syria on Saturday, with activists saying that about 100 people had been killed just days before a cease-fire that calls on the government to withdraw its heavy weaponry from cities and towns is to take effect.

headline: The Road We Need Not Have Traveled
text: The Pentagon’s prosecutors formally charged Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men last week with war crimes for planning and carrying out the murder of 2,976 people on Sept. 11, 2001, and referred their case to a constitutionally flawed military tribunal that will be convened at the Guantánamo Bay detention camp, a global symbol of human rights abuses.

headline: Learning to Respect Religion
text: A FEW years ago, God seemed caught in a devil of a fight.

headline: The Other Arab Spring
text: ISN’T it interesting that the Arab awakening began in Tunisia with a fruit vendor who was harassed by police for not having a permit to sell food — just at the moment when world food prices hit record highs? And that it began in Syria with farmers in the southern village of Dara’a, who were demanding the right to buy and sell land near the border, without having to get permission from corrupt security officials? And that it was spurred on in Yemen — the first country in the world expected to run out of water — by a list of grievances against an incompetent government, among the biggest of which was that top officials were digging water wells in their own backyards at a time when the government was supposed to be preventing such water wildcatting? As Abdelsalam Razzaz, the minister of water in Yemen’s new government, told Reuters last week: “The officials themselves have traditionally been the most aggressive well diggers. Nearly every minister had a well dug in his house.”

headline: Divided by God
text: IN American religious history, Nov. 8, 1960, is generally regarded as the date when the presidency ceased to be the exclusive property of Protestants. But for decades afterward, the election of the Catholic John F. Kennedy looked more like a temporary aberration.

headline: What Would Jesus Do at the Masters?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In Executive Pay, a Rich Game of Thrones
text: IS any C.E.O. worth $1 million a day?

headline: 200 Slices of Wealth
text: Although the growth in executive compensation slowed last year, the pay numbers are still eye-popping.

headline: When Shareholders Make Their Voices Heard
text: IN spring, a shareholder’s fancy turns to thoughts of pay.

headline: Junta in Mali to Step Down
text: JOHANNESBURG — Political leaders in Mali on Saturday welcomed an accord signed by the junta that seized power last month in which it agreed to step down in “the hours and days ahead” and hand power to the president of the National Assembly.

headline: Spam Invades a Last Refuge, the Cellphone
text: Text message spam has started waking Bob Dunnell in the middle of the night, promising cheap mortgages, credit cards and drugs. Some messages offer gift cards to, say, Walmart, if he clicks on a Web site and enters his Social Security number.

headline: Mauricio Lasansky, Master Printmaker, Dies at 97
text: Mauricio Lasansky, an Argentine-born master printmaker who was equally well known for a series of drawings depicting the horrors of Nazism, died on Monday at his home in Iowa City. He was 97.

headline: Edmund L. Epstein, Scholar Who Saved ‘Lord of the Flies,’ Dies at 80
text: Edmund L. Epstein, a literary scholar who, as a book editor in the late 1950s, was so taken by a well-reviewed but not especially popular first novel by a largely unknown British writer that he decided to reprint it in paperback, thus enabling the extravagant American success of “Lord of the Flies” and its author, the future Nobel Prize winner William Golding, died on April 1 in Melville, on Long Island. He was 80.

headline: Verlander Continues to Seek Perfection
text: Here is a sign of how dominant Detroit’s Justin Verlander was last season: throwing only one no-hitter left him disappointed.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail in Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

headline: In-Nuendos
