text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but if I’m going to spend the time doing a large Sunday puzzle, I like one that makes me think. Not too hard, mind you; just enough so that I feel it’s been worth my time. Daniel A. Finan offers us just such a puzzle today. The puzzle itself is fairly easy, but the theme, with its clues hinting at the entries, with the circled letters further hinting at the answers, is a brain bender suitable for a relaxing holiday Sunday.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 8
text: Religion and politics have been frequent topics during the battle over President Obama’s health care law and the Republican presidential campaign. Several Sunday news shows, marking Easter and Passover, will feature discussions of the spiritual state of the nation.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail in Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.  Go to the slide show.

headline: Gemologist Earns Spot in Kentucky Derby With Win in Wood Memorial
text: They say good stallions stamp their foals, and on Saturday, Gemologist flashed the same resolve that once characterized his sire Tiznow in consecutive victories in the Breeders’ Cup Classic in 2000 and 2001. Undefeated but not seriously tested in four previous starts, Gemologist emerged as one of the leading Kentucky Derby contenders after he resolutely turned back Alpha down the stretch of the Grade I $1 million Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.

headline: Berkeley Group Digs In to Challenge of Making Sense of All That Data
text: It comes in “torrents” and “floods” and threatens to “engulf” everything that stands in its path.

headline: Tracy Morgan, the Newest Knick
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — From coaching changes to injured star players to the incomparable rise of an unheralded phenomenon, attention and pressure have never strayed from the Knicks this season, a reality solidified by a schedule that allows little time away from the limelight. On Saturday afternoon, that pressure was lifted for a few minutes when the comedian Tracy Morgan attended practice. Morgan, the co-star of NBC’s “30 Rock,” was filming a segment for “Access Hollywood.” He briefly played Carmelo Anthony one on one and talked faux strategy with Coach Mike Woodson.

headline: Little Farm
text: When you round a bend in Tilden Nature Area in Berkeley, the sound of bleating day-old lambs is a definite clue that you have left the city. You can smell the manure in the crisp morning air, as well as a whiff of hay. The Little Farm, which opened in 1955, decades before the current homesteading explosion, was built to teach urban children about food production. Most days, the swarms of youngsters now seem more interested in feeding the animals than in the origin of their meals.

headline: A Fresh Discovery, Three Decades in the Making
text: The novelist Joe R. Lansdale, of Nacogdoches, has never been one of those authors determined to cultivate a reputation as a “serious” artist. He is much too busy writing: crime fiction and sci-fi fantasy, pulp tributes and young adult novels, comic books and horror stories.

headline: Running for Congress Against Octogenarians
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: U.S. Defines Its Demands for New Round of Talks With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and its European allies plan to open new negotiations with Iran by demanding the immediate closing and ultimate dismantling of a recently completed nuclear facility deep under a mountain, according to American and European diplomats.

headline: As Large Companies Opt Out, Concerns Grow for Workers’ Compensation System
text: When Walmart, one of Texas’ largest private employers, dropped out of the state’s workers’ compensation system in March, it was a heavy blow to advocates of the system, who have watched more large companies offer private —  and in many cases, less generous —  injury benefits.

headline: Tuna Again? In Fault-Finding England, It’s a Cause for Divorce
text: LONDON — In her 30-odd years as a divorce lawyer, Vanessa Lloyd Platt has heard it all. The woman who sued for divorce because her husband insisted she dress in a Klingon costume and speak to him in Klingon. The man who declared that his wife had maliciously and repeatedly served him his least favorite dish, tuna casserole.

headline: Meager Participation Hobbles Drug Oversight
text: Byung Sik Yuh, the owner of Nichols Hill pharmacy in Oakland, filled more than 5,000 online prescriptions for addictive painkillers before the California State Board of Pharmacy moved last year to revoke his license. The patients who picked up the prescriptions at Mr. Yuh’s pharmacy had never met their doctors, nor had physical examinations. They filled out a brief online survey and paid an anonymous doctor to write prescriptions over the Internet.

headline: The Short-Time Amateur
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As far as final rounds as an amateur go, Kelly Kraft could certainly do worse: The 23-year-old U.S. Amateur champion will play Augusta National in the fourth round of the Masters on Sunday before officially beginning his professional career on Monday.

headline: Hopeful Signs for a Homegrown Mets Roster
text: More and more these days, the Mets are feeling made in New York.

headline: God Makes a Comeback
text: My Sunday column is about what seems a new intellectual wave — a measured respect for religion even among some atheists and agnostics. As I note in the column, the trend a few years ago was for best-sellers that denounced God and faith in the most caustic terms, but now — just in time for Easter and Passover — we have a series of books that don’t exactly buy into God, but are still admiring of aspects of religion. I’m happy with this trend, as a step toward civility and a bridge over the “God Gulf” — but what’s your take? Read the column and post your thoughts, please.

headline: Lundqvist Is Also a Sure Thing During the Awards Season
text: The end of the N.H.L. regular season on Saturday also marked the time when voters started casting their ballots for the league’s major awards. Here are the favorites.

headline: Flustered Woods Loses Temper and More Ground
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods has heard crowds roar on the back nine at Augusta National for his entire professional life. Birdies at the 11th hole. Eagles on 13 or 15. Glorious championship walks up No. 18, the whistles from the fans cutting through the Sunday evening gloaming.

headline: Donald Recalls the Awful Moment
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Luke Donald knows the exact moment he wrote off his chances of winning the Masters: When his second shot at the par-5 13th looked to have plenty of carry but hit the top edge of the bank in front of the green and rolled back into the water.

headline: After Trying Stretch, Hughes Is Eager to Get Started on Fresh Season
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The one good thing Phil Hughes thinks about last season is that it is over. It was a frustrating campaign for Hughes that included a stint on the disabled list from April 15 until July 6 with inflammation of his right shoulder.

headline: Edward and the Elephant
text: Among the 67,000 sore, weary, traumatized Federal soldiers in Ulysses S. Grant’s army that followed the Confederate retreat back toward Corinth, Miss., after the battle of Shiloh was my great-great grandfather, Pvt. Edward D. Willis.

headline: Welfare Limits Left Poor Adrift as Recession Hit
text: PHOENIX — Perhaps no law in the past generation has drawn more praise than the drive to “end welfare as we know it,” which joined the late-’90s economic boom to send caseloads plunging, employment rates rising and officials of both parties hailing the virtues of tough love.

headline: Rangers, With Eye on Top Spot in League, Fall Flat at the Finish Line
text: The Rangers came into Madison Square Garden for their season finale Saturday with a full lineup, hoping to clinch the Presidents’ Trophy as the N.H.L.’s No. 1 team and enter the playoffs on a high note.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 7, 2012

headline: The Puzzle of Measuring Poverty
text: Despite four years of economic distress, the welfare rolls have barely budged, as my article this weekend shows. Many researchers see evidence of growing destitution, but the resources of the very poor have become increasingly hard to measure. Different yardsticks show diverging trends.

headline: It Looked Good on Paper
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The third-round pairing of Sergio García and Rory McIlroy, the once and current European prodigies, looked great on paper. Once they teed off, in the third-to-last group, it proved hard to watch.

headline: Leading From Behind
text: As the Rangers’ last man between opposing players’ shots and the back net, Henrik Lundqvist has led the team to the playoffs with stellar goaltending.

headline: On TV, Bored Ex-Champion Turns to Fighting Crime
text: Chess is often a plot element in television dramas, but until “Endgame” premiered last year on the Canadian network Showcase, the game itself had never had a starring role.

headline: Boston College Wins 5th Title, but Underdog Puts Up a Fight
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The expected coronation of Boston College as king of men’s college hockey did not come without a struggle. The top-seeded Eagles were pushed to the limit but outlasted the underdog Ferris State, 4-1, in the Frozen Four title game Saturday night at Tampa Bay Times Forum.

headline: A Friendship Dating to 1976 Resonates in 2012
text: The two young men had woefully little in common: one was a wealthy Mormon from Michigan, the other a middle-class Jew from Israel.

headline: Yanks’ Rally Can’t Offset Kuroda’s Shaky Start
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When Hiroki Kuroda pitched for the Los Angeles Dodgers, runs were usually at a premium, and Kuroda pitched accordingly. He was precise and careful, knowing he had to limit damage early on because one run in the first inning might determine the outcome of the game.

headline: Despite Deadly Fungus, Frog Imports Continue
text: A clerk serving Cantonese-speaking customers at a cluttered market in San Francisco’s Chinatown reached into a tub of American bullfrogs. She drew a one-pound frog from the top of the pile. She whacked its head, sliced its neck and placed its body in a plastic grocery bag.

headline: Police Suspect Single Gunman in Attacks in Oklahoma
text: The authorities in Tulsa, Okla., were scrambling on Saturday to find a man who they say opened fire on five people in four apparently random shootings a day before, killing three people and wounding two more.

headline: Kira Krieger, Samuel Senders
text: Kira Krieger and Samuel Lawrence Senders were married Wednesday evening at the St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort in Bal Harbour, Fla. Rabbi Dovid Vigler officiated.

headline: Courtney Morgan and Andrew Montgomery
text: Courtney McClung Morgan and Andrew William Montgomery are to be married Sunday evening at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. Dmitry A. Terekhov, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Laila Tabatabai and Shaan Raza
text: Dr. Laila Shaheen Tabatabai and Dr. Shaan Mohammed Raza were married Saturday at the Saratoga Hilton in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Maulana Sakhawat Hussain, a Muslim cleric, performed the Shiite ceremony.

text: Jennifer Michele Lenhart and Andrew Richard Carranza were married Saturday on the Brooklyn Bridge. Eric Faison, a Universal Life Church minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Renée Robichaux, Guy Endore-Kaiser

Robichaux Jr. of New Orleans, was married there Saturday evening to Guy Endore-Kaiser, the son of Gita Endore and Michael N. Kaiser, both of Los Angeles. Judge Kirk A. Vaughn of Louisiana’s 34th Judicial District, who presides in Chalmette, La., officiated at the New Orleans Botanical Garden.

headline: Shannon Liu, Hayes Shair

headline: Adria Waldbart, C. Allen Garrett Jr.

headline: Showtime: A Japanese Star Is Ready for His Close-up
text: HONG KONG — Every baseball player who makes it to The Show has stellar credentials. All the pitchers in the major leagues have a zillion strikeouts, and all the hitters have piles of home runs or a great slugging percentage. They’re also likely to have outstanding stats in categories like DIPS, OPS, BABIP and VORP — the arcane indices made popular by Moneyball.

headline: A Chance to Unfreeze the Standoff on the Glacier
text: HONG KONG — The search for 135 people buried under an avalanche in Pakistan resumed at first light on Sunday.

headline: U.S. Transfers Control of Night Raids to Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Accelerating the transition of military responsibility to the Afghan government, the United States agreed Sunday to hand control of special operations missions to Afghan forces, including night raids, relegating American troops to a supporting role and bringing the raids under Afghan judicial authority.

headline: David Wilson, Fourth-Ranked Running Back in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping the Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: As Russian Real Estate Money Floods in, Could New York Go the Way of London?
text: LONDON — “The real estate market in the United States may still be slumping, but its high end is enjoying a remarkable updraft, propelled by money flowing in from all corners of the globe, including from developing countries like Brazil, China and India,” writes our colleague Alexei Barrionuevo in his latest real estate piece. “But no group is consistently writing bigger checks than the Russians.

headline: Arrests in Shootings End a Terrifying Weekend in Tulsa
text: TULSA, Okla. — Late on Thursday afternoon, Jacob C. England, 19, posted a message on his Facebook page, expressing grief — and anger — over the second anniversary of his father’s death. Mr. England’s father, Carl, was shot on April 5, 2010, at an apartment complex here, and the man who was a person of interest in the case, Pernell Jefferson, is serving time at an Oklahoma state prison.

headline: Santorum Takes Monday Off to Be With Daughter
text: Rick Santorum said in a statement issued late Saturday that he will not campaign on Monday so he can stay with his daughter Bella, who was hospitalized on Friday.

headline: Unemployment and Inflation
text: I thought it might be useful to provide a bit of data context for my post on central bank mandates. What did we think we knew about unemployment and inflation?

headline: Behind the Steering Wheel and Not a Grammarian in Sight
text: It was a dark Sunday evening in early October when Mark Vincent reluctantly set off on a city chore shared by some and lamented by many: moving his car to abide by alternate-side parking rules. Mr. Vincent lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn; his car is a maroon 1992 Honda that he and his wife inherited from her father after her father could no longer drive.

headline: Overabundant Bunnies Find Off-Campus Haven
text: It’s Easter weekend, so bunnies are in the news. This prompted me to check in on an issue I touched on in 2009, during a visit to the University of Victoria on Canada’s Vancouver Island.

headline: Indian and Pakistani Leaders Encourage Ties in a Rare Visit
text: NEW DELHI — In the first visit to India by a Pakistani head of state in seven years, President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Sunday expressed a mutual desire to improve relations between their rival South Asian nations, and Mr. Singh announced that he would at some point visit Pakistan for the first time since taking office.

headline: Reactions to the Death of Mike Wallace, ’60 Minutes’ Pioneer

headline: Mike Wallace, CBS Pioneer of ‘60 Minutes,’ Dies at 93
text: Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of America’s best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on “60 Minutes,” died on Saturday. He was 93.

headline: Site Finds Home Hosts, Not Kennels, for Your Dog
text: Couchsurfing.org and Airbnb9.com offer home stays to travelers seeking an alternative to hotels. Now your dog can get a similar service: a home instead of a kennel.

headline: Four Officers Are Shot in Brooklyn; Assailant Is Critically Wounded

headline: Last Word: Mike Wallace
text: Mike Wallace, the tough-guy interrogator of “60 Minutes,” was the personification of 20th-century television news. He made his name confronting the famous and infamous on camera.

headline: Ryan, Obama, and Deficits
text: Hmm. There’s an obvious calculation I haven’t see done: how does the Ryan proposal scored more or less honestly — that is, without the “mystery meat”, the assumed revenue from closing loopholes that Ryan refuses to identity — compare with the Obama budget?

headline: A Look Back 100 Years To Focus on the Titanic
text: The Titanic exhibition in Belfast opened late last month, promising the world’s largest display of materials on the ship built and launched from the city 100 years ago. But for Titanic buffs who can’t make the trip to Ireland, a few exhibitions on our shores promise a look at the now mythic voyage.

headline: South Korea Suspects That North May Test Nuclear Device as Well as Rocket
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea appears to be preparing for its third underground nuclear test even as it presses ahead with assembling a long-range rocket for its planned launching of a satellite this month, a South Korean government spokesman said Sunday.

headline: Cricket and the Ajmer Sharif Shrine Bolster India Pakistan Relations
text: When Pakistan’s leaders visit India to try to bolster fragile relations between the two countries, both sides can always count on cricket and the famous shrine of Ajmer Sharif to provide the perfect cover for informal talks.

headline: Mike Wallace, 1918-2012

headline: Cardinal Dolan Talks of Role of Religion in Politics
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan weighed in on the role of religion in politics in an Easter Sunday appearance on “Face the Nation,” pledging to fight President Obama’s contraception policy and defending Rick Santorum over a comment that reading John F. Kennedy’s 1960 speech about the separation of church and state almost made him throw up.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games’ Surpasses $300 Million in North America
text: The kids of “The Hunger Games,” even in their third weekend in theaters, ran laps around the rested adults of “American Reunion,” selling an estimated $33.5 million in tickets to repeat as the No. 1 movie in North America.

headline: Mickelson Has History for Him and Against Him
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. – The final pairing Sunday has produced 19 of the past 21 Masters champions, which has many people here rushing to fit Phil Mickelson for his fourth green jacket. Mickelson is in the last group with Peter Hanson, who has his first lead in a major championship.

headline: In Europe, Unease Over Bank Debt
text: PARIS — Only a few months ago, banks around the world were scrambling to sell piles of European government bonds that had lost value as the Continent’s sovereign debt crisis flared.

headline: Pro’s Perspective: Liking Mickelson’s Chances
text: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 PGA Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia is in his third season on the Champions Tour.

text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bubba Watson is an iconoclast in a sport of conformists, in possession of a swing that defies duplication and a mind so overactive that he has a hard time focusing for more than a few seconds.

headline: Work Doesn’t Stop for Cink After a Dismal Third Round
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Convention holds that the Masters doesn’t begin until the back nine Sunday. For the former Georgia Tech star Stewart Cink, it essentially ended on the front nine Saturday when he shot a five-over 41 on his way to an 81. He rebounded with a closing 69 to finish at eight over.

headline: Egyptian Presidential Candidate Carries Banner of the Old Order
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak’s intelligence chief and vice president filed papers in Egypt on Sunday declaring himself a presidential candidate. His entry gives Egyptians a chance to cast a vote against the revolution and for the old order.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include wholesale trade inventories for February (Tuesday); import prices for March and the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for March and the trade deficit for February (Thursday); the Consumer Price Index for March and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

headline: Edoardo Molinari Has Had Enough of the Masters
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Edoardo Molinari signed for his final-round two-over-par 74 a few minutes before his younger brother, Francesco, teed off with his playing partner, Ian Poulter. He said the two were staying in separate residences and hadn’t spoken since Saturday night.

headline: Foundation Files Reveal Insights on Culture
text: James Baldwin needed some money.

headline: Anything You Can Do, I Can Do in a Glowing Squiggle
text: Decadancetheatre, a Brooklyn group started by Jennifer Weber in 2004, has an admirable purpose: to redefine the image of women in hip-hop. Ms. Weber’s work goes against what is often an unfortunate sight: female dancers feigning toughness in baggy pants and baseball caps. In the past she has taken on Stravinsky’s “Firebird” and Jerome Robbins’s “Cage.” She doesn’t have a one-note mind.

headline: Singing of Beasts and Battle, With Folky Starts and Arena Finishes
text: Iceland could be a British isle or a Canadian province for Of Monsters and Men, the Icelandic band that headlined Webster Hall on Friday night. Of Monsters and Men connects two strains of Celtic-rooted music that spur robust, foot-stamping singalongs: the sea chantey and the arena-rock chorus, the folky and the anthemic. Its songs regularly ascend from guitar-strumming, accordion-tootling openings to brawny rock marches topped by la-las for the crowd to join, a strategy also used by Mumford & Sons, the Decemberists, Arcade Fire and, in decades past, the Scottish band Big Country.

headline: Jackson Heights’ Ambassador of Yoga
text: Muhammad Rashid adopted yoga into his daily routine and has encouraged other Muslims to do so, challenging those who view yoga as a sin against Islam.

headline: Seeking to Clear a Path Between Yoga and Islam
text: As a community activist in Queens, Muhammad Rashid has fought for the rights of immigrants held in detention, sought the preservation of local movie theaters and held a street fair to promote diversity.

headline: Anthony at His Best Against the Best
text: Carmelo Anthony was dancing, spinning, hopping and hollering, a fountain of bravado and joy, a star on a mission, a force unleashed. The moment suited him.

headline: After Three Games, the Yankees Are Still Looking for a Win

headline: No-Hit Bid Silenced, Mets Still Make Noise
text: There was a familiar clash of emotions creeping through Citi Field on Sunday afternoon, a mixture of “Could it be?” and “Here we go again.” The Mets have never had a pitcher throw a no-hitter, and each potential bid now is fraught with the cumulative weight of each previous disappointment.

headline: Origin of Speciousness
text: I was unhappy with President Obama’s decision to call Republicans “social Darwinists” — not because I thought it was wrong, but because I wondered how many voters would get his point. How many people know who Herbert Spencer was?

headline: Jump, Twirl, Paint, Act!
text: LONDON — Seventy Shakespeare productions from companies around the world, performed in 30 theaters all over Britain. A 33-foot-high puppet of Lady Godiva (wearing undergarments by the fashion designer Zandra Rhodes) moving through the streets of Coventry and into London, powered by 50 people on bicycles. Music from everywhere performed free in choice spots up and down the Thames.

headline: Serena Williams Continues Dominance to Win Family Circle Title
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — On what has long been her shakiest surface, Serena Williams looked as solid as she ever had Sunday.

headline: Lessons From Ants to Grasp Humanity
text: To the biologist Edward O. Wilson, the Metropolitan Museum of Art encapsulates some of the conflicting impulses natural selection has instilled in humans: the innate drive for expression that spurs some of us to make art, the selfishness that motivates others to earn the riches needed to collect it, and the altruism that compels the donation of collections for the public good — as long as the donors’ names are inscribed on the walls too.

headline: Care for Romance and Acrobatics With Your Ceviche?
text: CHICAGO — Dinner theater, that derided and mostly moribund genre, is making an unlikely comeback at the Lookingglass Theater here, where one of this city’s most renowned chefs, Rick Bayless, is preparing a savory meal onstage, and doing a modest bit of acting in a modest little comedy too.

headline: London 2012 Festival
text: A look at some of the works in the eight-week festival of cultural events before, during and after the Olympics.

headline: A Diva Dips Into Indie Rock and Musical Theater
text: Not quite two years ago the soprano Renée Fleming released an album that constituted the biggest surprise of a noteworthy career: “Dark Hope,” a collection of rock songs in plush arrangements, came out on Decca in June 2010. Most of the indie-rock acts represented on the disc, like Arcade Fire and the Mars Volta, were urged upon her by Q Prime, the pop-music management firm that hatched the idea.

headline: Seattle Reporter Finds Bubbles of Corruption Under the Space Needle
text: There they are, thick on the ground in Jim Lynch’s “Truth Like the Sun”: setups for familiar plot twists that allow a novel to trudge forward on autopilot, delivering nothing of value to either reader or author. Mr. Lynch’s book, very good to begin with, is all the better for not exploiting such cheap tricks.

headline: A Puzzle That Makes Sense
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Tasty! And a nice way to start our new solving week.

headline: In Verdi’s Parisian Social Whirl, a Star Shines, Then Plummets in Flames
text: In the opening moments of Willy Decker’s striking modern production of Verdi’s “Traviata,” the dying courtesan Violetta moves slowly across the stage toward a huge ticking clock that symbolizes her mortality, her bright red dress a solitary splash of color against a barren white wall. Her loneliness amid the bourgeois claustrophobia of the Parisian beau monde is evocatively realized in this alluring staging, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening.

headline: As Technology Evolves, AT&T Adjusts a Theme
text: AT&T is rethinking “Rethink possible.”

headline: Surprising Disparity at the Spring Nationals
text: A deal is played in the same strain at both tables in a match. The two opening leads are identical. What has been the greatest disparity in the number of tricks ever won?

headline: Arrests in Case of Chinese Artifacts
text: Two men and a woman were arrested on Saturday in connection with a museum theft of two Chinese artifacts with a combined estimated worth of $3.2 million, The Associated Press reported. A large jade water bowl inscribed with a Chinese poem dating to 1769 and a Dehua porcelain sculpture were taken from the Oriental Museum at Durham University in England after thieves broke into a ground-floor gallery on Thursday night. Craig Barclay, the museum curator, confirmed in a statement that both items were from the Qing dynasty, 1644 to 1912, the last imperial dynasty in China. Police officials said that the items had not been recovered, and that they were attempting to locate several other suspects.

headline: Supremacy in Jeopardy for ‘Today’
text: These days, the effervescent smiles on the “Today” show, America’s most popular morning television companion, are concealing anxiety.

headline: NBC’s ‘Today’ Wins a Ratings Showdown
text: “Today” removed any doubt that it would win its weeklong showdown against “Good Morning America” by scoring its biggest ratings win of the week on Thursday morning. “Today,” long the ratings leader, topped “Good Morning America” by 435,000 total viewers Thursday and by 227,000 in the age group preferred by advertisers, viewers between 25 and 54. Both totals were the biggest of the week. To try to close the ratings gap of many years between the two programs, “Good Morning America” brought in the former “Today” star Katie Couric as a guest host, a move that “Today” countered with a widely publicized appearance by Sarah Palin as guest host on Tuesday. “Today” won the first two mornings of the week by totals in the 300,000 range; “Good Morning America” won Wednesday by 87,000.

headline: Newspaper Barons Resurface
text: Is there anything more forlorn than the American metropolitan newspaper? First readers began deserting in droves, then the advertisers followed. Family owners headed for the exits and then hedge funds and other financial players scooped up newspapers thinking they were buying at the bottom of the market. Greater fools came and went, each saying they could cut their way to former glory and renewed profitability. They got a haircut instead.

headline: Berkeley Rep Workshop
text: The Berkeley Repertory Theater is set to announce Monday that a group of 40 writers, directors and composers will gather there this summer in an effort to develop 13 new projects for the stage. The four-week creative workshop, the Ground Floor, is designed to provide the artists with the space and resources to hone their work. It will include things like “The Food Project,” a series of short dining-centric scripts from 20 playwrights including Julia Cho (“The Language Archive”), David Edgar (“Continental Divide”) and Amy Freed (“Freedomland”); and plays from Marcus Gardley (“On the Levee”) and Dan LeFranc (“Sixty Miles to Silver Lake”) commissioned by the theater.

headline: Leaving Las Vegas: The Telethon
text: The Muscular Dystrophy Association will move its Labor Day telethon this year to the Los Angeles area from Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. A spokeswoman for the Muscular Dystrophy Association declined to provide details. But an official at the South Point Hotel Casino and Spa, where the telethon has been held for six years, confirmed the move. The organization made another big change last year when it announced that the comedian Jerry Lewis would not host the telethon for the first time since 1966. The 2011 show was six hours long and used several hosts, raising $61.5 million, according to telethon officials.

headline: Bands Improvise New Ways to Live-Stream Shows
text: For music fans, more and more consumption these days happens through online streaming services like Pandora, Spotify and TuneIn. But when it comes to live shows there’s not much out there: for the most part, only big festivals and promoters have had the resources to send as-it-happens audio over the Internet.

headline: North Korea Prepares Rocket Launch
text: North Korea on Sunday continued to prepare for a rocket launch that officials say will carry a weather satellite, a claim the United States doubts.

headline: Lin Is Happy With Recovery So Far
text: Six days removed from surgery, an upbeat Jeremy Lin said Sunday he nearly had full range of motion in his left knee and was biking and walking with ease. Basketball, however, remains a ways off.

headline: Private Equity Firms Duel Over Water Park Operator
text: It is rare to see private equity firms lock horns in a public bidding war. But a heated auction appears to be brewing for Great Wolf Resorts, the big indoor water park operator.

headline: Owner Had Right to Clear Zuccotti Park, Judge Says
text: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that Brookfield Properties, owner of the park used as an encampment by Occupy Wall Street protesters, had the right to clear them to address deteriorating conditions inside the park.

headline: Eighth Place Is Good for Nostalgia but Little Else
text: As the final seconds of overtime ticked away, as Tyson Chandler twice saved the misfiring Knicks on the offensive glass, as the ball found its way into Carmelo Anthony’s hands on the far right wing, the thought had to occur to the returning Larry Johnson sitting at courtside and anyone else who was in the building on a particular tension-filled night in June 1999.

headline: Peter Douglas, Sentry of California’s Coast, Dies at 69
text: Peter Douglas, who fought for decades to preserve the California coast — treasured for its vast stretches of pristine beaches, jagged cliffs and delicate wetlands — died on April 1 at his sister’s home in La Quinta, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Begrudging the Wildcats’ Success and Opportunities
text: A new baseball season is under way, the N.B.A. is headed toward another exciting finish, and yet the University of Kentucky’s success in men’s basketball has sparked outrage that lingers a week after the national championship game.

headline: Banker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA recently nominated Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth, to be the next president of the World Bank — a privilege accorded to the United States since the bank’s founding in 1946. A European, in turn, gets to run the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Kenneth Libo, Scholar of Immigrant Life, Dies at 74
text: Kenneth Libo, a historian of Jewish immigration who, as a graduate student working for Irving Howe in the 1960s and ’70s, unearthed historical documentation that informed and shaped “World of Our Fathers,” Mr. Howe’s landmark 1976 history of the East European Jewish migration to America, died on March 29 in New York. He was 74.

headline: Tightening the Lid on Pain Prescriptions
text: SEATTLE — It was the type of conversation that Dr. Claire Trescott dreads: telling physicians that they are not cutting it.

headline: How to Fix the World Bank
text: FOR the first time since the World Bank’s creation at the end of World War II, the United States is facing a real challenge over the bank’s leadership. Leaders of some developing and emerging economies have refused to support President Obama’s unexpected choice of Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College, to lead the bank.

headline: My Beautiful Cushy Tushy
text: When my younger daughter was about four years old, she stood in our kitchen, pulled up her shirt and popped her tummy straight out. It was impressive, that round little belly. I smiled, and she grinned back. “That’s as cute as I can make it,” she said proudly.

headline: Roger Furst Dies at 78; Equipped Mountaineers in the Northeast
text: Roger Furst, one of two fishing buddies who founded the Eastern Mountain Sports retail chain, which has equipped thousands of people to trek deep into the mountains, ski in the backcountry or scale a peak, died on March 16 in Sherman, Tex., a day after his 78th birthday.

text: Everyone with a mobile device is going to have to start paying more attention as wireless carriers turn to limited data plans. But how many megabytes are in a movie?

headline: For Lindsey Vonn, Professional Triumph and Personal Turmoil
text: VAIL, Colo. — Skiing in the mountains above the Vail resort last week, Lindsey Vonn slowed to a stop at the top of a trail named in her honor after she won the 2010 women’s Olympic downhill.

headline: Quiz: Do You Know Your Data?
text: What is a megabyte? And how many does it take to watch one movie? With cellphone carriers offering increasingly complex data plans, people are being forced to think about how they are using the Internet on their smartphones.

headline: Do You Need That Test?
text: If health care costs are ever to be brought under control, the nation’s doctors will have to play a leading role in eliminating unnecessary treatments. By some estimates, hundreds of billions of dollars are wasted this way every year. So it is highly encouraging that nine major physicians’ groups have identified 45 tests and procedures (five for each specialty) that are commonly used but have no proven benefit for many patients and sometimes cause more harm than good.

headline: A Ballooning Megabyte Budget
text: Everyone knows how long a minute is. And your cellphone carrier keeps close tabs on how many you have used this month. Now, in the smartphone era, more people are being forced to think about how many megabytes of data they are using.

headline: Taking Credit Where None Is Due
text: As Friday’s jobless numbers showed, the economic recovery has been listless and fragile, but its upward trajectory has been clear enough that Republicans have been forced to acknowledge it. To avoid giving President Obama the slightest bit of credit for the improvement, however, they have come up with increasingly convoluted explanations that have little relationship to reality.

headline: Keeping Students’ Mental Health Care Out of the E.R.
text: During the 2010-11 school year, Adeline Seise’s son Gabriel, a second grader, repeatedly disrupted classes at Public School 67 in the Bronx.

headline: Volunteers Scramble to Save a School for Immigrants
text: As a result of the economic downturn and a dwindling endowment, the International Center, which has taught English and helped immigrants assimilate for decades, faces dissolution and eviction from its Manhattan home.

headline: Children Can Never Be Safe in Adult Prisons
text: After an unconscionable delay of nearly three years, the Justice Department needs to issue the final, mandatory rape-prevention policies for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal dollars. They must improve on the proposed rules issued last spring.

headline: Detour on Fourth Hole Costs Mickelson His Chance
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As Phil Mickelson stared after his tee shot at Augusta National’s par-3 fourth hole Sunday, his face was calm, calm and then — suddenly — twisted in despair.

headline: In Russia, Charges Are Dropped in Jail Death
text: MOSCOW — Russian investigators have dropped the charges against a former prison doctor who was one of only two people to face punishment in the death of a 37-year-old lawyer whose arrest and maltreatment underscored the selective and sometimes brutal nature of Russia’s justice system.

headline: Financing for Job Programs Has Declined
text: Federal funds for some training and job search programs have fallen even as more people have lost jobs. Figures below are adjusted for inflation.

headline: Big Warning on Little Fish
text: There is more to smart fishery management than protecting the big, delicious species, like striped bass, cod, tuna and salmon. A huge and growing portion of the world’s commercial catch — 37 percent by weight — is made up of small fish, like herring, sardines, anchovies and menhaden, which are food for larger predators.

headline: Federal Funds to Train the Jobless Are Drying Up
text: With the economy slowly reviving, an executive from Atlas Van Lines recently visited Louisville, Ky., with good news: the company wanted to hire more than 100 truck drivers ahead of the summer moving season.

headline: ‘Super PAC,’ Eyeing General Election, Aims Blitz at Obama
text: American Crossroads, the biggest of the Republican “super PACs,” is planning to begin its first major anti-Obama advertising blitz of the year, a moment the Obama re-election campaign has been girding for and another sign that the general election is starting in earnest.

headline: The Taint of ‘Social Darwinism’
text: Given the well-known Republican antipathy to evolution, President Obama’s recent description of the Republican budget as an example of “social Darwinism” may be a canny piece of political labeling. In the interests of historical accuracy, however, it should be clearly recognized that “social Darwinism” has very little to do with the ideas developed by Charles Darwin in “On the Origin of Species.” Social Darwinism emerged as a movement in the late 19th-century, and has had waves of popularity ever since, but its central ideas owe more to the thought of a luminary of that time, Herbert Spencer, whose writings are (to understate) no longer widely read.

headline: On Easter Sunday, Tebow Is a Headliner
text: GEORGETOWN, Tex. — Tim Tebow fans embraced the opportunity to don their new Jets finery and celebrate Easter with him at an outdoor service that drew thousands of worshipers Sunday.

headline: Data Scientists Get Ranked
text: What is the best way to rank statisticians? When you do find the best of a batch, are they, on average, out of the ordinary?

headline: Rose Returns, but the Rust Shows
text: Late in the first quarter on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, the Chicago Bulls, the team with the best record in the N.B.A., were shooting 8 percent from the field. The Knicks were shooting 71-percent and had raced to a 22-6 lead.

headline: AccentHealth Puts Medical Content on Waiting Room TVs
text: Patients sitting in waiting rooms are often relegated to watching television or reading well-worn magazines to pass the time. But in many doctor’s offices these days, the standard television offerings like daytime talk shows are giving way to a more focused kind of programming: health content.

headline: Tradition and Boat Race Both Upended on the Thames
text: LONDON — It is, in its way, one of Britain’s great anachronisms: a university boat race steeped in pageantry and tradition with nothing but honor at stake, a moment when old buffers in satin-trimmed blazers can revel in upper-crust camaraderie and pretend that the important things in the world remain much as they were when the race was first run in 1829.

headline: Serena Williams Captures First Clay Title Since 2008
text: Serena Williams emphatically defeated Lucie Safarova, 6-0, 6-1, to win the final of the Family Circle Cup in 58 minutes on Sunday in Charleston, S.C. It was her first clay-court title since winning the tournament in 2008; only 4 of her 40 career titles have come on clay.

headline: Are Some Buildings Too Ugly to Survive?
text: Do even ugly buildings deserve to be saved, if they are architecturally significant?

headline: Long Waiting Lists Again for Kindergarten Seats
text: More than 2,400 children are on waiting lists to get into kindergarten classes at their zoned New York City public schools in September -- partly as a result of an increase in applications, city officials said.

headline: City to Install ‘Smart Screens’ in Some Public Phone Booths

headline: California May Close a Home to Its Past
text: WHITTIER, Calif. — Here, in an adobe home now tucked between a freeway and a railroad, once sat the last governor of Alta California, as it was known under Mexican rule. The governor, Pío de Jesús Pico, was one of the richest men in the area, his ranchito stretching for nearly 9,000 acres.

headline: Ex-K.G.B. Agent Said to Win South Ossetia Presidency
text: MOSCOW — Early results from a fourth round of voting in South Ossetia on Sunday indicated that the former K.G.B. official Leonid Tibilov had been elected president, bringing an end to a long, tumultuous campaign season that proved an embarrassment to Moscow, the region’s source of military and financial support.

headline: Comedy Timing Is Bad as News and Film Collide

headline: America’s Place in the New World
text: “It’s election season again, and the main contenders for the Oval Office are knocking themselves out to reassure Americans that their nation remains at the pinnacle of the global pecking order,” Charles A. Kupchan writes in Sunday Review of The New York Times. Mitt Romney recently declared that “this century must be an American century.” Not to be outdone, President Obama insisted in his State of the Union address that “anyone who tells you that America is in decline” doesn’t “know what they’re talking about,” Mr. Kupchan writes.

headline: Indian and Pakistani Leaders Encourage Ties in a Rare Visit

headline: Seeking to Clear a Path Between Yoga and Islam
text: “As a community activist in Queens, Muhammad Rashid has fought for the rights of immigrants held in detention, sought the preservation of local movie theaters and held a street fair to promote diversity, ” Sarah Maslin Nir writes in The New York Times. “But few of those causes brought him anywhere near as much grief and controversy as his stance on yoga.”

headline: U.S. Said to Have Picked an Ambassador to Myanmar
text: HONG KONG — It appears that the United States will soon name Derek J. Mitchell as the new ambassador to Myanmar, according to Josh Rogin on The Cable blog of Foreign Policy magazine. The report was confirmed by The Financial Times.

headline: Iranian Officials Send Mixed Signals as Nuclear Talks Near Resumption
text: LONDON — A senior Iranian official hinted on Monday that Iran would consider limits on its home-grown stockpile of enriched uranium, offering what seemed a modest compromise to partly meet Western concerns ahead of the planned resumption this week of nuclear talks with a group of six global powers.

headline: Camera in the Net? Might Just Work
text: As a youngster in the late 1950s, Barton Silverman used a discount card to get into New York Rangers games at Madison Square Garden for half price. Fittingly, he could  see only half the game. “The balcony overrode the ice and the balcony blocked one half of the ice,” he said.

headline: For Bilawal Bhutto Zardari and Rahul Gandhi, Divergent Public Styles
text: It did not take Bilawal Bhutto Zardari long during his first visit to India to show he is a very different type of political prince than Rahul Gandhi – at least when it comes to public relations. The moment the son of Pakistan’s president, Asif Ali Zardari, and the late former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto landed Sunday in New Delhi, he launched what became a daylong monologue on Twitter.

headline: How a Photo of Joel Klein Saved a Teacher's Job
text: The city wanted to fire a Washington Heights music teacher, Michael Dalton, for inappropriately holding three third-grade boys in his lap, The Times reports. But then Mr. Dalton, 48, presented a novel -- and successful -- defense: a photo of Joel I. Klein, the schools chancellor at the time, who also appeared to have children sitting in his lap. An arbitrator returned him to the classroom.

headline: Saul Gootnick: 'You Have to Do Baby Steps'
text: Forest Hills High School has more than 3,800 students, 12 assistant principals and 195 teachers. Despite its size and crowding issues, it has earned an A on its progress report three years in a row. The principal, Saul Gootnick, said his team changed the culture of the school by focusing on the classroom and introducing changes one step at a time. "You have to have a plan and you have to make people believe in what you think," he said.

headline: The Empathy Gap
text: In general, I’m a numbers and concepts guy, not a feelings guy; when I go after someone like Paul Ryan, I emphasize his irresponsibility and dishonesty, not his evident lack of empathy for the less fortunate.

headline: A Protest Movement’s Second Wind?
text: MOSCOW — “Day 24 is over,” Oleg Shein wrote in his blog just after midnight on April 8. “Tomorrow is Day 25. We are not on a suicide mission. Nor are we on a mission to make me the mayor. We are on a mission to secure fair elections that will put an end to the mafia system of government in Astrakhan.”

headline: Considering the Victims of a Sexual-Misconduct Nightmare

headline: ‘Do You Know Who Died?’
text: Heavy boots woke me. They struck the floor upstairs like mallets on a wooden gong. They paced the room above, paused, then paced back again.

headline: Gervais Says New Show Isn’t Mocking Disabled People
text: It wouldn’t be a new Ricky Gervais project if that British comedian weren’t pre-emptively defending it against accusations of insensitivity, would it? In this latest instance Mr. Gervais, the veteran Golden Globes host and creator and star of comedies like “The Office” and “Extras,” is standing up for a new series, “Derek,” that has potential viewers concerned that it may be making fun of disabled people, BBC News reported.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: News Intrudes on a Summer Comedy, and Recalling Mike Wallace
text: Executives at 20th Century Fox have been quickly rethinking the marketing strategy for its summer comedy “Neighborhood Watch” in light of the shooting of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman, a community watch participant in Sanford, Fla., who has said he acted in self-defense, Michael Cieply writes. Fox last month pre-emptively withdrew its trailers and advertising materials for the movie, which features Ben Stiller and Vince Vaughn as four suburban watch members who fight an invasion by space aliens. The new marketing focus will play up the alien invasion aspect of the story.

headline: Monday Reading: The Easiest Way to Cheat on Your Taxes

headline: AT&T Sells Majority Stake in Yellow Pages to Cerberus
text: AT&T said on Monday that it had agreed to sell a majority stake in its yellow pages business to Cerberus Capital Management for about $950 million, giving the private equity firm an opportunity to resuscitate a declining operation.

headline: The Kindest Cut
text: Until a few weeks ago, the last time I subjected my hair to a major cut was 1989. At 35, I had been spending my summer at the bedside of my mother, who was dying of an inoperable brain tumor.

headline: New Herman Wouk Novel, ‘The Lawgiver,’ Coming From Simon & Schuster
text: Simon & Schuster will release a new novel by Herman Wouk, the 96-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “The Caine Mutiny,” the publisher said on Monday.

headline: Documentary Is Another Voice in the Underage Model Conversation
text: The documentary “Girl Model” opens with hundreds of scantily clad adolescent and teenage girls lined up in an auditorium. A model scout calls models one-by-one to the stage and begins commenting on their weight, body shape and signs of acne.

headline: Antidepressants Can Raise Blood Pressure During Pregnancy
text: Taking antidepressants during pregnancy raises the risk of high blood pressure in expectant mothers, a new study shows.

headline: A Living Autopsy of the Ron Paul Campaign
text: The Republican primary has reached an endgame. Mitt Romney has turned his attention to President Obama and the general election. Rick Santorum is trying to remain relevant. And Newt Gingrich has downsized his campaign.

headline: In South Korea Scandal, Echoes of Watergate
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An unfolding political scandal ahead of Wednesday’s parliamentary elections has many South Koreans drawing comparisons to Watergate: illicit surveillance, an attempted cover-up, destruction of evidence, arrests of people connected to the president — and questions over what the president himself may have known.

headline: Lineup Unveiled for Inaugural Montclair Film Festival
text: A premiere screening of “Tiger Eyes,” a film adaptation of the novel by the New Jersey native Judy Blume that was directed by her son, Lawrence Blume, is among the Garden State-centric events planned for the first Montclair Film Festival, its organizers announced on Monday. The festival, which will run in Montclair, N.J., from May 1 through 6 (and bills itself with the cheeky slogan “It’s Sundance. Only Jersier”), will open with a gala screening of “The Oranges,” the Julian Farino comedy set in suburban New Jersey and starring Hugh Laurie, Leighton Meester and Oliver Platt. Other events include a tribute to Kathleen Turner on May 2, which will feature a live interview with that actress; a May 3 screening of “Cloudburst” that will be attended by its star, Olympia Dukakis; a comedy event called “The What-Is-It?,” featuring commentary on esoteric film clips by the “Daily Show” producers Rory Albanese and Adam Lowitt; and conversations with the actor Patrick Wilson, the director Michael Moore, and Michael E. Uslan, a producer of “The Dark Knight” and “The Dark Knight Rises.” A complete lineup can be found at montclairfilmfest.org.

text: Tightening the lid on pain prescriptions | Sam Grobart on why it is time to think about how much data you use on your smartphone | David Carr looks at the return of newspaper barons.

headline: Tumi Sets I.P.O. Price Range at $15 to $17

text: The gold rush for patents continues.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Los Angeles Times: A secret dinner in which the star ingredient is an herb associated more with brownies than fine cuisine. Jonathan Gold reports. — Eric Asimov

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: John Anagnost joined XplusOne, New York, in a new post, vice president of sales for the Eastern region. He had been president at Reprise Media, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Hunx and His Punx
text: I learned two things at the recent Hunx and His Punx show at the Echo in Los Angeles. 1. I am too old to mosh. 2. Having a flamboyantly gay lead singer no longer poses any limitations whatsoever on a band’s demographic reach. People from every possible walk of life crammed the floor in front of the stage, from gutter punks to frat boys, all of them worshiping at the altar of adorable feyness that is Seth Bogart and his Punx. Looking like a scrawny version of a Tom of Finland drawing, and sporting costumes designed by the one and only Peggy Noland, Hunx steered the crowd into a frenzied surge. The passion very nearly swallowed me whole. With squawking, cheeky lyrics that poked fun at sexuality, crushes and just plain sex, Hunx and His Punx are an irresistibly twisted, fantastical cross between CBGB’s punk culture and a 1950s surf pop band.

headline: "Historic"
text: A negative ad launched by the Romney campaign focused on Rick Santorum's 2006 loss in the Pennsylvania Senate race.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Anderson on the ‘Religion’ of Stupid Digital Games
text: Sam Anderson, critic at large for The Times Magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on stupid digital games. He has most recently written for the magazine on Haruki Murakami and on the theme park called Dickens World.

headline: Leading Off: Unconventional Wins
text: As much as the Masters would like to stage-manage everything in its leafy-green, mythical utopia where everyone is polite, the world is still segregated according to how the rich power brokers want it and usually even the flowers bloom on cue, it can’t stage-manage what happens in the actual tournament, no matter how much it wants to. And so it ended up with Bubba Watson, the man of a million laid-bare emotions, a homemade swing, a pink driver and a hobby restoring a car made famous by “The Dukes of Hazzard,” crafting the craziest of shots out of the woods in the playoff, then watering the 10th green with tears.

headline: No Seizure Risk From Measles Vaccine in Older Children
text: A large new study has ruled out concerns that children over 4 are at greater risk of seizures after getting a common measles-containing vaccine called MMRV. The vaccine — which combines the shot for measles, mumps and rubella, or MMR, with the vaccine for varicella, or chickenpox — is given to children in two steps, first as toddlers and then again between ages 4 and 6.

headline: Street Style: Spring Scarves
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of April 2.

headline: Dear FloFab: No Dessert for Me
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: 0-3 Starts and the Lesson of the 2011 Red Sox
text: The Yankees and the Red Sox are both 0-3 for the first time since 1966, but if last season taught baseball fans anything, it is that losing streaks are losing streaks, no matter when they happen.

headline: Morning T | Mélanie Laurent
text: The actress Mélanie Laurent talks about her latest film, “Les Adoptés,”; her new role as the face of an iconic Dior fragrance; and the benefits of being free.

headline: As Hundreds of Men Perished, One Ignored a Rumor to Survive
text: Had you been a woman traveling in second class on the Titanic a century ago, your chances of survival were quite favorable — 86 percent were saved. For the men in second class, one of whom was my grandfather Lawrence Beesley, the odds were the reverse — only 14 percent survived, and the rest were drowned in the freezing waters of the Atlantic.

text: Slap Shot is featuring reports from writers at the colleges and universities playing in the N.C.A.A. Frozen Four tournament.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Jorge Lorenzo Surges to Win MotoGP Opener in Qatar
text: Casey Stoner’s forearms could not have picked a worse time for a pit stop.

headline: It’s Probably Not Going to Be You Who Beats the Market
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: AOL Shares Soar on Patent Deal With Microsoft
text: Will AOL’s patent deal appease shareholders?

headline: UBS Banker Joins TAP Advisors
text: A senior technology banker at UBS has left the firm to become vice chairman of TAP Advisors, a boutique investment bank.

headline: Like Father, Like Son
text: Most Northerners who fought in the War of the Rebellion declared that they did so to preserve the Union. But many citizen soldiers enlisted for other reasons — some quite personal, discussed privately if at all, and certainly not in polite society.

headline: Preparing Children and Teens for a Tough Tick Season
text: A post last week on the Times’ Green blog encouraged Northeast residents to brace for a hungry tick season. Various environmental factors (specifically, fewer white-footed mice to feed on this year, leaving ticks looking for tasty mammal alternatives) mean that this spring and summer the woods will be filled with poppy-seed-size black-legged ticks in need of a meal.

headline: Products Named for ‘Dirty Jobs’ Try to Clean Up
text: For decades, fans have been able to buy merchandise inspired by their favorite television shows, like posters, T-shirts, records, books, jigsaw puzzles and dolls. But now a TV series has generated products that are meant to be practical rather than trinkets and knickknacks.

headline: Documenting the Olympic Dreams of Iraq’s Rowers
text: Haider Nozad, an Iraqi oarsman, wants to go back to the Olympics.

headline: Raf Simons Takes on the Dior Mantle
text: PARIS — The Belgian designer Raf Simons is expected to be named Tuesday as the next artistic director of Christian Dior. The post has been empty for more than a year since the dramatic departure of John Galliano in March 2011. Mr. Simons, who is 44, began his career in men’s wear in 1995 and went on to revitalize men’s and women’s lines at Jil Sander 10 years later.

headline: Out of State Guns
text: Last week, yet another school shooting served as a reminder of how desperately America needs to have a conversation about guns—though naturally we won’t have one due to the lobbying efforts of the National Rifle Association.

headline: Image of the Day: April 9
text: India and Qatar signed several agreements during the Emir’s visit, on subjects from educational cooperation to oil.

text: Explorers and United States government experts have put together the first comprehensive map of the Titanic’s resting place, illuminating a square mile of inky seabed as a guide to better understanding the liner’s death throes and better preserving its remains.

headline: Syrian Reportedly Detained for Bold Protest
text: A 33-year-old Syrian woman was reportedly arrested in Damascus on Sunday as she staged a bold protest outside the Syrian Parliament building, standing in traffic with a banner that read, “Stop the killing, so we can build a country for all Syrians.”

headline: The Iceberg Was Only Part of It
text: What doomed the Titanic is well known, at least in outline. On a moonless night in the North Atlantic, the liner hit an iceberg and disaster ensued, with 1,500 lives lost.

headline: Another Strong Fund-Raising Quarter for Warren in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren raised more than twice as much money as Senator Scott P. Brown last quarter in the high-stakes Massachusetts Senate race, bringing in $6.9 million compared with $3.4 million for Mr. Brown.
