text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Real Estate Brokers’ First Acts
text: A hand model, an actor and a rapper are among those enjoying a second career in real estate. Watch video of their prior incarnations.

headline: Rangers’ Playoff Report: Notes on Gaborik, Callahan, Kreider and Dubinsky
text: The Rangers were without two key players Monday for the first practice in preparation for their first-round Stanley Cup playoff series with Ottawa. Marian Gaborik, the team’s leading goal scorer with 41, was sidelined with the flu. The team’s captain, Ryan Callahan, who scored 29 goals, was out for what the team called personal reasons.

headline: TimesCast | Author: Frank Langella
text: March 30, 2012 — The actor Frank Langella writes about meeting some of the 20th century’s biggest celebrities in his memoir, “Dropped Names.”

headline: After Ship Sank, Fierce Fight to Get Story
text: To newspaper readers, and to the anxious crowds that jammed the streets around newspaper offices, hoping to see giant-letter bulletins be posted on the walls, it was the unforgettable story of the unsinkable ship. Behind the scenes, in the fiercely competitive newsrooms of a city with more than a dozen daily papers, it was the equally unforgettable story of two larger-than-life editors, one brilliantly analytical, the other brilliantly theatrical.

headline: The Taste of Spring, by the Bunch or Bag: Indian Tofu With Spinach
text: It’s hard for me to resist buying spinach at the farmers’ market this time of year. The bunches are plush, and the leaves and stems, pale pink at the base, are tender. I’d almost forgotten what mature spinach tastes like, since I’d gotten into the habit of buying the bagged baby spinach that you don’t have to stem; at my Iranian market they sell three-pound bags at a very good price. But fresh, locally grown bunch spinach is definitely worth revisiting, even if it does require more prep time. Ever since reading this article about the loss of nutrients and susceptibility to contamination that can occur when greens and lettuces are bagged, I’ve become a little less enamored with bagged baby spinach, despite the convenience.

headline: N.F.L. Upholds Suspensions in Saints Scandal
text: The N.F.L. upheld the season-long suspension of New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton on Monday, and the shorter suspensions of two other team executives, as the league continued to grapple with the bounty scandal that has overshadowed much of the off-season.

headline: On Our Radar: Gas, Gas and More Gas
text: With a mild winter in much of the country having tamped down gas demand and with production of natural gas thriving due to the success of hydraulic fracturing technology, a.k.a. “fracking,” the country is running out of storage space and as a result some producers are slowing down, the Associated Press reports. But just as the market seems saturated, and the Energy Department reports that prices are extremely low, the Interior Department’s Bureau of Land Management has issued new rules that will allow for another 3,600 wells in eastern Utah, the Salt Lake Tribune reports.

headline: Once a Rapper, a Ballerina or a Model, Now in Real Estate Sales
text: The music video for Notorious B.I.G.’s song “Big Poppa” has dancing and gambling, a thumping rhythm and a young Sean “P. Diddy” Combs sitting in a hot tub surrounded by scantily clad women.

headline: In Bodrum, Turkey, a Hotel for Art and Artists
text: This spring, guests at Casa Dell’Arte will have access to a white sand beach, Balinese and deep-tissue massage and workshops with the Pakistani experimental video artist and provocateur Basir Mahmood.

headline: Grand Jury Won’t Be Convened in Florida Teenager’s Killing
text: The special prosecutor appointed to investigate the killing of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin said Monday that she had decided not to convene a grand jury in the case, which incited protests nationwide after the local authorities in Sanford, Fla., decided not to pursue charges against the crime watch volunteer who shot the unarmed teenager.

headline: Occupy Spring Training
text: Occupy Wall Street protestors gather to practice tactics they say will keep them cohesive and strong when they demonstrate again in May.

headline: 2 Tulsa Shooting Suspects Confess, Police Say
text: TULSA, Okla. — The two men accused of killing three black people and wounding two others in shootings that terrified this city over the Easter weekend confessed to the police shortly after their arrest Sunday morning, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Braised Squid With Artichokes
text: Mark Bittman prepares a dish he brought back from Italy: a simple braise with artichokes and squid.

headline: Looks as if a Hawk Egg Is Hatching
text: While we can’t count hawks until they’ve hatched, it sure looks as if there is a hole in one of the eggs in the Hawk Cam nest high outside the New York University president’s office high above Washington Square Park, the kind that is made by a baby hawk pecking its way to daylight. Folks on the chat room noticed it around 1:30 p.m. today — Day 34 after an egg was spotted in the nest and well into the expected hatch window.

headline: The Minimalist: Braised Squid With Artichokes
text: I did an artichoke recipe just about every year I wrote the Minimalist column. This one, a simple braise of artichokes and squid, was inspired by a trip to Liguria, a region in northwest Italy. The cooking is absurdly easy, but the prep is not. Artichokes are a nuisance to clean, and there are only two ways around it. One is to use frozen hearts, and that kills the dish, and the other is to move to Europe, where artichokes are sold pre-trimmed. There are men and women who work in the markets in Italy who clean artichokes by the case; they can trim down to the heart in about 10 seconds. Literally.

headline: The Campster | Spring Trail Accessories
text: With winter weather relenting and fiddleheads beginning to pop up, it seems spring is officially here. Which, for some of us, means getting back to sleeping under the stars. Yes, it might be a little muddy on the trail, but the rivers are high and the edibles abundant. And with fewer clothing layers to bring along, your pack will have just enough spare room to fit these spring essentials.

headline: Rangers Prepare by Looking at Themselves
text: When the Rangers begin their first-round playoff series against the Ottawa Senators on Thursday night, it will be the first time the franchise has had home-ice advantage in the postseason since 1996. Despite finishing the season on a sour note Saturday by losing a game to the Washington Capitals and the Presidents’ Trophy to the Vancouver Canucks, the anticipation was not diminished.

headline: At 20, Camden Yards Tries to Keep Up
text: BALTIMORE — At age 20, Oriole Park at Camden Yards is not a relic in disrepair. Yet, as the Yankees will discover during their three-game series against the Orioles that started Monday night, the stadium has undergone a modest face-lift that is partly a response to what newer ballparks have done since 1992.

headline: Against Nashville, the Wings Will Rely on Their Experience
text: The Detroit Red Wings are not surprised to be starting the playoffs by facing the Nashville Predators, as that showdown has seemingly been locked in for the last two weeks.  The only unknown was who would take the fourth seed, gaining the home ice advantage over the fifth seed.

headline: Musical by David Byrne and Fatboy Slim Part of Next Public Theater Season
text: The Public Theater announced on Monday that its 2012-13 season will include two new musicals: A three-hour adaptation of Edna Ferber’s novel “Giant,” with a score by Michael John LaChiusa (“Hello Again,” “Queen of the Mist”), and a deconstruction of the rise and fall of Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, by the musicians David Byrne and Fatboy Slim.

headline: Owing a Debt to Europe’s Woes
text: Europe may be in crisis, but that is proving to be a boon for the Continent’s filmmakers. Economic austerity, social, religious and generational conflict, immigration from the Islamic world — all those concerns and more have helped contribute to a bumper crop of movies for the fourth annual Disappearing Act European film festival in Manhattan that reflect, and reflect upon, current realities.

headline: Caucus Click: Easter Tradition at the White House
text: A Secret Service agent helped a child at President Obama’s Easter egg roll at the White House.

headline: Brush Fires Across Region Are Spread by High Winds
text: Updated Tuesday April 10 | Driven by high, fast-shifting winds, a five-alarm brush fire swept through the former Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island on Monday and burned until 4 a.m. Tuesday morning, fire official ssaid.

headline: With Concepts in Manhattan, Chevrolet Tries to Ignite Design Students’ Interest
text: Before press previews for the 2012 New York auto show, Nick David, the Chevrolet senior exterior designer credited with the Tru 140S concept car, met with students from the design program at the Pratt Institute. He was joined by marketing manager John McFarland.

headline: Caregiving as a ‘Roller-Coaster Ride From Hell’
text: More than 40 million women are the primary caregivers for a sick person, very often the man they are married to. Caregiving, after all, is a wife’s expected role, and most accept it perforce as a duty that offers precious time to express love and wishes, settle financial and legal matters, and right past wrongs.

headline: Instagram Signals Break in Facebook’s Deal-Making Style
text: Facebook’s $1 billion takeover of Instagram is notable in many ways, including size. But it’s also the first time the social-networking titan didn’t strike a deal almost entirely for the programming talent of its target.

headline: Finding a Sitter for Your Dog, via the Web
text: Sites like Airbnb enable people to rent an extra bed in their apartment to travelers. A new site called Rover.com lets you rent your lap to dogs when their owners are out of town.

headline: Many More Indie Films Are Released, but Not Very Widely, Study Finds
text: LOS ANGELES — Toward the back of an annual statistical download last month from the Motion Picture Association of America were some numbers that reveal the changing contours of film distribution in the United States.

headline: Provençal Spinach Gratin
text: There are a few versions of spinach gratin in Provence (there it is called a tian). This one is all about spinach – no eggs or cheese, just spinach and lots of garlic, a bit of flour to absorb moisture and hold everything together, and bread crumbs to make the top nice and crisp.

headline: Allure of Online Browsing Leads Couple to Dalliances
text: Brandt Johnson’s “Just Sex” is set in the present, but perhaps it’s better to think of it as a comedy of manners from the turn of the century — the 21st century.

headline: Protesters Hold ‘Spring Training’ at Zuccotti Park
text: About 100 people were gathered inside Zuccotti Park on Friday as Zak Solomon stood on a granite bench and offered instruction on protest tactics with names like “Melt,” “Wall,” and “The People’s Gong.”

headline: Rocking and Rolling to ’60s Racial Tension in Omaha
text: You’d think a play about riots, race, rape, the late 1960s, murder and jazz would be explosive. That “My Occasion of Sin” is based on a real-life tragedy should only fan the flames. Instead this play by Monica Bauer about events in her hometown, Omaha, is preachy and slow, clunking with inconsistent characterization and force-fed symbolism.

headline: Setting a Budget (Set to a Hip-Hop Beat)
text: Many teenagers do not get excited about topics like money management and investing. But some of them might take notice of a new hip-hop video titled “Time Is Money,” in which Syretha Shirley, a high school sophomore in Las Vegas, raps about, of all things, her checking account.

headline: Years After Acid Horror, Suicide Stirs Pakistan
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Fakhra Younas went under the surgeon’s knife 38 times, hoping to repair the gruesome damage inflicted by a vengeful Pakistani man who had doused her face in acid a decade earlier, virtually melting her mouth, nose and ears.

headline: Photo Replay: April 9
text: The day in sports included the European weight lifting championships in Turkey; English Premier League soccer matches; and the Phillies’ home opener in Philadelphia.

headline: A Creator Specializes in Getting Close Up
text: The young choreographer Avi Scher likes to say that he has a mission: presenting top-quality ballet dancers in intimate spaces at affordable prices. On Saturday at the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater, all elements of that formula were in place, including Herman Cornejo of American Ballet Theater. But so was the final, fatal ingredient: Mr. Scher’s choreography.

headline: Bush-Era Torture: A Dissenting View
text: We know that President George W. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and their lieutenants did not like dissenting viewpoints. The justification for the invasion of Iraq depended on the muzzling of anyone who doubted the existence of weapons of mass destruction, and for the most part political appointees fell into line after that point. Jack Goldsmith, who withdrew the Bybee memo justifying torture before resigning from the Office of Legal Counsel, was a notable exception.

headline: Diving With Care
text: The first comprehensive map of the Titanic’s resting place should help prevent further damage by visitors to the site.

headline: Setting the Stage for the Titanic Tragedy
text: New research suggests that a series of celestial and atmospheric events may have affected the Titanic disaster and rescue attempts, 100 years ago this week.

headline: Live From the Cutting Room Floor
text: I was a guest on “Up w/Chris Hayes” Saturday, talking, it seemed, about everything: a bit of an ambitious agenda. When I go back, the conversation will continue.

headline: Drilling Down: What Small Businesses Should Know About Crowdfunding
text: In this week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we quoted from a blog post in which Ryan Caldbeck gave three reasons why crowdfunding will be good for investors. We went back to Mr. Caldbeck, who helped found crowdfunding site CircleUp, to talk about what small businesses need to know about the sites.

headline: Judge Tells Bloomberg to Release 911 Report
text: A state judge ordered Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday to release what is said to be a sharply critical report on New York’s costly, much-delayed emergency dispatch system, but gave the city a week to appeal.

headline: The Short, Explosive Rise in Instagram’s Valuation
text: It’s safe to say that few companies have experienced as rapid a rise in valuation as Instagram.

headline: Victory Built on Creativity and One Spectacular Shot
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: Similar Moves, Echoed in Different Dances
text: At Joyce SoHo on Thursday, Sydney Skybetter’s dancers looked attractive in the grays and blacks of Karen Young’s tasteful costumes. Kate Ashton lighted them dimly from the side and below, casting their shadows on a wall. To music that was liturgical in sound if not in origin, the skilled dancers swirled prettily, stretching a leg behind them at hip level and rotating like turnstiles.

headline: A Master of Verse Spreads Bad Cheer
text: “Deprivation is for me,” Philip Larkin once observed, “what daffodils were for Wordsworth.” He was right, of course: unhappiness, loss, disappointment, boredom and fear of death are the bread and butter of his verse. Larkin was the Eeyore of poets, the Debbie Downer of modern literature. The familiar T-shirt — “Life’s a Bitch and Then You Die” — pretty much sums up the central theme of his work.

headline: A Sense of Glasnost at a Carnegie Keyboard
text: Judging by his enjoyable concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, the Russian-American pianist Maxim Anikushin has a genuine affinity for the music of Samuel Barber. In 2010 Mr. Anikushin performed a Barber concert in honor of that composer’s centennial, and he is working on a disc of his music for Albany Records.

headline: Hunger Strike
text: With her severe bob and heavy line of red lipstick, the author Herta Müller looks like she fell out of an Otto Dix painting. After Müller won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2009, one critic sniped that she should get a new haircut, lest foreigners assume that’s how all German women look. Other reactions to the Nobel news were more basic: “Herta who?”

headline: After a Frustrating Season, Dubinsky Is Ready for a New Chapter
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Forward Brandon Dubinsky used the word nightmare here Monday to describe his part of the regular season just past. It was part of a remarkable self-analysis that Dubinsky conducted for reporters after the Rangers’ first practice ahead of Thursday’s playoff opener against Ottawa.

headline: 110 in the Shade
text: Q. Will climate change affect the incidence of diseases and medical conditions?

headline: Mike Daisey to Develop New Work With Cape Cod Theater Project
text: Despite being found to have fabricated details in his one-man show “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” Mike Daisey will lead off the season at the Cape Cod Theater Project this summer.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: It’s official: Raf Simons has a new gig.

headline: TimesCast | Turkey and Syria Clash
text: April 9, 2012 — Turkish officials accused the Syrian military of shooting at refugees inside Turkey for the first time.

headline: Rushdie Among Those Who Respond to Israel’s Ban of Günter Grass
text: On Sunday Israel’s interior minister, Eli Yishai, declared the author Günter Grass unwelcome in Israel. This came after a controversial poem by Mr. Grass was published in the German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung. The poem, “What Must Be Said,” is not being analyzed for its rhyme scheme. In it, Mr. Grass writes: “Why do I say only now, / Aged and with my last ink, / That the nuclear power of Israel endangers / The already fragile world peace?”

headline: Tending a Sick Comrade Has Benefits for Ants
text: When one ant in a colony has an infection, the others don’t avoid their sick comrade. Instead, they approach the infected ant and lick it to remove pathogens.

headline: Improvisation Mixed, Reflected and Remixed
text: Even when you have an iPod, there are those moments in New York life when you find yourself witnessing uncomfortable private moments: a couple, bickering on a subway platform and going at each other with barely disguised fury — in the form of eye-rolling, crossed arms and furrowed brows. In “other stories,” Alexandra Beller has created and directed a work about these everyday occurrences, and while I’d like to be supportive about giving life experiences meaning through dance, it’s just painful.

headline: Treating Sleep Apnea Without the Mask
text: About 28 million Americans have sleep apnea, which causes repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night, sometimes resulting in loud snoring and gasps for air. For decades, the standard treatment has been “continuous positive airway pressure.” A mask worn at night pushes air into the nasal passages, enabling easier breathing. C.P.A.P. reduces and in some cases completely prevents episodes of apnea.

headline: Spring Vacation Means Hit Broadway Shows Reap the Benefits of Higher Ticket Prices
text: The start of April school vacations led some Broadway producers to charge high premium prices for more seats last week because of family and tourist demand, and as a result several of the shows – “Wicked,” “The Lion King,” “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” and “The Book of Mormon” – brought in huge sums per person on average, according to weekly box office data published on Monday.

headline: The Titanic 100 years later; the science of science festivals; and rethinking the value of pets.
text: The Titanic 100 years later; the science of science festivals; and rethinking the value of pets.

headline: An Italian Soprano’s Salon Songs
text: During the triumphant New York recital debut of the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, it was hard to keep from being a little upset with her. Here was a remarkable artist in her prime at 51, a musically intelligent and vocally splendid singer with a significant career in Europe who has been embraced by discerning maestros like Riccardo Muti.

headline: Afghan Killings and an Amnesia Defense
text: In several interviews, the lawyer for Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier accused of murdering 17 Afghan civilians last month, has said that his client does not remember much from the night of the shootings. “He has some memories of before the incident, and he has some memories of after the incident,” the lawyer, John Henry Browne, said. “In between, very little.”

headline: Dempsey Does It Again
text: Chelsea may be heading to the first leg in the semifinals of the Champions League next week, but Fulham’s American international Clint Dempsey is certainly headed for a prodigious payday sometime soon, real soon.

headline: Films That Allow the Elusive to Elude
text: It’s safe to say that there never was a choreographer with a greater appetite for performing at different locations than Merce Cunningham. Over the decades his company danced not just in a wide variety of theaters and galleries, but also in the Piazza San Marco in Venice; beside the ocean in Perth, Australia; in the Royal Albert Hall in London; in the ruins at Persepolis; and in  Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Impatience to Get Thin Sends Some to Canada
text: Tammy Kwarciak, a 44-year-old nurse whose weight had been creeping up for years, was determined to lose 50 pounds. So in February, she drove from her home in Port Huron, Mich., across the border into Canada and had a small balloonlike device inserted into her stomach.

headline: Seeking Robots to Go Where First Responders Can’t
text: In the event of another disaster at a nuclear power plant, the first responders may not be humans but robots. They may not even look humanoid.

headline: Limbaugh to Leave AM Station in Philadelphia
text: “The Rush Limbaugh Show” is leaving the dominant conservative talk radio station in Philadelphia, one of the biggest radio markets in the country.

headline: TimesCast | Nuclear Talks to Resume
text: April 9, 2012 — Iran sends mixed signals days before the planned resumption of nuclear talks with global powers.

headline: Let Grannie Go
text: One of the first posts I wrote for this blog was on the Supreme Court’s first ruling of this term, Cavazos v. Smith. Shirley Ree Smith was found guilty in a 1997 California trial of shaking her seven-week-old grandson to death, and sentenced to 15 years to life. But the Ninth Circuit overturned the conviction, arguing that there was “no demonstrable support” for it.

headline: ‘Carrie’ Revival, Now Dead, Has an Autopsy
text: After achieving notoriety as a nightmarishly campy, $8 million flop on Broadway in 1988, the musical “Carrie” rose from the ashes as a fervently earnest, $1.5 million revival Off Broadway this winter, and ran for 80 performances, or about four times as many as the original production had. But the second coming it wasn’t.

headline: Regulators Sue Silicon Valley Entrepreneur
text: Benedict Van was trying to make a name for himself in Silicon Valley. For two years, the entrepreneur would crisscross California, paying house visits to investors in hopes of raising cash for a pair of online start-ups he founded.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Humanoid Robots and Unlocking iPhones
text: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Marriott Says It Stopped Ad Service Hidden in Wi-Fi
text: Last week, the Courtyard by Marriott hotel in Midtown Manhattan was discovered to come with some hidden extras: The free Wi-Fi connection inserted lines of code for serving special ads into every Web page a guest visited.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mexico and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Mexico, Pakistan, Delaware and Tunisia.

headline: Socialsecuritymedicareandmedicaid Strikes Again
text: Jared Bernstein and Dean Baker are both mad, understandably, at Robert Samuelson, who pulls out, for the 7 millionth time, the old Social Security bait and switch. Here’s how it works: to make the quite mild financial shortfall of Social Security seem apocalyptic, the writer starts out by talking about Social Security, then starts using numbers that combine SS with the health care programs — programs that are very different in conception, financing, and solutions.

headline: Despite Good Health, Bank Holds Tight to TARP Funds
text: It’s the bank bailout mystery.

headline: An Olympian Camera Bag, Now for Mortals
text: Lowepro has built a camera bag of Olympic proportions.

headline: The Campaign Shifts to the General Election
text: With Mitt Romney now more than halfway toward the 1,144 delegates needed for the G.O.P. nomination, and President Obama engaging him, the battle lines for the general election are coming into view.

headline: A School Lottery That Favors Needy Children
text: Children’s Aid College Prep has a space in Morrisania and a new principal in place, and interviews for teachers are under way. All it needs are the children. But the charter school's lottery to fill its 120 initial seats, which took place Monday morning, was slightly different from other school lotteries, with extra weight given to children with high needs.

headline: Grassley Assailed for Calling Obama ‘Stupid’ on Twitter
text: United States Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican from Iowa, started a Twitter argument over the health care overhaul law last weekend when he called President Obama “stupid,” prompting Mr. Obama’s chief strategist, David Axelrod, to suggest a “6-year-old” had hijacked the senator’s account to embarrass him.

headline: A Celebration of Science With a Popular Touch
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — With the applause just winding down for a scantily clad all-girl rock band, John Durant climbed onstage, carrying his 2-year-old son.

headline: 1000 Fifth Avenue, 3:07 P.M.
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art broke its never-open-on-a-Monday rule this week in honor of spring break at city schools.

headline: An iPhone Case Ready for a Dunking
text: Many waterproof iPhone cases turn the sleek device into a oversized lump with all the elegance of a 1950s diving bell.

headline: More Brainpower Seen in Soccer’s Top Scorers
text: Brawny athletes are rarely brainy, or so the stereotype goes. But a new study reports that soccer players actually have superior executive functions, the brain processes responsible for planning and abstract thinking. And the more elite the player, the better these functions.

headline: Changes in Social Status Seen in Gene Regulation in Monkeys
text: Social stress is known to have adverse health effects on both humans and primates.

headline: Tunisia Cracks Down Again on Protesters Defying a Ban
text: CAIRO — The six-month-old government of Tunisia cracked down with tear gas and batons Monday on thousands of protesters who filled a central artery of the capital in defiance of a new ban on demonstrations there.

headline: American Hostages Taken in Iran
text: On November 4, 1979, Iranian students stormed the the American embassy in Tehran starting a hostage crisis that would persist for the next 444 days.

headline: Growing the Numbers (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s Never a Good Time (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fox Renews Three Shows
text: Fox on Monday gave new season orders to three shows: “New Girl,” “Raising Hope” and “Glee.” The move came a little more than a month before the network sets its next season schedule and shares it with advertisers. Now the producers and writers of those shows can breathe a little easier and make plans for their next seasons. “All three of these comedies add a fresh and distinctive flavor to our Tuesday nights, and I’m really happy to bring them back,” Kevin Reilly, president of entertainment for Fox Broadcasting, said in a statement. “New Girl,” starring Zooey Deschanel, above, had its premiere last fall and is the No. 1 new scripted series this season among viewers ages 18 to 34. “Raising Hope” isn’t as popular but it held up well when it was moved into an 8 p.m. time slot recently. As for “Glee,” its future involves following its glee club characters after they graduate from high school at the end of this season.

headline: Can Fido and Whiskers Enrich Children’s Lives?
text: In this era of mommy confessionals, I must admit: I am not a pet person. With their allergic father, I have reared three children without benefit of in-house canines, felines or invited rodents.

headline: New Songs From Old Materials
text: SPIRITUALIZED“Sweet Heart, Sweet Light”(Fat Possum)

headline: A Health Crisis Strikes. Then What?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is This the Sound of Bubble Ready to Pop?
text: Yes, $1 billion dollars is a lot of money for a company with $0 in revenue.

headline: Barney McKenna, Banjo Player in the Dubliners, Dies at 72
text: Barney McKenna, whose racing, raucous and often lyrically haunting banjo playing helped propel the Irish folk band the Dubliners to fame, died on Thursday at his home in Dublin. The last of the original members of the band, he was 72.

headline: For Reservas, No Cellar Required
text: IT’S accepted wisdom today that most wine drinkers do not have the money, the storage space or the patience to wait years as their bottles age to maturity. Consumers expect wines to be ready, or at least enjoyable, immediately after they buy them.

headline: Günter Grass’s Poem, and the Israeli Reaction
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bill to Help Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Let the Faculty Teach
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Independent Scotland?
text: To the Editor:

headline: You Say Tomato, I Say Oosthuizen
text: Spelling Louis Oosthuizen’s out-of-Afrikaans surname is easier than figuring out how to pronounce it.

headline: Tsunami Projections Offer Bleak Fate for Many Japanese Towns
text: KUROSHIO, Japan — The simulations shocked this sleepy community on the tip of Japan’s Shikoku island: a huge undersea quake could bring a tsunami as high as 112 feet here, a government-appointed expert panel said. The waves could arrive in minutes and engulf most of the town, swallowing up even the foothills that the residents had counted on for high ground.

headline: For Mets’ Bullpen, Too Much of a Good Thing May Not Be So Good
text: Among the many sources of optimism during the Mets’ three-game winning streak to open the season, the bullpen stood out.

headline: The Campaign Shifts to the General Election
text: With Mitt Romney now more than halfway toward the 1,144 delegates needed for the Republican nomination, and President Obama directly engaging him, the battle lines for the general election are coming into view. Graphic

headline: Microsoft’s AOL Deal Intensifies Patent Wars
text: The global gold rush in technology patents gained speed on Monday when Microsoft agreed to pay more than $1 billion for 800 patents held by AOL.

headline: AT&T’s Lumia Salespeople Don’t Seem So Hot for the Phone
text: AT&T has poured loads of money into advertising Nokia’s new Lumia 900 phone, but if a visit to four stores in New York is any guide, AT&T store employees don’t seem that sold on the device.

headline: After Yankees’ Slow Start, Only Girardi Does the Talking
text: BALTIMORE — Even after the Yankees were swept by Tampa Bay in a season-opening series, Manager Joe Girardi did not hear from Hal Steinbrenner, the club’s managing general partner. Girardi insisted that it was “par for the course” and that conversations with Steinbrenner usually took place when Steinbrenner attends a Yankees homestand.

headline: Brands Cheer Their Virtues With Anniversary Candles
text: IF Madison Avenue had its own hit parade or Hot 100, “The Anniversary Waltz” might be the top song of 2012.

headline: New Chief Selected at Avon
text: Battered by the recession, Johnson & Johnson turned in 2009 to Sherilyn S. McCoy, a longtime executive who had joined the company as a scientist in 1982, to overhaul the company’s pharmaceutical division. It was a wrenching process that involved reorganizing the business at a time when patents on important drugs were expiring.

headline: Food Stamps Helped Reduce Poverty Rate, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — A new study by the Agriculture Department has found that food stamps, one of the country’s largest social safety net programs, reduced the poverty rate substantially during the recent recession. The food stamp program, formally known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, reduced the poverty rate by nearly 8 percent in 2009, the most recent year included in the study, a significant impact for a social program whose effects often go unnoticed by policy makers.

headline: Toyota, Eschewing Sedate Design, Is Ready for Pizazz
text: TOYOTA CITY, Japan — After decades of emphasizing staid reliability, Toyota wants to start running with the cool kids.

headline: Facebook Makes a Play for Mobile With Its Instagram Scoop
text: Why did Facebook just spend “about $1 billion” on a photo sharing site that is entirely free and has no immediate way to make money?

headline: Fans React to Surprising Start
text: After the Mets started the season with a string of wins, fans are cautiously enthusiastic about the team’s prospects.

headline: Mets Fans Revel, for Now, in an Undefeated Season
text: Enjoy it. Brag about it. Dine out on it.

headline: N.E.A. Is Said to Cut Aid to Arts Programs on PBS
text: The National Endowment for the Arts, a major supporter of PBS shows devoted to performing arts and independent documentaries, is proposing substantial cuts in their financing.

headline: Anthony, Playing His Way, Is Scorer the Knicks Expected
text: The shots were deep, timely and bold — the kind that alter fates, reshape impressions and restore faith. Carmelo Anthony launched them Sunday afternoon, and when the net swished, there was no doubt in the air at Madison Square Garden, only happy delirium.

headline: Some Explaining to Do for Republican Leader
text: WASHINGTON — By definition, the majority leader of the House has the majority of incumbents to protect in an election. So it came as something of a shock when House Republicans learned that a political action committee affiliated with Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, who currently holds that leadership slot, had donated $25,000 to a group devoted solely to taking out incumbents.

headline: E.P.A. Denies an Environmental Group’s Request to Ban a Widely Used Weed Killer
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday said that the widely used herbicide 2,4-D would remain on the market, denying a petition from an environmental group that sought to revoke the chemical’s approval.

headline: Let’s Keep Our Hands Off the Emergency Oil Supply
text: AS oil and gasoline prices rise, political pressure to tap the roughly 700 million barrels in the national Strategic Petroleum Reserve is building, including among some in Congress. The global oil market is fundamentally strained and suffering from an array of unwelcome but unremarkable problems. Yet the oil reserve is neither designed nor well equipped to address these chronic weaknesses. Instead it should be preserved to address an emergency disruption in supply.

headline: For the Elderly, Emergency Rooms of Their Own
text: Phyllis Spielberger, a retired hat seller at Bendel’s, picked at a plastic dish of beets and corn as her husband, Jason, sat at the foot of her hospital bed, telling her to eat.

headline: Practicing Prudence in Picking Travel Cards
text: WITH all these frantic credit card merchants beseeching me these days, I feel as if I’m a tourist wandering the Marrakesh souk. “Joseph! Last chance to earn 35,000 bonus miles!” implores a new e-mail message from Delta Air Lines for its Gold Delta SkyMiles credit card from American Express.

headline: The Indios, Once the Pride of Ciudad Juárez
text: A soccer team that made an improbable rise buoyed a city riven by violence. Now the team is gone, although the violence remains.

headline: In the Diamond Business, but Not Wearing Them
text: EVEN as a child, I loved the thought of flying. I remember having a book detailing the logos of almost every airline in the world. Today, nothing breaks up the monotony of a long stay on a tarmac more than finding a new airline logo and trying to figure out its origin.

headline: Bring the Justices Back to Earth
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: A Costly Toy Subsidized by Others
text: When the numbers don’t seem to add up, it’s worth asking some questions.

headline: Team of Hope, Gone in City of Violence
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Returning to the soccer stadium here, I feel like an archaeologist on a dig. Fine brown sand dusts the stadium’s concrete steps and concourses. Pigeons roost in the rafters, Pollocking plastic bucket seats that spell out “Indios,” the name of the team that no longer plays here, that no longer even exists. Worshiped in their time, the Indios lie dead, entombed in Mexican memories like Moctezuma himself.

headline: Mobile Card-Processing Machines for Marketers on the Road
text: People do not carry as much cash as they once did, relying instead on debit and credit cards for even a cup of coffee. But until recently, entrepreneurs, trade show exhibitors and other small-business people who sell products on the road had to lug around a bulky machine and a stack of paper slips to process the cards, or risk losing business.

headline: Evidence in Science and Religion, Part Two
text: In the post previous to this one, I revisited the question of the place of evidence in the discourses and practices of science and religion. I was prompted by a discussion on the the show “Up w/ Chris Hayes” (MSNBC, March 25) in which Steven Pinker and Richard Dawkins stated with great force and confidence that a key difference between science and religion is that the conclusions of the former are based on evidence that has emerged in the course of rigorous rational inquiry publicly conducted, while the conclusions of the latter are based on dogma, faith, unexamined authority, subjectivity and mere trust.

headline: Fanfare for the Comma Man
text: Is it safe to talk about punctuation again? Eight years ago, Lynne Truss’s best-selling “Eats, Shoots & Leaves” took, in the words of her subtitle, a “Zero Tolerance Approach” to the subject. Although Truss’s focus on errors drew the ire, if not the fire, of grammarians, linguists and other “descriptivists,” her book was, for the most part, harmless and legitimate. Still, it overlooked a lot. Maybe more than any other element of writing, punctuation combines rules with issues of sound, preference and personal style. And as Truss didn’t adequately acknowledge, even the rules change over time.

headline: A Work-and-Save Project in Bangladesh: It Makes a Village
text: SOMESHPUR, Bangladesh — The village of Someshpur is a ragged collection of huts made of metal sheeting and thatch. Children scamper among the chickens in the unpaved square. The village, like the rest of Bangladesh, struggles to make ends meet.

headline: ‘Major’ Violations Reported at Baylor
text: The joy ride of the 2011-12 Baylor athletic season appears to have hit a speed bump. A report released Monday revealed violations in the university’s men’s and women’s basketball programs that the N.C.A.A. deemed “major.”

headline: Former Skeptic Now Embraces Divisive Tactic
text: Twelve years back, a former New York police commissioner spoke with disdain of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s get-tough police tactics, particularly the stopping and frisking of thousands of men, most of them black or Latino.

headline: Raising the Floor on Pay
text: As the nation’s economy slowly recovers and income inequality emerges as a crucial issue in the presidential campaign, lawmakers are facing growing pressure to raise the minimum wage, which was last increased at the federal level to $7.25 an hour in July 2009.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 9, 2012

headline: A Lie Races Across Twitter Before the Truth Can Boot Up
text: It took only two minutes. An unfounded report on a little-known blog claiming that Gov. Nikki R. Haley was about to be indicted rocketed from South Carolina political circles into national circulation, along the way becoming the latest lesson in the perils of an instantaneous news culture.

headline: Release of City Teachers’ Rankings Prompts Lawmakers to Weigh Limiting Access
text: Ever since New York City’s Education Department released 18,000 public-school teachers’ performance rankings, generating news coverage about the lowest and highest scorers, there has been talk in Albany of preventing a repeat.

headline: A Shift in Strategy in Pennsylvania for Romney
text: Mitt Romney’s attempt to pull off a victory in Rick Santorum’s home state of Pennsylvania was all set to go into overdrive Monday with attack ads highlighting how voters there soundly rejected him in his 2006 Senate race.

headline: In French Vote, Sound and Fury From the Left
text: PARIS — They sang “The Internationale,” carried red flags and shouted “Resistance!” They booed whenever the word “rich” was pronounced, and they applauded when their leader, Jean-Luc Mélenchon, called the far right “professional racists” and the Socialist candidate “a pedal-boat captain.”

headline: The Two Economies
text: The creative dynamism of American business is astounding and a little terrifying. Over the past five years, amid turmoil and uncertainty, American businesses have shed employees, becoming more efficient and more productive. According to The Wall Street Journal on Monday, the revenue per employee at S.&P. 500 companies increased from $378,000 in 2007 to $420,000 in 2011.

headline: Obama Candidate Sketches Vision for World Bank
text: WASHINGTON — Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the anthropologist and physician who is President Obama’s surprise choice to run the World Bank, does not have a detailed public record laying out his views of economic development, the bank’s central mission. He is not a development scholar nor, like previous presidents, a banker or foreign policy éminence grise.

headline: Fed Chief Seeks More ‘Resiliency’
text: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, called on regulators Monday to stem risks from financial institutions operating beyond traditional oversight and favored steps to promote the “resiliency” of money market funds.

headline: Football and Swahili
text: I was at the University of North Carolina when I heard the Swahili anecdote.

headline: A Sacred Peak With Rich Ore Deposits
text: The Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes in Montana are seeking to have a mountain peak listed on the National Register of Historic Places in the hope of calling attention to a copper and silver mining company’s plans to burrow beneath it. The tribe has traditionally used the site, Chicago Peak, for praying, fasting and seeking visions.

headline: National Database Planned to Combat Cellphone Theft
text: WASHINGTON — The soaring popularity of smartphones has produced an unwelcome, if predictable, side effect: an epidemic of smartphone thefts.

headline: Minaya’s Imprint Is Seen All Over the Mets’ Lineup
text: Omar Minaya was vacationing with his family in Florida on Monday, reacquainting himself with his wife and children after the grind of spring training. Even so, he plans to sneak away now and then to see prospects for the coming amateur draft. Scouting is Minaya’s passion, and now his eyes belong to the San Diego Padres.

headline: Killing of Bangladeshi Labor Organizer Signals an Escalation in Violence
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A labor activist who was arrested two years ago for his role in protests against low wages in Bangladesh’s garment industry was found murdered outside this city last week, labor rights advocates and the police said on Monday.

headline: Even as Violent Crime Falls, Killing of Officers Rises
text: WASHINGTON — As violent crime has decreased across the country, a disturbing trend has emerged: rising numbers of police officers are being killed.

headline: Contentment’s Elusive Recipe
text: Long before chefs were made of iron and “barefoot” brought to mind “contessa” and a cultured 9-year-old could tell farfalle from fusilli at 10 feet, an anxious Southern man named Craig Claiborne sat on a remote island in the Pacific and plotted to turn the American culinary world on its head.

headline: A Rockier Pathway to Work
text: Hundreds of thousands of unemployed people are desperate for new skills to pull them back into the job market, but when they visit a job-training center, they are often turned away. As Motoko Rich reported in The Times on Monday, Seattle’s seven centers had money to train only 5 percent of the 120,000 people who came in last year seeking new skills, and the numbers are similar elsewhere.

headline: Despite Warning, Old Handouts Die Hard for Greek Politicians Facing Voters Soon
text: ATHENS — With the country perched on the edge of a financial abyss and international creditors anxiously awaiting more belt-tightening measures, Greek lawmakers have been working extra hard lately. But not always in the ways one might expect.

headline: President Assad’s Latest Bluff
text: The international community’s latest attempt to stop President Bashar al-Assad’s reign of terror in Syria is failing. Instead of abiding by a commitment to a cease-fire negotiated with the United Nations, he has kept his killing machine rolling, raising the death toll to an estimated 9,000 Syrians in the year since the start of the uprising.

headline: An Exchange of Views
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a very clever debut today by Gregory Philip Butler, and we’ll learn more about him in a bit. Meanwhile, however, I will say that I appreciated the twist of finding the ROLE REVERSAL, or “ELOR,” in the middle of each of the three theme entries; a little extra “something” is what distinguishes this from a Monday puzzle.

headline: Corrections: April 10
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Bogus Challenge to Cigarette Warnings
text: The tobacco industry has never been bashful about fighting back against attempts to regulate the promotion of its deadly, addictive products. The latest is an effort to derail new regulations requiring large health warnings on cigarette packages by making baseless First Amendment claims. It is the subject of an important case being heard on Tuesday by a federal appeals court in Washington.

headline: Prosecutor in Martin Case Will Alone Determine Its Merits
text: MIAMI — Angela B. Corey, a Republican state attorney with a reputation for toughness, has decided not to seek a grand jury review of the Trayvon Martin shooting, keeping the resolution of a case that has transfixed the nation solely in her hands.

headline: Pulling Back From the Exurbs
text: The view from a helicopter over the outer edges of Las Vegas in about 2004, at the height of the housing bubble, was of sprawl overtaking desert as fast as builders could throw up framing and lay on the stucco and roofing tiles. People were flooding in. The Clark County School District was hiring 2,000 teachers a year.

headline: The President, Gas Prices and the Pipeline
text: Like every president seeking re-election, Barack Obama walks the fine line every day between the discordant goals of motivating his party’s strongest loyalists and reaching out to swing voters for their support. A few weeks ago, that pathway took him to a tiny town in Oklahoma, where, caught between the anti-drilling demands of the environmental community and the thirst for more affordable gasoline from unions, business owners and drivers, the president announced his support for building half of an oil pipeline.

headline: Minimum Wage or More
text: New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Illinois are among the states considering raising the minimum wage.

headline: Brazil and U.S. Accentuate the Positive
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Dilma Rousseff’s first visit to Washington as Brazil’s president was certainly cordial enough.

headline: Nova Looks Sharp, Offense Clicks and the Yankees Win
text: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira waited throughout the winter and spring for the Yankees to line up after a game and shake hands. Most starters depart the ballpark by the ninth inning of spring training games, so the first opportunity for a victorious postgame procession needed to come in the regular season. The Yankees waited three games longer than they hoped, but on Monday they finally secured a 6-2 victory.

headline: Lush Walls Rise to Fight a Blanket of Pollution
text: MEXICO CITY — “We must cultivate our garden,” Voltaire famously wrote at the end of “Candide,” but even he could not have imagined this: a towering arch of 50,000 plants rising over a traffic-clogged avenue in a metropolis once called “Mexsicko City” because of its pollution.

headline: Pennsylvania: Nun Testifies About Being Fired
text: A Roman Catholic nun testified Monday that she was fired from her job as director of religious education at a Pennsylvania parish after reporting her suspicions about a priest who had been convicted of receiving child pornography. Sister Joan Scary said at the landmark sexual abuse trial of two priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia that she reported her suspicions about another priest, Edward M. DePaoli, to Cardinal Anthony J. Bevilacqua in 1996. Father DePaoli, who was convicted on child pornography charges in 1986 and sentenced to probation, had been receiving magazines of a sexual nature at an office where Sister Scary worked. In May 1996, she said she sent one of the magazines to Cardinal Bevilacqua with an anonymous note expressing her concern. She told the court that the Rev. James Gormley, the pastor of the parish where she was working, later fired her. Judge M. Teresa Sarmina said she allowed prosecutors to refer to other abuse cases to allow jurors to understand the church’s pattern of response.

headline: Rhode Island: Bill Would Ban Dogs on Drivers’ Laps
text: A bill in the General Assembly would prohibit motorists from driving with dogs in their laps. A first offense would draw a fine of $85, and a second $100. The State Traffic Tribunal would hear the cases. The bill was introduced by State Representative Peter G. Palumbo and has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee.

headline: So-So Start for Pelfrey; Big Finish for Mets
text: The giddiness of unforeseen perfection will continue in Queens for at least another day.

headline: One Sick Dog, One Steep Bill
text: Is it ethical to spend $25,000 at the vet? Is it O.K. to have a pet if you can't afford such treatments?

headline: We Have a Baby Hawk!
text: Updated, 8 a.m. Tuesday | There is a new addition to the red-tailed hawks’ nest overlooking Washington Square Park. At 11:02 p.m. on Monday, almost nine hours after Hawk Cam fans initially reported that one egg had a small beak-sized hole, a fuzzy baby hawk emerged between two broken halves of an eggshell, making its debut on The New York Times’s Hawk Cam.

headline: Frank H. Strickler, Watergate Defense Lawyer, Dies at 92
text: Frank H. Strickler, a Washington lawyer who represented two of President Richard M. Nixon’s top aides, H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, in the tangled legal aftermath of the 1972 Watergate break-in and its cover-up, died March 29 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 92.

headline: Hewlett-Packard: Once More Toward the Cloud
text: Hewlett-Packard says it is again revamping the corporate sales of its servers and software to better take advantage of the growing market for cloud computing by large businesses.

headline: Report Disputes Christie’s Basis for Halting Tunnel
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey exaggerated when he declared that unforeseen costs to the state were forcing him to cancel the new train tunnel planned to relieve congested routes across the Hudson River, according to a long-awaited report by independent Congressional investigators.

headline: In Surprise, China Posts Trade Surplus
text: HONG KONG — China ran an unexpected $5.35 billion trade surplus last month, government figures released on Tuesday showed, indicating the country remains a strong exporter despite weak demand in Europe in recent months.

headline: On a New Web Site, ‘The Real George Zimmerman’ Speaks, and Solicits Funds
text: Last Updated | 5:46 p.m. George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who shot and killed an unarmed, black teenager in Florida six weeks ago, broke his public silence over the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin on a new Web site: TheRealGeorgeZimmerman.com.

headline: America Is Eating Its Poor
text: When Rendezvous wrote about Europe’s “lost generation” of unemployed young people — and what their lot in life will mean for Europe’s future — many RDV readers voiced their concerns about the overall decline of The West. Wrote Ian Walthew in France:

headline: Christine Brooke-Rose, Inventive Writer, Dies at 89
text: Christine Brooke-Rose, an English experimental writer known for wielding words with the ardor of a philologist, the fingers of a prestidigitator and the appetite of a lexivore, resulting in novels that exhilarated many critics and enervated others, died on March 21. She was 89.

headline: Malaysia Weighs End to Indefinite Detention
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Malaysian government introduced legislation on Tuesday that would limit the time it could detain people suspected of security-related offenses without formal charges to 28 days. The bill would replace the Internal Security Act, a law enacted decades ago that allows indefinite detention without trial.

headline: Burmese Are Wary of Tourism’s Dark Side
text: HONG KONG — As dramatic political reforms continue to take shape in Myanmar, a wave of tourists has already started to arrive, eager to explore the country’s magnificent temples, beaches and highlands.

headline: Who Deserves Welfare in India?
text: Living on 29 rupees (a little more than 50 U.S. cents) a day may not be “such stuff as dreams are made on,” in William Shakespeare’s immortal turn of phrase from “The Tempest.” But according to India’s Planning Commission, which is charged with measuring such things, anyone spending more than that meager amount is considered to be above the poverty line.

headline: At the Varli Food Festival, Andhra Shrimp and Halwa Cupcakes
text: Seafood momos and spicy crab meat stuffed inside papadum cones. Kachori chaat and paneer kati rolls. Gajar ka halwa cupcakes and date rose pistachio chocolate dark truffles.

headline: Attacks Attest to Afghan Insurgents’ Spring Offensive
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a further sign that the insurgents’ spring offensive is under way, suicide bombers struck in western and southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing 16 people, according to Afghan officials in Herat and Helmand, where the attacks took place.

headline: Tensions Mount as Syria Truce Seems Elusive
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian peace plan that was brokered under United Nations auspices appeared to be on life support on Tuesday, with Syria disregarding the initial step of returning its security forces to their barracks and senior diplomats around the world preparing for an ever more unlikely cease-fire set for Thursday.

headline: The Amazing Matzo Stimulus
text: When Aron Streit started making matzo in 1916, unleavened bread was a serious growth business, at least on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. By the late 1920s, Streit could afford to build a special machine that mixed, kneaded and cooked dough. A decade later, his family added the cotton gin of kosher food — an automated conveyor belt with a Rube Goldberg-esque basket system that moved the matzo to a packaging area on a higher floor. They even opened a retail store next door that allowed customers to watch it in action.

headline: ‘Death Traps’ in Dhaka
text: A patriot might not readily describe his native city as a “death trap” and a beautiful place in the same breath, but for the Bangladeshi photographer Abir Abdullah, they’re not mutually exclusive. Bangladesh and its capital, Dhaka, one of the most populous and dense cities in the world, face complex challenges, as a robust economy frequently beset by natural disasters.

headline: North Korea Is Set to Launch Satellite Despite Criticism
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Tuesday that it had completed preparations to launch a satellite into orbit, as South Korea and other Asian nations told their airlines and ships to change their routes to avoid the North Korean rocket.

headline: College Admissions Advice for ‘Neurotic’ Parents
text: J.D. Rothman never thought of herself as a neurotic parent — until her two sons started looking at colleges. As she listened to other students discuss literally out of this world accomplishments, like “discovering galaxies,” she wondered how her son, without such a hook, would gain admission to a top school.

headline: Obama Goes on Offensive Over Taxes on Wealthy
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — All but certain now that his Republican opponent will be Mitt Romney, President Obama has made his proposed “Buffett Rule” minimum tax for the wealthiest Americans like Mr. Romney a centerpiece of his re-election campaign, defying the political risk of being seen as a tax-and-spender by wary voters.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Chaos Among Closers
text: It’s best not to overreact to what happens over a small sample at the beginning of the season, but when performance affects roles, fantasy owners need to pay attention. This is best illustrated with closers, who as a whole are off to a terrible start in 2012. Here are the most tenuous situations:

text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Dragone Classics, Including Murphy-Bodied Duesenberg, to Be Auctioned in May
text: WESTPORT, Conn. — The Duesenberg I was invited to drive off the lot, a 1931 Model J Custom Beverly, was expected to bring $1.5 to $2 million at the coming sale of Dragone Auctions on May 19. The car’s value didn’t stop the brothers Manny and George Dragone from letting me take a spin in the Duesenberg, or a 1963 Ferrari 250 GT Lusso, around this seaside Connecticut town.

headline: Sony Revises Expected Loss to $6.4 Billion
text: TOKYO — Sony more than doubled its projected net loss for the past financial year to ¥520 billion, its worst loss ever, as an additional tax expense hurt a company already battered by heavy losses in its television business, a strong yen and natural disasters in Japan and overseas.

headline: Remembering a Massacre
text: MONTREAL — Ten years ago on April 11, I was standing on Baralt Avenue in downtown Caracas amid a chaos of tear gas, waving flags and surging protesters, but it was the crackling explosions that made me fidgety. They sounded like the firecrackers protesters had been setting off all through the seven mile march but, at this point, who could tell?

headline: Albany Considering Limiting Release of Teacher Reports
text: Anna M. Phillips reports in The New York Times on Tuesday that legislators are increasingly open to the idea of allowing parents to see the evaluations of their child's teacher, but not releasing those reports generally.

headline: Worst Loss This Year for Wall St.
text: The stock market sank deeper on Tuesday, eroding the first quarter’s blockbuster gains for a fifth straight day, as fears about the debt crisis in Europe re-emerged.

headline: Daily Report: Fighting Cellphone Theft With a Database

headline: In Court, Trying to Understand Asperger Syndrome

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bloomberg: The United States has agreed to formally recognize cachaça (above) as a distinctly Brazilian spirit. Since 2000, Brazil has had to label its native liquor—which is distilled from sugar cane juice—as “Brazilian rum,” a label that has irked some cachaça producers. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau will begin the process by publishing notice of the proposed change and soliciting comment. Should the measure go through, Brazil will also extend official recognition of America’s bourbon and Tennessee whiskey. — Robert Simonson

headline: St. Jude Is Rebuffed Over Report on Device
text: In a setback for St. Jude Medical, a medical journal late Monday rejected the company’s request that it retract a published report that found that 20 deaths were linked to failures of a heart device component made by the company.

headline: New Stance on Forgiving Mortgages
text: WASHINGTON — The overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Tuesday opened the door to forgiving some mortgage debt of homeowners who owe more than their houses are worth, as the Obama administration has recently urged.

headline: Penn Virginia Buys Chief Gathering for $1 Billion
text: Penn Virginia Resource Partners agreed on Tuesday to buy the energy pipeline company Chief Gathering for $1 billion as it expands its foothold in the booming shale gas sector in the United States.

headline: Spain Bond Yields Rise, Reviving Fears of a Renewed Euro Crisis
text: MADRID — Spain’s borrowing costs rose Tuesday to levels not seen since early January, raising concerns that the financial crisis in Europe was heating up again after a lull. Stock markets closed sharply lower across the region.

headline: For High School Athlete With Down Syndrome, Age Is an Issue
text: Last New Year’s Eve, Eric Dompierre was at a party with his high school basketball teammates. At 12:30 a.m., he called his father, Dean Dompierre, to see if he could stay out for another hour. By 2 a.m., his father was good-naturedly dragging him home.

headline: New York’s Lucky Rice Festival Is Going to Las Vegas
text: Three years ago, Danielle Chang, who had been the chief executive of the fashion company Vivienne Tam, decided she would try to start a pan-Asian food festival in New York. She named it Lucky Rice, partnered with City Harvest, and got a number of local Asian chefs and restaurants to participate with tastings, dinners and other events over four days in 2010. Last year it expanded to a week-long series of events. Now, she said, “It’s my full-time job.”

headline: BAM and IFC Collaborating on New Comedy Showcase
text: There’s no shortage of jokes to be made about Brooklyn, but are there enough places in Brooklyn to make jokes? The Brooklyn Academy of Music and the IFC cable channel are working together on a new opportunity for comedians to perform their material in that borough (whether  their bits are about Marty Markowitz or double-wide baby strollers).

headline: Death of a Briton Is Thrust to Center of China Scandal
text: BEIJING — The mysterious death of a 41-year-old British businessman in a Chongqing hotel room late last year was thrust to the center of the biggest political scandal to hit China’s Communist Party in a generation on Tuesday, as the authorities declared the death a murder and named the wife of one of China’s most powerful men the leading suspect.

headline: Corning to Buy Majority of a Becton Biosciences Division
text: Corning agreed on Tuesday to buy the majority of a Becton Dickinson’s biosciences unit for about $730 million in cash, amid continued interest in deals for life sciences and laboratory equipment businesses.

headline: Chris Weitz to Write Young-Adult Novels
text: The writer and director Chris Weitz is trying his hand at young-adult fiction. Mr. Weitz, who directed “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” will write a trilogy of post-apocalyptic novels for Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of the Hachette Book Group, his publisher announced. The first book in the series, “The Young World,” is expected to be released in spring 2014.

headline: Most Important Game for the Knicks: Against the Celtics
text: New York’s victory over the Bulls on Sunday gave the Knicks a record of 29-27, which placed them in a tie for the seventh playoff spot in the Eastern Conference with the Sixers. Since New York defeated Philadelphia in 2 of their 3 contests this year, the Knicks would have the advantage in a tie-breaker should the two teams finish the regular season with the same record.

headline: In Miami, Winning Clearly Isn’t the Only Thing
text: MIAMI — In an effort to revitalize their long-struggling franchise and attract the Latino baseball fans of South Florida, the Miami Marlins built a new $634 million stadium, revamped their uniforms, signed one of the biggest Hispanic stars in the league and hired a brash manager from Venezuela who guided the Chicago White Sox to a World Series title. The team even made sure its electronic concessions menus alternated between English and Spanish.

headline: Have an N.H.L. Question? Slap Shot Has Answers
text: 11:59 a.m. | Updated Will the Rangers have any trouble with the Senators? Will the Philadelphia-Pittsburgh series go seven games? How far can the Devils go this year? Jeff Z. Klein, the N.H.L. reporter for The Times, and Christopher Botta, a contributor to The Times and to Slap Shot, will answer questions from readers. Submit questions in the comments field, and answers will appear on Slap Shot later this week.Comments for this feature have been closed.

headline: Critic of Conservation Efforts Gets Critiqued
text: Peter Kareiva, the chief scientist of the Nature Conservancy and perhaps the most prominent critic of the conservation movement from within its own ranks, has had his arguments sharply challenged. The pushback has come both in the comment string on Dot Earth following my recent post on him and at Breakthrough Journal, which posted “Conservation in the Anthropocene,” an essay by Kareiva and two colleagues, followed by a package of rebuttals and, most recently, a response from Kareiva et al.

headline: Instagram Users Fail to Welcome Their New Overlord

headline: A Roadblock to Recovering Money for Madoff’s Victims
text: Most investors lose almost all of their money once a Ponzi scheme collapses, and the trustees appointed to clean up the mess try to find any deep pocket available to recover something. Unfortunately for the trustees, the legal doctrine of “in pari delicto,” Latin for “in equal fault,” may block any recovery.

headline: Rolling Stones Heading to Studio to ‘Get the Feel Again’

The guitarist Ronnie Wood offered some tantalizing hints on Monday, saying that the group would go into a recording studio later this month “to just bat some ideas around” and “get the feel again.”

headline: Want to Place Bets on Facebook’s Next Acquisition?

headline: Protecting What Mali Stands For
text: WASHINGTON — I asked my Sudanese cabbie where he was from. “China,” he replied. In the city that acts like it runs the world, he is fed up that so few people know their Darfur from their Juba. If that’s true of Sudan, with so much at stake, pity the rest of a diverse continent that Rick Santorum, a candidate for the Republican Party’s nomination for president of the United States, called a single country of Islamic fanatics.

headline: All Hail Azawad
text: Here’s yet another contentious line drawn in the sand of the Sahara desert: The northern half of Mali has just declared independence, and would henceforth like that you call it Azawad, pretty please. “We solemnly proclaim the independence of Azawad as of today,” Mossa ag Attaher, a rebel [1] spokesman, told the France 24 TV channel on Friday, April 6.

headline: Derby Dreams Ride In on a White Horse
text: For Hansen, the reigning 2-year-old thoroughbred champion, every race is like a work of performance art. Not in the way he runs, which is almost always at the front of the field, but the way he looks as he does it. He is the color of alabaster, a striking white vision set against the bays, browns and chestnuts he has left behind in all but one race.

headline: Credit Card Rates Up Slightly, but 0 Percent Offers Get Longer
text: Interest rates on general consumer credit cards ticked up in the first three months of the year, but no-interest offers generally got longer, a new analysis from CardHub.com finds.

headline: A Goldman Co-Head of Global Mergers to Step Down

headline: HBO Orders a Third Season for ‘Game of Thrones’
text: As the saying doesn’t quite go but should from now on: a Lannister always gets a third season. HBO said on Tuesday that it was ordering another year of “Game of Thrones,” its fantasy drama about the warring clans of Starks, Lannisters, Baratheons, Greyjoys and Targaryen (among other unusual permutations of vowels and consonants) on the mythical continent of Westeros. The series, which is adapted from George R. R. Martin’s best-selling “Song of Ice and Fire” novels and produced by David Benioff and D.B. Weiss, was a breakout hit in its first season, earning an Emmy nomination for best dramatic series and winning an Emmy and a Golden Globe for its star Peter Dinklage, who plays the manipulative Tyrion Lannister. Season 2, which began on April 1, is already off to a strong start, drawing nearly 4 million viewers for the debut broadcasts of each episode that have been shown so far. Dates for the production and premiere of Season 3 of “Game of Thrones” were not announced but should occur some time after Daenerys Targaryen crosses the Red Waste.

headline: Another Bogus Attack on Health Reform
text: Oh, boy. It turns out that the WaPo featured on its front page a report by Charles Blahous of the (yes, Koch-funded) Mercatus Center — although the Post describes him as a Medicare trustee, giving the impression that this is somehow an official document — claiming that the Affordable Care Act will actually increase the deficit. Jonathan Chait does the honors:

headline: The Buffett Rule
text: Few things capture the difference in values between President Obama and his Republican opponents quite as neatly as their positions on the Warren Buffet-inspired Buffett Rule, which would require Americans making over $1 million a year to pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes.

headline: The Body Whisperer

headline: Psychiatry May Also Face Scrutiny at Norway Killer’s Trial
text: After an earlier psychiatric report declared him to be a paranoid schizophrenic living in a “delusional universe,” a second evaluation by Norwegian psychiatrists released on Tuesday found Anders Behring Breivik, the anti-Muslim extremist who methodically killed 77 people in Oslo last year, to be legally sane, according to Norwegian officials.

headline: A He-Wax for Him
text: YEARS after the word “metrosexual” entered the mainstream, there’s nothing eyebrow-raising about men getting a manicure or a facial. Lately though, guys’ grooming has gone one step further, deep into territory that was previously reserved solely for women: bikini waxing.

headline: A Brush With Art, and Royalty, in Monaco

headline: Slide Show: Pera Soho
text: In a neighborhood more preoccupied with fashion than food, Pera Soho, reviewed this week, is a step in the right direction. (An expensive one, though.) An accomplished Turkish chef is in charge here; his best dishes are revised classics, like minced lamb kebab, smoky eggplant purée and lacy kunefe, shreds of phyllo with butter, honey and clotted cream.

headline: In California, a Fast-Charging First
text: A Los Angeles-based firm claims to have installed California’s first public fast-charging station, which opened for business last week. The unit, which can recharge the battery pack of a Nissan Leaf in about 30 minutes, is located at the Stanford Shopping Center in Palo Alto, adjacent to Stanford University and about 30 miles south of San Francisco.

headline: Teenage Birthrates at Record Low
text: Despite (or because of?) the popularity of shows like “Teen Mom” and “16 and Pregnant,” teenage birthrates are at record lows in the United States.

headline: A Dinner Party With Two Mike Wallaces
text: The telephone rang. It was Sy Presten, an old-school press agent who had been pitching items to columnists in New York since the days of Walter Winchell.

headline: Edible Selby | Green Zone
text: Cookbook, a green grocery store in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles run by the master gardener and chef Marta Teegen, is a monument to the principle of quality over quantity: inside the modest 500-square-foot space is nearly everything a cook with a penchant for natural ingredients could possibly want. The best organic produce, yes. But also Dr. Bob’s ice cream, fresh-cut flowers, pasture-raised meats, Mast Brothers chocolate, Creminelli salami, Café Fanny granola and an ever-changing menu of prepared foods, derived each week from a different cookbook of Teegen’s choosing. Mediterranean sources, like “Moro East” by Sam and Sam Clark, are in heavy rotation. “We are interested in looking at what new things people are doing with food,” Teegen says, “but we also like to go back to the classics.” More…

headline: Lost in the G.S.A. Scandal, Confusion About a Small-Business Contract
text: The scandal unfolding at the General Services Administration mostly has to do with outrageous spending. The agency, which essentially serves as the government’s back office, managing property, federal purchases and some administrative services, pulled out all the stops when it sent 300 employees to a Las Vegas resort for a conference in 2010 — the bill for the five-day affair totaled $823,000 and included extravagances like luxury hotel suites and $7,000 worth of sushi. But one issue raised in the investigation into the boondoggle hasn’t gotten very much attention: a government contract for running part of the conference that should have gone to a small business seems to have gone to a large company.

headline: Etgar Keret’s Stories Read by a Chorus of Voices
text: For his latest collection of stories, “Suddenly, a Knock on the Door,” the Israeli writer Etgar Keret gathered an all-star cast to read his comic, surrealist, often very brief works. The final roster of participants includes Ira Glass, Neal Stephenson, Miranda July, George Saunders, Aimee Bender, John Sayles and Michael Chabon.

headline: Scully Misses Dodgers Opener With Illness
text: It might be a new era at Dodger Stadium, but the one thing everybody loves about the old era — play-by-play gem Vin Scully — was noticeably absent from the Dodgers’ opening day broadcast on Tuesday. The Dodgers announced he was out sick with a bad cold, which meant he would miss the home opener for the first time since 1977. That one wasn’t a sick day. He was calling the first round of the Masters.

headline: Emanuel Azenberg, Neil Simon’s Favorite Producer, Will Get Special Tony Award
text: Few producers have had as much success backing plays on Broadway as Emanuel Azenberg, who shepherded more than 20 Neil Simon comedies over the last four decades (including hits like “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Lost in Yonkers”) and won eight Tony Awards out of 25 total nominations. Now the 78-year-old Mr. Azenberg will add another Tony to his shelf this June as the recipient of the 2012 award for lifetime achievement in the theater, the organizers of the annual awards ceremony announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Not-So-Raging Middle Class

He set about creating a visual archive of the individual signs (seen above and below) about 250 of which will appear in his exhibition titled “Let This Be a Sign,” which opens at the Swiss Cottage Gallery on May 23 as part of the London Festival of Photography.

headline: In Auckland, Exploring the South Seas Without Setting Sail
text: For some reason, few memories are more indelible for me than when I hear familiar phrases in an unexpectedly foreign language. Like when as a teenager I pulled a Beatles LP off my dad’s shelf and dropped the needle on “I Want to Hold Your Hand” – in German. (“Komm gib mir deine Hand”). Or when, as a student teacher in Los Angeles, I witnessed an assembly of grade-schoolers robotically recite the Pledge of Allegiance – in Spanish (“Juro fidelidad a la bandera de los Estados Unidos de América…”).

headline: ‘Two and a Half Men’ Tumbles to Lowest Audience in Five Years

headline: Drug Data Shouldn’t Be Secret
text: IN the fall of 2009, at the height of fears over swine flu, our research group discovered that a majority of clinical trial data for the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu — data that proved, according to its manufacturer, that the drug reduced the risk of hospitalization, serious complications and transmission — were missing, unpublished and inaccessible to the research community. From what we could tell from the limited clinical data that had been published in medical journals, the country’s most widely used and heavily stockpiled influenza drug appeared no more effective than aspirin.

headline: Weaving a Tapestry Between Bits of Prometheus
text: Thomas Crawford’s American Classical Orchestra is working hard to be the period-instrument orchestra that survives and thrives in New York, where so many others have foundered. It is, in a way, a stealth contender: counting its earlier incarnation as the Orchestra of the Old Fairfield Academy, the ensemble has been exploring the late-18th- and early-19th-century repertory for 27 seasons. And its roster is full of names familiar from other period-instrument groups that ply the New York-Boston freelance corridor, among them the violinist Linda Quan, the violist David Miller, the cellist Myron Lutzke, the flutist Sandra Miller, the oboist Marc Schachman and the trumpeter John Thiessen.

headline: Starting From Scraps
text: LEFTOVERS get short shrift. Relegated to the back of the fridge, abandoned among forgotten condiments and that container of heavy cream stuck to the shelf, they are mostly thought of as late-night snacks, economy dinners or tomorrow’s lunch. Even the word “leftovers” carries the negative connotation of the unwanted, the uneaten, the scraps.

headline: Beinart Fires Back
text: The day my book, The Crisis of Zionism, hit the shelves I gave a speech at the University of Maryland. During question and answer session, an older Jewish man–grim-faced, teeth-clenched—demanded to know how I could criticize Israel for occupying the West Bank when most West Bank Palestinians effectively govern themselves, and when the Palestinians have shown themselves unwilling to live at peace. I responded that while Palestinians do indeed bear part of the blame for the lack of a Palestinian state, Israel’s policy of subsidizing Jews to move to settlements—including settlements deep in the West Bank—only strengthens the most militant forces in Palestinian society. He rose again in protest, then sat down and glared.
