text: Part 8: The actress talks about what it was like to be the first female cast member to return as a host on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Elaine Benes
text: Part 6: The actress recounts how she and her iconic “Seinfeld” character became publicly intertwined, and recalls when she realized “Seinfeld” had become a hit.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Making ‘Veep’
text: Part 10: The actress explains why the process of making “Veep” was a completely unique experience, even to a veteran television actress.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Not a Great Look
text: Part 7: The actress tells the story behind her famous “Seinfeld” dance, and explains why she now hates dancing.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: I Was Horrible
text: Part 5: The actress recalls her experience on “Saturday Night Live,” where she started as a 21-year-old.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Disappointing Woody
text: Part 12: The actress tells the story of how she blew the single scene she had in “Hannah and Her Sisters.”

headline: TimesTalks | Julia Louis-Dreyfus Preview
text: The actress discusses her iconic and award-winning comedic roles on “Seinfeld” and “Veep.”

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Vincent’s Picks
text: Part 15: The actress discusses her own political activism and talks about what her sons think of her comedy.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Being Selina Meyer
text: Part 2: The actress discusses what attracted her to the title role in “Veep,” and explains why the vice presidency is a ripe subject for comedy.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Cornstarch Utensils
text: Part 3: The actress talks about how the experience of making “Veep,” a single-camera comedy, differed from her work on multi-camera sitcoms like “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine.”

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Having Said That
text: Part 9: The actress describes what it was like playing herself on “Curb Your Enthusiasm.”

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: It’s Not a Parody
text: Part 11: The actress talks about her character on “Veep” and the “great separation” between her and the president on the show.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: He Vas My Boyfriend
text: Part 14: The actress recalls the comic actresses who influenced her the most growing up.

headline: Yankees Face Unknown on Friday the 13th
text: The Yankees are the most successful franchise in professional sports, having won 27 World Series championships. But the team may be tempting fate by having its home opener on Friday the 13th. Never before, in a history that dates to 1901, has the franchise opened at home or on the road on that date.

headline: Obamas and Bidens to Release Tax Returns
text: WASHINGTON — Punctuating a week of political assaults on Mitt Romney over taxes, President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. plan to release their own income tax returns on Friday, along with a statement calling on Mr. Romney to do the same, according to an Obama campaign official.

headline: Once Taboo, Germans’ Anti-Israel Whispers Grow Louder
text: BERLIN — To judge by the outpouring of comments from politicians and writers and from the newspaper and magazine articles in response to the Nobel laureate Günter Grass’s poem criticizing Israel’s aggressive posture toward Iran, it would appear that the public had resoundingly rejected his work.

headline: South Sudan: Border Tensions Increase
text: South Sudan said Thursday that it was prepared to withdraw from the contested city of Heglig, which it captured from Sudanese forces this week, under certain conditions, but that it was also prepared to send its army back to Abyei, another contested city along the border. The minister of information, Barnaba Marial Benjamin, echoing statements by President Salva Kiir, said South Sudan “cannot talk about withdrawal” unless contested regions were demilitarized and international observers were put in place. Until then, Mr. Marial said, South Sudan would remain in Heglig, an oil-rich city that both Sudan and South Sudan claim and Sudan has controlled since 2005. But South Sudan has accused Sudan of using contested border regions as a “springboard” for attacks on its territory. Since their split last year, the two sides have been caught in a dispute over a host of issues, including citizenship, the demarcation of the border and how to share the South’s oil. On Thursday, the United Nations Security Council demanded “a complete, immediate and unconditional end to all fighting” between Sudan and South Sudan.

headline: Yankees Are Bracing for the Power of Pujols
text: As a member of the St. Louis Cardinals, Albert Pujols, one of baseball’s most dangerous and captivating hitters, played in only four games at the old Yankee Stadium: an interleague series against the Yankees in 2003 and then the 2008 All-Star Game.

headline: Myanmar: Dispute Over Oath of Office
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party said Thursday that it was negotiating with the government to change the oath of office for lawmakers because it contravened the party’s official platform. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi and 42 other members of her party, the National League for Democracy, won seats in Parliament in landmark elections on April 1. The victory was a major step toward reconciliation between the democratic movement and the military-backed government. But the party now says it objects to a part of the oath of office that commands lawmakers to protect and safeguard the country’s Constitution. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi has repeatedly said some articles in the Constitution are undemocratic, including a provision that one quarter of the seats in Parliament are reserved for the military, and the party wants to amend the document.

headline: In Newark, Mayor Saves a Woman From a Fire
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark carried a woman out of a burning house and was treated for smoke inhalation on Thursday night.

headline: Pennsylvania: Bomb Threats Continue After Arrest
text: The police at the University of Pittsburgh have arrested a New York man on charges of making terrorist threats to four professors, but he was not charged with making more than 60 bomb threats that have caused major disruptions across the campus since mid-February. The man, Mark Lee Krangle, 65, of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., a graduate student at the university in the mid-1970s, was arrested as he stepped off a plane at Pittsburgh International Airport on Wednesday, university officials said. The bomb threats, however, continued Thursday morning, causing hundreds of students to be rousted from dormitories, libraries and classrooms. No devices have been found.

headline: All Aboard the Rangers Train
text: Amid the hustle and bustle of the New York City subway system, a train wrapped from top to bottom in Rangers red and blue is causing some passengers to stop in their tracks.

headline: Ecuador: Failing Universities to Close
text: The police and education officials on Thursday moved to shut down 14 universities that the government determined did not meet basic academic standards. The schools, with a total of about 38,000 students, were on a list of failing universities, sometimes called “garage universities” because of accusations of their low quality. The move is part of a broad effort to improve higher education by President Rafael Correa’s government. The government said it would take a year to close the schools, allowing about 10,000 students who are in their final year of studies to graduate. Most of the remaining students would be given the chance to transfer to other academic programs.

headline: On ‘American Idol,’ a Shock and Then a Save
text: “American Idol” viewers proved this week that they are anything but predictable and that the best singers do not always win the popularity contest. The viewers voted to eliminate not only Jessica Sanchez, who has consistently been one of the most impressive performers on the show, but also the other two singers in the bottom three were Joshua Ledet and Elise Testone, who turned in powerhouse performances this week.

headline: Luke Askew, Character Actor, Is Dead at 80
text: Luke Askew, a character actor perhaps best remembered as the wayward stranger who brings Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper to a hippie commune in the 1969 motorcycle odyssey “Easy Rider,” died on March 29 at his home in Lake Oswego, Ore. He was 80.

headline: Signs Europe Bending on Airline Carbon Fee
text: “The European Union, heading for a trade war over a new toll on the greenhouse gas emissions of international airlines using European airspace, has been warned that the measure could wreck the prospects for global action on climate change,” Harvey Morris writes in the International Herald Tribune’s Rendezvous blog.

headline: An Agonizing Life in Limbo for the Infosys Whistleblower
text: “It has been 17 months since Jack B. Palmer first made a quiet complaint through internal channels at Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company he works for, saying he suspected some managers were committing visa fraud,” Julia Preston writes in The New York Times. “Since then, Mr. Palmer says, he has been harassed by superiors and co-workers, sidelined with no work assignment, shut out of the company’s computers, denied bonuses and hounded by death threats.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,915 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Iran, the United States and a Political Seesaw
text: Far from a monolithic relationship, Iran and the United States have spent as many decades as friends as they have as enemies.

headline: Stiff Sentences for 2002 Killings
text: A court on Thursday sentenced 18 Hindus to life imprisonment for killing 23 Muslims in Gujarat State in 2002 during India’s worst sectarian violence in recent years, The Associated Press reports. Five others were sentenced to seven years in prison.

headline: Comolli Out at Liverpool After Getting the Numbers All Wrong
text: There’s a scene in “Moneyball” that depicts the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool owner John W. Henry in a discussion with Oakland A’s General Manager Billy Beane high above Fenway Park. Beane, played by Brad Pitt, has been summoned to meet with Henry after building a winning team with an unfashionable franchise based on statistical data ignored by everyone else; that system came to be known as Moneyball.

headline: Amid Mass Protests, Syrian Cease-Fire Is Tested by Reports of Clashes
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrians by the thousands marched through the streets of cities and towns across the country on Friday, testing a tenuous, day-old cease-fire that the United Nations struggled to shore up when the rapid deployment of international observers snagged on Russian objections.

headline: On the Bus, Away From the Pack
text: Eric Thayer, 37, has been covering the Republican nominating contest almost nonstop since last July in Iowa. He has mostly photographed for The New York Times but has also worked for Reuters in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: Off To Pomona
text: Very early, as you can see, to talk macro. Slides for the talk (pdf).

headline: Delhi Tries to Lure Voters for City Elections
text: When Delhi’s polls open on Sunday for municipal elections, will the turnout be any better than last time?

headline: ‘First Generation’ Chronicles Students’ Difficult Path to College
text: The college admissions process can be confusing on its own, but the missteps are multiplied, it seems, when a young applicant looks around and can find no relatives who’ve ever been through it.

headline: The Early Word: Big Money
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Is There a Republican Alternative to Obamacare?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Reconnecting Through Art
text: At the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, David Rosenberg, a guide, stood before a stone piece depicting a six-armed figure. “Now, what would be a good reason to have six arms?” Mr. Rosenberg asked his audience, a half dozen or so elderly adults with dementia and their caregivers.

headline: Study Abroad, Mormon Style
text: Mormon college students pause their studies to serve in missions. It’s a real education.

headline: Greg Childs, Fifth-Ranked Receiver in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: At Age 19, From Utah to Uganda
text: LAST summer, Jared Dangerfield was simply 19, skateboarding the streets of suburban Salt Lake City, plugged into the Jewish reggae singer Matisyahu. He had just wrapped up his year at Utah State University, where there was a girl he liked to make laugh.

headline: Rocket Failure May Be Test of North Korean Leader’s Power
text: SEOUL, South Korea — For the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, the spectacular failure of a rocket meant to put a satellite into orbit was more than a $1 billion humiliation. It could be the first test of whether anyone will dare challenge his rule, and raises the question, American officials said, of whether he will be tempted to recover by staging a larger provocation.

headline: Q&A: Removing Yourself From YouTube
text: Q.

headline: Setting the Tone for Tennis’s Much Bigger Stars
text: Professional tennis is, at its core, a selfish pursuit, but Ivan Ljubicic, who is about to play his last tournament, has done his part to make it less so.

headline: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
text: A few weeks ago I wrote a post about two small businesses that were taking different approaches to employing Groupon-style social-network marketing as a way of drumming up business.

headline: JPMorgan Chase’s Earnings Beat Expectations
text: 9:03 a.m. | Updated

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: JPMorgan Chase’s Earnings Beat Expectations  |  Kicking off a series of earnings reports from the nation’s biggest banks in the coming days, JPMorgan Chase said Friday that it earned $1.31 a share in the first quarter of 2012, compared with $1.28 a share in the same period a year ago. On a reported basis, revenue rose 6 percent, rising to $26.7 billion, from $25.2 billion.

headline: Daily Report: Google Announces 2-for-1 Stock Split
text: Google may have had a challenging first three months of the year from a public relations standpoint, with government officials and ordinary users alike troubled by the company’s new privacy policy, David Streitfeld writes in The New York Times on Friday. But its financial results, reported on Thursday, were another matter, as the company largely rebounded from a weaker previous quarter.

headline: Opinion Report: Cutting Costs
text: From the editorial page

headline: The Importance of Being Earnest
text: “Take him and cut him out in little stars!” Jessica Chastain fairly shouts, re-enacting her interpretation of Juliet’s famous monologue, the bold gambit that got her admitted to the Juilliard School a decade ago. “Most people do it so precious and sweet, a girl just married, but she is going to be a woman, and ‘he shall die’ means orgasm! It was crazy. I was on the ground by the end of the audition. When I finished, the admissions panel was like, Who is this little redheaded girl coming in here?”

headline: Wells Fargo Profit Rises 13%, as Revenue Increases
text: Wells Fargo, one of the nation’s largest consumer lenders, posted a 13 percent increase in first-quarter profit on Friday, the latest in a series of upbeat report cards for the bank.

headline: For Obama, Going Positive May Be More Difficult This Time
text: President Obama’s campaign has left no doubt about how it intends to run against Mitt Romney, portraying him as a bazillionaire elitist and conviction-free flip-flopper who has allied himself with the Republican Party’s most extreme positions.

headline: Channeling Iran in the High-Stakes Nuclear Talks
text: ISTANBUL — Let’s play devil’s advocate and consider what Iran might want to say as it heads into talks in Istanbul this weekend with leading world powers that are intent on curbing its nuclear ambitions.

headline: An Ineffectual Start for Elder Sister
text: NEW DELHI — When Mamata Banerjee defeated the Communist Party of India (Marxist) last May after 34 years of power in West Bengal, her victory was portrayed by optimists as the beginning of a Kolkata Spring. Free of the communists’ rural thugs and urban heelers, the story went, the state would finally enter the 21st century.

headline: Antiques Roadshow
text: For a couple of consummate movers and shakers, there’s no place like home — wherever that may be.

headline: A Georgian Olive Branch
text: TBILISI, Georgia – Visitors don’t have to look much farther than Georgia’s largest ski resort, Gudauri, to see evidence of this small nation’s shifting policy toward Russia.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Back to the ’50s in Politics, and Chris Nolan on Shooting in Film
text: Politico says it has found a thread in the Obama campaign’s framing of its expected opponent, Mitt Romney: comparing him to Don Draper of “Mad Men.” Not the drinking, womanizing or even charisma of Draper, Politico is quick to point out, but rather, in Democrats’ eyes, as “a hopelessly retro figure who, on policy and in his personal life, is living in the past.”

headline: New Share Class Gives Google Founders Tighter Control
text: Google may have the motto “don’t be evil.” But it is certainly not a democracy.

headline: Where Amish Snowbirds Find a Nest
text: FROM December through April, Amish travelers pack charter buses making overnight runs from Ohio to Florida. Stiff black hats are gingerly stowed in overhead bins as the bus winds its way through hilly farm country, making pickups in small towns with names like Sugarcreek, Berlin and Wooster.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the Julia Louis-Dreyfus Photo Shoot
text: For the photo illustrations for this week’s profile of Julia Louis-Dreyfus, we asked Louis-Dreyfus to channel Audrey Hepburn — but with a twist. You’ll notice that in each of the three film publicity stills we recreated — from “Funny Face,” “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” and “Charade” — something is awry. The idea was to put Louis-Dreyfus in these iconic poses that she (comically) can’t quite pull off.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 13: Opening Day in the Bronx
text: Good morning. Expect another sunny, at times windy, day with highs in the mid 60s.

headline: S.& P. 500 Suffers Biggest Weekly Decline of the Year
text: Stocks fell on Friday, giving the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index its biggest weekly decline of the year, as consumer confidence dropped, China’s growth slowed and the cost of insuring against a Spanish debt default rose to a record.

headline: Former Manager Is Convicted of Harassing Leonard Cohen
text: Everybody knows it’s not uncommon for fans of Leonard Cohen‘s to become fixated on him and his romantic if sinister music. But a jury has decided that a former business manager of that Canadian singer-songwriter harassed him by sending him hundreds of e-mails and voicemail messages that at times left him feeling threatened, The Associated Press reported.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Village Voice: The sudden weekend warmth in New York should be a fine excuse to get your summer drink on. Robert Sietsema lists his five favorite margaritas around town. — Patrick Farrell

headline: A Conversation With : ‘The Meadow’ Author Adrian Levy
text: Adrian Levy is co-author of “The Meadow,” a newly released book about the 1995 kidnappings of six foreigners in Kashmir and the aftermath. He and Cathy Scott-Clark, both veteran journalists, also have written books about Russian artwork, Pakistan’s nuclear weapons and jade.

headline: Friday Reading: States Seek To Limit Patients’ Drug Bills
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Fill in the Blank: Being a Reporter Is the ______ Job in the World
text: This week, we learned a few things about being a reporter that seem to suggest that the craft, as currently situated, is an unhappy piece of work.

headline: Newark Mayor Speaks About Fire Rescue
text: Updated, 10:18 a.m. | Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark held a 10 a.m. news conference to talk about how he saved a neighbor from her burning home Thursday night.

headline: In ‘The Meadow,’ a Chilling Alternate View of the 1995 Kashmiri Kidnappings
text: In the summer of 1995, six foreign tourists were kidnapped in a meadow in Kashmir by a group calling itself Al Faran.

headline: Even the Three Stooges Needed Second Fiddles
text: Disparage the Three Stooges if you must, you cineaste. Dismiss their films with a weary wave of your smoldering Gauloise. But give them this: Moe, Larry, Curly and Shemp inhabited a world entirely their own, a surreal place where cream pies could fly, and hammer blows to the head never drew blood.

headline: Image of the Day: April 13
text: Rongali Bihu, or the Assamese new year celebrations in Assam.

headline: Renting a Giant Rat
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Leading Off: The N.H.L. Goes Long
text: If the N.H.L. is good for anything — aside from its cottage industry in defining which skull-rattling hits are dangerous and which are just boys being boys — it is good for taking up time. Yes, it has a season that is best measured by the geologic time scale. Yes, its playoffs are so long the Stanley Cup champions have no idea whom they played in the first round. And so, on the second day of the playoffs, why not have four overtimes?

headline: The Game Is Called Chicken
text: From Matt Bai’s article, we learned that the two parties’ leaders can get within a few hundred billion dollars of a nearly $3 trillion deficit deal. But we also learned that, even if one of those leaders (President Obama) were to concede the entire amount of that difference (i.e., rolling his revenue demands back from $1.2 trillion to $800 billion), the other leader (John Boehner) still couldn’t sell it to his own team. Which means we didn’t actually end up within a few hundred billion dollars of a deal. We ended up pretty much where we started: With one side absolutely refusing to raise even a minuscule amount of revenue and the other side willing to do trillions in cuts as long as it got some new revenue in return, but never getting it. Unlike Bai, I see little grounds for optimism here.

headline: The Real Oil Shock
text: When Adam Davidson writes, “In Europe, where taxes keep gas prices well above $5 a gallon, citizens are more likely to take public transportation and live near the center of town,” what he’s doing is expressing a real “let them eat cake” attitude. Outside the downtown areas of a handful of huge cities, Americans have very little access to public transportation. Europeans are more likely to take public transportation because nearly the entire map of Europe is served by affordable, clean and safe public transportation that runs frequently.

headline: To Mooch or Not to Mooch?
text: A colleague recently took a business trip to Manhattan that was paid for by the organization we work for, an underfinanced nonprofit. There was construction at her hotel, which understandably affected her comfort. She complained and was offered three free nights for a subsequent visit. She hasn’t told our supervisor, but she wants to use the credit for a weekend away with her husband. I feel she should offer the credit to our employer. We face serious budget constraints and could use the free stay on another business trip. NAME WITHHELD

headline: I Was 18 and Pregnant
text: When I was 18 and about seven months pregnant, I bumped into a friend of my mother’s at the clinic. Tante Safi was Egyptian — like my mother — and had lived in America for more than 20 years. I called her Tante, French for “aunt.” She had struggled with cancer for as long as we’d known her.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Childhood
text: The fixation on a cure for early puberty makes an already uncomfortable time in a girl’s life infinitely more fraught. I had my first period at 10, and when I told my mother, she collapsed on the bed, sobbing: “My baby is going to be short and fat. Short and fat!” My body-mass index placed me on the extreme low end of overweight. What followed were two years of bone scans, forced physical activity, a strict diet and endless scrutiny of my body’s changes. No attempts were ever made to make me feel that puberty was normal, because my parents were very clear that my puberty was abnormal. In the long run, I turned out utterly normal (and taller and thinner than average), but I didn’t feel comfortable in my own body until years after I no longer stood out as precociously mature.

headline: Pump It Up
text: Oil, that is. Texas tea.

headline: The Soft Middle of François Hollande
text: Even after a precampaign diet last year — less wine, less cheese and especially less chocolate — François Hollande, the Socialist who is currently favored to become the next president of France, still has a soft face and looks slightly sloppy in his medium-gray suits. He used to be referred to as “Flanby,” after a brand of wobbly caramel pudding, just one of a string of insulting nicknames for a convivial man considered always at the second rank of politics. He has been called “a living marshmallow” and “Mr. Little Jokes,” and just last year, Martine Aubry, the head of the Socialist Party, described him as a couille molle, a nasty way of saying he has no guts. Recently, a frustrated Nicolas Sarkozy, fighting hard to be re-elected, fumed: “Hollande is useless! He’s useless, do you understand?”

headline: Who Made That Stiletto?
text: The ancient Greeks depicted Aphrodite in elevator shoes. Centuries later, Venetian courtesans clopped around in towering chopines, while during the reign of Louis XIV, red heels were a mark of nobility. But it was after World War II that the stiletto took hold. Soldiers who spent years abroad dreaming of high-heeled pinups, one historian wrote, came home to wives whose wartime work required more sensible shoes. As women returned to domestic life, higher heels could, and did, become all the rage. From the 1950s’ froth of experimentation, the stiletto was born.

headline: ‘The Second Shelf’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: A MOMENT IN THE SUN,  by John Sayles. (McSweeney’s, $18.) With its political intrigue, fraught romances and life-threatening adventures, Sayles’s vast historical novel recalls both Harriet Beecher Stowe and Thomas Pynchon. The book opens in 1897, during the Klondike gold rush, and closes in 1903, the year after the Philippine-American War ended. In between, Sayles takes the measure of America from the perspectives of Western ramblers, war profiteers, black soldiers and Filipino insurgents.

headline: Why French Parents Are Superior (in One Way)
text: Consider this: Our children are three times more likely to be overweight than French children. In fact, we lead the world in producing overweight children, but the French have one of the lowest rates of overweight children in the developed world.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TIME TO START THINKING: America in the Age of Descent,  by Edward Luce. (Atlantic Monthly, $26.) To restore its waning competitiveness, America will need a much more effective federal government, Luce, a British journalist, warns.

headline: Resting Places
text: One of the first things to strike you about Michael McGriff’s work is that it’s populated: his poems have people in them. What strikes you next is that the citizens of McGriffville are mired in various stages of desperation.

headline: Once More, With Feelings
text: For a while, we heard everywhere F. Scott Fitzgerald’s pronouncement that there are no second acts in American life. We took it for the notion that youth was everything — you made it while you were young or not at all — but it primarily applies to Fitzgerald himself. By 1934, when Dick Diver appeared in “Tender Is the Night,” the stock market had crashed, the expatriate rich seemed beside the point and the beautiful young writer had only six years to live. He died at 44 — a kid! His American life didn’t get a second act.

headline: The Iron Lady and the Gipper
text: In 1950, a 24-year-old industrial research chemist named Margaret Roberts stood unsuccessfully as a Conservative candidate in the British general election. “We believe in the democratic way of life,” she told the voters. “If we serve the idea faithfully, with tenacity of purpose, we have nothing to fear from Russian Communism.”

headline: Executive Overreach
text: Some readers will come to Rachel Maddow’s first book expecting an entertaining left-wing screed against the military. They may be surprised to discover instead a lively but serious argument about American history.

headline: Trench Poet
text: It has never been easy to follow Hamlet quite as far as he would like to go — as far, even, as “the undiscovered country from whose bourn / No traveler returns.” Just ask Horatio, who tries to prevent his reckless friend from chasing Old Hamlet’s ghost at the beginning of Shakespeare’s tragedy and who counsels an intellectual restraint toward its end as the two confront mortality itself in the graveyard. When Hamlet, contemplating Yorick’s skull, attempts to “trace the noble dust of Alexander” to the cork that seals a cask, the prudent Horatio admonishes, “ ’Twere to consider too curiously to consider so.”

headline: Under Siege
text: “Children in Reindeer Woods,” the first of the Icelandic writer Kristin Omarsdottir’s novels to be translated into English, is an assured introduction to her work. In Lytton Smith’s translation, its tone is placid throughout, a smooth skin that stirs only slightly, for laughter’s sake or to tremble in anticipation of violence.

headline: Who’s There?
text: Americans have developed a peculiar reverence for the concept of “reality.” We use the term to legitimize all manner of sleazy entertainment, and to judge our political leaders, whose capacity for being “real” is apparently measured by their willingness to drink beer with us. Of course, this bias has long informed our literary tradition, in which realism signifies authenticity and adulthood, the normative and hallowed province of James, Hemingway and Carver. Depart from it at your peril, ink-stained wretches, for a conveniently labeled ghetto awaits you — experimental, fabulist, surreal — all terms that signify, in the popular imagination anyway, artifice, obscurity and a kind of childish indulgence.

headline: Goldman’s Blankfein Collects $12 Million
text: Compensation for the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, fell roughly 35 percent to $12 million in 2011, in a year when the company’s stock tumbled 46.2 percent.

headline: A Missionary Impulse
text: “The Jews are like rats,” Peter Beinart’s grandmother told him when he was a boy. “We leave the sinking ship.” This grandmother — who was born in Egypt and lived in South Africa but dreamed of joining her brother in Israel — believed that Israel was the last refuge of a hounded people, and she made Beinart, who was born in the United States, believe it, too.

headline: Breadwomen
text: Five or six years ago, my mother and I sat in a darkened theater talking about a couple we knew. The wife was an executive with Ivy League degrees. The husband had some nebulous part-time job, but mostly he stayed home with the kids. What, I wondered, does he have that’s attractive to her? There was a pause. Sperm, my mother replied.

headline: 100 Years at Sea
text: Centenaries are often just a dusting off and reassessment of faded historical memory. But 100 years after the Titanic sank in the North Atlantic, it is remarkable to contemplate how little the ship has drifted from public consciousness. Schoolchildren the world over still recognize the luxury liner’s name thanks to a century’s worth of books, articles, films and deep-ocean exploration. The interrupted stories of those who died on its voyage, however, and the troubled post-disaster lives of those who survived, are less well known. Two new books attempt to fill that void. Yet like the crew members who ushered the wealthy into the lifeboats first, these narratives favor first class over steerage.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: NO ONE  By Gwenaëlle Aubry.Translated by Trista Selous.  Tin House, paper, $12.95.

headline: Dreams of Youth
text: Lynda Barry’s excitable, bittersweet cartoons and collages are practically a cultural fixture, like little black dresses or “The Simpsons.” So it’s a welcome surprise to discover she actually had a formative period. BLABBER BLABBER BLABBER (Drawn & Quarterly, $24.95), the first volume of a projected complete-works series called “Everything,” compiles Barry’s early comic strips, drawn circa 1980, when she was still groping toward her sensibility and developing her recurring characters. Still, there’s not a lot you could call juvenilia here, beyond a pasted-in 1972 drawing of a creature emerging from a can of “tomato monster soup” (captioned “I drew this in the ninth grade and felt incredible afterward”) — except in the sense that her mature work aspires to be juvenilia, to extract nervous comedy and pathos from the way young people explain the world to themselves.

headline: Big Jewels!
text: With heavyweight roles and gems to match, the brightest actresses from across the pond prepare to dazzle. Go to our interactive feature >>

headline: Romney vs. Romney
text: It’s unlikely that Mitt Romney saw the film “The Graduate” when it appeared in 1967. He was a 20-year-old Mormon missionary in France at the time, isolated from the cultural influences that shaped most Americans of the baby-boom generation, and his taste in movies ran to more wholesome fare like “The Sound of Music.” If he had seen it, though, one doubts that he would have scoffed along with his contemporaries during the scene in which a smarmy businessman declares that the key to the future is “plastics.” He might have considered it useful career advice.

headline: My Life With Bob
text: With no small amount of trepidation, I lay open here the first page of my diary — high-­schoolish stabs at intellectualism, fleeting girlish obsessions, deliberately obscure annotations and all. After many failed adolescent attempts at keeping a journal, the summer after my junior year in high school, I finally found a format I could adhere to: Never mind describing the back-and-lack-of-forths of unrequited crushes and falling-outs with friends. I decided to list the books I read instead.

headline: Plans for The Elevens, a Member-Owned Restaurant, Are Still in Limbo
text: It was called The Elevens, and it was a shimmering dream: a sort of fusion of a utopian culinary community and Cheers bar. But now its opening has been delayed, and its owners have had to reconsider its central concept: a self-financed community of drinkers and diners.

headline: After Rescuing Woman From Fire, a Mayor Recalls His Fear and Focus
text: There was a moment, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark said Friday, when he “thought we were not going to make it.”

headline: Business Day Live | April 13, 2012
text: Looking at earnings in the financial sector; Ron Lieber interviews Scott Griffith, chief executive of Zipcar; and on credit card fees, a test of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's power.

headline: Candor and Celebration on North Korean TV After Failed Rocket Launch
text: As my colleagues Choe Sang-hun and Rick Gladstone report, hours after a North Korean rocket disintegrated within minutes of launching on Friday, the country’s state media took the unusual step of admitting the failure.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/13
text: Getting Blown Away, Literally The airport on the Caribbean island of St. Maarten is mere yards away from a strip of beach, making takeoffs a tourist attraction. But a YouTube video that has attracted more than four million views shows a woman who got too close being blown by a plane’s exhaust into a concrete barrier, despite warning signs. Airport officials now say they will increase security measures. (USA Today)

headline: Making Spinach the Star of the Meal
text: Many people serve spinach as a side dish, but in this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to serve spinach as the main course.

headline: Believe Charter Network Founder Indicted
text: The city's determination to close the Believe Charter Network schools came into focus on Thursday when its founder, Eddie Calderon-Melendez, was arrested on 11 felony counts, including tax fraud, grand larceny and falsifying business records.

headline: Minorca Revealed
text: What does a 270-square-mile biosphere look like? Take a tour of Minorca.

headline: Off the Coast of Spain, a Tranquil Biosphere Reserve
text: MINORCA, the first place in Spain to see the sun rise, is aglow at the end of the day. As I pulled my suitcase down the cobbled, car-free lanes of Ciutadella, the island’s ancient capital, an ocher glow bloomed across the faces of residents who sat on the terraces of back-street bars, their voices echoing within a canyon of Gothic and Baroque buildings.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Michael Kranish and Scott Helman discuss their biography of Mitt Romney; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jeremy Denk talks about the sounds of nature; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Obama, Like Buffett, Had Lower Tax Rate Than His Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — For months, President Obama has marveled that the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary, citing it as an egregious example of an unjust tax code. It turns out that another famous and well-compensated American does, too: Mr. Obama.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Hearts and Courage
text: The lesson of the Tin Man hits home at P.S. 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, as the weather warms and the fifth-grade production of "The Wizard of Oz" continues to come together. Helene Stapinski, a parent volunteer who is co-producing the musical, writes in this week's installment of "The Munchkins Are a Problem" about a school tragedy -- and how the show goes on.

headline: In Defense of an Accused Teacher
text: A United Federation of Teachers chapter leader writes about his friend, Eric Chasanoff, one of 16 teachers who were recently profiled in newspaper stories about teachers who were cleared by arbitrators after being repeatedly charged with inappropriate behavior with students. He defends Mr. Chasanoff and writes: "Department of Education officials used the procedure they negotiated, and lost. For them to say, now, that it was unfair, smacks of sour grapes."

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The ’wichcraft ice cream kiosk reopens for the spring and summer on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. in Bryant Park, north of 40th Street and east of Avenue of the Americas. A scoop of ice cream or an ice cream sandwich will be handed out free.

headline: Times of London Sued in Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — As Britain’s hacking scandal shows little sign of easing, a high-profile London lawyer who has been closely involved in pursuing cases involving Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids said on Friday that his firm was suing the upmarket Times of London over e-mail hacking for which the newspaper has apologized.

headline: Mammoth Lakes, Calif., Faces Bankruptcy
text: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — It was a seemingly perfect day at this ski resort town high in the Sierra Nevada this week, one that could have redeemed the season’s poor snowfall under brighter circumstances. Families here on spring break were enjoying the slopes or shopping at the luxury outlet mall. Some stocked up at the Vons supermarket for dinner, while others braved the half-hour waits at the town’s popular restaurants.

headline: Inside the List
text: LOVE, NIA: “There are two phone calls parents don’t ever want to get from their children,” the writer Adriana Trigiani once said. “No. 1 is: ‘I’m in prison. Come fetch me.’ And No. 2 is, ‘I’ve written a novel . . . and it’s set in your hometown.’ ” As far as I can tell Trigiani has never done time, unless you count writing for TV (she worked on “The Cosby Show” and other sitcoms), but she did set her first three novels in the Blue Ridge Mountain town of Big Stone Gap, Va., where she grew up. Since then she has frequently turned to her Italian-American heritage for material; her 12th novel, “The Shoemaker’s Wife,” which slides onto the hardcover fiction list at No. 5, is based on the lives of her immigrant grandparents. A couple of years ago, in a conversation with the novelist Lauren Baratz-Logsted, Trigiani said she is sometimes mistaken for the actress Nia Vardalos, who wrote and starred in “My Big Fat Greek Wedding.” “Once on a plane,” she said, “a lady asked for my autograph. I said, ‘I’m not her.’ And she went back to her seat and halfway through the flight, she came back with a napkin, and she said, ‘Either sign this or I’ll tell the entire plane who you are and you’ll have to sign all the napkins.’ So, I signed, ‘Love, Nia Vardalos,’ on the napkin.”

headline: Obamas and Bidens Release Their 2011 Tax Returns
text: The White House released on Friday the president’s and the vice president’s 2011 state and federal income tax returns.

headline: Magic Fingers
text: “There’s really no logic,” says Peter Philips, Chanel’s creative director for makeup, explaining how he dreams up nail colors that regularly achieve mythic status before they even hit store counters. “I observe and listen to women, and then I follow my heart and my guts. It’s not a factory. I’m not a chicken that lays an egg. I just try to seduce women into discovering something they want. Because if they don’t like it, they won’t wear it.” Philips is obviously on to something, because Chanel’s nail polish sales have grown in the United States by 84 percent in the four years since he joined the brand.

headline: Trial Starts in Plot Against Danish Paper Over Cartoons of Prophet
text: STOCKHOLM — Four men went on trial in Denmark on Friday on charges of plotting a shooting spree in late 2010 at a Danish newspaper that published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, with prosecutors suggesting they intended to focus on the defendants’ links to Pakistan.

headline: Ford Tries to Save the Lincoln Brand
text: Ford Motor, alone among America’s Big Three automakers, staved off bankruptcy and survived the financial crisis. Its sales, profit and stock price have surged. Now it faces what may be an even tougher challenge: Can it save its faltering Lincoln brand?

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $13,000,000
text: A three-story Park Avenue town house never publicly listed for sale has changed hands for $13 million, making it the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

headline: Russian Lender Building Its Own Bloc in Eastern Europe
text: MOSCOW — The motto of the Russian state-owned bank Sberbank is “always nearby.” Its branches, adorned with a cheery green-and-white logo, are truly ubiquitous in its home market.

headline: Poland Trying to Build Banks' Defenses
text: The Polish authorities say they are open to an inflow of Russian capital, even if they are doing what they can to bolster Polish banks against Russian takeovers.

headline: Shumpert Is Old School, and in a Good Way
text: J.R. Smith’s heroics were enough to lead the Knicks to what could prove to be the most crucial win of the season, a 111-107 victory over the Bucks on Wednesday.

headline: Despite Good News, U.S. Bank Stocks Fall
text: Congratulations to JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo for beating estimates. Yet, those earnings reports weren’t enough to prevent a sagging in bank stocks on Friday.

headline: Mayor Cory A. Booker's Press Conference
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark spoke to the press the morning after saving his neighbor from a burning building.

headline: Weighing In on Consumer Agency’s Action on Upfront Card Fees
text: Updated: Friday, 6:40 p.m. to add bureau comment.

headline: The Great Locomotive Chase
text: For Confederates, the quickest connection across the Appalachian Mountains, which roughly split the eastern and western theaters of the war, was a railroad line from Richmond, Va., to Chattanooga, Tenn. From Chattanooga other lines fanned west and south toward the Mississippi and the Gulf of Mexico. Consequently, the Mountain City’s strategic significance was far greater than its population of just 2,500 people might lead one to believe.

headline: A To-Do List for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau released preliminary plans this week to require banks to improve their mortgage servicing and become more open and accountable in their dealings with consumers.

headline: On the Lens Blog: On the Bus, Away From the Pack
text: Eric Thayer, 37, has been covering the Republican nominating contest almost nonstop since last July in Iowa. He has mostly photographed for The New York Times but has also worked for Reuters in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: Sometimes it takes a little while for a great actress to find her footing as a star. How could it be otherwise? When one earns one’s living and professional acclaim by being an uncanny chameleon, it is a difficult trick to step unmasked into the bright light of fame. For Jessica Chastain, our cover girl, the path from critic’s darling to world-class celebrity has been one she has trod, in my view, with care and grace. When, in February, she walked the red carpet at the Oscars in a strapless embroidered gown by Sarah Burton for Alexander McQueen, she announced herself as being far more than a thespian able to portray anyone in any era for any auteur. (Her slate of releases is staggering.) I love that she chose McQueen for such a moment, that she understood how extraordinary fashion could be an entirely natural partner in the project of self-definition. Chastain is a great beauty and a terrific talent and, as Lynn Yaeger reveals, a lovely young woman on the verge of a major career.

headline: Why Are Charter Schools Exempt from Bullying Law?
text: In an opinion article, an official with the New York Civil Liberties Union says that charter schools should not be exempt from the state's new anti-bullying law. The legislation, which requires that schools provide in-class instruction from kindergarten through 12th grade about the importance of tolerance and respect for others, goes into effect in July.

headline: The New Republic Hawks Access to a ‘Once in a Lifetime’ Dinner
text: The New Republic on Friday evening canceled its planned lottery to attend the White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner, after being told that it violated the association’s rules. For more details, click here.

headline: BET Plans a Late-Night Satirical News Show
text: Add BET to the list of channels who will be competing in late-night television.

headline: Expanded Drawing Center to Reopen in September
text: The Drawing Center will reopen on Sept. 13 after a yearlong expansion, Brett Littman, the executive director announced on Friday.

headline: Unseen Guide’s Silent Journeys to Lyric Nature
text: FOR decades Nathaniel Dorsky has been making work of rare and sometimes startling beauty. If you haven’t heard of him, it’s because he makes short, silent experimental films that feature brightly colored flowers, bursts of sunlight and shifting pools of shadow instead of characters, plots and stories. Mostly he remains unknown to the larger audience because his work is relegated to that ghetto known as American avant-garde cinema. On Monday a program of his recent work will be shown in downtown Los Angeles at Redcat, an exhibition space in Walt Disney Concert Hall; Mr. Dorsky, who talks about his work in accessible, charming fashion, is scheduled to appear in person. On Friday another program of his work will be at the UCLA Film & Television Archive, also in Los Angeles.

headline: Wars: Imagined and Real
text: Politicians are always declaring a “war” on something. Often the conflict is entirely in their imaginations– like the War on Christmas and the War on Religion. Sometimes it’s a label designed to lend a sense of urgency to a problem they are not going to fix – like the War on Poverty and the War on Drugs.

headline: TimesCast | April 13, 2012
text: President Obama’s tax returns become a political weapon | The 100th anniversary of the Titanic’s sinking.

headline: A New Oversight Panel on Fracking
text: In an effort to streamline federal regulation of the domestic natural gas boom, President Obama on Friday announced creation of an inter-agency task force to ensure what he called the “safe and responsible development of domestic natural gas resources.”

headline: General Motors Recalls 50,000 Crossovers for Windshield Wiper Flaw
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Introducing ‘By the Book’
text: At his book signings and readings, David Sedaris, the author of many best-selling books, frequently promotes the work of other writers, telling audience members what he’s been reading recently and heartily recommends.

headline: Time for Some Garden Work: Redesign Planned at Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum
text: A cloistered garden at the historic Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston will be redesigned by the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh, the museum announced on Friday.

headline: The Danger of Flying While Khan
text: Shah Rukh Khan, India’s Tom Cruise, got detained at an American airport.

headline: From an Early Adopter to a Social Media Star
text: ROMANY MALCO was doing a live comedy show online, playing Tijuana Jackson, a prison-hardened life coach, when the phone rang. Mr. Malco was in the middle of a dark bit, in which Tijuana tells a story about being molested as a child. “I know it sounds crazy and horrible, but people would bust up when I would tell this story,” he said.

headline: China Says It May Reduce Role of Foreign Firms in Surveillance
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government, citing security concerns, has signaled that it may scale back the role that foreign companies play in the country’s fast-growing video surveillance industry.

headline: Business Day Live: Car Sharing
text: Looking at earnings in the financial sector; Ron Lieber interviews Scott Griffith, chief executive of Zipcar; and on credit card fees, a test of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s power.

headline: Journalists Invited to Pyongyang Are Scooped by Rocket Launching and Failure
text: More than 50 foreign journalists accepted coveted invitations to North Korea this week for the gala celebrations exalting the centenary of the country’s deceased founder Kim Il-sung, the ascension of his grandson Kim Jong-un to the top leadership posts and, perhaps most alluring, the launching of a multistage rocket that North Korea had said would triumphantly place a satellite into orbit.

headline: Your Suggestions on Force-Placed Insurance
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, returns to a subject he has discussed before — force-placed insurance. That is hazard, flood or wind insurance that a mortgage lender buys for the homeowner at a price that is almost always higher than the market rate.

headline: A World of Troubled Beauty
text: THE sheer beauty in Michael Glawogger’s trilogy of documentaries showing people at work across the globe can be startling. Whether it’s a scene involving an Indian dye worker coated head to toe in ochre, a voluptuous Mexican stripper turned into a touchable goddess by mesmerized men, or a roiling open-air slaughterhouse in Nigeria, Mr. Glawogger’s spectacles can induce in viewers awe at the visuals, surprise at the intimate access to exotic lives, and perhaps a vague sense of guilt. You might wonder: Is this for real, and is it O.K. to like it?

headline: How Green Are Electric Cars? Depends on Where You Plug In
text: IT’S a lot like one of those math problems that gave you fits in sixth grade: a salesman leaves home in Denver and drives his electric car to a meeting in Boulder. At the same time, a physicist driving the same model electric car sets out from her loft in Los Angeles, heading to an appointment near Anaheim.

headline: Japan Seeks to Restart Some Nuclear Power Plants
text: TOKYO — Hoping to avert potentially devastating summer power shortages, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that his government would seek to restart two nuclear reactors, in what would be a first step toward ending an almost complete shutdown of the nation’s nuclear power industry.

headline: Concern Raised Over Painkiller’s Use in Sports
text: When Mets pitcher R. A. Dickey partly tore the plantar fascia in his right foot last May, he turned to a treatment that in recent years has become a go-to elixir for professional baseball and football players: Toradol, an injectable anti-inflammatory drug.

headline: Why Hopkins-Maryland Always Matters
text: BALTIMORE — When the Johns Hopkins University men’s lacrosse team takes the field Saturday, it won’t be just another game for the Blue Jays. It won’t be just another meeting of top-ranked teams or just another rivalry game at historic Homewood Field. When Hopkins greets the University of Maryland at center field for the opening face-off — the surrounding grandstands appropriately divided between Hopkins’ light blue and Terrapin red — it’s never just another battle. It’s a lacrosse war.

headline: Chris Barley and Marc Kushner
text: DURING a summer internship in 2007, Chris Barley thought that he had found a mentor in the architect Marc Kushner. Both were 6-foot-4, dapperly handsome and from religious families.

headline: Saints Owner Agrees to Buy Hornets
text: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, agreed on Friday to buy the city’s N.B.A. franchise, the Hornets, for $338 million from the league.

headline: Wheelies: The Repeal Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Meanings in the Market
text: MONEY isn’t everything.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘A Streetcar Named Desire’
text: The latest Broadway revival of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” Tennessee Williams’s 1947 classic play about sex, booze and betrayal set in an apartment in the French Quarter of New Orleans, is mostly faithful to the original. But there is one very big twist this time around: the cast is multiracial. The production, from the producers of the all-black 2008 revival of Williams’s “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” stars Nicole Ari Parker as Blanche and Blair Underwood as Stanley, with Daphne Rubin-Vega as Stella and Wood Harris as Mitch. It is now in previews at the Broadhurst Theater.

headline: Robert Duffy Brings Marc by Marc Jacobs to Las Vegas
text: Robert Duffy, the president of Marc Jacobs, opens the Marc by Marc Jacobs store in Las Vegas today at the Forum Shops at Caesar’s Palace. The new boutique, the company’s second at Caesar’s (a Marc Jacobs collection shop opened in the Palace last year), will, like all great Marc by Marcs, stock a number of exclusive, location-themed accessories. Among them, playing cards ($10), one-of-a-kind sterling silver cuffs ($245) and belt buckles ($295) that look like they came straight from the rodeo show. To celebrate the grand opening, T asked Duffy for his tips on where to go and how to win in Sin City.

headline: Flamenco, and Food, in Madrid’s Retiro Park
text: Now through the summer, visitors to Madrid can see first-rate Spanish dance and flamenco performed Wednesday through Sunday nights at the 540-seat, Florida Park theater in elegant Retiro Park. Before and during the performances, full-course dinners, tapas meals or simply drinks are available, depending on how much one wants to indulge.

headline: From the ‘Broncs’ to ‘Coney,’ New York as a Scrabble Board
text: In the battle of the boroughs, it’s Queens, 15; Manhattan, 14; and Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island with zero; at least when it comes to Scrabble.

headline: Renewed Europe Worries Sap Deal-Makers Confidence
text: LONDON – Deal-making in Europe remains a tough sell.

headline: Bridal Hunger Games
text: JENNIFER DERRICK’S weight had crept to 159 pounds from 125, and she knew she would not fit into her grandmother’s wedding dress.

headline: New Woody Allen Film, Set in Rome, Draws Some Grumbling There
text: ROME — After London, Barcelona and Paris, Woody Allen‘s newest tribute to a European capital, “To Rome With Love,” had its premiere here on Friday. But the amorous sentiment may not be requited judging by the grumblings of some Italian journalists and film critics at a crowded post-screening news conference.

headline: Carbon In, Carbon Out: Sorting Out the Power Grid
text: Electric car mile-per- gallon equivalent in the United States.

headline: After an Excellent Season, Some Questions for Minnesota
text: The University of Minnesota men’s hockey team was picked to finish sixth out of 12 teams in its conference before the season — in the end it made it to the Frozen Four.

headline: Yankees Adjust Order: Rodriguez Bats 3rd, Cano 4th
text: Manager Joe Girardi is tinkering with the Yankees’ lineup after only six games of the 2012 season. But it is not because of anyone’s early struggles, he said.

headline: Parental Quandary: When Young Boys Joke About Rape
text: Two readers wrote to me recently with similar quandaries: young sons, around middle-school age, uncomfortable with the language that’s beginning to surround them at school.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Latest ‘Drops of God’
text: There are seven new titles on the manga list this week. Most of them are fairly deep into their stories. At No. 1, for example, is Volume 8 of Season 2 of “Rosario+Vampire,” about a high school where the student body is comosed of werewolves and vampires. At No. 2 is Volume 39 of “Bleach,” whose main character can see spirits and helps usher them into the afterlife. And at No. 3 is Volume 27 of the romance “Skip Beat!” I’m more likely to pick up Volume 3 of “The Drops of God,” which enters our list at No. 6 this week. The series, by Tadashi Agi and Shu Okimoto, centers on the son of a famous wine critic who must identify 12 wines to claim his inheritance. I included Volume 1 in our Holiday Gift Guide last year.

headline: Louvre Teams Up With Nintendo for New Guides
text: PARIS – Who says video games and high art don’t mix? The  Louvre this week offered a new fleet of interactive guides using the Nintendo 3DS, the handheld gaming devices, and featuring audio commentary about more than 700 sculptures and paintings along with three-dimensional models and high-definition photographs of several works.

headline: Rose Terrible but Bulls Beat Heat Anyway
text: Picture this scenario: Miami is playing Chicago, a pre-playoff glimpse at the Eastern Conference’s top teams. The Bulls’ Derrick Rose, the league’s reigning most valuable player, is shooting terribly, missing 12 of 13 shots and scoring a career-low 2 points.

headline: Learning to Run a Business by Running a Business
text: Last month, 2,500 people from across the nation and nine countries, including Bulgaria and Indonesia, gathered for a trade show at the Park Avenue Armory on Manhattan’s East Side. Working for companies that ranged from software development to tattoo studios, they hobnobbed and made deals. What made this different from the hundreds of other trade shows in the city each year? All of the participants were high school students who represented 153 schools from the United States and abroad.

headline: My Three Favorite Romney Spoofs of This Election Cycle
text: O.K., so we now know that in purportedly private moments, Mitt Romney talks about things like his wife’s “dressage horse.” Laugh if you must. While he may not inspire all segments of the Republican base, Romney has truly overachieved when it comes to offering material to comedians. We did some Romney-parodying of our own in the magazine this weekend, with a new screenplay by Etan Cohen, imagining a conversation between Romney and Newt Gingrich. But there’s so much more out there. Here are my favorite Romney spoofs of this election cycle.

headline: ‘American Idol’ and ‘Touch’ Get Ratings Boost on CBS Repeats Night
text: A full slate of repeats on CBS allowed the other broadcast networks to gain some ground in the ratings on Thursday. Fox was by far the No. 1 network for the night, according to Nielsen data, as both “American Idol” and “Touch” received a bump in viewership from last week. They finished with 15.3 million total viewers and 8.2 million, respectively.

headline: ‘Seven on Seven’ Collaborators Discuss the Meeting of the Digital and Art Worlds
text: “Seven on Seven,” an annual contemporary-art-meets-technology summit that has attracted some big names from both the art and tech worlds since its founding in 2010, will have its third incarnation on Saturday at the New Museum in Lower Manhattan. The event, founded by Rhizome, the new-media art organization in New York, actually begins a day earlier, when seven artists and seven people from the world of the digital revolution, meet for the first time and pair off. Then they sequester themselves, reality-show-style, in rooms around the city for a single day of collaboration, trying to hatch a project that might look like art, an app or something else that defies easy classification, playing around in what Robert Rauschenberg called the gap between art and life.

headline: A Dance-Heavy Coachella Begins in the Desert
text: INDIO, Calif. — This year’s edition of the three-day Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival begins on Friday, to run through Sunday. It has changed in at least one respect that the average festival-goer will barely notice: the entire lineup will repeat one week later, with identical order and set times. Both weekends have sold out; attendance is expected at around 75,000 per weekend.

headline: Romney Warns Gun Lobby of a Second Obama Term
text: ST. LOUIS — As he works to energize the conservative base ahead of the general election, Mitt Romney came to the annual gathering of the National Rifle Association on Friday seeking support from a powerful group that has not always embraced him.

headline: Fatal Collision Makes Car-Sharing Worries No Longer Theoretical
text: Last month, I wrote about RelayRides, a company that helps you rent your car to strangers. It’s a big enough idea that the company has attracted investments from Google and General Motors.

headline: RelayRides, Insurance and a Fatal Crash
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I explore the implications of a fatal accident that occurred when a renter at RelayRides, a car sharing company, had a fatal accident using someone else’s personal vehicle that left four other people injured.

headline: Want to Read Cuomo’s Story? Biographers Will Offer Options
text: The latest genre in book publishing appears to be biography of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Former Analyst Pleads Guilty in Dell Insider Trading Case
text: A former research analyst pleaded guilty to criminal charges in an insider-trading case that federal prosecutors have described as a “circle of friends” who together earned about $62 million in illegal gains in Dell stock.

headline: Coming Soon: ‘Taxmageddon’
text: WASHINGTON

headline: TimesCast | Zimmerman Appears In Court
text: April 12, 2012 — After being charged with second degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, George Zimmerman made his first court appearance Thursday afternoon.

headline: As Nuclear Talks With Iran Restart, New Hopes for Deal
text: ISTANBUL — Diplomats gathered here on Friday for talks with Iran about its nuclear enrichment program, with European officials suggesting that a serious commitment from Iran to negotiate may be enough to continue the talks at another round in late May.

headline: Google Ad Project Updates Classic Alka-Seltzer and Avis Pitches
text: A project by Google to reimagine classic advertising campaigns from the 1960s and 1970s for contemporary sensibilities — and technologies — is proceeding with work for two additional brands.

headline: Live Analysis: Yankee Stadium Opener — Yankees 5, Angels 0
text: Justin Sablich, with the help of his Times colleagues, is covering the Yankees home opening game against the Angels live from Yankee Stadium. Continue reading for live updates and analysis.

headline: Fivestory, a New Midtown Boutique, Chooses Carefully
text: On Thursday afternoon, Fred Distenfeld looked unfazed and spotless in his suit as workmen carried slabs of polished stone into the town house at 18 East 69th Street. On April 19, it will open as the boutique Fivestory.

headline: Posada Throws Ceremonial First Pitch, to His Father
text: Jorge Posada watched his former teammate Andy Pettitte halt a one-year retirement to return to the Yankees last month. Now that Posada, the former catcher, is retired after 17 seasons with the club, he joked that he must wait a year, as Pettitte did, before he considered a return.

headline: How Old Is the ‘Fire Stone’?
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: Eyewitnesses to Mayor Booker's Rescue
text: Eyewitnesses recount Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark's rescue of  a neighbor from her burning home on Thursday night.

headline: Dueling Pencils: 4 Firms to Compete for Project at Menil Collection in Houston
text: Four architecture firms will compete to design the first major building project under the Menil Collection’s long-range plan to improve its campus in Houston, Josef Helfenstein, the museum’s director, announced on Friday.

headline: DeBoer: Popular With Devils, Less So With Panthers
text: As the Devils begin their series against Florida, it seems that both sides are happy that Peter DeBoer is the Devils’ coach.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Tree for the Hopeful
text: For a few brief hours, a “wish tree” flourished in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, and the hopeful and the heartbroken pinned their desires to an English elm. “Peace.” “Get the job.” “I wish my son wouldn’t use drugs.” “I wish my wife would love me.” All written on strips of ribbon and thumbtacked to the trunk. Then the parks department got wind of it. Soon, there was only one wish left. Read more on The Local »

headline: U.S. Condemns Prison Term for Ukraine’s Ex-Defense Chief
text: MOSCOW — The United States Embassy in Ukraine on Friday condemned as politically motivated the imprisonment of a former defense minister allied with Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister whose own imprisonment has provoked an international outcry.

headline: Sizing Up the Impact of Tax Cuts (and Their End)
text: Without the Bush tax cuts of 2001, 2003 and 2008 and the Obama tax cuts of the last few years, median after-tax household income would be about $1,750 a year lower than it is. All of those tax cuts, of course, face an uncertain fate, because they are scheduled to expire at the end of this year.

headline: Ignoring College Rankings to Find My No. 1 School
text: Where did senior year go? I feel like someone pressed a fast-forward button from August to April. I blinked, and my college application process was over — except for the decision.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Unspoiled Sounds of Nature
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Jeremy Denk reviews “The Great Animal Orchestra,” the musician and naturalist Bernie Krause’s new book about what can be heard in the world’s truly wild places, where human noise has not changed the soundscape. On YouTube, you can hear audio clips to accompany the book, like “water sounds” and “fire sounds.” There’s also a clip available of Mr. Krause explaining how the bursting cells of a tree make a kind of music, which one commenter on YouTube says sounds “like Aphex Twin.” Mr. Denk writes:

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Awash in Cash
text: We examined Facebook’s $1 billion deal for a mobile start-up, Microsoft’s $1 billion deal for patents and a $2.15 billion “lawsuit waiting to happen.” A look back on our reporting of the last week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Wavii: A Facebook for Topics
text: Facebook has transformed how we keep tabs on friends, by training people to constantly publish short status updates about the delicious meal they just ate or the killer vacation they just took. A site called Wavii opened to the public earlier this week that wants to do the same thing for topics, with short bursts of news on everything from corporate acquisitions to celebrities.

headline: Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street, 11:41 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Mayor kisses Muppet.

headline: Bob Lutz, Design Critic? Grading the Ex-G.M. Executive on His Latest Gig
text: Robert A. Lutz, the former vice chairman and product czar of General Motors, has been peripatetic in retirement, taking on advisory roles for Lotus, G.M. and the electric truck and van start-up Via Motors, in addition to writing a book, “Car Guys vs. Bean Counters: The Battle for the Soul of American Business.” As a columnist for Forbes.com, Mr. Lutz recently assumed the mantle of design critic, discussing the front ends, or faces, of recently unveiled cars, including several from the current New York auto show.

headline: Reasons to Be Sent to the Principal's Office
text: New York City principals are expected to create a culture of leadership in their buildings. Their offices say something about their personal style. Take a look at a group of principals in their offices, and send in more photos to build our collection.

headline: A Résumé Centering on Latin Jazz, With Interests That Include Cultural Fusion
text: The emblematic tune in Yosvany Terry’s early set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night was the closer, “Summer Relief,” a slippery bit of cultural cross talk. It began with a Yoruba chant by the conga player Pedro Martínez, in a call-and-response with the band. A groove materialized, in irregular polyrhythm, and then came a coiled melody assigned to Michael Rodriguez on trumpet and Mr. Terry on alto saxophone.

headline: Brushstroke Adds a Sushi Bar, and a Chef
text: Eiji Ichimura (above), who owned Ichimura on the Upper East Side before it closed in 2008, is now the sushi chef at Brushstroke, one of David Bouley’s restaurants in TriBeCa.

headline: Painting a New York Everyman
text: “Moses is described in the Torah as the most modest man who ever lived. My father was the second most. He thought of himself, and wanted others to think of him, as simply ordinary. Perhaps that inspired me to often depict him as Everyman.” — Max Ferguson

headline: A Decision on the Bahrain Grand Prix — Oh, and There’s a Race in China Too
text: SHANGHAI — Until today’s first practice sessions for the Chinese Grand Prix, the talk in Shanghai had not been about the race here at all, but about whether the Bahrain Grand Prix — the race scheduled after this one — would take place. Finally, after a day and a half in Shanghai, all the various stakeholders are agreed: Bahrain will happen.

headline: TimesCast | Presidential Tax Returns
text: April 13, 2012 - The White House strategically releases President Obama's tax returns.

headline: Meyer Defends His Tenure at Florida
text: Months before Urban Meyer can coach his first game with the Ohio State Buckeyes, he had to play some defense.

headline: New Figures Stoke the Home Inequity Debate
text: A little more light is being shed on a type of loan that has been stinking up bank balance sheets.

headline: The Matzo Economic Miracle
text: For this week’s It’s the Economy column, Adam Davidson and I visited two of the leading matzo manufacturers in the country. We learned a few things about the matzo business. First, kosher laws make matzo-baking a total pain in the tuchus. Second, that can be good for business. After all, the complexity of kosher laws could scare off potential competitors.

headline: Spring Staples | Twinkle Toes
text: Seasons change and so must accessories.

headline: TimesCast: Presidential Tax Returns
text: The White House strategically released President Obama’s tax returns. Richard W. Stevenson reports.

headline: Photo Replay: April 13
text: The Grand National horse racing meeting continued in Aintree, England, and the world fencing championships took place in Kiev, Ukraine.

headline: TimesCast | A Grandmother's Survival
text: Jim Dwyer, Metro’s ‘About New York” columnist, spoke with the New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn about her grandmother’s escape from the Titanic.

headline: Lefties Aren’t Special After All
text: Amsterdam

headline: Diamonds as a Commodity
text: Could diamonds be the new gold?

headline: Don’t Kill the Electric Car
text: My article in the Automobiles section on Friday addressed the question of electric-vehicle greenhouse-gas emissions.

headline: Erik Larson to Write Book on Sinking of the Lusitania
text: Just as the publishing industry has finished marking the 100th anniversary of the Titanic’s sinking with dozens of related books, at least one publisher is looking ahead to another anniversary: the sinking of the British ocean liner Lusitania by a German U-boat during World War I. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said on Friday that it had acquired a nonfiction book by Erik Larson, the author of “The Devil in the White City,” that will “offer a fresh take” on the sinking.

headline: Has Motherhood Replaced Sexism?
text: Officially conceded, after the commentary on yesterday’s post regarding Hilary Rosen’s description of Ann Romney as “never having worked a day in her life:” the “mommy wars” between (some) stay-at-home mothers and (some) mothers who work outside the home are still raging.

headline: In 3-D: How Mariano Rivera Dominates Hitters
text: Mariano Rivera is one of the best closers in the game, thanks in part to a cutter pitch that leaves his hand much like a fastball but crosses the plate very differently.

headline: Holland Tunnel Inbound to Shut Overnight
text: Ever get the urge to re-texture a tunnel roadway?

headline: Bachata Royalty, Long-Haul Rapper, Australian Brats
text: Vena

headline: A Nomadic Life Has Roots in Jazz
text: “LISTEN to this,” the pianist Kirill Gerstein said, clicking “play” on his iPhone. The recording, a synthesizer track that approximated the sounds of a piano and a vibraphone, was a rough demo for “The Visitors,” a work the jazz pianist Chick Corea had written for Mr. Gerstein and his former mentor the vibraphonist Gary Burton.

headline: Mitch Petrus’s Newest Groove
text: As Mitch Petrus’s role with the Giants increased during the 2011 season, he found it more and more difficult to find time for his other passion: his alt-rock band, known as Vikings of the North Atlantic or VONA.

headline: The Chic, Lethal Salons on the Screens of France
text: PARIS

headline: Was Hilary Rosen’s Remark About Ann Romney ‘Witless’?
text: Several readers have objected to my calling Hilary Rosen’s comments about Ann Romney “witless.” They seem to think I’ve joined Republicans in expressing “faux outrage.”

headline: Ringing Voice and Guitar Echo Globally
text: CALL it double exposure. “Folila,” a new album by Amadou & Mariam, the blind husband-and-wife duo from Mali, was recorded twice, once in New York with an all-star cast of indie musicians and once in Mali with a crew of traditional instrumentalists. Though their original plan was to make two albums, they ended up mixing the separately recorded tracks together.

headline: Adrift in New York, Web Comics Seek a Larger Audience
text: WHEN Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson met for lunch at Cafe Cluny in the West Village recently, they looked tanner than usual. Ms. Glazer had taken up biking: “It’s my new thing,” she said.

headline: For Objects of a Gaze, a Chance to Return It
text: What’s with the shared bill? Over the past few months, choreographers have been pairing up everywhere, from New York Live Arts to the Kitchen and, finally, Danspace Project, where on Thursday evening, another double bill was unveiled, featuring Liz Santoro and Anne Zuerner. There’s something regressive about this way of packaging dance. Ms. Santoro’s “We Do Our Best” may not have been perfect, but it deserved its own night.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 13
text: Subjects include wildfires throughout the region, Occupy Wall Street’s move to the sidewalks and a kidney transplant between brothers.

headline: Baby Hawks Get Their Close-Up
text: The eyases that hatched earlier this week in Washington Square Park were photographed for the first time.

headline: April 15 — 21
text: THE 19th annual NEW YORK AFRICAN FILM FESTIVAL presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and African Film Festival, mainly at the Walter Reade Theater this week, offers a valuable roundup of documentaries and features, most released in the last two years. This edition’s theme, 21st Century: The Homecoming, explores the modern notion of home and homeland while commemorating the 100th anniversary of the African National Congress and the 50th anniversary of independence for Algeria, Burundi, Jamaica, Rwanda and Uganda.

headline: A Walk Up the Wild Side of the Alps
text: NO day ever broke more thrillingly.

headline: Star Pianist Establishes the Tempo of the Night
text: If you consider how far in advance artists are booked at major American orchestras, it did not take the New York Philharmonic long to schedule the fast-rising Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden’s debut with the orchestra , which took place on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. van Zweden, an accomplished violinist who came later to conducting, is not widely known in America. Now 51, he has been thriving as the music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra since 2008, and he brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall last May for an impressive program as part of the Spring for Music Festival.

headline: In A.C.C. Tournament, a Different Spot for Maryland Women’s Lacrosse
text: The A.C.C. tournament is on the horizon for the No. 5 Maryland women’s lacrosse team, and it already knows that it will not be in a familiar spot. For the first time in recent memory, the Terrapins did not receive one of the top two seeds in the tournament. Which means if they have any plans of hoisting the A.C.C. trophy, they’re going to have to do it the hard way.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 13
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: A Success on Opening Day
text: There were no rings to distribute and no flag to be raised, but opening day at the Stadium otherwise could not have gone better for the Yankees. Beginning with Jorge Posada’s ceremonial first pitch and ending with a strikeout by reliever Dave Robertson, it was a day to soothe pinstriped hearts after last season’s bitter postseason elimination.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 13
text: More Photographs

headline: Crisis and Aftermath, in Treasury’s Slide Show
