text: The Treasury Department published an interesting slide show Friday afternoon illustrating the depth of the financial crisis, the impact of the government’s intervention and the state of the economy.

headline: Chic in Review | Jean Paul Gaultier for Diet Coke
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Korea, Israel and Egypt.

headline: Parents’ Fight With Apple Over ‘Bait Apps’ Moves Forward
text: Is Apple doing enough to protect parents’ wallets from their own children? That seems to be the debate that has been brewing in a year-old lawsuit related to iPhone apps and the purchasing mechanisms inside them.

headline: Attacking Romney From the Right
text: If you covered up the byline, you might guess the attack on Mitt Romney’s gun policies was coming from Governor Rick Perry of Texas, the former presidential candidate who likes to jog while carrying a handgun with a laser sight.

headline: Spain Targets Tax Fraud to Counter a Recession
text: MADRID — The Spanish government approved a number of measures on Friday to crack down on tax fraud as part of its efforts to reassure investors that Madrid can replenish the public coffers by bringing to the surface some of the country’s hidden wealth.

headline: What JPMorgan’s Bonds Say About the Fortress Balance Sheet
text: One number in JPMorgan Chase’s first-quarter earnings suggests that not everyone believes in the fortress balance sheet.

headline: Landlocked or Not, Seaweed Salad
text: THOUGH I wouldn’t describe myself as a health nut, I do tend to cook and eat with an eye toward wholesome ingredients. Naturally there are some exceptions, but it’s always nice when the food you crave is actually good for you. With spring in full force, I seem to want cleaner, lighter fare. And seaweed, especially seaweed salad, has been beckoning.

headline: Seaweed, in Salads and More
text: For this week’s City Kitchen column, I got to play around with seaweed. Seaweed salad was the dish I was craving. I have eaten a fair amount of it over the years (some good, some wonderful and some too strangely bright green to be natural) but had never made it myself. Along the way, I learned a lot, and treated myself and my guests to more than just salad.

headline: No Scrolling Required at New Dating Sites
text: CAN you find love in six minutes?

headline: Middle-Eastern Fare, With a Corner-Diner Feel
text: I love a good diner. There’s something about the abundance of choices, the inclusive atmosphere and the often reasonable prices that’s uniquely American and wonderfully comforting.

headline: Broccoli Rabe, Olive and Parmesan Calzone
text: Time: About 40 minutes

headline: A Violinist Wielding Both Bow and Baton
text: Joshua Bell has shown little inclination to trade in his violin for a baton, so the announcement last September that he would become the music director of the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields in London seemed surprising. As it turns out, the position does not actually demand that he let the fiddle slip from his lands, let alone exchange it for a stick.

headline: See You Later, Pizza, This Dough Is for Calzones
text: MAYBE it’s the suggestive power of the name, but rarely do I use pizza dough for anything else, even though it’s perfectly suitable for savory tarts, flatbreads and rolls. Once I get pizza on the brain, it’s hard to redirect. Then I got reacquainted with an old friend also made from that same dough: the calzone.

headline: Between the Lines of Harvard’s Red Book
text: THE first thing you need to know about the Red Book is that when Harvard graduates talk about it (which they do a lot), they’re not talking about Mao Zedong’s pamphlet of axioms. That is, they’re not talking about “The Little Red Book” but about The Big One, the one that lands at five-year intervals with the thud of a Manhattan phone directory on the doorstep of everyone who has ever graduated from the college, and keeps on arriving for as long as they live, whether they want it or not, a gift from the tireless alumni association.

headline: Video: How to Make Calzones
text: This week’s column is about making calzones, which is something that can be done with your favorite pizza dough.

headline: How to Make Calzones
text: Pizza dough might just have a higher calling: calzones. Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make them at home.

headline: An Artist’s Journey From Comic Books to Museum Walls
text: PARIS — R. Crumb, the American cartoonist, is said to be a timid, reclusive soul who doesn’t like visitors, photographers, reporters or even fans.

headline: Baby Hawks Get Their Close-Up
text: In the center of a messy, bowl-shaped pile of branches, twine, plastic bags and pizza plates, two baby hawks lifted their wobbly white pompom heads Friday morning to snap at red chunks of rat flesh dangling from their mother’s beak. Steadying the rodent corpse with a talon, she tore stringy entrails and delicately fed them to her offspring, bit by bit.

headline: Homage to an Abbey, Tucked Into a Casino
text: ONLY in a phantasmagoria like Mohegan Sun could one encounter a place like Ballo Italian Restaurant and Social Club, “inspired by” San Galgano, a 12th-century Tuscan abbey. Ballo’s gothic arches rise in stark contrast to the gargantuan Native American-themed décor surrounding them. Enormous gates open onto cathedral-vaulted dining rooms, a central 158-foot Carrara marble bar, and a cocktail lounge (the “abbey”) with modish, not-so ecclesiastical, zebra-striped chairs. On Friday and Saturday nights, from 11 p.m. until the casino closes at 2 a.m., the restaurant turns into a nightclub with a D.J., dancing and a late-night menu.

headline: Now Online | T Summer Women’s Fashion 2012
text: The Summer Fashion and Beauty issue of T stars Jessica Chastain, taking a break from nonstop filming to chat with Lynn Yeager. There’s also a road trip with William H. Macy and a portfolio of the big jewels of the season on six young actresses, including Hayley Atwell and Eve Hewson, from across the pond. Don’t forget to check out The Selby as he shops at Cookbook in Los Angeles, or to read Joyce Maynard’s account of taking the short-hair plunge. Looking for more on cosmetics? Let Peter Philips, Chanel’s creative director for makeup, fill you in on new nail colors, and Sandra Ballentine reveals why last night’s makeup is better the next day. When you’re done, head over to “Salad Days,” a surrealist fashion fantasy, and meet the musical duo Big Deal. See more from the issue >>

headline: Hitting the Streets in a Harlem Precinct
text: There’s only one thing wrong with “NYC 22,” the latest CBS cop show. Every minute that you’re watching it, you are wearyingly aware of how very many cop shows there are.

headline: The Art of Raising Kids
text: To the Editor:

headline: Baldwin’s Unwritten Novel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unneeded Medical Tests and the Health Care Picture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wright Misses Another Game
text: David Wright was held out of the Mets lineup for the third game in a row on Friday, one day after seeing a hand specialist for his fractured right pinkie.

headline: Safety of Medical Implants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hollywood Union Reaches Tentative Labor Agreement
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s movie and television companies tentatively agreed to a new three-year contract with the union representing  50,000 set designers, makeup artists, grips and other film workers on Friday, defusing the possibility of a showdown over health and pension benefits when the current contract expires in July.

headline: U.S. Will Pay a Settlement of $1 Billion to 41 Tribes
text: In one of the largest financial settlements made to American Indian tribes, the federal government said this week that it had ended dozens of lawsuits by agreeing to pay tribes more than $1 billion for the mismanagement of funds and natural resources that the government holds in trust.

headline: An Interview with the Head of Zipcar
text: Ron Lieber interviews Scott Griffith, chief executive of Zipcar, a popular car-sharing service.

headline: A Kink With a Twist: BMW-Inspired Roof Pillars Take a Sudden Turn
text: YOU may not recognize Wilhelm Hofmeister’s name, but you’ve seen his kink.

headline: Homegrown Power for Auto Plants
text: BERLIN

headline: So Perfectly Ordinary That It’s Extraordinary
text: OJAI, Calif. — BUILDING great supercars is easy; it’s getting the ordinary ones right that’s tough. Cars that sell for less than $20,000 are built on robotized fast-moving assembly lines that depend on a steady stream of robust, inexpensive parts that snap together quickly. Too often, manufacturers sacrifice character and performance to keep their cheapest machines moving efficiently through those lines.

headline: Modest, With Mass Appeal
text: Though engineered to be built by the hundreds of thousands, the 2012 Hyundai Accent doesn’t look or feel generic.

headline: One Fate in Tulsa for 3 Strangers Familiar With Struggle
text: TULSA, Okla. — Shortly after midnight on Good Friday here, Bobby Clark was standing at the corner, waiting for his brother. Dannaer Fields was walking home after playing dominoes at a friend’s house. William Allen was walking, too, headed home after visiting his brother.

headline: Assange TV, Presented by the Kremlin
text: Updated | Saturday | 3:00 p.m. As my colleague Noam Cohen reports, “The World Tomorrow,” a new talk show hosted by Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, begins on Tuesday on the Russian government’s satellite network Russia Today. The network, which broadcasts in English, Spanish and Arabic, unveiled commercials for the program across its channels on Friday, promoting it online and on the air.

headline: The Weiwei Way on View in Paris
text: PARIS — Four hours after Ai Weiwei’s video streaming project abruptly came to an end last week, a tweet by the artist, “Byebye to all the voyeurs,” acted as a reminder that bearing witness to his own art is as much a part of the Ai Weiwei artistic experience as the art itself.

headline: Look Out! Rehash Ahead in a Four-Hour Sinking
text: There’s no new way to sink the Titanic, not after so many books and movies and so much James Cameron.

headline: Educating Olympians
text: TEAM U.S.A. has an official diaper (Pampers) and an official restaurant (McDonald’s). So why not an official educator? The U.S. Olympic Committee has added its first university sponsor. Through 2016, the for-profit DeVry University will offer Olympic athletes full or partial scholarships, with sticker prices up to $60,000. At least 20 Olympians, including two pentathletes, a shooter and a weight lifter, have enrolled. Patrick Sandusky, a U.S. committee spokesman, cites the convenience of online programs for athletes trying to cram while training. As for sports, the school of management does have club basketball.

headline: #Graduation
text: @JinTropia Graduation speech of 2012: I’d like to thank the Internet, Google, Wikipedia, Microsoft Word and Copy & Paste.

headline: Where Your Money Goes
text: IN December, when President Obama was considering what the government should do to promote college affordability, he convened a White House round table with 10 college presidents, the head of a prominent education foundation, and Jane Wellman, whose tiny Delta Project on Postsecondary Education Costs, Productivity and Accountability has produced some of the best-regarded data and reports on the issue.

headline: The Bottom Lines
text: To help students comparison shop, the Department of Education now posts on its College Navigator Web site each college’s average net price — the estimated total cost of attending (tuition and fees, room and board, books and other expenses) less the average amount of grants and scholarships awarded. Generous financial aid can make a college with a lofty sticker price a better value.

headline: Now, Deduct This
text: IN this year’s Publication 970, in the patch where the I.R.S. explains who is eligible for the tuition and fees deduction, a sentence is gone: the one that says students must have a high school diploma or G.E.D.

headline: How to Be a Better Test-Taker
text: THE REALITY

headline: When the Calculator Says 1 + 1 = 4
text: THE glossary of terms rings familiar to any cost-conscious college applicant: sticker price, tuition discount, expected family contribution. Now another has entered the lexicon: net price.

headline: Selling the Campus Farm
text: FORGET the cheese brick and salami round that Dad picks up on alumni weekends. Today’s college farm cultivates exotic fruits, expensive Asian greens and grass-fed beef. Students are developing product lines for high-end tastes, and honing not just basic husbandry skills but also marketing savvy in the interest of turning their acreage into profit centers.

headline: A Second Opinion: The Post-Baccalaureate
text: THREE years ago, Molly Grassini was living the life of a struggling actor, landing roles in small theater productions, acting in a Web series and bouncing between auditions in Los Angeles. The closest she came to a career in health care was a featured part in a Vitamin Water ad.

headline: Rethinking Some Old Habits, One of Them Close to Home
text: Readers who give up print newspapers and switch to digital devices will gain a benefit many have probably not thought about: they will be slashing the carbon emissions associated with their news habit.

headline: Socially Out There
text: AT 1 o’clock every Thursday afternoon, 30 or so students gather on the green at Rollins College, in central Florida, and laugh for 15 minutes straight. At first, the mirth is clearly forced, but “it becomes very real very fast,” insists Christian Kebbel (pictured below), founder of the Rollins Laughing Club. “You walk away feeling light and happy.”

headline: Pre-Med’s New Priorities: Heart and Soul and Social Science
text: PROF. PIERS J. HALE knew something was up when his students at the University of Oklahoma were clamoring this spring to get into his medical ethics class, which was formerly populated largely by social science majors. What led to the sudden burst of popularity, he discovered, were plans by the Association of American Medical Colleges to revise the medical school admissions test to incorporate a hefty dose of social science.

headline: Apps for Navigating Campus Life
text: WE think of mobile phones as our personal electronic Dobbies, so it’s not surprising that the smartphone app is becoming the panic button of choice for navigating college life.

headline: Truly Food for Thought
text: THE study of food has had a home in higher education for generations. Agriculture was a founding mission of the land-grant university system started in the 1860s. Nutrition programs are commonplace. Culinary schools were around long before Julia Child turned Le Cordon Bleu on its butter-sauced ear.

headline: Failure Is Not an Option
text: JAMES FRANCO, America’s favorite graduate student, has been hailed as a multitasking savant for his intellectual pursuits: fiction writing at Columbia University and Brooklyn College, poetry at Warren Wilson College, filmmaking at New York University. Not to mention current studies in English at Yale, and digital and media art at Rhode Island School of Design.

headline: De-Triple [d-trip-uhl]: verb, -pled, -pling
text: STUDENTS who dally in sending a deposit can land in a double room retrofitted for three in overbooked residence halls. Are they cramped? “Well … maybe,” acknowledges the Web site of the University of California, Santa Barbara. When space opens up, a student can be “de-tripled.” This is generally a good thing. Santa Barbara has a waiting list to de-triple. Still, a triple costs 20 percent less than a double, saving about $850 a quarter.

headline: Upward-Facing Soldier
text: YOU are sitting behind the Humvee where you’ve dragged a wounded soldier. You’ve wrapped the gaping hole in his leg, given him a shot of morphine and radioed up the line for help. Your eye is trained on a distant, hazy point through the scope of an assault rifle. You can see the tiny, magnified bodies of your enemy. Maybe they are waiting for another explosion. A bigger one. Your heart starts pounding harder. The temperature is over 100 degrees. The kid next to you, a kid you always found slightly annoying, with his Massachusetts accent and his unwillingness to walk in the front position of the line, is now holding a bloody pad to his thigh and biting down on a bandanna to keep from screaming. Sweat is pouring down his face.

headline: Graduating, Cum Latte
text: Dear College Presidents: Budget cuts could force more of you to write and present your own commencement speeches this year. Ease your task with the following form.

headline: German in a Multicultural World
text: ON the day in November 1989 that the Berlin Wall came down, Michael Legutke, a linguist working for the West German government, was in Casper, Wyo., leading a training workshop for the state’s German teachers. When the TV news affiliate learned there was a real live German, right there in Casper — and one who had grown up in East Germany and spoke flawless English — he was recruited to do a live feed. Dr. Legutke found himself facing a camera, taking turns offering news commentary with Tom Brokaw in Berlin. Moved by the images of East Germans streaming through the breached wall into the west, Dr. Legutke wept during the broadcast.

headline: Your College Experience
text: With graduation around the corner, we invited students to send photos they’ll put on their memory shelf.

headline: A Stylish Spot Beckons With Asian Flavors
text: WHEN Monsoon swept into Babylon near the end of February, it made quite an impression. This new pan-Asian restaurant is owned by the Bohlsen Restaurant Group, which also runs the well-regarded Prime in Huntington and Tellers Chophouse and Verace, both in Islip, among others.

headline: The Provocateur
text: ON the last night of February, Arthur Sando was having a drink at the Brentwood Restaurant and Lounge in Los Angeles when a bearded silver-haired man took a seat next to him, ordered a glass of pinot noir and began typing into his BlackBerry.

headline: Chardonnays From Steel
text: Chardonnay made in stainless-steel tanks is emerging as a strength at Long Island wineries. This white wine, a terrific companion to the region’s maritime cuisine, generally sells for less than $20.

headline: Why Decades Can Pass Between Idea and ‘Eureka!’
text: WASHINGTON — How will the world meet its rising demand for energy? Experience suggests the solutions might already be at hand, although it may be years before they are widely recognized because energy inventions have an exceptionally long gestation period.

headline: Deals of Great Disparity
text: In Monday’s column, I gave a deal from a team match in which both Souths played in spades with a low-club lead. One declarer won 11 tricks, the other only 7. I wondered whether there were deals with a greater disparity of tricks taken.

headline: Should We End Life Tenure for Justices?
text: To the Editor:

headline: For North Korea, Rocket’s Failure May Be Learning Opportunity
text: Disasters are a regular part of rocket science, as demonstrated by the American experience with its Vanguard program.

headline: Steaks, Chops and Chorizo, Too
text: GIVEN its name, it’s no surprise that the Mercer Street Charcoal Grill and Deli has chops, chicken and steaks on the menu. The surprise — and it’s a happy one — is that there is a Latin flavor to many of the dishes.

headline: Reinventing Venus and a Lying Puppet
text: Emblems of mass culture and everyday life were divvied up rather quickly in the early days of Pop Art. Jasper Johns, more of a neo-Dada artist than a Pop artist, took the American flag, targets, maps and numbers. Andy Warhol opted for movie stars and other A-list celebrities. Roy Lichtenstein painted comics, and Claes Oldenberg sculptured mass-produced food. Jim Dine, who was also involved in Happenings in the late 1950s, got greeting-card hearts, garden-shed tools, Pinocchio and, a bit later, the Venus de Milo.

headline: Mornings After, Many of Them
text: Fairly early in “Carry It On,” Maureen McGovern imagines the tabloid headline when she dies: “Disaster-Theme Queen Bites the Dust” appears on a National Enquirer-like page on the wall-size video screen upstage. And that’s as good an introduction to Ms. McGovern as any.

headline: British Prime Minister, in Myanmar, Wants Sanctions Suspended but Not Lifted
text: BANGKOK — In the first visit of a British prime minister to Myanmar in decades, David Cameron said Friday that he supported a suspension — but not a lifting — of European Union sanctions against the country, a nuanced position that received the support of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy activist who recently won election to public office.

headline: Spain Cautions Argentina on Takeover of Energy Firm
text: MADRID — The Spanish government warned on Friday that it would take unspecified retaliatory measures against Argentina if it proceeded with plans to take back control of YPF, the large oil and gas producer, from Repsol, its Spanish parent.

headline: Spiritual Seeker’s Quest, From Blondie to Swedenborg
text: One day, when he was 13 years old and growing up in Bayonne, N.J. — “the backside of the Statue of Liberty,” he now calls it — Gary Lachman decided that he had had enough of Catholicism.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include wildfires throughout the region, Occupy Wall Street activists’ move to the sidewalks, and a kidney transplant between brothers.

headline: Employers Don’t Have to Post Union Notices, Judge Rules
text: A federal judge in South Carolina ruled on Friday that the National Labor Relations Board did not have the authority to order most private employers to post notices telling workers about their right to unionize under federal law.

headline: A Mainstream Canvas for an Abstract Expressionist
text: Jonathan Epstein makes an almost melodramatic entrance in John Logan’s “Red.” Playing the angry Abstract Expressionist artist Mark Rothko at TheaterWorks Hartford, he first appears upstage, walking, deliberately and very slowly, toward the audience. He lights a cigarette (the floor of his studio will soon be covered with crushed butts) and smiles inscrutably out into the lights. That opening tells us a lot about this very serious production directed by Tazewell Thompson with an interesting hit-and-miss energy.

headline: Do Grades Matter?
text: JAMES FRANCO survived his D and now teaches a graduate-level class at New York University. But what about the little people? Do grades matter?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Digital Designers, and 3-D Chocolate Printers
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Callahan’s Leadership: Goals and Bodychecks
text: Eleven years ago, Ryan Callahan, a determined but seemingly unexceptional teenager from Rochester, was the beneficiary of a favor between an agent and a coach.

headline: Use Your (Louder, Livelier) Library Voice
text: YOU might associate libraries with hushed tranquillity rather than lively music, but the gradual transformation of many libraries into de facto cultural community centers is changing that. Offering the intimacy of clubs, sometimes without the ticket costs and always without the distractions — no clinking of glasses or paying of checks during the set — library music rooms are attracting enthusiastic audiences for first-rate folk, modern jazz and classical concerts in and around Westchester County.

headline: Not Just Another Fake Mona Lisa
text: A researcher at the Prado in Spain has discovered that the museum’s copy of the Mona Lisa was painted by someone working next to Leonardo da Vinci while he created the original.

headline: Bill Cunningham | All the Frills
text: The Fifth Avenue Easter promenade was blessed with glorious weather that brought out the throngs.

headline: Beneath That Beguiling Smile, Seeing What Leonardo Saw
text: MADRID

headline: Cyclist Heads for Paralympics
text: AFTER months of training, the word came on Monday: Damian Lopez Alfonso, the Cuban bicycle racer who lost both arms in a childhood accident, would be going to London to compete in the 2012 Paralympic Games.

headline: Canadian Police Search Construction Company in Montreal
text: OTTAWA — The offices of SNC-Lavalin, the Canadian construction and engineering company that had close ties to the regime of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan dictator, was searched by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police on Friday.

headline: New Republic Cancels Lottery to Attend Washington Dinner
text: The New Republic has quickly canceled its plan to send one lucky subscriber to the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner this month after being told that it would be violating the association’s rules.

headline: Why North Korea’s Rocket Mattered
text: MEDFORD, Mass.

headline: Romney Assures N.R.A. of Support for Gun Rights
text: ST. LOUIS — As he seeks to inspire the conservative base ahead of the general election, Mitt Romney spoke to the National Rifle Association on Friday, seeking the support of a powerful group that has not always warmed up to him.

headline: Yankees Replay: Home Opener
text: Images from the Yankees’ first game in the Bronx this season, a 5-0 victory over the Angels.

headline: Maimed on a Subway Platform, Now Panhandling on the Trains
text: The man stood just outside the emergency door at the 110th Street subway station, motionless, waiting. A downtown train approached, screeching, and slowed, and precisely as its doors opened, the man slipped a practiced hand around a turnstile and pushed the emergency gate open, shuffling with a cane into the first subway car.

headline: An Australian Import Speaks to Brooklyn
text: When Toby’s Estate arrived in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in January, it did not take long for the buzz to be heard. And that was not just because of its Rwandan espresso. The first United States outpost of the popular Australian coffee company, this cafe and roastery, housed in a bright, airy former meatpacking factory, instantly attracted all the neighborhood’s types: the entrepreneurial set convening at communal tables for late power breakfasts as well as the stroller-rolling families nestling into the long navy couch.

headline: Ride to Ballgame on Vintage Train Transports Fans to Another Era
text: A subway train came and went. And another, and a few more. But the crowd gathered on an uptown platform in Grand Central Station on Friday morning was not budging.

headline: Talbots Forecasts a Decline in First-Quarter Sales
text: Talbots, the women’s apparel retailer, said it expected first-quarter sales to fall from the year-earlier period, setting off a 14.7 percent decline in its share price on Friday. Stock in the company fell 46 cents, to $2.67 a share. Talbots said after the close of trading on Thursday that it expected sales for the quarter ending April 30 to fall 9.6 percent from last year to $272 million, as its store base shrinks. Analysts had forecast revenue of $280 million. Talbots swung to a loss for the year ending Jan. 28, as it ceded business to competitors and increased its promotions. Talbots is based in Hingham, Mass.

headline: N.B.A. Solidifies One Ownership Issue, but Another Takes a Wrong Turn
text: The N.B.A. resolved one franchise headache Friday when it announced the sale of the New Orleans Hornets, a ward of the league since 2010, to Tom Benson, the owner of the Saints, for $338 million.

headline: Party May Be Long-Term Loser in Chinese Scandal
text: BEIJING — The scandal that climaxed here on Tuesday when Communist Party leaders suspended the Politburo member Bo Xilai and accused his wife of murder seems poised to destroy a charismatic party leader who challenged President Hu Jintao and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao’s vision for China.

headline: Coinstar Surges on Preliminary Quarterly Results
text: Coinstar, the operator of the Redbox movie-rental kiosks, said in a preliminary report that its first-quarter sales and profit exceeded its February forecast, driven by higher prices. The shares rose $4.47, or 7 percent, to $65.78, on Friday, bringing its gain this year to 44 percent. Profit from continuing operations was $1.62 to $1.66 a share, the company, which is based in Bellevue, Wash., said on Thursday. Sales advanced to $567 million to $569.2 million. Analysts forecast first-quarter profit of 89 cents a share on sales of $538.6 million. Coinstar plans to disclose final results on April 26. Coinstar said it benefited last quarter from lower-than-expected card-processing fees and the popularity of movies like “Moneyball,” “Puss and Boots” and “50/50.”

headline: CBS’s Chief Executive Was Paid $69.9. Million for 2011
text: Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, received $69.9 million in 2011 total compensation, 21 percent more than a year earlier, the company said Friday in a regulatory filing. Mr. Moonves’s package included a salary of $3.5 million, a bonus of $27.5 million, stock grants of $8.5 million and options awards of $27.3 million, CBS said. Stock in CBS rose 42 percent last year after the company reduced debt and developed a plan to add $3 billion in revenue, including some through sales of TV shows outside the United States and to online streaming services including Netflix.

headline: Software Service in India Tumbles After Forecast
text: Infosys, India’s second-largest software services exporter, forecast sales that missed analysts’ estimates, setting off a 13 percent decline in its share price on Friday. American depositary receipts of the company, which is based in Bangalore, India, fell 13 percent to $49.15 a share. Sales in the year that began April 1 may range from 384.3 billion rupees ($7.5 billion) to 391.4 billion rupees, Infosys said. Analysts had expected revenue of 396.3 billion rupees for the period. The company also reported fourth-quarter sales that were lower than analysts had predicted.

headline: Bay’s Homer and Dickey’s Pitching Lead Mets to Win in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — It is not that Terry Collins wants his hitters to be less patient.

headline: Reminding You Later
text: APP Metrofocus

headline: Behind Instagram’s Success, Networking the Old Way
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Past midnight, in a dimly lighted warehouse jutting into the San Francisco Bay, Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger introduced something they had been working on for weeks: a photo-sharing iPhone application called Instagram. What happened next was crazier than they could have imagined.

headline: A State Divided
text: Along the coast, communities have largely bounced back from the recession, but inland areas are still struggling with high unemployment and a persistent housing crisis.

headline: In California, Economic Gap of East vs. West
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — For decades, California has been seen nationally and by its own residents as a state divided into north and south, urbane tree-huggers versus car-obsessed beach hoppers. But the more meaningful division, it turns out, may be between east and west.

headline: Ducking the Crisis in Medicare
text: NESTLED within the many commendable aspects of President Obama’s health care plan — including the individual mandate — sits a problem that has gone virtually unnoticed by commentators obsessed with the Supreme Court’s review of the law: how to pay for it.

headline: Solid Results at 2 Banks Bode Well for the Industry
text: Revenue is back.

headline: Unexpected Ally Helps Wal-Mart Cut Waste
text: Michelle Harvey, an employee of the Environmental Defense Fund, has a security badge to a site that used to be considered enemy territory: the headquarters of Wal-Mart Stores in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Seeking Nuclear Insight in Fog of the Ayatollah’s Utterances
text: WASHINGTON — C.I.A. analysts studying the geopolitical gamesmanship now at play over Iran’s nuclear program have expensive and highly classified tools at their disposal, but one of their best sources is free and readily available: the public utterances of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

headline: Despite Power Shift, Angels Start Season Adrift
text: You know it has been a rough start for the Los Angeles Angels when a double play is the season highlight for their marquee player.

headline: 17 Floors Up, Rescue of 3 Shows Clash of Agencies
text: The high-level rescue of three building workers left dangling on Friday from safety harnesses 17 stories up took only 10 minutes, but it illustrated that a lack of coordination between New York City’s Police and Fire Departments continues.

headline: For Baffert, Derby Victory Would Be Best Medicine
text: HOT SPRINGS, Ark. — Bob Baffert’s horses arrived at Oaklawn Park this week, including two whose ambitions for the Kentucky Derby rest on a successful Arkansas Derby run Saturday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 13, 2012

headline: Resurgent Beirut Offers Haven Amid Turmoil of Arab Spring
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Down a ramp from Beirut’s clamorous seaside road, motor yachts bob along a curving waterfront promenade. Tablecloths gleam white, and bottles of wine sweat in silver coolers. The boardwalk’s rough planks, a nod to maritime authenticity, present a design flaw perhaps foreseeable in this city: Women with Louis Vuitton handbags are forever extracting their spike heels from the cracks.

headline: A Priest Unafraid of Trouble
text: AH, now here comes Father Moloney, ambling down East Ninth Street in his priest’s outfit, a crucifix on a heavy chain around his neck.

headline: An Economic Divide in California
text: The economic divide between western coastal communities and inland communities in California.

headline: After Number of Gifted Soars, a Fight for Kindergarten Slots
text: Nearly 5,000 children qualified for gifted and talented kindergarten seats in New York City public schools in the fall, 22 percent more than last year and more than double the number four years ago, setting off a fierce competition for the most sought-after programs in the system.

headline: City’s Top Technology Official Resigns Amid Clashes Over Troubled Projects
text: New York City’s chief technology official resigned after clashing repeatedly with a deputy mayor over the management of several costly, ambitious and troubled projects that have bedeviled the Bloomberg administration, people briefed on the confrontations said on Friday.

headline: Things Are Looking Up
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — So I moseyed my way around this puzzle by Mark Diehl, humming the Kiss earworm “Rock and Roll All NITE”, and eventually made my way to 1 Across, which I was mildly surprised to discover was the rather risqué UPDRAFTS (clued as “Skirt raisers?”)

headline: Corrections: April 14
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Reviewing the Hyundai Accent
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the 2012 Hyundai Accent, the entry-level vehicle from the ascendant Korean automaker.

headline: Thousands in Cairo Protest Mubarak Aide’s Presidential Bid
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s rival Islamist groups flexed their political muscle on Friday, drawing thousands of supporters from across the country to Tahrir Square to protest the presidential campaign of the longtime spy chief under the government of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: How to Prevent Oil Spills
text: BP held its annual meeting on Thursday, and, all things considered, the company’s shareholders had much to be happy about. Yes, a small percentage voted against the $6.8 million pay package that the board awarded Bob Dudley, the chief executive. And there were plenty of protesters in attendance, including angry Gulf Coast residents and climate change activists.

headline: Knicks Rout Wizards to Move Into Tie for 7th in East
text: The Washington Wizards may not help one another very much on the court, but they are renowned for masking their opponents’ problems. The Knicks were the beneficiaries Friday night at Madison Square Garden, obliterating the Wizards, 103-65.

headline: Friday Night Music: Katzenjammer
text: A commenter recommended this group — and they’re just what I needed to cheer me up after a cold, very rainy day in southern California.

headline: On the Way to International Talks, Making a Stop for Domestic Concerns
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — President Obama arrived here on Friday for a two-day meeting with more than 30 other leaders of Western Hemisphere nations — but not before making a stop with domestic political overtones in the election battleground state of Florida, to preview the meeting’s trade-and-jobs theme.

headline: Justice for Trayvon
text: America has heard the calls for justice from a Florida family.

headline: Iranian Dissident Opposes Sanctions on Tehran
text: Shirin Ebadi, the Iranian human rights lawyer and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has no affinity for the authorities in Iran, who she fears would have her arrested or worse if she returned home. But she has found herself standing with them in opposition to the onerous nuclear sanctions imposed on her country.

headline: Answers to Questions About the Titanic and New York
text: The Lifeboats Made It

headline: In Yonkers, a Strong Dose of Reality
text: Bad budget news has been piling up recently in Yonkers, New York’s fourth-largest city, and citizens there can expect more on Monday, when Mayor Michael Spano presents his first spending plan. He will have to close an $89 million gap in a $940 million budget, and as hard as that job sounds, it will only get harder. In the next three years the city’s shortfalls are projected to keep growing, like snowdrifts in Buffalo, to a total of $465 million.

headline: Frightening Fizzle
text: North Korea’s new leader, Kim Jong-un, blew his chance to set his country on a saner, more productive path when his military tested a ballistic missile on Friday — the rocket disintegrated soon after takeoff.

headline: At Sea a Century Ago
text: The Titanic was never meant to be ordinary, but it was meant, in time, to become normal, queen of the trans-Atlantic liners sailing on a regular schedule between New York and the south of England. Had it survived, it might have prospered as its sister ship the Olympic did, serving as a fast troop-carrier in World War I and again as a passenger liner after 1918.

headline: Republicans and the Gun Lobby
text: Republican politicians gathering at the National Rifle Association convention in St. Louis are eagerly pandering to a powerful political lobby that is intent on making the nation’s gun laws weaker and more riddled with more dangerous loopholes. Rather than tackling public safety risks like the Stand Your Ground law implicated in the killing of Trayvon Martin in Florida, Mitt Romney and others offered nothing but exhortations to defend the Second Amendment’s right to bear arms at all costs.

headline: Rangers Rookie Wastes No Time in Postseason Debut
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Brian Boyle was circumspect Friday about Senators defenseman Erik Karlsson, whom he jabbed six times in the head while Karlsson, 8 inches shorter and 65 pounds lighter, hung on for dear life during a second-period scrum in Game 1 of the Rangers’ 4-2 win over Ottawa on Thursday.

headline: Coffee, With a Side of Catch-Up
text: Ashley Parrish, the editorial director of the Web site Daily Candy, wants her estimated six million readers to see her as “a really cool friend who knows how to live the sweet life.” Ms. Parrish, 32, joined Daily Candy in March 2011 after almost a decade at Hearst Corporation, where she started at Harper’s Bazaar at age 22. An adjunct professor at New York University, her alma mater, she is teaching a six-week blogging workshop there. She lives in a duplex on Madison Avenue at 38th Street with two cats, Merlin and Cleopatra.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Lenders are starting to reach out to risky borrowers again, China announces an unexpected trade surplus and Facebook buys Instagram for $1 billion.

headline: Rodriguez Ties Griffey With Homer
text: Alex Rodriguez became a major league player in July 1994 as an 18-year-old phenom, a No. 1 pick with half a season of minor league experience before the Seattle Mariners called him to join Ken Griffey Jr. on their big-league roster. At the time, Griffey was perhaps baseball’s biggest rising star, and Rodriguez appeared set to join him.

headline: Guinea-Bissau Premier, Election Front-Runner, Is Deposed in a Coup
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A grimly familiar sequence of gunfire in the capital, military communiqués on the radio and the arrest of government officials is repeating itself in the small coastal state of Guinea-Bissau — apparently the latest West African nation to succumb to a coup d’état.

headline: The State of Afghanistan
text: THE key trends of the war in Afghanistan can be summarized fairly simply. The hard part is figuring out what they collectively add up to. The muddled picture no doubt contributed to recent poll results showing that two-thirds of Americans oppose their country’s involvement in the conflict. Afghans themselves seem confused; according to a 2011 Asia Foundation poll, 73 percent of citizens support their national government (and even higher percentages their army and police), but only 46 percent believe the country is headed in the right direction.

headline: China: An Artist Fights Back
text: Ai Weiwei, China’s most famous rebel artist, said Friday that he had filed a lawsuit with two courts against the Beijing tax authorities for violating his rights in bringing a tax case against him. Tax officials have said Mr. Ai’s company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development Ltd., owes the equivalent of $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai says he does not owe that amount and has insisted that his wife, Lu Qing, is formally in charge of the company. Tax officials recently rejected an appeal filed by Mr. Ai. He said Friday that he was filing his lawsuit based on the fact that the tax authorities had not followed proper procedures in bringing their case against him. Mr. Ai said both courts promised to deliver an answer in one week.

headline: Falling Wall Injures Two Children in Brooklyn
text: Two children were seriously injured on Friday when a brick wall separating properties in Brooklyn collapsed, the authorities said.

headline: The Battle for a Comic-Book Empire That Archie Built
text: MAMARONECK, N.Y. — The entry vestibule at Archie Comic Publications here is a glass portal to childhood innocence, sunny summer days and endless nostalgia: The back end of a vintage white Cadillac, with its killer shark-fin fenders and leather interior intact, has been retrofitted to function as a sofa. Two salvaged audio hookups from an extinct drive-in movie theater complete the Memory Lane montage. Framed posters of Archie, the gullible Riverdale High School redhead, and his equally colorful entourage invigorate the walls.

headline: Texas Board Approves Rules on Use of Stem Cells
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Texas Medical Board on Friday approved controversial new rules on the use of adult stem cells, raising concerns that Texans could receive therapies that have not yet been proven to work and that could be unsafe.

headline: House Republicans to Tackle Ambitious Budget
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans return from spring recess next week to face the difficult — some say impossible — task of filling the gaping holes in the House-passed budget, including figuring out how to slash income tax rates without costing the government any money and finding nearly $3 trillion in savings from entitlement programs over the next decade.

headline: Making Education Brain Science
text: LAST month, two kindergarten classes at the Blue School were hard at work doing what many kindergartners do: drawing. One group pursued a variation on the self-portrait. “That’s me thinking about my brain,” one 5-year-old-girl said of her picture. Down the hall, children with oil pastels in hand were illustrating their emotions, mapping where they started and where they ended. For one girl, sadness ended at home with a yummy drink and her teddy bear.

headline: Red Sox Settle Some Jitters With Big Win in Home Opener
text: BOSTON — He had become, through some fault of his own, the poster boy for the Red Sox’ historic September swoon of 2011. The Boston right-hander Josh Beckett ate chicken and drank beer in the clubhouse while his teammates were on the field. He was neither repentant nor remorseful for the activity, though a few of his teammates, not to mention pretty much all of Red Sox Nation, felt otherwise.

headline: A Killing, and Queries About a Life
text: A few years ago, Tatianna Kantorowicz, an aspiring filmmaker in her 20s and a Columbia University graduate student living on the Upper East Side, wanted to make a movie about teenagers coming of age in Manhattan. She had come to New York by route of her native Bogotá, Colombia, and Swiss boarding school, and maintained an interest in those teenagers who seemed to inhabit the city free of the ceaseless parental ministrations that have come to define the current age. Eventually, she wrote a script and sent it to a producer, a young Wesleyan University graduate working in the world of independent film.

headline: Claude Miller, Film Director and Truffaut Protégé, Dies at 70
text: Claude Miller, a French director whose spare and sometimes disturbing films focused on the interior lives of tormented characters, especially women, while never losing sight of their exterior beauty, died on April 4 in Paris. He was 70.

headline: Dora Saint, a k a Miss Read of Fiction Fame, Dies at 98
text: Dora Saint, whose novels about the gentle rhythms of English village life, written under the crisp, pedagogical pseudonym Miss Read, drew a wide following on both sides of the Atlantic, died on April 7 at her home in Shefford Woodlands, in Berkshire, England. She was 98.

headline: Andrew Love, Tenor Saxophonist for the Memphis Horns, Dies at 70
text: Andrew Love, a tenor saxophonist who as half of the Memphis Horns helped define what came to be known as the Memphis sound, infusing 83 gold and platinum records with instrumental buoyancy, died on Thursday at his home in Memphis. He was 70.

headline: Rout for U.S. Women
text: The United States women’s team romped past Switzerland, 10-0, in the semifinals of the world championship in Burlington, Vt., setting up a final Saturday against Canada. The two teams have met in every final in the event’s history, with Canada holding a 9-4 edge.

headline: Secret Service Agents Accused of Misconduct
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — Twelve Secret Service agents assigned to this port city in advance of President Obama’s arrival for the Summit of the Americas were relieved of duty, amid accusations of misconduct that is said to have involved prostitution, a government official confirmed Friday.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Massachusetts: Court Rules for Breast-Feeding Test-Taker
text: The highest court in Massachusetts ruled Friday that breast-feeding mothers must be afforded special accommodations when they take state medical licensing exams. The case was brought by Sophie Currier, a former Harvard Medical School student who sued the National Board of Medical Examiners in 2007 after it denied her additional break time during the exam to pump milk for her baby. She had asked for extra time and a private room to express her milk. After two courts ruled in her favor, the medical board appealed to the Supreme Judicial Court, which found that lactation is a sex-linked distinction that is legally protected.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: At Nuclear Talks, Iran and 6 Nations Agree to Meet Again
text: ISTANBUL — Iran and six world powers agreed Saturday to hold a new round of talks in Baghdad on May 23, Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, said after the first meeting in nearly 15 months on Tehran’s disputed nuclear program.

headline: Is ‘Didi’ Headed For a Fall?
text: Aamra ekhon-o boli ni kon kagoj porte hobe, kintu agami dine kintu setao bole debo. (Till now, we haven’t told which newspapers must be read, but in the future, we will do that as well.) — West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, speaking on March 29 in defense of her government’s decision to bar all but 13 newspapers from more than 2,400 government-approved libraries across the state.

headline: The Weekend Word: Taxes
text: Today’s Times

headline: Marvin Jones, Fourth-Ranked Receiver in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: Meditation on the Colors of Nature
text: Bark is not really brown. Is that obvious? It didn’t occur to me until our year in the woods.

headline: Software Service in India Tumbles After Forecast
text: Infosys, India’s second-largest software services exporter, “forecast sales that missed analysts’ estimates, setting off a 13 percent decline in its share price on Friday,” Bloomberg News reports. American depositary receipts of the company, which is based in Bangalore, fell 13 percent to $49.15 a share.

headline: U.N. Votes to Send Observers to Syria Amid a Shaky Truce
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As low-level violence sputtered in various Syrian cities on Saturday, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously to send an advance team of up to 30 military observers to begin monitoring the tenuous cease-fire.

headline: At Coachella, When the Night Comes
text: INDIO, Calif. — If you want to play Coachella, make sure there are Fender Jaguars or Mustangs or Jazzmasters or maybe even Toronados in your band, and make your music imply innocence. Still, you probably will not headline that way. If you want to play the privileged slots between 9 p.m. and midnight, switch to a different instrument, or dump your guitars and get some DJ software.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A 48-year-old-farmer in the state has invented a “singing lantern,” Kashmir Live reported. Gulam Mohammad Mir invented the musical lantern to spare himself the surprise of unannounced military search operations at his house in south Kashmir. The device, fitted with motion sensors, alerted him of any human activity and helped him prepare for searches of his home.

headline: Ripples on the Surface of Easter
text: ISTANBUL — A happy Easter to all our Orthodox readers.

headline: Travel With the Tate to See the World’s Art
text: The Tate galleries often display art from around the world. Now, the arts institution is hoping to take its visitors on the road, as part of Tate Travels, a series of 14 trips related to the arts organized in partnership with the Ultimate Travel Company.

headline: Preview: Julia Louis-Dreyfus in ‘Veep’
text: A clip from HBO’s new show about Washington politics, created by Armando Iannucci.

headline: Starwood Rewards Offer: Bidding for Foodies
text: Starwood Hotels & Resorts has introduced a slate of rewards for foodies who are members of its loyalty program. As part of a foray into culinary awards, the Starwood Preferred Guest program is offering the chance to bid on rewards like a sushi-making class with the chef  Masaharu Morimoto or dinner with Thomas Keller at Per Se.

headline: Tévez: So How Do You Like Me Now?
text: Whatever you might have to say about the obstreperous and confounding Carlos Tévez you do have to admit that the man does know how to score goals.

headline: Increasingly in Europe, Suicides ‘by Economic Crisis’
text: TREVISO, Italy — On New Year’s Eve, Antonio Tamiozzo, 53, hanged himself in the warehouse of his construction business near Vicenza, after several debtors did not pay what they owed him.

headline: For Liverpool and Red Sox, the Same Owner and Parallel Debacles
text: LONDON — John Henry is the principal owner of two of the sporting world’s most visible, storied and valuable franchises — the Red Sox of Boston and the Reds of Liverpool. Yet at the moment, his baseball and soccer teams are united not in towering success but in stunning collapse.

headline: China Adjusts Currency Trading Rules
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government announced on Saturday that it would allow the renminbi to vary more in value against the dollar during each day’s trading, but gave no hint that it would accept the Obama administration’s demands to allow the currency to show a longer-term trend of appreciation against the dollar.

headline: Paperwork Buries Veterans’ Disability Claims
text: Even after Ian Rodriguez left the Marine Corps in 2006, he still felt like he was in Iraq.

headline: Trustee Says the Mets’ Owners Had a Limited Ability to Pay
text: Nearly a month ago, the owners of the Mets avoided a jury trial by agreeing to pay $162 million to the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud.

headline: Variety: A Leisurely Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — One of the things I like about Paula Gamache, aside from the fact that she makes puzzles that I enjoy, is that she tells me what to do. Today, she is advising me — all of us, really — to get some R AND R. Perfect advice for a Sunday.

headline: Mile-High Oddities With the Rockies
text: One of the things that make baseball fun is the frequency of statistical oddities. The first full week of this season was replete with them, with Denver as a backdrop.

headline: Swing, Batter Batter, Swing
text: “Only connect.” — E. M. Forster (or was it Ted Williams?)

headline: Agents for Secret Service Face Misconduct Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Secret Service placed 11 employees on leave on Saturday as the agency’s internal watchdog opened an investigation into accusations of misconduct involving prostitution in Cartagena, Colombia, where President Obama arrived on Friday for a summit meeting.

headline: In San Antonio, a Coach’s Player, a Player’s Coach
text: SAN ANTONIO — Gregg Popovich has never worried that Tim Duncan will lobby management to get rid of him behind his back. They are as tethered to each other as this city is to the Alamo. For 15 of his 16 years as the Spurs’ coach, Popovich has told assistants, “We have the easiest job in the N.B.A. because of Tim Duncan, because of who he is and the way he conducts himself.”

headline: For Parise, One Order of Business at a Time
text: NEWARK — The elephant in the Devils’ dressing room lurks near Zach Parise’s locker. Parise has had a terrific season, overcoming knee surgery to score 31 goals and adapting quickly to his new role as the captain. But he still stands to become an unrestricted free agent July 1.

headline: Catcher’s Tears Were a Likely Inspiration for Rickey
text: The Montreal Royals, the top minor league team in the Brooklyn Dodgers organization, broke baseball’s color line on Oct. 23, 1945, by signing shortstop Jackie Robinson of the Kansas City Monarchs in the Negro leagues. The Associated Press reported that the Dodgers’ president, Branch Rickey, said he had given a lot of thought to discrimination since his coaching days at Ohio Wesleyan University in the early 1900s.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Moscow Protesters Take Their Show on the Road
text: ASTRAKHAN, Russia — With their political credibility largely on the line, the organizers of Moscow’s huge antigovernment street protests staged a rare major action outside the capital on Saturday, rallying about 1,500 people against suspected ballot fraud in Astrakhan’s mayoral election.

headline: Lidge Adds Depth to Nationals’ Bullpen
text: Brad Lidge pitched just 25 games for the Philadelphia Phillies last season, but his earned run average was 1.40, and he struck out more than a batter an inning. Even so, the Phillies were content to let Lidge go to a division rival, the Nationals, who signed him to be a setup man for Drew Storen.

headline: Experts Split on Possibility of Remains at Titanic Site
text: Federal officials, who have long struggled to assert protective authority over the resting place of the Titanic, say the site may harbor many undiscovered corpses and thus should be accorded the respect of a graveyard and shielded from looters and artifact hunters.

headline: Pacers Thriving on Court, Not at Gate
text: The N.B.A. is often criticized for being a league in which teamwork takes a back seat to catering to the biggest stars and egos. But the Indiana Pacers, with a roster of relative unknowns, are unexpectedly in line for the third seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs.

headline: Mixing Golf and Ravioli With Business
text: This interview with  Annette Catino, president and C.E.O. of QualCare Inc., an alternative employer health insurance plan based  in Piscataway, N.J., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Stores, and More, for Breast-Feeding Moms
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Duplicating Afghanistan From the Ground Up
text: FRESNO, Calif. — When Sgt. First Class Darrell Rowe’s Army bosses told him they were sending him for a week of beekeeping and tree pruning here in California’s fertile Central Valley, he was irked.

headline: Social Networks, Small and Smaller
text: FACEBOOK makes sharing easy — too easy, some would say. Because one’s social network often consists not only of actual friends but also relatives and sort-of friends, along with sort-of friends of their sort-of friends, you need to be careful about what you post. Yes, the site does allow you to define smaller circles of friends, but that requires constantly monitoring what should — and should not — be shared with whom.

headline: Competition Is Healthy for Governments, Too
text: SHOULD governments — of nations, states and towns — compete like business rivals?

headline: Profits Have Stalled. Has the Market?
text: WHILE the stock market was soaring during the last two quarters, a big worry was hanging over it: corporate earnings growth was slowing. Still, bullish investors could take comfort that  stocks were  cheap by most standards.

headline: Letters: Executive Pay, Revisited
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sudan and South Sudan Keep Up Their Border Attacks
text: MOMBASA, Kenya — Sudan and South Sudan engaged in a second day of direct military clashes and aerial bombardments on Saturday in what the South described as a “limited war” between the two nations that will continue indefinitely “off and on.”

headline: Letters: Out of Alignment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Volatile Philippine Region Courts Tourists, Cautiously
text: MANILA — Tawi-Tawi, a remote island province, has white sandy beaches and stunning views, but selling it as a tourist destination has proved challenging for Philippine officials.

headline: A Solemn Path Back to Myanmar for the U.S.
text: MYITKYINA, Myanmar — In the fog-swathed mountains north of here toward the border with China, more than 700 American airmen, flying cumbersome cargo planes loaded with war supplies, perished in the last stages of World War II.

headline: Cotton Fields and Brownfields
text: I’M the oldest of 12 children. My father emigrated from Mexico to the United States in the late 1930s as an undocumented worker. He joined the U.S. Army when the country needed soldiers for World War II but was quickly discharged for health reasons. We still have his discharge papers. He eventually became a naturalized citizen.

headline: Africa’s Population Surge
text: At current growth rates, sub-Saharan Africa, which now makes up 12 percent of the world’s population, will account for more than a third by 2100.

headline: Africa’s Population Boom
text: Sub-Saharan Africa’s population has more than tripled over the past 50 years to 860 million — and it is still rising exponentially.

headline: In Nigeria, a Preview of an Overcrowded Planet
text: With earth’s population approaching unsustainable levels, much of the growth is in sub-Saharan Africa, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.

headline: The Rise of the Independent Work Force
text: IN the last month, I’ve worked for five employers, bid on three projects, been a member of two virtual teams and participated in a conference call in the middle of the night. I am 36 years old and a 21st-century employee.

headline: Nigeria Tested by Rapid Rise in Population
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — In a quarter-century, at the rate Nigeria is growing, 300 million people — a population about as big as that of the present-day United States — will live in a country roughly the size of Arizona, New Mexico and Nevada. In this commercial hub, where the area’s population has by some estimates nearly doubled over 15 years to 21 million, living standards for many are falling.

headline: Two South Africans Still Look to Secure Berths in Olympics
text: It remained uncertain Saturday whether the South African sprinter Oscar Pistorius would become the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics.

headline: Angels Pitcher Finds Hard Way Is His Only Way
text: Jerome Williams will start for the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday night at Yankee Stadium. He has never pitched in the Bronx, never faced the Yankees and never worn No. 42, which all players will do as baseball honors Jackie Robinson.

headline: Kim Jong-un, in New Position, Promotes 70
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Hours after the failure of a highly trumpeted rocket launching marred his ascension to North Korea’s highest posts, Kim Jong-un promoted 70 military officers to the rank of general, the North’s main ruling party newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, reported on Saturday.

headline: Chasing Another Gold and Honoring the Past
text: Christie Rampone, the captain of the United States women’s soccer team, is preparing for her fourth trip to the Olympics. The Americans will try to defend their gold medal in London. Rampone, 36, who grew up in New Jersey and attended Monmouth University on a basketball scholarship, has also played in four World Cups and won the 2009 Women’s Professional Soccer title with Sky Blue.

headline: Early to Bed, Early to Rise and Early in the Fields
text: Surprisingly warm weather has ushered in a planting season much earlier than normal and planters in the Midwest say they expect a good crop — provided that Mother Nature doesn’t throw a curveball.

headline: Disaster Reignites Debate Over Battle at Earth’s Ceiling
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In the snowy wastes of Siachen, where Pakistani and Indian soldiers face off in a high-altitude battle zone ringed by Himalayan peaks, the fight is against the mountain, not the man.

headline: Wright Is Back in the Lineup
text: PHILADELPHIA – One day after it appeared that Mets third baseman David Wright would probably go on the disabled list for a broken right pinkie, he was in the lineup for Saturday’s game against the Phillies. Wright homered to center field in the first inning off of Vance Worley.

headline: Major Givers Are More Likely to Get White House Access
text: An analysis based on matching names of White House visitors with names of Democratic donors indicates that those who gave more were more likely to visit or have meetings at the White House.

headline: Senators May Stack Scoring Line for Game 2
text: Ottawa Senators Coach Paul MacLean is considering putting his three best offensive players, Jason Spezza, Milan Michalek and Daniel Alfredsson, together on one line.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, with pictures from the suspension of Rick Santorum’s presidential campaign and President Obama’s visit to Florida.

headline: The Cybercrime Wave That Wasn’t
text: IN less than 15 years, cybercrime has moved from obscurity to the spotlight of consumer, corporate and national security concerns. Popular accounts suggest that cybercrime is large, rapidly growing, profitable and highly evolved; annual loss estimates range from billions to nearly $1 trillion. While other industries stagger under the weight of recession, in cybercrime, business is apparently booming.

headline: Why Medical Bills Are a Mystery
text: RISING health care costs are busting the federal budget as well as those of states, counties and municipalities. Policy makers and health care leaders have spent decades trying to figure out what to do about this.

headline: Douglas Shulman
text: Douglas Shulman is the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, overseeing the collection of more than $2.4 trillion in taxes, of which $12 billion pays for his agency. The deadline to file federal income taxes is Tuesday, April 17.

headline: The Downside of Cohabiting Before Marriage
text: AT 32, one of my clients (I’ll call her Jennifer) had a lavish wine-country wedding. By then, Jennifer and her boyfriend had lived together for more than four years. The event was attended by the couple’s friends, families and two dogs.

headline: No One Called Me a Slut
text: TWO weeks ago, a bomb went off outside a Wisconsin abortion center. In recent years, several states have passed or tried to pass laws requiring women seeking legal, constitutionally protected procedures to first undergo medical examinations. A young woman has been called a slut after testifying in favor of insurance coverage for contraceptive care. These are but a few of the stories about attacks on a woman’s right to choose.

headline: Diversity and Healing in Ireland
text: Ireland’s government is moving forward with plans to end the Catholic Church’s monopoly of the nation’s primary school system. More diversity in institutions and ideas will be good for students. The change should promote healing in a country traumatized by the church’s cover-up of years of sexual abuse of children by rogue priests.

headline: Young, Black, Male, and Stalked by Bias
text: The door to the subway train slides open, revealing three tall, young black men, crowding the entrance, with hooded sweatshirts pulled up over downward-turned faces; boxer shorts billowing out of over-large, low-slung jeans; and sneakers with the laces untied.

headline: From Flash to Fizzle
text: I DON’T remember how old I was when I first climbed up to the roof of my family’s home in suburban Maryland. Eleven, maybe? Twelve? But I do remember what I saw up there. It was the night of the Fourth of July, and it was turning dark enough for the fireworks.

headline: Minesweeper at Lunchtime, a Federal Crime?
text: In 1984, Congress passed the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, a narrow statute to curb computer hacking, when hacking was so novel that criminal laws did not really address it. The act has been expanded repeatedly so it is one of America’s most extensive criminal laws.

headline: Albany Can Kick the Money Habit
text: While New York waits for Gov. Andrew Cuomo to keep his promise to reform its election system, some powerful New Yorkers are stepping into the vacuum. A coalition that includes Barry Diller; Chris Hughes, a founding member of Facebook; the banker David Rockefeller Sr.; and the restaurateur Danny Meyer plans to push Albany into fixing the lax rules for financing political campaigns.

headline: Someone Dies. But That Is Only the Beginning.
text: THEY pour in by the dozens every day: reports of the dead from near and far. Daniel Slotnik, a news assistant, handles them, including the heartfelt pleas from family members hoping their departed loved one will be elevated to that special form of life after death: an obituary in The New York Times.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: What Is the Role of Faith in Public Policy?
text: Readers discuss the delicate balance between church and state in today’s society.

headline: Good Night, Ryan
text: A filmmaker explores the fate of Specialist Ryan Yurchison, who returned from Iraq with P.T.S.D. and, after seeking help at the local V.A. hospital, died of a drug overdose in a possible suicide.

headline: ‘Good Night Ryan’
text: Through my own experiences working as a filmmaker and cameraman in Iraq and Afghanistan over the past nine years, I’ve seen many young soldiers turn into troubled veterans.

headline: More Help for the Wealthy
text: Taxes are never popular, especially in April of an election year. But the Republicans’ latest effort to tilt the tax code in favor of the wealthy, and starve the government of needed revenue, is particularly cynical.

headline: Working and Women
text: BY the standards of Hilary Rosen, whose name and swipe at Ann Romney just possibly crossed your radar last week, my mother also never worked a day in her life, at least not after she delivered the first of four epically needy, fiercely loved and ferociously grateful children.

headline: Come Back, Sarah Palin!
text: “SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE” writers have devastatingly lampooned Mitt Romney as a corny, coreless candidate who evokes an “Eh, I guess” response in voters. Now they’re worried that we’re heading, comedy-wise, toward an “Eh, I guess” election.

headline: The Man With the Google Glasses
text: A MAN wakes up in a New York apartment, brews coffee and goes out into the world, and everything that can appear on a smartphone or iPad appears before his eyes instead: weather reports, calendar reminders, messages from friends, walking maps of New York, his girlfriend’s smiling face.

headline: Tax Break
text: The deadline for filing tax returns is Tuesday. Elbow-deep in the language of gross income, of capital gains and losses, of 1098, 1099 and W-2, we asked six writers: Is there any room for poetry?

headline: A Veteran’s Death, the Nation’s Shame
text: HERE’S a window into a tragedy within the American military: For every soldier killed on the battlefield this year, about 25 veterans are dying by their own hands.

headline: Scenes From Coachella: Day 1
text: A look at some of Friday’s performances at Coachella.

headline: Sentenced to Basketball
text: Carroll Academy, a school operated by a Tennessee juvenile court, uses sports to help teenagers stay out of trouble.

headline: The Case of a Blind Woman and Her Invisible Manuscript
text: LONDON — When she went blind as a result of diabetes, Trish Vickers set out to fill the void in her life by writing poetry. Then she turned to writing a novel, her pen guided by a system of elastic bands stretched across the paper. With 26 pages written, and a plot that turned on a woman whose life implodes, she began to dream of finding a publisher.

headline: ‘It Ain’t About the Record’
text: HUNTINGDON, Tenn. — It was early on a Friday morning, and there was an emergency in Carroll Academy’s Room 5. A student named Destiny was sitting alone, crying. With cameras in every classroom, she could be seen on the monitor in the security office.

headline: The Lady Jaguars
text: The players on the Carroll Academy girls basketball team have little experience with organized sports and myriad troubles outside of school.

headline: Authorities Bar 3 Leading Candidates in Egypt Race
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian election authorities eliminated three of the country’s leading presidential candidates in one broad stroke on Saturday night in an unexpected decision that once again threw into disarray the contest to shape the future of Egypt after the ouster of Hosni Mubarak.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Parenting
text: Amy Chua’s best-seller, “The Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” trumpeted the benefits of raising children with draconian strictness in the Chinese fashion (or allegedly so). Pamela Druckerman’s “Bringing Up Bébé: One American Mother Discovers the Wisdom of French Parenting” made the case for a more casual, laissez-faire approach. But each mode has something to offer! Thus, cruelty and indifference combine to perfect effect in the philosophies of the “Hunger Games” Mother. Who better to help parents navigate the brutal, futuristic dystopia that is contemporary childhood? A primer, above.

headline: Lester Breslow, Who Linked Healthy Habits and Long Life, Dies at 97
text: Dr. Lester Breslow, a public health leader whose research gave mathematical proof to the notion that people can live longer and healthier by changing habits like smoking, diet and sleep, died Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, with pictures from the suspension of Rick Santorum’s presidential campaign and President Obama’s visit to Florida.  Go to the slide show.

headline: Growth Prospects for Uranium Stir Concerns
text: HOBSON — At the back of a South Texas uranium processing facility, a few dozen black container drums stood outside, waiting to be shipped. Each was filled with about $50,000 worth of yellowcake, a powdery substance created from raw uranium.

headline: Boos Rain on Hughes After Shaky Start Against Angels
text: The glow emanating from the Yankees’ home opener Friday quickly dimmed Saturday. The Los Angeles Angels exacted their revenge on Phil Hughes, whose second sloppy start revived questions about his place in the rotation.

headline: Waiting for Observers, Syrians Document New Violence on YouTube
text: As my colleague Neil MacFarquhar reports, the United Nations Security Council voted Saturday to send an advance team of up to 30 military observers to Syria, where activists appeared to document the security forces opening fire on protesters at a funeral in the city of Aleppo.

headline: Grid Iron
text: Administrivial Tournament Alert! Marbles, the Brain Store, is having FOUR exciting crossword tournaments all on April 28 from 1-4 p.m. How can they do that, you ask? Four different locations, giving you just that much more chance to win Valuable Prizes. Sign up for any of the locations, which include Bloomington, Minnesota; Columbia, Maryland; King of Prussia, Pennsylvania; and Chicago Illinois. Click here for the full kit and kaboodle.

headline: Muslims on Wall Street, Bridging Two Traditions
text: NAIEL IQBAL’S co-workers couldn’t figure him out.

headline: How the Tech Parade Passed Sony By
text: TOKYO

headline: The Children’s Bell Tower
text: On a grassy knoll off Highway 1 in Bodega Bay, an elegant three-tiered steel scaffold with 140 chimes is flanked by Monterey cypress and eucalyptus trees. The Children’s Bell Tower is a memorial to 7-year-old Nicholas Green. He was killed during a highway robbery in 1994 while vacationing with his family in Italy.

headline: Luxury Stores Pull Out Mandarin Phrase Books to Make the Sale
text: Over five days in January, a group of visitors to New York was treated to a private concert with the pianist Lang Lang at the Montblanc store, cocktails and a fashion show attended by the designers Oscar de la Renta and Diane Von Furstenberg, and a tour of Estée Lauder’s original office.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 15
text: The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, joins three Sunday shows this week and will discuss March’s jobs report and the Obama administration’s proposal to raise taxes on the wealthy. He will appear on ABC’s “This Week,” NBC’s “Meet the Press” and CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Pets of San Francisco, Earthquake Planners Have You Covered
text: In a city known for accommodating for pets — where pet dogs, not to mention cats, outnumber the city’s school-age children — and where local laws regulate doghouse architecture, San Francisco emergency planners are working to take care of pets in the next big earthquake.

headline: Plan to Track Quake Threat Is Questioned
text: A hulking research vessel would haul air guns, echo sounders and other instruments along the California coast day and night for several months as part of a proposed $64 million effort to map seismic fault lines near the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.

headline: Heat in Forecast Prompts Changes for Boston Marathon
text: Runners who decide not to compete in the Boston Marathon because of the unusually warm weather conditions forecast for Monday will be allowed to defer their entries to next year’s race, the Boston Athletic Association announced. The announcement applies only to official entrants who do not start the race. No refunds for 2012 entries will be given. In addition, the finish systems that generally shut down just before 5 p.m. will remain open until approximately 6 p.m.

headline: Once More With Feeling: Perry vs. Big Government
text: ​Ross Ramsey, executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: For You, What Was the Most Affecting Titanic Story, Event or Image?
text: April 16, 1:59 p.m. | Updated

headline: Program That Sends Urban Students to Elite Colleges Comes to Houston This Fall
text: Starting this fall, high school seniors in the Houston Independent School District will have an opportunity to vie for one of 30 golden tickets to a unique higher-education experience.

headline: It All Started One Night in the ’80s at Gruene Hall
text: In 1985, a few years before the words “singer-songwriter” were permanently affixed to his name, 19-year-old Todd Snider showed up in San Marcos, knowing only that he had come “to sing.”

headline: Prominent Political Prisoner Is Released Early in Belarus
text: MOSCOW — Belarus granted early release on Saturday to one of its most prominent political prisoners in a move that might be intended to ease its strained relationship with the European Union.

headline: Failing Our Military Veterans
text: My Sunday column argues that we have let our veterans down. This column came to me in conversations with Ashley Gilbertson, an ace photographer for the Times who worked for years in Iraq and more recently has chronicled the struggles of veterans upon returning home. I was flabbergasted to learn from Ashley that more veterans kill themselves every year than the sum of all the soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan since those wars combined.

headline: Henry and Liverpool Try to Right Their Ship
text: John Henry and his partners in the Fenway Sports Group, who have won praise for their stewardship of the Boston Red Sox and were seen as saviors when they purchased Liverpool two years ago, now have two famed but struggling teams on their hands. Jeré Longman checks in from Merseyside. Read the article and come back to comment.

headline: For Wright, 9 Good Fingers Are More Than Enough
text: PHILADELPHIA — Any lingering doubt David Wright might have had about playing with a fractured right pinkie vanished after one pitch Saturday.
