Phillies pitcher Vance Worley threw a 90 mile-an-hour belt-high fastball that Wright crushed to the deepest part of the ballpark, beyond the marker on the center-field fence that indicates 409 feet.

headline: Obama Says Legalization Is Not the Answer on Drugs
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — Leaders at a summit meeting of many of the Western Hemisphere nations on Saturday discussed alternatives to what many consider a failed “war on drugs” that is too reliant on military action and imprisonment. But President Obama said flatly that “legalization is not the answer.”

headline: Blaze Spreads on a Windy Day in the Bronx, Injuring 9 Firefighters
text: Two firefighters who fell through a collapsing floor were among at least nine injured on Saturday afternoon as they fought a fire that spread swiftly from one multifamily house in the east Bronx to three neighboring buildings, officials said.

headline: N.R.A. Official Attacks Florida Shooting Coverage
text: ST. LOUIS — A senior official of the National Rifle Association accused the news media on Saturday of engaging in sensationalized coverage of the Trayvon Martin killing, in the first comments that the gun lobby has made publicly about the fatal shooting since it occurred six weeks ago.

headline: NATO Sees Flaws in Air Campaign Against Qaddafi
text: WASHINGTON — Despite widespread praise in Western capitals for NATO’s leadership of the air campaign in Libya, a confidential NATO assessment paints a sobering portrait of the alliance’s ability to carry out such campaigns without significant support from the United States.

headline: Google Is Faulted for Impeding U.S. Inquiry on Data Collection
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google first revealed in 2010 that cars it was using to map streets were also sweeping up sensitive personal information from wireless home networks, it called the data collection a mistake. On Saturday, federal regulators charged that Google had “deliberately impeded and delayed” an investigation into the data collection and ordered a $25,000 fine on the search giant.

headline: One Favorite Rolls, but Another Tails Off
text: HOT SPRINGS, Ark. — It was a good old-fashioned horse race at Oaklawn Park when Bodemeister went wire to wire to take the 76th running of the $1 million Arkansas Derby on Saturday. No drama, no gimmicks; Bodemeister, a Bob Baffert trainee, simply rolled to the lead and stayed there, widening away to a nine-and-a-half-length lead.

headline: White House Opens Door to Big Donors, and Lobbyists Slip In
text: Last May, as a battle was heating up between Internet companies and Hollywood over how to stop online piracy, a top entertainment industry lobbyist landed a meeting at the White House with one of President Obama’s technology advisers.

headline: Coaches Face New Scrutiny on Sex Abuse
text: The case of Jerry Sandusky, a former defensive coordinator for Penn State’s football team accused of child sexual abuse, is now working its way through the courts. But it is already having an impact on thousands of other coaches, both volunteer and paid, who find themselves facing new scrutiny from parents, sports organizations and even state legislators.

headline: Mild Punishment for a Vicious Hit
text: The playoffs were only hours old when they produced a tumultuous episode in Nashville, where Predators defenseman Shea Weber smashed the head of Red Wings forward Henrik Zetterberg against the glass.

headline: Overly Aggressive Player Is Own Worst Enemy
text: It is almost always better to be the aggressor in chess. Players who give their opponents time to plan and organize an attack often end up losing.

headline: Notes on (Civil War) Camp
text: Civil War paintings can be misleading.

headline: Penguins’ Prospects and Communication Whiplash in 140 Characters
text: Here’s a Twitter-scale post on an Antarctic icon, climate change and the news process, which often begins with a news release. Click the links in sequence to get my point.

headline: Father Pat and the Brinks Job
text: Father Pat Moloney, an East Village activist, talks about his arrest in connection with a $7.4 million Brinks robbery in 1993.

headline: Senators Win, but Only After a Few Angry Shots
text: It was nothing more than retribution, frontier justice in its simplest form. But in the peculiar context of playoff hockey, what the Ottawa Senators did at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night was also a stroke of tactical genius.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 14, 2012

headline: Ottawa Rallies Around Alfredsson After a Hard Hit Sends Him Off for the Evening
text: For the second time this season, Daniel Alfredsson of the Senators was unable to finish a game at Madison Square Garden, apparently because of a head injury. But Alfredsson’s teammates rallied around their captain for Ottawa’s 3-2 overtime victory over the Rangers in Game 2 of the first-round series.

headline: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 2
text: A look at the Ottawa Senators’ overtime victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden in Game 2 of the teams’ first-round playoff series.

headline: An Art Critic in Africa
text: Seeing culture on its own terms. Articles, commentary and pictures.

headline: Maire Abraham, Zachary Conrad
text: Dr. Maire Madden Abraham and Zachary Elliot Conrad were married Saturday afternoon at St. Helen’s Roman Catholic Church in Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Michael A. Saporito, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ginamarie Lafkas, Nathan Aumock
text: Ginamarie Nichole Lafkas and Nathan Michael Aumock were married Saturday at the Willowdale Estate in Topsfield, Mass. Leading the ceremony was John A. Rudberg, the bridegroom’s stepfather, who received temporary permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

text: Amanda Lynn Kay and Dr. Andrew Ian Gitkind were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Sharon B. Ballan at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y.

headline: Stephanie Adams, Patrick Ryan
text: Stephanie Maria Adams and Patrick Martin Ryan were married Saturday by the Rev. David Kerrigan, a retired Roman Catholic priest, at the Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

headline: Meghan Giulino, Paul DeLaney III
text: Meghan Elizabeth Giulino and Paul Henry DeLaney III were married Saturday at the St. Albans School’s chapel on the grounds of the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow, Jr., an Episcopal priest and the former senior chaplain of St. Albans, performed the ceremony.

headline: Carolyn Sufrin, Jacob Harold
text: Dr. Carolyn Beth Sufrin and Jacob Christopher Thomas Harold were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at Annadel Estate Winery in Santa Rosa, Calif. Benjamin S. Abram, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Tina Tyrell and Ethan Pomerance
text: Tina Tyrell and Ethan Ira Pomerance were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Susan Turchin, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Carlyle hotel. Later that day, Dan Gordon, who is the bridegroom’s brother-in-law and a Universal Life minister, led a ceremony that included Jewish and Greek Orthodox elements at La Grenouille, the restaurant.

headline: Anne Keenan, Alexis Seeley
text: Anne Fleming Keenan and Alexis Katherine Seeley were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Winery in Brooklyn. Sarita Bhatt, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Jamie Ruzow, Gregory Radwan
text: Jamie Alison Ruzow and Gregory Ian Radwan are to be married Sunday at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson is to officiate.

headline: Claire Agre, Blair Johnson
text: Claire Coleman Agre and Blair Alexander Johnson were married Saturday at the Cylburn Arboretum in Baltimore. Seamus McNally, a friend of the couple who became an American Marriage Ministries minister for the ceremony, officiated.

headline: Giulia Melucci and Gavin Smith
text: Giulia Anne Melucci and Gavin Steven Grainger Smith were married Monday at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Joel M. Warden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

text: Janet Will Teagle, the daughter of Janet D. Teagle and Walter C. Teagle III of Mill Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jeremy Martin Graham, a son of Phyllis Ann Graham and James Mack Graham Jr. of Plano, Tex. The Rev. Simon Foster, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John’s of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

headline: Lucy Painter and Malaga Baldi
text: Dr. Lucy Naughton Painter and Malaga Jan Baldi are to be married Sunday in their New York apartment by Richard Sadowsky, a Universal Life minister.

headline: Anina Nolan and Powell Fraser III
text: Anina Chrysler Nolan and Powell Alexander Fraser III were married Saturday evening at the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. Katherine G. Carew, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Kate Yulman, Gregory Williamson
text: Kate Jennifer Yulman, the daughter of Janet K. Yulman and E. Richard Yulman of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Gregory Scott Williamson, a son of Madeline Williamson of Brooklyn and the late Kenneth Williamson. Rabbi Terry A. Bookman officiated at the Breakers resort in Palm Beach, Fla., with Cantor Lisa Segal taking part.

headline: Caitlin Monahan, Ryan Condal
text: Caitlin Hennessey Monahan and Ryan J. Condal were married Saturday at St. Vincent de Paul Church in Bayonne, N.J. The Rev. Joseph F. Barbone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Cara McNamara, Jasmit Sandhu
text: Cara Elizabeth McNamara and Jasmit Singh Sandhu were married Saturday evening at the Riverview, an event space in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. A. Waine Kargul, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. In the morning, a Sikh ceremony was led by Giani Komal Singh at the Guru Nanak Darbar Gurdwara, a Sikh temple, in Southington, Conn.

headline: Jeffrey DeHart, Benjamin Halton
text: Jeffrey Patterson DeHart and Dr. Benjamin Thomas Halton were joined in a commitment ceremony on Saturday. Alfred Fuchs, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Fleisher Art Memorial, a community arts center in Philadelphia.

headline: Marie Harf and Joshua Lucas
text: Marie Elizabeth Harf and Joshua Paul Lucas were married Saturday at the Vienna Presbyterian Church in Vienna, Va. The Rev. Erin E. Bair, an Anglican priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Chuck and Lucien Noel Jr.
text: Elizabeth Renee Chuck and Lucien Francois Noel Jr. were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a Manhattan restaurant. Susanne Wilson, who is affiliated with Journeys of the Heart, a nondenominational religious organization, officiated.

headline: Anne Buckman, Andrew Calder
text: Anne Tracy Buckman and Andrew Thomas Calder were married Saturday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Kirk Ullery, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, taking part.

headline: Desireé Hernández Sánchez, Neil Kernis
text: Desireé C. Hernández Sánchez, a daughter of Dr. Ana R. Sánchez Duverge and Dr. Miguel H. Hernández Gutierrez of Puerto Rico, was married Saturday to Neil Irwin Kernis, a son of Susan Collins Kernis and David N. Kernis of Trumbull, Conn. Kenneth S. Greenwald, the bridegroom’s godfather, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at his Manhattan apartment.

headline: Stoudemire Is Hitting His Stride in Practice
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amar’e Stoudemire ran up and down the court at a scrimmage Saturday, moving much like the top-scoring threat the Knicks signed to a maximum contract in the summer of 2010.

headline: Avoiding Another Tick on the Doomsday Clock
text: HONG KONG — It’s still 5 minutes to midnight.

headline: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
text: WOODWARD, Okla. — The tornadoes were unrelenting — more than 100 in 24 hours over a stretch of the Plains states. They tossed vehicles and ripped through homes. They drove families to their basements and whipped debris across small towns throughout the Midwest. In some areas, baseball-size hail rained from the sky.

headline: Anointing Rock Legends From the Coasts
text: CLEVELAND — The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, a gleaming glass pyramid on the shore of Lake Erie, has become a proud symbol of this city. And Cleveland’s rock fans turned out in droves for the hall’s 27th induction ceremony on Saturday, only the third time it has been held here.

headline: A Coachella Festival United by Dance Music
text: INDIO, Calif. — I may give up on thinking about the central musical focus of Coachella. Let me put that another way: if one were to give up, this would be the year. The vibe this time is kind of Pauly D goes to Burning Man, sponsored by Volcom and NPR. The mostly blue-state, caucasian, neo-lotus-eating North American aesthetic mean, late teenage to middle-age, small-batch to mass-pop.

headline: Kendall Wright, Third-Ranked Receiver in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: Complex Attack by Taliban Sends Message to the West
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide bombers and gunmen barraged the diplomatic quarter and the Parliament in the Afghan capital for hours on Sunday and struck three eastern provinces as well, in a complex attack clearly designed to undermine confidence in NATO and Afghan military gains.

headline: North Korean Leader Stresses Need for Strong Military
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In his first speech in public since assuming the leadership of North Korea, Kim Jong-un said Sunday that his “first, second and third” priorities were to strengthen the military, and he declared that superiority in military technology was “no longer monopolized by imperialists.”

headline: Lapses in Cease-Fire Reported as U.N. Monitors Prepare to Begin Mission in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With an initial team of six United Nations military observers scheduled to arrive in Syria on Sunday to monitor compliance with the cease-fire, government shellfire continued to rake central Homs and other flash points.

headline: Drinks for Bellying Up to The Bar With Less Belly
text: Vacation isn’t the ideal time to start counting calories, but for hotel guests still preparing for bikini season, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts doesn’t see why you shouldn’t have your cocktail and lose weight too. Its “skinny drink” initiative has encouraged bartenders at several of its hotels and restaurants to offer drinks with fewer calories and healthier ingredients this spring.

headline: Disruptions: Innovation Isn’t Easy, Especially Midstream
text: In  Instagram’s early days, in offices in the South Park neighborhood of San Francisco, basking in the blue glow of half a dozen computer screens, sat an old Polaroid camera. It was a Rainbow SX-70 OneStep Land Camera.

headline: Taliban Free 384 Inmates in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — In what is being called the biggest jailbreak in Pakistani history, Taliban fighters stormed a prison in the northwestern town of Bannu early Sunday, freeing almost 400 prisoners, including a militant commander who tried in 2003 to assassinate the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Pomp and Fireworks in North Korea
text: North Koreans celebrated the 100th birthday of Kim Il-sung, North Korea’s founding president.

headline: Geithner Scolds Romney Over Women and Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner joined the partisan sparring over women on Sunday, rejecting out of hand the Romney campaign’s assertion that the burden of joblessness had fallen disproportionately on women.

headline: For Americans Abroad, Taxes Just Got More Complicated
text: PARIS — As income tax filing deadline rolls around, spare a thought for the millions of Americans overseas who have been singled out by Congress for special treatment, with a new form that will add to the hassle of tax time for many and, critics say, set up the unwary for penalties.

headline: More on the Link Between Earthquakes and Fracking
text: Scientists from the United States Geological Survey have cautiously weighed in on a subject that has sparked public concern in some parts of the country: spates of small earthquakes in oil- and gas-producing areas.

headline: Insane in Spain
text: Back from travel! (But more crazy travel next week)

headline: Israel Moves to Block Activists From Entering
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — Hundreds of police officers fanned out at Ben-Gurion International Airport on Sunday as Israel moved to block scores of pro-Palestinian campaigners from entering the country.

headline: With Italy and Spain, Further Tests for Europe
text: BRUSSELS — Is the euro crisis back with a vengeance, or do investors have a needless case of anxiety?

headline: Excerpt: 'Peter and the Starcatcher'
text: A scene from the Broadway play about Peter Pan, at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games’ Has Another Big Weekend
text: “The Hunger Games” was the No. 1 movie in North America for an astounding fourth weekend in a row — the first release to achieve that feat since “Avatar.” “The Hunger Games” (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $21.5 million over the weekend for a new domestic total of $337.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data.

headline: Bachmann’s Praise of Romney Falls Short of Endorsement
text: Just five months ago as a presidential candidate, Representative Michele Bachmann took aim at Mitt Romney by saying “he has been very inconsistent in his positions.”

headline: Scenes From Coachella, Day 2
text: A look at some of Saturday’s performances at Coachella.

headline: Bay Out With Jammed Finger
text: PHILADELPHIA – Mets outfielder Jason Bay was scratched from Sunday’s lineup against the Phillies with a jammed right ring finger. Bay sustained the injury sliding into first base Saturday. David Wright sustained a fractured right pinkie last week on the same type of play.

headline: Some Side Dishes Served Up as a Varied Main Course
text: In most of its recent New York performances the Takacs Quartet, which established itself as one of the world’s eminent string ensembles soon after its founding in 1975, has hewed to canonical staples. Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Mendelssohn dominated its edifying programs in the city last year. Likewise its latest recordings for the Hyperion label have focused on Haydn, played with vigor and refinement.

headline: Volley of Words on the Ravages of War
text: “Federer Versus Murray” often comes off more like a highlight reel than a play.

headline: A Festival With Broader Horizons
text: The annual cinematic blitz that is the Tribeca Film Festival is once again poised to hit. For two weeks, beginning Wednesday with the world premiere of the romantic comedy “The Five-Year Engagement,” made by the team behind “Forgetting Sarah Marshall,” 90 feature films will blaze across screens around New York City. The invasion will culminate with the premiere of “The Avengers,” a popcorn explosion in which superheroes band together to forestall global catastrophe.

headline: Celebrating Robinson and Other Black Players, on the Field and in an Exhibit Hall
text: 1:54 p.m. | Updated Major League Baseball will again honor Jackie Robinson for his role in breaking the color barrier, which occurred 65 years ago Sunday, when players across baseball wear 42 on their uniforms, a nod to Robinson’s number with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

headline: Scenes From Coachella, Day 2
text: More Photographs

headline: There Go Starving Artists, Trying It All, Even the Lotto
text: In “Mandorla,” Jenny Rocha’s evening-length work, the atmosphere was something akin to a rowdy or forlorn carnival, depending on your point of view. (For me it was on the sad side, but that had more to do with the weakness of the production than its tone.) Ms. Rocha, clearly the mandorla of her “Mandorla” — an almond-shaped aura that surrounds religious figures — was center stage much of the time.

headline: Rock Music With Tropical Punch, a Soundtrack for a Hip Island Hotel
text: The sense of completion on the first Tanlines album, “Mixed Emotions,” which was released last month by True Panther, is palpable. It’s patient, brightly colored and often exuberant, walking the line between spare club music and dance-minded rock, with mild Caribbean flourishes for added punch.

headline: Iraq Emerges From Isolation as Telecommunications Hub
text: PARIS — Iraq, cut off from decades of technological progress because of dictatorship, sanctions and wars, recently took a big step out of isolation and into the digital world when its telecommunications system was linked to a vast new undersea cable system serving the Gulf countries.

headline: Crowd-Sourcing Expands Power of Brain Research
text: In the largest collaborative study of the brain to date, scientists using imaging technology at more than 100 centers worldwide have for the first time zeroed in on genes that they agree play a role in intelligence and memory.

headline: Cue the Goal-Line Technology Debate
text: Goal or no goal? Travesty or justice?

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Zen for High Schoolers: ‘Notice the Anxiety. Notice the Fear.’
text: La-keeyatta Steward, 17, sat on a small black pillow one recent Tuesday afternoon, her legs tucked under her. Her meditation instructor told her to imagine her body pulled upward by a string, so she lowered her shoulders and straightened her back.

headline: Daring to Cut Off Amazon
text: TULSA, Okla. — Plenty of people are upset at Amazon these days, but it took a small publishing company whose best-known volume is a toilet-training tome to give the mighty Internet store the boot.

headline: After Hearing With Shanahan, Rangers’ Hagelin Is Suspended Three Games
text: 8:47 p.m. | Updated Matt Carkner suspended one game for instigating an altercation with Brian Boyle. Here is the video of Brendan Shanahan explaining the punishment.

headline: Anthony’s Big Day Is No Match for Big Three
text: For 42 minutes, the ledger was nearly even — Carmelo Anthony on one side, points flying from his fingertips, the Miami Heat on the other, unleashing every ounce of their star power to match him in a rousing Sunday matinee at Madison Square Garden.

headline: For Most, Choice of Stay-at-Home Motherhood Is Far From a Luxury
text: The layoff notice was not a complete surprise. At the shipping center in Denver where Jeanine Maez filled mail orders, the trend had been toward paperless transactions.

headline: A Not-Quite-Young Man With a Plan Follows a Type-A Pursuit of Health
text: In “Drop Dead Healthy” A. J. Jacobs describes taking the Staten Island Ferry en route to the starting line of his first triathlon. A passenger notices Mr. Jacobs’s duffel bag not because it is camouflage patterned but because the camouflage colors are red and pink.

headline: Arguing About Language
text: Today I’m going to hopefully beg a question which will incentivize the reader to share their views.  Yes, I’m writing about English grammar and usage.

headline: Book Publishing’s Real Nemesis
text: The Justice Department finally took aim at the monopolistic monolith that threatened to dominate the book industry. So imagine the shock when the bullet aimed at threats to competition went whizzing by Amazon — which not long ago had a 90 percent stranglehold on e-books — and instead, struck five of the six biggest publishers and Apple, a minor player in the realm of books.

headline: Excuses Spring Eternal, but Not in Fair Weather
text: It was so warm this past winter, many golf courses in the Midwest and the North never closed, with players tromping around the grounds from Thanksgiving to St. Patrick’s Day. Those courses that did close flung open the doors for the spring season several weeks earlier than usual, and with good conditions.

headline: Dressing Up and Discovering What’s in the Toy Box
text: It’s a little worrisome to discover that the kids have emptied out the costume trunk. So many props should keep them occupied, and maybe they’ll entertain the grownups while they’re at it, but the situation is already messy, and it’s bound to get messier.

headline: Reconfigured Requiem With Words to the Fore
text: For the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer the unexpected is the norm. Among other experiments, Mr. Fischer likes to test unusual seating plans with the Budapest Festival Orchestra, which he helped to found and directs, and other orchestras, to alter balances and bring out intriguing details, especially those involving woodwinds.

headline: New York Public Library Defends Plan to Renovate
text: The New York Public Library is engaged in a public-relations blitz to address criticism from scholars and writers who object to the library’s plan to reimagine its Fifth Avenue flagship building at an estimated cost of $300 million.

headline: Double-counting Doubletalk
text: Some readers have asked me for a reaction to Steve Rattner’s piece on Medicare and the Affordable Care Act. The short answer is that it’s a classic piece of concern trolling – the practice, all too common among a certain class of commentators, of professing sympathy with progressive policy goals, then, invariably, finding a way to support right-wing talking points.

headline: Man, Alive to Machine Possibilities
text: Last week Ralf Hütter, the singer and founder of the pioneering German electronic band Kraftwerk, recalled the first time the band came to New York City: in 1975, for an American tour to promote “Autobahn,” an unlikely hit sung in German and backed by electronics. The group members were carrying, he said, a few suitcases, some synthesizers in padded boxes they had built themselves and, for visuals, a slide projector.

headline: Inequality and Crisis Response
text: Wells and Krugman from the Occupy Handbook has been serialized in Slate Salon

headline: Remembering Hans Kreijns, Dutch Champion
text: One of the world’s great players, Hans Kreijns from the Netherlands, died on April 4 at 83.

headline: A Sketch Artist Animates a Fraternity of Bumblers
text: The four interrelated tales of “Oki’s Movie,” Hong Sang-soo’s beguiling new film, are preceded by “Pomp and Circumstance,” played over handwritten credits. Elgar’s stately march becomes an ironic refrain to the misadventures and regrets of the three recurring characters, two men and a woman, who navigate different stages in their lives at a film school. The unsubtle musical theme is also a sharp contrast to Mr. Hong’s casually brilliant feat of storytelling, akin to an ingeniously wrought suite of literary short fiction.

headline: Mets Stumble Against Phillies, Missing Out on a Sweep
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets entered Citizens Bank Park on Friday with a two-game losing streak, David Wright injured and the heart of their lineup struggling. They faced a three-game series against the Phillies, who have won five consecutive National League East crowns and were sending Cliff Lee and Cole Hamels to the mound during the weekend.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for March and business inventories for February (Monday); housing starts and industrial production for March (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims, home resales for March, leading economic indicators for March, and the Philadelphia Fed index (Thursday).

headline: It’s Like a Borgasmord
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Man, I’m full. I just finished Lynn Lempel’s puzzle and I don’t think I could eat another square, sorry, thing.

headline: Bradley Cooper Joins ‘The Elephant Man’
text: Bradley Cooper, People’s Sexiest Man Alive in 2011, will take on one of acting’s most unflattering roles, in the Williamstown Theater Festival’s revival of “The Elephant Man.” Mr. Cooper will portray John Merrick, the deformed man at the center of the play, by Bernard Pomerance. Mr. Cooper portrayed Merrick as part of his senior thesis at the Actors Studio Drama School, and appeared in the festival’s production of “The Understudy” by Theresa Rebeck in 2008. He will be joined onstage by Patricia Clarkson, who will play an actress who befriends Merrick during his hospital stay. Ms. Clarkson, also a veteran of the festival, appeared in “The Ride Down Mount Morgan” by Arthur Miller in 1996. Directed by Scott Ellis (“The Little Dog Laughed”), “The Elephant Man” is scheduled to run from July 25 to Aug. 5. Ticket orders can be placed at wtfestival.org.

headline: Stones to Record? Not So Fast
text: After saying at a news conference last week that the Rolling Stones would head into a recording studio this month “to just bat some ideas around,” the guitarist Ronnie Wood has amended those comments after receiving a phone call from Mick Jagger. “I heard from Jagger; he’s going: ‘What the hell? We don’t know anything yet,’ ” Mr. Wood, above, said on Sunday, speaking with Billboard.com from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, where he was inducted on Saturday for the second time. He said that he had expressed a personal view and that he would love to go into the studio, but that nothing had been set. “So I have to make a personal apology to the rest of the band,” he said. “I didn’t mean to say things out of line.”

headline: TED Teams With NPR
text: TED, the nonprofit group that sponsors conferences on ideas, is coming to NPR. A 10-episode series titled “TED Radio Hour” will begin on April 27 on NPR stations and at ted.npr.org, the two organizations plan to announce on Monday. The show, hosted by Alison Stewart, the former anchor of the PBS series “Need to Know,” draws from an archive of more than 1,200 TED talks, each lasting 18 minutes or so, which become the kernels for a broader conversation, Eric Nuzum, NPR’s vice president for programming, said by telephone. Each episode is organized around a theme: one pairs competing talks on the cause of happiness; others look at the power of crowds and food sustainability. Chris Anderson, who runs the TED conferences, said in a phone interview that the challenge was to “take material that was in some cases three or four years old and make it seem fresh and relevant” by letting Ms. Stewart explore points in more depth and bring in other voices. Local stations will broadcast the program at varied times; WNYC in New York is scheduling it for the summer. NPR will wait to approve a second season, but Mr. Anderson is optimistic: “I don’t think the world’s going to run out of ideas any time soon,” she said. “I would say that curiosity is a self-fueling fire.” TED is also exploring television. “There are lots of conversations and discussions afoot,” Mr. Anderson said, declining to provide specifics.

headline: Yale Drama Winner
text: “Beautiful Province,” a new play by Clarence Coo about a 15-year-old boy who travels across Canada with his French high school teacher, is the winner of the 2012 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright, the judge for the series, John Guare (“The House of Blue Leaves,” “Six Degrees of Separation”), is to announce on Monday. Mr. Coo will receive the $10,000 prize, from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and the play will be published by Yale University Press. A staged reading is set for Sept. 18 at Lincoln Center Theater. The runners-up were Saviana Stanescu for “Useless” and Jesse Weaver for “We Shall Catch Larks.”

headline: Severe Storms Spawn Tornadoes in the Midwest
text: At least 122 tornadoes were reported overnight Saturday across Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska and Iowa, causing damage across the region and killing six people in Oklahoma.

headline: Bidding to Change Golf’s Perception as Sport for Rich
text: Wednesday is National Golf Day, and a chief goal of the day is to explain golf in all its forms, not just those typically envisioned by non-golfers.

headline: Pandora Courts Local Advertisers, by Offering Well-Defined Listeners
text: The music was pumping and the finger food laid out in abundance one recent evening in a subterranean Manhattan bar, as executives of Pandora Media, the Internet radio service, mingled with some of their most prized new advertisers.

headline: A Great Show in China, a Lingering Cloud Over Bahrain
text: SHANGHAI — As I wrestled my way out of the sardine can of a Metro train car packed with racegoers for the Chinese Grand Prix Sunday I said to myself, “Hey, wait a minute, this series is not supposed to have succeeded in China! Why do I see thousands of spectators disembarking from this train, and only a tiny minority of them being foreigners?”

headline: Mere Mortal’s Approach to Shot That Won Masters
text: I’ve been thinking about Bubba Watson’s astonishing, Masters-winning shot from the pine straw next to the 10th hole at Augusta National last week. I wonder how average recreational players would approach such a shot: 160 yards with overhanging trees in the way, and you must hook the ball about 40 yards and land it on a severely elevated green protected by deep bunkers and a cathedral of tall, intimidating loblolly pines.

headline: Making Visas-for-Dollars Work
text: AMONG the most popular tools for attracting foreign investment to the United States is the EB-5 program. It seems like the perfect win-win: any foreigner who invests between $500,000 and $1 million here, and creates at least 10 domestic jobs from that investment within two years, gets a green card.

headline: Progressive Rock Station, WBCN, Returns on HD
text: From a newly repurposed electric green school bus parked next to his split-level home in suburban Hingham, Mass., Sam Kopper is broadcasting music live on a Friday night. But is anyone listening?

headline: Europe’s Economic Suicide
text: On Saturday The Times reported on an apparently growing phenomenon in Europe: “suicide by economic crisis,” people taking their own lives in despair over unemployment and business failure. It was a heartbreaking story. But I’m sure I wasn’t the only reader, especially among economists, wondering if the larger story isn’t so much about individuals as about the apparent determination of European leaders to commit economic suicide for the Continent as a whole.

headline: Teixeira Is Slow to Start; Girardi Is Slow to Worry
text: After an off-season spent changing his workout routine and losing weight in an effort to improve his batting average, Mark Teixeira was hitting .188 with only two extra-base hits through the Yankees’ first eight games.

headline: Murray Rose, Australian Olympic Swimming Star, Dies at 73
text: Murray Rose, who won four Olympic gold medals in swimming for Australia, becoming one of his nation’s most celebrated athletes before going to Hollywood to try his hand in the movies, died Sunday in Sydney, Australia. He was 73.

headline: Trial in Martin Case, Filled With High Emotion, Would Draw a News Swarm
text: The Orlando Sentinel’s Twitter account for the Trayvon Martin case is up and running. So, too, is its topics page, with links to all the newspaper’s articles about Mr. Martin and the man who shot and killed him, George Zimmerman, as well as video clips of its reporters talking about the case on television. A Facebook page will go online on Monday. And a Web video series might be next.

headline: Africa’s Free Press Problem
text: AS Africa’s economies grow, an insidious attack on press freedom is under way. Independent African journalists covering the continent’s development are now frequently persecuted for critical reporting on the misuse of public finances, corruption and the activities of foreign investors.

headline: President Speaks Out on Guard Investigation
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama commented for the first time on Sunday about the Secret Service employees accused of soliciting prostitutes before a summit meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, saying he expected a high standard of conduct from his security team and adding that he would be “angry” if the accusations were proved true.

text: Bill Pennington talks to Arnold Palmer and his grandson Sam Saunders about golf club technology.

headline: Butch Bouchard, Imposing Pillar of Montreal Canadiens’ Defense, Dies at 92
text: Butch Bouchard, the Hall of Fame defenseman and longtime captain of the Montreal Canadiens, who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams in the 1940s and ’50s, died on Saturday in Brossard, Quebec, near Montreal. He was 92.

headline: N.H.L. Suspends Rangers’ Hagelin Three Games for Elbowing Alfredsson
text: Carl Hagelin was late for the Rangers’ practice Sunday afternoon, but he had an excuse. Hagelin, a rookie wing, spent about 15 minutes in a phone hearing with Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L.’s vice president for hockey operations and player safety.

headline: Lou Goldstein, Borscht Belt Master of Simon Says, Dies at 90
text: Lou Goldstein was the consummate tummler, one of a zany species of entertainer who kept them laughing, or tried to, long ago in the borscht belt hotels of the Catskills.

headline: The Sweet Spot
text: THE other day Rick Santorum, with rigor mortis setting into his campaign, stepped up to a microphone in Mars, Pa. (Yes, really.) His complaint was a familiar one: For too long the Republican “aristocracy” has shoved moderate nominees down the throats of the voters. “There’s one person,” he declared, referring to Ronald Reagan, “who understood we don’t win by moving to the middle. We win by getting people in the middle to move to us.”

headline: After Florida Shooting, N.R.A. Crowd Sticks to What It Knows
text: ST. LOUIS — Inside the seven-acre showroom at the National Rifle Association’s annual convention here during the weekend, firearm enthusiasts filtered in and out of the sea of booths displaying handguns and the holsters designed to hide them.

headline: News Corporation’s Pursuer Had Modest Start
text: Rupert Murdoch has made a career of painting his critics as elitist, privileged and out of touch. But the English lawyer who stands at the center of the legal battles that have engulfed his News Corporation did not attend a select law school or work at a top London law firm.

headline: From the Birthplace of Big Brother
text: The George W. Bush team must be consumed with envy. Britain’s government is preparing sweeping new legislation that would let the country’s domestic intelligence agencies monitor all private telephone, e-mail, text message, social network and Internet use in the country, bypassing requirements for judicial warrants.

headline: Letting Carmelo Anthony Go It Alone May Not Help Knicks
text: There may or may not have been a playoff statement made by the Miami Heat on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, but there certainly was a personnel seminar conducted by LeBron James and Dwyane Wade. Stylistically and statistically, they sent a pointed message to the Knicks on the virtues of all-stars who go out of their way to share.

headline: Declining as a Manufacturer, Japan Weighs Reinvention
text: AMAGASAKI, Japan — A few years ago, the densely built-up coastal region around this port was called Panel Bay because of its concentration of factories making the sophisticated flat-panel screens that were symbols of Japan’s manufacturing prowess. But now the area has become a grim symbol of its industrial decline.

headline: Keeping a Promise to Home Care Aides
text: Evelyn Coke, who died in 2009 at age 74, was a home care aide whose case for fair pay went to the Supreme Court in 2007, where she lost 9 to 0. At issue were federal rules that define home care aides as “companions,” a label that exempts employers from having to pay minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime. The justices said that only Congress or the Labor Department could change the rules.

headline: Many U.S. Immigrants’ Children Seek American Dream Abroad
text: Samir N. Kapadia seemed to be on the rise in Washington, moving from an internship on Capitol Hill to jobs at a major foundation and a consulting firm. Yet his days, he felt, had become routine.

text: President Obama’s aides have said said they thought it was possible to win Arizona, a state that analysts believe is heading Democratic in national elections, but may not be there yet.

text: LONDON — My partner likes to say our children will soon be “more British than American.” This is because they will soon spend more of their 2-year-old lives in Britain than in the United States.

headline: 3 Arrested in Manhattan as March Turns Into a Melee

text: PHILADELPHIA — All the elements that have so far fashioned the Flyers-Penguins matchup as the most compelling of the N.H.L. playoffs were present Sunday at Wells Fargo Center, but so was perhaps the one component it had lacked.

headline: Pseudoscience and Tennessee’s Classrooms
text: Eighty-seven years after Tennessee was nationally embarrassed for criminally prosecuting the teaching of evolution, the state government is at it again. This time it has enacted a law that protects teachers who invite students to challenge the science underlying evolution and climate change. The measure is a transparent invitation to indulge pseudoscience in the classroom and a transparent pandering to a vocal, conservative fringe.

headline: Victims’ Advocates Protest as Prosecutors Detain 17-Year-Old Rape Victim in California

headline: Unanswered Questions in F.C.C.’s Google Case

But a report over the weekend from federal regulators has rekindled questions over exactly what the company was doing — questions the search giant has spent years trying not to answer.

headline: Homegrown Bomb Plot Is Rarity for Open Court
text: The three high school classmates from a workaday section of Queens were trained in bomb-making in the tribal areas of Pakistan, where they received their orders directly from senior members of Al Qaeda, prosecutors said. They gathered explosives, chose targets and picked the days in September 2009 when they planned to take their own lives, in three separate bombings in the New York subway system.

headline: Tutoring Surges With Fight for Middle School Spots
text: As their parents sat anxiously in a waiting room, five children were sharpening their test-taking skills in a tutoring center in TriBeCa, underlining words that might hold clues to the answers and crossing off the illogical multiple-choice options intended to trip them up. For homework, there were more practice problems.

headline: Fire in Catskills Ravages Site of Old Brown’s Hotel
text: A fire over the weekend swept through a condominium complex in the Catskills that was once the Brown’s Hotel, where Jerry Lewis and other comedians entertained crowds of vacationing New Yorkers.

headline: Opening Up a Path to Four-Year Degrees
text: PHILADELPHIA — At the end of his first year at the Community College of Philadelphia, Christopher Thomas decided that his goal — to go back to school and get a degree — was no longer worth it. He was in debt from thousands of dollars in student loans. After class, he rode a bus an hour and a half to a suburban restaurant where he worked as a waiter. When the shift ended at midnight, it took him three buses to get home. He couldn’t afford a computer, so in the middle of the night, he walked to his aunt’s house and used hers to finish his class work.

headline: Two Giants of Finance Will Release Diversity Data
text: At the behest of New York City’s public pension funds, two of the biggest financial companies with headquarters in the city, Goldman Sachs and MetLife, have agreed to publicly disclose information about the racial and gender breakdowns of their staffs.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers and Romney Face a Delicate Tango
text: WASHINGTON — If Mitt Romney is considering a quick pivot to the center as he heads into the general election, he will find an imposing impediment: fellow Republicans in the House.

headline: Let the Nanotargeting Begin
text: Over the past decade, political campaigns, interest groups and a network of private companies have developed sophisticated tools to target tinier and tinier fractions of the electorate. Campaigns now have access to the voting histories, housing values, recreational preferences, automobile ownership and television and Internet viewing habits of individuals. The explosion of consumer data derived primarily from credit card usage and Nielsen ratings has become a powerful weapon in the hands of politicos.

headline: Gingrich and Paul Defy Calls to Rally Around Romney
text: With Rick Santorum out of the Republican presidential field, clearing a path to the nomination for Mitt Romney, the fight to become the party’s standard-bearer is over, right?

headline: Spanish King’s Hip Surgery Follows Controversial Hunting Trip
text: King Juan Carlos of Spain underwent hip replacement surgery during the weekend following an accident in Botswana, where he had gone to hunt elephants, a vacation that spurred criticism of the monarch’s lifestyle at a time when the country is coping with an economic crisis.

headline: ‘We’re Not Really Bad Kids’
text: HUNTINGDON, Tenn. — The Carroll Academy girls basketball team had just lost by 59 points to Dresden High School, the top team in the conference. Still, Tonya Lutz, Carroll Academy’s coach, lauded her team’s effort. Randy Hatch, Carroll Academy’s day-to-day director and founder of the basketball program, reached into a pocket and slipped $20 to one of the girls, as he usually does after games.

headline: Ai Weiwei on the Pen and the Gun
text: HONG KONG — When we last looked in on Ai Weiwei, the rebellious Chinese artist was suing the Beijing tax authorities over their charges against him. The Public Security folks had pulled the plug on Weiweicam, his project that was streaming live video feeds from inside his house to the Internet. He has continued to break the rules of his release from prison, blaming his lack of self-discipline, telling The Economist, “C’mon, I can’t even lose weight!”

headline: April 16, 1947 | Fire Causes Huge Explosion in Texas City
text: On April 16, 1947, America’s worst harbor explosion occurred in Texas City, Tex., when the French ship Grandcamp, carrying ammonium nitrate fertilizer, caught fire and blew up, devastating the town.

headline: Yankees’ Slumbering Bats Quickly Come to Life

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: A Political Spouse Once More

headline: As Army Prepares to Shrink, Its Chief Tries to Reassure His Soldiers
text: WIESBADEN, Germany — Hundreds of American troops crowded the bleachers inside a gymnasium at the historic garrison here as Gen. Ray Odierno, the Army’s top officer, tried to address what seemed to be on the minds of every soldier: the future.

headline: Raising the Memory of the Titanic, and a City’s Role in Its Creation
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — One hundred years after the Titanic slid beneath the icy Atlantic, this city, where the doomed ship was built, noted the occasion on Sunday by unveiling a memorial to the victims in a ceremony that was part of an effort to shape a shared history in what is still a deeply divided society.

headline: Is Siachen Worth Fighting Over?

headline: Trickle of Returning NRIs to Become a Flood

headline: U.N. Truce Observers Arrive in Syria as Shelling Continues

headline: How Do You Archive Your Life?

headline: In the Arcadian Woods
text: Often I sense its electric energy during the initial phone call. Anxiety is like that. It leaps from you to me then back again like some unruly spirit. But that faint buzz reveals surprisingly little else about the being on the other end of the line. Who is not at times worried, nervous, troubled, frantic or even panicked? Anxiety may be an omen of vast import, or not much at all. Like the robot in the television series “Lost in Space” who proclaims “Danger, Will Robinson,” this primal alarm sends out its warning, but of what? As a psychiatrist, it is part of my job to find out.
