text: Coty tried to rally support on Monday for its $10 billion unsolicited bid for Avon Products. But it was unclear whether the effort had succeeded.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Citigroup’s First-Quarter Net Income Falls 2%  |  Citigroup reported better-than-expected earnings on Monday, driven by steady demand for loans from consumers and businesses and an improving economic condition in the United States.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Planning for Zimmerman Trial, and What Breitbart Wrought
text: The shooting death of Trayvon Martin has transfixed social networks and news coverage, and that’s before there was an arrest. Now that George Zimmerman has been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting, news outlets are preparing for a televised trial that could receive blanket coverage on television networks and Web sites, Brian Stelter writes. “It has the potential to be as big as the O. J. Simpson trial — and just as divisive,” said Piers Morgan, the CNN interviewer.

headline: Monday Reading: When to Buy That Plane Ticket
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Gary Oldman to Direct Jack White Concert Webcast
text: Even though he has never been any of these things in real life, Gary Oldman has slipped seamlessly into the film roles of a violent, dreadlocked pimp; a vampire count; and a man who sliced off his own face. Now can he play the part of the director of a live concert broadcast, without having done it before?

headline: Vain Glorious | A New Face Balm for Men
text: Who: Ursa Major

headline: The Trademarked Beard
text: MOSCOW — I was discussing a newly submitted article with a colleague at the magazine we edit when another editor ran into the room shouting, “Did you see? They didn’t let Verbitsky out of the country because someone has trademarked his  beard.” Mikhail Verbitsky, a mathematician, is a popular blogger.

headline: On the Campaign Trail, Reciting Family History
text: They are certainly a luckless bunch, all those would-be mayors not named Quinn. How improvident of them not to have had a grandparent who booked passage on the Titanic, thereby giving them an interesting legacy of their own for all those reflections on the great ship’s final moments, a century ago on Sunday.

headline: Daily Report: Unanswered Questions About Google
text: The Federal Communications Commission fined and censured Google for obstructing an inquiry into its Street View project, which had collected Internet communications from potentially millions of unknowing households as specially equipped cars drove slowly by.

headline: Testing, Tutoring and Worrying Occupy City School Parents
text: Testing, striving and tutoring are very much in the news on this warm April day, the first back from spring break for public school students and staff. The New York Times has a report about the rise in tutoring for elementary school students, in preparation for the standardized exams, which begin this week. The results of the gifted and talented testing are in. And there is worry about graduation rates now that senior have to pass five Regents exams to earn their diplomas.

headline: Lee Equity Partners to Take Edelman Financial Private
text: The wealth management firm Edelman Financial said Monday that it would go private after accepting a $258 million bid from Lee Equity Partners, the latest private equity shop to go hunting for asset managers.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 16: An Influx of 7-Elevens
text: Good morning. Leave your jacket at home today, the hottest day of the year thus far. Highs will reach the mid-80s.

headline: The Palin Counterfactual
text: After Rick Santorum’s exit from the race last week, Philip Klein and HotAir’s Allahpundit considered what would have happened if Sarah Palin rather than Santorum had been Mitt Romney’s right-wing foil. I think that this point from Klein is interesting …

headline: Goldman Sachs Sells Shares in China Bank for $2.5 Billion
text: Goldman Sachs has sold $2.5 billion of shares in the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China to the Singaporean sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings and other institutional shareholders.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Real Simple: Need that nudge to give your fridge a thorough spring cleaning? You’ll find it here, in this magazine’s exhaustive guide to how long food truly lasts in the refrigerator, the freezer and the pantry. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Great Wolf Declares KSL Takeover Bid Superior
text: Great Wolf Resorts has switched sides in the mounting bidding war over the water park operator.

headline: Street-Crossing Time Trials
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Horror, The Horror
text: Atrios, aka Duncan Black, is celebrating his 10th blogoversary with a countdown of America’s Worst Pundits. And he emphasizes just how bad a decade it has been,

headline: Leading Off: The N.H.L.’s Head Games
text: If the N.H.L. had any grasp on long-term reality, it would be curled up in the fetal position at headquarters today. Because for all its occasionally impressive-sounding talk about making the game safer, for all of the discipline guru Brendan Shanahan’s suspension videos and for all the traditional claptrap about players knowing what’s best for the game (which is why, the argument goes, they should patrol it themselves, with their fists), just go ahead and enter the first round of the playoffs into evidence in all of those future concussion lawsuits against the league. While they’re at it, the players should just go ahead and sue one another as well for treating other players’ heads like piñatas.

headline: Ancient Chinese Relics to Be Displayed at Discovery Times Square
text: In Times Square, one kind of ancient religious legacy is about to make way for another. “Warriors: Defenders of China’s First Emperor,” a new exhibition of artifacts, including 10 of the terracotta soldiers created more than 2,000 years ago to protect China’s first emperor, Qin Shi Huang, in his afterlife, will open at Discovery Times Square on West 44th Street on April 27. The new exhibition, which succeeds a popular show featuring examples of the Dead Sea Scrolls, will also include a set of gates from an ancient Han burial chamber, never before publicly displayed, and 20 other artifacts that will be shown in the United States for the first time, among dozens of other pieces.

headline: Some Tax Breaks Unavailable to Same-Sex Couples
text: Updated: Tuesday, 12:55 p.m., to clarify how the earned income credit works in the example provided.

headline: Video of Anders Behring Breivik in Court
text: As my colleagues Mark Lewis and Alan Cowell report, Anders Behring Breivik, the gunman who has admitted that he killed 77 people during twin attacks in Norway last year, appeared in court in Oslo on Monday.

headline: Animating Crumb
text: A new museum exhibition in Paris features an interactive animation of a Robert Crumb comic, a collaboration between the American cartoonist and a Belgian digital media artist.

headline: Business Day Live | April 16, 2012
text: Weighing an economic slowdown in China and commodities traders boycott an exchange over regulatory dispute.

headline: Maggie Smith Departing ‘Downton Abbey’? Studio Says ‘Not True’
text: It looks like Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess of “Downton Abbey,” will not yet have the time to discover what a weekend is: Maggie Smith, the actress who portrays that character on “Downton Abbey,” the hit British costume drama, is not planning to leave that series, a press representative for the studio that produces it said Monday.

headline: To Fight a Dam, Rather Than ‘Live on Your Knees’
text: At a casual glance, Lake Turkana in northern Kenya may not seem a fount of milk and honey. The temperature around the lake hovers around 100 degrees, and tourists are warned not to approach the water because of the crocodiles and vipers lurking among the volcanic rocks.

headline: Business Day Live: A Slowdown in China
text: Weighing an economic slowdown in China, and commodities traders boycott an exchange over a regulatory dispute.

headline: ‘GMA’ Appears to Nudge ‘Today’ From Top Spot After 16 Years
text: Updated, 11:00 p.m.The morning television shake-up that NBC News said would not come — even as recently as two weeks ago — arrived on Monday when ABC’s “Good Morning America,” based on preliminary weekly ratings, defeated NBC’s “Today” show for the first time in 852 weeks.

headline: New York Public Library President is Taking Reader Questions
text: The New York Public Library’s plan to bring its Mid-Manhattan branch and the Science, Industry and Business Library into its lion-flanked Fifth Avenue landmark building – creating a circulating as well as a research library there for the first time — has caused concern among academics and writers.

headline: Scenes From Coachella, Day 3
text: A look at some of Sunday’s performances at Coachella.

headline: Kenyans Sweep Top Spots in a Warm Boston Marathon
text: BOSTON — He felt his first cramp in the first mile. With more than 25 miles still to run in unseasonably steamy conditions, Wesley Korir knew then and there that the 116th Boston Marathon was going to be unlike any other race he had ever run.

headline: Surviving a Deadly Twister, Twice in 65 Years
text: WOODWARD, Okla. — On April 9, 1947, Wilma Lake was alone in her apartment on Oak Avenue when a tornado swept through this rural town in the dark of night. She survived — crouching beneath a table — but many of her neighbors did not.

headline: Video of Taliban Firefight in Kabul and Its Aftermath
text: As my colleague Alissa J. Rubin reports, Afghan forces on Monday ended a complex attack by Taliban fighters in the heart of Kabul and the main cities of three provinces, retaking a building in the capital that had been used as a base of operations.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/16
text: Parks and Recreation Just in time for summer trip planning, the May issue of Outside magazine features 12 off-the-beaten-path national parks that you just might have to yourself. (Outside)

headline: In New York, Tutoring Intensifies in Race to Middle School
text: In New York City, where “even seats in public schools can be the rewards of a Darwinian contest,” the tutoring industry has found a whole new lode to mine: preparing fourth and fifth graders for the standardized tests that are crucial for getting into top middle schools. The result may be an unfair advantage for families who can afford the extra money and time.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Nico Rosberg Wins First Formula One Grand Prix of His Career
text: Nico Rosberg, the Mercedes AMG Petronas driver, was first on the starting grid entering the Chinese Grand Prix on Sunday. Were this the highlight of the weekend for the Mercedes factory team, which hadn’t captured a pole since 1955, it would have been momentous, but Rosberg had grander plans.

headline: Romney Talks of Ending Some Tax Deductions for Wealthy
text: Mitt Romney inadvertently offered a public preview of some of his economic plans on Sunday, revealing to high-dollar donors at a private fund-raising event that he wants to eliminate tax deductions for wealthy people who own second homes.

headline: Numberplay: Living on the Far Side
text: Imagine each of the planets in our solar system were evenly covered by a billion people. At any given moment how many people would be living on the far side? (The far side is the part of a planet not visible from any other planet.)

headline: Protesters Arrested in Sleep-Out and Demonstration Near Stock Exchange
text: Updated, 11:24 p.m. | The police arrested four people near the New York Stock Exchange on Monday morning after telling Occupy Wall Street protesters, who have been gathering there for a week, that they were not permitted to sit or lie down on sidewalks. Several additional arrests followed in the evening, with the possibility of more to come.

headline: Death Row Inmate’s Best Lawyer Was Himself
text: WASHINGTON — Albert Holland Jr., a death row inmate in Florida, has no legal training and seems to be suffering from a mental illness — “perhaps a disorder involving paranoia or delusional thoughts,” a federal judge wrote recently.

headline: Gearing Up for Test Day. And Then What?
text: Laura Klein, a middle-school teacher in the Bronx, writes that test prep is in full swing at her school -- as it must be, given all that rides on the results. But the problem is not in using precious school time to teach to a test. "Our failure is that we struggle to inspire them beyond the test," she writes -- and students have to be reminded why learning must continue in the sunny months of May and June.

headline: Street Style: Bomber and Varsity Jackets
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of April 9.

headline: Look of the Moment | Kate Bosworth
text: The Look: Wild. An animal-print tee gets on swimmingly with a pair of black Daisy Dukes and desert boots.

headline: China Premier Calls for End to Corruption
text: As a murder and corruption scandal enveloping a former member of China’s elite leadership continued to snowball, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao issued a new call on Monday for the government to end a culture of graft lest it lead to the end of Communist rule.

headline: Capitals Goalie Takes Rapid Rise Save by Save
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Just a month ago, 22-year-old goalie Braden Holtby stepped off the ice in St. John’s, Newfoundland. His team, the Hershey Bears of the American Hockey League, had just been defeated, 6-1.

headline: Slide Show: Day 3 at Coachella
text: More Photographs

headline: In Economics, You Are What You Model
text: Oh, for the days of two-handed economists. Following the 2008 financial crisis, we are instead plagued by warring camps of macroeconomists who agree the profession has achieved a deep understanding of the economy and who disagree about almost every detail.

headline: A Population Antidote: High School for Girls
text: High school for girls = population control = sustainable growth.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev to Take Controlling Stake in Caribbean Brewer
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world’s largest brewer, agreed on Monday to take a controlling stake in the Caribbean drinks maker Cerveceria Nacional Dominicana, or C.N.D., for $1.2 billion.

headline: Briton in a Chinese Scandal Reportedly Brokered Overseas Money Transfers
text: BEIJING — Neil Heywood, the British businessman at the center of a scandal involving the former Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, was believed to have transferred large sums of money overseas illicitly for Mr. Bo’s family before his death in November, one person familiar with an inquiry into the case said on Monday.

headline: U.N. Council to Expand North Korea Sanctions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The United Nations Security Council officially censured North Korea on Monday over the failed rocket launching of a satellite last week, saying it “strongly condemns” the action and had ordered its sanctions committee to expand the blacklist of North Korean goods, companies and individuals connected to that country’s nuclear and missile programs.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Former Enron Chief’s Latest Appeal
text: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear the latest appeal by Jeffrey Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron serving a 24-year sentence in a federal prison for his role in the energy company’s collapse.

headline: Romney Moving Ahead With Search for Running Mate
text: Mitt Romney is starting to bear down on his search for a running mate, but he cautioned in an interview on Monday that a final selection may not come until the Republican convention in August. And he disclosed that he had picked someone to lead the search.

headline: Can Roads and Russian Forests Coexist?
text: In 2009, in checking back on development patterns in the Amazon River basin, I examined this question: “Can Roads and Rain Forests Co-Exist?” Here’s a Dot Earth Postcard from Erik Hoffner, a writer and photographer associated with Orion Magazine, examining the same question in the context of Russia’s old forests and new highway plans. His missive is sent from northern California, not Russia, because he’s there to help honor Evgenia Chirikova, a Russian forest campaigner who’s the European honoree in this year’s Goldman Environmental Prize awards.

headline: Freedom Comes to Washington
text: President Abraham Lincoln signed the District of Columbia Emancipation Act into law on April 16, 1862, a step heralded by abolitionists across the country. Never before had Congress passed a measure designed to destroy slavery in a place where it was already entrenched. As one newspaper put it: “The actual interest at stake was not extensive — a citadel never occupies a large proportion of the territory it represents — but the principle involved in the question was vital.” The capital’s liberation was, Frederick Douglass wrote, “a priceless and an unspeakable blessing” for those it freed and “the first great step towards that righteousness which exalts a nation.”

headline: BTG Pactual Chief Fined Over Insider Trading
text: LONDON — André Esteves, the chief executive of the Brazilian bank BTG Pactual, was fined 350,000 euros ($457,000) by the Italian financial regulator on Monday for insider trading.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Steven Amato, chief content officer at Omelet, Los Angeles, was named president, a new post, and chief content officer of a new division, Omelet Studio. Omelet also recently formed an agency management committee that is composed of Mr. Amato; Ryan Fey, chief brand officer; and Don Kurz, chairman and chief executive, along with five managing directors: Naj Allana, Mark Anderson, Sarah Cathcart, Sean McNamara and Mike Wallen.

headline: The Tappan Zee’s Future, According to Readers
text: Our call for submissions for how the Tappan Zee Bridge — due to be replaced — might be reimagined as a walkway and/or park drew some thoughtful suggestions, including an “edible bridge,” a “Bridge of Flowers” and a call to demolish the thing.

headline: Rollaways of BMW 7 Series Sedans Prompt Upgrade of Safety Investigation
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said reports of 16 crashes prompted it to intensify an investigation into whether the automatic transmission on almost 122,000 BMW 7 Series sedans could slide into Neutral and roll away when the driver intended the gear selector to be in Park.

headline: Disney to Team With Chinese Company to Make ‘Iron Man 3’
text: “Iron Man” is going to China.

headline: Coty Tries to Rally Support for Avon Bid Amid Skepticism
text: If Avon Products‘ stock price is any indicator, Coty still has some work to do in persuading investors in the cosmetics company to accept its $10 billion unsolicited bid.

headline: U.S. Candidate Is Chosen to Lead the World Bank
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank on Monday named as its next president Jim Yong Kim, a global health expert and the president of Dartmouth College, a widely expected appointment that continues the longstanding tradition of an American leading the Washington-based development institution.

headline: How the Buffett Rule Would Affect Small Businesses
text: On Monday afternoon, the Senate is poised to consider — if only briefly — the so-called Buffett Rule, President Obama’s plan to make sure that millionaires pay at least as much of their income in tax as middle-class Americans. Supporters, however, are not likely to find the 60 votes necessary for the Senate to actually debate the bill.

headline: Missing: 5 Guitars Belonging to Tom Petty Band
text: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers are offering a $7,500 reward for the return of five guitars that were stolen from a studio near Los Angeles where the group was rehearsing for a United States tour, the rock group announced on its Web site. Last Thursday, someone got into the studio in Culver City and made off with two of Mr. Petty’s prized instruments – a 1967 12-string Rickenbacker electric and a 1965 Gibson electric. Also missing were three other rare guitars belonging to the bassist Ron Blair, the rhythm guitarist Scott Thurston and the lead guitarist Mike Campbell.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces an Eclectic Lineup of Juries
text: The jurors who will decide the winners of the competitive categories at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival are your usually unusual bunch of entertainment industry notables, including Academy Award winners, up-and-comers and the guy who manages Justin Bieber.

headline: Media Companies Ask Judge to Open Florida Defendant’s File
text: Lawyers representing more than 20 media companies on Monday asked the Florida judge overseeing the trial of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch organizer who killed the teenager Trayvon Martin, to unseal the court file.

headline: TimesCast | April 16, 2012
text: Afghan forces end an attack by the Taliban | Egyptians face a shifting presidential race | Retraction rates are rising in scientific journals.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Charles McGrath on Dreaming in Caro-ese
text: Charles McGrath, writer at large for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story on the biographer Robert Caro, who just finished the latest volume in a massive biography of Lyndon Johnson that he has been working on for nearly 40 years. McGrath’s most recent articles for the magazine were on Stephen Colbert and the novelist Nicholson Baker.

headline: Ads Urge ‘Book People’ to Help Children Read
text: A new public service campaign seeking to help children read brings together two collections of all-stars: a Who’s Who of literary characters and a lineup of well-known musicians.

headline: J.K. Rowling Starts Her Potter Encyclopedia
text: J.K. Rowling may be putting the finishing touches on her first novel for adults, a dark comedy set for release in September, but she hasn’t forgotten about Harry Potter.

headline: Image of the Day: April 16
text: A blanket factory collapses after a fire in the boiler.

headline: The Myth of Shrinking Government
text: Mitt Romney was overheard yesterday telling a group of big donors that he has a secret plan to eliminate a bunch of federal departments and agencies. Because the plan is so terribly secret, he couldn’t even tell this friendly group what precisely he plans to cut, but he assured them that he will do plenty of big, important cutting and consolidating.

headline: Iraq Election Official’s Arrest Casts Doubt on Prospect for Fair Voting
text: BAGHDAD — In making the optimistic case for the development of democracy here, American officials typically point to the 2010 parliamentary elections, which were judged largely free and fair by international monitors including the United Nations. But with the arrest of the head of Iraq’s election commission, the prospect for fair elections has been thrown into question.

headline: Sex Pistols to Reissue ‘God Save the Queen’
text: The Sex Pistols said they would rerelease “God Save the Queen” in late May for the 35th anniversary of the single’s controversial debut back in 1977, the New Musical Express reported. First released during Queen Elizabeth’s Silver Jubilee, the song created a political firestorm. The lyrics and nihilistic vision of Britain’s future offended many people and the BBC refused to play it: “God save the Queen/ She ain’t no human being / There is no future / In England’s dreaming.” (The Sex Pistols, never ones for understatement, also referred to the British government as “a facist regime.”) Still, the song went to No. 2 on the British singles chart.

headline: The Real Reasons Why You Buy
text: Before we buy something we tell ourselves stories.

headline: Milan Furniture Fair | Colour One for Mini
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Sound and the Fury
text: Q. What are the noises that M.R.I. machines make?

headline: Talk Pizza With Bittman
text: Save the date: Mark Bittman, who argues this week that the best pizza is the kind you make yourself, will host an hourlong chat this Wednesday at 3 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time on The Times’s Facebook page (facebook.com/nytimes), answering reader questions on the ins and outs of making pizza. Among the topics to be discussed: how to achieve the perfect crust in a home oven, tricks for working with dough, unusual toppings to embrace, whether it’s worth investing in a pizza stone and the larger question of what makes for a successful pie. You are welcome to post your pizza-related comments and questions for Mr. Bittman below, but please join in at the appointed hour to participate in the discussion in real time.

headline: Gout and About
text: I’ve been meaning for a while now to write a follow-up to my gout blog post, the robust reaction to which gratified me and confirmed yet again that so very many of us—for health, ethical, environmental or budgetary reasons—must carefully limit and choose what we eat, in ways that are often challenging and sometimes even frustrating. But I lacked the time. And I lacked just the right fresh material for an update.

headline: Raised-Fist Salute Has Varied Meanings
text: Anders Behring Breivik, the anti-Muslim militant who admitted to killing 77 people in a bombing and shooting spree last year, began his first day of trial on Monday with a disturbing, rod-straight salute of the arm, his fist closed tightly.

headline: Tax Day Procrastination Links
text: For nearly two decades, Monsanto and corporate agribusiness have exercised near-dictatorial control over American agriculture. But public opinion is turning against Monsanto, and in November, a statewide citizens’ ballot initiative will give Californians the opportunity to vote for GMO labeling (a similar measure was introduced in Vermont, but is currently stalled by cowardly legislators). This is going to be huge. By the way, a poll suggests that 60 percent of California voters would support a soda tax. Related: now we finally know what’s been missing from our family dinners: Sierra Mist.

headline: Fence Is Behind an Explosion of Life in a Wild Corner of Hawaii
text: KAENA POINT, Hawaii — Before Polynesian settlers arrived here hundreds of years ago in their outrigger canoes, Hawaii had more than 120 species of birds — and no mammals to eat them. Land birds flourished in the absence of land predators, and seabirds flew in from all over the world to nest undisturbed on the ground.

headline: Protecting Kaena Point
text: Visitors can enter the 60-acre nature reserve through three gates.

headline: Homes With Star Quality Are Now Hiring an Agent
text: To step inside Merele Williams-Adkins’s deliciously restored Clinton Hill brownstone is to enter a world of 15-foot ceilings, white marble mantels and fabulous art. You feel as though you have sauntered into pages of an elegant furniture catalog, or onto the set of a quirky independent film. And in a sense, you have.

headline: Alfredsson Will Not Return for Game 3
text: 7:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: Koran Giveaway in Germany Has Some Officials Worried
text: BERLIN — A drive by a fundamentalist Muslim group to give a copy of the Koran to every German, Swiss and Austrian household has tapped into the widespread anti-Islamic feeling in Germany and created an uproar among politicians and security officials concerned that the group handing out the holy books is using the campaign as a cover to recruit radicals.

headline: In Mali, Art as Real as Life Itself
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Political tumult in the last few weeks — a military coup, a Tuareg and Islamist takeover in the north — has all but eliminated tourism in this West African nation, which has long been a magnet for Western travelers in search of firsthand encounters with living art traditions.

headline: Where Do Our Global Children Belong?
text: What country parents best has become the American neurotic obsession de jour, with the French scoring high points for both the training and the feeding of children, as our colleagues over at the Motherlode blog have been chronicling.

headline: Argentina to Seize Control of Oil Company
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, announced on Monday that the government would seize a majority stake in YPF, the nation’s largest oil company.

headline: Kreider Makes Rangers Debut
text: 7:47 p.m. | Updated

headline: After Mistakes, Scientists Try to Explain Themselves
text: Naoki Mori, the Japanese cancer researcher who has had 30 papers retracted by scientific journals, was asked to give his side of the story. In an e-mail, he acknowledged that his colleagues “were lax in certain regards in the preparation of papers,” but he denied having committed a grave offense.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: 1:48 p.m. | Updated Status Update: Remember the Fashion NYC2020 survey Mayor Bloomberg announced about two years ago? He and other officials set out to analyze New York City’s fashion industry and, they hoped, identify strategies to better position the city as a global fashion hub. The forecast? Nothing to cheer about, WWD reports. (Read the full report.)

headline: For Two Economists, the Buffett Rule Is Just a Start
text: WASHINGTON — High earners who are worried that this year’s Tax Day will be the last one before their rates rise have more than just the White House and Washington to blame. They can also look to two academically revered, if publicly obscure, left-leaning French economists whose work is the subtext for the battle over tax fairness.

headline: Israeli Anger at Foreign ‘Provocateurs’ Boils Over
text: Updated | 10:11 p.m. Viral video of a senior Israeli Army officer striking a Danish man in the face with a rifle on Saturday in the West Bank, during a mass bicycle ride challenging restrictions on the use of certain roads by Palestinians, has drawn attention to an increasingly acrimonious struggle between the government of Israel and European rights activists who travel to the region.

headline: Does Exercise Make You Overeat?
text: Some people respond to exercise by eating more. Others eat less. For many years, scientists thought that changes in hormones, spurred by exercise, dictated whether someone’s appetite would increase or drop after working out. But now new neuroscience is pointing to another likely cause. Exercise may change your desire to eat, two recent studies show, by altering how certain parts of your brain respond to the sight of food.

headline: Want Your College Student to Party Less? Pay Less
text: It may be possible to provide too much support to your college-age children — too much financial support, at least.

headline: A Sharp Rise in Retractions Prompts Calls for Reform
text: In the fall of 2010, Dr. Ferric C. Fang made an unsettling discovery. Dr. Fang, who is editor in chief of the journal Infection and Immunity, found that one of his authors had doctored several papers.

headline: With Test Week Here, Parents Consider the Option of Opting Out
text: While thousands of New York public school students will sit for mandated standardized tests this week, only a handful will be deliberately kept from picking up their No. 2 pencils to fill in the test sheet bubbles. That doesn't mean more parents aren't thinking about keeping their children home.

headline: After 73 Years of Shoes, a Store Is Closing Its Doors
text: Tom Austin Shoes, a 73-year-old mainstay of the Serious Grown-Up Menswear district in the West and East 40s (J. Press, Paul Stuart, Brooks Brothers and others) will be closing at the end of May. It is to reopen later this summer as an Allen Edmonds store, carrying only that manufacturer’s shoes, belts, apparel and accessories.

headline: ‘Matilda’ Wins Record-Setting Seven Olivier Awards
text: “Matilda the Musical,” an adaptation of the Roald Dahl novel headed to Broadway next season, won seven Olivier Awards, the London equivalent of the Tonys, on Sunday night.

headline: Central Bank Not Expected to Try to Ease Europe’s Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — As the euro zone crisis shows signs of heating up again, political leaders are once more looking to the European Central Bank for help.

headline: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Headed Up Again
text: After dropping for two years during the recession, emissions of the gases blamed for global warming rose in 2010 as the economy heated up, the Environmental Protection Agency reports.

headline: New Home Jersey: Hoops ‘R’ U.S.
text: If one color has been missing from recent iterations of the jersey worn by United States national team players — men and women — it is most certainly red.

headline: Italian Government Takes Steps to Oust Maxxi Museum Board
text: ROME — Less than two years after the opening of Maxxi, Italy’s national museum of contemporary art, the Italian Culture Ministry last Friday initiated procedures to replace the board of directors of the foundation that manages the museum with a government-appointed administrator. The decision was taken, according a terse statement issued by the ministry, after the board failed to approve the 2012 budget, which is expected to register a “significant” deficit.

headline: Beetles’ Birth Explosion Puts Trees Under Stress
text: Mountain pine beetles attack and kill weak pine trees, boring into bark to lay their eggs. They attack the trees in hordes, and their larvae feed off fungi in the trees.

headline: Table Talk | Donna in Williamsburg
text: Leif Huckman was midslumber when he first found inspiration: “I had a dream where I walked to a bar whose door sign read ‘Donna.’ I let it roll around in my head for a few days, and it felt right. It stuck.” The dream, coupled with his longing to have a nearby spot that served both dependable cocktails and late-night snacks culminated in Huckman’s new bar Donna, which opens tonight in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: 2 Pulitzers for Times; Huffington Post and Politico Win
text: The New York Times won two Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its reporting on Africa and for an investigative series on loopholes that allow the wealthiest Americans and corporations to avoid paying taxes. In a sign of the changing media landscape, two primarily online news outlets, The Huffington Post and Politico, won their first Pulitzer Prizes.

headline: On Love and Autism: Our Favorite Student Comments
text: Love on the Spectrum: In the video above, Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, two college students living in Greenfield, Mass., discuss how autism affects their lives and relationship.

headline: 2012 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music
text: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. The complete list of winners in Letters, Drama and Music is below.

headline: 2012 Journalism Pulitzer Winners
text: PUBLIC SERVICE

headline: They Kill the Tyrant but Can’t Seem to Bury Him
text: Greek tragedy, magic realism and pulpy horror movie conventions collide in José Rivera’s “Massacre (Sing to Your Children),” an assaultive allegorical consideration of the use of violence as a response to life under a repressive regime, and of our own role in perpetuating that tyranny.

headline: Real Words or Gibberish? Just Ask a Baboon
text: While baboons can’t read, they can tell the difference between real English words and nonsensical ones, a new study reports.

headline: Drilling Down: Small Businesses and Location-Based Marketing
text: In this week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we quoted from a blog post in which Brian Honigman, a digital marketing manager for Marc Ecko Enterprises, offers advice on using location-based networks. We went back to Mr. Honigman to dig deeper into how small businesses can use these services. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: Carlyle Executives’ I.P.O. Pitch, in Their Own Words
text: Why invest in the Carlyle Group‘s stock as the private equity giant’s initial public offering nears? Let the firm’s top executives explain.

headline: A Return to Celery City
text: I wrote about celery once before long ago; I don’t know why, since as I mentioned in my piece Sunday in The Times Magazine, I had detested it. But if you’re a food writer for long enough, you get to write about almost everything.

headline: Ex-Goldman Director Faces New Insider Trading Claim
text: Rajat K. Gupta, the former director of Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble who is accused of leaking secret corporate information to the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam, faces a new insider-trading claim.

headline: Nap Time, Brought to You by Daimler
text: According to Daimler, the day is coming when your Mercedes-Benz will no longer sit idly by as your driving fitness erodes.

headline: Following the Crowd Isn’t Just for Teenagers
text: Many a parent may say that teenagers succumb to peer pressure. A new study reports that toddlers and chimpanzees do too — but orangutans, on the other hand, don’t seem to follow the crowd.

headline: Community College Serves as a Path to Four-Year Institutions
text: This year’s graduating class at the Community College of Philadelphia includes many students who will soon enter four-year colleges, including the University of Pennsylvania and Bryn Mawr, Michael Winerip writes this week.

headline: Exxon and Russia’s Oil Company in Deal for Joint Projects
text: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil and the Russian state oil company Rosneft signed a strategic agreement on Monday that will open American domestic oil and gas fields to Russian investment for the first time.

headline: Touched by Bloodshed, Working Now to Spare Others
text: Last month, Tameeka Ford Norville was sitting in her lilac-colored office at the Ingersoll Community Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where she runs an after-school program, when the phone rang. Shots had been fired in the housing projects next door, a resident told her. Ms. Ford Norville locked the center’s doors and told her staff to make sure the children were accounted for.

headline: On Campus, Opening Up Conversations About Sex
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — For a table set up by a campus student group, this one held some unusual items: a gynecologist’s speculum, diaphragms, condoms (his and hers) and several packets of lubricant. Nearby, two students batted an inflated condom back and forth like a balloon.

headline: The Get | Eliane Fattal for S.J. Phillips ‘Think of Me’ Ring
text: Nestled in London’s West End on New Bond Street stands the 143-year-old jewelry house S.J. Phillips. Little has changed for the British purveyor of rare and exceptional pieces — some dating back to the 1600s — and that’s part of its charm. But every now and then a client comes along who is as distinctive as the gems in the vitrines.

headline: Israeli Military Officer Suspended for Striking Activist With Rifle
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military announced the suspension on Monday of a senior officer caught on videotape striking a Danish pro-Palestinian activist in the face with an M-16 rifle during a standoff between soldiers and participants in a bike tour organized to draw attention to the living conditions of Palestinian villagers in the West Bank.

headline: Fire Lieutenant Dies Fighting Brooklyn Warehouse Blaze
text: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | A veteran New York City fire lieutenant died on Monday after battling a three-alarm blaze at a warehouse in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: Barclays Unites Corporate Finance and Deal Teams
text: Barclays announced on Monday that it has combined its corporate coverage and deal-making teams into a new “corporate finance mergers and acquisitions group,” according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook. The newly reorganized unit will be led by Tom King, Paul Parker and Ros Stephenson. “One specific objective here is to secure more lead left financings and more transformational and ‘one-stop’ M.&A. deals,” Hugh E. McGee III, Barclays’ global head of investment banking, wrote in the memo.

headline: Early Investors See Promise in Palestinian Start-Ups
text: DUBAI — When Yadin Kaufmann helped start Veritas Venture Partners in 1990, Israel’s technology industry barely existed. Only a handful of companies had gone public on American exchanges and financing was tough to come by.

headline: The Science of Obituaries: Dead Pools, Obits in the Can and More
text: In Sunday’s column, I wrote about the obituaries in The New York Times. I didn’t have space to bring a number of elements in so I would like to supplement the column with some additional stuff relating to obits, which I find to be one of the most interesting content elements in The Times.

headline: Teenage Birth Rates Continue to Drop
text: Fewer teenagers gave birth in 2010 than in any other year since 1946, government researchers announced last week, and there is good evidence that today’s teenagers are initiating sex later and using birth control more consistently than previous generations did.

headline: As a Defendant Bullies and Boasts, Questions Arise on a Court’s Limits
text: THE HAGUE — In the nine years since his arrival in The Hague, Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian politician, has often harangued judges and has taken pride in provoking and trying to outwit prosecutors. At a recent hearing in his war-crimes trial, he had another bit of theater up his sleeve.

headline: Tides and the Titanic (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: TimesCast | Attacks End In Afghanistan
text: April 16, 2012 — Afghan forces ended coordinated attacks by the Taliban on Monday. Thirty-eight attackers were killed but civilian casualties were low.

headline: In Sickness and Health (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Doctors on Pets (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: TimesCast | Egypt's Presidential Race
text: April 16, 2012 — Egypt’s presidential elections will take place next month, but the field has already changed significantly for voters.

headline: Making Baby’s Shots Less Tearful
text: Infant vaccinations can be a distressing experience for both parent and child. But new research suggests that parents can lessen the sting of an injection by soothing their babies with a quick series of comforting measures, including a popular technique called swaddling.

headline: Canadian D.J. to Kick Off a Summer of Canadian Art at Mass MoCA
text: In the pop music world, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams has built substantial indie credibility through its affiliation with Wilco and its sponsorship of the Solid Sound Festival. Now the museum is adding to that reputation by inviting Brendan Canning, a founder of the Canadian musical collective Broken Social Scene, to be the D.J. at a Memorial Day weekend dance party that is part of the opening of an exhibition of Canadian art that will continue through next spring.

headline: Now Showing | Backstage at the Vera Wang Bridal Show
text: On Sunday afternoon Vera Wang presented her spring 2013 bridal collection, which, due to its lack of white dresses, didn’t feel very bridal at all. Looking to the Far East for inspiration, Wang chose red, a color that is believed to be protective and also to symbolize love, to star in the show. Cinnabar, cherry and scarlet were the hues. Out of the 15 looks presented, 10 were strapless. One standout, a crimson mermaid gown with a hand-draped bodice and inverted flange skirt with embroidered crystal wheat detailing, had everyone in awe. Watch the dresses come to life here in a behind-the-scenes video directed by Don Ashby exclusively for T.

headline: Reality TV, No Channel Changing Allowed
text: If reality television didn’t exist, Caden Manson/Big Art Group would have had to invent it. The caterwauling banalities and strenuous camp on more or less constant display in the company’s “Broke House,” at the Abrons Arts Center, bring to mind a grad student bingeing on the Bravo channel after taking a bit too much allergy medication.

headline: Absorbing Life’s Lessons, Happy or Sad
text: The only generic thing about Barbara Cook’s new show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency is its unnecessary title, “Let’s Fall in Love”: unnecessary because everyone familiar with Ms. Cook’s voice is already in love with her. Ms. Cook, now 84, still has the goods. By that I mean a darkened soprano that is beautiful by any measure and the gift for conveying a profound empathy.

headline: Really? Car Accidents More Frequent on Tax Day
text: THE FACTS

headline: Too Many Pills for Aging Patients
text: My 92-year-old aunt was a walking pharmacy, and a month ago it nearly killed her. The episode also cost the American medical system several hundred thousand dollars.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from New York, Norway, Afghanistan and North Korea.

headline: Anders Breivik
text: The Anders Breivik trial started in Oslo on Monday. Mr. Breivik, the self-described commander of the Norwegian Resistance Movement, has admitted to killing 77 people in a rampage last July, but according to the story in today’s Times has “denied criminal responsibility on the grounds that he was protecting Norway from Islamic immigration.”

headline: Perfecting the Art of Expression in Movements Subtle and Bold
text: A head shuttling over still shoulders, side to side, pupils swiveling along seductively. That’s a cartoon representation of Indian dance, but it’s nevertheless an essential ingredient of the Bharata Natyam tradition. When Priyadarsini Govind, a Bharata Natyam virtuoso from Chennai, in South India, performs the gesture, her head moves decisively but minimally, the better to set off an extraordinary pair of eyes.

headline: Behind the Scenes at Vera Wang Bridal
text: A close look at Vera Wang’s spring 2013 bridal collection.

headline: Wines and Beers, by the Slice
text: I KNOW what you are thinking: What could possibly be said that’s new about wine and pizza? There’s nothing to it. Just pick some fresh Italian red wine, not too expensive, like Barbera d’Alba or Dolcetto di Dogliani, and be done with it.

headline: Deputy Chancellor Rodriguez Retires
text: Laura Rodriguez, the deputy chancellor for students with disabilities and English language learners, stepped down on Monday. In a news release, the Department of Education announced that Ms. Rodriguez will be replaced by Corinne Rello-Anselmi as of July 1.

headline: On a Sunday Shift, Caught in the Taliban’s Sights
text: Nawroz was just a simple cook, working with the 10 masons and carpenters in a partly-finished six-floor building near the Parliament complex in Kabul.

headline: The Caucus Click: Securing the Scene for Romney
text: Secret Service agents completing a security sweep before a Romney campaign event Monday at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

headline: Seeing Met’s ‘Ring’ in a Desert Spectacle
text: LAS VEGAS — Ten times a week, 48 weeks a year, the Cirque du Soleil spectacle “Ka” plays inside the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino here. The show, created and directed by Robert Lepage, occupies the custom-built Ka Theater, which has a capacity just under 2,000. Since “Ka” opened, on Feb. 3, 2005, more than 5.5 million people have arrived amid hissing flames and tribal drums to watch it.

headline: Early Works in Church Setting, With a Japanese Twist
text: The Japanese early-music ensemble Anthonello had an unusual programming notion for its New York debut, presented as part of the Early Music Foundation’s series at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Saturday evening. The concert, “Music as the Shogun May Have Heard — 1591,” promised to look at the brief period in the 16th century when Christian missionaries established a foothold in Japan, bringing with them the first Western music heard there.

headline: Attention Problems May Be Sleep-Related
text: Diagnoses of attention hyperactivity disorder among children have increased dramatically in recent years, rising 22 percent from 2003 to 2007, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But many experts believe that this may not be the epidemic it appears to be.

headline: Mark Rylance Play, Written With a Favorite Poet, Is Coming to Minneapolis Theater
text: Mark Rylance has cribbed from the work of Louis Jenkins long enough. Having twice recited compositions by Mr. Jenkins, the mischievous poet of Duluth, Minn., in lieu of more traditional acceptance speeches at the Tony Awards, Mr. Rylance will give him proper credit on a new play they have written together that will make its debut at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis next year.

headline: Future, SWV and Kat Edmonson Release New Albums
text: FUTURE

headline: Aides Play Down Romney’s Talk on Taxes for Wealthy
text: Senior advisers to Mitt Romney said Monday that Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, was merely tossing around ideas, not making policy announcements, when his chat with donors about some significant changes to the tax code was overheard by reporters at a fund-raiser this weekend.

headline: Coachella, Part 1: Few Surprises
text: INDIO, Calif. — Well, in the end it’s a business. But so it is at the beginning, and in the middle.

headline: Endless Screenings Don’t Bring Everlasting Health
text: This month, nine major medical specialty groups published a list of 45 tests and procedures that often have no clear benefit for patients and can cause harm — CT scans for simple headaches, for example, and X-rays for routine lower back pain. You don’t often hear calls from doctors for fewer tests and procedures.

headline: Defending Muslim Law From Those Invoking It
text: There are good ways and bad ways to die. Then there was the death afforded, around A.D. 750, to a Persian political adviser named Ibn al-Muqaffa. His limbs were dispatched from his body, and he was forced to watch as they were roasted slowly in an oven.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: E-Book Covers and Digital Resurrection
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Taking Risks in Theater
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pizza and Calzone Recipes
text: Have a ball of pizza dough in front of you? Here’s what to do with it.

headline: Reasons for Cohabiting
text: To the Editor:

headline: $800 Million Target for Romney Campaign and Republican Committee
text: 9:28 p.m. | Updated  A new joint fund-raising initiative between Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee will aim to raise $800 million by November, part of what Mr. Romney’s campaign estimates will be a total of $1 billion spent to defeat President Obama and elect Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor.

headline: Not Mere ‘Companions’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn’s Northside Festival Unveils Lineup
text: The rapper GZA, one of the founders of the Wu-Tang Clan, will perform all the songs from his landmark 1995 album “Liquid Swords” as part of this year’s Northside Festival in Brooklyn, organizers announced Monday. He will be backed up by Grupo Fantasma, a Latin funk outfit from Texas.

headline: Using Opioids to Treat Pain
text: To the Editor:

headline: Graham Company Plans Move to Cunningham Studios
text: The place probably has good dance vibes.

headline: The Challenge of Going Vegan
text: From Bill Clinton to Ellen DeGeneres, celebrities are singing the benefits of a vegan diet. Books that advocate plant-based eating are best sellers. But is eliminating meat and dairy as simple as it sounds?

headline: Pulitzer Prizes: The Effects of War at Home
text: Craig F. Walker of The Denver Post was awarded his second Pulitzer Prize on Monday afternoon for “Welcome Home: The Story of Scott Ostrom,” which won in the feature category. And Massoud Hossaini of Agence France-Presse won the 2012 prize for breaking news photography for his coverage of a bloody attack in Afghanistan — his third major award for the image.

headline: Nationals Beginning to See Their Moves Pay Off
text: WASHINGTON — Except for a few seasons, including several dating to Calvin Coolidge’s presidency, baseball has been unkind to Washington. Whether as the Senators, who deserted the city twice, or the Nationals, Washington’s teams have been a fixture at the bottom of the standings. They made it to Broadway in the hit play “Damn Yankees,” but in the world of baseball, they have been a continual flop.

headline: Pulitzer Fiction Snub Has Book Publishers Fuming
text: Just when the publishing industry thought things couldn’t get any worse.

headline: Friendship, Competition, Pathogens: Gauging an Outbreak at the Olympics
text: In anticipation of the Summer Olympics in London in July, The Lancet Infectious Diseases, a British medical journal, has been publishing a series exploring the possibility that the Games could trigger a global outbreak of disease.

headline: Are Young Social Activists Too Idealistic?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Patterns: Doctor’s Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate
text: Urologists with a financial interest in a laboratory send more prostate biopsies for analysis and have a lower rate of cancer detection than those who use independent labs, according to a new study.

headline: A Rise in Retractions
text: April 16, 2012 - Science writer Carl Zimmer interviewed Dr. Arturo Casadevall about the recent rise in retractions in scientific journals.

headline: Risks: More Signs of Rest’s Regulatory Powers
text: Researchers have found further experimental evidence that inadequate sleep can increase the risk of obesity and diabetes. A five-week study showed that sleep disruption decreases insulin secretion, increases blood glucose levels and slows metabolism enough to lead to significant weight gain.

headline: G.S.A. Officials Get a Grilling Over a Trip to Las Vegas
text: WASHINGTON — It is a remarkable moment when Congressional Democrats and Republicans turn their scorn from each other and join forces to focus it on someone else.

headline: Hazards: Poor Health in Pregnancy Linked to Delays
text: A mother’s diabetes, hypertension or obesity during pregnancy may increase her child’s risk of autism and developmental problems.

headline: Knicks Are Back Where They Started
text: The season was new, hope was abundant and the Garden was four shades of jolly after the Knicks defeated the Boston Celtics on Christmas Day. All things seemed possible.

headline: The Buffett Rule: Right Goal, Wrong Tool
text: Syracuse

headline: In Senate, Republicans Block Debate on ‘Buffett Rule’
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday blocked a move to open debate on the so-called Buffett Rule, ensuring that a measure pressed for months by President Obama and Senate Democrats to ensure that the superrich pay a tax rate of at least 30 percent will not come to a decisive vote.

headline: The Well transformation; cutting corners in science; and sex at Harvard.
text: The Well transformation; cutting corners in science; and sex at Harvard.

headline: Is Support for Gay Rights Still Controversial?
text: The Republican state senators who voted for same-sex marriage have not paid a price. In fact, it may be a net gain for them.

headline: As the Jets Regroup, Holmes Has No Regrets
text: The Jets reconvened Monday for the first time since the day after their season ended in dysfunction and despair, a teachable moment that presented an opportunity for introspection and self-improvement.

headline: Lewis Nordan, Writer Who Spun Lyrical Tales, Dies at 72
text: Lewis Nordan, a Mississippi-born writer whose fiction conjures a dreamlike world that straddles the whisker-thin margin between a legend and a lie, but whose best-known novel was based on a historical murder of national import, died on Friday in Cleveland. He was 72.

headline: With Jeter Hot, and Other Yankees Not, It May Be Too Hard to Rest Him
text: With a three-run homer and a double in Sunday night’s victory over the Los Angeles Angels, Derek Jeter continued his terrific start to the season. He had 15 hits, including a team-high six extra-base hits, and through nine games, he was off to the third-best start in his career.

headline: How Well, and How Poorly, We Harvest Ocean Life
text: To hear some people tell it, the increasingly energetic and sophisticated fishing industry has left the world’s oceans a shambles, with species of cod, sharks, tuna and other fish hunted almost to extinction and vast stretches of the ocean floor wrecked by bottom-scraping trawlers.

headline: Call to Restore Income Tax on Suburbanites
text: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, will call on Tuesday for restoring New York City’s long-abandoned suburban commuter tax to help stabilize the finances of the region’s creaky mass transit network.

headline: Iran: Ready to Resolve Dispute, and Eager to Ease Sanctions
text: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Salehi said Monday that Iran was prepared to resolve the nuclear dispute with world powers at their next meeting, in Baghdad on May 23, if the West showed some good will by easing the sanctions imposed on Iran. Mr. Salehi, above, also hinted that Iran might be willing to change its uranium enrichment policy, which is at the heart of foreign suspicions that the Iranians are secretly developing the capacity to make nuclear weapons. The first talks in 15 months on the dispute adjourned Saturday with both sides calling them constructive. Mr. Salehi told the Iranian Student News Agency that the talks were “a turning point in the Iran-West dialogue.” Still, neither the United States nor the European Union has indicated any intention to ease the sanctions, which their proponents call necessary to press Iran to negotiate in good faith. On Monday, United Against Nuclear Iran, a pro-sanctions group based in New York, said that Porsche AG, the German auto company, would end its business in Iran, making it the second carmaker to do so this month.

headline: Jones and Mets Facing Off for a Final Season
text: ATLANTA — The longtime Braves third baseman Chipper Jones’s announcement that he would retire at the end of the year has turned this season into a farewell tour of sorts.

headline: Economy or Personality?
text: With the focus now fully on the campaign between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, commentary about the issues, the voting blocs and the strategies of the two campaigns dominates political discourse. But having polled on the last 10 presidential elections, I’m struck by a meta-question about each candidate’s viability that may trump all else. Obama and Romney both carry so much political baggage that one or the other will have to defy modern political history to win in November.

headline: Echoes of the End of the Raj
text: London

headline: Greece: Ex-Official Is Detained
text: Akis Tsochatzopoulos, a former defense minister, was detained Monday after testifying in connection with a money-laundering racket he is accused of using to conceal under-the-table payments from military-procurement deals. With elections on May 6, the authorities are eager to show foreign creditors that action is being taken to stamp out the corruption that contributed to Greece’s dysfunctional state. Mr. Tsochatzopoulos has denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Justices Weigh Overtime Exemption for Drug Firm Representatives
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court considered on Monday whether representatives of pharmaceutical companies who visit doctors’ offices to promote their companies’ products are entitled to overtime. The answer turns on whether those visits are sales calls or something else.

headline: Mali: Ancient Books Stolen
text: The United Nations expressed alarm on Monday over the safety of ancient books and documents in the storied city of Timbuktu as reports said that rebels had pillaged and looted the Ahmad Baba Institute of Higher Islamic Studies and Research, as well as other institutions. Many of the archives document Timbuktu’s golden era between the 12th and 15th centuries. Irina Bokova, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, appealed to Mali’s neighbors and art collectors to refrain from trying to sell the stolen items and urged warring factions in Mali to respect Timbuktu’s rich history as a “cultural crossroads and center of learning.”

headline: South Sudan: Blasts at U.N. Site
text: The United Nations said Monday that one of its peacekeeping compounds in South Sudan sustained “material damage” over the weekend when it was hit with five bombs. No United Nations employees were hurt, but two people on the base were killed, initial reports said. Susan E. Rice, the American ambassador to the United Nations, condemned the attack, which is under investigation, and she called the escalating violence between South Sudan and Sudan “a threat to regional as well as international peace and security.”

headline: Embarrassed by Bad Laws
text: A year ago, few people outside the world of state legislatures had heard of the American Legislative Exchange Council, a four-decade-old organization run by right-wing activists and financed by business leaders. The group writes prototypes of state laws to promote corporate and conservative interests and spreads them from one state capital to another.

headline: In a Changing Market, Low Prices vs. More Comfort
text: IN the past, when domestic airlines talked about providing more comfortable service for passengers in coach, the conventional wisdom always cleared its throat and pointed out that this had not worked. No, the conventional wisdom insisted, passengers are interested only in getting the cheapest fare.

headline: Disabilities Act Prompts Flood of Suits Some Cite as Unfair
text: A small cadre of lawyers, some from out of state, are using New York City’s age and architectural quirkiness as the foundation for a flood of lawsuits citing violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline: Talking With Iran
text: Iran’s agreement over the weekend to hold a new round of nuclear talks next month with the United States and five other powers is a constructive development. On Monday, Iran’s foreign minister, Ali Akbar Salehi, said Tehran is ready to resolve its nuclear disputes “quickly and easily” and suggested flexibility on uranium enrichment.

headline: When Mom Travels for Work
text: Amy Kossoff Smith, the founder of a parenting Web site, has a ritual when she has to go on the road. She leaves a printed itinerary of all the carpools, sports practices and games, baby-sitter hours and anything else her husband might need.

headline: Witness Details Plot to Attack Subways
text: At Al Qaeda’s terrorist camp in the mountains of Pakistan, three former high school classmates from Queens encountered heavily armed Islamic militants from all over the world.

headline: Romney’s Favorability Is Weakest on Record, Polling Shows
text: Mitt Romney is facing a severe crisis of popularity.

headline: Mothers Will Get the Glory in P.&G.’s Campaign
text: THERE are few things that seem more patriotic than mothers and the Olympics. On Tuesday, Procter & Gamble, the world’s largest advertiser, will announce its new campaign — its biggest ever — called “Thank You, Mom,” focusing on thanking mothers of Olympians and would-be Olympians around the world.

headline: Maersk Mc-Kinney Moeller, Longtime Shipping Magnate, Dies at 98
text: Maersk Mc-Kinney Moeller, an immensely rich and powerful Danish businessman who transformed his family’s shipping company into the world’s largest, died on Monday in Copenhagen. He was 98.

headline: Fists Are Up, and So Are the Penalties
text: The signature image of the opening games of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs has not been a dramatic overtime goal or an acrobatic save.

headline: Make-or-Break Verbs
text: This is the third in a series of writing lessons by the author.

headline: In Schools Cut by the City Ax, Students Bleed
text: New York City is filled with schools marked twice over for death.

headline: Ex-Teacher at Bronx Private School Accused of Sexual Misconduct
text: A former math teacher at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx was arrested Monday on charges of engaging in sexual conduct with a teenage student.

headline: An Unexpected Memento While Walking at O’Hare, And Other Misadventures
text: I REMEMBER my first business trip.

headline: Alabama Digs a Deeper Hole
text: A new legislative session has given Alabama lawmakers an opportunity to repeal the cruel, destructive and embarrassing immigration law they passed last year — the worst in the nation. It looks as if they’re blowing it.

headline: Homelessness Among Female Veterans
text: The Veterans Affairs Department is in the middle of an ambitious five-year plan to end homelessness among veterans by 2015. It should make sure that this effort protects the vulnerable population of women, whose risks and needs can be far different from those of men.

headline: Stock Split for Google That Cements Control at the Top
text: “It’s stupid,” Larry Page, Google’s co-founder and chief executive, exclaimed about the prospect of splitting the company’s shares. “If you own 10 shares at $40 or one share at $400, it’s the same thing! You just need to know how to divide.”

headline: How Does Press Irk Cuomo? Document Offers Clues
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is known to be sensitive to news coverage of his administration, and his aides are often quick to chastise reporters who write things they find objectionable.

headline: The White House Argument
text: I’ve been critical of President Obama’s budgets. I’ve argued that while I like the way Obama preserves spending on things like scientific research and programs for the vulnerable, he doesn’t do enough to avoid a debt crisis.

headline: Son’s Parties and Privilege Aggravate Fall of Elite Chinese Family
text: BEIJING — As the grandson of revolutionary giants, Bo Guagua enjoyed the prestige and privilege that accompanies membership in China’s “red aristocracy.”

headline: Santorum to His Supporters: ‘Stay Tuned’
text: Rick Santorum said Monday night that he would be “active” in the presidential campaign, but he did not endorse Mitt Romney or encourage voters in states like Pennsylvania to vote for Mr. Romney in their coming primaries.

headline: After Refining Image, New Scandal for Secret Service
text: WASHINGTON — For an agency that has long been known as a “good ol’ boys” club, the prostitution scandal involving 11 members of the Secret Service has dredged up an image that the agency appeared to have moved beyond.

headline: Licensing Push After 2 Deaths From Elevators
text: Elevator technicians would have to be licensed to work in New York City under legislation proposed at a public hearing on Monday and written in response to two elevator deaths in Manhattan in the last four months.

headline: City Settles Lawsuit That Claimed Bias and Retaliation
text: New York City has agreed to pay $750,000 to a black official of the city’s Human Resources Administration who had claimed in a lawsuit that the agency’s commissioner and others had retaliated against her because she had complained about contracting practices.

headline: Turning the Tables on Russia
text: Who knew that what corrupt Russian officials care about, more than just about anything, is getting their assets — and themselves — out of their own country? They own homes in St. Tropez, fly to Miami for vacation and set up bank accounts in Switzerland. They understand the importance of stashing their money someplace where the rule of law matters, which is most certainly not Russia. Besides, getting out of Russia is one of the pleasures of being a corrupt Russian official.

headline: Last Resort, So Checkout Is a Problem
text: Peering through her silver lorgnette, the martini-packing woman with the big jewelry is woozy with disorientation. “There’s certainly nothing familiar about this terrain,” says the woman, Babe, an aging heiress played by Shirley Knight in the murky stew of exotica called “In Masks Outrageous and Austere,” which opened on Monday night at the Culture Project.

headline: Look Over There

Not that signs with arrows on them are necessarily nostalgic, but I admit to having owned an “I’M WITH STUPID” T-shirt back in the day, and having my friends jockeying not to be standing on the pointing arrow side of me. Ah, adolescence.

headline: ... And Love Handles for All

headline: Afghan Assaults Signal Evolution of a Militant Foe

headline: Notes on Poll-Watching, as Shift Toward General Election Season Begins
text: In a couple of weeks, we’ll be starting our FiveThirtyEight forecasts for the general election. But there’s still a fair amount of work to get those ready, and we seem to be seeing an increasing number of head-to-head polls pairing President Obama against Mitt Romney in the meantime. Thus, as we transition into general election season, I wanted to articulate a few quick reminders about the philosophy I take toward looking at these polls and other important pieces of general-election related data.

The thump, thump, thump of basketballs bouncing on the wood floor echoed through the vast emptiness of the Jackson Community College gym.

headline: N.F.L. and Union Meet on Bounties

headline: New York’s Poverty Rate Rises, Study Finds
text: The number of New Yorkers classified as poor in 2010 increased by nearly 100,000 from the year before, raising the poverty rate by 1.3 percentage points to 21 percent — the highest level and the largest year-to-year increase since the city adopted a more detailed definition of poverty in 2005.

headline: Antipoverty Tax Program Offers Relief, Though Often Temporary
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Karen Spain spent several long months before receiving her tax refund this year in a state of suspended panic. The rent was three months late. Her car’s brakes were shot. And she could no longer afford to pay her electricity bill.

headline: Prosecutor Who Ran Ethics Unit Leaves Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Monday announced the departure of a high-profile prosecutor who ran its ethics unit during the botched case against Senator Ted Stevens and has since played a prominent role in the Obama administration’s efforts to prosecute officials for leaking information to the press.

headline: Panetta Reassessing His Travel Options
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Monday that he was looking for less expensive alternatives to his travel most weekends from Washington to his walnut farm in Carmel Valley, Calif., which costs taxpayers close to $32,000 per trip. Mr. Panetta is required to travel on military aircraft so he can remain in constant and secure contact with the White House and national security officials. The Associated Press has calculated that his 27 round-trips to California since he took office in July have cost the government as much as $860,000. So far he has reimbursed taxpayers $17,000, or $630 per trip, based on a government formula. Mr. Panetta said at a news conference that he regretted the cost and was studying alternatives that might save money and also enable him to fulfill his responsibilities “not only to my job, but my family.” He gave no hint about the alternatives. The Pentagon press secretary, George Little, said that “no one wants the secretary of defense making decisions on classified military operations from the middle seat on a crowded commercial jet.”

headline: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 3

headline: Champions League Preview: Would a Barcelona-Madrid Final in May Be Trouble for Spain in June?
text: Cristiano Ronaldo set a Spanish league record on Saturday by scoring his 41st goal of the season in Real Madrid’s win over Sporting Gijon, but Spain’s newspapers didn’t even get a chance to report the unprecedented feat before Barcelona’s Lionel Messi matched it with two against Levante that day.

headline: Thinking About a Round-Trip Ticket From Myanmar

headline: April 17, 1961 | The Bay of Pigs Invasion Against Castro
text: On April 17, 1961, about 1,500 C.I.A.-trained Cuban exiles began the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in what would become a failed attempt to overthrow the government of Fidel Castro, the Marxist revolutionary who had seized power in January 1959.

headline: On Witness Stand, Norwegian Says He Would Kill Again
text: OSLO — Demanding his acquittal, a self-styled anti-Islamic militant on trial for killing 77 people in Norway’s worst peacetime atrocity took the stand for the first time on Tuesday, describing the deaths as “the most spectacular sophisticated political act in Europe since the Second World War” and saying he would do it again.

headline: Meet Nancy Powell, the United States’ New Ambassador to India
text: Nancy Powell, the first female American ambassador– designate to India, will arrive in New Delhi later this week bearing a few words of Hindi, a much-used camera and ambitious plans for the countries’ relationship, according to an introductory video released Tuesday by the Embassy.

headline: Searching for the Next Snuggie
text: The Inventors Association of Manhattan meets on the second Monday of each month in the conference room of a Times Square law firm. I went to their most recent meeting to explore an idea that I’ve been hearing a lot about lately — that we are living in a golden age of the independent inventor. Or as Ron Reardon, a patent agent who was a guest speaker that evening, explained, the odds of making money “aren’t good — 1 in 100, 1 in 1000, I’m not sure — but they are better than the lottery.”

headline: What They Said: India’s Interest Rate Cut
text: The Reserve Bank of India has cut the “repo rate,” or the rate that it lends money to commercial banks, by 50 basis points to 8 percent, the first rate cut in three years. The Reserve Bank left the “reserve repo rate” and “cash reserve ratio,” or amount of cash banks must keep on hand, unchanged at 7 percent and 4.75 percent, respectively.

headline: Should Couples Live Together Before Marriage?
text: According to a recent Op-Ed, a majority of young adults in their 20s will live with a romantic partner at least once, and more than half of all marriages will be preceded by cohabitation. Why do you think this is? Why do you think of cohabiting, or living together before marriage, in general? Why?

headline: The Taliban Attacks: Afghanistan
text: A series of brazen attacks by the Taliban rocked Afghanistan on Sunday, with suicide bombers and gunmen staging offensives in Kabul and three eastern provinces for nearly 18 hours. A Taliban spokesman said the attacks were “a message to those foreign commanders who claim that the Taliban lost momentum.”

Who are the top pickups, and just as importantly, who is getting dropped?

headline: Frito-Lay Pledges a Major Shift Toward Natural-Gas Trucking

headline: From Bleak Central India, a People’s Movement

headline: Quiet Additions to a Modernist Masterpiece
text: RONCHAMP, France — Completed in 1955, Le Corbusier’s hilltop chapel of Notre Dame du Haut in this hardscrabble patch of eastern France attracts some 100,000 supplicants each year, architectural and religious. If critics still sometimes blame Le Corbusier for inspiring generations of soulless, cookie-cutter housing projects and office parks, he remains the high priest of Modernism for singular works like this.

What the Silicon Valley-based engineer did know was that his wife, Theresa, had a little closet problem — that is, a collection of unworn items clogging up the racks. But when he asked her (and other female friends) why they held on to these garments, the answer he kept hearing was: “It’s too hard to do anything else with them.”

headline: The Taliban Attacks: Pakistan
text: LONDON — On Sunday before dawn more than 100 Taliban equipped with automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades stormed the central prison in Bannu, a town adjoining the restive tribal belt along Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan. After blasting the main gate with explosives and blowing holes through walls, they freed 384 prisoners, among them Adnan Rashid, a former Pakistan Air Force technician who was on death row for plotting to assassinate former President Pervez Musharraf.

headline: A Hollywood Agent Goes Bollywood
text: As interest in Bollywood continues to grow in the United States, American talent agencies are taking note. Jai Khanna, a manager with Brillstein Entertainment Partners, is targeting talent from India, hoping to bring them into the American mainstream. Beverly Hills-based Brillstein’s client list, which already included heavyweights like Brad Pitt, Adam Sandler and Bill Maher, now boasts Irrfan Khan and Hrithik Roshan, and could soon welcome many more Bollywood names, if Mr. Khanna has his way.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Corporate Control at Google, and a New Tupac Tour?
text: Hulu, created as an online service for watching network television, will pitch original programming to advertisers on Thursday as part of the “upfronts,” which are typically reserved for cable channels and network broadcasters. It is quite a shift for Hulu, which is growing steadily (two million subscribers for its $8-a-month Hulu Plus service), Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write, “despite disagreements among its corporate owners, and the new restrictions those owners have placed on free streaming of network shows.”

headline: Britain Arrests Muslim Cleric, Again Seeking Deportation

They said they would resume efforts to remove him from Britain.

headline: Young People Tire of Old Economic Models
text: At the recent United Nations conference on “gross national happiness,” a scattering of young participants looked on with a clear sense of urgency as mainly graying dignitaries, economists, scholars and others pondered ways to gauge progress that go beyond traditional monetary measures. One was Christopher Stampar, a sophomore from the University of Miami who works for the nonprofit group Nourish 9 Billion. He received one of the most enthusiastic rounds of applause when he let it slip that he was 19. Read his blog post on the experience here.

headline: Not Shaken, Not Stirred: James Bond Drinks Beer

This latest sign of the times is a result of a product placement deal between the brewers of Heineken beer and the producers of the “James Bond” movie franchise, one that even the series star, Daniel Craig, is lamenting as “unfortunate.”

headline: Push in Paris for More Pressure on Syria as Money Ebbs and Cease-Fire Wobbles
text: PARIS — International sanctions aimed at the Syrian government have cut its financial reserves in half, and pressure must be maintained on Damascus to stop its bloody crackdown on opponents despite a shaky five-day cease-fire, the French foreign minister, Alain Juppé, said on Tuesday.

headline: Football, Baseball and the Evolving Tastes of Fans
text: Major League Baseball is under way, and its Saturday afternoon ratings are down slightly from last year. That’s nothing new. In October, the sensational Cardinals and Rangers’ seven-game World Series drew an average of 16.6 million viewers a night. Before that, the last time a Cardinals World Series went seven games was 1987; the average nightly audience was 35 million.
