headline: Sleep Apnea, or A.D.H.D.?
text: On the Well blog today, Kate Murphy reports that many children are being “given a diagnosis of attention hyperactivity disorder when in fact they have another problem: a sleep disorder, like sleep apnea.” Sleepless children become moody and “wired,” and have trouble focusing and sitting still. “No one is saying A.D.H.D. does not exist,” says one expert, but “we need to rule out sleep issues first.”

headline: A Desk Lamp That Keeps Going and Going
text: Known for its unstoppable bunny and the batteries that keep him going, Energizer recently introduced a line of well-designed household lighting products, including flameless candles and accent lamps.

headline: Leading Off: A Pause in the Goonery
text: The Rangers accomplished something notable other than a 1-0 victory over Ottawa in their first-round playoff series Monday night. Yes, goalie Henrik Lundqvist climbed back onto that pedestal he has decorated and called home this season. And yes, we are learning that Brian Boyle has skills way beyond growing a cheesy mustache. But more remarkable is that the Rangers won without resorting to thuggery. No messages sent. No ax grinding or headhunting. In the N.H.L. playoffs — and especially for the pugilistically-inclinded Rangers — this qualifies them for a Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Discovery Shuttle Makes Final Flight
text: Before being permanently brought down to Earth, the space shuttle Discovery hitched a final ride on Tuesday to its new home at the Smithsonian on the back of a 747.

headline: Boehner and McConnell Endorse Romney
text: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio formally endorsed Mitt Romney as the Republican presidential nominee on Tuesday, throwing the weight of his office behind Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, roughly a month before the candidate can amass the delegates necessary to make it official.

headline: Face Time | Chloë Sevigny
text: When I heard Chloë Sevigny would be making a guest appearance on NBC’s “Law & Order: SVU” on April 18, I knew exactly what was in order. Before you could say “indie actress,” I was knocking on Sevigny’s door, camera in hand, sans makeup bag. (Apparently, Sevigny is not too keen on having her makeup done.) She had a few events to attend that night and was just about finished with her prettifying process. I wanted to know more about her makeup know-how, the products she uses and who does that fabulous hair.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/17
text: Into Africa Holland Cotter, in a series of articles, makes a compelling case for visiting West Africa for the art alone. (And a handy multimedia guide distills it for you.) (The New York Times)

headline: Americans Fill Orange Prize Shortlist
text: Three Americans have been named to the shortlist of the Orange Prize for Fiction, an annual prize in Britain that is awarded to a novel written by a woman in English. The finalists this year include Ann Patchett for “State of Wonder,” Cynthia Ozick for “Foreign Bodies” and Madeline Miller for “Song of Achilles,” a debut novel. Ms. Patchett, who opened a bookstore of her own in her native Nashville last year, won the Orange Prize a decade ago for her novel “Bel Canto.” The other finalists are Esi Edugyan for “Half Blood Blues,” Anne Enright for “The Forgotten” and Georgina Harding for “Painter of Silence.”

headline: Less Money. More Voters.
text: It’s been a bad year for the twin goals of getting more people to participate in democracy and reducing the level of special-interest money to influence them. As more states continue to impose onerous voter ID requirements on minorities and the poor, unlimited dollars from the wealthy continue to pour into (not-really) “independent” groups to pay for attack ads.

headline: On Our Radar: Cautious Support for British Fracking
text: A report commissioned by the British government recommends that it allow the shale gas exploration process known as hydraulic fracturing to proceed, but with tighter rules on monitoring seismic activity and more detailed drilling surveys. [Reuters]

headline: The Girth of the Globe
text: Several readers wrote to me in response to today’s column with the same smart, interesting question: What about Europe? What about all the other countries that, like ours, are fundamentally wealthy and have abundant food and yet don’t have our rates of obesity or as many fat people as we do? Don’t their citizens face the same genetic and evolutionary obstacles that we do?

headline: The General Election Ground Game: A First Look
text: Having essentially secured the Republican nomination, Mitt Romney now faces a general election to-do list. He must try to repair his favorability ratings among independent voters, which were eroded by a bruising primary campaign. He must try to close a gender gap that shows women supporting President Obama by a wide margin.

headline: For Some Pitchers, No Reason for Fear
text: In a recent video from M.L.B. Productions, some of the game’s biggest stars talked about which hitters in baseball are the most intimidating to face.

headline: Well-Tended Flower Children
text: AESTHETICALLY speaking, hippies have never been my bag. I’m all for peace, love and understanding, but I’m also partial to regular showers, stiletto heels and gender-specific haircuts. Psychedelic motifs make me dizzy, and tie-dye just seems as if laundry day went terribly wrong.

headline: A Final Chance to Name the Baby Hawks
text: Update, April 19, 6 p.m. | The voting is now closed. The voting form has been removed. Results will be posted Friday morning. Thank you for voting!

headline: Special Treatment for Murakami Paperback
text: “1Q84,” the 925-page Haruki Murakami novel whose translucent jacket dazzled design aficionados upon its release last year, will receive special treatment with its paperback publication next month. The book will be published as a three-volume set on May 15, a spokesman for Vintage said on Tuesday. John Gall, the art director for Vintage, designed the paperbacks to be visible through a clear plastic box, fitting together to create one image. The list price is $29.95, and Vintage will initially print 50,000 copies.

headline: Dewey Loses Eight More Partners as Departures Accelerate
text: Eight more lawyers announced Tuesday that they were leaving Dewey & LeBoeuf, adding to the wave of departures from the embattled New York law firm.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Greater Luxembourg?
text: Luxembourg is about as cuddly as countries come: prosperous, picturesque and delightfully tiny. At 999 square miles, it is the smallest but one of the European Union states [1]. You could drive its length (55 miles) or its width (35 miles) in less time than it takes to watch a feature-length movie — provided you don’t stop at one of the many touristy villages or vineyards along the way. The capital, also called Luxembourg [2], is a cozy city of barely 100,000 souls; its major problem is not drugs or urban decay, but the apparently unfixable fact that it’s rather boring [3].

headline: Police Officer Stabbed in Head in East Harlem

headline: In the N.B.A., There Is a Message in Point Differentials
text: In the N.B.A. teams are ranked in their conference and division by the percentage of games won. Whether a team is victorious by a single point or a large margin plays no part in the standings with the rare exception of tie breakers. In essence, a team that wins all five of its games by 20 points is deemed equal to a team that wins its five games by 1 point.

headline: Couple Questioned About Bomb Threats at University of Pittsburgh

headline: Panetta Proposes New Sexual Assault Rules for the Military
text: Under pressure from Congress and veterans advocates, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta on Monday announced new policies to combat sexual assault in the ranks. Most significantly, the secretary will require that all sexual assault complaints be handled by more senior officers — colonels or Navy captains — than the unit commanders who typically handle them now, a move expected to lead to more prosecutions.

headline: In Agent Scandal, Inquiry Leads to Colombian Bordellos

headline: Bill Porter, Designer of Pontiac GTO, Moves to a New Biorhythm
text: Bill Porter, the former General Motors designer credited with the 1968 Pontiac GTO, has become something of a trend spotter in retirement. headline: ALEC Backs Down
text: It’s not often that a grassroots campaign against a well-funded business organization actually works. But that may have happened today. The American Legislative Exchange Council – responsible for spreading “stand-your-ground” laws and voter ID restrictions to dozens of states around the country –announced that it will disband its Public Safety and Elections Task Force, the internal panel that was the impetus for those kinds of laws. ALEC will now concentrate on economic issues.

headline: Blight Threatens California’s Citrus Trees

headline: Ready for My Video Chat Close-Up

Unemployment, low consumer confidence, tight credit and more arcane Wall Street metrics will all be implicated, but the real culprit is sitting blame-free in America’s living rooms and dens: the television.

headline: Nature Made | Kria Jewelry Collection
text: “You can’t find bones and skeletons just out and about,” laments the Reykjavík-born designer Johanna Methusalemsdottir. Fortunately, Methusalemsdottir gets help from her friends and family in Iceland, who collect and ship boxes of skeletons, teeth and other natural discards to her so that she may use them in her jewelry collection, Kria. “My studio is filled with bones and weird things that keep me really happy,” says the designer, who moved to New York as a teenager and currently makes every piece by hand in her Brooklyn studio. Her latest collection, her fifth, was inspired by the cod, a fish that kicked off decades of territorial disputes and has been central to Icelandic culture for centuries. Pieces look like wisps of smoke, cast in sterling silver and tethered to thin chains. The look book stars Methusalemsdottir’s 18-year-old daughter, India Salvor Menuez, wearing the delicate and primal-looking pieces. “The coarse sweater, the knitting, it really reminded me of fish nets and I wanted it to feel like a portrait of an old sailor or maybe a Native American,” says Methusalemsdottir. “Just very organic, nothing forced.”

headline: Father Knows Best
text: The tax filing deadline is upon us—two days later than usual since April 15 fell on a Sunday and Monday was Emancipation Day, which the Internal Revenue Service dutifully recognizes. Despite this reprieve, an estimated 10 million filers are expected to ask for an extension, and Mitt Romney is among them.

headline: A Slice, and a Relaxed Wine or Beer Pairing

Not surprisingly, the book is endorsed by Ferran Adrià and Juli Soler of El Bulli, with whom Mr. Chartier, a French-Canadian wine and food writer, worked closely for several seasons at their restaurant.

headline: In Rome, It’s the Week of Culture
text: Seeing cultural sites in Italy this week just became easier. Italy’s 14th Settimana della Cultura (“Week of Culture”) started on Saturday and goes through April 22. In Rome, that means free entrance to state-run sites like the Baths of Caracalla, Crypta Balbi, Palazzo Altemps and Palazzo Massimo (the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine are not participating this year). The Galleria Borghese will also be free, although the 2-euro fee for the obligatory reservation is not waived.

headline: ‘The Voice’ Still Leads on Monday, Even as Viewership Slowly Erodes

headline: Rediscovering Pulitzer Winners After a Blank Year

Or “Lamb in His Bosom,” by Caroline Miller? Anyone? … Bueller?

headline: New Study Identifies 'Opportunity Gap' for Students
text: A new report finds students in certain well-off neighborhoods have more access to high-performing middle schools than students from low-income communities in the Bronx and Brooklyn. The Schott Foundation report also concludes that students from low-income, mostly black and Hispanic districts, have fewer experienced teachers and are less likely to attend gifted and talented programs and specialized high schools.

text: In pacing, tone and general absurdities, “Your Boyfriend May Be Imaginary,” a sharp new comedy by Larry Kunofsky, has the feel of a David Sedaris story.

headline: The Knotty Ties Binding America’s Ex-Leaders
text: The term “Presidents Club” is used to describe airport lounges that exclude most passengers. It can also designate any group of civic leaders or other association that wants to sound important. It has sometimes been used by American presidents to describe the ties that bind them, but it is not a formal entity. Ex-Presidents Herbert Hoover and Harry S. Truman joked about starting “a former presidents club” when they met at the inauguration of President Eisenhower and wondered what to do with their futures.

headline: A Bridge in a Day
text: The Massachusetts Department of Transportation is learning the advantages of a technique known as “accelerated bridge construction” to move a span into place in a day.

headline: Tom Petty’s Stolen Guitars Are Recovered

Ron Iizuka of the Culver City, Calif., police department declined to provide details, though he confirmed the guitars stolen last Thursday from a rehearsal studio had been found.

headline: Asked and Answered | Joseph Altuzarra
text: There are few things that fashion folk love more than fresh-off-the-runway style for a bargain. Last year, J.Crew proved that shoppers could have just that when they collaborated with the 2010 CFDA / Vogue Fashion Fund winners Billy Reid, Prabal Gurung and Eddie Borgo. This week, the preppy-classic brand introduced its latest combined effort––a seven-piece capsule from the 2011 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner Joseph Altuzarra that includes a list of closet staples like denim bottoms, cashmere sweaters and crisp, gingham shirts ($85-$345). Here, T talks to Altuzarra about his design process, his CFDA win and the cake that came soon thereafter.

headline: The Lowly Anchovy: Customers Finally Take the Bait

headline: Three Standout Dishes at Alison Eighteen
text: For those who feel harassed by how complicated dining in New York has become, Alison Eighteen may feel like something of a safe harbor. It’s a straightforward restaurant where you aren’t told that everything is meant to be served family style, or tapas style, or in a tasting menu that has to be ordered a month in advance.

headline: Seared Red Rice With Spinach, Mushrooms, Carrot and Egg
text: Rice bran oil has a very high smoke point, so it’s a perfect oil for searing and stir-fries where that high-heat seared flavor is desired. You can make this dish with any type of rice, but I love the red rice I’ve been finding in whole-foods stores, whether from Thailand or Bhutan.

headline: His Best Friend at His Fingertips, a Pianist, 96, Plays On
text: “That’s his fountain of youth right there: the martini,” a patron squealed the other night at Nino’s Tuscany on West 58th Street.She was pointing to a brimming two-olive vodka martini resting on the grand piano being played by Irving Fields.

headline: Beware the Suited Men Wielding Letter Openers
text: Years before “Everybody Loves Raymond” propelled Brad Garrett to stardom, he was a stand-up comedian opening for Frank Sinatra in Las Vegas. He capped his warm-up act on one particularly unresponsive night by deadpanning: “You’re a great audience. Stick around for Frank.”

headline: Classics, Homespun and Fresh

They house the library and post office, hardware stores and knickknack dens, an aging sweet shop and a still-vigorous chocolatier.

headline: Have You Always Wanted a Roll-Up Water Bottle?
text: In this week’s It’s the Economy column, Adam Davidson asks if we have entered a golden age of American invention. We learned that it’s easier than ever for inventors to go from idea to prototype to finished product, but it’s harder than ever to protect those ideas from copycats. So has intellectual theft turned inventors into a secretive, media-wary bunch? Not the inventors we met.

headline: Senate Republicans Announce Plan to Support Challenge to Recess Appointments

text: Amazon Publishing has snapped up the rights to publish 14 James Bond books in the United States, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Military News Roundup: Taliban Evolution, Veteran Disabilities and Homelessness, and Panetta’s Travel
text: The New York Times Web site is rich with military-related stories today. So, here, for your skimming pleasure, is a roundup of all the good reading.

headline: Levon Helm in Final Stages of Cancer Battle
text: Levon Helm, the drummer with the Band, has reached the final stages of his battle with cancer, according to a note posted on the musician’s Web site. Mr. Helm, 71, received a diagnosis of throat cancer in 1998 and nearly lost his voice, though he has continued to sing on albums and at concerts. The note, signed by his daughter and wife, asked fans to send “prayers and love to him as he makes his way through this part of his journey.”

headline: The Story of a Girl, and How It Spread
text: The Holocaust documentary “Inside Hana’s Suitcase” recounts the story of a Jewish girl from Czechoslovakia named Hana Brady, whom the Nazis orphaned; separated from her brother, George; and killed at Auschwitz. Hana and her suitcase are already well known to the many readers touched by Karen Levine’s similarly titled 2002 book. This heartstring-tugging film from the director Larry Weinstein earnestly carries on Ms. Levine’s dual dramatization of Hana’s tale and its transmission.

headline: The Guide and Spirit of Ailey II Steps Down
text: Somewhere near the top of the modern-dance family tree, where the foliage is plentiful, you’ll find Sylvia Waters.

headline: At London Olympics, NBC Says, ‘If Cameras Are on It, We’ll Stream It’
text: All 32 sports at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London will be streamed live at nbcolympics.com.

headline: What a Pianist Is Learning From 32 Sonatas
text: For any serious concert pianist, Beethoven is more than just a composer. His music for the piano, and in particular his 32 numbered sonatas, are a summit by which prowess and insight are measured as well as a process by which those qualities can be developed. Far from being fixed on a page, the sonatas live anew in the hands of each performer who comes to them with integrity and passion.

headline: In Judging Hostile Bids, Look at How Recent Targets Fared

headline: In a Shift, Vornado Addresses Investor Concerns
text: Vornado Realty Trust, whose diversified portfolio includes a large swath of office towers near Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and strip shopping centers in the Northeast and California, was once considered the company with the magic touch. But lately many investors and analysts have soured on Vornado, a real estate investment trust, saying it failed to capitalize on opportunities in the downturn and has become too unwieldy for investors to evaluate.

headline: Spinning Eerie Harmonics Into a Panorama of Emotions
text: The composer Christian Ofenbauer, a professor at the Mozarteum University in Salzburg, Austria, aims to write music “senza espressione,” avoiding the expressive gestures inherent in Baroque, Classical and Romantic music. Plenty of contemporary composers have abandoned traditional musical devices to exciting effect, but there was little to retain a listener’s interest in Mr. Ofenbauer’s “BruchStück IX” when the Quatuor Diotima performed it at the Austrian Cultural Forum on Monday evening.

headline: Graphic Cigarette Warnings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Popular J.&J. Drugs May Not Return Until 2013
text: Efforts to fix manufacturing problems at three Johnson & Johnson plants are taking longer than expected, meaning that some popular over-the-counter consumer brands may not return to store shelves until next year, company executives said Tuesday.

headline: Illness and Superstition
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neuhaus Opens on Madison Avenue
text: For most Americans, the word praline conjures up the sugary pecan-studded candy from Louisiana. But in francophone Europe, pralines are filled chocolates. And it was exactly 100 years ago that the praline, a hard chocolate shell with a creamy flavored interior, made its debut at the Neuhaus chocolatier in Brussels.

headline: A Warming Trend From North Africa
text: Harissa is the sriracha of North Africa, a chile-based condiment that elevates many a dish. Though its origins are Tunisian and it is most widely used there and in Algeria, its popularity has recently spread to Morocco, where more restaurants are serving it, especially with grilled meats. Mina Kallamni, 65, who grew up in Casablanca, said she did not even taste it until she was 16, but then she became hooked. In New York, she has founded Casablanca Foods with her son Fouad, and their first product is harissa. Unlike typical harissa, which is a ruddy red-orange, hers is a vibrant magenta. It is made without preservatives. The spicy version takes no prisoners; the tangy mild and medium are more approachable.

headline: Ibérico Pork in the Neighborhood
text: Call it the other red meat. Uncured cuts of pork from Spanish Ibérico pigs, the same ones that forage for acorns and become some of the finest hams on the planet, are now being sold online in the United States, by Wagshal’s in Washington; La Tienda in Williamsburg, Va.; and Nicky USA in Portland, Ore. Need I say grilling season? The fresh meat is red, beeflike and marbled. Seared medium rare, then sliced, it is silky-tender, with a mildly earthy flavor. It is not as buttery as Wagyu beef, so you are not sated after two bites.

headline: Midsummer Night Swing Unveils Its Lineup
text: The lineup for the Midsummer Night Swing series of concerts this year includes a European boogie-woogie combo with Charlie Watts on drums and a concert by masters of forró music from northeastern Brazil, some of whom have rarely appeared outside their homeland, Lincoln Center announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Memorial, Ribald and Reverent, for Christopher Hitchens
text: On Friday in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, friends and fans of Christopher Hitchens, the author and columnist who died on Dec. 15, will gather for “some highmindedness and some laughs,” according to Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair.

headline: Twins’ Mauer and Morneau Flash Old Form
text: For one night, it was 2006 all over again, with Joe Mauer and Justin Morneau collecting key hits in a Minnesota Twins victory.

headline: Israeli Minister Agrees Ahmadinejad Never Said Israel ‘Must Be Wiped Off the Map’
text: Last Updated, April 18 | In a reminder that Persian rhetoric is not always easy for English-speakers to interpret, a senior Israeli official has acknowledged that Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, never actually said that Israel “must be wiped off the map.”

headline: With Eye on Past, Karzai Lays Out Vision for an Independent Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a sweeping speech on Tuesday that touched on some of the heroes of Afghanistan’s past 150 years, President Hamid Karzai laid out a vision of a modern, independent Afghanistan that could outlast security upheaval and foreign entanglement. And he made an emotional defense of his outreach to the Taliban, urging the insurgents again to lay down their weapons, if only to hasten the withdrawal of American forces.

headline: Top Iran Nuclear Scientist, Once Targeted for Assassination, Gets New Emergency Post
text: The head of Iran’s Atomic Energy Organization, a top nuclear scientist who narrowly avoided an assassination attempt less than two years ago, has been given a new post as the commander for nuclear and radioactive emergencies, the Iranian military announced Tuesday.

headline: Guillen Returns to Dugout After Suspension

headline: Buses With 3 Doors? What’s a Rider to Do?
text: In many cities around the world, there are simple established rules for riding buses: board at the front and exit at the back, making for an orderly passenger flow.

headline: Web Site Stole Job Seekers’ Data in Tax-Fraud Scheme
text: A Web site that promised to connect people with much-needed jobs during the recession was actually a means to steal the applicants’ personal information in a scheme to file fraudulent tax returns, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: Each Side Accuses the Other of Breaking Syrian Cease-Fire

headline: Paul Bogart, TV Director, Dies at 92
text: Paul Bogart, a puppeteer who bumbled into the new medium of television in 1950 and rose to be an Emmy-winning director known for popular shows like “All in the Family” and “The Defenders,” died on Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 92 and lived in Chapel Hill.

headline: Kurds Remain on the Sideline of Syria’s Uprising
text: KILIS, Turkey — The Kurds of Syria, long oppressed by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, are largely staying out of the fighting that has gone on for more than a year in their country, hedging their bets as they watch to see who will gain the upper hand.

headline: William Finley, Actor in De Palma Movies, Dies at 71
text: William Finley, a character actor who appeared in many films by Brian De Palma, most memorably as the title character in the 1974 rock opera “The Phantom of the Paradise,” died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Flyers Are in Control, Surprising Themselves and the Penguins
text: VOORHEES, N.J. — Three games into a series in which their opponents, the Pittsburgh Penguins, have seemingly careened out of control, the Philadelphia Flyers are pleased, and maybe even a little surprised, that they are not behaving like the Flyers often have in the past.

headline: Regulators to Ease a Rule on Derivatives Dealers

headline: Britain Presses for Information on Death in China
text: LONDON — After months of soft-pedaling by British diplomats in the case of a British businessman believed to have been murdered in China, Prime Minister David Cameron and his government abruptly changed course on Tuesday, going to Parliament with a blunt demand that China “expose the truth behind this tragic case” and do so in a manner that “is free from political interference.”

headline: Abiding by the Fair Sentencing Act
text: The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 addressed a gross inequity in federal sentences by reducing the disparity in punishment for a crime involving crack versus powdered cocaine. Previously, under a 1986 law, 50 grams of crack (the weight of a candy bar) led to a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years — the same sentence that applied to 5,000 grams of powdered cocaine (enough to fill a brief case). A street dealer of crack cocaine often got a longer sentence than the major trafficker who sold the powdered cocaine made into crack. The new law cut the 100 to 1 ratio to 18 to 1 — not equalizing the penalties as it should have but markedly reducing the difference.

headline: The Big Spill, Two Years Later
text: Friday is the second anniversary of the explosion at BP’s Deepwater Horizon rig that killed 11 workers and spilled upwards of five million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Thanks partly to nature’s resilience, some progress has been made. The gulf is open to fishing, beaches are mostly clean and President Obama has resurrected an ambitious oil exploration plan that he shelved immediately after the spill.

headline: A Visit With ‘The Greatest Living Food Writer’
text: Colin Spencer, whom Germaine Greer once called “the greatest living food writer,” turns 80 next year, and shows no signs of slowing down. His latest book, “From Microliths to Microwaves,” a history of food in Britain from pre-historic times to the present, is the work of a scholar. (In it he argues, in a way that’s reminiscent of Jared Diamond, that agriculture — or at least agriculture as it’s practiced now — is one of the great tragedies of the human race.)

headline: Using His Software Skills With Freedom, Not a Big Payout, in Mind
text: Nadim Kobeissi, master hacker, summoned for interrogation multiple times as a teenager by cyber-intelligence authorities in Beirut, Lebanon, sat in the backyard of a restaurant in Brooklyn, astounded that he was being treated to lunch.

headline: Marketers Find a Friend in Pinterest

headline: Romney Aide Turns Focus to Search for His No. 2

headline: Right Steps on Military Sexual Assault
text: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta on Monday announced several encouraging steps to fight sexual assault in the military. The most notable is the requirement that complaints be handled by senior officers — colonels or Navy captains — instead of lower-ranking officers who are often ill equipped or reluctant to pursue assault cases.

headline: Keeping the Peace, Armed With Only a Whistle
text: Jeré Longman of The Times, in London to cover Wednesday’s Champions League semifinal between Chelsea and Barcelona at Stamford Bridge, reports on the man who could have the biggest impact on the game: the German referee Felix Brych. Chelsea is familiar with Brych, who worked one of the Blues’ matches against Napoli in the Round of 16, but it would be understandable of their fans were wary of any referee in his spot after a couple of heartbreaking experiences against the Catalans in recent years. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Romney’s Critique of War Policy Gets a Closer Look
text: Mitt Romney has made Afghanistan a showcase for his attacks on President Obama’s foreign policy. He says Mr. Obama has undercut American interests by setting timetables for withdrawing troops, providing the Taliban — who displayed their resilience with attacks over the weekend — further reason to wait things out. He called Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta “misguided and so naïve” for announcing plans to hand over primary combat responsibilities to Afghan forces next year and leave American troops mainly in training and other roles.

headline: One for the Country
text: I had to catch a train in Washington last week. The paved street in the traffic circle around Union Station was in such poor condition that I felt as though I was on a roller coaster. I traveled on the Amtrak Acela, our sorry excuse for a fast train, on which I had so many dropped calls on my cellphone that you’d have thought I was on a remote desert island, not traveling from Washington to New York City. When I got back to Union Station, the escalator in the parking garage was broken. Maybe you’ve gotten used to all this and have stopped noticing. I haven’t. Our country needs a renewal.

headline: In California Quake Research, Boring Is the Hoped-for Result

Engineers constructed a five-story building — complete with an operating room, an elevator, a kitchen loaded with glassware and a heavy air-conditioning unit perched on the roof — and placed it atop a platform known as a shake table on the outskirts of San Diego. Observers were issued hard hats and a strict set of safety instructions.

headline: Rankings Did Not Motivate College Official Who Falsified SAT Scores, Report Finds
text: The former admissions dean at Claremont McKenna College, who recently admitted to exaggerating SAT scores for several years, was not trying to improve the school’s standing in the closely watched U.S. News & World Report rankings but instead attempting to conceal bad news from his boss, the school’s president, who had established goals for higher SAT statistics, according to a report released Tuesday.

headline: Can the Samajwadi Party Ease U.P.’s Shia-Sunni Conflict?
text: A chill ran down Ruby Rizvi’s spine when, about three weeks ago, she heard the footsteps of hundreds of people outside her house near Mahboob Ganj Chauraha in Lucknow.  After ensuring the safety of her three children, she peeped out of the window of her first-floor home. The mob, some 1,500 strong, she estimates, approached her husband’s pharmacy on the ground floor, with swords and metal rods.

headline: Dissident to Travel Out of Myanmar After 24 Years of Resolving to Stay Put
text: BANGKOK — After 24 years of stubborn campaigning for democracy in Myanmar and a steely determination to stay inside the country despite official admonishments to leave, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will make her first foreign trip since 1988, visiting Norway and Britain, the spokesman for her political party said on Wednesday.

headline: Prosecutors Press Norwegian on Extremist Affiliations
text: OSLO — The self-described anti-Islamic militant on trial for killing 77 people in Norway last summer insisted on Wednesday that he belonged to a cell within an organization with members across Europe.

headline: How Exercise Could Lead to a Better Brain
text: The value of mental-training games may be speculative, as Dan Hurley writes in his article on the quest to make ourselves smarter, but there is another, easy-to-achieve, scientifically proven way to make yourself smarter. Go for a walk or a swim. For more than a decade, neuroscientists and physiologists have been gathering evidence of the beneficial relationship between exercise and brainpower. But the newest findings make it clear that this isn’t just a relationship; it is the relationship. Using sophisticated technologies to examine the workings of individual neurons — and the makeup of brain matter itself — scientists in just the past few months have discovered that exercise appears to build a brain that resists physical shrinkage and enhance cognitive flexibility. Exercise, the latest neuroscience suggests, does more to bolster thinking than thinking does.

headline: Can You Make Yourself Smarter?
text: Early on a drab afternoon in January, a dozen third graders from the working-class suburb of Chicago Heights, Ill., burst into the Mac Lab on the ground floor of Washington-McKinley School in a blur of blue pants, blue vests and white shirts. Minutes later, they were hunkered down in front of the Apple computers lining the room’s perimeter, hoping to do what was, until recently, considered impossible: increase their intelligence through training.

headline: 2012 N.F.L. Mock Draft, Updated
text: Jonathan Bales is the founder of TheDCTimes.com and is helping analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

headline: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
text: I was in the middle of a staff meeting when my wife called. Our 16-year-old cat, who had not been eating for days, was clearly nearing the end and my wife had a vet on the way to the house. My son, who works with me, was about to leave to go home. I had what I would call “the moment.” All working people have them — the moment when you ask yourself, “Should I go home, or should I stay and continue to fight the battle?” Quick. Make a decision.

headline: Conquering Food Deserts With Green Carts
text: 9:21 a.m. | Updated When we think of a “desert,” we don’t picture southwest Philadelphia or a small town in upstate New York. But that’s the description given to areas of the United States that lack ready access to healthy food — like fresh fruits and vegetables. These grocery-store deprived zones have come to be known as “food deserts” and the federal government estimates that they are home to millions of Americans (pdf), including more than 23 million people who live in low-income neighborhoods that are more than a mile from a supermarket.

headline: Device Malfunction Casts Doubt on Industry Pledge
text: As doctors scramble to understand the risks posed by a flawed heart device component made by St. Jude Medical, the episode is raising a bigger question — whether the $10 billion heart device industry has fully embraced promised safety reforms.

headline: Romney and Obama Are in a Tight Contest, Poll Finds

If you speak of starting a project, or taking a trip, or trying to pay a debt, the outcome is always understood to be conditional.

headline: Iran Arrests 15 People Accused in Assassination Plot

headline: A Match Made in Literary Heaven: Descendants of Dickens and Tolkien to Collaborate
text: A literary partnership between Charles Dickens and J. R. R. Tolkien would have been downright impossible, if not undesirable. (A tale of hungry workhouse hobbits who want more gruel? An evil, all-seeing eye visited by foreboding spirits on Christmas?) But a London publisher has nonetheless found a way to get their names onto the same project, in the form of a collaboration between descendants of Tolkien and Dickens, BBC News reported. The publisher Thames River Press said it would release two fantasy novels written by Michael Tolkien, aimed at younger readers and based on stories told to him by his grandfather, the “Lord of the Rings” author J. R. R. Tolkien. Gerald Dickens, a great-great grandson of Dickens, will narrate the audiobook releases. BBC News said the first book, called “Wish,” was inspired by the Florence Bone story “The Rose-Colored Wish” and chronicles two children who come into possession of an evil sorcerer’s enchanted artifact; the second book, “Rainbow,” takes its inspiration from another work by Ms. Bone called “The Other Side of the Rainbow.”

headline: Clean Technology on the Brink

But that technology is going to fall off a cliff unless government steps in quickly to revitalize the solar, wind, nuclear, battery and clean vehicle sectors with new spending and federal policy, according to a new study from three research groups.

headline: Big City Dialogue: Raising Teenagers in New York

headline: In Gentrified Brooklyn, Hopes for More School Alternatives

headline: Vain Glorious | Ardency Inn
text: Coachella may not be where you’d expect to have a beauty brand make its debut, but for Ardency Inn it’s proven to be ideal. Based on the energy and the aesthetic of New York’s music scene, the concept is the brainchild of the Paris-born marketing and business development executive Gilles Kortzagadarian — an LVMH alum with time clocked at Dior, Benefit and Makeup Up For Ever — and his partner Stephane Siboni. The five-piece offering includes highly pigmented, buildable color cosmetics packaged in boxes with colorful boom box prints, modeled in the campaign visuals by an assortment of up-and-coming musicians like Holly Marilyn of the Child. The gimmicks, however, stop at the innovative, well-executed formulas. Standout products include Encore Long Play Lip Color in Lovecat (a teeth-whitening, blue-based red), Punker One Stroke Liquid Eyeliner (a multi-use felt-tip pen) and Night Lights Shadow in Borealis Black (gunmetal shimmer suspended in rich, refined black powder).

headline: $420 ‘Superman’ Check Sells for $160,000
text: It took 56 bids, but a check endorsed by the creators of Superman that conceded the ownership rights to the character went for $160,000 at auction at Comicconnect.com.  The check was issued by Detective Comics Inc. and was for $420, which included $130 for the rights to Superman, $210 for stories in Detective Comics, and two $36 payments for stories in More Fun and Adventure Comics. It was made out – incorrectly – to Seigel and Schuster, misspellings of the surnames of Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster, the writer and artist team who created Superman.

headline: Woman Recounts Quarrel Leading to Agent Scandal

headline: Don’t Say ‘Gay.’ Do Say ‘Intelligent Design.’

Earlier this month the governor allowed passage of a law protecting teachers who challenge the “scientific weaknesses” of topics such as “biological evolution, the chemical origins of life, global warming and human cloning.” The sponsors say it fosters “critical thinking;” its opponents point out the obvious: It’s an anti-science measure intended to promote creationism and intelligent design, and to cast doubt on climate change.

text: President Obama greeted supporters on Wednesday as he arrived in Cleveland. Mr. Obama will hold a town-hall-style meeting and deliver a speech in Lorain County, just west of Cleveland.

headline: Amid New Strife, Deal Is Near on Full Team of Cease-Fire Monitors for Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Representatives of the United Nations and Syrian government moved on Wednesday toward reaching an agreement that would allow a full contingent of 250 observers to deploy in Syria to monitor a fragile cease-fire, despite suggestions from Syrian officials that they intended to restrict some aspects of the operation, including the independent use of helicopters.

headline: Tortorella Measures His Words, but Not His Praise
text: OTTAWA — Rangers Coach John Tortorella was brief in his remarks after the Rangers’ morning skate here. When asked why coaches are so secretive during the playoffs, he answered, “I don’t want to tell you.”

headline: The Well Quiz: Test Your Vegan I.Q.
text: Do you prefer broccoli to barbecue? Quinoa to quiche? Whether you are a vegan, a vegetarian or a devoted carnivore, most of us have a lot to learn about plant-based eating. Take the Well Quiz to test your knowledge of all things vegan.

headline: The Films of Paul Thomas Anderson
text: A look back at the director’s work.

headline: British Ex-Foreign Secretary Accused in Qaddafi Foe’s Rendition
text: LONDON — Lawyers for a Libyan military commander, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, said on Wednesday that they had begun legal action against a former British foreign secretary, Jack Straw, following accusations that Mr. Straw was directly involved in secret rendition operations that delivered him and another man to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s secret police in 2004.

headline: U.S. and NATO Finalize Pacts on Ending Afghan War
text: BRUSSELS — The United States and its allies in NATO finalized agreements on Wednesday to wind down the war in Afghanistan, paving the way for President Obama to announce at a NATO summit meeting in Chicago next month that the unpopular, nearly 11-year-old conflict is close to an end.

headline: Is Citi Just the Beginning?
text: When I walked into work this morning, I found this anonymous message on my voicemail. The call, of course, was referring to the fact that Citigroup’s shareholders voted down CEO Vikram Pandit’s $14.9 million pay package for 2011. (The caller was wrong to refer to Pandit as the chairman.)  True, the vote was nonbinding—the result of Dodd-Frank, which calls for shareholder votes on pay packages—but it has clearly shaken Citi, which announced that it would meet with shareholder groups to hear their complaints. Their main gripe is that Pandit’s pay is not linked strongly enough to performance. But the main reason I’m posting this reader’s short response is that I think she may well be on to something:

headline: Summitt Stepping Down as Tennessee Coach
text: Less than a year after she received a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimer’s disease, Pat Summitt has stepped down as Tennessee’s women’s basketball coach, ending her remarkable 38-year career in building one of the signature programs in the sport.

headline: Tesco to Spend $1.6 Billion to Revive U.K. Business
text: LONDON — The British supermarket chain Tesco announced a £1 billion investment program Wednesday that it hopes will revive earnings in its home market by expanding its online business while adding fewer large stores.

headline: In Arizona, Immigrants Make Plans in Shadows
text: PHOENIX — Miguel Guerra has a wife, three children and a house. He has a car, but no driver’s license. He has business cards, but no immigration papers. He got into the habit of keeping his cellphone close when he drives so he can quickly call a cousin, the only legal resident among his relatives in the United States, in case he gets pulled over.

headline: Making the Most of Nothing
text: ALTHOUGH I am married with no plans to be single, I recently signed up for several online dating sites as research for a book I am writing. The process was fun until I saw a question asking me to describe my hair. I didn’t want to check the “bald” box. I wanted to say I had a shaved head. But a “shaved head” wasn’t a choice. (What? No write-ins?) So I sighed and checked bald, no doubt setting off an instant downgrade of my profile.

headline: Champions League: Barcelona at Chelsea
text: Bayern Munich’s 2-1 victory over Real Madrid on Tuesday, on a last-minute goal by Mario Gomez, was a terrific way to start the Champions League semifinals. Wednesday’s match — Barcelona at Chelsea — was just as good. To follow the game as it happened, read on.

headline: A Comfy Chair? A Little Quiet? Your Own Table? Sorry, Ma’am, We’re All Out
text: Can restaurant design be discriminatory?

headline: Sony Is Said to Gain Europe’s Approval on $2.2 Billion EMI Bid
text: Sony has won European regulators’ approval for its $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing, which would create the largest catalog of songs in the world, according to a person briefed on the process.

headline: Cavaliers Continue Slide; Pistons Play for Pride
text: N.B.A. draft conspiracy theorists may have raised an eyebrow or two if they were watching the Cleveland Cavaliers at the Detroit Pistons on Tuesday. The Cavs, 13th in the Eastern Conference, and the Pistons at 10th, are clearly cruising toward the lottery.

headline: Italy Pushes Back Balanced Budget by 2 Years
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti on Wednesday pushed back Italy’s balanced budget target by a year, amid a deepening recession that economists say has been worsened by new austerity measures.

headline: On Our Radar: Tree Killer Crosses the Hudson
text: The emerald ash borer has been found east of the Hudson River for the first time, in the Dutchess County hamlet of Rhinecliff. Luckily, the colony was caught less than a year after it got established, forestry experts say. [Associated Press]

headline: After Argentina’s Move on Oil Company, Spanish Corporations Take a Wary View
text: MADRID — N2S, a Spanish supplier of software to the energy sector, has almost half of its 85 employees in Latin America, spread among Mexico, Brazil and Peru.

headline: Fresh Face | Amira Ahmed
text: The breakout model Amira Ahmed is more than just a beautiful face framed by a short, edgy haircut. For the half-Somali, half-Filipino, who surfs the West Coast — “I love waiting for that special wave” — and hits the Tignes in the French Alps to snowboard between fashion seasons (“simply a must!”), modeling is as much about traveling and maintaining the routine-less lifestyle she knows so well as it is a job. Born in Stockholm, the 22-year-old grew up on her stepfather’s boat, where, she says “the sea became my playground.” Upon coming ashore, she attended boarding school in Prague, then college in London where she studied international relations. “It’s natural that I would find work that I could do everywhere,” she says. Now based in Brooklyn, Ahmed most recently landed campaigns for Gap, AllSaints and L’Oreal. Just don’t expect her to start nesting anytime soon.

headline: Ask Anne Lamott, Author of ‘Some Assembly Required’
text: What, exactly, do you ask a woman who’s already written that “I thought such awful thoughts that I cannot even say them out loud because they would make Jesus want to drink gin straight out of the cat dish,” who has called her own mind “barely inhabitable” and added that “when people have seen you at your worst, you don’t have to put on the mask as much?”

headline: In Spain, Euro Rescue Fund May Face Its Biggest Test
text: LUXEMBOURG — The euro zone’s rescue fund has already helped mount full-scale bailouts of three of Europe’s smaller economies.

headline: Justices Limit Suits Under Law on Torture
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled unanimously  on Wednesday that the family of an American citizen killed during a visit to the West Bank may not sue the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization under a 1991 federal law, the Torture Victim Protection Act.

headline: When American Faith Transcended Differences
text: The obvious allusion in the title of Ross Douthat’s new book, “Bad Religion,” is to a veteran Los Angeles  punk band. But I kept thinking of Dan Aykroyd’s “Saturday Night Live” character Leonard Pinth-Garnell, a pompous fop who hosted sketches like “Bad Cinema” and “Bad Ballet.” Pinth-Garnell would introduce a ridiculous performance — think of John Belushi attempting arabesques — then sum up merrily at the end: “Well now! That wasn’t very good at all, was it?”

headline: Goldman Is Said to Be in Talks to Sell Petershill Fund
text: Goldman Sachs is said to be in negotiations to sell one of its most notable portfolios, Petershill, which has suffered some major setbacks in its hedge fund investments.

headline: Earth Day and All Days: 10 Ways to Learn About the Environment
text: Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are 10 ideas for commemorating the day, observed each year on April 22, or exploring issues related to the environment in the classroom or home on any day of the year.

headline: Berkshire Shareholders Unfazed by Buffett Diagnosis
text: Not every corporate executive gets a call from the president asking about his health. But then, there is only one Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Sampling Rap, Salsa and Al Jazeera
text: AT a party last fall celebrating Terry Richardson’s photography exhibition “Mom & Dad” at the Westway, a former strip joint turned nightclub in the far West Village, the D.J. Venus X blasted through a torrent of disparate musical styles during her two-hour-plus set: Chicago juke (a low-fi interpretation of break beat); Dominican dembow (a Latin spin on reggaetón); local underground rap; South Africa house music; Spanish salsa; Turkish techno.

headline: Reimagined ‘Cinderella’ Casts Its Leading Couple
text: The Broadway-bound production of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” has found a leading lady who fits the glass slipper – as well as the actor to play her prince. Laura Osnes, who starred as the outlaw Bonnie Parker in the Broadway musical “Bonnie & Clyde” last year, will play a re-invented Cinderella in the production aiming to open during the 2012-13 theater season, while Santino Fontana (“Sons of the Prophet,” “Billy Elliot”) will play the prince, the show’s producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyers Want to Limit Pettitte’s Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — The lawyers for Roger Clemens are seeking to limit the testimony of Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte at Clemens’s perjury trial, according to a document filed Wednesday in United States District Court.

headline: Consumer Advocates Seek Halt to ‘Yo-Yo’ Car Financing
text: Consumer advocates are urging the federal government to crack down on so-called “yo-yo” automobile financing. That’s when a buyer is allowed to leave the sales lot with a car even though the sale isn’t technically final, only to be called back to the dealership days later and pressured to sign a new financing agreement with less favorable terms.

headline: Dear Reformers: Teachers Are Neither Heroes Nor Zeroes
text: A Queens English teacher writes: Dear education reformers, I humbly submit that teachers are not the Zeroes you make us out to be. Nor are we all Heroes. We rarely confront fire-breathing dragons, but we do face off against hormone-engorged adolescents. We don't pull swords from stones, but we do pull thoughtful answers from reluctant learners. And we do face off against 'poverty, hunger, discrimination, abuse, bullying and neglect. Sometimes, we even win.

headline: No Disney Ending for This Woodworker
text: What would a world without art be like? In “Pinocchio’s Ashes,” the Danish playwright Jokum Rohde’s leaden satire, the answer is: unpleasant.

headline: The Flaws in the New Liquidation Authority
text: How would one of the large American financial institutions fare in the new Dodd-Frank Orderly Liquidation Authority? That’s the question that motivates a new paper I wrote for a symposium at the University of Cincinnati, and it seems to have already hit a nerve.

headline: City Opera Returning to Its Roots
text: New York City Opera, which last year announced a plan to take opera to the people with performances around the city, said on Wednesday that it had established agreements to perform in two places: the Brooklyn Academy of Music and New York City Center, its original home.

headline: A Big Step Forward for Liquefied Gas Exports
text: Cheniere Energy crossed a big hurdle in its push to export natural gas this week when the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission gave its stamp of approval to the Houston company’s proposed liquefied gas export terminal in Sabine Pass, La. FERC’s assent had been considered the most uncertain element of a long government approval process, and the Texas-based company now hopes to start exporting by late 2015 or early 2016. It would be the first major liquefied gas export terminal in the lower 48 states.

headline: Volkswagen Group to Add Ducati to Product Portfolio
text: 10:48 a.m. | Updated

headline: Judge Quits Trayvon Martin Case Over Potential Conflict
text: The Florida judge overseeing the murder case against George Zimmerman stepped aside on Wednesday at the request of Mr. Zimmerman’s lawyer, who had questioned whether her assignment could create a potential conflict of interest.

headline: Reactions to Death of Dick Clark, New Year’s Eve Icon
text: 9:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Dickey Picks Bad Day to Have a Bad Start
text: ATLANTA — For all the fickleness of its flight, R. A. Dickey’s knuckleball had been producing remarkably steady results for its owner.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SCENT MEMORIES

headline: City App Contest Won by a Tool for Those Who Make Apps
text: There were almost 100 entries into New York City’s third annual Big Apps contest, grappling with urban issues like transportation, education and land use. In the end, the top prize went to a project whose main goal was to make it easy for developers to make more apps.

headline: Name Change
text: The filmmaker Sharon Shattuck recalls the apprehension she experienced when her father, a transgender cross-dresser, decided to legally adopt a woman’s name.

headline: ‘Name Change’
text: I’ve heard much debate in the past year about what constitutes a “healthy family.”  Some politicians argue that the best environment for a child is one with a mother and a father — and the underlying context here is that a “normal” family should be helmed by a “normal” heterosexual couple.

headline: TV Emperor of Rock ’n’ Roll and New Year’s Eve Dies at 82
text: Dick Clark, the perpetually youthful-looking television host whose long-running daytime song-and-dance fest, “American Bandstand,” did as much as anyone or anything to advance the influence of teenagers and rock ’n’ roll on American culture, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Fig. 19
text: BACK in the early 2000s, a lounge called Passerby blurred the line between gallery and bar. Attached to Gavin Brown’s Enterprise gallery in Chelsea, it drew cool, artsy patrons who might have gone to an opening at the gallery earlier that night.

headline: Theater Talkback: A Good Play Can Be Read as Well as Seen
text: You can’t see Quiara Alegría Hudes’s “Water by the Spoonful” right now, even though it just won the Pulitzer Prize for drama. The play, the second part of a trilogy, ran for less than a month in its world premiere at Hartford Stage in late 2011. The other two finalists, Jon Robin Baitz’s “Other Desert Cities” and Stephen Karam’s “Sons of the Prophet,” were far better known, having enjoyed prominent and well-received New York productions; “Other Desert Cities” is playing on Broadway and is a likely contender for the Tony Award for best play, to be announced in June.

headline: Syrian First Lady Is Urged to Challenge Crackdown
text: President Bashar al-Assad made a rare appearance with his wife, Asma, on Syrian state television this week, greeting throngs of supporters and packing food aid for the restive city of Homs, shattered by a military bombardment this year that was itself ordered by Mr. Assad.

headline: Flying Through Airport Lines
text: MORE than 10 years after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks completely altered the airport experience, travelers have a variety of options that will shorten wait times at security and immigration. But speedier processing has some downsides. Some programs charge a fee, and all require surrendering such personal information as employment background, travel history and biological data like fingerprints.

headline: More Than Mrs. Sting
text: DURING a visit to India to celebrate her 50th birthday, Trudie Styler consulted a seer. Recently, she recalled the episode, highlighted by a reading of her Vedic chart, with mock incredulity. “Oh, madam, by golly, this chart is very unique,’ ” she was told. “ ’By 2012, you could be asking for the Taj Mahal — and you would get it.’ ”

headline: Hot Off the Press | Kiosk Paper
text: Alisa Grifo and Marco ter Haar Romeny started Kiosk with an especially infectious idea: to highlight functional design goods from around the world, focusing on one country at a time. Their store, perched one floor above SoHo’s Spring Street, opened in 2005, and its concept quickly caught on. They now curate small international pop-ups, including one in the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum’s famed gift shop.

headline: U.S. Companies, Hiring Abroad
text: American-owned multinational companies grew in 2010, but they mostly grew abroad.

headline: Enjoying Turntables Without Obsessing
text: Buying records is easy. You can find them by the milk crate at yard sales, for a few dollars apiece in used record stores, and there are new, special pressings by contemporary musicians like Shelby Lynne, whose “Just a Little Lovin’” album, at $30, is a top seller. But buying the instrument needed to listen to them, a turntable, is a different matter.

headline: Do Romney’s Favorability Ratings Matter?
text: Mitt Romney’s personal favorability ratings have been relatively poor throughout this election cycle. In his best surveys, roughly equal numbers of Americans have said they hold favorable and unfavorable impressions of Mr. Romney while in other cases they have been substantially net-negative.

headline: PayPal Strength Helps eBay Exceed Forecasts
text: EBay, the Web site where people once auctioned off the detritus of attics and garages, is quietly positioning itself to become a force in mobile retailing, as evidenced by a sustained turnaround of its Internet marketplace and the soaring popularity of the PayPal online payment system.

headline: The Yoga Mogul’s Sordid Fall
text: Back in 2010, Mimi Swartz wrote a profile in The Times Magazine of John Friend, the founder of Anusara Yoga, who at the time was expanding his brand of feel-good yoga to 200,000 students in 70 countries and was planning a huge arts-and-yoga center in Encinitas, Calif.

headline: Rice Noodle Salad With Crispy Tofu and Lime-Peanut Dressing
text: Unrefined expeller-pressed peanut oil contributes a wonderful nutty flavor to this dressing.

headline: Why Was Warren Buffett Screened for Prostate Cancer?
text: A day after Warren Buffett announced he had prostate cancer, the question on the minds of many men and their doctors is this: “Why was an 81-year-old man screened for the disease in the first place?”

headline: Share Your Memories of Dick Clark and New Year’s Eve
text: Dick Clark, who died on Wednesday, helped make rock ‘n’ roll a staple of American pop culture with “American Bandstand.”

headline: A Swiss-E.U. Battle Over (European) Immigrants
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union reacted angrily Wednesday to a move by Switzerland to stem a recent wave of immigrants from central and eastern Europe, calling it discriminatory and unjustified.

headline: For a Closing School, Mock Trial Team Successes Are Bittersweet
text: The mock trial team from Grace Dodge  Career & Technical High School gave it their best, but they lost to Hunter College High School in a citywide competition. It was a disappointing loss, considering the school is scheduled for phase out, and neither students nor their coach know whether the mock trial team will continue as the school shrinks every year until closing.

headline: Photos of Soldiers Posing With Body Parts Add Strain to a Taxed Relationship
text: The United States presence in Afghanistan received another political black eye on Wednesday after The Los Angeles Times published photographs apparently showing United States soldiers posing with body parts of dead insurgents. Reacting quickly, a wide assortment of American officials, all the way up to President Obama, condemned the actions. Our colleagues Graham Bowley and Alissa J. Rubin report that Leon E. Panetta, the defense secretary, said of the photographs: “This is not who we are, and it’s certainly not what we represent when it comes to the great majority of men and women in uniform.” President Obama called for an investigation of the matter and said that those responsible would be held accountable, according to the White House.

headline: On and Off the Clock, Conduct Matters
text: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

headline: In Rome, Art Meets Astronomy
text: Rome’s artistic bent would usually be described as a mix of Renaissance and Baroque, with dusting of ancient. But through April 22, the Fondazione Alda Fendi is showing “Transit of Venus,” its new Esperimenti, which runs counter to that trend. This event, the latest in occasional multimedia shows that blend projection and displays, is a collaboration between Alda Fendi of the fashion house of the same name, and the curator Raffaele Curi. It is loosely inspired by the passage of Venus between the Earth and the Sun, estimated to happen June 6.

headline: Reporter in Azerbaijan Beaten After Filming Dispute
text: MOSCOW — An Azeri newspaper reporter was severely beaten by guards from Azerbaijan’s state oil company on Tuesday when he tried to film the demolition of houses by company employees.

headline: UBS’s Stenzler Departs as Co-Head of U.S. Mergers
text: UBS’s co-head of mergers and acquisitions in the United States, Ehren Stenzler, has left the firm, a spokesman for the Swiss firm said on Wednesday. It is the second prominent departure from the investment bank in two days.

headline: Italdesign-Giugiaro Maintains Traction With a Longtime Client
text: Giorgetto Giugiaro and his firm Italdesign recently unveiled new designs for an old client, demonstrating that the studio has retained customers since its acquisition by the Volkswagen Group in 2010.

headline: ‘It’s Not You, It’s Me,’ We Tell Our Clothes
text: CATHY BEGIEN estimates she has purchased 50 shirts from Steven Alan, the house brand of the independent-design hub based in downtown Manhattan. “I loved their washed-out, wrinkly, comfy preppiness,” said Ms. Begien, 36, a brand manager for a designer, who lives in the West Village. “I loved having a brand-new one because it smelled a certain way.”

headline: In a ‘Prebuttal,’ Romney Attacks Obama’s Economic Record
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Mitt Romney on Wednesday issued a withering dissection of President Obama’s speech at the Democratic National Convention in Denver four years ago, delivering a point-by-point rebuttal of what he said were his opponent’s unfulfilled promises to revive the economy.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Alex Prager’s ‘Compulsion’
text: Alex Prager, whose work has appeared in The Times Magazine, has a new must-see exhibition: “Compulsion,” showing at the Yancey Richardson Gallery in New York. In addition to photographs, Prager puts forth a beautiful short film, “La Petite Mort.” Prager’s witty take on orgasm brings high drama and humor together in a most unusual way.

headline: Ambitious Photo Tools That Won’t Make You Feel Dumb
text: If you want to share a photo on the fly, there’s Instagram, and then there’s everyone else.

headline: Stone Links: The Unanswered Question
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Mexico and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Mexico, Gaza, South Korea and Afghanistan.

headline: And the Walls Came Tumbling Down, Again
text: JANET W. FOSTER, a Columbia University architectural historian, is well versed in the nuances of the Dutch-American farmhouse, the slope of a Queen Anne, the hue of a Downingesque cottage.

headline: London Debut for Sundance
text: LOS ANGELES — This is typically the time of the year when John Cooper, the director of the Sundance Film Festival, catches his breath. The art house spotlight has moved on to New York, where the Tribeca Film Festival started Wednesday. The Cannes Film Festival will take over from there. The next Sundance? Still a safe nine months away.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Earnings Slip
text: Bank of New York Mellon reported Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings fell 1 percent as revenue lost from the sale of a unit and lower foreign-exchange trading offset gains from rising asset levels.

headline: The Church Versus the Right
text: In February, the Catholic Church attempted to impose its opposition to birth control on its employees, upsetting Democrats and the left. This week, the Church is criticizing Republicans, acting in the highest tradition of its social mission by speaking out against spending cuts on programs for the poor.

headline: Of Pretzels, Space Heaters and the Fate of the Planet
text: A reader in New Mexico, John Mihelich, raises an interesting question about my recent article  about a climate change poll. The poll showed that a large majority of the public believes that global warming is influencing the weather in the United States and that it probably made some recent weather disasters worse.

headline: Digital Notes: Coke and Spotify Team Up to Go Everywhere
text: Can Coke help bring Spotify to all the corners of the world?

headline: TimesCast | Photos Strain Relations
text: April 18, 2012 — In Afghanistan, newly released photos strain already tense relations with the United States.

headline: Swingin’ on the Moon to Las Vegas Lounge Music
text: The wild party continues at the Iridium, where the singer and bandleader Terese Genecco recently celebrated her third anniversary of once-a-month Tuesday-evening performances with her raucous eight-piece Little Big Band. This spiky-haired self-described “love child of Dean Martin and Judy Garland” is a natural extrovert whose combined roles of performer, bandleader and M.C. make her a gregarious cheerleader for the brassy ’50s and ’60s Las Vegas lounge music she adores.

headline: Apollo Raises Bid for Great Wolf to $7 a Share
text: The battle for Great Wolf Resorts isn’t over yet.

headline: Rock’s Most Benign Satisfactions
text: Pick your poison: the simp or the cad. Being held through the night or getting a high five on the way out the door. Warm and fuzzy or cold and brusque. Pretty lies or ugly truth.

headline: Are Most People in Denial About Their Weight?
text: As I was walking through the gym the other day, I caught a glimpse of an overweight woman across the room. But then I did a double take, and then another. The woman was me — I had seen my own reflection in a distant mirror and, for a split second, hadn’t recognized myself.

headline: Dick Clark’s Insight — Tape New Year’s Stars in August
text: Ted Harbert, the chairman of NBC Broadcasting, said that one of Dick Clark’s great strengths was that “he was a great booker. He knew that stars made the rating for these shows.” One of his most brilliant coups, Mr. Harbert said, was how he assembled the New Year’s Eve show.

headline: Seeing Scipio Through Eyes of Mozart as a Teenager
text: Back in 2001, when the Gotham Chamber Opera was known as the Henry Street Chamber Opera, it introduced itself with the American stage premiere of a bona fide Mozart rarity, “Il Sogno di Scipione”: a work that the composer wrote when he was 15 but that apparently went unperformed until 1979. The staging, by Christopher Alden, was modern and quirky, and a universe removed from the vision of mythical antiquity that Mozart imagined. But it was a hit, and the company quickly found its footing as a purveyor of unusual works, old and new.

headline: Vatican Reprimands a Group of U.S. Nuns and Plans Changes
text: The Vatican has appointed an American bishop to rein in the largest and most influential group of Catholic nuns in the United States, saying that an investigation found that the group had “serious doctrinal problems.”

headline: Guitars Ring With Harmonious Humility, as Youth Meets Age
text: Innocence and experience have almost always found a meeting place in jazz, which by its nature produces an endless tide of youthful prodigies and wise old men. There’s nothing unusual about the exchange of insight across generations, but occasionally you see it happen in real time, as clearly as a light bulb flicking on in the room. That’s the case at the Blue Note this week, where the venerable guitarist Jim Hall has augmented his working trio with a second guitar player, the bright-eyed virtuoso Julian Lage.

headline: 3 in Scandal Being Forced Out of Secret Service, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — Three Secret Service employees implicated in a prostitution scandal during President Obama’s trip to Colombia last week are being forced out of the agency.

headline: A Prefab, Short on the Fab
text: WEST HURLEY, N.Y.

headline: Regulators Defend Derivatives Rule
text: Regulators approved a rule on Wednesday that spells out the type of derivatives dealers that will soon face federal oversight, a crucial piece of the broader regulation for the market that played a major role in the financial crisis.

headline: It’s Not About Winning the Game
text: Ruth Fremson has photographed a number of schools over the years, but she’s gained  full access into only one, in 2007, at a high-achieving public high school in Massachusetts.

headline: Mark Bittman on the Art of Making Pizza
text: Mark Bittman (who thinks the pizza you cook yourself is better than any you could buy) answered your pizza-making questions on The New York Times Facebook page Wednesday afternoon; below are highlights from the conversation. For recipes, how-to videos and more, let the Pizza Issue be your guide: nytimes.com/pizza.

headline: The New York Times/CBS Poll
text: The results from the latest New York Times/CBS poll on the 2012 presidential race.

headline: Unearthing Dwellers of an Aquatic Past
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 13 through 17 with 957 adults throughout the United States.

headline: In Wariness on Economy, Poll Finds Opening for Romney
text: A rising number of Americans see improvement in the economy, but a persistent wariness about their own financial circumstances is allowing Mitt Romney to persuade voters that he could improve their economic prospects more than President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: A Home in The Farmhouse Style in Malta
text: A four-bedroom house, built using the limestone of a dismantled 18th-century Maltese palace, has the solid frame of a traditional Maltese farmhouse, but a fully modernized interior.

headline: House Hunting in ... Malta
text: A HOME IN THE FARMHOUSE STYLE IN MALTA

headline: Dick Clark Dies at 82
text: Dick Clark, the television host of “American Bandstand,” did much to advance the influence of teenagers and rock ’n’ roll on American culture.

headline: Homes for $500,000
text: Properties in Texas, Chicago and Washington, D.C.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: TAYLOR, TEX.

headline: Views on the 2012 Election, Candidates and the Economy
text: Results from nationwide telephone interviews conducted April 13-17 with 957 adults, including 852 registered voters.

headline: Devils Still Put Their Faith in Brodeur
text: NEWARK — The Devils have much more pressing issues these days than their goaltender. They need to cut back on their penalties, for one, because the Florida Panthers are carving them apart with their efficient power play during the teams’ first-round playoff series.

headline: Barcelona Ballet at City Center
text: The dancer Ángel Corella brought his company to City Center on Tuesday.

headline: In the Catskills, Assembled From a Kit
text: A modern prefab house made of galvanized steel is awash in light and air.

headline: House Passes Transportation Extension
text: The House on Wednesday easily passed the 10th stop-gap measure extending existing transportation law, this time through September — adding the Keystone XL Pipeline into the mix.

headline: Saving an Officer’s Life, With Running Clothes Beneath His Scrubs
text: View more videos at: http://nbcnewyork.com.

text: STUART LESLIE is an industrial designer who has helped develop a surprisingly broad range of consumer products, from home appliances to the packaging for single servings of Heinz ketchup.

headline: Embracing Spanish Heritage and Riding a City’s Energy
text: Dancers like Ángel Corella are hard to come by, and that speaks to more than just the radiance of his technique. He’s generous with his talent too. On Tuesday evening Mr. Corella returned to City Center with his Barcelona Ballet, formed in 2008 as Corella Ballet Castilla y León.

headline: Radicchio or Asian Greens Salad With Golden Beets and Walnuts
text: Walnut vinaigrette is especially compatible with bitter greens like radicchio and pungent Asian greens. Both work beautifully here.

headline: 007 Shakes Things Up in Istanbul
text: While much of Istanbul is beaming with pride that it was chosen as a location for ‘‘Skyfall,’’ the next movie in the James Bond series, some merchants in the Old City seem to be shaken, not stirred.

headline: Sales at Mitchell Gold + Bob Williams and Others
text: Upholstery is 20 percent off and floor models are 30 percent off at Lekker Home, through April 22 with the code “springbreak” (the Dromedary love seat by John Derian, originally $2,850, is $2,280); 1317 Washington Street, Boston, (617) 542-6464, lekkerhome.com.

headline: Brooklyn Toile, Graffiti and All
text: The traditional toile pattern depicts pastoral scenes, but the wallpaper company Flavor Paper is reinventing it with three new Brooklyn-themed designs.

headline: Scene City: Vanity Fair Kicks Off Tribeca Film Festival
text: Movie stars, power players and politicos turned out for Vanity Fair’s annual Tribeca Film Festival party.

headline: Dartmouth Chooses Architects for Revamping of Art Museum
text: Dartmouth College has selected Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects to design a major expansion and renovation of its Hood Museum of Art, the college announced on Wednesday.  The Hood’s collection has increased to more than 70,000 works and the project, which will increase gallery space at the museum’s 1985 building and add classrooms, new entrance areas and amenities, is part of Dartmouth’s new Arts District.

headline: Tumi Prices I.P.O. at $18 a Share, Above Estimated Range
text: Tumi is packed and ready for its initial public stock offering.

headline: Oven-Roasted Salmon, Quinoa and Asparagus With Wasabi Oil
text: Seasoned oils like the wasabi oil I buy at my local specialty grocery can embellish a simply cooked piece of fish, a bowl of grains or steamed vegetables. Here the salmon is cooked in the oven, and the wasabi-seasoned oil (mine is canola oil-based) is drizzled on just before serving. It’s served with quinoa, which you can also dress with the oil, and vegetables in season.

headline: Brooklyn Museum’s Feminist Art Post to Become Permanent
text: Elizabeth A. Sackler, the art collector and philanthropist, announced a major donation to the Brooklyn Museum at its Brooklyn Ball gala benefit on Wednesday evening, where she was an honoree. Ms. Sackler, whose gift created the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art five years ago at the museum, announced a seven-figure donation to support the establishment of a permanent curator of feminist art for the institution.

headline: Deconstructing the Pulitzer Fiction Snub
text: To the Editor:

headline: Independents in Washington
text: Artists, actors and shopkeepers are turning a once gritty stretch of 14th Street into a creative corridor.

headline: The NK Shop Moves to a New Space in Los Angeles
text: After three years on Highland Avenue in Hollywood, Todd Nickey and Amy Kehoe have moved their beloved NK Shop, and their interiors business, to the heart of the Los Angeles design district. They merged two storefronts on Beverly Boulevard into a 3,200-square-foot retail space with plenty of room to display their own furniture line, as well as tabletop and decorative accessories (by the likes of Olmay Home, Campo de’ Fiori and Terrafirma) and vintage pieces.

headline: Donna, in Williamsburg, Brings Back the Patina of the Old
text: Nobody can patina like Evan and Oliver Haslegrave, the brothers, ages 29 and 32, who have designed so many of a certain type of neo-antique East Village, Lower East Side and Brooklyn establishment in recent years: two bars (Elsa and Duck Duck) and three restaurants (Paulie Gee’s, Manhattan Inn and Goat Town), as well as a beer store, an ice-cream parlor and a clothing boutique. They are distinguished by the Haslegraves’ exquisite lighting and handcrafted details, and recall the McNally brothers in their early years.

headline: A Garden Inspired by Mexico
text: The vast majority the of 3,000 plants in John G. Fairey’s Texas garden are from seeds of heat-tolerant natives of the area.

headline: Growing From His Mistakes
text: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.

headline: Greenhill Swings to a 1st-Quarter Profit
text: Greenhill & Company reported a $16.1 million profit for its first quarter, swinging from a loss a year ago as the firm benefited from a 51 percent surge in advisory revenue.

headline: Gardening Advice From John G. Fairey
text: JOHN G. FAIREY has much to teach gardeners, in his offhand way, when they visit.

headline: On the Road to the Cannabis Cup
text: It may not be celebrated like roses or orchids, but marijuana is a flowering plant all the same, with a community of growers dedicated to its propagation (and boosting THC content). Each November, the best of them gather in Amsterdam for the High Times Cannabis Cup, a kind of taste-off for the stoner set.

headline: Qualcomm Beats Forecast, but Strains to Get Chips
text: Qualcomm, the largest maker of mobile phone semiconductors, reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street’s expectations on Wednesday, but it also forecast disappointing sales and profit for the current quarter as it increases spending to improve output of new chips for smartphones.

headline: Yum’s Profit Jumps 73%, Helped by Taco Bell Sales
text: Yum Brands, the owner of the KFC and Pizza Hut restaurant brands, said Wednesday that its first-quarter profit rose 73 percent as new menu items at the Taco Bell chain helped its same-store sales rebound.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. What’s the best way to declutter my home before I show it to potential buyers? Can I leave packed boxes in a corner or do I need to move things into storage?

headline: Where Art and Design Meet
text: The 15th annual Sculpture Objects and Functional Art Fair opens on Friday at the Park Avenue Armory, with more than 50 galleries showing studio art and design, all for sale and open to the public.
