headline: Mixed Pairs Winners at Spring Nationals
text: The winners of the Rockwell Mixed Pairs at the Spring Nationals in Memphis last month were Sheila Gabay of Newton, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass. They finished two-thirds of a board ahead of Bernace De Young of Miami and Richard Reitman of Los Gatos, Calif. Third were Les and Gloria Bart, a husband and wife from Bradenton, Fla.

headline: Antibiotics in Livestock
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bills Seek to Change Rule on Generic Drug Labels
text: Democrats in the Senate and House introduced companion bills Wednesday that would permit generic drug companies to update warning information about the drugs they manufacture, a change that could allow patients to sue the companies for failing to warn about the risks of taking their drugs.

headline: Lionel Richie on Top After 26 Years
text: After 26 years Lionel Richie is No. 1 again. Mr. Richie’s latest album, “Tuskegee” (Mercury Nashville), with new country versions of his old hits like “Hello” and “Easy,” made with stars like Shania Twain and Willie Nelson, is on the top of Billboard’s album chart in its third week of release. Helped by a prime-time special last week on CBS, “Tuskegee” sold 128,553 copies, the label announced, a 35 percent jump from the previous week. It is Mr. Richie’s first No. 1 album since “Dancing on the Ceiling” in 1986, which featured hits like “Say You, Say Me” and the title track. Adele’s “21” (XL/Columbia) holds at No. 2, with 92,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, which rounds its publicly reported numbers to the nearest thousand. Nicki Minaj’s “Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded” (Young Money/Cash Money/Universal Republic), which opened at No. 1 last week, fell to No. 3, with 81,000 sales, a 68 percent drop. And the British boy band One Direction — not to be confused with the American group One Direction, now suing the British group over its use of the name — holds at No. 5, with 66,000 sales of its debut, “Up All Night” (Syco/Columbia). Also this week, two new albums charted high: “New Life” (RCA) by the R&B singer Monica  is No. 4, with 69,000, and “Slipstream” (Redwing) by Bonnie Raitt opened at No. 6, with 64,000, her highest-charting album and best sales week in 18 years, Billboard reported.

headline: Witness Describes Bomb-Making Process for Thwarted Subway Plot
text: The ingredients could be found in supermarkets, beauty shops and hardware stores. They included seemingly innocuous items like flour, butter, batteries, a two-liter soda bottle and Christmas lights. And, the man added, ball bearings.

headline: Anticipating Space Shuttle’s Arrival, Old Warplanes Ship Out
text: On the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Intrepid, sacrifices had to be made.

headline: John Golding Dies at 82; Zeroed In on Abstraction
text: John Golding, an English art critic, scholar and painter who courted abstraction in every facet of his career — seeking to define it in the work of others and to produce it in his own — died on April 9. He was 82.

headline: Canada: Request to Leave Guantánamo
text: Omar Khadr has applied to be transferred to a prison in Canada from Guantánamo Bay to serve the remainder of his sentence for war crimes. Mr. Khadr, a Canadian, was captured in Afghanistan in 2002 after a firefight that left an American sergeant, Christopher Speer, dead. In 2010, a United States military commission sentenced Mr. Khadr, who was 15 at the time of the episode, to 40 years in prison, but he is only required to be imprisoned for a maximum of 8 years under the terms of a plea bargain. The Conservative government had been reluctant to repatriate him. But a government official, who declined to be identified because of restrictions on discussing negotiations with other governments, said American officials had asked for his application to be granted as “a diplomatic favor.”

headline: Tunnel and Dredging Projects to Make Room for Bigger Ships in Harbor
text: The Panama Canal was more than 2,000 miles away, but very much on the minds of the officials who stood next to a hulking machine on Staten Island on Wednesday to announce a project that involves building a water tunnel to Brooklyn and dredging New York Harbor to make room for deeper cargo ships.

headline: In a Shift, Medicare Pushes Bids
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that it would vastly expand the use of competitive bidding to buy medical equipment for Medicare beneficiaries after a one-year experiment saved money for taxpayers and patients without harming the quality of care.

headline: Bloomberg Calls for Residential Smoking Rules
text: The owners of residential buildings would have to adopt smoking policies and disclose them to prospective apartment buyers and tenants, under a law proposed Wednesday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has made curbing smoking a cornerstone of his public health policy.

headline: ‘I Won the Ballgame’
text: HUNTINGDON, Tenn. — It was a last chance. The score was close. And Tonya Lutz was not going to let the opportunity slip.

headline: Guantánamo Trials Should Be Open
text: LAST week I stood before a military judge at Guantánamo Bay to argue that the press and public had a constitutional right to observe the proceedings of military commissions. It is an argument I’ve made scores of times on behalf of news organizations objecting to closed proceedings in criminal and civil trials, but this was the first time that a military commission — part of a system of tribunals created in 2006 to try terrorism suspects — agreed to hear such arguments from the press.

headline: U.S. Caps Emissions in Drilling for Fuel
text: WASHINGTON — Oil and gas companies will have to capture toxic and climate-altering gases from wells, storage sites and pipelines under new air quality standards issued on Wednesday by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Early Bloomers
text: THE naturalist and philosopher Henry David Thoreau coined a wonderful word for an imagined instrument in his 1854 book, “Walden”: the “realometer.” Thoreau’s realometer would allow an inquiring person to measure the reality of his perceptions, to push past the “mud and slush of opinion, and prejudice, and tradition, and delusion, and appearance ... to a hard bottom.”

headline: NATO After Libya
text: NATO can be proud of the role it played in supporting the overthrow of Libya’s murderous dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. But the alliance’s own confidential assessment, reported in The Times on Sunday, pointed out that European members, who were among the first to call for military action, could never have pulled it off without extensive American involvement.

headline: In a Semifinal, One Shot by Chelsea Foils Many Chances by Barcelona
text: LONDON — The pressure was withering, two dozen shots whizzing past, the team’s own control of the ball infrequent. But Chelsea knew that its patience and muscularity had given trouble through the years to Barcelona’s finesse.

headline: On Broadway, Investors With Shallow Pockets
text: Broadway musicals usually cost $5 million to $10 million to produce, and that money often comes in checks for $50,000 or more from experienced investors who wouldn’t mind the tax write-off if their show flops. But this season’s revival of “Godspell” has introduced a new breed: shareholders who have put as little as $1,000 each into the $5 million musical and in return have gotten a rare inside look at show business, including the ear of the lead producer.

headline: The Intrepid Prepares for the Enterprise
text: The Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum of New York City removed three planes from its deck in preparation for the arrival of the Enterprise, the prototype for space shuttles.

headline: Neighbor’s Wet Concrete Floods Hotel Cafe
text: A wall gave way on the first floor of Le Parker Meridien hotel in Midtown Manhattan late Wednesday morning and sent concrete spewing into the hotel coffee bar from a construction site next door, the city’s Buildings Department said.

headline: Women’s Work
text: We’re accustomed to talking about a “divided” Supreme Court, riven with ideological conflict. But a mean little 5-to-4 decision that the court issued last month all but overlooked in the breathless run-up to the Affordable Care Act arguments, suggests another kind of divide as well: a gender gap.

headline: Speculators and the Gas Pump
text: No matter what Mitt Romney and other Republicans say, there are no easy fixes for rising gas prices. With the national average price hovering near $4 a gallon, Americans are understandably concerned, and President Obama was right to call for more scrutiny of the oil markets.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 5
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Need Research on Generation Y? There’s a Film for That
text: NBCUNIVERSAL is forming a unit called Curve Films, but there is no intention for it to compete with siblings at the company like Universal Pictures or Universal Television.

headline: Hit on Hossa Draws Suspension and Adds to Safety Concerns
text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Blackhawks and the Phoenix Coyotes have played three overtime thrillers in the first three games of their series, but the focus at the United Center on Wednesday — as it has been across the N.H.L. throughout the playoffs — was on suspensions, illegal hits and player safety.

headline: In Ohio, Hurdles for Both Candidates
text: ELYRIA, Ohio — The battle for Ohio is on, but for many voters here choosing between President Obama and Mitt Romney is like trying to decide between liver and brussels sprouts — a selection they would rather not have to make.

headline: Ireland Takes Up Bill on Abortion Access
text: DUBLIN — One of the most deeply divisive issues in Irish society was reignited Wednesday night when the Irish Parliament began debate on a bill that would provide for limited access to abortion.

headline: Officials Say a Little Italy Tradition Is Back: The Mob at San Gennaro
text: Little Italy — or Littler Italy, as certain wits have called it — has lost a good deal of its square footage and authentic flavor over the years. Caught between an encroaching Chinatown and a growing SoHo fashion trade, its pork stores and red-sauce joints have been left to huddle largely on its main drag, Mulberry Street. The 2010 census failed to find a single neighborhood resident — not one — who was actually born in Italy.

headline: Birth Control and Teenage Pregnancy
text: An encouraging new report shows a big decline in the rate of teenage births. From 2009 to 2010, the birth rate among young women ages 15 to 19 fell 9 percent, to 34.9 per thousand, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. That is a record low for the 65 years that data have been available, and a remarkable 44 percent drop from the 1991 rate. This good shift is largely the result of an increase in teenagers’ use of birth control — a fact that Congressional Republicans ignore as they seek to dismantle reproductive health programs.

headline: Stabbed in Brain, Officer Escaped ‘Death’s Door’
text: The wild swing connected to the left side of the police officer’s head, a presumed punch until the blood started flowing. The officer, Eder Loor, reached to his temple and felt the handle of a knife.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 18, 2012

headline: NASA Contest Seeks Videos On Its Earth-Probing Efforts
text: NASA is holding a contest in which earthlings are invited to create short videos showing “what you find inspiring and important about the unique view and understanding of Earth provided by NASA science.” Here’s their video promoting the competition, which is open for entries (posted to YouTube) between Earth Day, Sunday, April 22, and May 31:

headline: A Dose of Compassion
text: Medical marijuana, which can help relieve pain and nausea in patients with cancer and other illnesses, is now available in the District of Columbia and 16 states, including New Jersey. There is no reason patients in New York State, who are under the care of doctors, should be deprived of this useful treatment.

headline: For Senate Democrats, Vote Revolves Around Women
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans have seized on gas prices as their motivating political issue of the moment. House Democrats cling to the Ryan budget as the document that is going to propel them back to power when voters recoil at its spending cuts. But the political weapon of choice for Senate Democrats is the plight of women, and they appear to have no intention of letting it go.

headline: Nazareth High School to Remain Open
text: When it was decided that Nazareth High School in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, would close in June, the players on the school’s nationally ranked girls basketball team thought they were leaving their school with a final championship send-off. But on Wednesday the Lady Kingsmen found out they will be back to defend their title in 2013.

headline: Approval Is Seen for Sony’s Takeover of EMI Publishing
text: Sony has won the approval of European regulators for its $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing, a critical step in the company’s bid to create the largest catalog of songs in the world, according to a person briefed on the process.

headline: Not Quite a Teen, Yet Sold for Sex
text: If you think sex trafficking only happens in faraway places like Nepal or Thailand, then you should listen to an expert on American sex trafficking I interviewed the other day.

headline: Rape Suspect Is Freed, Long After a Woman Recants
text: The allegations that the Brooklyn district attorney announced in June were shocking: Four men were accused of abusing a young woman for a decade, raping her and forcing her to have sex with others beginning when she was 13.

headline: Mistaken Identity May Be Closer Than It Appears
text: It’s a rich, slow-spreading smile, like butter melting in a skillet over a low flame. And whenever it creeps across James Corden’s face in the splendidly silly “One Man, Two Guvnors,” which opened on Wednesday night at the Music Box Theater, you know two things for sure: You’re in for trouble, and you’re already hooked. Struggle as you will, there ain’t nothing you can do about it.

headline: A Family Numbed by Grief and Booze
text: Time crawls to a dead stop as you watch “Ninth and Joanie,” a stupefyingly dull drama by Brett C. Leonard presented by the increasingly rudderless Labyrinth Theater Company at the Bank Street Theater. The actual presence of a kitchen sink might enliven Mr. Leonard’s kitchen-sink drama about an Italian-American father and son immured in grief in South Philadelphia. Watching the slow drip of a leaky faucet for two hours would be more entertaining than this misguided production, directed with ponderous indulgence by Mark Wing-Davey.

headline: Outliers
text: Administrivial Leaving on a Jet Plane Alert! I’m all packed and leaving to speak at the Erma Bombeck Writers’ Workshop this weekend, but fear not; there will be Wordplay even in my absence because the emus are just that good. They will also be holding down the fort until I get back, so keep solving and feel free to discuss the puzzles as always. Enjoy your weekend, and I’ll see you for the Monday post.

headline: Corrections: April 19
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Pentagon Sought to Stop Paper From Using Photos
text: The grisly photographs of American soldiers posing with the body parts of Afghan insurgents during a 2010 deployment in Afghanistan were the source of a dispute between The Los Angeles Times and the Pentagon lasting weeks.

headline: Papers Detail BP Settlement in Gulf Oil Spill
text: The estimated multibillion-dollar settlement between BP and lawyers representing individual and business plaintiffs in the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill was fleshed out on Wednesday in hundreds of pages of motions and exhibits.

headline: Do Wealthy Colleges Deserve Their Tax Breaks?
text: Should government change its tax exemption policies for universities as a way of equalizing educational resources in America?

headline: Indian State Finds Itself in Tight Grip of Addiction
text: KAZIKOT VILLAGE, India — In this village not far from the Pakistani border, the wheat harvest is only days away. Water buffaloes are resting in the shade. Farmers are preparing their fields. And drug addicts like Pargat Singh are crouched in the shadows, injecting themselves with cocktails of synthetic drugs.

headline: In Brazil and Elsewhere, Dismay at Argentina’s Nationalization Move
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In a fiery speech justifying her decision to nationalize the oil company YPF, Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, cited her admiration for Petrobras, Brazil’s state-controlled oil giant, and other state oil companies in Latin America.

headline: A Boy’s Fast Fame, Built of Cardboard and Tape
text: LOS ANGELES — On an industrial street lined with auto repair shops, there are few signs that this is the home of an Internet sensation. But slow down at the end of the block, just off the freeway in eastern Los Angeles, where a 9-year-old boy has created a makeshift arcade in his father’s auto parts store with balls, cardboard boxes and tape.

headline: Knicks Say Goodbye to New Jersey
text: NEWARK — The Knicks packed their jerseys and their high-tops, boarded a bus and crossed the Hudson River one final time Wednesday night, not to pay their last respects to the Nets of New Jersey, but to bury them, without sentiment or sympathy.

headline: Penguins Turn Tables and Trounce Flyers
text: PHILADELPHIA — Several questions emerged after the Penguins resurfaced by trouncing the Flyers in Game 4 on Wednesday night, but one above all seemed most relevant: just how did Pittsburgh ever lose? Not the previous three games of this playoff series, but at all?

headline: Missing a Pet Peacock? Coyotes Come to Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — The “urban coyote” problem has come to Atlanta at last.

headline: Seeking the Polish Soul, by Drink and Bite
text: In Poland’s capital, Warsaw, Poles are finding a new confidence in the simpler tastes formerly associated with the smothering grip of Communism.

headline: Flavor of Nostalgia Grows More Appealing to Poles Brimming With Pride
text: WARSAW — The bartenders in white shirts and black bow ties served endless shots of vodka followed by platefuls of herring in oil, and the occasional kielbasa, on small white plates as the crowds eagerly downed their drinks with an enthusiastic toast: “Na zdrowie!” Polish for “Cheers.”

headline: Kuroda Loses Command; Yankees Lose Gardner
text: Hiroki Kuroda was introduced to his new home fans last Friday, when he pitched eight scoreless innings in the Yankees’ home opener. It was a memorable welcome for Kuroda, who last off-season signed a one-year contract to pitch in the Bronx this season. Manager Joe Girardi gushed about his performance. The capacity crowd gave him a standing ovation.

headline: Pakistani Judge Upholds 3 Women’s Conversions
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  — A controversy over religious conversions that has captivated Pakistanis was resolved in dramatic fashion on Wednesday when a judge ruled that three Hindu women who converted to Islam under disputed circumstances had chosen to go with their new Muslim husbands, causing consternation among the families they left behind.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Ellison in Court, and Spectrum Sale
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

headline: Tweaking Iconic Logos, a Student Makes His Mark
text: HONG KONG — Tampering with the world’s most recognized corporate logos can be a dicey enterprise. Why fool around, for example, with the red-and-white swirl of Coca-Cola? Or the once-bitten apple of Apple?

headline: With Rally, Senators Prove to Be Rangers’ Match
text: OTTAWA — The Rangers are facing an opponent as scrappy and resilient as themselves.

headline: Veterans Department to Increase Mental Health Staffing
text: The Department of Veterans Affairs will announce on Thursday that it plans to hire about 1,600 additional psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers and other mental health clinicians in an effort to reduce long wait times for services at many veterans medical centers.

headline: Life, Interrupted: A Young Cancer Patient Faces Infertility
text: The family minivan idles at the intersection of 59th and York in Midtown Manhattan. My boyfriend swabs my midriff with alcohol as he steadies the needle. My parents look on from the front seat, quietly studying their 22-year-old daughter and the young man they’ve known for only a month. The needle is filled with gonadotropin, a hormone that stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. I’m late for my checkup at the fertility clinic.

headline: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 4
text: Henrik Lundqvist made 28 saves, but Ottawa rallied from a two-goal deficit to win.

headline: Focus, People!
text: The general election is off to an inauspicious start.

headline: Word of the Day | ideology
text: ideology •\ˌi-de-ˈä-lə-je, ˌi-\• noun

headline: Love in the Time of Cancer
text: During her yearlong battle with leukemia, Suleika Jaouad’s diagnosis has tested and strengthened her relationship with her boyfriend, who stuck by her side throughout her treatments.

headline: Punjab in the Tight Grip of Addiction
text: In this village not far from the Pakistani border, the wheat harvest is only days away. Water buffaloes are resting in the shade. Farmers are preparing their fields. “And drug addicts like Pargat Singh are crouched in the shadows, injecting themselves with cocktails of synthetic drugs,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times, about Kazikot village in Punjab State.

headline: Test Launch of Agni V, India’s Long-Range Missile
text: “India said Thursday it had successfully launched a missile with nuclear capability and a 3,100-mile range, giving it the ability to strike Beijing and Shanghai,” Hari Kumar and Heather Timmons report in The New York Times.

headline: Signs of an Asian Arms Buildup in India’s Missile Test
text: NEW DELHI — India’s successful test on Thursday of a long-range ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead is the latest escalation of an arms race in Asia, where the assertiveness and rising military power of China has rattled the region and prompted a forceful response from the Obama administration.

headline: After Ugly Incidents, Wondering Where to Assign Blame
text: This is the time of year when the N.H.L. — with the energy and excitement brought by the playoffs — lands on the national stage. From overtime games that can extend into the morning hours, to the fast, physical play to the uncertainty of every series, the league has the ability to attract the casual fan for its postseason.

headline: Bibby Makes Most of a Chance to Contribute
text: NEWARK — The final Knicks-Nets game in New Jersey on Wednesday night bore witness to point-guard matchups that might have left the fans preferring a game of four-on-four had the stakes not been high.

headline: Beijing Auto Show Preview: Mercedes Concept Style Coupe
text: Two years ago at the Beijing auto show, Mercedes-Benz stretched the form language, as well as the spelling, of the shooting brake body style with a design study it called the Concept Shooting Break. Now the German automaker is poised to rekindle the semantics wars with the Concept Style Coupe, a compact four-door vehicle scheduled to make its official debut in Beijing on April 23.

headline: News Quiz | April 19, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: What They Said: India Tests Agni V Nuclear Missile
text: India said Thursday that it had successfully launched a new nuclear-capable missile from Wheeler Island off the coast of Odisha, the eastern state formerly known as Orissa. The missile gives India, for the first time, the capability of striking the Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai. Scientists at India’s Defense Research and Development Organization developed the missile.

headline: A Leader of Jazz at Lincoln Center Steps Down
text: Paul Simon and his band invaded Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday night to raise money for the nonprofit arts institution. Wynton Marsalis and the in-house orchestra backed Mr. Simon up, putting a jazz sheen on a stirring set from the songwriter’s long career.

headline: April 19, 1995 | Timothy McVeigh Bombs Oklahoma City Building
text: On April 19, 1995, a truck bomb exploded outside the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring 500. It was the deadliest terrorist attack on American soil until the events of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: What the World Said: Foreign Reaction to India’s Long-Range Missile Launch
text: Mark Toner, Spokesperson, United States Department of State :“Naturally, I just would say that we urge all nuclear-capable states to exercise restraint regarding nuclear capabilities. That said, India has a solid nonproliferation record. They’re engaged with the international community on nonproliferation issues. And Prime Minister Singh, I believe, has attended both the nuclear – both of the nuclear summit – security summits, the one in Washington and then Seoul.” (Daily Press Briefing)

headline: The First Middle School Chess Champs
text: WHAT is the first middle school team to win the United States Chess Federation’s national high school championship?

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 19, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Obama Is President, but Football Is King.”

headline: Behind the Scenes of Power
text: Never-seen photographs by Garry Winogrand, with audio commentary from George McGovern.

headline: Amazon Creates a Software Rental Store
text: Amazon.com’s Amazon Web Services business, facing looming competition for its business of renting online data storage and computing, is introducing a store where customers will be able to rent business software from a number of third-party providers, including I.B.M., Microsoft and SAP.

headline: Breaking Into Prison
text: Sean Kernan’s noirish photo essay on prison life was not the result of careful planning, research or even an interest in issues of incarceration.

headline: Help Us Identify Who’s in These Photographs
text: This week’s Look features recently discovered photographs by Garry Winogrand from the 1960 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles. To identify the faces in the crowd scenes that Winogrand captured, our photo department and others talked to dozens of people who were at the convention, including George McGovern. (Listen to McGovern’s story about the awkward confrontation at that convention between Robert Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson.)

headline: Is It Ethical to Eat Meat?
text: Herbivore, omnivore or carnivore? Some people just can’t go a day without chicken, steak or fish, while others refuse to eat food that has even touched meat. The Well blog recently wrote about “The Challenges Of Going Vegan” in a society dominated by meat and dairy. Meanwhile, The Ethicist is running an essay contest for adults asking them to “tell us why it’s ethical to eat meat.” What do you think?

headline: South Korea Says It Has New Missile
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea said Thursday that it had developed and deployed a new cruise missile capable of a precision strike anywhere in North Korea.

headline: Pressure Builds for Tougher Line as Syria Is Said to Shun Peace Plan
text: PARIS — International pressure for a harsher line on Syria escalated Thursday, with the president of France calling the Syrian leader a liar, the American secretary of state moving a step closer to endorsing use of military force, and the head of the United Nations accusing the Syrian government of failing to carry out nearly every element of a peace plan that went into effect a week ago.

headline: Cisco Announces Its $850 Million Spin-In
text: Cisco has notified its employees that it has funded an advanced networking startup, called Insieme, with $100 million, with the right to eventually buy the company for as much as $750 million more.

headline: Vodafone’s Legal Notice Against India Could Be Followed by Others
text: British telecom giant Vodafone Group’s legal proceedings against the Indian government, announced Tuesday in reaction to a recent proposed tax change, have little precedent in India, legal experts say.

headline: Post-Prozac Nation
text: Few medicines, in the history of pharmaceuticals, have been greeted with as much exultation as a green-and-white pill containing 20 milligrams of fluoxetine hydrochloride — the chemical we know as Prozac. In her 1994 book “Prozac Nation,” Elizabeth Wurtzel wrote of a nearly transcendental experience on the drug. Before she began treatment with antidepressants, she was living in “a computer program of total negativity . . . an absence of affect, absence of feeling, absence of response, absence of interest.” She floated from one “suicidal reverie” to the next. Yet, just a few weeks after starting Prozac, her life was transformed. “One morning I woke up and really did want to live. . . . It was as if the miasma of depression had lifted off me, in the same way that the fog in San Francisco rises as the day wears on. Was it the Prozac? No doubt.”

headline: ‘Give Me Butter! Always Butter!’
text: Fernand Point was not one of your gym-going, globe-trotting, Ph.D.-equipped chefs. He was a roast-chicken-for-breakfast-eating, two-bottles-of-Champagne-at-lunch-drinking, big fat (no way around it) guy, the stereotype of the mid-20th-century French chef and almost without question the most influential of his time.

headline: Would You Trust Ridejoy’s Web Site?
text: Last year, three friends who were making arrangements to drive to the famous Burning Man festival in Nevada’s Black Rock Desert concluded that there was great interest in ride-sharing but no easy way to match up those who had space in their cars with those who needed rides and would help pay for gas and other expenses. So they set up Burningmanrides.com.

headline: Britain vs. the European Court of Human Rights
text: LONDON — The British government found itself in a right royal pickle on Thursday on the issue of European human rights law over its bid to deport a radical Muslim cleric reputedly linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Valued at $104 Billion
text: Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion in early April, agreeing to pay roughly 30 percent in cash and 70 percent in stock. At that level, Facebook is pegging its value at north of $75 billion. But Facebook could actually be worth more, reports Evelyn M. Rusli of DealBook.

headline: Nokia Posts $1.2 Billion Loss as Phone Sales Tumble
text: Nokia, struggling to reinvent its smartphone business around Microsoft’s Windows Phone software, said Thursday that it might have to cut prices of its cheaper Lumia models to keep its new phones competitive in some markets.

headline: Ford to Build Plant in China to Bolster Global Sales

But they warn that unless proposals to reconfigure water distribution along the Klamath River are enacted, the problem could recur.

headline: Cannes Film Festival Lineup Is Unveiled
text: David Cronenberg, Lee Daniels, Walter Salles, Ken Loach and Michael Haneke will be among the directors vying for the Palme d’Or at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. The slate of 22 features that will be shown in competition at the festival, which runs from May 16 through 27 and will open with Wes Anderson’s latest film, “Moonrise Kingdom,” also includes “The Paperboy,” a drama directed by Mr. Daniels (“Precious”), adapted from the Pete Dexter novel and starring Nicole Kidman, Matthew McConaughey, Zac Efron and John Cusack; a film version of Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road,” directed by Mr. Salles (“Dark Water”); “Amour,” a new work by Mr. Haneke, a previous Palme d’Or winner for “The White Ribbon”; and “The Angels’ Share,” a comic caper from Mr. Loach, who received that award for “The Wind That Shakes the Barley.” Mr. Cronenberg’s adaptation of the Don DeLillo novel “Cosmopolis,” featuring the “Twilight” star Robert Pattinson, will also be in competition, while “Antiviral,” the debut film by his son, Brandon Cronenberg, will be among the features shown in the festival’s Un Certain Regard lineup. Other much anticipated works by filmmakers like Paul Thomas Anderson and Terrence Malick were not completed in time for the festival’s deadlines, Cannes director Thierry Frémaux said.

headline: Testing Takes Its Toll on Special Needs Students
text: It has been a challenging week for many third- through eighth-grade public school students in New York City, as they have started their days on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday with the federally mandated English Language Arts exams. But as Gotham Schools reported on Wednesday, the week has been especially challenging for some students with special needs.

text: The New York Times Company reported a large gain in first-quarter net income on Thursday, driven mainly by the sale of its regional newspapers, the sale of part of its stake in a New England sports group and an increase in circulation revenue at its flagship newspaper.

headline: Neeman’s Own
text: JERUSALEM — About two weeks ago, on the eve of Passover, Israel’s justice minister, Yaakov Neeman, dropped a policy bomb. He proposed a bill that would allow a small majority of legislators in the Knesset to reinstate laws struck down by the Supreme Court.

headline: Mayoral Candidates: Beware the Circling Vultures
text: A former deputy schools chancellor writes: 'For the first time in nearly two decades, the next mayor will likely be a Democrat. As a life-long registered Democrat, I look forward to that prospect. However, there are vultures circling this contest who would once again reduce our schools to the patronage mills of yesteryear, when no one was accountable for what happened to our kids.'

headline: Iraq Insurgency Asserts Presence With Wave of Attacks
text: BAGHDAD — A string of deadly explosions and other attacks shook Iraq on Thursday, with bombings in Baghdad and the northern city of Kirkuk resulting in the most fatalities. Over all, nearly three dozen people were killed and more than 100 were wounded, according to security officials.

headline: Easter in Ramallah
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Almost every year for over one hundred years on the Saturday before Orthodox Easter, the main street in Ramallah has been overtaken by marching boy scouts and girl scouts banging drums and blowing trumpets before tens of thousands of onlookers.

headline: 3 Arrested by British in Inquiry on Bribery
text: The British police arrested three people on Thursday as part of an inquiry into accusations of bribery stemming from the news-gathering and corruption scandal that has engulfed Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, the police said, bringing to 46 the number of arrests during more than a year of investigations.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Shooting Stars
text: The Samurai Shopper is not used to being a fly on the wall, but sometimes it’s a real buzz to be one. Recently I hung around the Chelsea Piers watching the photographer Patrick Demarchelier, the hairstylist Serge Normant and the beauty entrepreneur Laura Mercier put together Mercier’s “look” for her spring 2013 cosmetics collection. It was fun traipsing over wires and riffing through racks of tastefully curated coats, ornate necklaces and bales of tulle. And it was an education watching Mercier transform two gorgeous models into even more gorgeous models with makeup on. When makeup personnel at department stores have a go at me, I end up looking like RuPaul, only half as good.

headline: Is This the End of Proper Grammar? Hopefully Not
text: Unsurprisingly, The Associated Press won a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting early this week, for articles about the New York Police Department’s surveillance of Muslim neighborhoods and organizations in the wake of 9/11. Also unsurprising was fresh controversy that the award stirred, given the sensitive subject.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Least Gruesome’ Gruesome War Photos, and ‘Idol’ on Dick Clark
text: The decision by The Los Angeles Times to publish two photographs of American soldiers with the body parts of Afghanistan insurgents came after the strenuous objections of the Pentagon, Brian Stelter reported. The objections were not about embarrassment, the Pentagon’s spokesman insisted in an interview, but about the potential for the photographs to incite violence. The two photographs, out of a total of 18, that The Times published were “the least gruesome,” according to the reporter who obtained them.

headline: Display Space (for You) High Above Broadway
text: Women confident enough to want to see themselves on a billboard in Times Square can have their wish come true this week courtesy of Dove. As part of a new promotion called “Show Us Your Skin” the company will display photographs that women submit of themselves. The photos need not be limited to smiling faces. Women can submit a head shot, a full-body shot or focus on a body part like legs, feet or hands.

headline: A Well-Hydrated Romance, Courtesy of Nicholas Sparks
text: “Of course they killed someone,” I overheard a young woman say to her friend after a screening of “The Lucky One.” “It’s a Nicholas Sparks movie.” And how. This is the seventh of Mr. Sparks’s wildly popular novels to reach the screen, and it seems useful, in the interests of scholarship, to apprehend the “Nicholas Sparks movie” as a genre unto itself, with a distinct set of rules and defining features.

headline: Pat Summitt’s Signature: Success and Dignity
text: It was at once a moment expected and inevitable and yet one with no way to prepare. As Tennessee’s women’s basketball season marched on, it became clear Pat Summitt could not sustain her role as head coach much longer as she battled early onset Alzheimer’s and it became one long goodbye party, but one no one could acknowledge. And when the goodbye was finally uttered on Wednesday, with Summitt abdicating the throne she occupied for 38 years, the reality washed over everyone who is in some degree in her debt. And that would be everyone in the sport.

headline: Ex-Manager Is Sentenced to 18 Months for Harassing Leonard Cohen
text: The sentencing of an ex-business manager who was convicted last week of harassing Leonard Cohen brought no cries of hallelujah from the singer-songwriter, who said he hoped the “one-time friend” would devote herself “to the lowly practices of self-reform,” The Guardian reported.

headline: For Weed Warriors, the Motto Is Endurance
text: To the untrained eye, a weed is just a weed, and few of us can tell a thistle from a teasel. But for Paul Heiple and his team of Weed Warriors, knowing the difference is essential to their work routing out invasive plants that threaten the native species at Edgewood Park, a 500-acre natural preserve that overlooks California’s Silicon Valley.

They were reminders that in the long history of the yacht club, the oldest one on the West Coast, the loss of five sailors last weekend amounted to its greatest tragedy.

headline: Jake Gyllenhaal to Make American Stage Debut at Roundabout

headline: 36 Hours in Puebla, Mexico
text: THIS is a big year for Puebla. Mexico’s fourth-largest city is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Cinco de Mayo, when an outmanned Mexican army defeated the French troops of Napoleon III in 1862. To mark the occasion, the city’s hilltop forts are undergoing major renovations. But this colonial capital, known as one of the safest big cities in the country, is famous for food, not battlefields. Puebla’s namesake dish, mole poblano, will get its moment in the spotlight on May 2 and 3 at the first annual International Mole Festival. But with its intricate facades of Talavera tile, college town cafe culture, mild highland climate and historical sites, Puebla is always worthy of a weekend.

text: CLEVELAND – There are rebuttals, pre-buttals and, as Mitt Romney learned on Tuesday, pre-pre-buttals.

headline: In Case You’re Planning Ahead

Despite recent efforts to push back the beginning of the fashion season by at least a week to give New York designers more time to prepare, an idea that drew resistance from designers in Milan, the show dates are not changing.

headline: Group Shifts From Aiding Schools in Crisis to Those Starting Fresh
text: An organization that occupies a middle ground between those who believe schools should be more like community centers, and the education-reform movement, is expanding into six new schools next year. In the past, the group has typically worked with schools that are already overwhelmed by the problems that students living in poverty often present.

headline: More on Global Warming from a Republican Meteorologist
text: The meteorologist and energy entrepreneur Paul Douglas is keeping up his valuable effort to depoliticize the science pointing to a growing human influence on the climate. Last month, I noted a post in which he described the scientific case posed by the unabated emissions of greenhouse gases. He described himself as a “Republican deeply concerned about the environmental sacrifices some are asking us to make to keep our economy powered-up, long-term.”

headline: My Grandfather’s Life Insurance Policy
text: Assigning yourself a retail value while simultaneously imagining your own death, a k a buying life insurance, has to be one of the world’s most miserable experiences. But for one loyal pool of customers living in the housing projects of Brooklyn’s Brownsville and East New York in the ’70s and ’80s, there was a small consolation prize — my grandfather. Potbellied, with a big bulbous nose, brown polyester suit, and the dopiest, toothiest smile, he was the least smarmy life insurance salesman imaginable.

headline: Reinventing the Third-Year Medical Student
text: A year ahead in medical school, my friend had been a constant source of support and inspiration, offering study tips for courses and warnings about professors and, when he had neither, hilarious spot-on imitations of classmates and teachers. Patients he was beginning to see in his introductory course on the physical exam seemed to adore him, too; a few even wanted to set him up with their daughters.

headline: Christie a Favored Vice-Presidential Pick, Polls Find
text: With the general election race in its early days, the guessing game for vice-presidential nominees has already begun. Mitt Romney has initiated the search for his running mate, and two new polls asked the American public about a number of possible vice-presidential candidates.

headline: Home, Sweet Home
text: In October 1861 Alfred Lewis Castleman, a surgeon in the Fifth Regiment of the Wisconsin Volunteers, described the first death in his regiment. It was not from battle. “The poor fellow died of Nostalgia (home-sickness), raving to the last breath about wife and children,” he wrote. “Deaths from this cause are very frequent in the army.”

headline: App Smart Extra: Direct Your Dreams but Avoid Walruses

text: This Poetry Pairing matches the 2008 poem “Trout” by Kathryn Starbuck with the New York Times article “In Yellowstone, Killing One Kind of Trout to Save Another.”

headline: ‘Elderly’ No More
text: “Have you thought about changing the name of that blog you’re writing for?” Ann Fishman asked. “The boomers aren’t going to like it. They don’t ever want to get old.”

headline: The Recipe in San Antonio: Pace, Space and Parker
text: Before Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra went back to the drawing board after his team’s collapse in the 2011 N.B.A. finals, he first turned to Oregon’s football coach, Chip Kelly. In Kelly’s spread offense Spoelstra saw some of what he desired in his own team: a concrete use of elite athleticism, incredible speed in both personnel and approach, and a firm understanding of how to use the field of play as a tool of legitimate advantage.

headline: A Newsmaker in Every Sense of the Word
text: THE present-day obscurity of Joseph Alsop, a once-feared political pundit, is instructive in many respects, but especially in regard to the fleeting nature of power and fame in Washington. At one point during the Vietnam War, President Lyndon B. Johnson was reported to have commented, when he decided to deploy another 50,000 troops, “There, that should keep Joe Alsop quiet for a while.”

headline: The Get | Gucci Diamantissima Ring
text: While combing through the Gucci archives recently, the creative director Frida Giannini came upon a print — a graphic repeat of tiny diamond shapes that predated the brand’s iconic double G’s. Applied to canvas, it had been used to decorate luggage that couldn’t be made with leather during wartime shortages. Today, it finds a place among Gucci’s fine jewelry as the unifying motif in its new Diamantissima collection. Necklaces, earrings and rings, like the one shown here, all feature elaborate, byzantine latticework in delicate yellow gold. Look, how royal are we!

headline: State Tax Collections Pass Peak From Recession’s Start
text: State tax collections, which during the recession experienced their steepest and longest drop since at least the Great Depression, have been climbing back for the last two years and finally surpassed their previous peaks as 2011 drew to a close, according to a report issued on Thursday.

headline: Romney to Give Commencement Address at Evangelical University
text: Mitt Romney will deliver the commencement address at Liberty University, the evangelical institution founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell in Lynchburg, Va.

headline: Fox News Is Set to Renew O’Reilly and Hannity Through 2016 Elections
text: Whether a Democrat or a Republican is inaugurated president next year, the conservative commentators Bill O’Reilly and Sean Hannity will still be in their respective studios, holding forth for the Fox News Channel.

headline: Was Romney Right About John Kerry?
text: George Romney released 12 years of income tax returns when he ran for president in 1968. George Romney’s son, Mitt, plans to release just two, so his campaign’s looking outside the family for precedent.

headline: On Our Radar: Rising Seas
text: Nearly 300 energy installations in the United States are less than four feet above sea level and will be vulnerable to flooding by 2030, an official from the group Climate Central tells a Senate committee. Among them are natural gas infrastructure, electric power plants and oil and gas refineries. [Climate Central]

headline: Republican Voters in Ohio Give Romney Another Look
text: LORAIN, Ohio – Gail Shinsky, a retired Navy officer, did not vote for Mitt Romney in the Ohio Republican primary a month ago, opting for Rick Santorum instead.

headline: The Case for Starting Mike Bibby
text: Mike Bibby started at point guard as the Knicks played the Nets on Wednesday, filling in for the ill Baron Davis. It was just his second start of the season.

headline: The Man Who Made Rock ’n’ Roll Safe Enough for America
text: Before Ryan Seacrest became the inescapable prince of all media, there was Dick Clark. More soft-spoken and suave than Mr. Seacrest, Mr. Clark was in the right place at the right time at the right age. When he acquired his moniker “America’s oldest teenager,” the concept of a teenager was still a little exotic and even slightly racy; he helped make it a bit less intimidating.

headline: Looking Back at Dick Clark’s New York
text: Dick Clark had a commuter’s relationship with New York — a long-distance commuter’s relationship. He did not arrive on a train from the suburbs; he arrived on a plane from the West Coast.

headline: The Children’s Investment Fund Wages Battle With Coal India
text: MUMBAI, India — In 2010, when the Indian government sold 10 percent of the shares of Coal India, one of the world’s largest coal mine operators, the transaction was a way to raise money to help reduce its budget deficit.

headline: Investigating Mysteries of Polar Bears’ Ancestry With a DNA Lens
text: Polar bears, long thought to have branched off relatively recently from brown bears, developing their white coats, webbed paws and other adaptations over the last 150,000 years or so to cope with life on Arctic Sea ice, are not descended from brown bears, scientists report.

headline: New District Maps Toughen Democrats’ Race for House
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Representative Larry Kissell slid into a diner booth here and sought to explain — with no small amount of irritation, since he has apparently been asked many times — his decision to run in his newly configured House district, in contrast to two fellow North Carolina Democrats who retired rather than risk defeat in districts reshaped by Republicans.

headline: Disgraced Chinese Official’s Loyalists Are Rounded Up for Questioning
text: BEIJING — Officials in critical Communist Party and government posts in Chongqing who are considered loyalists of Bo Xilai, the city’s deposed party chief, are being detained as part of the wide-ranging investigation into Mr. Bo and his family, according to a Chongqing official and other people with knowledge of political appointments in the city.

headline: For Baum and Colgate, a Standout Season
text: The Colgate men’s lacrosse team boasts the best offense in the nation in terms of goals per game, largely due to the outstanding season junior attackman Peter Baum is having. Baum, a product of Portland, Ore., leads the nation in two major offensive categories–total goals and points with 48 and 63 respectively.

headline: Giving Shareholders a Voice
text: Staggered boards have long been a key mechanism for insulating boards of publicly traded firms from shareholders. This year, several institutional investors and a program working on their behalf have used shareholder proposals to move a large number of publicly traded firms away from such structures. Despite strong and expected criticism from the usual suspects, shareholders should welcome and support this work.

headline: Painting Looted by Nazis Is Returned to Owner’s Heirs
text: A painting looted by the Nazis from its Jewish owner more than 70 years ago was returned to his heirs on Wednesday after being loaned to a Florida museum, Reuters reported.

headline: Soon, a Safe Place for Unsteady Bicyclists
text: Even with a widening network of bike lanes, the city’s streets can still be intimidating for children and other New Yorkers trying to bicycle for a wobbly first time.

headline: Tortorella: No Excuses, Time to Grab Back the Momentum
text: The day after their 3-2 overtime loss in Ottawa, the Rangers’ players were given the day off. They had been on the ice for 10 straight days, going back to the first practice last Monday in preparation for their first-round series against the Senators.

headline: Judy Kuhn and Melissa Errico Cast in ‘Passion’ Revival

The show, directed by John Doyle, is to begin performances in February 2013. Additional casting, including the role of the soldier Giorgio, is still to be announced.

headline: Rejecting ‘Buffett Rule,’ House Passes Business Tax Cut

headline: Help in Deciding if Medical Tests Are Needed

headline: ‘It’s More Than a School': Proposing Programs to Meet Student Needs
text: Overview | What needs do various school populations have? How do schools meet those needs? Students consider the story of Carroll Academy, a Tennessee school run by a juvenile court, and how the school uses compulsory participation in basketball to provide structure for its female students. Then they think about the needs and existing programs at their own school, and then propose new programs to serve unmet needs.

headline: Devoted but Dateless
text: A CLOSE friend keeps saying: “Just lie about it on the first few dates. It’ll be all right.” She means lie about age. Not mine, though — my son’s.

headline: And So, Once Again, We Delay Our Big New Project
text: This is getting a little embarrassing. Twice now I have written about a new program that I think is going to allow us to dramatically expand our recycling efforts. Both times — when I first mentioned the program eight months ago and when I wrote about it again almost two months ago — I thought we were just a few weeks from introducing the program. Both times I was wrong. We have now determined that we are about six months away.

headline: An Opposite View
text: Our dining room windows and front porch face directly into an eyesore apartment across a small courtyard. We look at torn, roll-down curtains with mold and water damage, and a broken window that’s been repaired by shoving a sofa cushion into the gap and securing it with duct tape. Would it be rude to write a letter to the tenant offering to pay for repairs and new curtains? Maybe including a check and nice note?

headline: Digital Notes: Sony’s EMI Deal Is Approved by Europe
text: As expected, the European Commission has given approval to Sony’s $2.2 billion bid for EMI Music Publishing. To satisfy regulators’ concerns about how the deal would influence the online music market, Sony agreed to divest itself of  several song catalogs worth about $35 million in annual revenue. Universal’s $1.9 billion offer for EMI’s record labels is still being investigated in Europe. Both deals are also being reviewed in the United States by the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Out There | Consumer Culture

These are some of the “concepts” invented and explored by K-HOLE, a “trend forecasting report” collaboratively published by Greg Fong, Sean Monahan, Emily Segal, Chris Sherron and Dena Yago, five New York mid-20-somethings who straddle art, marketing and the fractal of grays between the two.

headline: Colin Spencer’s Taramosalata
text: I mentioned that Colin Spencer gave me lunch, and perhaps you saw the picture of him picking greens in his garden. Those made a lovely spring salad, along with which we had bread, scallops (with roe; they still do that throughout the U.K., happily) sautéed in butter and served with a brilliant sorrel sauce, and three beautiful local cheeses.

The dance would apply Mr. Brown’s deep understanding of the African diaspora to the company’s Latino heritage, by way of the Peruvian singer and preservationist of Afro-Peruvian culture Susana Baca.

headline: Getting in Ahmadinejad’s Face
text: Although Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s visit to a disputed island in the Persian Gulf, claimed by both Iran and the United Arab Emirates, created an international incident last week, video posted online later appears to show that Iran’s president was also forced to engage in what Americans call retail politics during his visit to the region.

headline: Reggae’s Mellow King, Defined by a Legacy He Couldn’t Outrun
text: A thorn in the side of the Jamaican reggae superstar Bob Marley was his lack of a black audience in the United States even at the height of his career. But in September 1980, eight months before his death at 36, that began to change with a triumphant engagement at Madison Square Garden, where he and his band, the Wailers, opened for the Commodores. The next day, according to “Marley,” a riveting two-and-a-half-hour documentary biography directed by Kevin Macdonald, he collapsed while running in Central Park. When examined, he was found to have inoperable, late-stage cancer.

headline: Candidate Is Said to Quit House Race in Queens
text: The field for the Democratic nomination in the newly redrawn Sixth Congressional District in Queens just became a little narrower.

headline: Rise in City’s Jobless Rate Continues to Outpace Hiring
text: No matter how much hiring companies in New York City do, the city’s unemployment rate keeps rising.

headline: Ai Weiwei Retrospective at the Hirshhorn
text: So much attention has been paid to Ai Weiwei the Chinese rebel that it seems to have eclipsed Ai Weiwei the artist. A major retrospective at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington this fall, as well as a recent installation and acquisition there, may shift the balance.

headline: The Man Behind the Curtain
text: The subtitle of “Mr. Broadway,” a posthumously published memoir by Gerald Schoenfeld, the longtime chairman of the theatrical powerhouse the Shubert Organization, promises us “The Inside Story of the Shuberts, the Shows, and the Stars.” That’s a pretty accurate description of this straightforward book written by a major player in the theater world for almost half a century, who died in 2008.
