headline: Best Part of the Breakup: New Songs
text: AT 6 p.m. on a Tuesday in mid-March the people streaming into the Living Room, a Lower East Side club geared to singer-songwriters, weren’t there for happy hour. Word had quietly gone out to friends and associates that Norah Jones and her band would be performing songs from her new album, “Little Broken Hearts,” and the small room was packed.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: A Rising Debate on Inequality
text: Beating profits estimates is no longer enough for Wall Street chiefs looking to earn million-dollar raises. That was the message delivered this week from Dallas, New York and London.

headline: Home-Sharing? Don’t Ignore Liability

headline: Finding an End to the Parent-Teacher Wars
text: According to Ron Clark, Disney’s American Teacher of the Year, new teachers remain in our profession an average of just four and a half years, “and many of them list ‘issues with parents’ as one of their reasons for throwing in the towel.”

headline: Airbnb and the Big Liability Insurance Questions
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a look at the liability insurance issues that come up for people who rent their homes (or rooms in their homes) on sites like Airbnb and HomeAway. As in other areas in the burgeoning collaborative consumption movement, like peer-to-peer car-sharing, insurance companies want to know just how much you’re sharing and how many people you’re sharing with.

headline: Penn State-Paterno Rift Gets $5.5-Million Salve
text: Penn State’s announcement that it has paid the Paterno family more than $5.5 million in honoring Joe Paterno’s contract obligations seemed like it might signal that the school and the family of its legendary coach had settled whatever differences might linger over Paterno’s firing. But the family’s lawyer said they have retained the rights to sue the school, even though Penn State had requested a release of that right.

headline: Teach the Books, Touch the Heart
text: FRANZ KAFKA wrote that “a book must be the ax for the frozen sea inside us.” I once shared this quotation with a class of seventh graders, and it didn’t seem to require any explanation.

headline: Tadashi Shoji Designs Gowns for All Silhouettes
text: A fan of stretchy, nonconstrictive fabrics and patterns that prize comfort and wearability, Mr. Shoji does not discriminate against size or age.

headline: The Unforeseen Consequences of the Bahrain Grand Prix
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Formula One completed its first day of practice on Friday. Nico Rosberg, the driver for the Mercedes team who won the race in China last Sunday, completed the fastest lap of the day as protesters gathered for further demonstrations around the capital to coincide with the “three days of rage” that uprising leaders have called for during the three days of the Bahrain Grand Prix.

headline: Red Sox Toast 100 Years at Fenway Park
text: BOSTON – More than 200 former players, including dozens of former fan favorites like Luis Tiant, Carl Yastrzemski, Jim Rice and Pedro Martinez, helped the Boston Red Sox commemorate the 100th anniversary of the opening of Fenway Park on Friday.

headline: Silhouettes Tailored to Every Woman
text: “SHE signed it for me — she is so cute! So sweet!” the designer Tadashi Shoji gushed as he lovingly clutched a piece of paper to his chest. On it was the original sketch he had made of the gown that the actress Octavia Spencer had worn to the Academy Awards in February. Next to the drawing of the gown, an elaborately draped white sheath covered in sparkly beads, Ms. Spencer had signed her name, along with the words: “Love you!”

headline: TimesCast | Bahrain Grand Prix
text: April 20, 2012 — The controversial Bahrain Grand Prix, which begins on Friday, has become a flash point between the Sunni royal family and much of the majority Shiite population.

headline: The Week in Pictures, April 20
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Why Should a Disability Limit High School Choices?
text: Bryan Stromer is an eleventh grader at NYC Lab High School, a place where he is happy and thriving. But he wound up at Lab by default, after another school that interested him could not provide the special education services he needs. Now on the Citywide Council on Special Education, he writes about his hope that the city's upcoming changes in special education will  make more schools accessible, giving students more options when choosing a high school.

headline: Warren and Brown Trade Jabs Over Taxes
text: BOSTON – It has been a week of tax wars for Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts and his presumed Democrat opponent, Elizabeth Warren.

headline: TimesCast | ‘Extreme’ Voters in France
text: April 20, 2012 — The first round of France’s presidential election takes place Sunday, and voters on the extremes, the far left and the far right, will play a significant role.

headline: Former Treasurer Convicted of Bribery in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA — An Indonesian court on Friday sentenced the former treasurer of the governing Democrat Party to four years and 10 months in prison and fined him 200 million rupiah for bribery, in the first of several verdicts in a case that has riveted the nation and shaken the party of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.

headline: Guard at the Met Wounded When Gun Goes Off
text: Shortly before 3 p.m., a single shot rang out at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Porsche’s Know-It-All 911
text: Computers mediate nearly all of the 911 Carrera S driving experience, but it still delivers unparalleled immediacy in its reflexes while retaining a supple ride for everyday use.

headline: US Airways Strikes Deal With AMR’s Unions
text: In an unusual move that could prefigure a serious bid for its bankrupt rival, US Airways said it had reached an agreement with the three main labor unions at American Airlines to support a merger, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports. Read more »

headline: 911: Brainpower to Match the Brawn
text: SANTA MARIA, Calif.

headline: A Russian Porsche by Way of Finland?
text: WHILE the Finns welcome Russian investment, like the decision to build the Marussia B2 sports car here, no one expects it to become a big seller in Finland.

text: TESTED 2012 Volkswagen Golf R

text: Photos from South Sudan, Egypt, Pakistan and New York.

headline: Documentary Filmmaker Wins Against I.R.S., Which Saw Her as a Hobbyist
text: LOS ANGELES — Documentary filmmakers can breathe a sigh of relief, knowing that the producer and director Lee Storey on Thursday won her case against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in the United States Tax Court.

headline: At No. 5 in Women’s Lacrosse, Is Maryland Under the Radar?
text: The No. 5 Maryland women’s lacrosse team, as it seemingly always has done, has had a successful season, losing just three games and heading into the A.C.C. tournament this weekend with eight wins in its last nine games. But rewind two and a half months in College Park, and this is probably not where the Terrapins expected to be.

headline: The DVR Log Jam
text: April 20, 2012 — If are you having a hard time deciding what to watch on TV Sunday night, you’re not alone.

headline: A Push to Make Motors With Fewer Rare Earths
text: FOR much of the last century, the straightforward solution to making a car perform better has been to install a bigger engine. In the hybrids and electric cars of coming years, however, the answer might be installing motors with more powerful magnets.

headline: Just 10 Looks | The Best of Bridal
text: These days, a walk down the aisle can seem more like a walk down a runway. White wedding gowns are still the norm, but brides can also opt for crimson, sapphire and blush. There are also pretty prints to choose from. Here, 10 of our favorite styles from the fall bridal collections.

headline: Obama Holds Fund-Raising Edge Over Romney
text: 4:40 p.m. | Updated  President Obama raised about $35 million in March, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday, leaving him with more than $104 million in the bank as he prepares to square off against Mitt Romney, the likely Republican nominee, in the general election campaign.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 20
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Adjusting a Waistline for a Wedding, but at What Cost?
text: A Field Notes column last Sunday (“Bridal Hunger Games”) reported on some diets that brides use to drop 15 or 20 pounds before their weddings: Weight Watchers and a personal fitness trainer, juice cleanses, the Dukan diet, diet pills, hormone shots and, new to the United States, a feeding tube diet.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper West Side co-op, a Douglaston colonial, a Clinton Hill condo and an East Village duplex.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom town-house condo with terraces and ocean views, steps from the beach in Long Beach, N.Y.

headline: Lada Love
text: With his collection of Ladas, Risto Nykanen hopes to keep alive the memory of the boxy Soviet automobiles that were once the family car of Finland.

headline: Carr and Stelter on Embarrassment of TV Riches Sunday Night
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss how Sunday night has become jammed with the most prestigious shows of the week, whether on cable or network TV, including “The Good Wife” on CBS; “Nurse Jackie” on Showtime; “Girls” on HBO; “Mad Men” and “The Killing” on AMC. Some are complaining that their DVRs can’t keep up with the offerings.

headline: Syria Protests Cite Observers and a Truce as Faltering
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Demonstrations erupted across Syria on Friday, with some of the protesters’ anger focused on United Nations observers, who have decided that they will not circulate on Fridays, the normal day for mass rallies that are suppressed by the government. Despite an ostensible cease-fire, violence flared across the country, with a roadside bomb killing 10 soldiers in the south, according to the state-run news, while YouTube videos posted from the devastated city of Homs showed flames and intense black smoke after government shelling of a downtown residential neighborhood.

headline: John Forté's Journey to Russia
text: The Fugees musician documents his nine-week trip to Russia.

headline: The Person, Not the Alzheimer’s
text: A new book and photo exhibit portray efforts around the world to help Alzheimer’s patients connect with the outside world by focusing on their individual traits and histories.

headline: Before the Cast Takes the Stage, the Crowd Is on Its Feet
text: At the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Wednesday night, the standing ovation came before the show started. Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, commanded the audience to rise, but the ovation would have happened anyway. After 38 years as artistic director of Ailey II, the organization’s second company, Sylvia Waters was stepping down. To honor her, the least you could do was stand up.

headline: Photo Replay: April 20
text: A look at the day in sports, from the field at Fenway Park to the open water.

headline: Watching Every Click You Make
text: WHEN you write a post on Facebook about your sudden craving for blue cheese, an advertisement for gout prevention might suddenly pop up on your page. Post the phrase “bacon tidbits,” and you might get an ad for a book called “Forbidden Lessons in a Kabul Guesthouse.”

headline: Infrastructure Spending Yields Results
text: I don’t usually do personal-anecdote analysis, but a quick thought here.

headline: One on One: Lane Becker, Author of ‘Get Lucky’
text: Lane Becker, above left, is the co-founder of Get Satisfaction, an online customer service community platform, and the co-founder of Adaptive Path, which claims to be one of the world’s first user experience design firms. Mr. Becker has co-written a book titled “Get Lucky” with Thor Muller, above right, also a co-founder of Get Satisfaction. The book, as Mr. Becker describes it, is a manual for serendipity in the digital age. Below is an edited interview.

headline: Income of the Elderly
text: In response to this post, some readers asked for data on the income of the elderly. Here’s the Social Security Administration source. If you look at Table 9B6 you’ll see (left column) that 55 percent of the elderly get more than half their income from Social Security; 33 percent get more than 80 percent of their income from that source.

headline: Gaming Meets Giving
text: Carol Roth, business analyst, evaluates an investor pitch from a small business.

headline: The Science of the Search for the Boy on the Milk Carton
text: Upon the discovery of buried human remains, forensic archaeologists and anthropologists typically keep digging in a circle around them, in effect creating, beneath the bones, an elevated section of dirt.

text: More Photographs

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Drone Lists and iPhone Rumors
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Is It Ethical to Eat Meat? You Be the Judge
text: With a clap of thunder and a puff of smoke, the Ethicist column’s first-ever essay contest ended on April 8. Then slowly the smoke drifted away, and we beheld the results. They were astonishing.

headline: With This Mussel Sauce, One Spoonful Leads to the Next
text: THERE are some recipes that are all about showcasing the main ingredient, honoring that pristine piece of fish or dry-aged steak with a sprinkle of salt and pepper and nothing more.

headline: How to De-Beard Mussels
text: Farmed mussels are fine to use in this week’s recipe, spicy coconut mussels with lemon grass, above. If you are lucky enough to get your hands on some wild mussels (which are generally more intensely flavored than the farmed kind), you might have to de-beard them. It’s not hard but it does mean sorting through them one by one.

headline: Chic in Review | Don’t Mess With La Lohan
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Police Examine Death of Man Who Was Hit by Patrol Car
text: The Police Department is investigating the death of a man who was struck by a police car after a chase in the Brooklyn housing project where he lived.

headline: Stardom and Middle Age
text: Ingrid is the interesting one. She begins as a trophy-wife type with a French twist, goes through an entertaining Patsy Stone of “Ab Fab” phase and ends up as Janis Joplin.

headline: Video: On Crostini, or a Spoon
text: A few weeks ago, I demonstrated how to make fresh ricotta. This week’s video gives some ideas on how to use it. And of course, you can always use it to fill a calzone or two.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Argentina announces it will nationalize YPF, Jim Yong Kim is named president of the World Bank and Citigroup shareholders rebuff a pay package for the company’s chief executive.

headline: Kyle Larsen Voted Into Hall of Fame
text: Only one player was voted by his peers into the American Contract Bridge League’s Hall of Fame this year: Kyle Larsen of San Francisco.

headline: Bill Would Expand Insurance for Crops
text: For decades, farmers have been able to receive government money for not growing crops.

headline: A Break From Romanticism With Some Mozart
text: The pianist Garrick Ohlsson has been demonstrating his credentials as a Romantic powerhouse this season, with arresting performances of Liszt in honor of that composer’s bicentennial. He gave a Liszt recital at the 92nd Street Y in January and will perform a variation on that recital at Carnegie Hall on April 29.

headline: G.O.P. National Committee Warmly Embraces Romney
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — If any crowd would be expected to noisily receive Mitt Romney, it is the 50 leaders of the state Republican Parties — stalwarts careful not to make an endorsement during the primary season, but whose every fiber is tied to the success of the nominee.

headline: What’s It Like Having Power? How Would I Know?
text: “Veep,” HBO’s new comedy starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as vice president of the United States, has an awful lot of cursing in it. Too much, perhaps: if you fear the de-electrification and eventual domestication of swear words, you may feel that “Veep” takes us a little farther down that road. On the other hand, political people do swear. They have to, for their mental health. Today’s public servant is gaffe-phobic, linguistically constipated, mortgaged in spirit to this lobby or that. He must speak — when on display — in ceaseless, toneless platitudes. Then the heavy door closes, with the press and the people on the other side of it, and the air splinters with profanity.

headline: Benjamin Dickinson on 'First Winter'
text: Benjamin Dickinson, the director of "First Winter," discusses his film about a group of friends who become stranded while on a yoga retreat.

headline: Young Pianist at Home in the Past and the Present
text: Some young performers specialize in contemporary music because they think it is important to do so or to acquire a hip professional profile. The best reason to play new music is because it fascinates you. The Chinese-born, 28-year-old American pianist Jenny Q Chai demonstrated true affinity for contemporary music throughout the challenging program she played on Thursday night at Zankel Hall.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,924 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Top Score Isn’t Enough for Preschooler Seeking Seat in Prime Gifted Programs
text: The number of children who aced the test for gifted and talented programs rose by 47 percent this year, making it possible for there to be four applicants for every available seat in the most selective schools.

headline: Front and Back Rooms, Surprises on the Side
text: TRATTORIA Vivolo, run by the affable Dean Vivolo, is one of the weirdest-looking restaurants around. The distinctive shiny chrome diner, which is the restaurant’s front room, is a vestige of another age, before such eateries morphed into the behemoths built today. The surprising view from the sparkly back dining room is of a huge mural painted on the side of a nearby building. The picture of a sunny oceanfront seen through a few birch trees will make most customers smile, as will the restaurant’s other incongruities.

headline: New Meters for the Rhymin’ of Simon
text: Transformations, extrapolations and a few collisions were on the program when Paul Simon performed with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra on Thursday night at the Rose Theater, part of a three-night fund-raising series. (With tickets costing hundreds of dollars, perhaps it was no coincidence that the first words Mr. Simon sang were “She’s a rich girl,” from “Diamonds on the Soles of Her Shoes.”)

headline: State Scraps ‘Pineapple’ Test Question
text: The New York State education commissioner, John B. King Jr., pulled a series of questions from this year's eighth-grade English Language Arts exam, after an uproar about a question involving an absurd scenario of a pineapple and the hare that it challenged to a race.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: Anyone could have predicted this: House Republicans are seeking to slash food stamp funding in order to preserve Pentagon spending. Wow. No kidding. Let’s kill poor people in other countries instead of feeding people here? What a concept! Almost makes me want to not write about anything else.

headline: Tribeca: In ‘First Winter’ the Power Goes Out, so the Director Uses Candles
text: In the drama “First Winter,” playing at the Tribeca Film Festival on Friday night, with more screenings next week, a group of Brooklynites seek solace on a yoga retreat. They get more peacefulness than they bargained for when a catastrophic event leaves them without power and dwindling resources. The critic Stephen Holden singled out the film in his look at the festival’s 11th edition. The first feature from the director Benjamin Dickinson, “First Winter” was shot on 16-millimeter film and uses only natural lighting (including cheap candles from Ikea). The spare narrative is mirrored in the filmmaking style, and in this video, Mr. Dickinson explains the methods he used to create the mood.

headline: Just Try to Believe: Life Will Get Better
text: The very fact of living feels strangely tenuous for the restless souls of Chekhov’s “Three Sisters.” The distant future and recollections of a happier past are forever tugging them away from thoughts of the present, lending the characters an almost ethereal quality. Even a seemingly inarguable event like the breaking of a clock seems to hint at an existential mystery.

headline: When the Supermarket Is a Mile Away
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fox Network at 25: Blazing Trails and Burning Bridges
text: In April 1987 the Fox Broadcasting Company opened for business in prime time with two half-hour comedies, “Married ... With Children” and “The Tracey Ullman Show.”

headline: A Film Settles Accounts From the ’60s
text: Booker Wright, a black waiter in a whites-only restaurant in Greenwood, Miss., neither protested nor preached as the civil rights movement of the 1960s roiled the Delta. But the film “Booker’s Place: A Mississippi Story,” scheduled to premiere on Sunday at the Tribeca Film Festival, portrays him as one of the small heroes of that grand movement.

headline: The Local Approach, Applied to Seafood
text: ONLY a gutsy and independent chef would name a restaurant after a mollusk better known in Europe than here, as Bill Taibe has done with his new place, the Whelk in Westport. But, as he said in a telephone interview, “I enjoy sharing my knowledge about food with others.” Calling the new place Le Mer, as a bookend to his other Westport restaurant, Le Farm, would have been, in his words, “too obvious, like hanging lifesavers or anchors on the walls.”

headline: A Fenway Park Celebration Ends When the Yankees Step on the Field
text: BOSTON — In what was surely the largest number of Red Sox ever assembled, 212 former players gathered Friday afternoon to help 36,770 fans celebrate the 100th anniversary of Fenway Park. But, as has often happened here, 25 Yankees spoiled the party.

headline: Bettman Supports Shanahan and Defends League’s Safety Record
text: With the first round of the playoffs attracting attention for fighting, illegal hits and suspensions, N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said Brendan Shanahan was doing a “very, very good job” in his role as the league’s disciplinarian.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
