headline: The Week in Pictures for April 20
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include national chess champions from a school in Brooklyn, the Intrepid’s preparations for the arrival of the space shuttles’ prototype, and the resumption of the search for Etan Patz.

headline: Afghan Youth Orchestra Plans to Visit the U.S.
text: One of the best-known facts about music in Afghanistan, at least in the West, is that it wasn’t. The Taliban banned it when they took power in 1996, beating musicians, burning instruments and destroying cassette tapes in the name of their severe and extreme vision of Islam.

headline: A Visit to Beirut
text: To the Editor:

headline: Attention Expats: Singapore Is Better Than Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Singapore and Hong Kong are engaged in a constant battle: which, oh which, is the more important Asian financial center? And which is more capable of attracting the top-quality workers that are needed to run the trading floors, logistics operations and universities that make both cities global players?

headline: A Prominent Bankruptcy Lawyer Now Ministers to His Firm
text: Over the last several decades, Martin J. Bienenstock has established himself as one of America’s most prominent bankruptcy lawyers, advising General Motors and Enron. Now, he faces perhaps the most challenging assignment of his career: the restructuring of his own law firm.

headline: Beijing Auto Show Preview: Lamborghini Urus Concept Hints at Hyper-S.U.V.
text: 8:05 a.m. | Updated

headline: Gingrich Won’t Leave Race, or Costly Secret Service Protection
text: As long as Newt Gingrich stays in the presidential race, he is still receiving Secret Service protection — at a cost of more than $40,000 a day.

headline: Reviewing the Porsche 911 Carrera S
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the Porsche 911 Carrera S, the heightened-horsepower specification of the 911, which underwent a major refresh for the 2012 model year.

headline: Deporting Parents Hurts Kids
text: LAST May, President Obama told an audience in El Paso that deportation of immigrants would focus on “violent offenders and people convicted of crimes; not families, not folks who are just looking to scrape together an income.”

headline: French Media Question Election Reporting Rules
text: PARIS — After months of noisy campaigning in the presidential race — rousing the crowds, pressing flesh, inundating Twitter — France’s politicians and pollsters fell silent at midnight Friday, by law.

headline: Quirky Buccaneers With Feet of Clay
text: COMPUTER graphics may dominate animation features today, but some filmmakers are not ready to abandon more traditional techniques, even as those styles have gotten a dimensional makeover. Henry Selick breathed new life into stop motion with the first such feature to be released in 3-D, “Coraline” (2009). This year four more artisans will revisit 3-D stop-motion: Chris Butler and Sam Fell this summer with “ParaNorman”; Tim Burton, in the fall with “Frankenweenie”; and Peter Lord, a founder of the British animation company Aardman whose “Pirates! Band of Misfits” opens Friday.

headline: Forced to Retire at 22
text: SHOREVIEW, Minn. — The enlarged cutout on the wall of the PINnacle Wrestling School, in an industrial park here north of Minneapolis, shows Jake Deitchler’s finest moment in Greco-Roman wrestling. On his knees with fists clenched, Deitchler screams with joy after winning the 2008 Olympic trials at 146 pounds, making him the first high school wrestler in 32 years to qualify for the United States team.

headline: Robust, Italian and Out to Charm
text: RESTAURANTS like Sacramone’s are what have made Italian cuisine the Island’s favorite: places where the owners extend a warm welcome, and the food is robust, abundant and reasonably priced.

headline: Bahrain’s Formula One Gala Not Going as Planned
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — The Sunni monarchy has been hoping that the Formula One Grand Prix, its showcase annual event, would restore Bahrain’s stature as a stable Persian Gulf kingdom, blighted after months of antigovernment protests by the Shiite majority that led to the cancellation of the race last year.

headline: From a Charcoal Pit, a Slice of Portugal
text: THERE are plenty of ethnic restaurants in Hoboken — Indian, Malaysian, Cuban, take your pick — but as best I can determine, only a single Portuguese establishment.

headline: Hillman Curtis, a Pioneer in Web Design, Dies at 51
text: Hillman Curtis, a former rock musician who became a prominent first-generation Web designer and a visionary figure in the Internet’s evolution from a predominantly text-based medium to the multimedia platform it is today, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 51.

headline: Amid Proxy Fight, Canadian Pacific Profit Rises
text: The Canadian Pacific Railway reported Friday that it had a first-quarter profit of 142 million Canadian dollars, a 318 percent increase from the same period a year before. But it was unclear if the results would undermine a proxy campaign for control of the railway led by William A. Ackman, the hedge fund manager, who is seeking to replace most of the railway’s directors and its senior management through a vote at its annual meeting next month. Fred Green, the chief executive of Canadian Pacific, said the quarterly results were an endorsement of the railway’s management and their operational plans.

headline: Space Shuttle Will Be Late to New York
text: The countdown clock for the arrival of New York City’s first space shuttle will have to be reset.

headline: Prime Spot
text: AMONG the more than 300 guests who attended the March 14 state dinner for David Cameron, the British prime minister, were a chosen few: the 19 people who got to sit at the head table with the president and the first lady.

headline: Sudan Says Military Evicts South’s Army From Oil Area
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan claimed Friday that its military had been victorious in forcing South Sudanese soldiers to pull out of a contested oil region as tensions between the two African neighbors remained high.

headline: For Earth Day, a Film Created by the Whole World
The Holiday for Fans of Liberalized Marijuana Laws
text: Despite a buzz-killing backdrop of federal raids and local crackdowns, marijuana fans celebrated their high holiday on Friday in all the traditional ways: smoking, speaking out and — no doubt — snacking.

headline: A Bahraini Activist Explains the Standoff Over Formula One
text: Thousands of opposition protesters marched in Bahrain’s capital on Friday, to protest the kingdom’s decision to go ahead with the Formula One Grand Prix this weekend, despite a crackdown on dissent in the country and a hunger strike by a jailed rights activist.

headline: Bewitched (Before Samantha)
text: John van Druten’s “Bell, Book and Candle” — or at least the sassy, stylish production now at Hartford Stage — could bring back wall-to-wall carpeting.

headline: Teddy Charles, Jazz Musician Turned Sea Captain, Dies at 84
text: Teddy Charles, a gifted vibraphonist who teamed up with many of the musicians who revolutionized jazz in the 1940s and ’50s and then literally sailed away to become a sea captain, died on Monday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: Scholars Pay Homage to Mets, 50 Years On
text: During his nearly 79 years, Ed Charles, also known as “The Glider,” has gone from playing baseball in the segregated Deep South to having a pivotal role as a Mets third baseman in the 1969 World Series to reciting his poetry on television. Some of life’s quirky turns have surprised him more than others, he said, but he never thought he would be sitting around with a bunch of Ph.D.’s talking about his beloved Mets.

headline: In a Rowdy Democracy, a Dictator’s Daughter With an Unsoiled Aura
text: GONGJU, South Korea

headline: Wall St. Protesters Lying on Sidewalk Are Arrested
text: The police arrested a group of Occupy Wall Street protesters who were lying on a sidewalk at the corner of Wall Street and Broad Street on Friday afternoon after one demonstrator announced that the law allowed them to do so as a form of political protest.

headline: They Dressed Like Groucho
text: You could say, with partial plagiarism: It was the best of nights. It was the worst of nights.

headline: Bank of America Accord in Lawsuit Is Challenged
text: Lawyers leading a class-action lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan against the directors of Bank of America over its purchase of Merrill Lynch have agreed to settle the matter for $20 million even though damages in the case could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs in a parallel suit against the bank’s board in Delaware.

headline: Martin Poll Dies at 89; Built a Movie Studio in New York
text: Martin Poll, who helped revitalize film production in New York in the 1950s and ’60s and later made his name in Hollywood, producing films like the Oscar-winning historical drama “The Lion in Winter,” died in Manhattan on April 14. He was 89.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Upsize
text: On the fashion scene, there’s a new interest in the carryall bag. Devoid of hardware, it relies on the simplicity of design and craftsmanship.

headline: Voting for Yesterday in France
text: Paris

headline: A Familiar Spectacle, With High Wattage
text: Is it those dancing feet, those bright costumes or those high-wattage smiles that dazzle the audience most in the first scene of the John W. Engeman Theater’s production of “42nd Street”? It is hard to decide, and it doesn’t really matter, because they blend into one terrific opening number, which turns out to be a harbinger of an altogether enjoyable show.

headline: Suspected Sale by China Stirs Concern at White House
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration says it believes that a Chinese manufacturer sold North Korea the chassis and other parts for a missile-transport vehicle displayed in a military parade this week, a senior official said Friday, raising new concerns about China’s ability to enforce a ban on military sales to North Korea.

headline: The Voice of Authority
text: It was Nov. 25, 1963, three days after the Kennedy assassination, and the powerful columnist was calling the neophyte president. Already, Joseph Alsop had penned a personal letter to Lyndon Johnson offering his support. The phone call was an attempt to offer something more: advice.

headline: Obama Sees Steep Dropoff in Cash From Major Donors
text: President Obama’s re-election campaign is straining to raise the huge sums it is counting on to run against Mitt Romney, with sharp dropoffs in donations from nearly every major industry forcing it to rely more than ever on small contributions and a relative handful of major donors.

headline: Profit Quadruples for Canadian Pacific Railway
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian Pacific Railway reported Friday that it had a first-quarter profit of 142 million Canadian dollars, a 318 percent increase from the same period a year before. But it was unclear if the railway’s favorable results would undermine a proxy campaign for its control led by William A. Ackman, the hedge fund manager.

headline: Search for Boy’s Body Returns to Cellar That Looked Uneven Decades Earlier
text: Investigators looking into the disappearance of Etan Patz began focusing recently on a handyman after a review of old case files showed that a concrete floor in a building in SoHo where he once had a workshop — and that was on the route Etan took when he disappeared — had looked uneven or was not all the same color, a person briefed on the case said on Friday.

headline: Among His Duties, Choosing the Guests
text: A look at the more than 800 people who have accepted invitations to state dinners, in some cases more than once.

headline: Assad’s Lies
text: The United Nations Security Council gave Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, a chance to end the killing and avoid complete chaos with a plan that called for a cease-fire, a withdrawal of troops from embattled cities and a political transition. It is deplorable — but no surprise — that he reneged on nearly every promise.

headline: In Venezuela, a Shortage of Staples
text: Venezuela is one of the world’s top oil producers, but shortages of staples are a chronic part of life.

headline: With Venezuelan Food Shortages, Some Blame Price Controls
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — By 6:30 a.m., a full hour and a half before the store would open, about two dozen people were already in line. They waited patiently, not for the latest iPhone, but for something far more basic: groceries.

headline: Before Hosting ‘Bandstand,’ Growing Up in a City With a Complicated Story
text: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — The picture in the 1947 A. B. Davis High School Yearbook seems to tell a familiar story.

headline: White Gloves Not Needed
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 20, 2012

headline: The Global Economy at Risk
text: Anxieties about Europe dominated this week’s meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Fund officials warned that the euro-zone crisis poses a grave danger to a weak global economy. Europe’s leaders, masters of denial, are still insisting on destructive austerity.

headline: A Film Festival Debut With a Local Twist
text: THOM POWERS, co-director with his wife, Raphaela Neihausen, of the Montclair Film Festival — to be held May 1 to 6 — said that putting together the town’s first cinematic extravaganza had been “a wholly immersive thing” since they signed on in November.

headline: Mismapping the Peninsula
text: Gen. George B. McClellan’s amphibious invasion of the Virginia Peninsula in March and April 1862 involved one of the great logistical achievements of the Civil War. By April 2 he had amassed 58,000 men, 15,000 horses and mules, 1,100 wagons and 44 batteries, along with extensive supplies and telegraph wire — and more troops were on the way.

headline: Corrections: April 21
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Lyric Little Bandbox Turns 100
text: Home runs come in various guises and sizes. But it is beyond dispute that the most magnificent home runs in baseball are hit at Fenway Park. More specifically, to left field in Fenway Park. So magnificent are they, in fact, that if you’re really being fair about it, it doesn’t matter who hits them. Even, as on Friday, Alex Rodriguez and Nick Swisher and Russell Martin did.

headline: A Love Story, Past and Present
text: “The Last Five Years,” by Jason Robert Brown, which Crossroads Theater Company is presenting in New Brunswick, is a two-character musical. It could be said, though, that the third character is time.

headline: Justice Under North Carolina’s Racial Bias Law
text: Marcus Robinson, who has been on death row in North Carolina since 1994, was the first person to challenge a death sentence under the state’s 2009 Racial Justice Act. That law is the nation’s first to give inmates the chance to have their sentences reduced to life without parole based on proof that racial bias played a significant role in their case.

headline: Restrained Youth’s Death in Yonkers Is Investigated
text: The police and state officials are examining a surveillance video that recorded the death of a 16-year-old boy at a private residential treatment center in Yonkers this week as staff members physically restrained him on the floor after a basketball game.

headline: A Healthy Breakfast
text: When it comes to making certain that children start the school day with a good breakfast, New York City could learn a lot from Newark, Detroit and Los Angeles. Administrators there are helping children in need — 10 million in the country — get a healthy breakfast at their desks.

headline: Stirring Memories of Better Times
text: BOSTON

headline: Friday Night Music: Leonard Cohen
text: A bit of beauty to end the week. Original:

headline: When Pineapple Races Hare, Students Lose, Critics of Standardized Tests Say
text: A reading passage included this week in one of New York’s standardized English tests has become the talk of the eighth grade, with students walking around saying, “Pineapples don’t have sleeves,” as if it were the code for admission to a secret society.

headline: Events Marked by Large Streamers
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Just what a Saturday puzzle should be, if not a tad on the easy side. I didn’t have to turn my brain inside out for every single answer, which kept me on the hook just enough to finish Barry C. Silk’s puzzle.

headline: F.B.I. Investigation Into Representative Don Young
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation released documents relating to a criminal investigation it conducted into Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, and a 2005 budget appropriation he helped secure for a highway project.

headline: In Figure and Form, Sculpture All Around
text: WHITE PLAINS — Entering “Sculpture: On and Off the Wall,” the group exhibition that fills both floors of ArtsWestchester’s Arts Exchange, you first encounter Emil Alzamora’s “Spaceman,” an all-white ceramic astronaut the size of a toddler mounted just above eye level. Arms reaching back, knees bent upward, helmeted head facing down, the figure might be hurtling through space, were its back not firmly anchored to the gallery wall.

headline: Alaska Lawmaker Put Campaign Money to Personal Use, Ex-Aide Told Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Don Young and his family routinely used campaign funds for personal expenses, like hunting trips, meals and charter flights to his home in Alaska, a former campaign aide to Mr. Young told federal criminal investigators.

headline: Guillen Is the Marlins’ Gift to Cable TV
text: The Miami Marlins are, for obvious reasons, an ideal team to follow in the Showtime series “The Franchise” this season. They have shed the Florida part of their name and redesigned their uniform. They escaped a football stadium for a colorful new home, Marlins Park. Jeffrey Loria, the owner, hired a new manager, Ozzie Guillen, and added Jose Reyes, Mark Buehrle, Heath Bell and Carlos Zambrano to the roster.

headline: Blood, Sweat and Illicit Bets
text: For more than a year, Devin Yalkin has photographed unsanctioned underground boxing matches in Chinatown in all their sweaty, bleary glory.

headline: The Bachelor Vote
text: “Even if you like Barack Obama, we can’t afford Barack Obama.”

headline: Rangers’ Boyle Does Everything Bigger
text: HINGHAM, Mass. — Brian Boyle was always the biggest one, whether at St. Paul Elementary School in the center of town or on the ice of the nearby Pilgrim Skating Arena, where he first learned to skate at age 3.

headline: Devils’ Kovalchuk Trying to Make Up for Lost Time
text: NEWARK — Ilya Kovalchuk worked out Friday instead of practicing with the Devils. With Game 5 of their Stanley Cup playoff series against Florida set for Saturday, Kovalchuk seemed to appreciate a day off his skates, even if he did not really need one.

headline: Israeli Desert Yields a Harvest of Energy
text: KETURA, Israel — Arriving at this bone-dry kibbutz in the Arava Desert late one afternoon in August 2006, Yosef Abramowitz, a social activist, Jewish educator and multimedia entrepreneur from Boston, opened the door of his van and was hit by a wall of heat.

headline: Looking to Move Up, Knicks Fail to Capitalize in Cleveland
text: CLEVELAND — Carmelo Anthony looked claustrophobic while playing with another post player on the court. Amar’e Stoudemire missed three free throws, had a shot blocked and looked lost. The Knicks shot 1 of 7 from the floor, and looked sluggish; they were outrebounded, 9-4, by a frontcourt pairing of Antawn Jamison and the rookie Tristan Thompson.

headline: Romney Set to Merge Staff With National Committee
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Mitt Romney’s top aides plan to move quickly after the primaries on Tuesday to integrate the campaign’s growing staff with the Republican National Committee, in an effort to avoid logistical stumbles that have hampered past nominees, campaign aides and committee officials said Friday.

headline: Fire Kills Two and Injures Four Others in Upper Manhattan
text: A woman and her husband were killed after a fire broke out on Friday in a second-floor apartment in Upper Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: Putting Meditation Back on the Mat
text: SEATED cross-legged on a black cushion atop a yoga mat, I struggled to keep my eyes closed and repeat the Sanskrit mantra in my head: ham-sa — I am that. Outside, on Third Avenue, police sirens wailed and cars honked as I tried to sit still in a room with eight other meditation students, keeping my breath slow and steady. Just as I was about to lose the focus on my breath, a soothing voice nearby chimed in: “You can hear the noises without getting attached to them. The attention comes from the inside.”

headline: Obama 2012 vs. Obama 2008
text: The Obama campaign is lagging behind its fund-raising pace of four years ago.

headline: Gone, Not Forgotten
text: DECADES can dull the shock and ease the sting of even a great tragedy. But, as New Yorkers learned this past week, some horrors never lose their grip.

headline: Post Offices Face Hurdles in Efforts to Diversify
text: WASHINGTON — Well before online bill paying was popular, the Postal Service in 2000 began operating a secure system that would have allowed it to remain the primary conduit for most Americans’ monthly payments. But the Internet industry objected, and Congress successfully pressured the Postal Service to abandon it.

headline: No Contract Negotiations for the Hot-Hitting Wright
text: David Wright, who entered the Mets’ series opener against the San Francisco Giants on Friday with baseball’s highest batting average, said before the game that there had been no discussions with the front office this season about his contract.

headline: Kazakhstan: Reporter Attacked
text: Five men attacked a journalist, Lukpan Akhmedyarov, near his home in Uralsk late Thursday, stabbing him eight times, his editor said Friday. Mr. Akhmedyarov had recently received threats warning him to halt his involvement in organizing antigovernment protests, said Tamara Yeslyamova, the editor of Uralskaya Nedelya, the newspaper where Mr. Akhmedyarov worked as a reporter. Doctors said he was expected to survive. Such attacks are not uncommon in Kazakhstan, an authoritarian former Soviet republic where journalists critical of the government are rarely tolerated. The Committee to Protect Journalists, based in New York, condemned the attack. The police have opened an investigation, local media outlets reported.

headline: Britain: Media Scandal Fuels Lawsuits
text: Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper group faces dozens of new lawsuits, a court was told Friday, as the phone-hacking scandal continues. A lawyer for several of the claimants, Hugh Tomlinson, said 44 new cases had been filed. British news reports indicated that two further claims had also been made. The cases include claims by Cherie Blair, the wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair; the soccer player Wayne Rooney; and Ted Beckham, the father of the soccer player David Beckham. Mr. Murdoch has already settled dozens of claims alleging illegal interception of voice mail messages by his reporters. A spokeswoman for News International, Mr. Murdoch’s British newspaper group, declined to comment.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Defends ‘Burlesque’
text: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi made a surprise appearance on Friday at a court in Milan where he is on trial on charges of abuse of power and paying for sex with an underage nightclub dancer. Speaking to reporters during a break in the trial, Mr. Berlusconi said that nothing untoward ever took place in his homes and that the dinners he hosted were “elegant” and “proper.” Responding to allegations by witnesses that women at the dinners, dressed as police officers and nuns, carried out stripteases, he explained that his guests were merely “practicing for burlesque competitions.” He added: “Women are exhibitionist by nature. And if they are in show business, they like to put on shows.”

headline: Tending a Bar Between the Tracks
text: WITH 33 years on the job, Tim Myles, 61, is the senior man on the Long Island Rail Road’s staff of 11 bar-cart attendants who work Pennsylvania Station’s platforms. Mr. Myles’s regular spot is on the platform between Tracks 20 and 21, at the bottom of the busiest staircase to the tracks, where he serves more than 20 departing trains a shift.

headline: The Hare and the Pineapple Question
text: A controversial — some say confusing — reading passage included this week in one of New York’s standardized English tests became the talk of the eighth grade.

headline: Mets’ Pitching Rebounds, but Hitters Fail to Deliver
text: After poor starts from Johan Santana and R. A. Dickey, the Mets were in dire need of a remedy for their sudden epidemic of subpar pitching.

headline: Concern in G.O.P. Over State Focus on Social Issues
text: Fiscal issues and union rights were front and center in many Republican-controlled legislatures last year. But this year, with the nation heading into the heart of a presidential race and voters consumed by the country’s economic woes, much of the debate in statehouses has centered on social issues.

headline: Keeping Body and Image in Shape
text: When the N.B.A. Hall of Famer  Walt Frazier, the loquacious Knicks analyst on the MSG network, is not on the road with the playoff-bound team, which he led to its first N.B.A. championship in 1970, the focal point of his Sundays is his bedroom. There Mr. Frazier, a k a Clyde, multitasks by exercising in bed, napping or surfing the cable channels. When he does go out, he works in a stop at  Clyde Frazier’s Wine and Dine, the restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen where he is a partner, acting as host and in-house celebrity. Mr. Frazier, 67, lives in a condo in West Harlem with his son, Walt III, 45, a forest of foliage (he is a plant freak) and 200 flamboyant suits. He also owns a bed-and-breakfast on St. Croix.

headline: Red Storm Lose a Coach to Michigan
text: Kim Barnes Arico led St. John’s to four N.C.A.A. tournament appearances during a 10-year transformation of a women’s basketball program that was winless the Big East season before she took over. Now she will try to realign the expectations at Michigan.

headline: An Excerpt From ‘Central Park: An Anthology’
text: From “Framed in Silver,” by Mark Helprin, in “Central Park: An Anthology”:

headline: Looking at New York as a Target
text: WHAT happened in Manhattan on Sept. 11, 2001, was a stunning wake-up call. But in “New York at War: Four Centuries of Combat, Fear and Intrigue in Gotham” (Basic Books, $29.99), the historian Steven H. Jaffe skillfully reminds readers that the city had been a tempting target before, that it suffered casualties in earlier conflicts and that other generations of officials worried about immigrants with dual loyalties and about balancing New Yorkers’ security and their civil liberties.

headline: Gardner’s Olympic Bid Stalls
text: Rulon Gardner’s effort to win a third Olympic medal in Greco-Roman wrestling at age 40 ended when he did not appear for a weigh-in at the Olympic trials in Iowa City, Iowa. Gardner won a gold medal at the 2000 Sydney Olympics and a bronze in Athens in 2004, but has since struggled with his weight. He ballooned to as much as 474 pounds before appearing last year on the television program “The Biggest Loser.”

headline: No City for Old Tankers
text: AN empty oil tanker makes a forlorn setting for a ghost story, and at Pier 9B in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the other day, the winds of April wailed a haunting accompaniment to a tale of maritime woe. Inside the tanker, the Mary A. Whalen, Carolina Salguero raised her raspy Brooklyn voice above the clang of iron chairs being blown over on the deck.

headline: The Secret Life of a Society Maven
text: THERE are certain stories that begin in earnest only when they seem to reach an end. It turns out, I wrote one last year.

headline: A Facial Theory of Politics
text: HOW important is a political candidate’s appearance?

headline: League Plans New H.G.H. Study
text: The N.F.L. has agreed to perform a population study to determine if the level of human growth hormone that triggers a positive test should be higher for its players.

headline: The New Shades of Feminism?
text: For many women, there are certain cultural critics who are like heat waves. Their polemical expeditions are forgettable between occurrences but stultifying in the instance and show no signs of letting up. They veer toward the specious, speculative art of the trend story. Sex, gender and domestic habit make up their range of interest, and whenever a relevant cultural sensation comes along, they can be counted on to tell us why we’re all worked up.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Unidentified gunmen shot dead a police officer on Friday in the heart of Srinagar, Kashmir Live reported. The attack comes just a few days after  an announcement by Chief Minister Omar Abdullah to remove security bunkers from Srinagar city in the following months. (Hindustan Times)

headline: Half a World Away, a Familiar Name
text: A lot of people know about Syd Greenberg in China. Mind you, he hadn’t been back there since the mid-1940s, when he was an Army Signal Corps photographer assigned to the China-Burma-India theater of operations, documenting how American and Chinese Nationalist troops fought the Japanese.

headline: The Weekend Word: Cash
text: Today’s Times

headline: Russell Wilson, 4th-Ranked Quarterback in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: This Sunday: The Keys to Intelligence, Happiness and Mental Health
text: Watch a video of Hugo Lindgren introducing the magazine’s special health issue.

headline: Counting on Votes From Paris-on-Thames
text: LONDON — In the campaign for the first round of France’s presidential election on Sunday, the main candidates have not forgotten the voters of Paris-on-Thames.

headline: Much Ado About Zero (Wonkish)
text: Ryan Avent and Matt Yglesias have been having a debate about whether the zero lower bound really matters for monetary policy, which is related to — but not the same as — the debate about whether the Fed is falling way short on the job. So let me throw in my two basis points here.

headline: About That Hammock
text: Recently I linked to Harold Pollack’s outrage over remarks by Paul Ryan, in which Ryan suggested that our safety-net programs are “a hammock that lulls able-bodied people to lives of dependency and complacency”.

headline: Hotel Rooms With a View Of Photography Shows
text: Dozens of hotels have notable art collections, but a few are focusing specifically on photography, with shows that wouldn’t be out of place at a gallery. W Hotels, for example, will introduce its first Instagram photo exhibition on May 1 at the Living Room in its Times Square property. The hotel is in partnership with the photo-sharing company to curate a display of pictures from New York-based Instagrammers who capture architecture, design and street art in the city. The exhibition will be on display through June.

headline: Avoid Roaming Charges With Offline Apps
text: For travelers who want to use digital applications abroad but would like to avoid the outrageous post-vacation data charges, Lonely Planet has a solution. The company recently introduced a series of travel-guide apps for several countries that can be used offline.

headline: For Earth Day, a Bit of Perspective
text: Millions of people worldwide will take to the streets, the parks and the National Mall on Sunday for the 43rd Earth Day, but perhaps some readers of the Green blog have yet to make specific plans. Here’s one idea: Tune in to Earth: The Operator’s Manual, one of the more interesting documentary series to come along in years.

headline: Dutch Austerity Talks Fail as Geithner Prods Europe
text: BRUSSELS — More uncertainty loomed for the euro zone on Saturday after the prime minister of the Netherlands, Mark Rutte, said he expected new elections to take place following the collapse of talks on new austerity measures.

headline: Oracle Vs. Google, Week One
text: It was Larry vs. Larry as two powerful chief executives of two of the most successful tech companies squared off in court in person.

headline: Success, Finally, on the Champions Tour
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Michael Allen smoked a drive down the middle, then lighted a victory cigar. He had a three-stroke lead on the final hole of the Encompass Insurance Pro-Am last Sunday in Tampa, Fla. The gesture was brash if not premature, but for Allen, on the verge of his first victory on the Champions Tour since 2009, it was a moment to savor.

headline: The Mets at 50: The Good, the Bad, but Mostly the Ugly
text: In 18 years of living under the same roof, there was only one late-night, father-waking-son baseball celebration — and it wasn’t for a World Series victory or trade-deadline blockbuster.

headline: Corona and Tijuana Have Matching Ambitions
text: As Club Tijuana continues its surprising push toward the playoffs in the Mexican Primera División, Joe Corona is anchoring its midfield while at the same time establishing himself as one of the best young American players.

headline: Obama Urges South Sudan and Sudan to End Strife
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged Sudan and South Sudan to end their fighting and begin negotiations to settle the intensifying conflict between the newly separated countries.

headline: From Morris to Lee: Ten Zeros in a Row
text: When a pitcher throws 10 shutout innings, as the Phillies’ Cliff Lee did on Wednesday in San Francisco, it evokes memories of Jack Morris, who did it for Minnesota in Game 7 of the 1991 World Series.

headline: Variety: An Earthly Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — April 22 is a good day to discuss all things Earthbound and, of course, discussing our planet has to include a discussion about life on Earth.

headline: Discarded Manager Basks in Cheers at Fenway
text: BOSTON

headline: U.N. Agrees to Send More Cease-Fire Observers to Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved increasing the number of cease-fire monitors in Syria on Saturday, and the battered Syrian city of Homs was calm for the first time in months as an advance team of those observers toured the city.

headline: In Bahrain, More Clashes, and Death of a Protester
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — After a night of clashes between antigovernment demonstrators and the police, a protester was found dead Saturday near this capital, as Bahrain struggled to restore calm before an international auto race on Sunday. Opposition groups blamed the police for the death.

headline: Finding Economic Lessons in Fading Era of Card Shows
text: Can the dying world of baseball card conventions provide a lesson in economics?

headline: Afghanistan’s Spy Agency Says It Thwarted 2 Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s intelligence agency, which has come under fire from Afghans for failing to detect multiple attacks here last weekend, said Saturday that it had apprehended militants plotting to kill one of the country’s vice presidents and another group smuggling tons of explosives into the capital hidden in a truck of potatoes.

headline: A Note on the French Election
text: I don’t know much about French politics. From here, however, it looks as if Sarkozy has a very clear idea of what he should be doing on economic policy, while Hollande doesn’t.

headline: In France, Using Lessons From Obama Campaign
text: PARIS — Arthur Muller, Vincent Pons and Guillaume Liegey, young Frenchmen who met in Cambridge, Mass., at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government and M.I.T., are working hard to get out the vote, American-style, for the Socialist challenger for the French presidency, François Hollande.

headline: In Comfortable Retirement, and Getting Tired of It
text: During my 14 years in the N.F.L., my favorite day was Monday. As long as I wasn’t preparing for surgery or being released, Mondays were special. They signified that I had made it through another week and was ready for another opponent. Even the soreness was oh, so sweet.

headline: A Ban on Some Seafood Has Fishermen Fuming
text: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — Standing on the deck of his rusted steel trawler, Naz Sanfilippo fumed about the latest bad news for New England fishermen: a decision by Whole Foods to stop selling any seafood it does not consider sustainable.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Edwards Trial Set to Begin, Reopening a Story of a Derailed Political Career
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — John Edwards, whose personal life and political career have publicly fallen apart over the last five years, will face a federal jury on Monday in the state that sent him to the Senate and twice rallied around his quest for the presidency.

headline: Lincecum Looks to Rebound From Slow Start
text: Tim Lincecum is scheduled to start against the Mets on Sunday at Citi Field, an opportunity for New York fans to get a look at the star pitcher for the San Francisco Giants. His appearance may be even more pronounced because Lincecum is searching for his first victory after struggling in three outings this season. Lincecum is 0-2 with a 10.54 earned run average.

headline: A Head-Scratching, Bone-Chilling Schedule
text: Leave it to the N.F.L. to turn the announcement of its regular-season schedule into a midweek celebration of events that will not occur for five months.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Hiring Outsiders
text: AS an employee, you may feel at some point in your career that you aren’t being paid what you’re worth. If the feeling is acute enough, you may lobby for a promotion and a raise. But suppose that doesn’t work. Then maybe, you think, it’s time to apply elsewhere.

headline: Multiple Paths to a Goal
text: I’M an only child. I decided early on that I needed the equivalent of brothers and sisters, so over my lifetime I’ve created deep relationships.

headline: Letters: How to Balance Faith and a Business Career
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Black Sea Swamp, Big Plans for Instant City
text: ZUGDIDI, Georgia — Reaching the site where Georgia’s government is breaking ground for Lazika, its grandiose city of the future, requires navigating livestock — shaggy cows and huge spotted hogs that sunbathe on the road to the hypnotic chirping of innumerable frogs.

headline: Letters: Voting With Your Feet in a Race of the States
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: The Flow of Funds to Nimble Companies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wal-Mart Hushed Up a Vast Mexican Bribery Case
text: MEXICO CITY — In September 2005, a senior Wal-Mart lawyer received an alarming e-mail from a former executive at the company’s largest foreign subsidiary, Wal-Mart de Mexico. In the e-mail and follow-up conversations, the former executive described how Wal-Mart de Mexico had orchestrated a campaign of bribery to win market dominance. In its rush to build stores, he said, the company had paid bribes to obtain permits in virtually every corner of the country.

headline: Don’t Be Evil, but Don’t Miss the Train
text: BACK in 2004, as Google prepared to go public, Larry Page and Sergey Brin celebrated the maxim that was supposed to define their company: “Don’t be evil.”

headline: What’s Your Story? Tell It, and You May Win a Prize
text: This interview with  Russell Goldsmith, chairman and chief executive of City National Bank in Los Angeles, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Master of the Media Spotlight Is Now Its Victim in China
text: BEIJING — Intimidating and courting Chinese journalists, Bo Xilai, an ambitious Communist Party official, fueled his political career by ably shaping his public image and seizing the spotlight in a way no peer had as he governed a Chinese city. But with his purge from the party’s top ranks this month, Mr. Bo has suddenly found himself the target of the same media apparatus that he once so carefully manipulated, and that now vilifies him in the name of the party’s leaders.

headline: The Preschool Race Is No Joke
Bobcats Are Fighting a Losing Battle
text: The Charlotte Bobcats probably feel that this season could not end soon enough, but first the team has some important business to take care of. It needs at least one more win to avoid finishing with the lowest victory total since the N.B.A. was formed in 1949.

headline: When 24 Hours Is 23:59 Too Long
text: THE Haggler’s recent column about PayPal, the online money transfer company, summoned forth a fresh round of “I can’t stand PayPal” e-mail. This one stood out.

headline: NATO Plans in Russian City Are Protested
text: MOSCOW — Nationalist and leftist groups marched on Saturday in a central Russian city to protest a proposal by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to set up a transit hub for goods shipped to and from Afghanistan.

headline: 30 Seconds: Different Star Turn for an Old Knuckleballer
text: Tim Wakefield retired at 45 in February after a 19-year pitching career that included 200 wins, 186 of them with the Boston Red Sox, and 2,156 strikeouts. But Wakefield’s elusive pitch is fluttering again in the big-screen documentary “Knuckleball.” The film had its premiere Saturday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival in New York. The movie chronicles the careers of Wakefield and R.A. Dickey of the Mets.

headline: Stocks and the Economy, Singing Different Tunes
text: “THE test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time, and still retain the ability to function,” F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in 1936. He might have been describing the difficulties faced by current analysts of the financial markets.

headline: Cardinals Create a 14-Karat Squirrel
text: The St. Louis Cardinals would not have won last year’s World Series without Chris Carpenter, who beat Texas in Games 1 and 7. So when the team president, Bill DeWitt III, worked with Jostens to design the championship rings, he made sure to consult Carpenter on his most unorthodox idea.

headline: Employees, Too, Want a Say on the Boss’s Pay
text: FINALLY, the shareholders are stirring.

headline: With Torres Suspension, N.H.L. Sends Message About Mayhem in the Playoffs
text: It took a week of unprecedented postseason mayhem and a slew of embarrassing headlines, but the N.H.L. may finally have found the will to curb the on-ice chaos that marked the start of this spring’s playoffs.

headline: Utah’s Hatch Will Face a Primary for Senate
text: SANDY, Utah — United States Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a six-term Republican who had been targeted for elimination by Tea Party groups, survived a test from nine challengers at his party’s state convention here on Saturday, but failed to win the supermajority needed to avoid a primary race.

headline: Giants’ Low-Key Ways Carry Over to Draft
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Over the last two years, the Jets have made several splashy off-season moves while the Giants have, in the words of the veteran linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka, “done it in the background.”

headline: Veteran Center Lands With the Knicks
text: CLEVELAND — Knicks Coach Mike Woodson described the newest Knick, Dan Gadzuric, in less than flattering terms: “A veteran big that’s been around, that can use fouls, rebound and defend.” A similar description could be made of the player he’s essentially replacing.

headline: Rape Accusation Against Handyman Tied to Search for Missing Boy
text: Federal agents and the police continued working with jackhammers to dig up a SoHo basement on Saturday in a search for the remains of Etan Patz as reasons behind their renewed interest in excavating the concrete floor emerged.

headline: Botswana’s Pride
text: Amantle Montsho, an Olympic hopeful who won the 400-meter track title at the world championships in August, has inspired a generation of female athletes in Botswana.

headline: Why Are We Drugging Our Soldiers?
text: SINCE the start of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, there has been a large and steady rise in the prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among our troops. One recent study of 289,000 Americans who served in those countries found that the rates of the disorder jumped to 22 percent in 2008 from just 0.2 percent in 2002.

headline: A Battle Beyond Breakfast
text: With its cereals losing ground, Kellogg, and its research institute in Battle Creek, Mich., is coming up with new products and strategies to help its sales abroad.

headline: When a Sugar High Isn’t Enough
Shoulder Pain Is a Setback for Pineda
text: BOSTON — For several weeks, starting pitcher Michael Pineda had been making what seemed to be steady progress in his recovery from shoulder tendinitis, passing each stage in the process without reporting any difficulties.

headline: Alice Temperley
text: Alice Temperley is an English fashion designer who introduced her label, Temperley London, in 2000. Interest in her clothing has surged in the last year because of the popularity of her clothes with the Duchess of Cambridge, formerly Kate Middleton, and her sister, Pippa.

headline: Bartleby Would Understand
text: For years now, presidential candidates and those running for House seats have dutifully filed their campaign financing reports, as required by federal law, electronically. But the Senate, ever arrogant, has clung to an antique, cumbersome paper method that serves to delay final disclosure of donors, often until after Election Day.

headline: A Fair Shot at a Job
text: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled 25 years ago that it was illegal under the Civil Rights Act for companies to exclude people from employment based on arrest or conviction records — unless there was a compelling business reason. Since companies all over the country appear to be ignoring this important policy, the E.E.O.C. needs to strongly reaffirm the ruling and give employers detailed guidance on how to comply when it meets to consider this issue on Wednesday.

headline: This Prodigal Season
text: The shadbush, a spindly white-flowered shrub, is starting to bloom. That means American shad — the fish technically known as Alosa sapidissima — are likely to be running up the great rivers of the Northeast, the Delaware, the Hudson, the Connecticut and their tributaries. You can join the red-eyed legion of shad anglers casting shad darts, a type of lure, on the Delaware. Or, you can simply read John McPhee’s “The Founding Fish,” which contains everything you need to know about the fish, though it might not help you hook one.

headline: The Latest on the Doomsday Virus
text: We can worry less that a newly created bird flu virus might kill tens or hundreds of millions of people if it escaped from the laboratory. But there is still some residual danger. And we remain appalled at the slipshod way in which this research was authorized despite its potential dangers to public health and national security.

headline: Another G.O.P. Roadblock
text: With their continuing attacks on abortion rights and reproductive health services, Congressional Republicans have shown themselves to be insensitive to women’s concerns. This week, the Senate is expected to take up the proposed reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, another measure many Republicans are opposing.

headline: Charles W. Colson, Watergate Felon Who Became Evangelical Leader, Dies at 80
text: Charles W. Colson, who as a political saboteur for President Richard M. Nixon masterminded some of the dirty tricks that led to the president’s downfall, then emerged from prison to become an important evangelical leader, saying he had been “born again,” died on Saturday in Falls Church, Va. He was 80.

headline: A Dangerous Mind?
text: LATE last year, a jury in Boston convicted Tarek Mehanna, a 29-year-old pharmacist born in Pittsburgh, of material support for terrorism, conspiring to provide material support to terrorists and conspiring to kill in a foreign country, after a 35-day trial in which I testified as an expert witness for the defense.

headline: The Dream of Leaving Cuba
text: Havana

headline: How Broadway Games the Tonys
text: BROADWAY likes to think of itself as a cultural engine humming year-round, but judging by the opening dates of many plays and musicals, it has become the narrowest of operations: an awards-obsessed, audience-starved industry that really revs just one month a year.

headline: The Flight From Conversation
text: WE live in a technological universe in which we are always communicating. And yet we have sacrificed conversation for mere connection.

headline: In Customer Service Consulting, Disney’s Small World Is Growing
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Maryland teachers were instructed to engage children by crouching and speaking to them at eye level. Chevrolet dealers were taught to think in theater metaphors: onstage, where smiles greet potential buyers, and offstage, where sales representatives can take out-of-sight cigarette breaks.

headline: Sacking a Palace of Culture
text: LONG before I became one of the New York Public Library’s so-called literary lions, I was a habitué of all of that great institution’s research facilities, from the hushed music division in the Performing Arts branch at Lincoln Center to a shabby corner of the Muhlenberg branch on West 23rd Street. I have returned Booker T. Washington’s stare in the Schomburg Center in Harlem, and the glassy gaze of Winnie-the-Pooh (yes, the original Bear of Little Brain, rather mangy now) in what used to be the Donnell branch, on West 53rd.

headline: In Therapy Forever? Enough Already
text: MY therapist called me the wrong name. I poured out my heart; my doctor looked at his watch. My psychiatrist told me I had to keep seeing him or I would be lost.

headline: Everyone’s Lives, in Pictures
text: ALIENATION, it’s worth remembering, used to be integral to photography. Susan Sontag wrote, in 1977, “While real people are out there killing themselves or other real people, the photographer stays behind his or her camera, creating a tiny element of another world: the image-world that will outlast us all.”

headline: A Hard Look at the President
text: FOUR weeks ago, I criticized The New York Times for overplaying an article on an investment made by Ann Romney’s blind trust. The article was but one installment of the intense campaign coverage scrutinizing Mitt Romney as he bids for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: An Invitation to Abuse and Chaos
text: Arizona’s cold-blooded immigration statute was enacted in 2010 to bring about “attrition through enforcement” — to make life so harsh for undocumented immigrants that they would be driven out of the state. It invites unfettered racial profiling and the abuse of police power. And, if allowed to stand, it opens the door to states’ writing their own foreign policy, in defiance of the Constitution.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Books in a Digital Age
text: Readers discuss e-book pricing and the future of publishing.

headline: Mets Rally After Losing 3-Run Lead to Giants
text: The follies were replayed on televisions throughout the clubhouse, repeatedly showing Manager Terry Collins wincing with disgust. The music still played and the players still smiled, because a win helped soothe Collins’s frustration.

headline: The Footprints on a Path to Gold
text: MAUN, Botswana — Victor Nkape’s 12-year-old daughter was running around the family’s cattle post here, amid the brambles, cows, goats and an occasional donkey, when he was struck by something that made the girl different.

headline: Plato’s Body, and Mine
text: IF only I had read Plato.

headline: On Old Walls, New Despair
text: LISBON

headline: A Body, a Scandal and China
text: IT all began with a dead body, in a hotel in the Chinese city of Chongqing. The corpse belonged to a British businessman who was said to have drunk himself to death — odd, considering that he rarely drank.

headline: Hoyer and Epstein Try to Build Winner for Wrigley
text: Jed Hoyer won two World Series, each with a very different meaning, as an assistant under Theo Epstein for the Boston Red Sox. The 2004 title signified the completion of a job that started before they arrived. The 2007 title fulfilled a new vision.

headline: The Wrath of Grapes
text: We know from a rare personal admission that Mitt Romney experienced a faint whiff of alcohol, a long, long time ago. “I tasted a beer and tried a cigarette once as a wayward teenager,” he said last November, “and never tried it again.”

headline: Gray Matter: A Facial Theory of Politics
text: In Gray Matter, Leonard Mlodinow writes that eyes of a certain curvature and a slight widow’s peak can help win an election.

headline: Portugal’s Pain, in Pictures
text: In Sunday’s column, I describe how Portugal’s capital changed through the lens of Ana Luisa Nogueira’s camera, which she used to photograph the writing on Lisbon’s buildings. Here are just a few of the pictures she has taken over the last two years.

headline: Down With Everything
text: DOES America need an Arab Spring? That was the question on my mind when I called Frank Fukuyama, the Stanford professor and author of “The End of History and the Last Man.” Fukuyama has been working on a two-volume opus called “The Origins of Political Order,” and I could detect from his recent writings that his research was leading him to ask a very radical question about America’s political order today, namely: has American gone from a democracy to a “vetocracy” — from a system designed to prevent anyone in government from amassing too much power to a system in which no one can aggregate enough power to make any important decisions at all?

headline: Alex Cassie, Who Aided ‘Great Escape’ From Nazis, Dies at 95
text: It was on the moonless night of March 24 and 25, 1944, that 76 Allied prisoners of war, most of them British, clambered down a 30-foot shaft and crawled through a 340-foot-long tunnel below the supposedly escape-proof Stalag Luft III camp in eastern Germany — the daring breakout that was celebrated in the classic 1963 movie “The Great Escape.”

headline: Taking the Waste Out of Wastewater
text: Drinking water reclaimed from sewage might sound disgusting, but it could be a necessary solution to our domestic water woes.

headline: ‘Taking the Waste Out of Wastewater’
text: Fourteen states suffering under drought. Water use in Southwest heads for day of reckoning. Water-pollution laws violated more than 500,000 times in five years. Ruptures in aging water systems cause pollutants to seep into water supplies.

headline: Letting Go Of
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Let us all breathe a sigh of relief. The Sunday puzzle has returned to normal. However you might define that.

headline: Bert Weedon, Guitar Teacher to a Generation, Dies at 91
text: Bert Weedon, a British guitarist whose popular instructional manual “Play in a Day” taught the instrument to a generation of young hopefuls — young hopefuls named Pete Townshend, Eric Clapton, John Lennon and Paul McCartney — died on Friday at his home in Beaconsfield, in the English county of Buckinghamshire. He was 91.

headline: Champions Come and Go Over 50 Years of Columns
text: In November 1934, Lester Markel, the Sunday editor of The New York Times, wrote to José Raúl Capablanca, a former world chess champion:

headline: The China Syndrome
text: My Sunday column is about the extraordinary scandal unfolding in China around Bo Xilai and his family. I thought I had seen everything in China, but I’m floored when a Politburo member’s wife is detained for allegedly murdering a foreigner.

headline: Program for Low-Income Housing Compels Building in Poor Neighborhoods
text: Plans to build a low-income apartment complex for seniors in one of San Antonio’s most fashionable neighborhoods had been posted for barely a week in January when the fury began.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 22
text: With Mitt Romney revamping his campaign to suit his status as the presumptive Republican nominee, the chatter about who could be his No. 2 is getting louder.

headline: Furnishing the House, Savoring the Crème Brûlée
text: Five years ago, you’d have been hard-pressed to find a cocktail-craving 30-something headed to a haute bar in Dallas’s design district, a once-industrial enclave centrally situated close to the Main Street district, near downtown. But now the design district is attracting new retailers, deep-pocketed developers and plenty of shoppers, thanks to a slew of buzz-worthy restaurants, chic stores and daring art galleries opening alongside brand-new apartments and lofts.

headline: Postgame Comments: Real Madrid 2, Barcelona 1
text: Cristiano Ronaldo scored his league-leading 42nd goal from a tight angle in the 73rd minute — answering a tying goal moments earlier from Alexis Sanchez — to give Real Madrid a 2-1 victory at Barcelona on Saturday. The defeat was Barcelona’s first at home in 55 games, and most likely signaled the end of the Catalans’ three-year reign as Spanish champions.

headline: Bahrain Race Is Not First Controversy for Formula One
text: LONDON — The furor over the decision to run this year’s Bahrain Grand Prix has cast Formula One motor racing into a controversy that is making headlines around the world, some of them in countries where most people would scarcely know their Fangios and their Schumachers, their Nürburgrings and their Monzas, from names picked at random from a telephone directory or an atlas.

headline: A Healing Presence Through 3 Administrations
text: When Gov. Ann Richards needed a flu shot in 1992, she summoned Tim Flynn, the Texas Capitol’s recently installed nurse, to her office.

headline: Rangers Await the Return of a Dynamic Rookie
text: The Rangers’ lineup will get a needed injection of speed for Game 6 in Ottawa on Monday when Carl Hagelin returns from his suspension. Hagelin was suspended for three games by the N.H.L. for a high hit in Game 2 that gave the Senators captain Daniel Alfredsson a concussion.

headline: Remembering a Fallen Firefighter
text: Relatives and members of the New York Fire Department paid their respects on Saturday at a funeral Mass for Lt. Richard A. Nappi, 47, on Long Island.

headline: Conservative Nonprofit Acts as a Stealth Business Lobbyist
text: Desperate for new revenue, Ohio lawmakers introduced legislation last year that would make it easier to recover money from businesses that defraud the state.

headline: Two Late Touchdowns Lift Yankees to a Surreal Victory in Boston
text: BOSTON — After so much frustration and disappointment two weeks into the season, it seemed things could not get any worse for the Boston Red Sox. But along came Nick Swisher, Mark Teixeira and the Yankees to prove that it could.

headline: ‘Presidential’ vs. ‘Political’ Trips: A Blurry Line, and Tricky Math
text: WASHINGTON — Facing 5,000 enthusiastic students at Florida Atlantic University, President Obama rolled up his sleeves and raised his voice to chastise Republicans for their spending cuts and “broken-down theories,” evoking chants of “Four more years!”

headline: Quietly Finishing the Job That Walsh Started
text: When the meddling and the mayhem became too much, Donnie Walsh extracted himself from Madison Square Garden and retreated 700 miles to the west, his work unfinished.

headline: In Uprooting of Kurds, Iraq Tests a Fragile National Unity
text: KHANAQIN, Iraq — In January, the dismembered body of Wisam Jumai, a Kurdish intelligence officer, was discovered in a field in Sadiyah, a small town in northeastern Iraq. Soon his family and friends, one after another, received text messages offering a choice: leave or be killed.

headline: In the 21st Perfect Game, Another Sigh for the Mets
text: With the third overall pick in the 2004 draft, the Mets decided to find a future ace for their starting rotation. They focused on three college pitchers: Justin Verlander of Old Dominion, Jered Weaver of Long Beach State and Philip Humber of Rice.

headline: From the Bench to the Grass Roots
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Today’s Vineyards, Yesterday’s Tall Oaks
text: On a recent sunny day in the Napa Valley, Robin Grossinger cupped his hands around his eyes and surveyed the landscape. He said the scene gave him “a feeling of grandeur.”

headline: Top-Seeded in First Round, Rangers May Not See the Second
text: The Rangers were not supposed to be hearing boos at Madison Square Garden this spring. But that was how their fans sent them off Saturday night after a 2-0 loss to the Ottawa Senators put the Rangers, the top-seeded team in the Eastern Conference, on the brink of elimination in the first round of the playoffs.

headline: San Francisco Puts Brakes on an App for Transit
text: If all goes according to the five-year plan approved by the Board of Supervisors, the city and county of San Francisco will upgrade its technology infrastructure to accommodate such trendy things as social networks, cloud computing, crowd-sourcing, open-source software and location-aware apps. But by then it will be 2016, or more than 10 product cycles by Silicon Valley standards.

headline: CrossFit Oakland
text: Sweaty people run laps on an urban side street, dodging forklifts from nearby industries. They go into a warehouse, where they grunt and groan through their weight lifting and conditioning workout at Crossfit Oakland, in Emeryville. Some say CrossFit is a cult. Others, especially post-workout, don’t say anything. They can’t. They’re too tired.

headline: Double Doses of Runs Batted In
text: In Saturday’s Yankees victory over Boston, Nick Swisher and Mark Teixeira each had six runs batted in. It was the fifth time in Yankees history that two players drove in at least six runs in the same game.

headline: Gouged by Some Small Groceries, Food Program Cracks Down
text: At Rancho Grande Supermarket in San Pablo, a package of 18 corn tortillas recently cost $7.80.

headline: Garcia Is Dark Cloud in Yankees’ Silver Lining
text: BOSTON — Somewhat obscured by the Yankees’ remarkable comeback over the Boston Red Sox on Saturday was another bad start by Freddy Garcia, whose velocity was down and whose pitches were up in the strike zone.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 21, 2012

headline: Senators Keep Lid on the Top Scorers
text: The cry of coaches in the Stanley Cup playoffs is for the best players on the team to actually play like the best players. After losing to Ottawa, 2-0, in Game 5 on Saturday to fall behind by three games to two in the Eastern Conference quarterfinals, the Rangers can search for a lot of reasons for their struggles. But the failures of Marian Gaborik and Brad Richards surely lead the list.

headline: Corrections: April 22
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 5
text: The Ottawa Senators pushed the top-seeded New York Rangers to the brink of elimination with a 2-0 victory Saturday night.

headline: Pedestrians Injured After Three-Car Wreck Spills Onto Sidewalk in Midtown
text: At least 10 people were injured Saturday night after a three-vehicle accident at the intersection of 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas in Midtown, the police said.

Wolf of River Vale, N.J. Rabbi James L. Simon is to officiate at the Estate at Florentine Gardens, an event venue, in River Vale.

text: Lynn Anne Faria and Kendra Lee Hutchinson were married Saturday evening at the Inn at Hudson in Hudson, N.Y. Leah D. Bonnema, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

text: Katherine Marie Cyrul and Gregory Andrew Frischmann were married Saturday at the Wadsworth Mansion at Long Hill Estate in Middletown, Conn. The Rev. James A. Stinson, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

text: Yiyang Wu and Benjamin Harnjy Cheng were married Saturday evening at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles L. Howard, a Lutheran minister and the University of Pennsylvania’s chaplain, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

text: Stacey Leigh Carfi and Dr. Andrew Alexander Stec were married Saturday evening at the Hilton Key Largo Resort in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. Joe Gallant, a priest ordained by the National Catholic Church, led a nondenominational ceremony.

Veale of West Hartford, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Sean Park Dobbin, the son of Linda Sue Park and Ben E. Dobbin of Rochester. Teresa Werth, a Sanctuary of Life minister, officiated at the Memorial Art Gallery in Rochester.

text: Ariel Esther Greenstein and Patrick Michael Dalin are to be married Sunday evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia. Rabbi Jill L. Maderer is to perform the ceremony.

text: Lesley Ann Slater and Kenneth Matthew Stumphauzer were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Janet Roberts at the Yale Club in Manhattan.

text: Lauren Michele Barkley and Dr. Kaivon Paul Rahaghi were married Saturday at the Regent Palms on Providenciales, an island that is a part of Turks and Caicos. The Rev. Sherlock Padmore, a Christ Is the Answer minister, led a nondenominational ceremony.
