text: Melissa Marshall McGuirk, a daughter of Nancy D. McGuirk and Terence Foster McGuirk of Atlanta, was married Saturday evening to Harold Edward Maude III, a son of Cathy K. Maude and Mr. Maude Jr. of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. Victor Donald Pentz, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Wesley United Methodist Church on St. Simons Island, Ga.

headline: Diego Prieto and Brad Oscar
text: Diego Prieto and Brad Oscar, both actors, were married Monday evening at the Arena Stage at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington. Molly Smith, a Universal Life minister and the theater’s artistic director, officiated.

headline: Elana Wilf and Brett Tanzman
text: Elana Beth Wilf, a daughter of Audrey and Zygmunt Wilf of Springfield, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Brett Evan Tanzman, the son of Brenda and Roy Tanzman of South Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Eliot I. Malomet is to officiate at the Museum of American Finance in New York.

headline: Alice Hagge, Adam Carey
text: Alice Van Keuren Hagge and Adam Max Carey were married Saturday evening at the Claremont House Bed and Breakfast in Rome, Ga. The Rev. L. B. Caywood, a retired Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: Emily Muncie, Benjamin Ciesinski
text: Emily Katharine Muncie and Benjamin Alan Ciesinski were married Saturday at Calvary Episcopal Church in Cincinnati. The Rev. Jason E. Leo, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Natalie Jones and Patrick Hallahan
text: Natalie Rita Jones and Patrick William Hallahan were married Monday in McLean, Va., at the home of Terry McAuliffe, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. McAuliffe, a friend of the couple who was appointed a civil celebrant by the Circuit Court of Fairfax County, Va., for the occasion, officiated.

headline: In Game as in the Season, ‘Things Kind of Snowballed’
text: BOSTON — With each somber pitching change in the grisly late innings Saturday, Bobby Valentine absorbed the fans’ frustration at Fenway Park. The Boston Red Sox are playing just as poorly for Valentine as they did for Terry Francona last September, and the boos washed over him.

headline: Already in Myanmar’s Reformation, an Impasse
text: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and 42 members of her National League for Democracy insist they will not take the oath of office on Monday unless a single problematic word is changed: The newly elected members of Parliament are refusing to swear that they will “safeguard” the Constitution. Instead, they want to say they’ll “respect” it.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: In Tehelka, a profile of Maharashtra Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan suggests that within a year or a month, depending on which anonymously sourced politician you listen to, a new leader will have replaced the state chief minister belonging to the Congress Party. The problem with Mr. Chavan, according to the article, is as much that he was imposed on Maharashtra by New Delhi to clean up the aftermath of the Adarsh housing society scandal in 2010, as that he is by all accounts “a good man,” unable to be swayed by land interests thereby unsuited to the state’s politics.

headline: Ryan Tannehill, 3rd-Ranked Quarterback in 2012 Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: Kenyans Kipsang and Keitany Take Wins at London Marathon
text: LONDON — They finished the way they always seem to finish now in big-city marathons, Kenyans winning so elegantly and regularly that they become almost interchangeable in their dominance.

headline: Have a Good Earth Day
text: Happy Earth Day, everyone. I hope at least some moment for you holds the joy exhibited by my son Jack when he got to dance inside an ancient redwood.  Share some such moments here.

headline: Hollande and Sarkozy Head to Runoff in French Race
text: PARIS — The Socialist candidate, François Hollande, won a narrow victory in Sunday’s first round of France’s presidential elections, riding promises of economic growth and a general dislike for the incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, into a favorable position before a runoff with Mr. Sarkozy on May 6.

headline: Updates on the French Presidential Election
text: The Lede followed developments in the first round of presidential voting in France on Sunday as President Nicolas Sarkozy came in second against his Socialist challenger, François Hollande, in his bid for a second term. The two will compete head-to-head in a run-off election on May 6.

headline: That Special Day: Bah, Humbug?
text: When I was growing up in the suburbs of New York, our first local Earth Day was organized around a drive to a town field where families were urged to dump items from their basements for recycling rather than tossing them in the trash. Hmmm. Recycling. It was an eye-opening concept for a kid in 1970.

headline: With Pact, U.S. Agrees to Help Afghans for Years to Come
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of negotiations, the United States and Afghanistan completed drafts of a strategic partnership agreement on Sunday that pledges American support for Afghanistan for 10 years after the withdrawal of combat troops at the end of 2014.

headline: The Drywall Chronicles
text: So Mitt Romney gave a speech at a closed Ohio drywall factory, which he tried to use as a symbol of Obama’s economic failure. The symbolism was perfect — not as an illustration of Obama’s failure, but as an illustration of just how stupid Romney thinks we are.

headline: Offering Luxury Stays With Some Breaks
text: The closest that many travelers get to a luxury hotel is by looking at an ad in a glossy magazine, but several new properties offer posh living for the midrange budget.

headline: Disruptions: With New Comforts, Growing Complacent
text: Google and Facebook, young and successful companies that they are, risk being left behind as technology shifts from PCs and Web browsers to mobile devices.

headline: Double Doses of Runs Batted In
text: In Saturday’s Yankees victory over Boston, Nick Swisher and Mark Teixeira each had six runs batted in. It was the fifth time in Yankees history that two players drove in at least six runs in the same game.

headline: Leading U.S. Under-20s, Ramos Likes What He Sees
text: As the third United States under-20 camp of the year was winding down recently in Portland, Ore., the team’s new head coach, Tab Ramos, was still getting settled into the job.

headline: Excerpt: 'A Streetcar Named Desire'
text: A scene from the Broadway revival of the Tennessee Williams play, with Blair Underwood as Stanley and Nicole Ari Parker as Blanche.

headline: Netherlands Pushes for Austerity Cuts Even as Debt Crisis Deals Blow to Leadership
text: BRUSSELS — The Dutch government — one of the last in Europe with an untarnished credit rating on the line — indicated Sunday that it would press ahead with efforts to pass an austerity budget, even as it appeared to be the latest European leadership forced into early elections by the Continent’s debt crisis.

headline: Applying the ‘Torres Blueprint’ to Neil’s Hit on Boyle
text: Does Ottawa’s Chris Neil deserve to be suspended for his hit on the Rangers’ Brian Boyle? Rangers Coach John Tortorella thinks so

headline: Secret Service Needs More Women, Lawmakers Say
text: WASHINGTON — Two female lawmakers, both of them members of oversight committees, said Sunday that the dearth of women Secret Service agents might have contributed to the scandal linking agency personnel to prostitutes in Colombia. And they credited a female supervisor in the agency for bringing it to light.

headline: ‘Think Like a Man’ Tops the Weekend Box Office
text: The No. 1 movie in North America over the weekend, and by a long shot (sorry, Zac Efron), came as a shock to the movie industry: “Think Like a Man,” a low-budget ensemble comedy aimed at African-American audiences, took in an estimated $33 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Sony spent less than $13 million to make this film, which is based on Steve Harvey’s book “Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man” and features the comedian Kevin Hart.

headline: Original Review: ‘A Streetcar Named Desire’
text: Brooks Atkinson’s original 1947 review of the Tennessee Williams play starring Marlon Brando, Jessica Tandy and Kim Hunter.

headline: Goodbye, Cruel World, I’m Joining the Circus
text: They say theater is the most ephemeral art, and yet it’s not just the landmark buildings on Broadway that remind us of ghosts of show business past.

headline: Vigorous Interpretations of Sounds Both Old and New
text: “In a mosaic each detail appears splendidly conceived,” the cellist Christophe Coin wrote in the booklet notes for a recording of string quartets by Beethoven as performed by the Quatuor Mosaïques, the sterling Austrian ensemble of which Mr. Coin is a member. “But it is the overall picture that one takes in at a single glance,” he continued, explaining that a similar process is brought to bear when a quartet weighs all the various factors that go into forming an interpretation.

headline: The Flick of a Skirt Can Speak Louder Than Words
text: Katie Workum takes on a lot in “Fruitlands,” her new dance named after a failed commune created in the 19th century by the American transcendentalist Amos Bronson Alcott. His daughter was Louisa May Alcott, and it’s hard to push her most famous novel to the back of your mind when watching this showcase for four women, each strong in a delicate way.

headline: Administration Torn on Secret Service Scandal Response
text: WASHINGTON — Just before Air Force One begins its descent, a group of agents huddle in a cabin near the back to study a map, a diagram and a step-by-step itinerary detailing the president’s every move once he steps off the plane.

headline: Discovering New Old Garry Winogrand Photographs
text: This week’s Look pages feature pictures taken by Garry Winogrand at the 1960 Democratic National Convention. They were discovered last year by Leo Rubinfien when he was going through the vast archive of Winogrand’s work at the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson.

headline: What We Talk About When We Talk About QE
text: Karl Smith is bemused; in two posts he asks what Wall Street thinks quantitative easing does, and apparently is getting a lot of vehemence but no coherence. (I liked this comment: “Zero hedge commentary suggests the fed manipulates our very life blood, as ordered by the lizard men, in order to create infinite debt and establish a soviet central planning regime.”)

headline: High on Emotion in the Mediterranean Glow of Folk Motifs
text: Nelly van Bommel, who was born to Dutch parents and grew up in France, is a choreographer with a penchant for athleticism and humor. Her narrative threads are loose, but one intention — at least made evident in “Pinguli, Pinguli,” shown at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Wednesday night — is to tell quick episodic stories that lean on the side of absurdity.

headline: 'Jesus Christ Superstar'
text: Scenes from the 2012 Broadway revival at the Neil Simon Theater starring Paul Nolan as Jesus and Josh Young as Judas.

headline: The First Round of the French Elections
text: Residents of France went to the polls on Sunday to winnow the field of presidential candidates from ten to two, who will face each other in a runoff on May 6.

headline: TimesCast | Small Money for Broadway
text: A new grassroots business model on Broadway, as small investors back a revival of “Godspell.”

headline: Climate Change to Affect Corn Prices, Study Says
text: Researchers have found that climate change is likely to have far greater influence on the volatility of corn prices over the next three decades than factors that recently have been blamed for price swings — like oil prices, trade policies and government biofuel mandates.

headline: A Lighter Side of Arm Wrestling, for Charity, Sport and Feminism
text: In a sweaty, packed back room at Public Assembly in Williamsburg on Friday night, an M.C. pumped up the crowd with profanity-laced announcements, burlesque dancers and an accordionist vied for the crowd’s attention, and a dance-off was in the offing.

headline: The Met’s ‘Ring’ After Oiling
text: No more sliding god entrances. Siegmund and Sieglinde move their intimate moments closer to the audience. And the creaking quotient has been reduced.

headline: Slashes and Shrieks in a Clamorous Return to the Barricades
text: David Coll, a young American composer based in Belgium, provided a perfectly reasonable accounting for the impulses that led him to create “Position, Influence,” a work presented at Roulette on Friday evening during the third and last program of this year’s MATA Festival. In an onstage interview Mr. Coll said that the piece reflected his political awakening during two years spent in Paris recently.

headline: Taking Eye Off Standings, Knicks Escape Against the Hawks
text: ATLANTA — The first step in the Knicks’ playoff preparation was to stop fixating on their playoff preparation, or at least the part about improving their postseason position.

headline: Aiming for Clarity, Fed Still Falls Short in Some Eyes
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has tried to speak more clearly and more frequently than his predecessors. He has lectured college students, met with members of the military and, since last April, held quarterly news conferences.

headline: Glaad Media Awards Honor Chaz Bono and Others
text: The 23rd Glaad Media Awards honored Chaz Bono, the transgender activist and author; the actor Josh Hutcherson; and others on Saturday in Los Angeles. The film “Becoming Chaz” was chosen as outstanding documentary, and Mr. Bono received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which was presented by his mother, Cher, and stepmother, Mary Bono Mack, for his work in fighting homophobia. Mr. Hutcherson was recognized for his efforts with the antibullying campaign Straight but Not Narrow.

headline: Cavorting in Bed and on the Stump Around Election Time in California
text: At the start of Seth Greenland’s comic novel “The Angry Buddhist” two American women get matching tattoos to commemorate their quickie affair in Mexico. Mr. Greenland notes that it will be harder for the married woman to explain why she has a new manga-style kitten on her buttock than it will for her single lover. Really, it’s hard to argue with that.

headline: Giroux and Flyers Finish Off Penguins
text: PHILADELPHIA — Just before the opening face-off of the Flyers’ playoff game against the Penguins on Sunday, Claude Giroux of Philadelphia skated over to his bench. He wanted to tell his teammate Danny Briere something. Briere leaned in close.

headline: A Muscular Performance to Ring Through Museum Halls
text: The Turkish pianist Fazil Say’s performance at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night was the only traditional piano recital presented in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium this season. That there was not a whole series of piano recitals represents a significant change in the institution’s musical offerings.

headline: ‘American Psycho’ as a Musical
text: The Headlong Theater Company in London has announced that the world premiere of the musical adaptation of “American Psycho,” based on the 1991 novel by Bret Easton Ellis, will be part of its 2012-13 season. Rupert Goold (“Enron”) will direct the production, which has music and lyrics by Duncan Sheik (“Spring Awakening”) and a book by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”). An opening date has not been set.

headline: QE Or Not QE, That Is The Question
text: OK, some readers have asked me to react to this critique by Mike Kimel. Brief response: Kimel apparently misses the distinction between ordinary monetary policy and quantitative easing, and also misunderstands what the Fed is buying.

headline: The Living Word
text: There is a standard view about language that one finds among philosophers, language departments, pundits and politicians.  It is the idea that a language like English is a semi-stable abstract object that we learn to some degree or other and then use in order to communicate or express ideas and perform certain tasks.  I call this the static picture of language, because, even though it acknowledges some language change, the pace of change is thought to be slow, and what change there is, is thought to be the hard fought product of conflict.  Thus, even the “revisionist” picture of language sketched by Gary Gutting in a recent Stone column counts as static on my view, because the change is slow and it must overcome resistance.

headline: Rangers, Sent to Brink, Have Very Little to Say
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers have learned the painful lesson that 51 wins, 109 points and the Eastern Conference regular-season title are of little value in the Stanley Cup playoffs. More than six months of resounding success over an 82-game season will become meaningless if they lose one of the next two games in the conference quarterfinals with the Ottawa Senators.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A More Vocal Federal Reserve
text: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has tried to speak more clearly and more frequently than his predecessors.

headline: Scots Win Lady Milne Trophy
text: The Lady Milne Trophy is an annual competition among women’s teams representing England, Ireland, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. This year’s event was held last weekend in Llandrindod Wells, Wales.

headline: What the National Front’s ‘Victory’ Will Mean
text: LONDON — The French love a protest vote and the electoral system is devised to indulge them. On Sunday, we are told, they voted with their hearts and in two weeks’ time they will vote with their heads.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: In Mitt Romney’s first full week without a major challenger to the Republican nomination, he focused his attacks on President Obama, who visited the swing state of Ohio for the fourth time since January.

headline: Film Festival Blooms With Ripe Perversity
text: If you’re one of those people who like to leave a movie theater feeling as if you’ve been punched, the Tribeca Film Festival stands ready to slug you.

headline: A Chance to Draw Attention to Yourself
text: What does it take to get a guy in his late 30s, a woman in her late 40s and a man in his early 60s practically thrown out of the august Upper East Side town house of the Society of Illustrators?

headline: A Son of Restaurants Calls for the Check
text: The dishes come out of the kitchen punctually in “The Big Meal,” Dan LeFranc’s multigenerational play set entirely in a series of unnamed restaurants.

headline: A Ruler in Crosswords
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s rare that we see a theme with repeated words in it, but we have one today, and I have to say that I thought it was very clever.

headline: Filmmaker Wins Case Against I.R.S.
text: Documentary filmmakers can breathe a sigh of relief, knowing that the producer and director Lee Storey won her case last week against the commissioner of Internal Revenue in United States Tax Court. The I.R.S. tried to disallow Ms. Storey’s deduction of expenses incurred while making and marketing the film “Smile ’Til It Hurts: The Up With People Story.” The movie played the festival circuit after it was finished in 2008, but it has yet to become a moneymaker. So the tax collectors contended that Ms. Storey, who is a practicing lawyer when she is not making documentary films, was engaged in a hobby — not a business — because she enjoyed filmmaking and wasn’t turning a profit despite considerable efforts to do so. That contention sent shivers through the ranks of documentary filmmakers, many of whom are in the same boat much of the time. Among the organizations that joined in a brief in support of Ms. Storey’s position — that businesslike behavior and an honest effort to turn a profit, among other things, entitled her to the deductions — were the International Documentary Association, Film Independent, the National Association of Latino Independent Producers, Women Make Movies, the National Alliance for Media Art and Culture, and the University Film and Video Association. In a ruling dated April 19 the tax court saw it Ms. Storey’s way. The court said that she was engaged in a real business, that her deductions were legitimate, and that she did not owe about $250,000, plus penalties, that was being claimed by the I.R.S. for 2006, 2007 and 2008.

headline: Private Electronic Lagoons Just Above the Aural Horizon
text: Watchful waiting was good strategy at the Unsound Festival, a five-day international caucus of the (mostly) electronic fringe in New York that ended on Sunday. Unsound’s offerings covered thrash-metal, dub reggae and ethereal pop. But they converged on a fondness for the amorphous, the unresolved, the shadowy, the liminal — sounds appearing just above the aural horizon — merged with the technology of loops, echoes and effects, and often with a video backdrop.

headline: With His Closer Struggling, Collins Decides It’s Time for Pep Talk
text: Frank Francisco represented the Mets’ version of a splashy off-season signing when the cash-poor club gave him a two-year, $12 million deal to close games. After Francisco’s second week in the role, Manager Terry Collins has already had to issue a vote of confidence.

headline: Part of Waste Problem Is Now Part of Solution
text: HONEST TEA, like other organic beverage sellers, normally promotes its real leaves, fair trade certified tea, less sugary taste and environmentally friendly packaging. Its newest campaign acknowledges that it is part of a problem of waste in discarded drink containers and, to counter that, encourages more recycling.

headline: Pelfrey Remembers a Perfect Teammate
text: Mike Pelfrey watched the highlights of a former minor league teammate, but it was not the same player he remembered.

headline: Czechs Protest New Austerity Measures
text: PARIS — Czechs over the weekend staged some of the biggest demonstrations in their country since the fall of Communism, taking to the streets to protest the austerity measures and rampant corruption that have brought the center-right government to the brink of collapse.

headline: As Protests Continue, Vettel Wins Bahrain Grand Prix
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — For the first time in a three-day weekend of auto racing at the Formula One circuit outside Manama, the emphasis on Sunday was on just auto racing.

headline: TV Corrects Itself, Just Not on the Air
text: After broadcasting an audio clip on the “Today” show about George Zimmerman last month that hit the trifecta of being misleading, incendiary and dead-bang wrong, NBC News management took serious action: it fired the producer in charge and issued a statement apologizing for making it appear as if Mr. Zimmerman had made overtly racist statements.

headline: China, Amid Uncertainty at Home and in Europe, Looks to Germany
text: BRUSSELS — As Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China tours Europe this week, it is no accident that Germany occupies a special place on his itinerary.

headline: John A. Hoyt, Champion for Animals, Is Dead at 80
text: John A. Hoyt, who made the Humane Society of the United States the largest anticruelty organization in the country during an era when changing cultural attitudes were greatly expanding the number of animal protection groups, died on April 15 in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 80.

text: WASHINGTON — Meetings of finance ministers and central bankers here over the weekend started with a pledge by wealthy nations to significantly increase the lending capacity of the International Monetary Fund to defend against the possibility of worsening economic conditions in the debt-laden euro zone.

headline: The Wrong Way to Stop Fake Drugs
text: Washington

headline: Start-Up Aims to Stream Pay TV Onto Web Devices
text: In a move that could hasten the slow pace of so-called TV Everywhere, a technology start-up is introducing a way to move a whole subscription’s worth of TV onto the Web, with or without the subscription company’s permission.

headline: From Doughnuts to Dollars, Building a Winner
text: From the visitors’ dugout last week, before a game at Fenway Park, Jon Daniels gazed out to his past. It was right up there, in the center-field bleachers, where he sat for the 1999 All-Star Game in Boston. Daniels had just graduated from Cornell and was working nearby, on the business side of Dunkin’ Donuts. He could not have known his future was right before him.

headline: The Face of U.S. Wrestling Will Change for the Games
text: IOWA CITY — Sandwiched around Rulon Gardner’s failed comeback and Henry Cejudo’s defeat and shoe-removing retirement, USA Wrestling filled its Olympic team with fresh-faced talent grappling for broader fame.

headline: Jeep Signs On as USA Basketball Sponsor
text: The United States Olympic program might not have picked its basketball team yet, but the team already has a full lineup of sponsors.

headline: Kings Eliminate Canucks; Bruins Head to Game 7
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A year ago the Vancouver Canucks came within a game of winning the Stanley Cup, losing the finals to the Boston Bruins in seven games.

headline: Go West, Young Religion: Mormonism on Exhibit
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The president, according to Mormon doctrine, is literally a seer, a prophet — the president, that is, of the church. Usually American presidents have a somewhat lower reputation.

headline: How States Should Approach Immigration
text: Arizona and Alabama have run into controversy. What are the alternatives to their policies?

headline: Let Arizona’s Law Stand
text: Philadelphia

headline: Kuroda-Darvish on Live in Japan
text: BOSTON — The Yankees’ game against the Boston Red Sox was rained out Sunday, which was bad news for those with tickets to Fenway Park, but great news for baseball fans in Japan.

text: When the N.F.L. starts its annual draft Thursday, Andrew Luck is expected to be the first overall pick by the Indianapolis Colts and Robert Griffin III, the Heisman Trophy winner, is expected to go second to the Washington Redskins.

headline: Facing a Robo-Grader? Just Keep Obfuscating Mellifluously
text: A recently released study has concluded that computers are capable of scoring essays on standardized tests as well as human beings do.

headline: Amylin Is Said to Pursue a Sale
text: Amylin Pharmaceuticals is seeking a potential buyer, after it rebuffed an unsolicited $3.5 billion takeover offer from Bristol-Myers Squibb earlier this year, a person briefed on the matter said Sunday.

headline: Missing Child Case in SoHo, All but Closed, Was Revived by a New Agent
text: More than five years ago, well before investigators descended on a basement in SoHo in a search for evidence in the disappearance of Etan Patz, the decades-old case of the missing child was at a dead end.

headline: Prime-Time Ratings Bring Speculation of a Shift in Habits
text: It is the police procedural that has network executives scratching their heads this season: The Case of the Disappearing Viewers.

headline: Amid Racial Shift in Harlem, Political Pulpit Is in Play
text: Adam Clayton Powell Jr. knew what his priorities were when he campaigned to become the first congressman to represent a new district centered in Harlem.

headline: For Results, Twitter Gets Out Early Word, in Code
text: PARIS — In France on Sunday, the flan was decidedly in the oven, while the tomato was surprisingly green. By the same token — according to Twitter, at any rate — the temperature in Budapest hovered near 25 degrees.

headline: Valentine Gets the Blame, and Readily Accepts It
text: BOSTON — A cold, steady rain that postponed Sunday night’s game was the only respite Bobby Valentine and the Boston Red Sox could find from their current dismal predicament. An awful week that began with a controversy and included five consecutive losses was capped Saturday with the team’s worst defeat in recent history, at the hands of the Yankees, no less.

headline: G.A.O. Calls Test Project by Medicare Costly Waste
text: WASHINGTON — Medicare is wasting more than $8 billion on an experimental program that rewards providers of mediocre health care and is unlikely to produce useful results, federal investigators say in a new report.

headline: Justices to Rule on Role of the States in Immigration
text: LENOX, Ga. — When Georgia passed a law last year authorizing the local police to question and detain illegal immigrants, Darvin Eason felt the impact immediately on his farms here in south Georgia.

headline: Gritty Musical Mainstay in the East Village Fades Out
text: For 16 years, the Lakeside Lounge employed a formula that never changed: a handpicked band every night, a jukebox loaded with classic songs, a cadre of quick-witted bartenders working under strings of colored lights, and an old-time photo booth that spat out strips of pictures shot using real film.

headline: Map of Sites of Bike Kiosks in Midtown Is Previewed
text: As New York City prepares for the arrival of its public bike-sharing program in July, most of the intrigue has been over where and how these bikes will be placed in the city.

headline: In Presidential Race’s Give-and-Take, Hope for a Fiscal Compromise
text: WASHINGTON — When television pundits and aging rock stars start commanding headlines in the presidential campaign, it is tempting to conclude that the election season will merely produce a long, painful case of cat scratch fever.

headline: Cuomo Administration, in Shift, Agrees to Whistle-Blower on Disabilities Panel
text: The Cuomo administration pressed the State Senate to disinvite a whistle-blower from a panel discussion on developmental disabilities being held at the Capitol on Monday, state officials said over the weekend.

headline: Water in Your Birdbath? That Will Be $300
text: Imagine Joseph Pomares’s surprise when he went to his local post office in Long Island City, Queens, one Saturday last summer to collect a certified letter. He had no idea what awaited him, but the last thing he expected to find was a summons from the city’s health department.

headline: Iranians Say They Took Secret Data From Drone

text: Months after Mount St. Helens erupted in May 1980, the New Jersey Nets ignited a blast of their own at what was then known as the Rutgers Athletic Center. Timing it to a visit by the Portland Trail Blazers — a franchise based about 50 miles southwest of the volcano — the Nets commemorated the event by handing out key chains filled with authentic Mount St. Helens ash.

text: Photos from the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s play, at the Broadhurst Theater.

text: New Jersey has always been a tired punch line, even before reality television cameras buttressed the stereotype of gum-smacking club-hoppers stuck in turnpike traffic.

headline: The Amnesia Candidate
text: Just how stupid does Mitt Romney think we are? If you’ve been following his campaign from the beginning, that’s a question you have probably asked many times.

headline: Valeri Vasiliev, Defenseman on Soviet Hockey Dynasty, Dies at 62
text: Valeri Vasiliev, the rugged top defenseman with the great Soviet hockey teams of the 1970s and ’80s, who won Olympic gold medals and watched another slip away in stunning fashion to the United States in 1980, died on Thursday in Moscow. He was 62.

headline: Anti-Illegal Immigration Laws in States
text: States that have passed or tried to pass legislation similar to Arizona’s strict immigration enforcement law.

headline: U.S. Wins Under-18 Title Again
text: Nicolas Kerdiles scored two goals and Collin Olson made 27 saves as the United States defeated Sweden, 7-0, in the final of the International Ice Hockey Federation under-18 championships in Brno, Czech Republic. It was the Americans’ fourth straight world title and seventh over all.

headline: The New York Primary
text: Every four years, the New York primary becomes less significant. The front-loading of the parties’ nominating processes has become so intense that Republican voters have made their choice before New Yorkers get a chance to vote on Tuesday. But in a year that started with the most right-wing fringe lineup we have seen, Republicans could have done a lot worse than Mitt Romney.

headline: Rain, Snow, Sleet and Congress
text: How vital is the United States Postal Service? The Senate is attempting to answer that this week as it debates the service’s obvious need to drastically reform its business model in the age of electronic communication. Postal officials say they must close about 3,700 underused post offices (there are 32,000 nationally) while offering alternative services through local businesses. They also want to consolidate hundreds of regional processing centers and eliminate Saturday mail deliveries.

headline: Bahrain Holds Grand Prix, Keeping Protesters at Bay
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Despite clashes between antigovernment protesters and the police in recent days, the Formula One Grand Prix, Bahrain’s showcase annual event, went off without incident on Sunday.

headline: Sports Replay: April 22
text: The day in sports, including the ice hockey under-18 world championships in the Czech Republic, the London Marathon, and the United States Olympic wrestling trials in Iowa City.

headline: Do You Know Your Rights?
text: Under federal labor law, employees have the right to join together to seek better pay and working conditions, with or without a union. If an employer tries to punish organizers, employees have the right to seek protection from the National Labor Relations Board. But employees still don’t have the right to be informed of their rights.

headline: Mud-Less Season
text: There are clear advantages to a spring without mud. I have not lost a boot to the suction of the barnyard swamp. I haven’t had to cut drainage channels through the corral. Nor have I had to tractor through primeval ooze while hauling a round bale to the run-in shed.

headline: Egypt Cancels the Delivery of Gas to Israel
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s state-owned natural gas company said Sunday that it was ending a deal to ship gas to Israel because of a payment dispute. Israeli officials responded by warning that the termination cast a new shadow over the bilateral peace treaty.

headline: Newly Elected Myanmar Lawmakers Balk at Word in the Oath of Office
text: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader in Myanmar, and 42 members of her party who won seats in Parliament in by-elections this month, insist they will not take the oath of office on Monday unless one word in it is changed. Instead of swearing to “safeguard” the country’s current Constitution, they want to say they will “respect” it. So far, the government has not agreed.

headline: A Sad State of Affairs

headline: Shift on Executive Power Lets Obama Bypass Rivals

headline: In Hippie Holdout, a Fight Over Worms and Moats
text: LAGUNITAS, Calif. — To find David Lee Hoffman’s front door, take a right at the bell tower and proceed past the moat with a boat named Titanic II. Step — gingerly — through the stone tunnel, then follow the brick steps up to the Worm Palace and the breathtaking view of the Solar Power Shower Tower.

headline: In Mayoral Race, Opponents Battle Incumbent’s Charm
text: LONDON — The students at Croydon College were not sure what Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, does, exactly. But they said they loved him just the same.

headline: Bernard Rapoport, Deep-Pocketed Texas Liberal, Dies at 94

headline: Your Ad, as Seen on YouTube

headline: Militants and Politics Bedevil Yemen’s New Leaders
text: CAIRO — Two months after a new president took office, Yemen’s fledgling interim government has found itself overwhelmed by a set of dangerous new challenges to the country’s stability, including a series of a bold attacks by a resurgent militant movement in the south and a festering political standoff in the capital.

headline: Manufacturing Bouncing Back For Chinese
text: HONG KONG — A closely watched survey of manufacturing activity in China rebounded in April, offering the latest sign that the Chinese economy was gradually regaining some of the momentum it lost last year.

headline: Sporting Kansas City Is Sitting Pretty These Days

headline: Thousands in Moscow Rally to Call by Patriarch

With no reference to last week’s flurry of activity — Peter declared his gubernatorial candidacy, Alicia decided to stand by his side, Jackie was conveniently, and melodramatically, hospitalized — this installment had a Hamburger Helper feel to it: mostly filler, little meat.

headline: The Cookstove Conundrum
text: Cooking the family meal can be a dangerous business for poor people in developing countries. According to a study by the World Health Organization, indoor air pollution from “primitive household cooking fires” is the leading environmental cause of death in the world. In most rural homes, which lack electricity, a stove can be an open fire and the fuel as basic as wood, dried animal dung or agricultural residue, together known as “biomass” fuels. The result is nearly 2 million deaths a year, worldwide, almost as many as are caused by malaria and tuberculosis combined. What’s worse, cooking with biomass releases carbon dioxide and “black carbon” into the atmosphere and consequently is a significant contributor to climate change.

headline: Prelude to a Kiss
text: The house I grew up in was ordinary in most ways — a small stucco two-story in suburban Florida at the end of a block lined with more of the same. One thing did set it apart, though: it was outfitted with an advanced security system of 57 crucifixes. The crosses were strategically hung throughout the house: the moment you left the gaze-range of one Christ, you walked straight into the radar of another. There were no blind spots, not even in the bathroom. I understood and even admired their ubiquity. There was no place in the house where I could hide from scrutiny. It was checkmate.

headline: First Among Estates
text: MOSCOW — As many as 65,000 people gathered in front of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior in Moscow on Sunday. Judging by the large number of buses parked nearby, they’d been brought in from various parts of Russia. This was not another anti-Putin protest; it was not even a protest: it was a huge communal prayer. Some of the participants were members of the clergy, dressed in gaudy gold-on-red church garb. But most appeared to be ordinary churchgoers who’d heeded the clergy’s call to come pray in defense of the church. Its leaders say it is under attack.

headline: What a Drip
text: The Chemex, that iconic nonelectric coffee maker, has finally met its match. The Kone filter from Able Brewing Equipment ($55 at ablebrewing.com) is a gorgeous piece of coffee gear, a stainless steel filter that fits most cone drippers, and whose precise holes (cut by a photochemical process) allow for a steady flow while minimizing sediment. The resulting best-of-both-worlds brew has the richness of French press and the clean flavor of drip. And unlike other metal filters, there’s no mesh to scrub. Now in its third iteration (a bumper was added, and its holes reconfigured), the Kone is a fixture at next-generation coffee bars like Café Grumpy on Manhattan’s Lower East Side and Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea in Venice, Calif. Able’s founder, Keith Gehrke, a former roaster at a coffee company and a co-founder of Coava in Portland, Ore., is now working on a ceramic coffee maker. Soon, the Kone will have its match, too.

headline: Breakfast Meeting: The Search Is On for Missing Prime-Time Viewers
text: Where are all the television viewers? That’s the question network executives are asking, Bill Carter reports, as they study the lower ratings for prime-time programming this spring. Viewing is down across the board, and it’s affecting hit shows like “Modern Family” as well as less popular offerings. Network executives cite good weather and the change to daylight time, but some analysts see more fundamental reasons, including the sporadic scheduling of new episodes and the preference of more viewers to watch shows on a delayed basis, instead of live.

headline: Charles Colson, R.I.P.
text: I took the last week off from blogging and columnizing in order to do some promotion for my new book on American Christianity, “Bad Religion,” and thus far one of the questions I’ve been asked most frequently involves the proper relationship between Christian faith and politics. In the book, I simultaneously argue that the corrupting influence of partisanship (on both the religious left and religious right) helps explain at least some of institutional Christianity’s post-1960s decline, and that Christians cannot simply be apolitical and leave partisan controversies alone, which would seem like the obvious way to avoid such corruption entirely. Which raises the obvious follow-up: Well, what would a healthier Christian engagement with political issues look like?

headline: Armed and Glamorous
text: In 2000, when the Philadelphia artist Adam Wallacavage began renovating his Victorian brownstone, each room of which has a different theme, old Charles Addams books were his design manual. “Wednesday always had an octopus painted on the end of her bed,” says the skateboarder turned photographer turned chandelier maker. “That was pretty much the inspiration for the octopus chandeliers.” Those chandeliers, which he originally designed for his “20,000 Leagues Under the Sea”-themed living room, mix baroque styling with creepily realistic details like suction-cup-lined arms. The fixtures, handmade with epoxy clay or cast in plaster, have evolved to incorporate vintage squeaky toys and Hello Kitty heads, and will be on view this month in “Shiny Monsters” at the Philadelphia Art Alliance. “I like to do a mix of goofy and elegant,” Wallacavage says.

headline: Please Try This at Home
text: Anyone can explore the living world just as Alexander von Humboldt and Charles Darwin did, even homebodies willing to venture no farther than the terrain around their doorstep. The modern natural historian can capture with camera rather than rifle. Binoculars are handy, but not required. Jars are good for putting bugs into, and heavy books for pressing plants, and a person can never have too many field guides. The one must is a journal, in which explorers note each thing found, when and where. It can be motivating to maintain a running species tally.

headline: Microsoft and Facebook Align Further With Patent Deal
text: SEATTLE — A plan by Facebook to acquire a broad range of patents through a deal with Microsoft is on its surface yet another twist in the battles over intellectual property engulfing the tech business.

headline: Heavy Backpacks Can Spell Chronic Back Pain for Children
text: My 11-year-old grandsons, Stefan and Tomas, weigh about 80 pounds each. On the 20-minute walk to their middle school and the uphill walk home, they carry backpacks that weigh about 12 pounds each, or 15 percent of their body weight.

headline: Government by Executive Order
text: President George W. Bush used his executive power to bypass Congress, almost as a matter of routine. Now President Barack Obama is pulling a similar stunt.

headline: Mr. Smith Goes to Kutaisi
text: KUTAISI, Georgia — It took me more than three hours last Thursday to get from the center of Tbilisi, Georgia’s capital and commercial and cultural hub, to the country’s brand new Parliament building, a stadium-sized oyster-shell-shaped building enmeshed in steel netting. That’s because the Georgian Parliament is being relocated to Kutaisi, this small country’s second-largest city, some 150 miles west.

headline: Investment Fund to Pay $1.3 Billion for Edinburgh Airport
text: LONDON – The investment fund Global Infrastructure Partners agreed on Monday to buy Edinburgh Airport for £807 million, or $1.3 billion, in its latest acquisition in the British airport sector.

headline: Before Game 6, Tight and Tight-Lipped
text: OTTAWA — Daniel Alfredsson, the captain of the Ottawa Senators, said he was “looking forward to playing” Monday night; Brian Boyle is out; and there are two ways for an N.H.L. coach to be uncommunicative — a jolly way and a tight, simmering way.

headline: So Much Life on a Little Patch of Earth
text: BELLINGHAM, Wash. — I’ve logged thousands of miles to catch a glimpse of one exotic creature or another, to Costa Rica to be dazzled by the bird known as the resplendent quetzal, to Hawaii to admire sea turtles, to Venezuela to spy man-eating anacondas. So it seemed more than a little odd that the one time I made a sighting worthy of a scientific publication, I was looking out of my living room window.

headline: Nestle Pays a High Price for Pfizer Unit
text: Nestlé is throwing down its cash.

headline: Riverdale, 6:20 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: A train, trees and the river in the fog.

headline: Pentagon Suspends Security Clearances in Scandal
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The Defense Department has suspended the security clearances of some of the 11 members of the military who are under investigation in a widening prostitution scandal in Colombia, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Monday.

headline: Look of The Moment | Rosie Huntington-Whiteley
text: The Look: Making the Cutoff. Add a dash of embellishment and pair with a crisp white shirt.

headline: Beijing Auto Show: Volkswagen E-Bugster Presages Shape of Drop-Top Beetle
text: Volkswagen used the Beijing auto show to unveil a convertible version of its E-Bugster, an electrically powered Beetle concept first shown in Detroit in January.

headline: M.T.A. Driver Charged With Keeping Woman on Bus
text: A city bus driver was arrested in the Bronx and charged with unlawful imprisonment Sunday night after he refused to let the police take an emotionally disturbed woman off his bus, the police said.

headline: Neil’s Hit Hangs Over Rangers-Senators Series
text: OTTAWA — A question about retribution hung in the air Monday morning ahead of Game 6 of the Rangers-Senators series. It centered on this Game 5 hit by Ottawa’s Chris Neil on the Rangers’ Brian Boyle …

headline: Losing the Future: Gutting Science Training
text: Last month I wrote about how state budget cuts were forcing public universities to raise tuition and cut programs. Some of the subjects most valuable for job and economic growth — like engineering, computer science and health sciences — have been most vulnerable, because they also happen to be among the most expensive to teach.

headline: A Red Sox Moment Even Nonfans Could Love
text: Even a Yankees fan could love this photo. Well, maybe on best behavior.

headline: NATO Shows Confidence in Afghan Security Forces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A week after a complex insurgent attack paralyzed the capital, NATO commanders on Monday offered a startlingly buoyant assessment of security gains across the country and of the readiness of the Afghan police and the army to take full control of their country as American and other international forces leave.

headline: Review of White House Staff Shows No Misconduct in Colombia
text: The White House said on Monday that it had investigated its own staff members and concluded that none of them were involved in the prostitution scandal in Colombia that has ensnared members of the Secret Service and the military.

headline: Police Report Lead in Theft of Chinese Artifacts from Cambridge University’s Fitzwilliam Museum
text: Police think that a stolen white minivan may have been used in a theft earlier this month of precious works of art from China worth nearly $29 million from the Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge in England, the BBC reported.

headline: In a Rivalry Game, Maryland Lacrosse Edges Hopkins
text: One of the greatest rivalries in lacrosse lived up to its advance billing on Saturday night, when Johns Hopkins and Maryland played their 108th game. The sold-out crowd of 8,500 at Homewood Field saw a thrilling battle between the Blue Jays and the Terrapins, two top-ten teams.

headline: Resignation of Police Chief in Martin Case Is Rejected
text: SANFORD, Fla. — Several hours after the city manager publicly announced that he had reached an agreement with Chief Bill R. Lee Jr. to resign over the Sanford Police Department’s handling of the Trayvon Martin shooting case, the City Commission voted late Monday afternoon to reject Chief Lee’s resignation.

headline: Really? Optimism Reduces the Risk of Heart Disease
text: THE FACTS

headline: Reader Idea | English Language Learners Discuss Love and Happiness
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: Plea for Bushwick High: Give Last-Chance School Another Chance
text: The president of the principals' union makes a case to save Bushwick Community High School, a transfer high school that is slated to be closed. Ernest Logan writes: "Not one student I encountered on my recent visit could figure out how losing their principal, teachers and cherished school name was going to help them."

headline: Who’s Afraid of Lindsay Lohan? Troubled Star to Play Elizabeth Taylor
text: It’s pretty clear what Elizabeth Taylor and Lindsay Lohan have in common: Ms. Taylor was one of Hollywood’s most talented and prolific actresses who performed in such enduring films as “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” “Suddenly, Last Summer” and “Butterfield 8,” while Ms. Lohan has performed janitorial duties at a morgue while awaiting a probation violation hearing.

headline: Donations for Eyeglasses in Poor Nations Are Better Than Recycling Used Pairs
text: Giving used eyeglasses to poor countries may please the donors, but it is not worth the high delivery costs, a new study has concluded, and a $10 donation would do more good.

headline: Social Security’s Financial Health Worsens
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration reported a significant deterioration in the financial outlook for Social Security on Monday, while stating that the financial condition of Medicare was stable but still unsustainable.

headline: Americans Remain Wary of the Stock Market, Survey Finds
text: Americans may be starting to feel more financially secure, but many remain wary of investing in the stock market, a new poll from  Bankrate.com finds.

headline: A Europe Tired of Cutbacks Has Few Alternatives
text: FRANKFURT — Citizens from Prague to Paris to Amsterdam have made it abundantly clear the last few days that they are tired of the economic austerity forced on them by the euro zone debt crisis.

headline: Under Scrutiny, Google Spends Record Amount on Lobbying
text: With Congress and privacy watchdogs breathing down its neck, Google is stepping up its lobbying presence inside the Beltway — spending more than Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft combined in the first three months of the year.

headline: Michaels Stores C.E.O. Connected to Wal-Mart Bribery Case
text: As Michaels Stores prepares to go public, the company’s chief executive, John B. Menzer, has been connected to the Mexican bribery inquiry facing Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Safety: Accidental Child Deaths Ebb; Risks Do Not
text: Accidental deaths among children under age 20 declined 29 percent from 2000 to 2009, according to a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, but deaths from poisoning and suffocation increased substantially.

headline: TimesCast | French Elections
text: April 23, 2012 — On Monday, analysts attributed part of a sharp drop in European markets to a narrow first-round victory by an anti-austerity Socialist in the French presidential election.

headline: American Car Parts Makers Gain in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Critics of the Obama administration’s thawed diplomatic policy toward Russia, known as the “reset,” say it has brought few concrete results. But this week, a visiting American trade delegation is promoting an economic benefit — a doubling of exports of American car parts to Russia over the past year.

headline: Assessing the Small Business Tax Cut
text: Early last week, the Democrats held a vote on a tax bill that defined their political philosophy but had no chance of passing. That was the Paying a Fair Share Act of 2012, better known as the Buffett Rule, which failed to get the 60 votes necessary for the Senate to take up the bill. On Thursday, House Republicans countered by passing their “Small Business Tax Cut.” The bill cleared the House handily, 235-173, largely on party lines, but it is no more likely to become law than the Buffett Rule.

headline: Ex-Prime Minister of Iceland Convicted on Charge Related to Financial Crisis
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Vermont Weighs Ending Vaccine Exemption
text: Vermont lawmakers are considering eliminating the “philosophical” exemption to the vaccination requirements that usually apply to children attending school and day care in the state. Vermont has one of the highest rates in the country of children who aren’t vaccinated according to the schedule recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and supporters of ending the exemption (which essentially allows parents to opt out of some or all of the recommended vaccinations on behalf of their children) argue that low vaccination rates contributed to an outbreak of pertussis in the state earlier this year.

headline: White House Announces Arts Education Plan
text: President Obama, aided by prominent artists, hopes to help turn around low-performing schools with a new arts education program, the White House announced on Monday.

headline: Leaderless for Months, CBS Films Appoints Co-Presidents
text: LOS ANGELES — After a difficult start in 2007, CBS Films continues to regroup quietly, and on Monday it named Terry Press and Wolfgang Hammer co-presidents.

headline: Prevention: Shingles Vaccine Is Shown to Be Very Safe
text: A study of people who received the shingles vaccine has found that it is safe and well tolerated, with an extremely low rate of side effects.

headline: Patterns: Brain Scans Forecast Eating and Sexual Behavior
text: Researchers have succeeded in predicting eating behavior and levels of sexual desire.

headline: When Reyes Returns to Citi Field, Will Cheers Follow?
text: David Wright said he expected Jose Reyes to receive a warm reception from the Citi Field crowd when he returns Tuesday night with the Miami Marlins, the team Reyes joined as a free agent this winter.

headline: Facebook’s Profit Falls 12% Ahead of Expected Offering
text: With its initial public offering drawing closer, Facebook disclosed on Monday that its profit in the first quarter fell 12 percent, to $205 million, as its expenses continued to climb.

headline: Mothers Challenge a Trace Contaminant in Tide
text: In their quest to rid cleaning products of toxic chemicals, consumer advocates have now set their sights on Tide, the best-selling laundry detergent.

headline: A Ratings Reprieve for the Networks
text: After plummeting to new depths in the ratings last week, the broadcast networks were granted a small reprieve on Sunday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, overall numbers were up when compared to last week’s in both total viewers and in the a18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by most advertisers. ABC in particular received some positive news, its second Hallmark Hall of Fame film, “Firelight,” drew 7.6 million total viewers, an improvement over the 6.5 million that watched the network’s first Hallmark movie last fall, “Mitch Albom’s Have a Little Faith.” “Once Upon A Time” (also on ABC) was up slightly when compared to its last new episode from three weeks ago, from 8.36 million total viewers to 8.84 million.

headline: The Confusion of Hospital Pricing
text: When Augie Hong awoke with severe abdominal pain nearly two years ago, he went to the hospital emergency room closest to his home in San Francisco. The diagnosis was acute appendicitis, and doctors removed his inflamed appendix.

headline: TimesCast | Myanmar's Political Discord
text: April 23, 2012 — After months of campaigning and a landmark election in Myanmar, Monday was supposed to be the first day of Parliament for former political dissident Aung Sun Su Kyi.

headline: Pretty Famous, but Still Star-Struck
Street Style: Coachella
text: Looks from the second weekend of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Mexican Immigration to U.S. Slowed Significantly, Report Says
text: Mexican immigration to the United States, the largest wave of migrants from a single country in the nation’s history, has stopped increasing after four decades of surging growth and may be declining, according to a report released Monday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: Instagram Deal Puts Horowitz on Defensive
text: Ben Horowitz, the co-founder of venture capital giant Andreessen Horowitz, has one thing to say to the armchair quarterbacks who criticized his decision not to double down on Instagram: Check the scoreboard.

headline: Dutch Governing Coalition Resigns After Failing to Pass Austerity Budget
text: THE HAGUE — The Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, announced the resignation of his coalition government on Monday after its partners failed to agree on austerity measures, leaving the Netherlands with a messy leadership vacuum at a time of anxiety about the euro.

headline: Noodle Soups From the Garden: Simple Vegetarian Pho Broth
text: Not long ago I had a delicious vegetarian pho in a Vietnamese restaurant in Los Angeles. The broth was heady with sweet spices and, like the traditional meaty soup, was served with rice noodles, bean sprouts and fresh herbs. I asked the waiter if he knew how the chef made the stock, and the sous chef came out and told me it involved lots of vegetables (well, yes), spices and … MSG! Though I often get headaches after eating monosodium glutamate, this restaurant didn’t use much of it. Still, when I left, I was determined to come up with my own meatless version of pho, sans MSG.

headline: Met Opera Unveils Summer Season
text: Free full-scale performances by the Metropolitan Opera in New York City’s parks increasingly look like a thing of the past. For the fifth summer in a row, the Met will present recitals instead of complete opera performances.

headline: More ‘Bartender Rock': Readers’ Choices
text: In my last post here, I asked readers to chime in on this whole nebulous business of “bartender rock.” A few went a long way toward defining it, getting much further than I did. Here, for example, is explainer guy from Chicago: “I think the throughline as to what qualifies is that it has credibility. . . . It’s music that doesn’t insist upon itself, but rather catches people’s ears and pushes them to ask, ‘Who is this?’” Peter from Oakland added, “A certain raggedness — or at least a roughness around the edges — seems to define much of what you’ve suggested.”

headline: A Dastardly Plot to Avoid Taxes
text: Contrary to the conventional wisdom, Republicans are not against all tax increases. Rep. Eric Cantor, the House Majority Leader, thinks poor people might need a tax hike.

headline: The Trade Show, Updated
text: The convention and meetings business is a middle-aged child of the jet age, nurtured by cities that built or greatly expanded exhibition halls, starting in the 1970s, to compete for corporate and association events.

headline: U.N. Observers Prove Little Deterrent to Syrian Attacks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces engaged in a bloody game of cat and mouse against United Nations observers on Monday, seeming to punish cities like Hama after the monitors left for daring to protest, and adopting a low profile as the monitors visited the Damascus suburbs.

headline: Recasting Gives a Lift to ‘Sister Act’
text: Recasting shows can be a challenge for Broadway producers when stars leave once their contracts are up – even causing some shows to shutter, as “Promises, Promises” did in 2011 when producers saw little upside in replacing Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth. But one Broadway musical has been having a good run of late with its new leading lady: The musical “Sister Act” has been performing far better at the box office since the former child star Raven-Symoné took over the lead role of Deloris Van Cartier on March 27.

headline: Interview With Alex Karpovsky
text: Alex Karpovsky discusses his leading roles in the thriller “Rubberneck,” which he also directed, and the comedy “Supporting Characters.” Both films played at the Tribeca Film Festival in 2012.

headline: Now Booking | Patagonia’s Best Beds
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: At Kennedy Airport, an Artist Fights to Save Her Sculpture
text: The managing agent for four airlines that run Terminal 1 at John F. Kennedy Airport had a plan: remove and destroy a two-story-tall sculpture that they commissioned 14 years ago and bring in more food stands.

headline: The Urge To Tighten
text: Do we need this? Sheila Bair has joined the crew urging the Fed to stop trying to promote economic recovery, on the grounds that it’s feeding a bond bubble.

headline: Bushism Forever
text: Just to confirm what I said in today’s column:

headline: For 50th Birthday of Shelby Cobra, Vintage Snakes Convene in California
text: In February 1962, Carroll Shelby set out to beat the Chevrolet Corvette by inserting a Ford V-8 engine into a lithe A.C. Ace roadster from England. Born humbly in the speed shop of Dean Moon near Los Angeles, the resulting Shelby Cobra would achieve nobility. And the road-going production version, built on Princeton Avenue in Los Angeles’s Venice neighborhood, sold well for a specialty model, a less punitively priced alternative to the Ferrari.

headline: Honoring a Father’s Memory With Words Carved More Deeply Than an Epitaph
text: If I were forced to describe Héctor Abad’s memoir, “Oblivion,” in a single word, that word would probably be: meh. His book is, to quote an offhandedly poisonous Paul Simon song lyric from the 1980s, “all right in a sort of limited way for an off night.”

headline: Deployment’s Hard Lessons for Children, and Their Teachers
text: Maren Newbold is a rising kindergartner at Yuma Lutheran School in Arizona. She’s a 5-year-old with a cheeky grin, shiny blond hair and a tiny, almost whispery voice. She’s also getting ready to bid her father farewell: he’s a Marine Corps aviator stationed at Marine Corps Air Station Yuma, about to embark on his second deployment in two years.

headline: Jimi Hendrix, Édith Piaf and Other #KitchenPlaylist Staples
text: First we asked chefs to share their cooking playlists; now we’ve turned to you. Below are a few highlights culled from Twitter; tweet yours at @nytdining using the hashtag #kitchenplaylist.

headline: Tribeca Video: Alex Karpovsky’s Pair of Firsts at the Festival
text: Alex Karpovsky may be one of the hardest working actor-filmmakers you don’t know well. A regular player on the indie scene, Mr. Karpovsky has directed five films in the past decade and appeared in a dozen movies in the past two years. He frequently pops up in films that play South by Southwest and Sundance. But this is a year of firsts for him. He has his first recurring role on a television series (Lena Dunham’s “Girls”) and he’s making his first appearance at the Tribeca Film Festival with two movies: “Rubberneck,” a psychological thriller that he also directed, and “Supporting Characters,” a comedy in which he plays a film editor. In this video, Mr. Karpovsky discusses his work both in front of and behind the camera.

headline: For David Paterson, Next Stop: M.T.A.
text: Over the years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board has had among its members its share of lawyers, failed mayoral candidates, union leaders — even the wife of a former Beatle.

headline: Bill Would Crack Down on Lavish Events
text: The Senate will be voting on Tuesday on a broad measure to limit spending at government conferences, and Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican who is the amendment’s author, wants his colleagues to know lavish events are not confined to the General Services Administration, which came under fire recently for holding an extravagant conference in Las Vegas.

headline: When Bots Attack
text: Hmm. In my inbox:

headline: Drilling Down: Making the Most of Cookiegate
text: In Monday’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we highlighted the experience of John Walsh and his Bethel Bakery, a Pittsburgh-area institution that found itself in the national spotlight last week when Mitt Romney compared his cookies to those at 7-Eleven. Mr. Walsh immediately responded by promoting a Cookiegate Special. We went back to him to see how it’s going. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: Vegetarian Pho With Asparagus and Noodles
text: When I make pho with vegetables other than those used to make the broth, as in this springtime pho, I cook the vegetables separately, so as not to infuse their flavor into the broth, and very briefly, so that they retain some crunch. I like to use thick stalks of asparagus and cut them on the diagonal into 2-inch lengths.

headline: Sudanese Warplanes Said to Attack South
text: An aerial bombardment and ground assault on South Sudan in recent days indicated that fighting with Sudan may not be over.

headline: Sweetness That Bites Back
text: FREAKISH. Bizarre. Absurd. Beyond human experience. And that’s been the more measured reaction to the 2010 vintage for German rieslings, which consisted of an unusually small crop of grapes that combined ludicrously high levels of acidity with unexpected amounts of sweetness.

headline: Even in a Prime Neighborhood, Some Forlorn Vacancies
text: As you walk east on 82nd Street with the Metropolitan Museum of Art at your back, Madison Avenue up ahead and lavish homes all around, you might not notice the pretty, pink town house on the south side of the street, No. 12. Its brick facade and white marble base seem perfectly at ease in the neighborhood, but if you stop for a moment and look up, you will see that several windows on the face of this fine building, on this most pristine block, are shattered.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Former Calpers Chief With Fraud
text: Federal regulators charged the former chief executive of the nation’s largest pension fund on Monday with defrauding a private equity firm into paying $20 million to his close friend, the latest case to raise questions about suspected conflicts of interest at state retirement funds.

headline: Barnes & Noble Shares Surge 18% After Jana Takes a Stake
text: Shares in the bookseller Barnes & Noble soared more than 18 percent on Monday after the hedge fund Jana Partners bought a 12 percent stake in the company.

headline: A Face in the Sun
text: Q. Will a facial moisturizer with S.P.F. 15 protection keep the skin from generating vitamin D on a sunny day?

headline: Big Price Tags Attached to Even the Littlest Leagues
text: Youth baseball and softball seasons are opening across the United States. It is a time for youngsters to field grounders and work on their swings while their parents determine whether they need to take out a home-equity loan before heading to the sporting goods store.

headline: Netflix Added 3 Million Online Subscribers in Quarter, but Expects Slower Growth
text: Netflix said on Monday that it finished the first quarter with nearly three million more streaming subscribers than it had started with, showing continued interest from Internet users despite the company’s missteps last year.

headline: Ravens Can Recognize Old Friends, and Foes, Too
text: Ravens have the ability to recognize old friends, a new study reports. And just like humans, they react negatively when seeing a foe.

headline: Many Veterans Face Long Wait for Mental Health Evaluations, Report Finds
text: The inspector general for the Department of Veterans Affairs released a report on Monday confirming what many veterans have long suspected: it takes longer to get a mental health evaluation from V.A. clinicians than the department has been willing to acknowledge.

headline: Portugal’s Finance Minister: We Tried Stimulus and It Didn’t Work
text: Defending austerity is not getting any easier for Europe’s politicians. And Vitor Gaspar, Portugal’s finance minister, has it harder than others. The country’s unemployment rate is 14 percent, and its economy, which has been stagnant for years, is expected to shrink another 3.3 percent in 2012.

headline: More Reserve Teachers Finding Permanent Jobs
text: The number of New York City teachers without a permanent assignment is at its lowest point in several years, solidifying the faith of city and union officials in an agreement on the teacher reserve pool implemented at the beginning of the school year.

headline: TimesCast | A Farewell to New Jersey
text: April 23, 2012 - Monday night, the Nets will play their final basketball game in New Jersey.

headline: The Bill Clinton Habit
text: If you were running the re-election campaign for President Obama, who would you ask for advice? Perhaps the man who almost destroyed his own presidency, and contributed to his wife’s loss in the 2008 primaries?

headline: A Bounty Hunter in the Big Easy
text: Gene Thacker, a New Orleans bounty-hunter known as Tat-2, is the central figure in “Big Easy Justice,” a 10-part series on Spike on Tuesday nights.

headline: Shakespeare and the City
text: Michael Cooper, who covers cities and urban affairs for the national desk of The New York Times, spent part of Monday, Shakespeare’s birthday, highlighting the playwright’s best lines about #cities.

headline: A Surprising Risk for Toddlers on Playground Slides
text: Last spring, Katie Dickman of Dunkirk, Md., was at the playground with her 18-month-old toddler, Hannah, when the little girl asked to ride down a twisting slide. Ms. Dickman accompanied her daughter, carefully keeping the child on her lap as they coasted to the bottom.

headline: Heart Transplants for Older Patients
text: Is Dick Cheney just the first of a new wave of older patients who will be receiving heart transplants?

headline: Elizabeth Warren Introduces Herself to Massachusetts Voters in New Ad
text: BOSTON – In a new television ad, Elizabeth Warren compares her climb from modest roots, to the struggles of college students today, who she says, drown in debt while “big corporations like G.E. pay nothing — zero — in taxes.”

headline: A wildlife expedition close to home; girlfriends of many species; and puncturing a myth about obesity.
text: A wildlife expedition close to home; girlfriends of many species; and puncturing a myth about obesity.

headline: Prowling New Orleans With Guns Galore
text: NEW ORLEANS — The man known as Tat-2 didn’t want his passengers to feel uneasy as he gave them a personal tour of greater New Orleans the other day.

headline: How Testing Is Hurting Teaching
text: A staff developer writes: 'The tests have gained an outsized influence on what happens in classrooms. They are not measuring student learning, as any good test should, but rather determining it. And in so doing they have shut down the most important quality of a good teacher -- the ability to learn.'

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: RIM Revamping and a $35 PC
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

headline: Facing Cyberattack, Iranian Officials Disconnect Some Oil Terminals From Internet
text: TEHRAN — Iran disconnected several of its main Persian Gulf oil terminals from the Internet on Monday, local news media reported, as technicians were struggling to contain what they said were intensifying cyberattacks on the Oil Ministry and its affiliates.

headline: Next Up to Bat: A Whiff of the Yankees
text: It’s practically a Zen koan: what is the smell of 27 World Series championships?

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Sudan, Bahrain, Syria and the Philippines.

headline: New Editor for Chicago Sun-Times
text: The Chicago Sun-Times and its sister print and digital media properties have a new editor. Wrapports, the investment company that owns the Sun-Times Media group, announced on Monday it had appointed Jim Kirk to the newly created role of editor in chief and senior vice president.

headline: Petits Pois de L’Oustau de Baumanière
text: Adapted from Sylvestre Wahid

headline: Xerox Results Exceed Predictions
text: Xerox, a provider of copiers, printers and business services, reported first-quarter earnings on Monday that exceeded analysts’ estimates after companies and governments farmed out more tasks to cut costs.

headline: Provençal Peas
text: At L’Oustau de Baumanière, a restaurant-cum-hotel in Les Baux, France, the peas go from garden in the morning to table at lunchtime.

headline: Spring Brings Caviar in a Pod
text: PARIS

headline: Boehner Sees One-in-Three Chance G.O.P. Will Lose House
text: Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio said on Monday that Republicans had a one-in-three chance of losing control of the House in November, a surprisingly downbeat assessment from a Republican leader who until now has expressed no fears of losing the gavel.

headline: New Albums From Jack White, Sarah Jaffe and Kenny Garrett
text: JACK WHITE

headline: In Pursuit of Riches, and Travelers’ Supplies, in the Asteroid Belt
text: Perhaps it will be a platinum rush that finally opens up the final frontier.

headline: American Airlines Cites Progress in Labor Talks
text: American Airlines went to court on Monday to ask a bankruptcy judge to void labor agreements with its three unions, though it signaled that the carrier had made progress in talks with one of those unions, representing its mechanics, that might result in fewer job cuts than American initially sought.

headline: A Little Sondheim Music, 17 Ways, but No Words
text: The songs of Stephen Sondheim represent such an ideal marriage of lyrics and music that it is hard to imagine these elements divorced. Still, on its own, Mr. Sondheim’s music is as rich, intricate and ingenious as music can be.

headline: Behind the Story: A Cancer Doctor on Depression and the Possible Next Antidepressant
text: Siddhartha Mukherjee, whose article on depression appears in this week’s health issue, is an assistant professor of medicine in the division of medical oncology at Columbia University. His book, “The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer,” a portion of which was adapted in the magazine as “The Cancer Sleeper Cell,” won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in general nonfiction. Mukherjee has also written for the magazine on whether the use of cellphones can cause cancer.

headline: Dancing Shoes Are Optional
text: Encores at recitals tend to display an artist’s virtuosity and range; it is rare that they can stand as symbols of the concerts they cap. But when the pianist Kirill Gerstein played a dazzling, slippery étude arrangement (by Earl Wild) of the Gershwins’ “I Got Rhythm” at the end of his exhilarating solo debut at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday, it neatly encapsulated what he had been doing so excellently all evening.

headline: American Track Gets New Leader
text: Just three months before the London Olympics and more than a year after its last chief executive left in a messy, protracted dispute, USA Track and Field finally settled on a new leader on Monday. In hiring Max Siegel, it did not travel far from its home base, choosing a former board member who has been serving as a marketing consultant for the organization since last year.

headline: Sheep Crochets, Pig Flips, Rats Wear Parkas, and Dragon Outsmarts Man
text: Dorothy had only the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion and Toto. Snow White had just seven dwarfs. Lilly, however, the young heroine of “The Dragon Child,” has all 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac to help her face the challenges of life. One of the beasts, as the title would indicate, is her parent. But, as it goes in fairy tales, the parent is mostly absent.

headline: Fly and Human Mothers Share a Milk Enzyme
text: Female tsetse flies produce only one egg at a time. The larva hatches in the mother’s uterus, and she feeds it with a milklike substance that she produces.

headline: The Neurological Roots of Lingering Regret
text: Studies have suggested that older adults are better off letting go of regrets, while younger adults, with more time left to make life changes, may benefit more from holding on to them.

headline: Pho With Broccoli and Quinoa
text: This time I decided to include a high-protein grain in my vegetarian pho broth instead of traditional noodles. The broccoli is thinly sliced and steamed or blanched separately.

headline: Too Many Receipts? A Solution in Your Pocket
text: YOU know what makes me feel as if I’m on the road circa 1987? Those annoying blank receipts that taxi drivers hand you at the end of the ride.

headline: A New Variant of Malware Takes Aim at Mac Users
text: Earlier this month, security researchers discovered a new piece of malware had infected more than half a million Apple computers in what was the largest-scale attack on Apple’s Mac OS X operating system to date.

headline: Pho With Carrots, Turnips, Broccoli and Tofu
text: I like this sweet, colorful combination of julienne carrots and turnips with either traditional rice noodles or heartier buckwheat soba. The carrots and turnips can be simmered directly in the stock, as they will contribute to its sweet flavor. The broccoli should be steamed separately.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Lyons'
