headline: In Europe, Now What?
text: Is this the end of austerity? What happens to Europe if the Germany-France alliance is broken?

headline: His Imagination Leaps Onto the Page
text: The adventurous New Victory Theater seems to be on a mission to prove that theater for children can be serious without being ponderous. In “The Book of Everything,” an adaptation of a novel by the Dutch writer Guus Kuijer, the 9-year-old hero, Thomas Klopper, must deal with weighty matters: religion, fear, a tyrannical father.

headline: Romney Backs Extending Low Interest Rates on Student Loans
text: CHESTER TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Mitt Romney circled back at the end of a brief news conference Monday afternoon to clarify an issue he had failed to mention before: his support of a temporary extension of a low interest rate on federal student loans, which President Obama also favors.

headline: Not Much Suspense Likely in New York G.O.P. Primary
text: Three weeks ago, Republican officials in New York imagined presidential candidates barnstorming across the state, voters turning out for the state’s primary in droves, and people across the country waiting in suspense for the results.

headline: Two Cuban Actors in Tribeca Film Missing After Flight to Florida
text: “Una Noche,” or “One Night,” a film showing at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells the story of three young Cubans who decide to defect to the United States, and last week the three main actors were scheduled to join the film’s director, Lucy Mulloy, at the New York premiere. But a funny thing happened when the plane landed in Miami last Wednesday: two of the actors promptly disappeared.

headline: Saints Deny Listening In on Rival Coaches
text: The New Orleans Saints denied a report Monday that said General Manager Mickey Loomis had the ability to eavesdrop on opposing coaches during games from 2002 to 2004.

headline: Rubio Is Latest Possible Running Mate to Join Romney on the Campaign Trail
text: CHESTER TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida looked on respectfully Monday afternoon as Mitt Romney addressed a group of reporters in a suburb of Philadelphia. He clasped his hands behind his back, rested them on his hips and folded them in front of him. He nodded almost imperceptibly at the appropriate times and, later, clapped along with the crowd.

headline: Is Quick Therapy the Best Therapy?

headline: Virginia Tech Fires Its Men’s Coach
text: Virginia Tech fired Seth Greenberg as its men’s basketball coach after nine seasons, after an exodus of assistants in recent years that left the program lacking the sort of continuity and collegiality Athletic Director Jim Weaver said he sought. Greenberg, whose only N.C.A.A. tournament trip with the Hokies came in 2007, did not learn that he had been fired until about an hour after a release was sent to reporters about a news conference later in the day.

headline: Davis Drops to .136; Mets Drop to .500

headline: Defense Department Plans New Intelligence Gathering Service
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is revamping its spy operations to focus on high-priority targets like Iran and China in a reorganization that reflects a shift away from the war zones of Iraq and Afghanistan that have dominated America’s security landscape for the past decade.

headline: The Depressing Lot of the Conflicted American Mother
text: Motherlode has asked women at different stages of their family and career lives to respond to Elisabeth Badinter’s “The Conflict” by describing how reading it has affected their views or plans for work and motherhood. The following is a continuation of an ongoing conversation.

headline: Tissue Maker Takes Flushables to Facebook
text: AMONG users of moist toilet paper wipes, 54 percent keep the product hidden from view, most often under the bathroom sink, according to consumer research by Kimberly-Clark, which makes Cottonelle Fresh Care, the leading flushable wipe. That troubles the brand, which reports that consumers who display wipes openly — typically atop the toilet tank — tend to use them twice as frequently.

headline: Yankees-Rangers Will Pair Japanese Pitchers
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — For the seventh time in major league history, two Japanese pitchers are scheduled to start against one another, and for perhaps the first time, it will be two of the best.

headline: Louisiana: Prison Conditions Draw Threat
text: In a sternly worded letter delivered to the Orleans Parish sheriff on Monday, the federal Department of Justice threatened litigation if “urgent and substantial action” were not taken to address widespread constitutional violations at the Orleans Parish Prison. Last November, as Monday’s letter publicly disclosed, federal officials sent the sheriff a draft consent decree, an agreed-upon but judicially mandated blueprint for comprehensive reform. The letter charged that the sheriff, Marlin Gusman, had “failed to seriously negotiate” since then, and that problems found in a federal investigation into the jail over two years ago “have persisted or have worsened.” In response to growing criticism, Sheriff Gusman announced the closing of one of the largest buildings at the jail complex two weeks ago.

headline: A Good ‘Brain Drain’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rhode Island: Pension Changes Proposed in Providence
text: Mayor Angel Taveras of Providence proposed a $638 million budget that assumes additional contributions from the city’s tax-exempt institutions and pension system changes. Mr. Taveras called on the City Council to adopt pension changes that he said would save at least $16 million in the coming fiscal year. The changes would also reduce the city’s unpaid pension liability, currently more than $900 million, by more than $236 million, he said. Changes to the pension system would most likely be challenged in court. Earlier this year, Mr. Taveras, a first-term Democrat, warned of possible bankruptcy unless the city found new revenues and significantly cut spending on its retirees.

headline: Numberplay Will Not Appear This Week
text: We apologize for the inconvenience. Numberplay will appear as usual next week.

headline: Civilians Describe Atrocities in Blue Nile
text: Two men in a detention center are burned to death. A woman, breastfeeding her child, is executed with a machine gun on the spot. A pregnant woman, whose only crime is sitting in the wrong market at the wrong time, has her leg blown off by an Antonov bomb.

headline: City Council to Assess Easing Steep Fines on Street Vendors
text: Moustapha Cisse’s entrepreneurial ambitions all but died last month.

headline: In Barcelona, Passion and Worry Fill Air Around a Team Not Used to Losing
text: BARCELONA — The heart of Catalonia burst with color on Monday as an unending array of roses covered the sidewalks from Las Ramblas to Avinguda Diagonal up near the Camp Nou stadium. April 23 here is La Diada de Sant Jordi, a celebration of St. George, Catalonia’s patron saint, who inspires a cultural phenomenon that is remarkably similar to Valentine’s Day — though with less chocolate and, oddly, more books.

headline: For an Old Italian Game, a Crescendo of Sorts
text: There was one corner of Woodlawn that seemed as if it would always remain stubbornly Italian: the bocce courts in Van Cortlandt Park.

headline: As China Official Rose, His Family’s Wealth Grew
text: DALIAN, China — Just a few weeks before his dramatic fall from power, Bo Xilai wrote an inscription in calligraphy, praising the Chongqing Water Assets Management Company, and urging support for its operations.

headline: The Europeans Are Revolting
text: Robin has a comment on the implications of European turmoil at the Guardian’s Comment is Free.

headline: In a Change, Mexico Reins In Its Oil Monopoly
text: COATZINTLA, Mexico — For seven decades, Pemex, Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly and a mainstay of the government’s revenue, regulated itself — which is a polite way of saying it could do pretty much as it pleased.

headline: Peace Without Partners
text: Tel Aviv

headline: Actress Takes Stand at Trial in the Killings of Relatives
text: CHICAGO — Preparations for the arrival of Jennifer Hudson, the singer and actress and beloved product of Chicago, at this city’s criminal courthouse were elaborate and months in the works: a private entrance was readied, a crush of news and entertainment reporters were required to sign pledges to abide by stringent rules of courtroom decorum and potential jurors were quizzed about their knowledge of “American Idol” and “Dreamgirls.”

headline: France Votes Its Discontents
text: The first-round vote in the French presidential election produced a curious bi-directional backlash — from the left against the policies of austerity and from the right against immigration. The final round, which will be held on May 6, is likely to be important for all of Europe.

headline: Wal-Mart Stock Falls Nearly 5%
text: Wal-Mart’s stock fell almost 5 percent on Monday, accounting for about one-fifth of the losses in the Dow Jones industrial average, as investors reacted to a bribery scandal at the retailer’s Mexican subsidiary and a report that an internal investigation was quashed at corporate headquarters in Arkansas.

headline: Callous Choices in the House
text: For months, House Republicans have been trying to wriggle out of the agreement they made in August that will force deep cuts in military spending. Now we know how they propose to do it: They will take tens of billions out of programs for the poorest Americans, particularly food stamps, along with health care for the middle class.

headline: A Would-Be Shoe Bomber Testifies in a Terror Trial
text: He was supposed to be the other shoe bomber. Saajid Badat said Osama bin Laden himself had dispatched him to board a plane with a bomb sewn in his shoe, which he would detonate in midair as part of a choreographed attack that would crash the American economy.

headline: For Bocce, a New Generation of Devotees
text: A dusty old game favored by Italian old-timers has evolved into a trendy social sport — one largely without taxing physical demands.

headline: Occupy Movement Looks Toward Political Conventions
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Hay and grass seed cover the bare spots on the lawn in front of the stately old City Hall where Occupy Charlotte’s camp held its ground for nearly four months. The occupiers are gone now and the protest movement quieted after arrests, a new anticamping ordinance and, to a degree, the group’s own missteps along the way.

headline: Displaying Value: The Case for the Liberal Arts Yet Again
text: Early on in his new book, “College: What It Was, Is, and Should Be,” Andrew Delbanco of Columbia University quotes the economist Richard Vedder and the former university president William Brody to the effect that little has changed in higher education despite enormous changes in technology, demographics, funding models, and student habits and attitudes. Vedder notes that “with the possible exception of prostitution, teaching is the only profession that has had absolutely no productivity advance in the 2,400 years since Socrates.” Brody is less wry, but the point is the same: “If you went to a [college] class circa 1900, and you went today, it would look exactly the same.”

headline: A Test on Equal Pay
text: On the question of equal pay for women, Mitt Romney has planted himself on both sides of the issue, flipping and flopping at the same time.

headline: Ryan Seacrest to Remain as Host of  ‘American Idol’
text: The Fox network said Monday evening that Ryan Seacrest had agreed to continue hosting the nation’s most popular reality television show, “American Idol.”

headline: The Undocumented and the Unborn
text: The Nebraska Legislature took a strange road to a good result last week. It overrode Gov. Dave Heineman’s veto of a bill to provide free prenatal care to undocumented immigrant women.

headline: MetLife Settles Cases on Benefits
text: MetLife on Monday became the third big life insurer to settle regulatory accusations of failing to keep track of policyholder deaths, trapping money that should have gone promptly to the beneficiaries.

headline: George Rathmann, Amgen Chief, Dies at 84
text: George B. Rathmann, who was the first chief executive of Amgen and helped build it into the world’s largest biotechnology company, died on Sunday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

headline: To Curb Rowdiness, Long Island Rail Road Will Ban Alcohol on Late-Night Weekend Trains
text: The notion of enjoying a cold one aboard a rush-hour commuter train leaving Manhattan may seem like a time-honored tradition, evoking visions of communal bar cars or perhaps a cocktail hour spent in solitude at one’s seat. But after midnight on weekends, the specter of alcohol aboard Long Island Rail Road trains carries a far more malevolent overtone; passengers described them as the “drunk trains,” characterized by fights and boisterous behavior. In March, passengers were accused of attacking two conductors.

headline: Hitting the Beach in Bangladesh
text: COX’S BAZAR, Bangladesh — It’s not Hawaii, and it’s not St.-Tropez. But Cox’s Bazar is an up-and-coming beach resort, with lush vegetation and soaring property prices to match.

headline: Insurers Alter Cost Formula, and Patients Pay More
text: Despite a landmark settlement that was expected to increase coverage for out-of-network care, the nation’s largest health insurers have been switching to a new payment method that in most cases significantly increases the cost to the patient.

headline: Arkansas Thinks Big in Hiring New Coach
text: John L. Smith has run with the bulls in Pamplona, skydived from 14,000 feet and climbed a peak of Mount Kilimanjaro. In the football world, he is known as an eccentric, whose legacy as a head coach ranges from being an innovator of the spread offense to telling his Louisville team at halftime of a bowl game that he was leaving for another job.

headline: Chávez Out of Sight but Big as Life on Twitter
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — During an extended stay in Cuba for cancer treatment, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela has taken to sending messages to the folks back home with slogans like, “We will live!” and “We will be victorious!”

headline: A Brooklyn School Saved Lives, and Some Now Try to Return the Favor
text: I was 18 years old with a baby and three high school credits. I was a gangbanger. I was shot and left for dead.

headline: The Creative Monopoly
text: As a young man, Peter Thiel competed to get into Stanford. Then he competed to get into Stanford Law School. Then he competed to become a clerk for a federal judge. Thiel won all those competitions. But then he competed to get a Supreme Court clerkship.

headline: Talking With Your Fingers
text: The latest word on the street about English in America – always bad, it seems – is that the shaggy construction of texting and e-mail spells the death of formal writing. Yet the truth about English in America – always sunnier, in fact – is that the looseness and creativity of these new ways of writing are a sign of a new sophistication in our society. This becomes clear when we understand that in the proper sense, e-mail and texting are not writing at all.

headline: A Reinvented Palais de Tokyo Reopens
text: The Palais de Tokyo, near the Place du Trocadero in Paris, has had a number of uses during its 75-year history. Before the opening of the Centre Pompidou on Rue Beaubourg in 1977, for example, it was the home of France’s national collection of modern art (formerly known as the Palais des Musées d’Art Moderne). In the 1980s it presented photography, films, and objects and decor of the cinema. And eventually it even closed.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: State Ponders Relinquishing Its Oversight of Vulnerable
text: ALBANY — The Cuomo administration is strongly considering relinquishing some of the state’s oversight and monitoring responsibilities over vulnerable populations, and giving that power to a nonprofit advocacy group, a top administration official said Monday.

headline: The Overrated Vice Presidential Home-State Effect
text: In comparison to the dog-and-pony show that has dominated the political news cycle as of late, the question of whom Mitt Romney might pick as his vice presidential nominee is at least one of some substantive importance. Since 1900, about 25 percent of the men and women nominated for vice president by the major-party candidates have later become presidential nominees themselves, and 15 percent have actually become president, whether by winning the office on their own or by succeeding an incumbent who died or resigned in office.

headline: Report on State Agency Oversight of Vulnerable
text: The State Office for People With Developmental Disabilities cites a “fundamental conflict” that prevents it from exercising oversight and proposes to turnover much of its work to a non-profit group.

headline: Deficit, and Inconsistent Play, No Cause for Alarm to the Devils
text: NEWARK — Martin Brodeur laughed when he leaned back inside the Devils’ dressing room Monday and said, “I’ve done it all.” And he has been in this spot before — three times in the last four years — with the Devils facing first-round elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Becoming an Olympian, and Then a Newlywed
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Less than 48 hours after making the United States Olympic wrestling team in front of 13,000 fans, Stephany Lee arrived at the wedding chapel in a Ford Explorer carrying Colorado plates and a small entourage. She changed into jeans and a striped shirt. Beaming, she made her way to an altar sitting in front of five rows of padded pews.

headline: ‘Tainted,’ but Still Serving on Corporate Boards
text: When David M. Poppe sat down a little over a week ago to write a letter to his investors, he knew he was taking an unusual step.

headline: Call for Growth to Counter German Push for Austerity
text: BERLIN — With political allies weakened or ousted, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s seat at the head of the European table has become much less comfortable, as a reckoning with Germany’s insistence on lock-step austerity appears to have begun.

headline: Classes Resume at Scene of Shootings in Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the makeshift memorial in front of Oikos University, around a table on which seven framed portraits were lined up, most of the flowers had withered and many of the handwritten notes had curled. But as classes began to resume on Monday morning after a gunman fatally shot six students and an administrator three weeks ago, the shooting’s effects remained raw among the students, teachers and even passers-by.

headline: French Far Right a Challenge for Europe and Sarkozy
text: PARIS — To win re-election in the runoff on May 6 against the Socialist François Hollande, Nicolas Sarkozy will need the support of right-wing voters who have turned their backs on him, disappointed with his presidency.

headline: ‘Ghost the Musical’
text: Photos from the new Broadway show at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

headline: Fees and Anger Rise in California Water War
text: SAN DIEGO — There are accusations of conspiracies, illegal secret meetings and double-dealing. Embarrassing documents and e-mails have been posted on an official Web site emblazoned with the words “Fact vs. Fiction.” Animosities have grown so deep that the players have resorted to exchanging lengthy, caustic letters, packed with charges of lying and distortion.

headline: A Haunted Hotel, a Haunted Family: Who Let the Ghosts Out?
text: Big hotels can be creepy, even when they’re not swarming with cultish conventioneers. Just think of the Overlook in the 1980 movie “The Shining,” the place that drove Jack Nicholson even further around the bend than usual.

headline: Waiting for Dad to Die: Laughs Pile Up
text: Oh, they’re just awful people, those Lyons. They’re whiny, denigrating, vicious, self-centered, recriminatory — the sort of blood kin who can’t cling to one another without drawing blood. And they’re a family that you will really, really want to spend time with. Honestly. And not just for (you should excuse the expression) the pleasure of their company.

headline: In a Broadway Afterlife, Time Goes by So Slowly
text: Generally speaking, I don’t believe in ghosts. But I’m convinced that the spirits of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne have taken up temporary residence in the wings of the Broadway theater that bears their names, where the new musical adapted from the popular movie “Ghost” opened on Monday night.

headline: Draggin’ Girl
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Greetings! I’m back from the Erma Bombeck Writers’ Workshop, and I must say I had a fabulous time. Not only was it incredibly inspirational to see all of these writers in one place being watched over by the spirit of Erma Bombeck, but I also learned a lot, including how to successfully “break the ice” with attendees by using the ladies’ room while wearing a live microphone.

headline: Bigger Role for Outside Conservative Groups
text: In states with some of the most competitive Senate races, Republican allies are out-spending Democrats.

headline: Live and in Person, History Comes to Chicago’s Classrooms
text: CHICAGO — It was an unusual day in social studies class at Frederick Von Steuben Metropolitan Science Center, a public high school on the North Side of this city. Monday’s class was taught by a substitute teacher: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former president of the Soviet Union.

headline: Even as It Hurts Mexican Economy, Bribery Is Taken in Stride
text: MEXICO CITY — Every now and then, the health department shows up at José Luis García’s food store in an affluent neighborhood here. Mr. García immediately reaches for his wallet.

headline: Rangers Live to Fight Another Day
text: OTTAWA — Facing the embarrassment of early elimination by the lowest-seeded team in the East, the top-seeded Rangers were hurtling toward an elimination that would have undone a season’s worth of accomplishment. A force field seemed to have surrounded the Senators’ net. When Craig Anderson was not making saves, Rangers forwards were missing open corners and firing the puck wide.

headline: Jeter and Rodriguez Help Yanks Prevail in Early Showdown
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Age is not an issue that Derek Jeter likes to entertain. A year ago, when he was 36, he bristled at suggestions that his extended batting slump was the result of his advancing years.

headline: The Mega Millions Solution
text: The Mega Millions lottery last month with its whopping $656 million prize captured the intense interest of Americans across the country. Estimates suggest that as many as 100 million people participated. No matter that the odds of winning the jackpot were known to be much less than being struck by lightning twice. Investing a few bucks (or in the case of Washington Wizards forward Chris Singleton, ten thousand) for the chance to become a centa-millionaire was irresistible for nearly half of the adult population of the country.

headline: New Fashion Wrinkle: Stylishly Hiding the Gun
text: Woolrich, a 182-year-old clothing company, describes its new chino pants as an elegant and sturdy fashion statement, with a clean profile and fabric that provides comfort and flexibility.

headline: Murdochs Set to Testify Before Judicial Panel
text: LONDON — In the protracted saga of Britain’s tabloid newspaper scandal, there have been few episodes more challenging for Rupert Murdoch and his son James than the testimony each will give this week at the judicial inquiry that has been holding excoriating hearings for the past five months into wrongdoing at the core of the scandal.

headline: Player Trades: Rare in N.F.L., Common for Eagles
text: PHILADELPHIA — Last October, cornerback Asante Samuel accused the management of the Philadelphia Eagles of “playing fantasy football.”

headline: Saying Goodbye, a Former Net Talks About the Knicks
text: NEWARK — Micheal Ray Richardson made a ceremonial appearance at Prudential Center on Monday night to help bring the curtain down on the New Jersey Nets, but he took the opportunity to offer good news on the state of another former team, as only he could.

headline: Conservative Groups Spending Heavily in Bid to Win a Senate Majority
text: The conservative groups that helped Republicans win the House in 2010 are pouring money this year into an aggressive campaign to capture the Senate, a goal that they consider just as vital as winning the White House.

headline: In Egypt Race, Battle Is Joined on Islam’s Role
text: CAIRO — He has argued for barring women and non-Muslims from Egypt’s presidency on the basis of Islamic law, or Shariah. He has called for a council of Muslim scholars to advise Parliament. He has a track record of inflammatory statements about Israel, including repeatedly calling its citizens “killers and vampires.”

headline: Time Expires on the Nets in New Jersey
text: NEWARK — The Nets’ longtime public address announcer, Gary Sussman, was back on the microphone for their final game in New Jersey on Monday night.

headline: Egypt Rejects Registration Bids From 8 U.S. Nonprofit Groups
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian ministry has rejected the applications for registration of eight American nonprofit groups, state media reported, in the government’s first action on the status of foreign-backed nonprofit groups since its criminal prosecution of three American-backed organizations set off a crisis in relations with Washington this year.

headline: Champions League: Chelsea Tries to Buck the System in Barcelona
text: Barcelona’s players claimed that “a tear had rolled down the face of the game” after they were felled by José Mourinho’s defensive Inter Milan two years ago.

headline: Word of the Day | ogle

headline: Canada: Immigration Hearing for Relative of Tunisian Leader
text: While a large number of people from Montreal’s Tunisian community attended an immigration hearing on Monday for Belhassen Trabelsi, the brother-in-law of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisia’s former president, Mr. Trabelsi was not among them. His lawyer told the Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada that Mr. Trabelsi feared for his safety. The government of Canada wants to revoke Mr. Trabelsi’s permanent resident status because it says that he failed to remain in Canada for at least two out of every five years. After trying Mr. Trabelsi in absentia, a court in Tunisia sentenced him in September to 15 years in prison and fined him about $500,000 for corruption. A wealthy businessman, Mr. Trabelsi has acknowledged that family connections gave him a position of privilege in Tunisia, but he denied having gained any illicit benefits.

headline: S.E.C. Sues SinoTech Energy of China for Fraud
text: HONG KONG — The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued another China-based company and two of its executives, charging them with lying to investors about the value of the company’s assets and how it used $120 million in proceeds from its initial public offering on the Nasdaq.

headline: Russia: Opposition Candidate Is Ending His Hunger Strike
text: An opposition candidate whose hunger strike to protest alleged ballot fraud drew national attention said Monday that he would start eating solid food. The candidate, Oleg V. Shein of the Just Russia party, said ballot fraud robbed him of victory in the mayoral race last month in Astrakhan, a regional capital in southern Russia. Mr. Shein said he stopped eating solid food March 16, though he drank water, and in recent days had some juice and a glucose injection. He said he would begin eating on Tuesday.

headline: Russia: Police Captain Arrested in Crackdown on Corruption
text: A police captain in Moscow was arrested over the weekend on charges of accepting a bribe of more than $40,000, according to a police statement released Monday, part of an apparent crackdown on police corruption after several scandals involving law enforcement personnel. The captain, who was not identified, was accused of taking the money from a car salesman in exchange for ignoring legal infractions. The police statement said the captain’s superiors would also be punished. Despite efforts by President Dmitri A. Medvedev to push for police reform, corruption remains widespread and abuse common. In March, a man died in police custody after officers allegedly sodomized him with a bottle. The episode incited national outrage and prompted new calls for reform.

headline: In Japan, Suffer the Children
text: HONG KONG — “She just took the razor and then she started cutting in front of me.”

headline: Power Play Is a Boost for Richards
text: OTTAWA — The Rangers’ win over the Ottawa Senators on Monday brought the end of a frustrating stretch for Brad Richards.

headline: Bo Xilai and Gu Kailai Family Connections
text: The close relatives of Bo Xilai, a former Chinese Politburo member, and his wife, Gu Kailai, may have profited from the couple’s political influence.

headline: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 6
text: The top-seeded Rangers staved off elimination with a 3-2 victory in Ottawa.

headline: A Hit Maker Bets Future Earnings on India Expansion Plan
text: “Insiders use outside money to make movies and television shows. That is the basic rule of Hollywood investment,” Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times. “But Peter A. Chernin is changing the rules.”

headline: Air National Guard Lobbies Successfully Against Budget Cuts
text: In combat zones, National Guard units generally take their orders from active duty commanders. Not so in Washington.

headline: News Quiz | April 24, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: In an Unlikely Corner of Asia, Strong Promise of Growth
text: “Bangladesh is probably one of the last places in Asia people would expect to see a thriving beachside resort with luxury hotels,” Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times. “And yet, Cox’s Bazar is exactly that — a place where affluent Bangladeshis go for a weekend of seaside fun.”

headline: A Conversation With: Zuber Jafri
text: A decade ago, Ahsan Jafri, a former member of parliament, was killed in the riots that besieged the state of Gujarat. On Feb. 28, 2002, witnesses said that Muslim women and children sought refuge in Mr. Jafri’s home in the Gulberg Housing Society, and that he made frantic phone calls seeking help because a mob that had gathered outside. The police arrived too late, survivors had said, and Mr. Jafri was killed along with 69 others when the mob set fire to his home. His widow, Zakia Jafri, filed suit in court in an effort, she says, to find justice.

headline: April 24, 1916 | Irish Nationalists Stage Easter Uprising in Dublin
text: On April 24, 1916, on Easter Monday, groups of Irish nationalists revolted against British rule by seizing a post office and other buildings in Dublin and declaring the formation of the Irish Republic.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 24, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Enzymes Try to Grab the Spotlight.”

headline: As Book Sales Grow, Publishers Flock to India
text: David Davidar recalls the advice once given to him by the writer R.K. Narayan about publishing books in India. “Don’t worry, you’ll be gone in a few years,” Mr. Narayan warned. “There aren’t enough writers here.”

headline: At Wal-Mart in Mexico, a Bribe Inquiry
text: Note: These questions focus on the basic details explained in the opening of a complex and lengthy news article. Students can answer them by reading down to the subheading “The Allegations Emerge.”

headline: A Biscuit Tin of Memories on Film
text: For the past dozen years, Pablo Delano has been consumed by the mystery of a Barcelona Biscuit Tin: who shot the hundreds of decaying negatives that were packed into the beat-up box he bought for $60 at a Barcelona flea market? Who were the people in the pictures? Where were the photos taken?

headline: Earth to Ben Bernanke
text: When the financial crisis struck in 2008, many economists took comfort in at least one aspect of the situation: the best possible person, Ben Bernanke, was in place as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: Murdoch Case Shifts Its Focus to a Minister
text: LONDON — The long-running tabloid newspaper scandal that has shaken Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire delivered a new jolt on Tuesday as its powerful and lucrative television operations moved to the center of a British judicial inquiry with disclosures that a senior cabinet minister, or at least an aide claiming to speak for him, worked covertly to help win approval for a $12 billion takeover of the BSkyB network.

headline: Why Do You Share Photos?
text: The purchase of Instagram by Facebook for $1 billion has put a lot of focus on the popularity of taking and sharing photographs online. Do you use Instagram or other photo services and apps? What compels you to share photos? How do you share them, and with whom?

headline: Brandon Jacobs Says Goodbye, Apparently at High Speed

headline: Part 2: Answers to Readers’ Questions on Financial Aid

headline: Insurer Details Higher Risks for Drivers After Deployment
text: A major insurer of active-duty troops, USAA, has released details from a study on the driving safety records of thousands of troops who returned from Iraq or Afghanistan. And as expected, the results showed that many struggle to readjust to American highways.

headline: Fantasy Focus: On Deck
text: It happens every year. Owners in redraft (one-year) leagues stash away top prospects hoping for a big impact early in the season, and it never comes. This year, plenty of benches are occupied by the likes of Bryce Harper and Mike Trout, while owners await word that the players’ organizations will give them a big league role.

headline: Le Pen Pricks
text: The Socialist candidate François Hollande and President Nicolas Sarkozy may be the ones who qualified for the second round of the French presidential election, but the big winner in Sunday’s first round was Marine Le Pen, of the far-right National Front. Though she won only third place, she garnered 18 percent of all votes, a record for her party.

text: Prices for modern South Asian art have skyrocketed in recent years in the United States, as deep-pocketed collectors bid up works by well-known names and newcomers alike. For many Indian Americans and others interested in work from the region, buying a quality piece is now out of reach.

text: Chase Stuart is a contributor to SmartFootball.com and Footballguys.com

headline: Behind an Owner’s Complicated Union Ties
text: Susan Parker has spoken in past posts about the rising costs of manufacturing her dresses in Asia and the challenges that arise when something goes wrong. Ms. Parker, who owns Bari Jay, has also mentioned that because her company is unionized, producing the dresses domestically becomes difficult.

headline: J.P. Morgan Appoints New Asia-Pacific Head
text: LONDON — Jeff Urwin has been appointed as the head of J.P. Morgan’s operations in the Asia-Pacific region, succeeding Gaby A. Abdelnour, who announced in March that he was leaving the firm.

headline: Former Apple Executive Blends Genres with iPad
text: One intriguing outcome of the iPad is how it has encouraged developers to create hybrid apps that don’t fit neatly into one genre. There are a lot of iPad books, especially for kids, that experiment with sounds, video and gamelike elements to enhance their storytelling.

headline: Study Links Plant Damage to Nanoparticles
text: Science fiction might have us believe that tiny particles seeping into soil and altering plant DNA will lead to the rise of giant killer tomatoes. But a new study suggests that exposure to certain nanoparticles may in fact have a shriveling effect on some plants.

headline: G.O.P. Chairman Previews General Election Campaign
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — In the coming days, the Republican National Committee will merge its operation with Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign in an effort to form a more formidable political organization to wage battle with President Obama in the fall.

headline: Samsung Heirs Stage a Korean Soap Opera
text: SEOUL — Lee Kun-hee, the chairman of the largest South Korean business conglomerate, Samsung, and the country’s richest man, is not known for being talkative. Partly because of his reticence, what few public remarks he makes are studied by his reverential employees with the same zeal that devout Christians might apply when parsing biblical quotations.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: ‘Tainted,’ but Still Serving on Corporate Boards  |  David M. Poppe, who manages money for the Sequoia Fund, knew he was taking an unusual step when he sat down a little over a week ago to write a letter to his investors, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column.

headline: Opinion Report: Equal Pay

headline: From Bangladesh to Rochester, With a Missed Connection
text: “The Newlyweds,” Nell Freudenberger’s affecting if sometimes ungainly new novel, starts off as a sort of high-concept Hollywood movie, mashing up the familiar fish-out-of-water story line with a girl-torn-between-two-boys plot. What all feels a bit like a paint-by-numbers exercise, however, gradually opens out into a genuinely moving story about a woman trying to negotiate two cultures, balancing her parents’ expectations with her own aspirations, her ambition and cynical practicality with deeper, more romantic yearnings.

headline: Rain Intercedes as Parents Protest Asbestos Removal at Cobble Hill School
text: With just a few hours notice, more than 100 parents, children and community members gathered in the schoolyard of Public School 29 John M. Harrigan in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, in a show of force against an asbestos abatement plan at the school. Some sported surgical masks, others carried signs with slogans such as “Protect Our Kids” and “What is Insidious? Asbestos.”

headline: Muslim Women in India Seek Gender Equality in Marriage
text: “Three years ago, Salma Khatun’s husband divorced her in a fit of rage after a quarrel, pronouncing what is known as the triple talaq in the presence of witnesses,” Nilanjana S. Roy writes in The International Herald Tribune. “The triple talaq is a formula of repudiation,” she writes. The first two times it is pronounced, it can be revoked, but the third time it makes a divorce binding, according to some interpretations of Islamic law.

headline: Daily Report: A Glimpse at Facebook’s Financials

headline: Why AT&T and Verizon Are Rooting for Windows Phones
text: In recent weeks, the two big American phone carriers, AT&T and Verizon, have been talking big about Microsoft’s Windows Phone software. AT&T has been hurling loads of money at marketing Nokia’s Lumia 900, a smartphone that runs on the Windows Phone operating system. And now Verizon, too, has revealed plans to aggressively promote Windows Phone 8, the next version of Microsoft’s software.

headline: Another Passionate Plea to Save Bushwick High
text: With just days until the Panel for Educational Policy meets on Thursday to vote on the closing of 26 public schools slated for "turnaround," forces are continuing to rally to save one school that many say amounts to much more than the assessment data that is now being used to judge a school's worth.

headline: Philippine Court Rules Aquino Estate Must Be Split Among 6,000
text: MANILA — In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court in the Philippines ruled unanimously on Tuesday to break up the rambling estate owned by the family of President Benigno S. Aquino III, parceling out land to more than 6,000 farmers and their families and removing a main obstacle to ending the oppressive plantation culture that has dominated the country for decades.

headline: Former Edwards Aide Testifies About Elaborate Efforts to Hide Affair
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Unfurling in almost cinematic form, an elaborate scheme to hide former Senator John Edwards’s affair and the child it produced was methodically set out by federal prosecutors here Tuesday.

headline: Harvard Releases Big Data for Books
text: Harvard is making public the information on more than 12 million books, videos, audio recordings, images, manuscripts, maps, and more things inside its 73 libraries.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Grilling for James Murdoch, and Facebook Tops 900 Million Users
text: James Murdoch, son of Rupert Murdoch and former head of the family’s British newspapers, is testifying in London Tuesday before a commission investigating press ethics, facing detailed and exhaustive questions from one of the commission’s lawyers, Robert Jay. When the question of phone-hacking came up, Mr. Murdoch stuck by his contention that he was ill informed by his subordinates, otherwise he would have ordered the executives to “cut out the cancer,” John Burns and Alan Cowell reported. He was also asked about his contacts with Prime Minister David Cameron, and whether political support from the Murdoch newspapers was tied to support for its business goals — a charge he denied. Rupert Murdoch’s testimony is set for Wednesday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 24
text: Non-resident Indian children, caught in a custody row in Norway, return to India.

headline: Cost of Spain’s Housing Bust Could Force a Bailout
text: By any measure, the Spanish real estate boom was one of the headiest ever. Spurred by record-low interest rates, Spaniards piled into holiday villas along the Costa Blanca, gaudy apartments in Madrid and millions of starter homes throughout the country.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Knowing When to Put an End to Therapy
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Losing a Starring Role in the Republican Primary
text: ’Twas but a few weeks ago that New York State’s Republican Party sounded practically giddy about the presidential primary that would be held on April 24 (which crack investigative reporting, in the form of looking at a calendar, reveals is upon us). This is our time, party leaders said, gushing like Sally Field when she accepted an Oscar in 1985.

headline: New Dolby Technology to Make Horror Movies Scarier
text: If you don’t like the sounds in scary movies but sometimes get dragged along to the theater anyway, you’re not going to be a big fan of the latest technology from Dolby Laboratories.

headline: On Our Radar: BP Settlement Dispute
text: Shrimp processors ask a federal judge to delay preliminary approval of BP’s proposed settlement of economic claims from the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. They contend that it favors shrimp harvesters and boat captains at the expense of shrimp docks, processors and others. [Reuters]

headline: Leading Off: Coaching Follies at Arkansas
text: It seems it was about five minutes ago that everyone was applauding the Arkansas athletic director for standing up as the voice of integrity. In reality, it was two weeks ago when Jeff Long made his impassioned speech that he had to fire the football coach Bobby Petrino because Petrino’s list of ethical transgressions trumped his winning record. In record time, however, Arkansas grabbed that new banner of goodness and light and whacked integrity right on the head with it.

headline: Modi’s Ratings
text: NEW DELHI — Narendra Modi, the leading figure of India’s right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party (B.J.P.), didn’t make Time magazine’s list of the 100 most powerful people in the world this year. Midway through the online polling, after Modi’s stock had started to surge, liberals in India organized a counter-campaign. In the end, 256,792 votes were cast for him and 266,684 votes against.

headline: Man Is Accused of Killing His Half-Sister and Wounding His Mother
text: Wednesday, 2:08 p.m. | Updated A family was torn apart by violence early on Tuesday morning when a man turned a gun on his mother after killing his 13-year-old half-sister, then engaged police in a lengthy predawn shootout in Washington Heights, the police said.

headline: Company Admits It Bilked Clients on Big Projects
text: The giant construction company that worked on Citi Field, the renovation of Grand Central Terminal and scores of other high-profile projects has admitted to a huge fraud scheme in which it overbilled clients for more than a decade and has agreed to pay $56 million in fines and restitution to avoid criminal charges, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday.

headline: Congress Takes Fresh Look at MF Global
text: A Congressional panel is continuing the examination of the collapse of MF Global and the firm’s misuse of customer money, as lawmakers seek to find ways to prevent a repeat of the financial debacle.

headline: N.F.L. Evolution:  The Eminence of the Left Tackle and Other Myths
text: The second of a three-part series. Part 1 on Monday examined how the evolution of the N.F.L. into a passing league is affecting the quarterback and wide receiver positions: a good quarterback just isn’t good enough anymore. Today, a look at offensive lines, running backs and tight ends.

headline: The Far Right and Europe’s Open Borders
text: LONDON — Europe’s open-borders policy is coming under threat as mainstream politicians react to what they perceive as a growing challenge from right-wing, anti-immigration parties such as France’s National Front.

headline: U.S. Women Learn Olympic Opponents
text: The United States was placed into a first-round group with France, Colombia and North Korea during the draw Tuesday in London for this summer’s Olympic women’s soccer tournament.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 24: The Nets Leave New Jersey
text: Good morning. Today should climb to a partly cloudy 60 degrees with strong winds possible in the afternoon.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Economist: From a distinguished journal, a loving evocation of the bagelness of Murray Lender, the pioneering bagel man who died last month at the age of 81. His term for the classic hole-in-the-roll was “the Jewish English muffin,” of course, and if he won praise as the Barnum of bagelmania, he also introduced innovations that appalled purists, including pre-slicing, freezing and Minute-Maid cross-promotions. Despite a stroke, he played his drums joyously until nearly the end. — Glenn Collins

headline: AT&T Posts Profit Despite Slow Contract Growth
text: AT&T, the nation’s No. 2 cellphone carrier, barely added any new monthly contract customers in the first quarter, but the company still managed to post a profit because it made so much money from the data plans of existing customers.

headline: Charles Aznavour Cancels New York Shows in Contract Dispute
text: Charles Aznavour’s cancellation of three shows at New York’s City Center this week was because of a contract dispute, not health problems, the French singer told the radio station RTL in an interview on Monday.

headline: When $2,600 in Premiums Yields $1.7 Million in Claims
text: Premiums for long-term care insurance, which helps cover the cost of nursing home or in-home care for the aged or disabled, have been steadily increasing, an industry group reported earlier this year.

headline: MF Global Trustee Calls for Fund to Protect Customers
text: The trustee tasked with returning more than $1.6 billion in missing customer money after the demise of MF Global has suggested establishing an insurance fund for commodities customers to safeguard assets in the event of a future collapse, according to a statement he read at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday.

headline: A Tricky Museum Question
text: Dear Diary:I’m sitting at the information desk one afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History. A woman, with a heavy accent, approaches to ask a question.

headline: Timely | Elisa Strozyk, Next Floor
text: After getting a master’s degree in the Textile Futures program at London’s Central Saint Martins in 2009, the Berlin designer Elisa Strozyk decided to make something that was part wood flooring, part rug. The result: wooden carpet. Sounds simple, but each rug is made of hundreds of individually sanded and oiled pieces of wood veneer that are cut and attached by hand to a textile base. The carpets, which are now produced and distributed by the German furniture manufacturer Böwer, generated so much interest in Strozyk that she skipped the usual apprenticeships and set up her own studio. She calls her work “the never-ending experiment.” Stay tuned.

headline: Futures Regulator Updates Congress on MF Global Inquiry
text: A federal official overseeing the regulatory investigation of MF Global outlined potential routes on Tuesday to mounting a civil enforcement action against the bankrupt brokerage firm and its top executives.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/24

(The New York Times)

headline: Institute Calls for Improved Coordination of Standards for E.V.’s
text: When the battery pack of a Chevrolet Volt caught fire last year weeks after undergoing federal crash tests, it highlighted the need for rigorous safety standards on the care and storage of lithium-ion batteries.

headline: Bronx Students Learn Their Search and Seizure Rights
text: Seventh grade students from M.S. 22 in the Bronx are learning how to advocate for themselves under the 4th Amendment, the section of the Bill of Rights that protects against unlawful search and seizure. Students showed off their legal expertise with a moot court competition on Friday.

headline: Court Approves Fisk University’s Sale of Georgia O’Keeffe Collection
text: The Tennessee Supreme Court has upheld a lower court decision allowing Fisk University to sell a 50 percent stake in a 101-piece art collection donated by Georgia O’Keeffe, The Associated Press reported on Monday.

headline: Inviting Cinderella Species to the Ball
text: We humans are quite fond of ourselves. So much so that our narcissism tends to influence our preferences for other species, too. We generally favor big, attractive mammals with forward-facing eyes, and this bias is reflected in the conservation dollars we donate. While polar bear fatigue does occur, conservation organizations that focus on large charismatic animals like that Arctic creature or tigers, elephants or chimpanzees — often referred to as “flagship species” — generate the most financial support, regardless of the animals’ status on the endangered species list.

headline: MF Global Hearing Addresses Recovery of Missing Client Money
text: At the MF Global hearing on Tuesday, Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, asked a simple question.

headline: Sinead O’Connor Cancels Her Tour
text: Sinead O’Connor says she is canceling her 2012 tour because she has bipolar disorder, the latest in a series of erratic pronouncements by the Irish songwriter suggesting she is deeply troubled.

headline: For Maryland Women’s Lacrosse, a Low Seed and Another Title
text: There have been questions all year about whether the Maryland women’s lacrosse team is as strong as it has been in recent seasons. The graduation of three senior defenders cast doubt on the defense. The offensive inconsistency earlier in the regular season cast doubt on the attackers. And above all, the team’s losses to Duke and North Carolina cast doubt on itsperennial domination in the Atlantic Coast Conference.

headline: Eight Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The Economist
text: I subscribe to way too many magazines, which means, inevitably, that I toss out a lot of them without reading every last article. Or sometimes, alas, without reading any articles at all. Some magazines, of course, are harder to throw out than others, The New Yorker being the classic example. To subscribe to The New Yorker is to accept the feeling of inadequacy that comes with flipping on SportsCenter rather than attacking the unread pile of them on your bedside table.

headline: Judge Rules That Protester Can’t Oppose Twitter Subpoena
text: A criminal court judge in Manhattan ruled on Friday that a writer from Brooklyn did not have the standing to oppose a subpoena delivered by prosecutors to Twitter seeking three months of old messages.

headline: Cooper Union Will Charge Tuition for Graduate Students
text: After months of agonized debate about its 110-year-old tradition of free education, Cooper Union will begin charging graduate students next year while maintaining, at least for now, its no-tuition policy for undergraduates, the college’s president said Tuesday.

headline: Lost Occupation, Lost Art as Sports Cartooning Declines
text: BALTIMORE — Mike Ricigliano practices a nearly extinct newspaper art: he is a sports cartoonist, poking fun at sports figures with pen, paper and a gag writer’s shtick.

headline: ‘Sons of Anarchy’ Creator to Track Real-Life Mayhem for Discovery
text: Kurt Sutter, the creator of the on-road mayhem in the hit FX biker drama “Sons of Anarchy,” will be taking the action off-script in a new show called “Outlaw Empires,” which will profile real-life crime organizations like the Crips, the Irish mob and the Aryan Brotherhood as well as an rogue biker gang, Entertainment Weekly reported on Tuesday.

headline: Redistricting Shapes Pennsylvania Primaries
text: Redistricting remains a wild card in many House races this year, and Tuesday’s primary in Pennsylvania will provide the latest test. Two Democrats are ensnared in a member-on-member battle, and one will emerge with his political career fatally wounded. Other Democrats and Republicans are fighting off feisty outside challenges with a redistricting twist.

headline: Minor Comeback for NBC on Monday, as It Faced Weaker Competition
text: The complete absence of new programming on CBS Monday night opened the way for NBC to mount a ratings comeback for its potent singing competition, “The Voice,” and its flagging drama favorite, “Smash.”

headline: Frank Bruni Does Hungary
text: Bruni’s beat and mine don’t overlap much, but he’s in Budapest, and doesn’t like what he sees.

headline: Herman Cain Moves On … to Comedy
text: Herman Cain is now comfortable enough with his status as a failed presidential candidate that he has begun poking fun at some of the missteps in his campaign, and in an appearance on Monday on Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show” he shows how he might just have a bright future in comedy.

headline: Freeh Responds to Furor Over MF Global Bonuses

headline: One Island, Two Countries
text: Apart from a dwindling seal colony and the automated lighthouse towering over it, nothing seems remotely remarkable about Market Island, a tiny skerry [1] in the strait separating the Gulf of Bothnia from the Baltic Sea. But Market, which is Swedish for “boundary marker” (not “market,” as you might assume), is an uninhabited sea-rock with a difference. It not only marks the meeting of two seas, but the meeting of Sweden and Finland.

headline: The Cotton Kings of Texas
text: As the reality of the war and the grip of the Union blockade settled upon the South, two brothers who had been among the most successful plantation owners in Texas decided to diversify their holdings — by taking up the dicey new business of blockade-running.

headline: The Lowdown on Google Drive
text: Google’s online storage service, Google Drive, is finally out with the expected 5 gigabytes of free storage. While the service has been discussed for months, few people had anticipated all that Google included in the service.

headline: Nissan Is Latest Company to Get Hacked
text: Nissan confirmed its computer systems were hacked two weeks ago.

headline: Spurs Quietly Take Top Spot in West
text: It happened so stealthily, without fanfare, but the results cannot be denied: the San Antonio Spurs have clinched the top seed in the Western Conference. The Spurs demolished the Blazers, 124-89, in San Antonio to lock things up in the regular season’s waning days.

headline: Channeling Bardot’s Up-Do
text: RETRO geometric prints, sleeveless shifts, false eyelashes: Walk into a dress shop or drugstore these days, and you might think you’ve been teleported back to 1965. With celebrities like Adele showing off vintage looks, and “Mad Men” inspiring makeup by Estée Lauder and clothes by Banana Republic, is it any wonder many women are trying to tease their hair?

headline: Turntable Setup for the Obsessive
text: Last week’s personal-tech feature was about a turntable guide which the headline writer rightly titled, “Enjoying Turntables Without Obsessing.”

headline: Former City Finance Commissioner Fined $22,000 for Conflict

headline: Fox News Host Corrects Obama’s ‘Silver Spoon’ Quote

headline: The iPhone Is Still a Strong Seller for AT&T and Verizon

headline: A Pitch to Collect Charity From Casino Gamblers

This week, we’ve got a video pitch from the social enterprise Casino Patron Charities that wants to turn casino gambling into a charitable activity by making it easy for casino gamblers to donate the change on their winnings to charity.

headline: It’s Fight Time in Bangkok
text: On a recent trip to Thailand, my fourth since 2000, I was fortunate to have some new adventures. One of the highlights was getting to see the national sport, the martial arts discipline known as muay Thai, firsthand and up close.

headline: Chris Bangle, the Novelist, Selects Winner of Design Competition

headline: What Primary?
text: Mitt Romney’s top fundraising zip code is 10021, comprising East 69th Street to East 76th Street in Manhattan. It’s one of the country’s richest areas, and reliably politically active in the large-donations sense of that term: In 2000, it supplied the most campaign dollars to both George W. Bush and Al Gore of any postal code in the United States.

headline: Living ‘Portion Size Me’
