text: SANFORD, N.C.

headline: Scene City: Carnegie Hall Gala Honoring Bill Cunningham
text: More than 450 people gathered for a cocktail party and dinner to honor the New York Times photographer with a Carneige Hall Medal of Excellence.

headline: Engineer Arrested in BP Oil Spill Case
text: HOUSTON — Two years after the immense BP oil spill that killed 11 people and blackened beaches along the Gulf of Mexico, federal prosecutors have filed the first criminal charges related to the accident, accusing a former company engineer of destroying evidence by deleting text messages that discussed the amount of oil leaking from the stricken well.

headline: Notes From the Recipe Tester: Why Peel a Pea?
text: Denise Landis has been testing recipes for The New York Times for more than 20 years. She is also the author of “Dinner for Eight: 40 Great Dinner Party Menus for Friends and Family.” Here, she offers tips for making one of this week’s Dining recipes.

headline: South Sudan Says Sudan Strikes Again
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — As aerial bombardments continued in the border region between Sudan and South Sudan on Tuesday, the South Sudanese president, Salva Kiir, met with President Hu Jintao of China, a crucial friend to both nations, saying that Sudan had “declared war” on his country, a spokesman for the South said.

headline: To Find Diversity Hot Spots, Follow the Ants
text: More on the biodiversity front:

headline: Mets Put Bay and Pelfrey on Disabled List
text: The Mets lost two games to the San Francisco Giants on Monday, dropping their record to .500 this season. On Tuesday, they lost two players.

headline: Jailed Ex-Premier in Ukraine Goes on Hunger Strike
text: MOSCOW — Ukraine’s jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, declared a hunger strike on Tuesday after what she said was an assault by prison guards that left her black and blue.

headline: Brown and Warren Spar Over Tax Returns
text: 3:16 p.m. | Updated BOSTON — Senator Scott P. Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said on Tuesday that he would release his personal tax returns from the last six years and challenged Elizabeth Warren, his presumed Democratic opponent, to do the same.

headline: Lumière | Made in France
text: When Lejaby Lingerie, the 82-year-old French bra-and-corset maker, announced last year that it was shuttering its fourth and only remaining factory in France and heading to Tunisia, it represented more than just another blow for French industry. It also provided one of the most unexpected symbols of the French presidential campaign: the bra.

headline: That Brawl? Elite Club Wants Nothing Said
text: The 144-year-old New York Athletic Club is known for its nurturing role in the history of American amateur sports, the hundreds of Olympic medals its members have won, and its fancy headquarters on Central Park South featuring squash courts, guest rooms, a library and a strict dress code.

headline: Debt Collector Is Faulted for Tough Tactics in Hospitals
text: Hospital patients waiting in an emergency room or convalescing after surgery are being confronted by an unexpected visitor: a debt collector at bedside.

headline: Cooper Union Will Charge Tuition for Graduate Students
text: Cooper Union, which has a century-old tradition of free tuition, will begin charging graduate students for their education, our colleague Richard Pérez-Peña reports.

headline: Everybody Got Dressed for Bill
text: Last night, more than 450 people gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria for a cocktail party and dinner to honor Bill Cunningham, The New York Times photographer, whose two columns, On the Street and Evening Hours, appear each week in Sunday Styles.

headline: Georgetown Faculty Latest to Chide Ryan
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, has been excoriated by some Roman Catholic leaders ever since he claimed this month that his budget plan, which slashes antipoverty programs, was inspired by the moral teachings of his Catholic faith.

headline: An E-Book That Glows in the Dark
text: If you intend to buy an e-book reader, here’s a tip: First, spend an evening sitting cross-legged on a lotus leaf, surrounded by incense and sitar music.

headline: Louis Langree Named Music Director of Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra
text: Louis Langrée, the French conductor who has been a mainstay of the Mostly Mozart Festival as its music director for a decade, will also become music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Langrée, 51, will start his four-year contract the season after next, the Cincinnati Symphony announced on Tuesday, but he will conduct two programs with the orchestra in November. He will immediately put a Francophone stamp on his new job, leading works by Franck, Messiaen and Saint-Saëns in the first set of concerts that month.

headline: The Boy Who Changed His Family’s Diet
text: On the last day of fourth grade, a fellow student stood in front of Marshall Reid and levied the cruel words that would change his family’s life. “You’re fat,” he said.

headline: Tribeca: ‘Wavumba’ and a Legend’s Last Shark Hunt
text: Kenya enchanted Jeroen van Velzen when his peripatetic family moved him there briefly as a child. In a fading fisherman on the country’s coast, the Dutch filmmaker found an embodiment of both his dreams about the place and the point where rosy imaginings collide with reality.

headline: Off the Beaten Track: Six Guys in a Starbucks in Bahrain
text: This is a continuation of yesterday’s post: Finding a Bahrain Different Than the One I Expected

headline: More People Seeking Help Cite Burden of Student Loans
text: More people seeking debt counseling are citing student loan debt as their main reason for seeking help, an analysis by a large credit-counseling agency shows.

headline: Ferrari Hybrid Powertrain Loses Flywheel, but Picks Up Power
text: Is the world ready for the better, faster, stronger version of the Ferrari Enzo? If it is, it had better be prepared for it to be a hybrid.

headline: Late in the Season, the Knicks Have Won Bigger
text: In my last post on Off the Dribble, I wrote that the percentage in which teams blow out their opponents may indicate they are stronger than their record would indicate. This season, the Knicks have won 28 percent of their games by 10 or more points. That rate ties them for seventh best in the N.B.A., a substantial showing despite their middle-tier ranking in terms of actual wins.

headline: Treating Sensory Processing Disorders in One Stop
text: The new WeeZee play complex in Westchester has a cute name, but a serious mission:  Louise Weadock, a psychiatric nurse and parent, founded the facility, based on her own and others’ research, to provide play and developmental activities for children with (and without) sensory disorders, and to continue the research into the effectiveness of sensory play as therapy.

headline: LeRoy T. Walker, a Pioneer of U.S. Olympics, Dies at 93
text: LeRoy T. Walker, a leading American track and field coach who was the first African-American to coach a United States men’s Olympic track team and to serve as the president of the United States Olympic Committee, died Monday in Durham, N.C. He was 93.

headline: Tortorella on Game 7: ‘My Thought Is to Win It’
text: Even on an off day, more than 48 hours before his Rangers host the Senators in Game 7, Coach John Tortorella chose not to engage in a discussion about what the first Game 7 in New York since 1994 means for the franchise and the city of New York.

headline: Photo Replay: April 24
text: A look at the day in sports included sunset surfing in Australia and a German Olympic balancing act.

headline: Tina Fey on the ‘30 Rock’ Live Episode and the Show’s Future
text: The first time, it’s a stunt; the second time it’s a tradition. On Thursday, “30 Rock” will once again journey from its home at Silvercup Studios in Long Island City, Queens, to NBC headquarters at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in Manhattan for an episode that will be shown live. As it did in a similar outing in October 2010, “30 Rock” will ditch its filmed format and adapt its fast-paced repartee and cutaway sight gags to a no-second-chances style more familiar to “Saturday Night Live” (whose base of operations at Studio 8H will again be the site of the “30 Rock” show).

headline: Scoring Is the Issue for Denver Lacrosse
text: Despite an 8-7 lead with only 19 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter, the No. 10/12 Pioneers lost by 9-8 in overtime to then-No. 17 Fairfield on Saturday afternoon at Lessing Field in Connecticut. With the loss, Denver dropped to 7-5 over all and 3-3 in the E.C.A.C., clinching the No. 4 seed in the conference tournament thanks to Air Force’s 14-4 loss to Ohio State over the weekend.

headline: Obama Opens Two-Day Trip to Try to Recapture Youth Vote
text: BOULDER, Colo. — President Obama opened a two-day, three-campus swing on Tuesday designed to recapture the youth vote that helped propel him to the White House four years ago, presenting himself once more as a product of poverty in implicit contrast to his wealthy opponent.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyer Tries New Approach
text: WASHINGTON — Standing in front of the jury box, Rusty Hardin, Roger Clemens’s lawyer, spoke in a near whisper as he ended his opening argument Tuesday, begging jurors to realize that the government’s perjury case against Clemens is “tragically wrong.”

headline: The Crisis of Zionism
text: Something I’ve been meaning to do — and still don’t have the time to do properly — is say something about Peter Beinart’s brave book The Crisis of Zionism.

headline: Discovery’s Soggy Logic on ‘Frozen Planet’
text: Here’s a question to ponder after reviewing the video of melting penguin ice sculptures above shot at the glitzy New York City celebration of the American production of “Frozen Planet.”

headline: Paris Festival Looks Beyond Borders  to Portland, Ore.
text: France loves nothing more than to fete its own patrimonial heritage. However the Gaîté Lyrique in Paris (3 bis rue Papin ; 33-1-53-01-51-51) has decided to import and honor a bit of foreign culture. Having paid tribute to Istanbul and Berlin, the organization turns its attention to the far-flung Pacific Northwest: specifically Portland, Ore. From April 24 to  29, Paris is host to the Keep Portland Weird festival.

headline: North African Chicken With Spicy Green Sauce
text: Time: About 1 hour 45 minutes plus overnight soaking

headline: Spicy Green Sauce
text: 1 preserved lemon (available at Middle Eastern groceries) or the grated zest of 1 lemon

headline: A Tunisian One-Pot Dish, as Spicy as You Like It
text: THERE’S a little Tunisian spot in Paris I like to visit for a casual meal. It’s totally bare-bones, but the place has a great feel and the food is simple and good.

headline: Wayne Shorter and Rufus Wainright Among Montreal Jazz Fest Performers
text: Wayne Shorter, Esperanza Spalding, Stanley Clarke and Hiromi Uehara are among the prominent jazz artists who will perform at the 33rd Montreal Jazz Festival this summer, organizers announced Tuesday. Like most major jazz festivals, the “Festival International de Jazz de Montreal” long ago abandoned any claim to purity and now includes several pop and rock groups. Rufus Wainwright, for instance, will open the festival on June 28 with a free outdoor concert at La Place de Festival. Among the other non-jazz musicians scheduled to perform are James Taylor, Ziggy Marley, Janelle Monae and Seal.

headline: Putin to Pass Control of Party to Medvedev
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin said Tuesday that he would step down as chairman of United Russia, the political party he has led since 2008, and hand the reins of the parliamentary majority to his protégé, President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

headline: At Duke, Wall Street May Still Hold Allure
text: Do college students still want to work on Wall Street? The question has proved hard to answer. (DealBook said no. The Wall Street Journal, two weeks later, disagreed.)

headline: Key Issues in Deciding College Football’s New Postseason
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The czars of college football — conference commissioners, ESPN executives and select university and bowl officials — descended on the Westin Diplomat hotel this week for a pivotal series of meetings tied to the future of the sport’s postseason.

headline: Jessica Ogden’s Creature Comforts
text: The designer Jessica Ogden once put on a fashion show that was inspired by Haruki Murakami’s “Kafka on the Shore,” a novel in which fish fall from the sky and a man converses with cats. The set featured stuffed animals and props that were meant to evoke a surrealist beach party, a whimsical conceit that is perfectly in keeping with Ogden’s elegantly naïve aesthetic. Seven years later, the idea has taken on new life in “Lily’s Castle in the Sand,” an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Apartment, a boutique-cum-gallery in Copenhagen. “Lily’s Castle” features Ogden’s paintings and clothing designs as well as an expanded collection of appliquéd and patchwork elephants, butterflies and other animals, some plush-toy cuddly, others the size of a rocking horse, and all of them gathered for afternoon tea. Ogden, who lives in Paris and designs quilts and the Madras line for A.P.C., worked with the costume designer Lee Benjamin, who outfitted Leigh Bowery and now collaborates with the comedian and drag queen Jonny Woo and the performance artist Scottee, to create the menagerie. She traces her fascination with the world of play — “I imagine these animals gossiping about who’s wearing what and who shall we invite next time,” she says of her Lewis Carroll-style party — to her childhood in Jamaica, where her British parents moved before she was born. Growing up there, she says, “gives you a lot of freedom for inventing games from nothing.”

headline: Change of Tone Could Help Google in European Antitrust Case
text: BRUSSELS — For the past two years, Google has worked hard to avoid facing formal antitrust charges in Europe that could mean years of expensive litigation and encourage the authorities in other parts of the world to take comparable action.

headline: New Yorker Word Nerds Drop ‘Slacks’ in Online Contest
text: Last Friday, the New Yorker’s Culture Desk blog announced a contest asking readers to nominate the word that most urgently needs to be eliminated from the English language. And now, the results are in: for the next week, no one who speaks English — or at least writes it on the magazine’s Web site — will be allowed to describe someone else as wearing “slacks.”

headline: After Delaware Primary, Gingrich Campaign Will ‘Reassess’ Race
text: Could this finally be Newt Gingrich’s swan song? After a roller-coaster campaign that saw the former House speaker stage multiple comebacks — hitting his high moment when he clobbered Mitt Romney in South Carolina three months ago — Mr. Gingrich now seems to be thinking about dropping out of the race altogether.

headline: Talking About Testing: Ideas for Inquiry and Discussion on Standardized Testing
text: Students in New York City are currently taking standardized tests, and The Times’s SchoolBook blog has been busy reporting on them — in posts on the outcry over a contested question about a pineapple without sleeves, on  parents choosing to keep their children home during tests, and from a staff developer on how testing is hurting teaching.

headline: Fed Outlook: No Big Steps, No Retreat
text: There are times when the Federal Reserve is on the verge of movement, when the latest economic data could easily produce a shift in the nation’s monetary policy.

headline: In Charter Battle, Union Turns to School's Namesake for Help
text: A years-long fight over unionization efforts by teachers at a Harlem charter school has crossed the Atlantic Ocean and landed in South Africa, at the doorstep of one of the famous families the school is named after. A letter from Max Sisulu, the speaker of the National Assembly of South Africa, asked the union and school's board of trustees to end their fighting.

headline: Dining Out at Ethnic Supermarkets in Los Angeles
text: I can trace my interest in supermarkets as tourist attractions to time I spent in the Dominican Republic 17 years ago, when, shopping with local friends, I was downright shocked by the variety of shapes and sizes of the kitchen tool invented to smash a once-fried plantain slice before tossing it back into the oil to make a tostón.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, England, North Korea and India.

headline: To Encourage Good Habits, Test Early and Often in High School
text: While some parents and educators are saying schools tests too much, one principal wants to test his students more, namely he wants his 9th graders to take the Regents tests. Practice, he believes, makes perfect.

headline: Older Men Still Being Screened for Prostate Cancer
text: Many men 75 years and older, who are far more likely to be harmed than helped by prostate cancer screening, continue to be tested for the disease, despite federal guidelines strongly advising against the practice.

headline: Kabul Toasts the Queen With a Cool Drink, and the Fizz of Diplomacy
text: Strains of “God Save the Queen” floated over Kabul on Sunday.

headline: TimesCast | Questioning Austerity
text: April 24, 2012 — As strict austerity measures take root across Europe, some wonder whether the cuts will harm more than they help.

headline: Bomb at Train Station Kills 2 and Injures 27 in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A bomb exploded inside the busiest railway station in this eastern Pakistani city late Tuesday afternoon, killing at least two people and injuring 27, police officials said.

headline: JPMorgan’s New Asia Chief Sees Growth Opportunities
text: Over his four years at JPMorgan Chase, Jeff Urwin has taken an increasingly global role. Now, the next stop in his career involves moving halfway around the world.

headline: Obama Calls Agents in Scandal ‘Knuckleheads’
text: BOULDER, Colo. — President Obama on Tuesday called the Secret Service agents caught in a prostitution scandal “a couple of knuckleheads” who did not reflect the overall professionalism of the agency.

headline: Art Is Long; Copyrights Can Even Be Longer
text: It is there in the new 3-D version of “Titanic,” as it was in James Cameron’s original film: a modified version of Picasso’s painting “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” aboard the ship as it sinks.

headline: The Culinary Definition of ‘Neighborly’
text: THERE are many different kinds of neighbors in Manhattan. There are those who bang on the ceiling at the slightest click of a high heel on hardwood. There are others who dart into a darkened doorway, threatened by a curious glance. And then there are Robyn and Jesse.

headline: Nonprofit Group Highlights Privacy Issues in Mobile Payments
text: Some mobile payment methods are so convenient that you can walk into a store and buy something without even taking your smartphone out of your pocket. But at what cost?

headline: Apple Profit Rises on Higher iPhone and iPad Sales
text: Not long after the iPhone came out, skeptics questioned how much appeal the costly device and related wireless service would have in countries like China with lower income levels. On Tuesday, Apple provided the answer: A lot.

headline: What’s in Store | Maison Kitsuné
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Facebook Fight in Germany Leads to Battle Over Privacy
text: BERLIN — Ariane Friedrich, a German Olympic high-jump hopeful, knows how to pull a tough face, a gun and, it seems, a fast one on a fan who sent her an obscene message over Facebook.

headline: With Depleted Primary Field, Romney Looks to Win Big
text: Republicans in five states are voting Tuesday in primaries that party leaders hope will serve to accentuate Mitt Romney’s status as the presumed nominee for the fall election against President Obama.

headline: Empellón Cocina
text: Inside the chef Alex Stupak’s Mexican restaurant in the East Village.

headline: A Taste of Mexico, as in a Dream
text: THE danger in writing about the smart and often inspired cooking at Empellón Cocina, Alex Stupak’s free-associating mash note to the food of Mexico, is that other chefs might get the idea that anybody can do what he has done.

headline: Beaming Colors From Up North
text: I SHOULD admit upfront that I knew the thread was frayed. Before I walked out my front door, I’d noticed how flimsily the button was held by the string, how uncertain it looked, almost shrugging in defeat.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Arrested in Russia and Nokia’s Problems
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

headline: As Demand Rises, Ohio’s Steel Mills Shake Off the Rust and Expand
text: CANTON, Ohio — The Ohio steel industry, led by a drilling boom in the gas and oil industry and a resuscitated demand for cars and light trucks, is growing again. Steel makers across the state are racing to keep pace with plans to add a total of two million square feet of production space at a cost of $1.5 billion.

headline: The Arizona Show
text: Senator Charles Schumer of New York, chairman of the Judiciary Committee’s subcommittee on immigration, refugees and border security, called a hearing this morning on Arizona’s immigration law.

headline: A Mexican Restaurant Has to Give Up Tacos
text: It’s not exactly a Mexican standoff, but it is a decidedly odd dining arrangement.

headline: Lincoln Center’s Out of Doors Returns for 42nd Year
text: A funk concert by Nile Rodgers, an experimental composition by Phil Kline and a recital by the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble are among the highlights of Lincoln Center’s 42nd Out of Doors festival, which will run from July 25 to Aug. 12.

headline: Prima
text: 58 East First Street (First Avenue); (646) 559-4823; primanyc.net.

headline: La Churreria
text: 284 Mulberry Street (Houston Street); (212) 219-0400; lachurrerianyc.com.

headline: David W. Levinson
text: Mr. Levinson, 63, is the chairman and chief of the L & L Holding Company, which is based in New York and owns and operates five million square feet of office space in the Manhattan area. Its portfolio includes 200 Fifth Avenue, once called the International Toy Center, and 425 Park Avenue, which is about to be redeveloped.

headline: Final for Chelsea; Creeping Doubts for Barcelona
text: BARCELONA, Spain — When it was over, and the balloons had shriveled and the whistles had faded away, Lionel Messi put his hands to his head. The slick, slippery forward stood still, rooted to his spot. It was as if he could not believe what he was seeing.

headline: Slide Show: Prima
text: Prima is a small restaurant in the East Village that acts like a bar — it’s a coffee bar in the morning, a raw bar, wine bar and cocktail bar at night — but some of the most exciting dishes to come out of the kitchen are classic restaurant fare, namely fish entrees prepared according to traditional French technique: seared in butter on the stovetop and finished in the oven.

headline: Knicks Give Grunwald a Promotion, and Woodson Gets a Boost
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks rewarded Glen Grunwald on Tuesday, removing the “interim” from his title of general manager after a wildly unpredictable season in which the team finished above .500 and is heading to the playoffs with considerable momentum.

headline: Why the Debt That Burdens the Modern World Is About More Than Money
text: A glance at the headlines from Europe, the news from Washington or this month’s bills will confirm that we live in an age of debt. Debt, a concept at once straightforward and almost metaphysically complex, is a source of personal, national and global anxiety, and forms a link between the individual and the worldwide economic system.

headline: Three Dishes at Empellón Cocina
text: At Empellón Cocina, Alex Stupak and his wife and partner, Lauren Resler, have given themselves permission to stick to Mexico’s traditional cuisine when it suits them and to leave tradition behind when that seems like a more intriguing path. I spoke with them on the phone this week to learn the inspirations and innovations behind three of the restaurant’s best dishes.

headline: Violence in Syria’s Capital Even With a Cease-Fire
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Three members of the Syrian security services used to suppress antigovernment dissent were killed in and around Damascus on Tuesday, according to the official media and activists, one of several indications that the cease-fire arranged under United Nations auspices continued to wobble.

headline: Refused, Reunited
text: The 1990s Swedish hardcore band performed at Terminal 5 on Monday night, its second New York City show after regrouping for the Coachella festival.

headline: Swedes Who Know How to Stay Mad as Hell
text: Like any sensible punk-rockers, the 1990s Swedish band Refused was skeptical about reuniting. “Why would these old guys play these old songs?” Dennis Lyxzen, the band’s lead singer (and screamer), asked onstage at the sold-out Terminal 5 on Monday night, in its second New York City show after Refused regrouped for the Coachella festival.

headline: Pioneers Who Helped Fill More Than a Breadbasket
text: In 1910 a dozen young Eastern European Jews moved to the Jordan Valley, then under Ottoman rule, and began to build an agrarian community based on a utopian socialist vision. Men and women were treated equally, everyone shared all they had, and no one had more than anyone else.

headline: Fraud Heightens Jeopardy of Investing in Chinese Companies
text: You might think that if you bought shares of a Chinese company that was listed on an American stock market, you would actually own a piece of that company.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Settles Pension Dispute With Musicians
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra said on Tuesday that it had settled a dispute with its musicians’ national pension fund, calling the agreement a “critical step” in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy court. The orchestra agreed to pay $1.75 million to the American Federation of Musicians and Employers’ Pension Fund, it said, in exchange for the fund’s dropping its claims against the orchestra. The orchestra had withdrawn from the fund, prompting the fund to say that it was owed $35 million as a consequence. That was one of the demands dropped under the agreement, the orchestra said.

headline: Principals Criticize Increased Costs of Test Scoring
text: City principals say their teachers will have to spend more school days than usual scoring state exams this year because of budget cuts to a pot of money that was used to keep teachers working late to score the exams.

headline: Riverpark Adds an Outdoor Farm Table
text: Riverpark, the restaurant in the Alexandria Center, a group of office towers overlooking the East River at 29th Street, has had its own farm since last year. Nearly 200 different edible herbs, vegetables and berries are planted in soil in 4,000 milk crates set up in the plaza in front of the restaurant.

headline: Big Ratings for Playoffs
text: More people are watching the Stanley Cup playoffs in the United States this year, partly because four national networks are covering them, up from two in recent seasons.

headline: The End of the World of Video as We Know It
text: The idea of going to a store to pick out a movie that you would take home and watch on your own TV: some of us remember when this was a novelty. We think it was before cellphones, but we’re not quite sure, having long ago given up on keeping up with technology.

headline: Patagonia Starts a Food Line
text: For years, Patagonia, the outdoor clothier, has been outfitting adventurers for forays into the wilderness. Now the company is exploring a frontier of its own: food. It’s starting a new line called Patagonia Provisions, advertised as “sustainable substance” — portable, nutritious, shelf-stable snacks to tuck into the pocket of that polyester fleece garment.

headline: A Louis Armstrong Performance, Recipes Included
text: On Jan. 29, 1971, five months before his death, Louis Armstrong performed for the last time, at the National Press Club in Washington, to celebrate the inauguration of Vernon Louviere, a journalist from New Orleans, as the club’s president. Served with the jazz were bayou dishes including shrimp mousse, jambalaya and a Jamaica rum pie prepared by Christopher Blake, a New Orleans writer and chef.

headline: For Santorum, It’s All Over but the Endorsement
text: This was supposed to have been Rick Santorum’s comeback night.

headline: Next Up to Testify, Rupert Murdoch, Who Has Been Prepping
text: Even as testimony by James Murdoch on Tuesday was agitating the British political scene — over the extent of his knowledge of phone-hacking at News International papers and particularly over his contacts with the British government concerning business deals — his father, Rupert, was prepared to take his seat on Wednesday.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Benefits

headline: Wal-Mart Vows to Fix Its Controls
text: Allegations of widespread bribery at Wal-Mart’s Mexican subsidiary continued to reverberate on Tuesday, with the company beginning a campaign to limit the damage as its shares declined further.

headline: Edwards’s Former Aide Takes the Stand
text: April 24, 20112 - At John Edwards trial in North Carolina, his former campaign staffer Andrew Young is on the stand for his second day of testimony for the prosecution.

headline: No Pressure: Just Make Obama Laugh
text: LOS ANGELES — A little over a week before Jimmy Kimmel would face the assembled Washington press corps, the nation’s political leaders and assorted celebrities, all decked out in formalwear in a noisy ballroom, he found himself waking suddenly in the middle of the night: He wasn’t racked by nerves; he had simply thought of another joke in his sleep.

headline: North Carolina, I Love You. I Really, Really Love You.
text: During his speech at the University of North Carolina today, President Obama mentioned North Carolina 10 times, mostly to say how much he loves it. “Love North Carolina,” he said. “I love North Carolina. I do. Every time I come down to this state I just love it that much more.”

headline: Misconduct in Colombia Varied, an Inquiry Finds
text: WASHINGTON — After the Secret Service scandal erupted nearly two weeks ago, the accusations of egregious behavior by the men entrusted with protecting President Obama seemed clear-cut. Members of Congress and tabloids depicted a dozen agency employees meeting prostitutes in their hotel rooms and drunken revels at brothels or strip clubs involving up to 20 women.

headline: The Soul of a New Ensemble: Musicians as Entrepreneurs
text: In a New York University lecture hall, business school students poked at iPads and iPhones to produce short melodic loops through speakers. A few feet away, a small group of musicians about the same age played along in a performance of Terry Riley’s Minimalist masterpiece “In C.”

headline: Wholehearted Songs for Lovelorn Joe Six-Packs
text: In 2009 Lee Brice released “Love Like Crazy,” the first single from the album of the same title, a pulpy croon that shuttled between two seemingly competing sides of Mr. Brice’s personality. Is he a wide-eyed celebrant of everlasting love or a kooky raconteur of life’s little offbeat surprises?

headline: Fresh Pairings for Liszt, With Bird Imagery Hovering
text: It would have been unlike Pierre-Laurent Aimard to celebrate Liszt’s bicentenary with a straightforward recording and recitals to match. Mr. Aimard has, to a large extent, taken over the role of the keyboard’s deep thinker from Alfred Brendel, with Jeremy Denk and Jonathan Biss in hot pursuit (not that there must be only one). His programs are typically built to look beyond how striking a set of works is, or how thoughtfully and colorfully Mr. Aimard plays them, though those thoughts invariably come to mind as well.

headline: Opening a Trove of City Snapshots, Not Quite a Million Deep
text: Call it “Forward to the Future.” The Bloomberg administration unveiled a trove of 870,000 digitized images and media from the city archives Tuesday, with photographs dating from 1858, color images from the 1980s of every building in the city, and farm maps dating to 160 years ago. The gallery is accessible free on the city’s Web site (though opening-day traffic was so heavy that it’s been down most of the afternoon), and reprints and digital copies are available for purchase.

headline: Tim Cook Spells Out the Rapid Growth of Apple’s iPad
text: Apple on Tuesday posted a blowout second quarter, nearly doubling its profit from the year-ago quarter. That’s notable because in years past, Apple’s second-quarter earnings had not been nearly as strong. The iPad, however, has helped change that.

headline: At CinemaCon, Theater Owners Are the Stars
text: LAS VEGAS — All week, movie executives will be arriving at Caesars Palace to kiss the rings of the big multiplex operators and learn about the latest advancements in popped corn. It’s CinemaCon, the official convention of the National Association of Theater Owners.

headline: Rising Demand in U.S. Helps 3M Beat Earnings Estimates
text: The 3M Company, maker of Post-it notes and fuel system tuneup kits, reported a 4.6 percent increase in its first-quarter profit on Tuesday, beating analysts’ forecasts, as industrial demand in the United States helped offset slowing markets abroad.

headline: Etan, and the SoHo of Our Childhood
text: Another heartbreak. Each time Etan Patz’s name comes back into the news, I hope for closure. I was his neighbor, and, like every other kid downtown, it could just as easily have been me. Only I didn’t think that at the time.

headline: The Caucus Click: Getting Ready for Romney
text: Campaign workers hung banners behind the stage in preparation for Mitt Romney’s primary night event on Tuesday in Manchester, N.H.

headline: For AlixPartners, a Sale Provides Avenue for Expansion Abroad
text: The consulting firm AlixPartners  changed hands on Tuesday after it agreed to be sold to the private equity firm CVC Capital Partners, but its goal of expanding abroad remains the same.

headline: Romney Adviser Takes Different Tack With Senate Race
text: Mitt Romney and Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts may share a senior adviser, Eric Fehrnstrom, but they’re certainly getting different advice, at least when it comes to tax returns.

headline: The Unconscious Impact of ‘The Conflict’
text: Motherlode has asked women at different stages of their family and career lives to respond to Elisabeth Badinter’s “The Conflict” by describing how reading it has affected their views or plans for work and motherhood. The following is a continuation of an ongoing conversation.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Team Draws Path Against Japan for Olympic Gold
text: One year after losing to Japan in a compelling World Cup final, the United States women’s soccer team may have the rematch it has been seeking at this summer’s London Olympics.

headline: Greenpeace Protests Apple’s Energy Practices By Releasing Balloons
text: The skies over the glass cube that serves as the entrance to the Apple store on Fifth Avenue turned a bit dark on Tuesday afternoon, at least for some shoppers inside. And a passing storm had nothing to do with it.

headline: Rangers in Game 7: By the Numbers
text: The top-seeded Rangers face eighth-seeded Ottawa in Game 7 at Madison Square Garden on Thursday. The Rangers’ record in Game 7’s is 3-5 but a perfect 3-0 at home, while the Senators are 0-4 in Game 7’s. But other numbers suggest this Game 7 is a tossup.

headline: Police Seeking Tips on Armed Robbery of McDonald’s in Queens
text: The police are looking for a robber who forced workers at a McDonald’s in Queens into a walk-in freezer at gunpoint on Thursday.

headline: For Bruins, Preparing for Game 7 Is Nothing New
text: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Another Stanley Cup playoff series, another Game 7 for the Boston Bruins. For the fifth time in their last six playoff series, the Bruins have been taken to the maximum, this time by the Washington Capitals. Game 7 of their first-round playoff series will be Wednesday night in Boston.

headline: Stylish Hotels Sprouting in Brooklyn and Queens
text: The New York City hotel market managed to defy the slump most of the country experienced during and after the recession.

headline: Understanding Motives Behind Teens’ Distracted Driving
text: Many young drivers are in denial about their distracted driving tendencies. Girls are far more likely to engage in distracted behavior behind the wheel than boys. Parents often set bad examples.

headline: Egyptian Actor Insulted Islam, a Court Finds
text: CAIRO — A court found Egypt’s most popular comic actor guilty on Tuesday of insulting Islam in roles in films mocking religious hypocrisy, alarming liberal-minded artists and intellectuals already anxious about the growing power of Islamists here after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Mixed Messages

headline: Marines Moving Women Toward the Front Lines
text: The Marine Corps, the most male of the armed services, is taking its first steps toward integrating women into war-fighting units, starting with its infantry officer school at Quantico, Va., and ground combat battalions that had once been closed to women.

headline: Apple Chief’s Offhand Comment Spawns Internet Quip
text: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, made an easily overlooked comment in Apple’s conference call with Wall Street analysts on Tuesday evening, during all the discussion of impressive quarterly sales and profits. But, of course, the Internet overlooks nothing.

headline: An Early Exit and Possible Shake-Up
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The Vancouver Canucks got revenge, but it did not help in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: BTG Pactual Raises $1.93 Billion in I.P.O.
text: BTG Pactual, the Brazilian investment banking powerhouse, raised $3.625 billion reais ($1.93 billion) on Tuesday night in the largest Brazilian initial public offering of stock since Banco Santander Brasil went public in 2009.

headline: Struggle Between Leaders of Players Union Creates Chaos
text: Five months after settling a damaging lockout, the N.B.A. players union is facing a more existential threat: an internal power struggle that has thrown the association into chaos.

headline: Israel Retroactively Legalizes 3 West Bank Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Tuesday retroactively legalized three Jewish settlement outposts in the West Bank, and moved to delay the scheduled evacuation of a fourth, in a provocative move that some critics said marked the first establishment of new settlements in two decades.

headline: An MF Global Trustee Defends His Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Louis J. Freeh, who gained prominence in Washington as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, delivered a broad defense on Tuesday of his latest role as bankruptcy trustee for MF Global.

headline: Yankees Growing Concerned on Pineda
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Yankees have growing concern about Michael Pineda’s right-shoulder injury, which has not healed as hoped and may be more serious than initially believed.

headline: Case of Mad Cow Disease Is Found in U.S.
text: The Department of Agriculture announced that it had identified a case of mad cow disease, the first in six years, in a dairy cow in central California.

headline: Romney Delivers Big Primary Wins, Assails Obama in Speech
text: Mitt Romney declared that he had accomplished a sweep of five states Tuesday night and laid claim to the Republican presidential nomination after what he said were 43 primaries and caucuses and “many long nights.”

headline: Should the Privacy of a ‘Stalker’ Be Protected?
text: One of Germany’s Olympic hopefuls is facing a whole new challenge that raises questions about victims and perpetrators and the limits of privacy in the digital age.

headline: Giving Away, and Then Seizing, Condoms
text: Last year, New York City health workers gave out 37.2 million condoms. That works out to an average of 70 condoms every minute of the year. The city got into mass-scale condom distribution to help prevent the spread of debilitating and deadly diseases.

headline: For Quinn Wedding, Politics on the Side
text: She has joked about caterer tastings and trying on dresses. She has sent out hundreds of invitations, sprinkled with references to an early romantic getaway at the Pierre hotel and a shared affection for the Jersey Shore. In just a few weeks, she will walk down the aisle, with brooches from her mother fastened in her hair and surrounded by wildflowers meant to evoke those on the High Line.

headline: A Cable Start-Up Lands 3 Big Brands
text: A START-UP cable channel led by Magic Johnson, the basketball star turned businessman, is getting an early vote of confidence from several large marketer clients of a major media agency.

headline: Taking On Dementia With the Experiences of Normal Life
text: WEESP, the Netherlands — The sparkling-new 23-unit Hogewey complex here is virtually indistinguishable from other residential developments in the area. The apartments open onto a courtyard with benches, ponds and fountains, with beds of flowers in season (this is the Netherlands, after all). One kidney-shaped pond planted with reeds and other vegetation occasionally attracts wild ducks.

headline: I Hunt, but the N.R.A. Isn’t for Me
text: Bend, Ore.

headline: Wendell Berry, American Hero
text: The sensibility of Wendell Berry, who is sometimes described as a modern day Thoreau but who I’d call the soul of the real food movement, leads people like me on a path to the door of the hillside house he shares with his wife, Tanya, outside of Port Royal, Ky. Everything is as the pilgrim would have it: Wendell (he’s a one-name icon, like Madonna, but probably in that respect only) is kind and welcoming, all smiles.

headline: Disability Insurance Causes Pain
text: Every year, when the trustees of Social Security and Medicare publish their report on the programs’ finances they set off a round of partisan bickering about the solvency of the twin programs covering pensions and health care for retired Americans.

headline: Muddy Waters
text: Washington

headline: No Rest for the Weary Watson
text: AVONDALE, La. — Ten years before Bubba Watson won the Masters on the strength of a miracle shot, he made his PGA Tour debut at English Turn Golf and Country Club, on the west bank of the Mississippi River, roughly 18 miles from the Tour stop’s current location at the T.P.C. Louisiana.

headline: Defendant No. 34 Has Her Say

headline: A Finishing School of Tough Love for Draftees
text: GAINESVILLE, Ga. — They share details with him about arrests and failed drug tests, substandard work habits and disciplinary infractions.

headline: With 5 More Victories, Romney Focuses on the Fall
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney effectively assumed the helm of the Republican Party on Tuesday after five primary victories across the Northeast solidified his stature as the presidential nominee-in-waiting who is trying to unite conservatives and persuade independent voters that President Obama does not deserve a second term.

headline: S.E.C. Asks if Hollywood Paid Bribes in China
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an investigation into whether some of Hollywood’s biggest movie studios have made illegal payments to officials in China to gain the right to film and show movies there, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Subsidize Students, Not Tax Cuts
text: In 2007, President George W. Bush signed a bill that cut in half interest rates on subsidized student loans until 2012. Those low rates will expire on July 1 — going back to 6.8 percent from 3.4 percent — and, to prevent college from becoming even more unaffordable for millions of students, the obvious move is to renew them. But nothing is that easy or sensible anymore in Washington, where House Republicans are far more interested in cutting taxes, largely for the rich, than they are in helping low- and middle-income students get a college education.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 24, 2012

headline: A Changed South Central
text: The population of South Los Angeles has changed significantly in the two decades since the acquittal of white police officers in the beating of Rodney King inflamed racial tensions across the city.

headline: Arizona and Interposition
text: An important verb appears on page 14 of the government’s brief in Arizona v. the United States, the case about four provisions of that state’s immigration law that will be argued on Wednesday in the Supreme Court. The government says Arizona is trying to “interpose” its own judgments on “national security, law enforcement, foreign policy, humanitarian considerations and the rights of law-abiding citizens and aliens.” It says the Constitution and Congress, in the Immigration and Nationality Act, give the executive branch authority to handle those issues.

headline: Battling Over Budget Cuts
text: The brief truce between the Air Force and the Air National Guard over proposed budget cuts may already be unraveling in the Senate.

headline: Rangers and Senators Near End of Roiling Series
text: The day after the Rangers forced a Game 7 with the Ottawa Senators — Thursday at Madison Square Garden — the teams awaited disciplinary rulings from the N.H.L. on the outbursts that stained the Rangers’ 3-2 victory in Game 6.

headline: Shifting Demographics in South Los Angeles
text: Since the Los Angeles riots 20 years ago, the once largely black South Central neighborhood is now two-thirds Hispanic.

headline: In Years Since the Riots, a Changed Complexion in South Central
text: LOS ANGELES — When racially charged riots blazed here two decades ago, South Central became a national symbol of rage in a poor black neighborhood.

headline: Consumers Need More Protection, Not Less
text: The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is supposed to shield Americans from abusive banking and lending practices. And in its first nine months, it has been doing a good job. But consumer advocates are rightly alarmed that the bureau might now revoke a Federal Reserve rule that limited the fees credit card issuers can charge new customers.

headline: A Dollop of Yogurt for — or, on — Obama
text: BOULDER, Colo. – Taking a bullet for the president is one thing. But fermented milk? It hasn’t been a great week for the Secret Service.

headline: Flamboyant Son of Fallen Chinese Leader Makes a Statement
text: HONG KONG — In the most sensational political drama in decades in China, the fall of the former Politburo member Bo Xilai has captivated the country for months with its cloak-and-dagger intrigue, charges of corruption and murder, and a compelling cast of personalities.

headline: Does the V.A. Get It?
text: The Department of Veterans Affairs says it plans to hire 1,900 psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, clinicians and clerical employees, a 10 percent increase in its mental health staff. That’s welcome progress for a system that is struggling to meet the needs of veterans. But there are questions about whether it will be enough — and whether the department is truly facing up to its problems.

headline: Using U.S. Dollars, Zimbabwe Finds a Problem: No Change
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When Zimbabweans say they are waiting for change, they are usually talking about politics. After all, the country has had the same leader since 1980.

headline: Group Says It Has Ceased Bomb Threats on Campus
text: As students headed to final exams at the University of Pittsburgh this week, with many exhausted and frustrated by more than 100 bomb threats that have disrupted classes and emptied dorms, they were hoping there would be no further evacuations now that a group has announced its bomb threat campaign is over.

headline: Push to Give Midsize Farms a Hub at a Bronx Market
text: Decades after the slow-food movement began championing the benefits of locally grown fruits and vegetables, pressure is mounting for New York City to stand up to big vendors and make room for the region’s midsize farms at the Hunts Point wholesale produce market in the South Bronx.

headline: ‘Nice Work If You Can Get It’
text: Photos from the Broadway musical starring Matthew Broderick and Kelli O’Hara.

headline: Fraud Trial for Espada Is Concluding After 6 Weeks
text: The six-week trial of Pedro Espada Jr., the former state senator whose audacious power grab brought the New York Legislature to a halt in 2009, approached its conclusion on Tuesday, with a federal prosecutor telling the jury during closing arguments that Mr. Espada used a nonprofit health care network that he ran as his own personal A.T.M.

headline: Bid to Block Postal Service Bill Falls Short in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday defeated a Republican attempt to block a vote on a bill to save the struggling Postal Service. The vote was 62 to 37.

headline: Are ‘Family Values’ Outdated?
text: Is the Republican ideal of family just a rhetorical device, or is it still a worthy goal for public policy?

headline: I See You

headline: Falling in Love, Footstep by Footstep
text: Every now and then, a bubble of pure, tickling charm rises from the artificial froth of “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” the pastiche of a 1920s musical featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin. Most of this show, which opened on Tuesday night at the Imperial Theater, registers as a shiny, dutiful trickle of jokes and dance numbers performed by talented people who don’t entirely connect with the whimsy of a bygone genre.

headline: Ten-Term Democrat Holden Loses in Pennsylvania Primary
text: Ten-term Representative Tim Holden of Pennsylvania was defeated in a Democratic primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, losing to Matt Cartwright, a lawyer, who made Mr. Holden’s vote against President Obama’s health care law a major issue in the newly redrawn 17th District.

headline: Study of Fighters Shows Brain Changes Are Seen Before Symptoms
text: LAS VEGAS — One of the questions Dr. Charles Bernick and his colleagues ask boxers who come to the Cleveland Clinic’s Lou Ruvo Center for Brain Health here is, “How many times have you been knocked out cold or gotten a concussion?” Most say, “never.”

headline: Genres Stretch, for Better and Worse, as YouTube Takes On TV
text: Standing in front of what looks like a frosted-blue shower stall, Hank Green, his nerd glasses riding low on his nose, puts his face up close to the tiny puppet on his finger.

headline: Mitt Romney Speaks in New Hampshire
text: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at a primary night rally in Manchester, N.H. Mr. Romney focused the majority of his remarks on the fall campaign.

headline: Even Before the Game, the Mets Lose Two
text: Jose Reyes was back at Citi Field on Tuesday night as a Miami Marlin, a walking, smiling symbol of how ephemeral baseball can be. Meanwhile, the Mets, his old team, were reeling from a double shot of disheartening injury news, a reminder that some things never change.

text: GREENSBORO, N.C.

text: BOULDER, Colo. — The arenas are rocking, the students are whooping and President Obama is feeling the love.

headline: Turkey Feels Sway of Reclusive Cleric in the U.S.
text: ISTANBUL — When Ahmet Sik was jailed last year on charges of plotting to overthrow the government, he had little doubt that a secretive movement linked to a reclusive imam living in the United States was behind his arrest.

headline: Fierce Debate on Arizona Immigration Law on Eve of Supreme Court Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — A day before the Supreme Court was to hear arguments on an Arizona statute that expanded the immigration enforcement powers of local police, the author of the law defended it in a Senate hearing under sharp questioning from Democrats, saying it “removes the political handcuffs from state and local law enforcement.”

headline: Devils Prevail and Force a Game 7
text: NEWARK — Early in overtime of a game the Devils had to win, Ilya Kovalchuk, their $100 million forward, collected a puck inside the Florida blue line, and instead of skating toward the goal, swerved to his right, then passed the puck instead of shooting it.

headline: Ruling Extends Sex-Discrimination Protection to Transgender Woman Denied Federal Job
text: In a decision hailed by advocates for transgender people, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ruled that a California woman who was denied a job at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives after revealing that she was transitioning from her former life as a man can seek legal redress under sex-discrimination regulations.

headline: Doris Betts, Novelist in Southern Tradition, Dies at 79
text: Doris Betts, an award-winning novelist and short-story writer whose characters grappled with religious faith, freedom, captivity and original sin in tales steeped in the Southern literary tradition, died on April 21 at her home in Pittsboro, N.C. She was 79.

headline: Poll: New Yorkers Want New City School Policies from Next Mayor
text: A majority of New York City voters disapprove of the way Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has handled his signature issue, education, and are looking for his successor to take the city schools in a new direction, according to a  NY1-Marist Poll released late Tuesday.

headline: Two Japanese Starters: One Good, One Great
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — One of the most highly anticipated pitching matchups in years, at least in Japan, was equal to the expectations Tuesday night.

headline: Justice Department Submits Correction Letter to Supreme Court
text: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court on Tuesday evening that it had provided incorrect information to the justices in an immigration case. The department, in a seven-page letter, expressed regret for failing in its “special obligation to provide this court with reliable and accurate information at all times.”

headline: George Cowan, Nuclear Scientist, Dies at 92
text: George Cowan, a chemist who helped build the first atomic bomb, detect the first Soviet nuclear explosion and test the first hydrogen bomb, died on Friday at his home in Los Alamos, N.M. He was 92.

headline: Romney Wins Five Primaries
text: Mitt Romney won primary victories in New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Delaware on Tuesday, but he chose to be in New Hampshire instead to speak about general election themes.

headline: Playing the Mormon Card
text: During the long Republican primary season, the highest-profile attack on Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith came in October during the Values Voters Summit in Washington, when the pastor who introduced Rick Perry to the assembly, Robert Jeffress of Dallas’s First Baptist Church, told reporters that “born-again followers of Christ should always prefer a competent Christian” for the presidency and dismissed Mormonism as a pseudo-Christian “cult.”

headline: The Evolution of the Runner’s High
text: Ferrets don’t often figure in studies of exercise, perhaps because they don’t exercise much. They slink like fog through tunnels, sprint briefly over open ground and spend much of their time sleeping. They are, in biological terms, what’s called a noncursorial species, meaning that they are reluctant and lousy distance runners.

headline: Salesforce Moves Into the Government Cloud and Social
text: Salesforce.com, best know for its sales, customer service and collaboration software for business, is now entering the government cloud business with a suite of new product offerings that could help the government adapt to today’s social era.

headline: Word of the Day | impale
text: impale •\im-ˈpal\• verb

headline: Yemen: Defiant Commander Gives Up
text: The commander of the country’s air force agreed to give up his post on Tuesday, easing a political standoff that began weeks ago after some officials loyal to the former president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, refused orders from the new president, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, to step down. Mr. Hadi, who took office in February, has also faced several other crises in recent weeks, including clashes between militants and the army in the south and a spate of kidnappings. After several days of negotiations brokered by a United Nations envoy, Jamal Benomar, the air force chief, Gen. Mohammed Saleh al-Ahmar, who is the former president’s half brother, agreed to be replaced on Tuesday by Gen. Rashid Ali Nasser al-Jund.

headline: U.S. Warns North Korea on Nuclear Test
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned North Korea on Tuesday not to conduct another nuclear test, saying it would create “greater instability in a dangerous part of the world.” At a news conference in Brazil during a South American tour, Mr. Panetta said he had no information that North Korea was preparing for a test, although the South Korean government believes that is the case. This month, North Korea tried and failed to launch a rocket meant to put a satellite in orbit, which the United States condemned. “I strongly urge North Korea not to engage in any further provocations,” Mr. Panetta said. North Korea conducted nuclear tests in 2006 and 2009.

headline: The Closer: Crawford’s Replacements Doing Just Fine
text: The Boston Red Sox are undoubtedly eager to get the injured Carl Crawford back into their lineup, but according to at least one statistic, they may not want to rush.

headline: Measles Deaths Drop in India
text: The number of measles deaths worldwide “has apparently dropped by about three-quarters over a decade,” according to a new study by the World Health Organization and others, the Associated Press reports.

headline: Son of Bo Xilai Reacts to News Media Coverage
text: The 24-year-old son of Bo Xilai, the ousted Communist Party official at the heart of a major political scandal in China, has made his first public statement to the news media.

headline: The ‘Medicine Baba’ Goes Door to Door
text: The “Medicine Baba,” Omkar Nath Sharma, 75, spends his days knocking on doors in Delhi’s upper and middle class neighborhoods, collecting their leftover medicines and giving them to the poor.

headline: News Quiz | April 25, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Foreign Journalists Fall for Modi P.R. Machine
text: Narendra Modi, the leading figure of India’s right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, “didn’t make Time magazine’s list of the 100 most powerful people in the world this year,” Hartosh Singh Bal writes in the Latitude blog of The New York Times. “Midway through the online polling, after Modi’s stock had started to surge, liberals in India organized a counter-campaign.” In the end, 256,792 votes were cast for him and 266,684 votes against, Mr. Bal writes.

headline: A Conversation With: USIBC Chairman Ajay Banga
text: Ajay Banga, the president and chief executive of electronic payment company MasterCard, was recently named the new chairman of the United States India Business Council, a trade group formed in 1975.

headline: Credit Suisse Profit Falls 96% in First Quarter
text: LONDON — Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that its profit fell 96 percent in the first quarter, as the big Swiss bank continued to contend with the dual headwinds of a new regulatory environment and an economic slump.

headline: April 25, 1945 | Conference to Form U.N. Meets as Allied Forces Near Victory Over Nazis
text: On April 25, 1945, in San Francisco, 46 nations met to discuss the creation of the United Nations, an international organization intended to maintain peace between nations. The conference began as troops from the United States and Soviet Union linked up on the Elbe River, in central Europe, a meeting that dramatized the collapse of Nazi Germany and the end of World War II in Europe.

headline: Murdoch, Center Stage, Plays Powerless Broker
text: LONDON — By his own telling, Rupert Murdoch has portrayed himself as a man with Britain’s most power-packed Rolodex: gossiping with Margaret Thatcher about Ronald Reagan, drinking too much after his backing secured an improbable victory for John Major, joshing that he and Tony Blair were like two porcupines mating, fielding barbed threats from Gordon Brown and slipping in the back door of 10 Downing Street as David Cameron’s first visitor after his election.

headline: Pakistan Says It Test-Fires Nuclear-Capable Missile
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan successfully tested an improved intermediate-range ballistic missile early on Wednesday, according to a statement by the Pakistani military.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 25, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Luxury Stores Pull Out Mandarin Phrase Books to Make the Sale.”

headline: Updates on Rupert Murdoch’s Testimony in Britain
text: The Lede followed testimony by Rupert Murdoch and other developments in a judicial inquiry into the behavior of the British press that grew out of a widening phone hacking and corruption scandal at Murdoch-owned papers in Britain. Mr. Murdoch’s son James  testified for several hours on Tuesday.

headline: Deck Me Out for the Ballgame
text: WHO is spending significant amounts of money on equipment for youth baseball?

headline: Photos That Move and Flow — Underwater
text: The underwater photographer David Doubilet has had more than 70 photo stories in the National Geographic magazine, a dozen books and countless exhibits across the world.

headline: What is the Ministry of Health Trying to Tell Doctors?
text: A top government minister, Ghulam Nabi Azad, this week delivered a jolt to India’s aspiring doctors that became front-page news on Tuesday: Any student wishing to continue their medical education in the United States would now have to sign a “bond” binding them to return to India once their studies were completed. Why? Mr. Azad said the tougher regulation was linked to a change in United States policy.

headline: Violence in Syria’s Capital Even With a Cease-Fire
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Three members of the Syrian security services used to suppress antigovernment dissent were killed in and around Damascus on Tuesday, according to the official media and activists, one of several indications that the cease-fire arranged under United Nations auspices continued to wobble. In addition, a small bomb exploded outside an Iranian culture and travel center in the center of Damascus, the Syrian capital, wounding four people but not causing much damage.

headline: What Leader Would You Invite to Speak at Your School?
text: Seniors at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan recently created a YouTube video to try to entice the Knicks star Jeremy Lin to speak at their graduation. And students in Chicago had the opportunity recently to be taught by Nobel Prize winners as well as other world leaders and celebrities. If you could invite any living leader – in politics, science, religion, entertainment, sports or anything else – to speak to your class, whom would you invite and why?

headline: Ericsson Reports Strong First-Quarter Earnings
text: Ericsson, the biggest maker of mobile telecommunications network equipment, said Wednesday that net income had more  than doubled in the first quarter of 2012 on a gain from the sale of its stake in a cellphone business and demand from operators in Latin America, China and Southeast Asia.

headline: Pakistan Says It Test Fires Nuclear-Capable Missile
text: Pakistan successfully tested an improved intermediate range nuclear capable ballistic missile early on Wednesday, according to a statement by the Pakistani military, Salman Masood writes in The New York Times.

headline: Part 3: Answers to Readers’ Questions on Financial Aid
text: As families finalize their college choices before the May 1 deadline, finding the best fit for their students and their budgets, we’ve once again opened our virtual Guidance Office for some advice.

headline: The Varying Impact of Austerity and Stimulus
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Early Word: Milestone
text: Today’s Times

headline: Hugo Chávez & The Supremes
text: MONTREAL — It happened every week. On Friday mornings, Venezuela’s top prosecutor, the justice minister, the solicitor general, assorted Supreme Court justices, police chiefs and top officials would meet in the vice president’s office to review politically sensitive court cases and decide how they should be handled. In each instance, the vice president had the last word: dismissal, acquittal or conviction.

headline: A Promising Brain Test for Football and Other Sports
text: A number of football players have been found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, but only after posthumous exams.

headline: The Criminalization of Bad Mothers
text: On a rainy day just after Thanksgiving, Amanda Kimbrough played with her 2-year-old daughter in her raw-wood-paneled living room, petting her terriers and half-watching TV. Kimbrough, who is 32, lives a few miles outside Russellville, a town of fewer than 10,000 in rural northwestern Alabama, near the border of Franklin and Colbert Counties. Textiles were the economic engine of the area until the 1990s, when the industry went into decline and mills shut down. Now one of the region’s leading employers is Pilgrim’s, a chicken supplier. The median household income is $31,213, and more than a third of children live below the poverty line.

headline: The Water Fight That Inspired ‘Chinatown’
text: For many people, at least outside the far West, the mention of California’s water wars tends to conjure Roman Polanski’s “Chinatown.” The 1974 film classic, starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway and John Huston, is loosely based on the success of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power in siphoning off most of the Owens River, a stream fed by the snowmelt of the Eastern Sierra, and bringing it to the Los Angeles basin about a century ago.

headline: Time to Revisit Food Deserts
text: In last week’s Fixes column I reported on a variety of initiatives that New York and other cities are engaged in to increase the availability of healthy food for sale, particularly fresh produce, in low-income neighborhoods that are believed to have insufficient access. The efforts include bringing in green carts and green markets to serve these areas, as well as offering financial, zoning and other incentives to attract new supermarkets and improve the quality and quantity of fresh food offerings in bodegas and corner stores. The work is explicitly designed to address what the government and many health experts have dubbed the problem of “food deserts.” It has catalyzed new retail food vendors in low-income areas, many of which have become successful businesses.

headline: Is My Family Business Going to Be an Orphan?
text: As I promised I would in a recent post, I have held a family meeting to discuss the long-term fate of my business. I have no plans to retire anytime soon, but I have just turned 56, and I don’t think it is too early — if it is ever too early — to plan for the future.

headline: Playing the Holocaust Card
text: JERUSALEM — The seven days between Holocaust Memorial Day (last Thursday) and Independence Day (this Thursday) are packed with national symbolism. Seven days to remind the Jews of Israel of their trajectory from near annihilation to sovereign revival. Seven days for much sorrow and much pride.

headline: Public Applies More Scrutiny to Exams That Are Supposed to Be Secret
text: This year has brought a heightened level of scrutiny to the state math and reading exams, as teachers and principals give the tests fresh consideration, knowing that under the new statewide teacher evaluation system and with schools in danger of being closed for poor performance, they could lose their jobs if students do poorly.

headline: Super PAC Ad Tries to Tie Romney to Oil Companies
text: Even as Mitt Romney continues to assail President Obama on the price of gas at the pump, Democrats are pushing back by trying to tie Mr. Romney to oil companies and the wealthy interests behind them.

text: Jonathan Bales, the founder of TheDCTimes.com, has helped analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s Profit Rises on iPhone Sales
text: Apple released its quarterly earnings on Tuesday, and as Nick Wingfield reports in Wednesday’s New York Times, it was yet another blockbuster period. The company nearly doubled its profit from the quarter the year before, buoyed largely by sales of the iPhone, especially in China.

text: The Republican National Committee officially embraced Mitt Romney as the party’s presumptive nominee on Wednesday morning after Mr. Romney claimed his new title in an energetic speech Tuesday night.

headline: The Big Wrong
text: It’s Official: Keynes Was Right, says Henry Blodget. Recent election results in Europe seem to have raised consciousness in a way literally years of economic data couldn’t: the austerity doctrine that has ruled European policy is a big fat failure.

headline: Broadcasting a World of Whiteness
text: THOSE looking for hints of racial tone-deafness on the second episode of “Girls,” last Sunday on HBO, wouldn’t have been let down. In an early scene Hannah, played by the show’s creator, Lena Dunham, and her nonboyfriend Adam (Adam Driver) have sex; as they’re finishing, Adam promises to make the “continent of Africa on” Hannah’s arm, a vexing intersection of eroticism and geography. Later Jessa (Jemima Kirke), nervously facing down an abortion, insists, “I want to have children with many different men, of different races,” as if they were trinkets to be collected, like key chains or snow globes.

headline: Testing Concerns Keep Coming
text: As math exams for the state's fourth to eighth graders begin on Wednesday, new controversy emerged about the quality of the exams and choices of the exam-maker, Pearson Education.

text: The euro area’s economic strategy, such as it is, rests on two pillars: confidence through austerity, and “internal devaluation”. You know how the first is going; what about the second?

text: Standard & Poor’s lowered its outlook for India on Wednesday, “citing the country’s struggle to rein in its relatively high debt and fiscal deficit amid a political impasse that is unlikely to ease before the next national elections in 2014,” Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times.

headline: Justices Seem Sympathetic to Central Part of Arizona Law
text: WASHINGTON — Justices across the ideological spectrum appeared inclined on Wednesday to uphold a controversial part of Arizona’s aggressive 2010 immigration law, based on their questions at a Supreme Court argument.

headline: N.F.L. Evolution: How Defenses Will Respond
text: The third in a three-part series. Part 1 examined how the evolution of the N.F.L. into a passing league is affecting the quarterback and wide receiver positions. Part 2 looked at the myth of the eminence of the left tackle and the coming resurgence at running back.

headline: Bookshelf
text: “All We Know” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30), Lisa Cohen’s book about three magnificent failures, opens with a startling portrait of Esther Murphy (1897-1962), who was like a proto-Susan Sontag — “she would pull great swaths of human history out of her memory, exhilarated by its ironies, its neglected crevices, and its meaning in the present” — except that she never finished a book. “Alex Katz: Maine / New York” (Charta, $45) evokes the painter’s natural habitats, contrasting blacked-out cityscapes with languid nature tableaus (above, center). The book is tied to an exhibition that opens in July at the Colby College Museum of Art in Waterville, Me. (More of Katz’s work, his prints, are on view at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.) Following volumes on olives and Champagne, the “Edible Series” goes on a springtime spree with “Vodka,” “Rum” and “Gin” (Reaktion Books, $17 each). In the gin book, Lesley Jacobs Solmonson traces the spirit’s appearance in written English to an 18th-century tract that called it “a fiery Lake that sets the Brain in Flame, burns up the Entrails, and scorches every Part within.” Sounds about right.

headline: A Candid Conversation With Alec Baldwin (Is There Any Other Kind?)
text: To hear Alec Baldwin tell it (or Tweet about it), you might think these were the final days at “30 Rock,” and that he would soon be saying goodbye to Tina Fey and the band of misfit characters on that NBC comedy. While the network has not yet made an official announcement, “30 Rock” is expected to be renewed for one last season, but in the meantime, Mr. Baldwin remains, shall we say, unsentimental about its long-term prospects and the broader state of affairs at NBC.

headline: Netflix: Earnings Offer a Stream of Bad News
text: Sometimes when big juggernauts stumble, we can’t help but murmur a bit of satisfaction. Ah, yes, all high and mighty weren’t you? But now look at you.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 25: Bird Strike Forces Emergency Landing
text: Good morning. It will be partly cloudy today, with highs in the mid 60s.

headline: IPhone Attracts Customers, but Sprint Loses $863 Million
text: Sprint Nextel on Wednesday reported a loss of $863 million in its first quarter, twice the size of its loss in the same quarter last year, but the company was encouraged by the new customers the iPhone was bringing it.

headline: Chasing, and Catching, a Purse Snatcher
text: Dear Diary:My New York apartment overlooked a crossing of two streets in the Village. You could hear and see a lot from there. One day I heard loud screams and ran to the corner window to look. Down the block a well-dressed middle-aged woman was doing the screaming. Apparently the woman’s purse had just been snatched, because a short person in white pants and shirt, hugging a large black handbag, was racing toward my building and the intersection. Meanwhile a stout professorial man, probably the victim’s companion, was pelting after the thief.

headline: How to Try Terrorists
text: Next month, more than nine years after he was captured, then thrown into a secret prison, tortured, and finally moved to Guantanamo Bay, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed will finally go on trial under the military commission system.

headline: Hungary Moves Closer to Getting New Aid
text: BRUSSELS — Hungary moved closer Wednesday to getting sorely needed financial support after the European Union accepted assurances that the government was not undermining the independence of the central bank, while referring to court two other laws that raised questions about the strength of Hungary’s commitment to democracy.

text: Need any evidence of the effort by President Obama to woo young people, as reported by The Times’s Peter Baker on Wednesday morning?

headline: ‘Lone Ranger’ Lassoes Jack White
text: Walt Disney Pictures has hired the rock singer, guitarist and producer Jack White to write, produce and perform the score for the upcoming “Lone Ranger,” the company announced Monday at the CinemaCon theater owners convention in Las Vegas. The film, directed by Gore Verbinski (“Pirates of the Caribbean,” “Rango”), stars Johnny Depp as Tonto and Armie Hammer as John Reid and is set for release on May 31, 2013.

headline: Arts Endowment Trims Support for PBS Shows
text: 2:48 p.m. | Updated The National Endowment for the Arts made sweeping cuts in its support of established PBS shows in the 2012 Arts in Media grants, which were announced Wednesday morning. Instead, the endowment awarded large grants to an array of gaming and Web-based projects.

headline: Gingrich Tells Romney He Will Quit Race
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich told Mitt Romney on Wednesday morning that he would suspend his presidential campaign next week and begin working to turn out conservative voters for Mr. Romney and Republican candidates in the fall election, Mr. Gingrich’s spokesman said in an interview.

text: Stocks advanced on Wednesday, giving the Nasdaq 100 index its biggest gain this year, as Apple’s earnings almost doubled and the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said the Fed was prepared to do more to stimulate growth.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A Child Changes His Family’s Diet
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bloomberg Businessweek: Rev up the Fryolator; it’s the semiannual French Fry Evaluation at McDonald’s Corporation, where the company’s three main spud suppliers — McCain foods, J.R. Simplot and Lamb Weston — competed before 15 tasters. Eyes were closed. There was sniffing. Munching, and, yes, spitting. The winner? Lamb Weston, from American Falls, Idaho. — Glenn Collins

headline: Tribeca: Juliette Binoche on Acting From Insecurity
text: In “Elles,” Juliette Binoche stars as a work-obsessed, discontented journalist. Her bourgeois life, presented mostly in a pristine Paris apartment and cloaked in muted shades of whites and grays, contrasts sharply with those of the subjects of her latest article, two female students who also work as prostitutes. Ms. Binoche’s character, Anne, is at first dismissive and shocked by their choices, but over the course of the film, which screens at the Tribeca Film Festival on Wednesday afternoon and opens in select theaters on Friday, finds they have fears, and desires, in common.
