headline: Plaque Honoring Michael Landon Is Returned to Park
text: You don’t have to share the Cartwright family’s spirit of frontier justice to appreciate the return of a plaque honoring the “Bonanza” star Michael Landon to a park in Collingswood, N.J., where the actor grew up, months after it was removed under unclear circumstances.

headline: On an Urban Heat Island, Zippy Red Oaks
text: Red oak seedlings in Central Park grow up to eight times faster than their cousins cultivated outside the city, probably because of the urban “heat island” effect, Columbia University researchers report.

headline: Dow Corn, Resistant to a Weed Killer, Runs Into Opposition
text: To Jody Herr, it was a telltale sign that one of his tomato fields had been poisoned by 2,4-D, the powerful herbicide that was an ingredient in Agent Orange, the Vietnam War defoliant.

headline: Childhood Obesity Leads to Unnecessary Surgeries
text: How does a 175-pound 10-year-old sound? Or a 200-pound 6-year-old? Or, far worse, a morbidly obese 6-year-old having his gallbladder removed because a high fat diet has caused it to malfunction and become a source of pain?

headline: Leading Off: N.B.A. Dips Into Head Shot Outrage
text: When the N.B.A.’s rather rusty wheels of justice finally kicked into gear and delivered a seven-game suspension to the Lakers’ Metta World Peace for his flying elbow K.O. of the Thunder’s James Harden, it was not a natural moment for the league. It could have simply borrowed a script from the N.H.L., handed down a pitifully light punishment, donned airport-strength ear protectors to drown out the outrage and moved on with its denial that concussions are any big deal. Instead, the N.B.A. took the time to explain all the complicating factors to its rusty wheel — hey, you try to make sense of the former Ron Artest with a piece of machinery — and came up with a suspension long enough to quell most outrage and yet wimpy enough to avoid truly upsetting the order of things.

headline: For the Well Heeled, the $40,000 Rental
text: For travelers more accustomed to stratospheric thread counts than high fill-power sleeping bags, upscale options are still available. The travel service Lloyd and Townsend Rose rents high-end homes and, well, castles throughout Britain at rates starting at roughly £25,000 (about $39,500) a week.

headline: Short of Cash? Rent a Lawn
text: ANY traveler to London this summer has no doubt scoured the listings of where to stay, where to eat and how to get around. But one resource that is probably overlooked is Londoners themselves, who during this time of high traffic will continue to rent out their resources to those on a budget strict enough that splurging for a night at a hotel — even if available — would be out of the question.

headline: Want to Go to the Olympics? Act Now
text: THERE may be less than 100 days until the opening ceremony of the London Olympics, but procrastinators can still get to the Games, which run July 27 to Aug. 12, if they’re willing to spend a little more money, be flexible when it comes to flight times and crowds, and don’t wait a moment longer.

headline: Panetta Urges Brazil to Buy Fighter Jets From Boeing
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pushed Brazil on Wednesday to buy $4 billion worth of Boeing-made Super Hornet fighter jets, saying the prospective sale reflected how important Brazil was to the United States.

headline: Pixar Adds New Movie to Slate
text: LAS VEGAS — If the pressure is on Pixar to prove that its creative spark remains intact after the critical crash that was “Cars 2,” then the Disney-owned animation studio appears to be rising to the challenge. In a presentation to theater owners here on Monday, John Lasseter, Pixar’s chief creative officer (and the director of “Cars 2”), said the studio has added a movie about the Mexican holiday Día de los Muertos to its slate. The film, which does not yet have a title or a release date, will be directed by Lee Unkrich, who won an Oscar for “Toy Story 3.”

headline: The Return of the Videophone (Again)

headline: A Place for Old Chickens, Outside the Pot
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Hindus regard the chicken as a vessel for evil spirits. The Chinese cook them to honor village deities. But here, chickens are a symbol of urban nirvana, their coops backyard shrines to a locavore movement that has city dwellers moving ever closer to their food. And the increasingly intimate relationships have led some bird owners to make plans for their chickens’ unproductive years. Hence a budding phenomenon: urban chicken retirement.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Comfortable with New Microsoft Office Features
text: Upgrading to a new version of Microsoft Office — and then figuring out where all your favorite commands, menus and tools are in the new version — is something many users face every few years. To help ease Office workers into the latest edition, Microsoft provides several tutorials for the Mac OS X and Windows versions of the programs in the suite, which includes Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

text: Honda and Acura top the list of car brands that best retain their value over time, according to an annual ranking from the automotive site Edmunds.com.

headline: British Police Say Madeleine McCann May Still Be Alive
text: LONDON — Investigators with Britain’s largest police force said on Wednesday that they believed that Madeleine McCann, the British toddler who vanished while on vacation with her parents in Portugal, could still be alive. Madeline’s story reverberated across the globe, and as the years have passed most have given up hope of ever finding her.

headline: Champagne Headphones on a Beer Budget
text: After a steady diet of earbuds – good earbuds – I wasn’t expecting to hear much improvement from a $100 pair of over-the-ear headphones. But I was in for sonic equivalent of a $14.95 all-you-can eat buffet — but one serving lobster, caviar and truffles. From the first note, the lush fidelity of the Grado SR80i headphones was a delightful shock.

headline: Beach Boys Release New Single
text: The reunited Beach Boys released their first new single in decades on Wednesday, making it available for purchase on major digital services like iTunes and Amazon.  The song, “That’s Why God Made the Radio,” sounds as if it could have been written in the 1960s. It is a slow romantic ode to pop radio, showing off the group’s famous five-part harmonies and syrupy sentiments.  The single is the first taste fans are getting of a new studio album by the same name, which is scheduled for release on June 5 by Capitol/EMI records.  The album, which has 11 new songs, marks the first time in decades the two original leaders of the seminal band, Brian Wilson and Mike Love, have put aside their acrimony to work together. Three other early members – Al Jardine, David Marks and Bruce Johnston – are also onboard.  The reconstituted band started a 50th Anniversary tour this week in Tucson and plans to play the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival this weekend.  The Beach Boys also released an online video on Wednesday describing the making of the single.

headline: Make Way for Ducks
text: They quack; they have feathers; they exude Robert McCloskey wholesomeness. They eat Wonder bread even though it’s evidently as bad for them as it is for young children. What’s not to like about ducklings?

headline: A Web Retailer Buys the Perfect Domain Name. Then Comes a Letdown.
text: Founded in 1929 by Sol Braverman, the Newark Nut Company began selling bulk nuts and dried fruit in an open-air market on Newark’s Mulberry Street. The business grew and then faded, and by 2002, it was being operated out of a mall in Newark’s demoralized downtown by two of Mr. Braverman’s sons. In 2003, as explained in last week’s Conversation column, a grandson, Jeffrey Braverman, joined the business and moved the company’s focus to the Web.

headline: Preparing to Look Good on Draft Night
text: The experts gathered around a conference table, sipped water and debated Dontari Poe, the oversize defensive tackle from Memphis and a likely first-round pick in the 2012 N.F.L. draft. In this room, early in draft week, his size was indeed an issue, but not his athleticism, smarts or speed.

headline: Was It a Mistake to Pay Lots of Money for a Clean Domain Name?
text: In a just-published case study, we recount a complicated decision facing the Newark Nut Company, a family-owned retailer based in Cranford, N.J.

headline: London Politics for $500 | Who is Siobhan Benita?
text: On a cold, wet Thursday in a depressing part of southeast London a kindly man handed out flyers that read: “Siobhan for mayor.” Nearby, Siobhan Benita, going on four hours of sleep, stood a few feet away talking to a potential voter. Until someone from the team announced that they were going to miss their next appointment at a public library facing closure, and off they rushed to catch the train. Soon, it would absolutely pour with rain.

headline: A Dancer Sees His Art Differently From a Russian Stage

headline: Met’s ‘Ring’ Machine Finishes the Spin Cycle
text: Attention! “Ring” alert from the Met! Now as Valhalla goes up in flames, the heads on white marble statues of the gods no longer go “pop” and explode. Instead, they crumble into pieces, and I think we can all agree that this is a more dignified way to suggest the twilight of the gods.

headline: Should Your Dog Be Watching TV?
text: Plenty of things will grab a dog’s attention: squirrels, tennis balls, funny smells, other dogs. But a TV channel?

headline: P.S.A. Testing Continues in Older Men
text: Men over age 75 and their doctors are largely ignoring changing medical guidelines for prostate cancer screening, a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association has found.

headline: Raising Glasses to Celebrate the Toast
text: Oscar Eustis was among the speakers Tuesday night at Brasserie Pushkin, the new Russian restaurant on West 57th Street, for a dinner celebrating the art of the toast. He didn’t know the toast he would be giving; it would be handed to him some time before the spotlight hit. But he wasn’t nervous. He’d had some practice at this sort of thing.

headline: The Fall of New Orleans
text: New Orleans was the jewel of the Confederacy. In addition to being the South’s largest city, it boasted considerable industry that produced ironclads, munitions and uniforms, among other items. More important, it controlled access to the Mississippi River from the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Lloyd Live: Blankfein Takes to the Airwaves
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein can be an elusive public personality. The Goldman Sachs chief does not do many interviews, save for the odd P.S.A. and foray into his musical tastes.

headline: Punch Brothers Talk About Music, the Lower East Side and Greg Maddux
text: It has always been hard to pigeonhole Punch Brothers.  They are an all-star bluegrass band, five virtuosos led by Chris Thile, the mercurial mandolin player, but their songs smash the three-chord harmonies and blazing march rhythm of bluegrass.

text: POP-UPS

headline: A Broadway Baby With Experience
text: TELEVISION viewers may know Nicole Ari Parker as the lawyer Teri on the Showtime series “Soul Food,” which ran for five seasons in the early 2000s, or perhaps from the short-lived “Deep End,” which ABC broadcast briefly in 2010. But on Broadway Ms. Parker is a neophyte. And she’s taken on quite a challenge, playing one of the most famous female characters in the theater — one that powerhouse actresses from Jessica Tandy to Cate Blanchett have performed — Tennessee Williams’s fragile, fading Southern belle Blanche DuBois.

headline: Occupy Student Debt Plans to Protest $1 Trillion Mark
text: Supporters of the Occupy Student Debt movement are planning several events on Wednesday to mark the moment when total student debt reaches $1 trillion, Inside Higher Ed reported.

headline: What Do Springtime Polls Tell Us About the General Election?
text: Since Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign, essentially ending the Republican primary contest, the starting positions for the general election have taken shape. About 10 national polls have been released: President Obama leads Mitt Romney 47.7 percent to 43.7 percent, according to the RealClearPolitics average of recent surveys.

headline: Whither the Ultrabook?
text: At January’s Consumer Electronics Show, one of the largest tech conventions, computer makers were relentlessly showcasing their ultrabooks — thin and lightweight laptops similar to Apple’s MacBook Air. Intel had at least a dozen on display in its booth. Three months later, you’d be lucky to even see an ultrabook in the wild.

headline: V.C.U. Turns to Steven Holl Architects for New Arts Center
text: Virginia Commonwealth University has long been one of the leading public university graduate arts and design programs in the country. Now it also wants to be a cultural destination for audiences and performers. The university on Wednesday unveiled the design for a new $32 million Institute for Contemporary Art, designed by Steven Holl and Chris McVoy of Steven Holl Architects. Calling the 38,000-square-foot building “part exhibition and performance space, part lab and incubator,” the university said the institute will feature a series of flexible programming spaces for visual art, theater, music, dance and film.There will be an auditorium with more than 240 seats, a sculpture garden, classrooms and a cafe.
