text: President Obama spoke to Tom Donilon, his national security adviser, while on Air Force One en route to the University of Iowa in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

headline: Israel’s Big Day, Under Sun and Cloud
text: JERUSALEM — The paradox that is Israel — wealthy, dynamic and safe, yet mistrusted, condemned and nervous — was on full display on Wednesday as the country mourned its fallen soldiers and began celebrating its 64th Independence Day.

headline: Cuomo Applauds Intensified Campaign to Ticket Distracted Drivers
text: For a driver in New York State, it’s a good week to put away the cellphone. That’s the objective behind Operation Hang Up, a statewide enforcement campaign targeting distracted drivers that began Monday and is scheduled to continue through April 29.

headline: An Advance Toward the Front Lines for Female Marines
text: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, James Dao wrote about the policy changes that will move female Marines closer to combat roles. He interviewed Gen. James F. Amos, the Marine Corps commandant, on the changes to policy, a subject first covered by The Marine Corps Times. Here are some of the new policies and initiatives:

headline: Supreme Court Argument Transcript: Arizona v. United States
text: On April 25, 2012, the Supreme Court heard more than an hour’s worth of arguments over several provisions of Arizona’s aggressive 2010 immigration law.

headline: ‘What Were You Thinking?’ For Couples, New Source of Online Friction
text: The more than 43,000 Twitter followers of Rosanne Cash, the singer and daughter of Johnny Cash, have come to expect her tart commentary on married life with her husband, John Leventhal, a Grammy-winning musician.

headline: Study Points to Roles for Industry and Organics in Agriculture
text: A paper in this week’s issue of Nature reinforces the argument that a hybrid path in agriculture — incorporating both industrial-style production and organic practices where they make sense — gives the best chance of feeding some 9 billion people by midcentury with the fewest regrets.

headline: Neuberger Museum Gets a New Director
text: Paola Morsiani, the curator of contemporary art at the Cleveland Museum of Art, has been appointed the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art of the State University of New York at Purchase, Thomas J. Schwartz, the president of the college, announced Wednesday. Ms. Morsiani, 50, will become the seventh director of the nation’s 10th largest university art museum, which has a collection of over 8,000 works in all media.

headline: TimesCast | Myanmar’s Hidden Islands
text: Myanmar’s tropical islands could become a prime tourist destination, if the government allows.

headline: A Curious Tooth Collection
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: Consumer Agency Looking Into Mandatory Arbitration
text: You may not know it, but the fine print in the rules governing use of your credit card and your checking account probably limits your right to sue in court if you have a dispute with the company providing the service. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said Tuesday that it is seeking information about that language in agreements for financial products and services.

headline: Were Those Boos Really for Reyes?
text: Jose Reyes’s first game in Citi Field as a member of the Marlins on Tuesday night elicited a lot of emotions. Some fans serenaded him with “Jose! Jose! Jose! Jose!” chants, while others booed him over the course of the game.

headline: New Diplomas Will Not Lower Standards, Regents Chancellor Says
text: Merryl Tisch, chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, made the case on WNYC on Wednesday that a proposed career and technical high school diploma would not be easier to obtain than the current Regents diploma. And, yes, she took questions about the current outcry over faulty state math and English exams. Listen to her interview on "The Brian Lehrer Show."

headline: Hedge Fund Managers See Tough Year for Industry
text: Hedge fund managers are predicting a tough year for the sector in 2012.

headline: At Fort Defiance, Saluting a Drinks Pioneer
text: Today’s history-minded mixologists follow various guiding lights from the past. Some bow at the altar of the 19th-century bartender Jerry Thomas, the so-called “father of American mixology.” Others look to Harry Johnson, a leading barman ofthe late 1800s.

headline: In London, Films About Palestinians
text: Casting a wide net over the topic of Palestine, the 2012 London Palestine Film Festival kicked off last week, presenting  contemporary comedic and dramatic films, a 1974 Susan Sontag documentary, and video installations.

headline: Brother of Fallen Chinese Politician Resigns Lucrative Business Role
text: BEIJING — The elder brother of Bo Xilai, the Politburo member now at the center of a huge political scandal involving murder and a potential cover-up, resigned Wednesday as executive director and vice chairman at Everbright International, a division of a giant state-owned Chinese conglomerate.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Said to Shed M.&A. Business
text: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland will spin off its mergers and acquisitions business by early next year, as the nationalized British bank continues to cut back on its investment banking unit, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: A New Leader, and Maybe Direction, for ‘Smash’
text: In a signal that NBC and the show’s producers may believe the future of “Smash” lies more in its soap opera elements than its inside look at the creation of a Broadway musical, the new guiding creative hand on the series is going to be Joshua Safran, an executive producer of the glossy CW soap “Gossip Girl.” NBC confirmed Wednesday that Mr. Safran is the choice to replace Theresa Rebeck as the hands-on executive producer – also known as show runner – of the second season of “Smash.”

headline: Invoking Ricky Ricardo, NuvoTv Aims at the ‘Bicultural Latino’
text: A popular figure from the early days of television was conjured up Tuesday night for an upfront presentation to help a cable channel sell commercial time.

headline: Kids Draw the News | Send Pictures
text: City Room has begun a new feature called Kids Draw the News, in which it asks students to submit their renderings of a current event. Today’s dramatic (though controversial) assignment: The spectacular brawl in the Tap Room of the New York Athletic Club.

headline: High Steaks | Beef Club in Paris
text: The name Beef Club may conjure images of bodybuilders or of a gay bar (or even a bar for bodybuilders), but in fact it should be taken at face value. Beef Club is an Anglo-style steakhouse, newly opened in Paris by Romée de Goriainoff, Pierre-Charles Cros and Olivier Bon, the trio behind the Experimental Cocktail Club and Nicolas Chevalier. (An Experimental Cocktail Club is set to open in New York, and they hope to expand to cities like Shanghai and Tokyo.)

headline: How About a Little Smartness Training?
text: In last weekend’s special issue devoted to mental health, Dan Hurley wrote about a study that has rocked the world of intelligence research. Apparently, a certain kind of working-memory training — done 15 to 25 minutes a day, five days a week — can increase what’s known as our fluid intelligence (reasoning, problem-solving, learning) in as few as four weeks. The regimen isn’t easy (though neither is bodily exercise for those new to it), but it’s tantalizing to think that this sort of mental workout can actually make us smarter. Try it out yourself here, with a version of the training that was used in the study. (You don’t need to download anything, but you may be prompted to restart your browser in 32-bit mode.)

headline: Amylin and Icahn Make Nice, Sending Shares Up
text: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has withdrawn his lawsuit against Amylin Pharmaceuticals, helping propel the diabetes drug maker’s shares up more than 3.5 percent.

headline: Photo Replay: April 25
text: Today in sports the 50-meter freestyle Olympic qualifier took place in Rio de Janeiro and Udinese fans showed their dedication in an Italian Serie A soccer match with Inter Milan.

headline: Gates Joins 2 From Bush Administration in Consulting Firm
text: Together again. Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, after a detour through the Obama administration, announced Wednesday that he was joining former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Stephen J. Hadley, a former national security adviser, in their strategic consulting firm. The move reunites the Bush-era foreign policy team.

headline: An Eric Ripert Dinner Fetches $200,000
text: Nicholas D. Lowry, the president of Swann Auction Galleries, often starts the bidding with a bottle of Herradura Tequila that might cost $50. He uses it to get the crowd going, and the item fetches far more than it’s worth.

headline: Petition Drive Challenges Standardized Testing
text: Critics of high stakes standardized tests have started an Internet campaign to petition for an overhaul of mandated testing.

headline: Double-Dip Recession in Britain
text: LONDON — Britain has fallen into its first double-dip recession since the 1970s, according to official figures released Wednesday, a development that raised more questions about whether government belt-tightening in Europe has gone too far.

headline: These Days Are Numbered: Eight Summer Math Ideas
text: The school year is starting to wind down in many places in the country, and it brings worries about so-called summer slide – the documented decline in student skills during the long summer break.

headline: Northwestern Women Fall to Florida
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — After a furious finish, the Northwestern women’s lacrosse team fell short once again. The result was a loud Florida celebration on the Wildcats’ home field, a mob of blue jerseys under airborne lacrosse sticks in front of a silent crowd of more than 1,500.

headline: At House Hearing, Schapiro Says Cost Analyses Are Slowing S.E.C.’s Work
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans on a House Financial Services subcommittee questioned on Wednesday whether the Securities and Exchange Commission had strengthened the cost-benefit analyses it conducts on newly proposed regulations.

headline: The Rangers’ Biggest Challenge? Face-Offs
text: 4:52 p.m. | Updated The Rangers took extra face-off practice Wednesday ahead of Thursday’s Game 7 versus Ottawa, and for good reason – they are getting killed on draws.

headline: For 2nd Week, Lionel Richie Tops the Charts
text: On the pop charts this week, Lionel Richie holds at No. 1, Maroon 5 has a fast-selling download, and two One Directions compete.

headline: Companies Raise Concerns Over Google Drive’s Privacy Protections
text: 5:50 p.m. | Updated Added more explanation from Google about the terms of service agreement.

headline: Banks Form Alliances to Buy A.I.G. Assets
text: Big banks, gearing up for a bidding war on assets tied to the collapse of the American International Group, have created unlikely alliances to mount offers for what was once viewed as the dregs of Wall Street.

headline: The Tenderness of Simmered Chicken
text: As much as I like a good roast chicken, I have always had a soft spot for simmered and boiled chicken, from iconic meaty Mexican soups to down-home American chicken and dumplings, to the French poule-au-pot and beyond. What can I say? It’s about tenderness, succulence and broth.

headline: Give Lehman High a Chance, a Student Says
text: On the eve of a Panel for Educational Policy vote Thursday to presumably close 26 struggling schools, a student at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx argues that doing so would undermine the improvements being made under a new principal, make it difficult to maintain programs and courses in the reconstituted school, and affect seniors who won't be able to obtain recommendations from teachers with whom they have bonded.

headline: Boeing Lifts Forecast After a Strong Quarter
text: An increase in airplane deliveries helped the Boeing Company report stronger-than-expected earnings on Wednesday and signaled that the company was getting past the problems that slowed production of its new 787 Dreamliner and 747-8 jets.

headline: Suiting Up for the N.F.L. Draft
text: Inside the Joseph Abboud showroom in Manhattan, where Rachel Johnson, a stylist, selected clothes for Dontari Poe, an oversize defensive tackle, to wear to the draft.

headline: Some Rest for the Weary
text: As I lounged on the couch, all I could think was: If I don’t do my hamstring exercises, they will be so sore when I start back up. And my quads … they’re going to kill me after I do a shooting session.

headline: A Hearing and Rallies Over a Law in Arizona
text: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of chanting demonstrators filled the sidewalk in front of the Supreme Court on Wednesday, denouncing an Arizona immigration law that was under debate inside, saying it would spread fear among Latinos in the state.

headline: A Low-Key Anchor With High Expectations
text: IT’S an old question: what makes a real New Yorker? Pronouncing Houston Street correctly? Knowing who Dr. Zizmor is? Turning off Taxi TV as soon as the meter starts?

headline: Did Blankfein Snub Paulson?
text: On Wednesday morning on CNBC, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief of Goldman Sachs, made a rare on-camera appearance to defend the embattled firm from its detractors.

headline: Dogfights on Your iPhone
text: The invasion of apps on toys continues with this weeks release of Foam Fighters Pacific from WowWee ($9.99), a set of three-inch styrofoam gliders that you can suction cup under your iPhone’s outside camera. Align the wings with an on-screen template and the app’s augmented reality features superimpose a WWII dogfight over your living room.

headline: Celebrity Spats Thrive on Twitter
text: IT’S not every mother who airs family grievances online. But when Courtney Love heard rumors that Dave Grohl, the Foo Fighters frontman, had made advances on her 19-year-old daughter, Frances Bean Cobain, which Ms. Cobain and Mr. Grohl denied, she blasted him on Twitter.

headline: Times Reporters Discuss the N.F.L. Draft
text: Judy Battista, Mike Tanier and Connor Ennis of The Times join readers in a discussion about this year's college draft.

headline: Bernanke Responds
text: Ben Bernanke responds to my magazine piece; as I see it, in effect he declared that he has been assimilated by the Fed Borg:

headline: Talking About the N.F.L. Draft With Times Reporters
text: Judy Battista and Mike Tanier, who write about football for The New York Times, joined The Times’s pro football editor, Connor Ennis, who served as host, and a handful of readers in a Google Plus video hangout to talk about this week’s N.F.L. draft.

headline: TimesCast | Rupert Murdoch Testifies
text: April 25, 2012 — In London, Rupert Murdoch played down his political influence on the British government during judicial hearings tied to the phone hacking scandal.

headline: Women See Worrisome Shift in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Gokce, a soft-spoken 37-year-old mother of two, has lived on the run for 15 years, ever since her abusive husband tracked her down, broke down her door and shot her in the leg six times after she refused to return to him.

headline: Homes for $625,000
text: Properties in Idaho, Boston and Key West.

headline: What You Get for ... $625,000
text: BOISE, IDAHO

headline: Surpassing the Great American Consumer
text: Once upon a time, the world vied primarily for the attention (and dollars) of American consumers. Just a decade ago, they were responsible for nearly a quarter of the world’s economy.

headline: Fête Accompli | Chanel’s Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Leaving the Nest to Fly Solo
text: TWO years after the Council of Fashion Designers of America established an incubator program in the garment district, the first group of young designers to cohabit in its space has left the nest, so to speak. Some of them are bigger than when they started. Some are not. But most say they are a little wiser. Ten new designers will move in next month.

headline: Watson to Buy Actavis for $5.9 Billion
text: LONDON – Watson Pharmaceuticals agreed on Wednesday to buy the Swiss drug maker Actavis Group for as much as 4.5 billion euros ($5.9 billion), as the American company looks to expand its presence in overseas markets.

headline: Obama Sings for College Affordability
text: On Wednesday night, President Obama appeared on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” and participated in one of the show’s funnier features: slow-jamming the news. The president sang about the rising interest rates on Stafford loans, using a similar refrain he’d used earlier in the day at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

headline: South Sudan to Get Aid From China; No Oil Deal
text: BEIJING — China has welcomed the president of South Sudan and agreed to provide bank loans and humanitarian aid, but it has stopped short of moving forward on an oil pipeline, a sign of the delicate position Beijing finds itself in as the biggest energy investor in both the new nation of South Sudan and its bitter foe, Sudan.

headline: White House Returns Fire Over Claim About Big Tax Increases
text: The Obama administration on Wednesday fired back at an adviser to Mitt Romney who had asserted that the president’s economic plans would mean a huge tax increase for all Americans.

headline: House Hunting in ... Prague
text: THREE-BEDROOM PENTHOUSE IN OLD TOWN PRAGUE

headline: A Designer Penthouse in Prague’s Old Town
text: A three-bedroom penthouse designed by the noted Czech architect Eva Jiricna is listed at $1.6 million.

headline: Partners at Andreessen Horowitz Make Charity Pledge
text: The partners of venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz are not quite billionaires. But they are following the lead of Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Cuomo Says Talk of White House Bid Is Premature
text: ALBANY — Even Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo acknowledged that there was something familiar about the situation.

headline: Stone Links: The Sources of Ethical Authority
text: At the Religion and Ethics section of The Australian Broadcasting Corporation’s website, two philosophers use the quote, “If there is no God, everything is permitted,” commonly attributed to Dostoevsky, as a touchstone for considering whether there is an ultimate source of ethical authority.

headline: Lawmakers Support Shifting Financial Oversight
text: Financial firms will face new regulatory scrutiny under legislation unveiled on Wednesday.

headline: Scene City: Time Magazine Toasts Its Top 100 Influencers
text: Time magazine honored 100 people that it named the most influential, among them Hillary Rodham Clinton, Rihanna, Stephen Colbert and others.

headline: American Austerity
text: With all the focus on Europe’s sudden discovery that austerity doesn’t work, we shouldn’t lose sight of just how much de facto austerity we’ve done on this side of the Atlantic. Here’s a comparison of changes in government employment (federal, state, and local) during the first four years of three presidents who came to office amid a troubled economy:

headline: A Lethal Beacon for Migrating Birds
text: On the morning of Sept. 11, 1948, “a good number of dead, dying and exhausted birds” were found at the base of the WBAL radio tower in Baltimore, in what was then viewed as a new and unusual phenomenon. Ever since communication towers began popping up in the United States in the 1940s and 50s, bird bodies have littered the fields below them, especially during migration season.

headline: $18 Million Gift for Theater at Yale
text: The Yale School of Drama and Yale Repertory Theater announced on Wednesday that they had received an $18 million gift — the largest in their history — to finance the creation of new plays and musicals through commissions to writers, developmental workshops and productions at both Yale Rep and other theaters that stage the work.

headline: Influential, and All in One Room
text: HALFWAY through the Time 100 party on Tuesday night, Stephen Colbert summed up the crowd.

headline: Paul Rudd and Emma Stone to Star in Live Reading of ‘The Apartment’
text: Should Paul Rudd ever need a place to stay in New York, one imagines there would be numerous volunteers to offer him lodging. In the meantime, Mr. Rudd will be crashing the role originally played by Jack Lemmon in a reading of the script for the 1960 Billy Wilder comedy “The Apartment,” alongside Emma Stone, who’ll be substituting for that film’s original co-star, Shirley MacLaine.

headline: Shylock’s Master Class on Rage
text: Just wait till they get angry.

headline: 3 to Pay $32 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges of Insider Trading
text: A deal lawyer, a trader and their middleman who carried out an insider trading scheme that lasted decades and included the use of code names and disposable cellphones settled charges Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $32 million.

headline: Humor Found Online, Posted Onstage
text: Usually it’s harder to be funny in writing than in speech. After all, with naked text you don’t have the helpful tools of timing, vocal intonation, facial expression, gestures or props.

headline: Google Makes Push Into E-Commerce With New Online Store
text: In a move it tried — and abandoned — once before, Google began selling a smartphone directly to consumers through a new online store on Tuesday.

headline: Discord on the Hill Extends to Domestic Violence Law
text: The latest ugly (and seemingly needless) partisan fight on Capitol Hill concerns a measure designed to prevent domestic violence against women.

headline: It’s an Absurd World, So Send in the Clowns
text: IN a new video chronicling a day in their lives, the artists Anthony Aziz and Sammy Cucher — life partners and collaborators since 1992 — emerge from the subway in Long Island City, Queens. They walk to their studio, where they review photographs tacked to a wall and video footage they shot in 2009 while traveling through Israel, Lebanon and the Balkans. The images are complemented by a relentless soundtrack of NPR reports on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the controversy over a proposed Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan, blended with snatches of Middle Eastern folk music and military drumbeats.

headline: ‘Aziz + Cucher: Some People’
text: A look at the new exhibition at the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Fast-Forward TV and 3-D Printer Gallery
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

headline: Life, Interrupted | Visiting Hours
text: Suleika Jaouad is in the hospital for a bone marrow transplant and has been isolated in her room for 24 days.

headline: Outfitting the ‘Veep’
text: WHEN Ernesto Martinez, the lead costume designer for the new HBO series “Veep,” started to think about how to dress the show’s star, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, for her role as the country’s first female vice president, he quickly decided that inspiration would have to come from somewhere other than the current office holders in the nation’s capital.

headline: TimesCast | Immigration at Highest Court
text: April 25, 2012 — The Supreme Court hears arguments regarding Arizona’s controversial immigration law.

headline: Face Time | Olivia Wilde
text: For me, the highlight of the Tribeca Film Festival was making up the lovely Olivia Wilde for the premiere of the documentary she produced, “Baseball in the Time of Cholera.” It follows the effects of a cholera outbreak on a young Haitian athlete named Joseph and the scandal surrounding the United Nations’s involvement in the affair. It was a special evening for her because it’s a film she is very proud of. You may have caught a glimpse of her looking gorgeous in Revlon’s latest ads. Between blush and mascara, Wilde and I chatted about what it’s like to be a global brand ambassador for Revlon and much more.

headline: Viacom Signs a New Lease to Expand in Times Sq.
text: Viacom Inc., the entertainment conglomerate that owns MTV, Comedy Central, Nickelodeon and Paramount Pictures, is expanding its presence in Times Square with one of the largest leases signed in New York City.

headline: For Dynamo, a Stunning Comeback
text: Dynamo Moscow beat Avangard Omsk, 1-0, Wednesday in Game 7 of the K.H.L.’s Gagarin Cup final, completing a comeback from a 3-1 series deficit and winning the club’s ninth Russian or Soviet domestic championship.

headline: Yankees Lose Pineda for Season, and Hughes Adds to Worries
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — It was a dreary day for the Yankees’ pitching rotation Wednesday, as news about Michael Pineda’s season-ending injury was followed by a bad outing from one of the pitchers the Yankees hope can make up for Pineda’s loss.

headline: An All-Star Cast Makes One Big Happy Family
text: Understatement, restraint and an implicit trust that the show’s virtues speak for themselves: those qualities describe the lavish concert performance of “The Sound of Music,” on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall. As the old slogan puts it, there was “no muss, no fuss, no bother.”

headline: The Rise of Designer Children’s Lines
text: In the last year or two, Lanvin, Gucci, Stella McCartney and Marni have entered the childrens’ clothing market.

headline: Glass Houses in the Countryside
text: In England, a modernist villa and a guest pavilion on a 23-acre estate.

headline: In the British Countryside, a Well-Packaged Life
text: HORSMONDEN, England

headline: Debt Unforgiveness
text: At the University of North Carolina yesterday, President Obama blasted a congresswoman who said she has “very little tolerance” for students who graduate with debt. He did not name her, but many people in North Carolina knew (or could have guessed) that he was talking about Virginia Foxx, the snarling Republican from the northwest corner of the state, whose lack of tolerance in many areas is not a secret.

headline: On the Road With the Proper Gear
text: Last month, I was sitting in a club lounge in Newark Liberty International Airport when I noticed a man in the seat across from me with this technological array in front of him:

headline: Sundance  Festival Moves to London
text: After more than three decades of showcasing independent film in Park City, Utah, the Sundance Film Festival will for the first time take place in London under the moniker Sundance London.

headline: That Dress Is So Preschool
text: ONE morning in the fall of 1956, in a salon at 12 East 57th Street, the eminent American couturier Charles James presented his first children’s-wear line to a group of editors that included Diana Vreeland. Sherry and cookies were served, and with a sense of camp that preceded Marc Jacobs by 50 years, Mr. James had ladies in nurses’ uniforms bring out the tiny garments.

headline: New Design From the Milan Furniture Fair
text: Highlights from the fair, where pieces made of industrial waste contrasted with deep-cushioned sofas that provide infantile comfort.

headline: ‘These Seven Sicknesses’ Returns to the Flea Theater
text: The Flea Theater will remount its production of “These Seven Sicknesses,” a five-hour, streamlined adaptation of seven Sophocles plays, from June 6 through July 1 at its TriBeCa space, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: In Court, Easterling Suicide Is the Focus
text: The suicide last week of Ray Easterling, a player with the Atlanta Falcons in the 1970s who was being treated for dementia, took center stage in court on Wednesday.

headline: Even on a Retro Highway, It’s Best to Watch the Road Ahead
text: The singer Maria Minerva — tall, imposing, underselling herself in a Boy London T-shirt and black leggings — stood behind, next to, around and in front of two laptops and a small keyboard. She seemed to have no fixed relationship to her gear, and her act didn’t involve much articulated, worked-out body language; when she wasn’t playing melodies on the keyboard, she sang and danced to hazy, anachronistic electro beats from her laptop, projecting absent-mindedness as if she were alone in her bedroom.

headline: 10 Questions for Timothy F. Geithner
text: The attacks on Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner that marked the early part of the Obama administration have died down somewhat as the economy has recovered. But struggles in Europe have created new economic challenges as Mr. Geithner serves out the remaining months of Mr. Obama’s first term, as the president implored him to. After touring a manufacturing plant in Clackamas, Ore., Mr. Geithner sat down Wednesday with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC to discuss the still fragile recovery and the quickening economic debate in the presidential campaign.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Crisis Mirrors Legal Industry’s Woes
text: The crisis confronting the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has stunned the legal profession. About 70 of Dewey’s 300 partners have left since January after their salaries were slashed because of the firm’s weak financial performance.

headline: For Marlboro Musicians, at Home or on Tour, Performance Is in the Details
text: Some composers write cheery music while their personal lives are in disarray. Others channel their suffering into angst-ridden compositions, as Bartok did in his String Quartet No. 6. Introducing the piece before a performance by Musicians From Marlboro on Tuesday evening the cellist Marcy Rosen detailed the genesis of the work, written in 1939, shortly before Bartok left his native Hungary and emigrated to America.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, the Philippines, Portugal and Washington.

headline: Banged-Up Rangers Hope to Feel Better After Game 7
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — N.H.L. players often say the goal during the early rounds of the Stanley Cup playoffs is to survive and advance. Facing a Game 7 on Thursday night against the Ottawa Senators, the Rangers are looking to do the same — although not in that order.

headline: Tranquillity Replaces Trash Talk and Heels
text: In the first episode of “Leave It to Niecy,” a reality show about the actress and comedian Niecy Nash, Ms. Nash is determined to prove to her children that she can orchestrate family fun. Dominic, the oldest child and only boy, tries to tell her that their family isn’t like others that have lived with cameras.

headline: Entwine
text: WITH its shabby-chic décor and unassuming entrance, Entwine looks like any other neighborhood wine bar in the West Village (which it is). But on Wednesday nights, it has becomes an unlikely place to spot celebrities and listen to musicians like Courtney Love and Joseph Arthur try out new material.

headline: Please, Don’t Feed the Artist
text: ON most days, you can hear Dawn Kasper’s installation at the Whitney Biennial before you see it. Bessie Smith or the Beatles or an episode of “The Young Ones,” a British sitcom from the ’80s, might be playing scratchily on one of her many devices, spilling out into an adjacent gallery and accompanied by a throaty guffaw from the artist, whom you might then come upon sitting cross-legged on a mattress, wearing a Hawaiian shirt, eating a sandwich and entertaining a few strangers.

headline: The Nobility, Behaving Not So Nobly
text: At first it seemed odd that the Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival would want to close its 2012 iteration with an evening of one-act operas that proudly luxuriate in the spirit of the Renaissance. But there are worse periods to explore when looking for innovative composition. Even a cursory listen to one of Gesualdo’s madrigals, say, can convince anyone that few works composed since then have been so thorny and searching.

headline: Another Spanish Soccer Titan Is Toppled by Penalty Kicks
text: MADRID — Penalty kicks are supposed to be near certainties for professional soccer players, and to outsiders, the question is how could they not be? A motionless ball, only 12 yards from the goal with no one but the hapless goalkeeper to beat, and he must stay on his line until the ball is kicked. For players like Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, wizards who score from impossible angles, success from the spot seems as if it should be virtually guaranteed.

headline: Madeleine Albright: By the Book
text: What book is on your night stand now?

headline: Serious About a New Language? Begin With Lesson 1
text: I’ve tried learning Italian through books, CDs, DVDs, tapes, and apps with phrase books and translation technology. Nothing stuck.

headline: The Antisocial Effects of Social Media
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Inventor Who Put Frozen Peas on Our Tables
text: Mark Kurlansky’s work includes “Salt,” a book about salt, and “Cod: a Biography of the Fish that Changed the World.” He specializes in the mix of showmanship and small-bore scrutiny that gives minor-sounding material the patina of great relevance. But his new book, “Birdseye,” asks what sounds, even for Mr. Kurlansky, like a feebly rhetorical question: “Ever wonder how those frozen peas and carrots and dinner entrees in your freezer came to be there?” The very probable answer: no, you have not.

headline: Anti-Semitism in Hungary
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Camera Doesn’t Take Pictures. It Describes Them.
text: The “Descriptive Camera” doesn’t work like your normal point-and-shoot camera. Instead, this contraption prints out a description of the photo you take, rather than an image itself.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: New tellings of old standbys mark the month, as two debut novelists take on bridal shenanigans while another reimagines teenage werewolves. Then there’s the story of an early feminist who fights the power in an antiquated setting.

headline: Ousted Chinese Leader Is Said to Have Spied on Other Top Officials
text: BEIJING — When Hu Jintao, China’s top leader, picked up the telephone last August to talk to a senior anticorruption official visiting Chongqing, special devices detected that he was being wiretapped — by local officials in that southwestern metropolis.

headline: Bird Flu Research Risks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sex Abuse in the Military
text: To the Editor:

headline: Music Film Is Delayed by Fees for Songs
text: In the 1960s many of the hits coming out of Los Angeles under the names of the Beach Boys, Sonny & Cher, the Mamas and the Papas, the Monkees and other top pop acts were actually recorded by an elite but largely anonymous corps of studio musicians nicknamed the Wrecking Crew. To gain them some belated public recognition Denny Tedesco, a son of one of the most prolific of those session players, spent more than 15 years making a documentary about the ensemble.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Names a New Executive Director
text: The trustees of Jazz at Lincoln Center have reached into the ranks of business leaders in the digital media sector for a new executive director, hiring Greg Scholl, a former NBC Universal executive with a background in digital music distribution, to manage the nonprofit arts institution.

headline: Wal-Mart in Mexico
text: To the Editor:

headline: 10 Questions for Timothy F. Geithner
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner sat down for an interview with John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC.

headline: A Decline in TV Watching
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Do Music’s Corporate Bosses Make? All Eyes on Live Nation
text: When the Warner Music Group was sold last year for $3.3 billion, observers of the music industry lost an important resource: as the last stand-alone, publicly traded major record company, Warner offered valuable insight into the economics of the business through its detailed quarterly accounting statements.

headline: Effects of Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defying Expectations With Dark Lyrics and a Dance Beat
text: Miike Snow, the Swedish band that started a three-night stand at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night, has given itself a tricky assignment: bringing angst and enigma into the artificial electronic paradise of electronic dance music. Its best-loved song, “Animal” — the crowd-pleasing finale on Tuesday — begins, “There was a time when my world was filled with darkness, darkness, darkness,” and doesn’t find much comfort from there.

headline: For Vevo, a ‘NewFront’ to Rival the ‘UpFronts’
text: The annual spring upfronts, when television peddles its wares to Madison Avenue, has a new wrinkle ahead of the 2012-13 season: media companies that specialize in online video and other digital delights are adding themselves to the lineup of presentations by broadcast and cable TV outlets.

headline: Federal Arts Endowment Sharply Cuts PBS Grants
text: The National Endowment for the Arts made sweeping cuts in its support of established PBS shows on Wednesday, and for the first time awarded significant grants to an array of gaming, mobile and Web-based projects.

headline: Pull Up a Broken Chair
text: The objects and installations created by Alex Mustonen and Daniel Arsham of Snarkitecture, a Brooklyn art and design studio, are almost always perplexing, purposely challenging people’s expectations. Their Cast Light, for instance, is a light bulb encased in a solid block of gypsum concrete that allows illumination to escape only through rough cuts in the material. And for “Dig,” an installation in New York last year at the Storefront for Art and Architecture, they conceived a cavelike interior, which Mr. Arsham chiseled out of solid blocks of expanded polystyrene in a series of performances.

headline: Senate Passes Plan to Give Postal Service Fiscal Relief
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday overcame opposition from several Republicans and passed legislation that would overhaul the financially ailing Postal Service, voting weeks before the agency plans to begin closing thousands of post offices and consolidating hundreds of processing centers to cut costs.

headline: China Slows Down, and Grows Up
text: MORE than half of Americans think China is already the world’s leading economy — an astonishing misperception, given that China’s gross domestic product is still less than half of America’s. As George Orwell once observed, “Whoever is winning at the moment will always seem to be invincible.” China has grown at a breakneck pace for so long that its aura of invincibility has grown to outsize proportions in the Western imagination.

headline: Week After Pulitzer Controversy, City Gives Writers a New Award
text: The literary world still has not recovered from its Pulitzer snub last week, when the absence of an award for fiction incensed publishers, authors and booksellers.

headline: Slumping Davis Dropped in Mets’ Order
text: Mets first baseman Ike Davis dragged a .131 batting average into their game Wednesday against the Miami Marlins, and after placing him seventh in the batting order, Manager Terry Collins said he would like to see Davis play his way out of his slump.

headline: Bernanke on What the Fed Can Do
text: It’s worth reading the entirety of this response from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, to a question I raised at a news conference on Wednesday. It’s a very clear statement of his views on what is probably the most important current question of economic policy: Why won’t the Fed do everything in its power to reduce unemployment?

headline: Devils’ Security Blanket, Brodeur Is Game 7 Veteran
text: NEWARK — Adam Henrique, the Devils’ superb rookie forward, was flipping through the channels Wednesday morning when hockey highlights compelled him to set down his remote control. Best he could tell, they were from a Game 7 — but from when, he wondered. The Devils were playing the Rangers, and the deciding goal came in overtime, on a wraparound by Stephane Matteau.

headline: Lionsgate Chief Marketing Officer Will Stay in Role ‘Long Term’
text: LOS ANGELES – Lionsgate said on Wednesday that Tim Palen would continue “long term” as chief marketing officer, ensuring continuity for that studio’s “Hunger Games” franchise and ending a power struggle over marketing duties resulting from its acquisition of Summit Entertainment.

headline: Expand Minds, Not the N.Y.U. Campus
text: FOR much of the last decade, universities across the country have been spending many millions on construction projects, building grand new campuses to draw more students.

headline: Ex-Morgan Stanley Executive Pleads Guilty to Violating Anticorruption Laws
text: One of Morgan Stanley’s former real estate executives in China pleaded guilty on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to violating federal anticorruption laws, as the American government continues to crack down on citizens who commit fraud and bribery abroad.

headline: A Move to Put Mustard in Food as Well as on It
text: COMMERCIALS for French’s mustard, the 108-year-old Reckitt Benckiser brand, have tended to feature backyard barbecues and ballparks where the mustard, unsurprisingly, is squirted on hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches.

headline: G.O.P. Questions Obama’s Travel Accounting
text: As President Obama returned to Washington on Wednesday after a two-day tour of crucial battleground states, the Republican National Committee requested an investigation into whether he was using taxpayer money for what amounted to campaign events.

headline: For Women at Games, Messages Are Mixed
text: LONDON

headline: Veterans and Brain Disease
text: He was a 27-year-old former Marine, struggling to adjust to civilian life after two tours in Iraq. Once an A student, he now found himself unable to remember conversations, dates and routine bits of daily life. He became irritable, snapped at his children and withdrew from his family. He and his wife began divorce proceedings.

headline: Oregon: Study of Coal Transport Sought
text: Gov. John Kitzhaber asked the federal government on Wednesday to conduct an environmental study of proposals to export coal to Asia from Montana and Wyoming through ports in Oregon and Washington. Mr. Kitzhaber did not take a position on the proposals, but his request, made in a letter to several federal agencies, echoed calls from opponents who say the proposals would clog the Northwest with new rail traffic, spread coal dust and increase global and local pollution.

headline: North Carolina: Budget Includes Money for Those Sterilized in Eugenics Effort
text: Gov. Bev Perdue called Wednesday for the state to spend $10.3 million to compensate victims of a eugenics program. Between 1929 and 1974, thousands of people were sterilized against their will under a state program intended to prevent poor, uneducated and sometimes mentally handicapped people from having children. The governor said the budget proposal would include $50,000 for each of the 132 verified victims of the program still living. The money would also support a state foundation that tries to find other former patients.

headline: Gov. Scott Rounds Up the Usual Zealots
text: It is outrageous that some of Florida’s most gun-friendly legislators are on a task force appointed by Gov. Rick Scott to examine the Stand Your Ground law at issue in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin. While Governor Scott has promised a full and fair review, his appointments raise serious doubts about that commitment.

headline: Idaho Airmail
text: Ray Arnold has been delivering mail for 34 years to a remote patch of Idaho in the northern Rocky Mountains, at a cost of $46,000 a year to the Postal Service.

headline: Neil Finds Three Ways to Torment Rangers
text: OTTAWA — Every facet of Chris Neil, the Ottawa right wing and Rangers nemesis, has been on display during the teams’ first-round playoff series.

headline: Rallies Will Kick Off Obama Re-election Bid
text: President Obama and the first lady will hold two big campaign rallies next week in what Mr. Obama’s political advisers are calling the official opening of his effort to win a second term in the White House.

headline: Equal Opportunity Panel Updates Hiring Policy
text: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on Wednesday approved an updated policy that makes it harder for employers to use background checks to systematically rule out hiring anyone with a criminal conviction.

headline: In Milan, Plush Reality
text: SOME of the most thought-provoking ideas at the International Furniture Fair in Milan, which ended on Sunday, issued not from the thousands of exhibition booths and off-site venues or even from the lips of the designers, pundits and producers who bring this stalwart city to life every April. They were written on the walls.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Is it worth spending money on flower arrangements for an open house?

headline: Espada’s Lawyer Calls Embezzlement Charges ‘Rotten to the Core’
text: A lawyer for former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. placed a giant poster of a red apple in front of a federal jury on Wednesday and said that the prosecution’s case claiming that her client embezzled money from a nonprofit health center was “rotten to the core.”

headline: Egypt’s Chaotic Election
text: Egypt’s democratic transition is in turmoil again as the country heads into next month’s crucial election for its first president since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. Egypt’s military-run government is running out of time to guarantee a fair and credible vote. Authorities need to finalize the list of candidates and decide where polling stations will be located, whether citizens must vote at specific stations, what rules the monitors must follow and how television airtime will be apportioned among candidates. And all this information needs to be widely publicized.

headline: Future of Rose Bowl Is Hot Issue for B.C.S.
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — There are few more enduring symbols in college football than the Rose Bowl, which, at the Bowl Championship Series meetings, has become emblematic of a sport caught between traditional pageantry and a lucrative future.

headline: Giant Rooftop Signs Move Closer to a Reality in Queens
text: The Manhattan skyline is world-renowned for the iconic profiles of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings. But the Queens skyline has long been an unremarkable, low-slung silhouette.

headline: A Database to Curb Abuse
text: The use and abuse in this country of powerful pain medications has spiraled upward in recent years. A report by New York’s attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, showed prescriptions in the state for oxycodone, the active ingredient in OxyContin, rose a remarkable 82 percent from 2007 to 2010, and nearly 17 percent for hydrocodone, the main ingredient in Vicodin.

headline: In Shift, Mexico to Review Wal-Mart Permits
text: MEXICO CITY — Two days after declaring it would not investigate bribery allegations tied to Wal-Mart’s rapid expansion in Mexico, the Mexican government said Wednesday that it would review permits related to the approval of stores and seek information from American authorities.

headline: With Wal-Mart Claims, Greater Attention on a Law
text: WASHINGTON — A decade ago, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars American companies from bribing officials overseas, was rarely enforced or discussed. Today, it strikes fear throughout the executive offices of companies with overseas operations, generating huge fees for law firms and large fines for the federal government.

headline: A Roof Over Your Head Isn’t Enough
text: EVERY week for the last three summers, I’ve kicked a footlong tube of curved white aluminum into a bush while hustling by with my lawn mower.

headline: Sales at Dinosaur Designs and Others
text: Resin housewares and glassware items will be up to 80 percent off at Dinosaur Designs, April 27 to 30 (the Insects Beetle jug, regularly $90, will be $20); 211 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), (212) 680-3523, dinosaurdesigns.com.

headline: Paris Designers Compose ‘Works’
text: Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, the Paris-based industrial designers, spent the last few years on their latest book, “Works,” which will be published by Phaidon next month to coincide with the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York.

headline: MoMA’s Latest Destination Is Mexico
text: The Museum of Modern Art Design Store’s new destination collection, introduced Thursday, highlights products made in Mexico. For the next few months, or while stock lasts, the shop will offer more than 150 items by 60 Mexican or Mexico-based designers — from tableware and decorative accessories to furniture.

headline: A Modernist Touch Outdoors
text: While you can furnish an entire home with modernist classics, that has not always been true for outdoor space. But Cassina, the Italian furniture manufacturer, has taken a step toward rectifying that situation with the introduction of pieces by Le Corbusier, Charlotte Perriand and Pierre Jeanneret, reworked for outdoor use.

headline: Expanding the Concept of Lighting
text: IN-EI, a new line of lamps created by the fashion designer Issey Miyake for the Italian lighting company Artemide, includes table, floor, ceiling and pendant lights. The collection, which is made from recycled PET plastic bottles, can be stored flat and expanded into three-dimensional forms without the use of internal frames.

headline: Lightly Seasoned Quarterback Is Still a Commodity
text: Andrew Luck has been hailed as a once-in-a-generation prospect because of his physical tools and mental dexterity. But Ryan Tannehill is perhaps the most intriguing player in this N.F.L. draft, in large part because of what he lacks: experience.

headline: The End of Newt
text: Well, the results of the latest wave of primaries are in. The people have spoken, decisively. All 10 of them.

headline: Chasing Fees, Banks Court Low-Income Customers
text: When David Wegner went looking for a checking account in January, he was peppered with offers for low-end financial products, including a prepaid debit card with numerous fees, a short-term emergency loan with steep charges, money wire services and check-cashing options.

headline: Republicans Urge Romney to Promote Positive Vision
text: Republicans have a message for Mitt Romney: it’s time to go positive.

headline: Mayor Vows to Go to Court to Fight Council’s Wage Bills
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, warning that the City Council’s efforts to raise the wages of some private-sector workers would drive away businesses, vowed on Wednesday to fight the Council in court.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 25, 2012

headline: Laker Cites ‘Passion,’ Not Anger, in Elbowing
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Peace? Not in the Lakers’ time.

headline: At Disney, It’s Tough to Find a Chief
text: LAS VEGAS — At a convention of movie theater owners here on Tuesday, Walt Disney Studios displayed plenty of fanfare, trotting out Johnny Depp to promote his 2013 remake of “The Lone Ranger” and hiring 11 bagpipe players to herald “Brave,” a film about a Scottish princess.

headline: After Recalls and Missteps, J.&J.’s New Chief Confronts Critical Challenges
text: Johnson & Johnson needs to rethink the way it brings drugs to market, expand its reach into global markets and rebuild consumer confidence by returning recalled brands to pharmacy shelves, the incoming chief executive, Alex Gorsky, said in an interview Wednesday.

headline: Retirement Homes Beckon for City Chickens
text: Urban chicken retirement is becoming a new phenomenon, giving aging birds a place to live out their sunset years.

headline: When Banks Compete With Check-Cashing Stores
text: An article in Thursday’s paper tracks the growing interest among major banks in offering prepaid debit cards, check cashing and wire transfers. Reading it together with a Bucks post from a few months back about the rise of payday-loan-like cash advance services from major financial institutions, you begin to understand just how seriously the banks take the idea of competing with old-fashioned currency exchanges and other storefront money centers that are known for their high fees and exorbitant interest rates.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 6
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: 2 House Democrats Defeated After Opposing Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The defeat of two conservative House Democrats by more liberal opponents in Tuesday’s Pennsylvania primary illustrates the strong hold the new health care law still has over committed Democratic voters and foreshadows an even more polarized Congress next year in the aftermath of the latest round of redistricting.

headline: As Analyst, Polian Still Focuses on Draft
text: After decades of being central to draft decision making with the Buffalo Bills, the Carolina Panthers and the Indianapolis Colts, Bill Polian’s personnel assessments matter a little less than in the past.

headline: We Are Not Stupid
text: It’s still about Mitt Romney, and we’re not stupid.

headline: Pakistani Premier Faces Verdict in Clash With Court
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — After months of standoffs and skirmishes in a courtroom clash between Pakistan’s top judges and civilian leaders, the Supreme Court is poised to deliver a verdict on Thursday that could land Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani in prison and cost him his job.

headline: Arizona v. United States
text: Solicitor General Donald Verrilli Jr. had barely started his argument against Arizona’s immigration law on Wednesday at the Supreme Court when Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. signaled where he stood — in sympathy with the state’s defense of the statute.

headline: Appeals Panel Overturns Conviction of Lebovits in Sexual Abuse Case
text: Saying that a detective’s handwritten notes had not been promptly turned over to defense lawyers before trial, a New York appeals court panel this week overturned the 2010 conviction of a cantor who had already served one year in prison for the repeated sexual assault of a teenager.

headline: Revealing Naked Power Behind Mask
text: Nudity has been so commonplace for so long on Broadway that it is now shocking when it shocks you. So give credit to the creators of “The Columnist,” David Auburn’s scrupulously assembled historical drama, for delivering a truly troubling glimpse of exposed flesh in the play’s opening minutes, a glimpse — it turns out — that is anything but gratuitous.

headline: A Global Puzzle
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Rebus alert! This is a longish one, so write in tiny letters if you’re solving on paper. It takes a lot of work to cram the whole WORLD into one small square. So it’s a small WORLD, get it? Is this thing on? Hey, where’s everyone going?

headline: Whitewashing on the Small Screen
text: Should there be more of a push to feature minorities in lead roles, or does this get in the way of truthful storytelling?

headline: General Orders Review of Military Schools After Class Is Told U.S. Is at War With Islam
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has ordered military schools to make sure they are not including anti-Islamic themes in training courses, the Defense Department said on Wednesday, after complaints surfaced about the curriculum in a course dealing with terrorism and radicalism.

headline: After Man’s Death, Scrutiny for a Police Chase
text: Tamon Robinson’s sideline of digging up cobblestones and selling them to scrap dealers had gotten him arrested numerous times.

headline: Winners at Southeasterns Regional
text: The Southeasterns Regional was held in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from April 9 to 15. The winners of the most master points were Judith Bianco, Win Allegaert and Kevin Bathurst of New York City, and Justin Lall of Henderson, Nev. In five events they won twice, were second twice and fourth once.

headline: Taking Their Dreams, but Not the Usual Ones, to Broadway
text: If the lights of Broadway were dimmed every time a dream died, it would be cast in eternal darkness. Yet hope continues, as reflected by the many people who are testing the world’s most unforgiving stage by investing in a new musical opening this week, the aptly named “Leap of Faith.”

headline: Anger at Sarkozy Fuels Far-Right Party in France
text: PARIS — Lionel de Marcy seems an unlikely supporter of France’s far-right party, the National Front. He comes from the Caribbean island of Martinique, has a good job in Paris and is the son of a former leader of the Socialist Party.

headline: Wright Gets Boost From Friendlier Dimensions
text: David Wright crushed yet another baseball that soared high and traveled far at Citi Field, sailing all the way to the wall at a spacious ballpark that tortured him for three years. But Citi Field has been shrunk, partly for Wright’s benefit.

headline: Grunwald Will Have Decision on Woodson
text: With his interim tag removed, and his status as the Knicks’ top basketball executive secure, Glen Grunwald’s first major decision will be whether to remove another interim label: his coach’s.

headline: Suspending a Campaign
text: As Mitt Romney moves toward locking up the Republican nomination, take a look back at the campaigns that were.

headline: Prostitutes Perplexed as Glare Falls on City’s Brothels
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — Rubbing eyes drowsy from lack of sleep and still smudged with the previous night’s mascara, the employees of the Angeles Bar Club trooped one by one on Tuesday afternoon into a tiny bedroom with stickers of Tinker Bell and Sleeping Beauty pasted on the mauve walls to sit down on a bed with a lime green comforter and be tested for sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Life Inside a Brothel in Cartagena
text: Though the recent scandal involving American Secret Service agents has cast new scrutiny on prostitution in Colombia, life in the brothels goes on as it always has.

headline: Black Man’s Killing in Georgia Eludes Spotlight
text: LYONS, Ga. — Norman Neesmith was sleeping in his home on a rural farm road here in onion country when a noise woke him up.

headline: Yielding to ‘the Real World,’ Gingrich Tells Romney He’ll Quit the Race
text: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich’s presidential campaign was always improbable: He was a Washington insider, twice divorced, with a lavish lifestyle and a penchant for off-the-cuff bluntness that is perfect for a pundit, not a politician.

headline: French Front-Runner Says He’d Seek to Renegotiate Fiscal Treaty if Elected
text: PARIS — The front-runner for the French presidency, the Socialist candidate François Hollande, said on Wednesday that if elected he would ask other European leaders to renegotiate a fiscal treaty in order to promote growth.

headline: In an Ideal World, Here’s How the Draft Would Unfold
text: The N.F.L. draft can be a turning point in a team’s history. It can also reaffirm the status quo, for better or worse. The three-day event, which begins Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, is an opportunity for teams to fill immediate needs, add developmental players or, in a few cases, kick-start franchise-wide paradigm shifts. The Colts have stated that they will take Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck No. 1 over all; the Redskins are enamored of Baylor quarterback Robert Griffin III and will certainly take him second. After that, anything is possible. Here, in alphabetical order, is a peek at the likely shopping lists for all 32 teams.

headline: Mobilizing Young Voters on Campus
text: President Obama wrapped up a barnstorming tour of college campuses in swing states on Wednesday.

headline: Two Parties Find a Way to Agree, and Disagree, on Student Loan Rates
text: IOWA CITY — As President Obama wrapped up a barnstorming tour of college campuses in swing states on Wednesday, Democrats and Republicans agreed that they wanted to avoid a steep increase in the student loan interest rate this summer. But the chief issue remained unsettled: how to pay the cost of doing so.

headline: Score One for the Helicopter Parents
text: Has a grandparent mocked your parenting today? Pointed out that you survived a childhood without a five-point-harness car seat, a bike helmet or laws requiring a gate around every pool?

headline: British Government’s Ties to Murdochs Scrutinized
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain and a senior member of his cabinet faced a growing scandal Wednesday over suggestions of intimate links between Rupert Murdoch’s business interests and the government presented by Mr. Murdoch and his son James this week as evidence in a judicial inquiry.

headline: Capitals Edge Bruins in the Closest Series
text: BOSTON — They hung around for the traditional handshake. They stayed a little longer to raise their sticks and salute their fans. But those were the actions of the defeated Wednesday night. The Boston Bruins’ defense of the Stanley Cup ended before it ever really began.

headline: U.S. to Step Up Drone Strikes Inside Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has given the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon broader authority to carry out drone strikes in Yemen against terrorists who imperil the United States, reflecting rising concerns about the country as a safe haven for Al Qaeda, a senior administration official said Wednesday night.

headline: 2 Abuse Victims Testify at Church Official’s Trial
text: PHILADELPHIA — Two men testified Wednesday of abuse they suffered as youths at the hands of a now defrocked Philadelphia priest. The two victims of Edward Avery, a former priest who has pleaded guilty to sexual assault charges, appeared during the landmark trial of Msgr. William Lynn, the former secretary for clergy at the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, who is charged with child endangerment. Monsignor Lynn is suspected of allowing priests accused of abuse to remain in positions where they could continue to abuse children.

headline: Finale Will Resolve Knicks’ Playoff Role
text: Before they could close out the Los Angeles Clippers, or bid a temporary farewell to their fans, before the Knicks could even be sure of their playoff destination, the chant started to boom:

headline: Still Working His Way Back, Pettitte Takes Loss in Trenton
text: TRENTON — Just hours after the Yankees announced that pitcher Michael Pineda would miss the remainder of the season with a shoulder injury, Andy Pettitte pitched for Class AA Trenton on Wednesday.

headline: Man Said to Be Acting Head of New England Mob Is Held
text: BOSTON — The man federal authorities say was the acting head of the New England mob was arrested here Wednesday morning, and in a federal court appearance in Providence, R.I., later in the day pleaded not guilty to multiple counts including racketeering and conspiracy.

headline: Corrections: April 26
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Women’s Soccer Pioneer to Be Honored by Jewish Hall of Fame
text: The hackneyed but long-running joke about Jews in sports was humorously summarized in the 1980 film “Airplane,” when the flight attendant Elaine, played by Julie Hagerty, said to a passenger:

headline: A Close Reading of the Fed’s Statement
text: The Federal Reserve’s statement was unusually similar to its previous language about the country’s economic conditions.

headline: With Pickup of Paul, Clippers Changed Style
text: The Los Angeles Clippers arrived in New York for their last regular-season game having completed the first part of their mission: they made the playoffs for the first time in seven years and for only the fifth time since the franchise moved from Buffalo to San Diego in 1978 and changed its name from the Braves.

headline: Karzai Critic in Congress Is Asked to Cancel Afghanistan Visit
text: WASHINGTON — Acting at the behest of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, senior American officials told a California congressman last weekend that he was not welcome in Afghanistan because of concerns that his sharp criticism of Mr. Karzai would undermine Washington’s efforts to rebuild trust with the government and restart preliminary peace talks with the Taliban.

headline: Word of the Day | felon
text: felon •\ˈfe-lən\• noun

headline: White House Promotes a Bioeconomy
text: The Obama administration is expected to announce a broad plan on Thursday to foster development of the nation’s “bioeconomy,” including the use of renewable resources and biological manufacturing methods.

headline: Of Mali, the Maldives and Crises Ecological and Political
text: PARIS — The Maldives and Mali, just a few letters apart on the United Nations roll call, are both poor Islamic states with few inhabitants scattered over wide, empty spaces. Yet they exemplify extremes that threaten a small, round planet.

headline: Virginia Spencer Carr, Literary Biographer, Dies at 82
text: Virginia Spencer Carr, a literary scholar whose book “The Lonely Hunter” remains the standard biography of Carson McCullers, died on April 10 at her home in Lynn, Mass. She was 82.

headline: Smartphone Patent Wars: The Coming Sequel
text: Billions of dollars are being spent to amass patent arsenals, and lawsuits are flying worldwide. Apple, Samsung, Microsoft and Motorola Mobility (or Google, after that patent-inspired acquisition is complete) are the heavyweights in the fray, seeking an edge in the fast-growing smartphone market, using intellectual property as a weapon.

headline: A Man on a Wire Above China’s ‘Grand Canyon’
text: HONG KONG — The best American rock climbers would already seem to have their hands full, from the Gunks and the granite crags in New Hampshire to the Hueco Tanks boulders in Texas, to the storied routes in Yosemite like Half Dome and El Capitan.

headline: Israeli Army Chief Says He Believes Iran Won’t Build Bomb
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military chief described the Iranian government as “rational” in interviews published Wednesday and said he did not believe it would build a nuclear bomb, appearing to put some distance between himself and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak.

headline: Japan Power Broker Acquitted in Scandal
text: TOKYO — A divisive power broker of Japan’s ruling party was acquitted Thursday of charges in a political financing scandal, freeing him to step up his opposition to Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda and a critical tax increase plan.

headline: Did Blankfein Snub Paulson Over Emerging Markets?
text: On Wednesday morning on CNBC, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief of Goldman Sachs, made a rare on-camera appearance to defend the embattled firm from its detractors, Kevin Roose writes in DealBook blog of The New York Times.

headline: Brazil: Panetta Pushes Boeing
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pushed Brazil on Wednesday to buy $4 billion worth of Boeing-made Super Hornet fighter jets, saying the prospective sale reflected how important Brazil was to the United States. During the first visit by an American defense secretary to the country in seven years, Mr. Panetta used a speech at Superior War College in Rio De Janeiro to focus on smoothing a sometimes thorny relationship and promoting American weapons sales. Brazil is deciding whether to buy 36 fighter jets worth about $4 billion in a competition between Boeing in the United States, Dassault Aviation in France and Saab in Sweden.

headline: Pakistani Prime Minister Is Spared Jail but Faces More Battles
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Senior judges embroiled in a bitter confrontation with the government made a tactical retreat on Thursday when they convicted the prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, on contempt charges, but imposed a symbolic sentence that allowed him to walk free minutes later.

headline: Ireland: Law on Abuse Is Proposed
text: Ireland has introduced draft legislation that would make it a crime to withhold information on child abuse from the state authorities. The new law was introduced in response to last July’s Cloyne Report, which found that a Roman Catholic diocese had failed to report such abuse as recently as 2008. Under the legislation, any person who fails to report abuse would face at least five years in jail. Justice Minister Alan Shatter said that the law would extend to the confessional and that it was “not acceptable that there can be a cloak of secrecy surrounding such offenses against children or other vulnerable people in society.”

headline: Deutsche Bank Earnings Fall 34%, Worse Than Expected
text: FRANKFURT–Deutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Thursday that profit had fallen 34 percent in the first quarter, more than expected, as the European debt crisis continued to depress fees from trading and other investment banking activities.

headline: News Quiz | April 26, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: In ‘The Commuters,’ a Photographer Chronicles Mumbai’s Working Class
text: You stare out of the window, you fiddle with your phone, you nod your head along to music, you block out the sounds and presence of people pressed against you, and you try to pass the time during another dreary morning commute in Mumbai’s local trains. It was out of this boredom that photographer Chirodeep Chaudhuri’s latest show “The Commuters” was born.

headline: Ex-President of Liberia Aided War Crimes, Court Rules
text: THE HAGUE — Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and once a powerful warlord, was convicted by an international tribunal on Thursday of arming, supporting and guiding a brutal rebel movement that committed mass atrocities in Sierra Leone during its civil war in the 1990s. He is the first head of state to be convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials after World War II.

headline: At British Inquiry, Murdoch Apologizes Over Scandal

headline: April 26, 1986 | Explosion at Chernobyl Nuclear Plant
text: On April 26, 1986, the world’s worst nuclear accident happened at the Chernobyl plant near Pripyat, Ukraine, in the Soviet Union. An explosion and fire in the No. 4 reactor sent radioactivity into the atmosphere.

headline: Updates on Rupert Murdoch’s Second Day of Testimony in Britain
text: The Lede followed a second day of testimony by Rupert Murdoch on Thursday and other developments in a judicial inquiry into the behavior of the British press that grew out of a widening phone hacking and corruption scandal at Murdoch-owned papers in Britain. On Wednesday, Mr. Murdoch downplayed the political influence of his media empire in hours of testimony. His son James appeared before the same judicial panel on Tuesday.

headline: Seeing Yourself as Others Do
text: While on spring break 10 years ago in Myrtle Beach, S.C., Jen Davis decided to turn the camera on herself. But at 5-foot-4 and 260 pounds, this was not an easy thing to do. Sitting on a sandy beach mat in a tank top and shorts, surrounded by friends in more revealing swimwear, she triggered a cable release hidden under her foot.

headline: U.S. Assets at Work, Unsupervised

Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.” From 2007 to 2008, he was the International Monetary Fund’s chief economist and director of research.

headline: What Have You and Your Family Accomplished Together?
text: Marshall Reid was an overweight sixth grader who wanted to get healthy, so he and his family worked together on plan. It worked and eventually, they wrote a book about it. Have you and your family ever taken on a big project or set a shared goal? Did you succeed?

headline: Exxon Mobil Earnings Disappoint
text: The global oil giant Exxon Mobil on Thursday reported disappointing first-quarter earnings, saying net income dropped 11 percent because of lower production volumes and weak chemical profit margins.

text: The futility of the Indian government’s attempts to control what is posted on Facebook, YouTube and other social media sites was thrown into high relief this week, after a video purportedly showing Congress spokesman Abhishek Manu Singvi having sex in his office resulted in his resignation.

headline: Fresenius Group Bids $4.1 Billion for Hospital Operator
text: LONDON — The health care company Fresenius Group on Thursday offered 3.1 billion euros ($4.1 billion) to buy the German hospital operator Rhön-Klinikum, as it looked to increase its presence in the German market.

headline: Japanese Soba and the Broth of Life
text: A bowl of soba is a beautiful, exotic and delicious centerpiece for a Japanese meal: the not-too-soft, nutty buckwheat noodles sitting in a mahogany broth — dashi — that’s as clear and glossy as beef consommé, not only salty and umami-complex but sweet as well. My favorite variety, tamago toji, is egg-topped. When it’s made right, the egg is almost foamy, soft-scrambled and tender, deliciously flavored by the dashi, a bit of which it absorbs.

headline: How Samuel L. Jackson Became His Own Genre
text: Before “The Mountaintop” opened on Broadway last fall, there were rumors that this fictional account of Martin Luther King Jr.’s last night before his assassination would present him as a flawed man, one who drinks and flirts with a motel maid. Kenny Leon, the director, told me recently, however, that he never would have had anything to do with something “that destroyed the iconic nature of Dr. King.” In fact, he said, when he first read the play, he realized that its innocently childlike King could be played only by “a sensitive actor bigger than life” — his friend Sam Jackson.

headline: The 15 Movies That Define Samuel L. Jackson’s Career
text: In the April 29 issue of the magazine, Pat Jordan writes about how Samuel L. Jackson became his own genre. Below, fifteen of the 100-plus movies in his oeuvre.

headline: How Do You Compete With FedEx and U.P.S.?
text: Recently, while wrapping up a meeting with a new client, Lone Star Overnight, the company’s chief executive talked about what he’s doing to shift his company’s culture. I’ve always been fascinated by company culture, but it’s especially interesting when someone is trying to transform a 20-year-old company with revenue of more than $50 million.

headline: Why Andrew Luck Deserves to Be Draft’s No. 1 Quarterback

headline: Lest We Remember
text: ISTANBUL — The other day Taraf, a Turkish language newspaper for which I write, ran a quarter-page ad depicting a pomegranate with a deep slash and the legend: “Some wounds do not heal with time.” The pomegranate is a symbol of the Armenian people, and in fine print you could make out the endorsement of many prominent Turkish Armenians for a gathering in Istanbul’s Taksim Square. The ad didn’t bother to explain the purpose of the assembly, leaving the date and time — April 24, 19:15 — to speak for itself.

headline: Decision Looms for City Schools
text: UPDATED | The Panel for Educational Policy, a city board controlled by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, will vote on the recommendation to close 24 city schools (two others were given reprieves early Thursday). The schools, which Mr. Bloomberg wants to make part of a federal "turnaround" program to be  eligible for nearly $60 million in federal money, will be closed at the end of this school year and reopened by fall, with up to half their staffs and, in many cases their administrations, replaced.

headline: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: Essays on the End
text: Let me acknowledge that perhaps not everyone wants to settle down in a comfy chair with a glass of wine, a purring cat, and 22 very personal essays about death and dying. My daughter has taken to asking me whether I wouldn’t rather read — or write — about puppies and kittens.

headline: The Road to Naypyidaw
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — The 43 seats of Parliament that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the other newly elected members of her National League for Democracy (N.L.D.) were supposed to fill on Monday remain empty. After winning by-elections by a landslide earlier this month, the Lady and her party are refusing to show up for their first legislative session in protest over having to take a pledge to “safeguard” the 2008 Constitution.

headline: Rice, a Private Equity Pioneer, to Step Down
text: Joseph L. Rice III, a pioneer of the private equity industry, plans to step down as chairman of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, his firm announced in a letter to clients on Wednesday.

text: Sometimes even the small companies can reveal big lessons about success on the Internet.
