headline: T Exclusive Video | A Polished Look by Chanel
text: When Peter Philips, Chanel’s creative director for makeup, wanted to showcase the latest collection of Chanel nail polish on film, he called upon Ruth Hogben, a London filmmaker known for her work with Gareth Pugh and Louis Vuitton. The inspiration to use sign language came shortly after.

headline: How an iPhone Audition Got Benedict Cumberbatch Into the ‘Star Trek’ Sequel
text: No, Benedict Cumberbatch is not going to tell us anything juicy about the top-secret role he’s been filming in the coming sequel to “Star Trek,” the next adventure of the starship Enterprise crew from the director J. J. Abrams.

headline: Thursday Reading: Should Your Dog Be Watching TV?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Magic Fingers
text: The Dutch model Saskia De Brauw shows off an array of chic Chanel polishes.

headline: A Bribery Case That Goes Beyond Corruption
text: If all goes as scheduled, former State Senator Carl Kruger will stand Thursday afternoon before a federal judge in Manhattan and get what’s coming to him for having accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes.

headline: Edwards Ex-Aide Admits Stealth Campaign Billing
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The drama of former Senator John Edwards’s trial took a few more twists on Thursday as Andrew Young, the eager aide whose fortunes and stature rose and fell with those of Mr. Edwards, admitted submitting misleading financial statements to a wealthy benefactor who thought he was helping the senator hide a mistress.

headline: Heavy Casualties Reported in Syria Explosion
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A number of Syrian civilians died in a poor neighborhood of Hama after their houses crashed down on them, but the government and the opposition offered widely different accounts on Thursday of the cause.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Says He ‘Failed’ on Hacking, and a Missing Vogue Profile
text: Rupert Murdoch completed his second and final day of testimony before the Leveson inquiry on press ethics on Thursday, addressing the phone-hacking scandal at his company’s News of The World that propelled the creation of the commission in the first place. “I also have to say that I failed,” Mr. Murdoch told the commission. “I am very sorry about it.” In addition, he suggested, Alan Cowell writes, that “there had been what he called a cover-up by underlings at The News of the World to hide the extent of the phone hacking scandal.”

headline: Making Information Matter in a Noisy Age
text: I was invited to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology earlier this week to outline my notion that it is possible, amid the reverberating noise and distraction, to use the Web and other emerging communication tools and networks to make the world a better place.

headline: Morning Buzz, April 26: A Protest Against Tuition
text: Good morning. Expect rain throughout the day with temperatures reaching the upper 50s, a surprisingly appropriate forecast to commemorate the anniversary of Shakespeare’s baptism.

headline: Lockheed Chief to Retire and Hand Reins to an Insider
text: Lockheed Martin said Thursday that its chief executive, Robert J. Stevens, would retire in December after eight years in the job. His successor will be Christopher E. Kubasik, who is now Lockheed’s president and chief operating officer.

headline: A Daunting Emissions Quest for U.S. Cities
text: More than 1,000 American cities have voluntarily committed themselves to ambitious targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. A recent case study focusing on Allegheny County, Pa., home to Pittsburgh, highlights how hard it will be for some to meet those goals, however.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Reuters: Despite assurances from the Agriculture Department, the blowback from the announcement of America’s first case of mad cow disease in six years (in a California dairy cow) has begun. Two major South Korean retailers and an English wholesaler have halted sales of United States beef, while Mexico, Korea and Japan say they will continue imports. — Glenn Collins

headline: A Photographer Is Approached for an Assignment
text: Dear Diary: I was photographing dancers in Madison Square Park on April 14, a stunning Saturday morning, and a big, burly 30-something and ruggedly handsome Con Ed worker saunters over to me from the plaza in front of the Flatiron Building, where he’d been working, and starts making small talk.

headline: Mods and Bikers | Bobbin Bicycles Land Stateside
text: When you come across a smart new upright bicycle on the floor of the TriBeCa cycling boutique Adeline Adeline this spring, don’t make the mistake of calling it Dutch. It very well may be a Bobbin, a line of British city bikes designed by Tom Morris and Sian Emmison, who until recently ran a bike shop of the same name in Islington, London. The line of bikes, which has been available in Britain since 2011, makes its New York City debut tonight, with a party at the TriBeCa store. (An earlier line of Britain-only Bobbin bikes has been popular for about five years among fashionable Londoners like Florence Welch, Lara Stone and the designer Erdem Moraglioglu.)

headline: Tribeca: Maggie Gyllenhaal on Sex Scenes From a Woman’s Perspective
text: “The plague of our times,” a character declares in “Hysteria,” Tanya Wexler’s new film, “stems from an overactive uterus.” The time is Victorian England and the focus is the invention of the vibrator. The romantic comedy, which plays at the Tribeca Film Festival on Thursday and opens commercially on May 18, stars Hugh Dancy as Mortimer, a forward-thinking doctor, and Maggie Gyllenhaal as Charlotte, a champion of women’s rights and the rebellious daughter of Mr. Dancy’s mentor, as well as his romantic match.

headline: Trouble With the Top Man
text: HOUSTON  — Aubrey K. McClendon, Chesapeake Energy’s audacious chairman and chief executive, has ridden the busts and booms in natural gas like a rodeo cowboy. He became a billionaire as the company he co-founded aggressively outbid competitors for land leases and drilled highly productive wells in virtually every major shale gas field in the country. And he acquired trophy assets like an N.B.A. team and a $12 million antique map collection.

headline: Support for Same-Sex Marriage Is Up
text: Same-sex marriage opponents often cast themselves as the defenders of traditional, mainstream American values. Increasingly, however, it looks as though the traditional and the mainstream are coming apart.

headline: With Panel Vote, Once-Venerable City Schools Will Close
text: The names of two-dozen New York City public schools, some of them among the oldest educational institutions in the city, are likely to be erased on Thursday night when a city board votes on proposals to close the schools. Among them are Flushing High School, which lays claim to being the oldest public high school in New York City, and Richmond Hill High School, which is so overcrowded that its students have overflowed into trailers. But in a last-minute reprieve, Bushwick Community and Grover Cleveland high schools were spared.

headline: Higher Prices Help PepsiCo Increase Earnings on Flat Sales
text: PepsiCo, the Hatfield of the country’s cola wars to Coca-Cola’s McCoy, used higher prices to eke out slightly better first-quarter earnings than analysts expected despite essentially flat revenue.

text: India launches its first indigenous radar imaging satellite.

text: The Passionist priests and and brothers of the Province of St. Paul of the Cross are among the investors in the musical “Leap of Faith,” opening Thursday.

headline: AstraZeneca C.E.O. to Step Down
text: David Brennan, the chief executive of AstraZeneca, will step down on June 1 as the big British pharmaceutical company struggles with competition from makers of generic drugs and the failure of several drug development projects.

headline: Activist Group Alleges Widespread Corruption in Defense Deals
text: Hiring foreign call girls, intimidation, money laundering, fraud and bribes – those are just some of the activities government officials, defense executives and middle men were accused of Thursday by the activist group India Against Corruption.

text: Banks aggressively court low-income customers; balancing education costs and job prospects in California; and a rise in malware targeting Mac users.

headline: Ross Douthat Talks About the State of American Christianity
text: In his new book “Bad Religion: How We Became a Nation of Heretics,” Ross Douthat, an Op-Ed columnist for The Times, writes about how Christianity lost its central place in American life through a variety of factors, among them the religion’s failed attempts to accommodate secular trends; a strong identification of the church with strictly conservative politics; a lack of great religious-inspired art; and the appeal to a “God within” that tailors spirituality to the citizens of a self-help age. I recently spoke with Mr. Douthat about the book via e-mail. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

headline: Lomography, an Analog Company Surviving in a Digital World
text: From the death rattle of companies like Kodak to the popularity of apps like Instagram that transform cellphone snaps into vintage-looking works of art, amateur film photography seems destined for the graveyard of obsolete technologies.

headline: The City’s Verdant Heart
text: There’s no dearth of specious, gaseous political rhetoric in this fevered democracy of ours, but one bit of grandstanding that irks me in particular is the occasional portrayal of the city as a dark graveyard for civic virtue stalked by hedonists with no sense of community.

headline: A $1,200 Dress for Your Little One?
text: From the Styles section: The high-fashion world, determined to leave no market untapped, is now turning out designer clothes for children. Just $1,200 for a Lanvin tulle dress, and don’t forget the $1,570 taffeta coat. Makes the $30 dry cleaning bill to get out the chocolate-frosted birthday cake look like milk money, doesn’t it? The vast majority of us, of course, still spend less on a t-shirt for a child than you could blow on a venti at Starbucks — but to see how the other 1 percent lives, check out the slide show.

headline: Using Business to Help At-Risk Middle Schoolers
text: Educators know many kids lose interest in school in the middle years when the work gets tougher and distractions increase. WNYC’s Beth Fertig reports on how one group is trying to keep middle school students' attention with business mentors.

headline: An Aging Japanese Town Bets on a Young Mayor for Its Revival
text: YUBARI, Japan — Most young people have already fled this city of empty streets and shuttered schools, whose bankrupt local government collapsed under the twin burdens of debt and demographics that are slowly afflicting the rest of Japan.

headline: Dear Boy Scouts: Let a Gay Mom Lead the Pack
text: By now, you may have heard of Jennifer Tyrrell, especially if you’re the parent of a child of scouting age. She’s the Bridgeport, Ohio, mother who (reluctantly) accepted the role of “den mother” for her 7-year-old son Cruz’s Tiger Scout pack a year ago (not, as many reluctant volunteer parents know, a position that adults are clamoring to fill) — and was told by the regional, and then national Boy Scouts organization earlier this month that she would have to leave her troop, because her sexual orientation “did not meet the high standards” of conduct set by the Boy Scouts of America.

headline: The Curious Case of the Telus Proxy Battle
text: The proxy battle involving the Telus Corporation, the $19 billion Canadian telecommunications company, is shaping up to be the most interesting of the year, involving allegations of empty voting, vote buying and secret share accumulations. What fun!

headline: Lawmakers Push for a Final Volcker Rule by the Summer
text: The lawmakers who sponsored an effort to rein in risky trading on Wall Street are now urging regulators to finalize a forceful version of the Volcker Rule by the summer.

headline: A Worrisome Rise in Jobless Claims
text: The odds that the economy has fallen into a spring slowdown – for the third straight year – rose this morning.

headline: Q. and A. About ‘Frontline’ Series on the Financial Crisis
text: 4:01 p.m. | Updated

headline: In Hockey, Game 7 Is Different
text: This time there was no Champagne, no Stanley Cup paraded around the rink, not nearly as much delirium as on that manic night, the last time there was a Game 7 in Madison Square Garden.

headline: Two Game 7’s? Isn’t There a Draft Going On?
text: It is a quirk of the modern sports schedule that pits the first night of the N.F.L. draft against two Game 7s in the N.H.L. playoffs, which is sort of like choosing between Audrey Hepburn or a Kardashian sister. Because yes, everyone will agree nothing rivals a Game 7 for drama and intensity, for players’ pouring their hopes and dreams onto the ice. And yes, it will get killed in the ratings by a parade of large men doing nothing but modeling specially tailored menswear. In today’s world, the Kardashians it is.

headline: TLC Is Said to Plan a Reunion Tour Using Projections of Lisa Lopes
text: Why let a little thing like death get in the way of a lucrative reunion? The two surviving members the girl group TLC are planning a reunion tour that will use video projections of Lisa Lopes, who died in a car crash a decade ago, according to the celebrity-watch Web site TMZ.

headline: Under Public Pressure, City Retreats on Cleveland and Bushwick High School Closings
text: UPDATED |  On the morning that a city board was scheduled to vote on the closing of 26 schools, city officials removed two of them from the list, saying that both could improve without the use of a more invasive strategy. In both cases, elected officials and other powerful advocates intervened to try to spare the school, and one of them, Merryl Tisch, said after hearing about the reprieve, "It's the first thing that's made me smile since the pineapple."

headline: Massachusetts Stamps a Catch-All Plate for E.V.’s, Plug-Ins and Hybrids
text: The Massachusetts Department of Transportation announced this week that it would make special license plates available for purely electric, plug-in hybrid and regular hybrid vehicles, becoming the second state, after Hawaii, to do so. The optional plates, which cost $20 with no annual fee, feature the letters EV, or EC for commercial vehicles, and a graphic of a car mated with a plug.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/26
text: Hidden Myanmar The 800 islands of the Mergui Archipelago in southern Myanmar remain largely empty even as a tourism infrastructure takes root in the rest of the country. The few visitors who make it are closely monitored, because, locals suspect, a massacre took place on one of the islands and illegal fishing, logging and smuggling still occurs. (The New York Times)

headline: European Union Protests Ukraine’s Treatment of Jailed Ex-Premier
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union pressed Ukraine on Thursday to allow “independent medical specialists” to visit the country’s jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, after she claimed to have been beaten by prison guards last week.

headline: Does Medicine Discourage Gay Doctors?
text: During my surgical training, whenever the conversation turned to relationships, one of my colleagues would always joke about his inability to get a date, then abruptly change the subject. I thought he might be gay but never asked him outright, because it didn’t seem important.

headline: As Bison Return to Prairie, Some Rejoice, Others Worry
text: WOLF POINT, Mont. — Sioux and Assiniboine tribe members wailed a welcome song last month as around 60 bison from Yellowstone National Park stormed onto a prairie pasture that had not felt a bison’s hoof for almost 140 years.

headline: For One More Day at the Office
text: Every only child knows there is a difference between being lonely and being alone. Growing up in Manhattan, I was a master at entertaining myself; I had an older half sister, but she didn’t live with me, so I was usually my own favorite company.

headline: Look of the Moment | Gwyneth Paltrow
text: The Look: No fuss. Natural hair, gothic nails and stilettos take a ladylike knit sheath and bicolor top-handle tote to a modern place.

headline: Teacher’s Aide on Upper West Side Charged With Sexually Abusing 8-Year-Old
text: Update | Mr. Abdalla was freed on April 26 after the district attorney’s office decided to defer prosecution while it continues to investigate his case.

headline: Crane Owner Is Cleared of All Charges in Fatal Collapse
text: The owner of a crane company was acquitted on Thursday of all charges in connection with the collapse of a tower crane in Manhattan nearly four years ago that killed two people.

headline: A Mixed Legal Outcome for an Egyptian Comedian
text: CAIRO — A court on Thursday dismissed a case against Egypt’s most popular comedian that charged him with insulting Islam in his films, just days after another court fined him in a separate case dealing with very similar charges. Egyptian state media had initially reported that his first conviction had been overturned on appeal, and the opposite outcomes in similar cases underscored the confusion and irregularity in the application of Egypt’s laws against defaming religion.

headline: Missing Curtain
text: The new Broadway musical “Once” forgoes the typical opening curtain to start the show on stage, audience invited.

headline: Citizens Bank Is Latest to Settle Suit on Overdraft Fees
text: Citizens Bank is the latest institution to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging that banks changed the order of customer payments to increase the amount they could collect in overdraft fees. The fees are charged when customers, by writing checks or using debit cards, spend more than is available in their checking accounts.

headline: Broadway Show Appetizers
text: THE orchestral overture has been a mainstay of Broadway musicals for decades, though in recent years some shows have dispensed with it. This season three Broadway productions — one of them a play — have added preshow components that have nothing to do with highlighting a composer’s score. They are meant to be mood setters and palate whetters for the audience — and fun to boot, or so the shows’ creators hope.

headline: Sean Payton Returns to the Zurich Classic
text: AVONDALE, La. — Two nights before the N.F.L. draft, the banished Saints Coach Sean Payton pulled off a trade. In a swap that involved sleeves of golf balls among other items, Payton swapped his amateur trio, which drew Ricky Barnes at the pairings party, with Ryan Palmer’s for Wednesday’s Zurich Classic pro-am.

headline: Ann Romney Discusses Super Tuesday Multiple Sclerosis Scare
text: Ann Romney had “a little bit of a scare” involving her multiple sclerosis before Super Tuesday, she told “Entertainment Tonight” in an interview set to be broadcast Thursday evening.

headline: Off-Broadway Companies Will Stage World Premieres by Shepard, Hwang and Guare
text: Signature Theater on Thursday announced world premiere productions of plays by Sam Shepard (“True West”) and David Henry Hwang (“Chinglish”) during the next 18 months, while another respected Off Broadway stalwart, the Atlantic Theater Company, announced its own world premieres by John Guare (“The House of Blue Leaves”) and Melissa James Gibson (“This”) for its 2012-13 season.

headline: App Smart Extra: Press Here
text: I’ve often written about children’s apps in a variety of contexts, including games, narratives and pure education (like the Barefoot World Atlas for iPad). Occasionally an app crosses over into two or more of those spheres, but too often that ambition muddies the final product.

headline: Swashbumblers Roiling Madcap Seas
text: “You can’t always just say ‘aarrr’ at the end of a sentence and think that makes everything all right.” This is wise advice and not only for pirates and piratephiles of all ages. It’s also the closest thing to a lesson — also: pigs are not fruit — in the delightful stop-motion animation “The Pirates! Band of Misfits,” a story of high-seas silliness from that British national treasure Aardman Animations (Wallace & Gromit). Exquisitely detailed — from its ocean breakers to the wavelike curlicues on a pirate’s luxurious beard — the movie is a curiosity cabinet of visual pleasures but so breezy and lightly funny that you may not realize at first how good it is. (You’re too busy grinning.)

headline: E.P.A. Official Spoke of ‘Crucifying’ Polluters
text: A high-ranking Environmental Protection Agency official has apologized for remarks he made to subordinates suggesting that the agency “crucify” some violators of pollution laws to deter others.

headline: Now Toting | Hartmann Luggage
text: Lightweight luggage is an obsession for frequent travelers and overpackers alike. I confess: I am both. But I am also a design snob, and if I’m going to consider grounding my gorgeous but relatively weighty T. Anthony pieces for what’s widely considered some of the lightest luggage around — polycarbonate plastic — it had better look good. Historically, this has been a tall order. The most attractive pieces in this category are often empty boxes inside, while the most practical ones, with zippered pockets and the like, tend to come in colors or exterior patterns that I’d rather leave on the baggage carousel.

headline: Newt Gingrich’s Debt
text: Newt Gingrich is preparing to make the transition from forgotten-but-not-gone to gone-and-hopefully-forgotten by dropping his presidential campaign next week. And he’s doing it in good Reagan-and-Bush-era Republican fashion – carrying on about fiscal responsibility while piling up a nice fat budget deficit.

headline: Business Day Live | Laura Tyson
text: April 26, 2012 — Laura Tyson, former chair of the President’s Council of Economic Advisers, discusses balancing education costs and job prospects in California.

headline: G.R.E. Will Allow Test Takers to Customize Score Reports
text: Students interested in eventually going to graduate and business schools will soon have a chance to put their best G.R.E. scores forward, officials announced this week.

headline: TimesCast | April 26, 2012
text: Rupert Murdoch apologizes for the hacking scandal | The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on the former Liberian president’s guilty verdict.

headline: Banco Espirito Chief to Tender Resignation From NYSE Board
text: Ricardo Salgado, the chief executive of Banco Espirito Santo, Portugal’s biggest bank, is expected to offer his resignation as a director of NYSE Euronext after failing to garner a majority of shareholder votes.

headline: Excerpt: 'Leap of Faith'
text: Raul Esparza and Talon Ackerman in “Like Magic,” a number from the new Broadway musical at the St. James Theater.

headline: Will The Stars Align for Small Nuclear Reactors?
text: A company that wants to build a new kind of nuclear reactor, one small enough that it could be delivered by truck, has found a potential customer.

headline: Farewell to Nova Iorque
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: Excerpt: 'Don't Dress for Dinner'
text: A scene from the Roundabout Theater Company's production, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

headline: Theater Talkback: A Seat at the Table
text: On Monday night, my play “The Lyons” opened at the Cort Theater on Broadway. Now, I’ve been writing plays for almost 30 years and been getting them produced Off-Broadway for 19. So, I guess I can’t be shocked that people keep asking me how it feels to have a play on Broadway “after all this time.”

headline: At the Oxygen Upfront, It Was Showtime
text: Most of the upfront presentations made to advertisers by television networks and channels follow the show-and-tell model. One cable channel decided to play up the show.

headline: Biden Paints Romney as Out of Touch on Foreign Policy
text: Taking the battle with Mitt Romney to the foreign policy front, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. praised President Obama on Thursday as the man who got Osama bin Laden and painted Mr. Romney as a Cold War relic who would leave American troops stranded in Afghanistan.

headline: Oil’s Dark Heart Pumps Strong
text: The cover of “Private Empire,” Steve Coll’s new book about the Exxon Mobil Corporation, is a forbidding black slab. Even the lettering looks dismal. It’s the color of a chain smoker’s lung.

headline: Previewing the Patriot League Men’s Lacrosse Tournament
text: The automatic qualifier for the N.C.A.A. tournament from the Patriot League will be determined this weekend at Colgate University, with a tournament that is as wide open as ever. With one exception, Colgate, Lehigh, Army, and Bucknell played each other in one-goal games this season (Colgate defeated Army by two goals). The four schools represented are the same four schools that made the league tournament last year, which was won by host Bucknell.

headline: Laura Tyson: The Public University Dilemma
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson, a contributor to this blog and an economist at the University of California, Berkeley, spoke with Catherine Rampell about the toll that state cutbacks have taken on public universities. Middle-class applicants are most seriously affected, as they may lack the assets or the financial aid to enroll. “It’s part of the broader polarization of the United States,” she says. Part of the solution might be to raise the sticker price for those who can afford it, in order to subsidize others — but such plans run up against state restrictions designed to ensure the university’s public mission.

headline: State Worker Drug Tests Struck Down in Florida
text: MIAMI — A federal court in Miami ruled Thursday that Gov. Rick Scott’s order to randomly test a majority of state employees for drugs is unconstitutional, saying there is not a compelling enough reason to do so.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Are Said to Be Examining Goldman Banker
text: Federal prosecutors in California are said to be investigating whether an investment banker at Goldman Sachs leaked confidential information about health care deals to the Galleon Group, the defunct hedge fund that was run by Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Study Indicates a Greater Threat of Extreme Weather
text: New research suggests that global warming is causing the cycle of evaporation and rainfall over the oceans to intensify more than scientists had expected, an ominous finding that may indicate a higher potential for extreme weather in coming decades.

headline: Wheelies: The Displacement Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Study Sheds Light on How Birds Navigate by Magnetic Field
text: Birds are famously good navigators. Some migrate thousands of miles, flying day and night, even when the stars are obscured. And for decades, scientists have known that one navigational skill they employ is an ability to detect variations in the earth’s magnetic field.

headline: Group Buys $6 Million Ad Targeting Obama in Swing States
text: The group Americans for Prosperity just went up with a $6.1 million ad buy in swing states that accuses the Obama administration of squandering American taxpayer dollars on green energy projects, asserting that some of the money actually went to foreign entities. The ad is going up in eight states: Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Mexico, Ohio and Virginia.

headline: Barclays Capital and Deutsche Bank Pick Up A.I.G. Assets
text: In the latest step toward unwinding the crisis-era bailout of the American International Group, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced Thursday that it had sold a chunk of the Maiden Lane III portfolio to a bidding group that included Barclays Capital and Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Samuel L. Jackson Was Ready for Some Football
text: One of the sidebars that accompanies this week’s cover story on Samuel L. Jackson is “Five Curios,” a short list of surprising appearances by the actor. To this mix, let’s add another, a curio among the curios: Jackson’s promo for “Monday Night Football” back in 2003. Far as I’m concerned, it belongs up there in the pantheon of sublime Jacksonian moments right between “Where’s my super suit?” (“The Incredibles”) and “Every time my fingers touch brain, I’m Superfly T.N.T., I’m the ‘Guns of the Navarone’ ” (“Pulp Fiction”). Many of the Jackson hallmarks are on display: the crazy eyes, the grin of mischief, the escalating intensity, the quick-shift vocal impersonations. And if it lacks swear words — the promo aired on prime-time TV, remember — it compensates with what, when seen today, is a different sort of transgressive thrill, a celebration of football’s skull-crushing essence. Try not to enjoy it when Jackson starts soaring: “You want to bury ’em in the turf. You want ’em lookin’ through their earhole! You want to say, ‘I like your teeth — especially the ones scattered around the 20-yard line.’ You want their mamas to say say: ‘Oh, no, that’s not my child! My child has a face!'”

headline: Early Menopause Linked to Bone Fracture Risk
text: Women who reach menopause early are at significantly greater risk for osteoporosis and bone fracture later in life, a Swedish study has found.

headline: On Our Radar: Invasive Tiger Shrimp
text: A rise in sightings of the invasive Asian tiger shrimp off the Atlantic and gulf coasts has government scientists scrambling to figure out the cause and the implications for native fish in those waters. “We can confirm there was nearly a tenfold jump in reports of Asian tiger shrimp in 2011,” a federal biologist says. [NOAA]

headline: Move on Oil Company Draws Praise in Argentina, Where Growth Continues
text: BUENOS AIRES — President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina has incurred the wrath of the European Union by expropriating a controlling stake in YPF S.A., the oil and gas company owned by the Spanish energy giant Repsol, prompting retaliatory salvos in a budding trans-Atlantic trade war.

headline: Politicians Find a Way to Agree, and Disagree, on Student Loan Rates
text: Republicans and Democrats agree: nobody wants to see the interest rates of student loans go up this summer. They disagree, however, about how to cover the costs that would keep that from happening, our colleagues Peter Baker and Jennifer Steinhauer report this week.

headline: On the Other Hand, It Could Have Been Worse
text: MINNEAPOLIS – Liam Hendriks, a rookie right-handed pitcher for the Minnesota Twins who hails from Australia, faced the Boston Red Sox twice in spring training. He threw five scoreless innings altogether, three perfect ones in a March 16 start at Boston’s home stadium, JetBlue Park in Fort Myers.

headline: Judge Agrees to Release 2nd Man Held in Rape Case
text: A State Supreme Court judge on Thursday authorized the release, until his trial, of a Brooklyn man who had been jailed for almost a year on charges of rape and sex trafficking, saying that there appeared to be problems with the credibility of his accuser.

headline: In Albany, a Bill for Mandatory Kindergarten
text: Following a push by City Council Speaker Christine Quinn, state lawmakers have introduced a bill allowing New York City to make kindergarten mandatory.

headline: BTG Pactual Surges on Trading Debut
text: Units of Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual rose sharply Thursday, their first day on the São Paulo stock exchange, even as other bank stocks fell.

headline: Tone-Deaf Lawyers Jeopardize the Draw Something Game
text: As many Draw Something fans know, this delightful app has become the victim of a very upsetting corporate “they ruined a great thing” story. But today, I’m delighted to be the bearer of good news. After doing a little sleuthing, I’ve learned that a happy ending is on the way.

headline: Medvedev, Unscripted, Admits Disappointments
text: MOSCOW — During a two-hour interview on Russian television on Thursday, President Dmitri A. Medvedev admitted disappointment over some of the goals of his four-year presidency, saying that his anticorruption drive was stymied “because officials are a corporation, and they do not want anyone to meddle in their affairs.”

headline: Cissy Houston Plans a Book on Her Daughter, Whitney, a k a ‘Nippy’
text: Cissy Houston, the gospel singer and mother of Whitney Houston, met with publishers in New York this week to shop a book about her daughter, several people who were in the meetings said.

headline: (Don’t) Take Your Children to Work Day

headline: Ford’s Challenges Mount in Europe

headline: ‘Apprenticeship’ to Chef Meant Only Long Hours and Sub-Minimum Wages, Suit Says

text: Chris Kreider, who scored of the winning goal in the Rangers’ 3-2 victory in Ottawa in Game 6, showed no signs of rookie nervousness before Game 7. He said he slept great and was ready to go.

text: After failing a chemistry exam in a lethargic 98-90 loss to Cleveland, Carmelo Anthony and Amar’e Stoudemire combined for an impressive 61-point, 22-rebound performance on Sunday – a 113-112 win over the Hawks – and provided a glimpse of what’s possible for the Knicks’ stars.

headline: With Radio Deals, Valentine Dials Up the Pressure on Himself

Nothing too violent; not the daily physical abuse at the hands of an older sibling one reader described in response, but a low-grade background of whacks, pinches and pushes.

headline: A Remade Tabloid Image of Houston’s Last Meal
text: That gruesome photograph of Whitney Houston’s last supper, first posted on TMZ shortly after her death, stuck in the visual memory of the German photographer Thomas Demand. There were the remains of room service delivered to her at the Beverly Hilton Hotel: a rolling table draped with a soiled tablecloth on which were a partially eaten hamburger and French fries, a Heineken can, a Champagne glass and a small white vase with purple flowers.

text: Verizon and AT&T reported their quarterly earnings in the last week, and they told nearly identical stories: Both are making a lot of money just from mobile data — the fees customers pay to reach the Internet over their networks. Some numbers shared by AT&T make it clear why.

headline: A Musical Son of the South Is Mourned in Woodstock

headline: Up Front
text: This week, Mohsin Hamid reviews Nell Freudenberger’s novel “The Newlyweds,” about an American man and a Bang­ladeshi woman who meet over the Internet and, despite the geographic and cultural gulfs between them, decide to marry. Hamid, the author of two novels, is himself a traverser of borders, having grown up mostly in Lahore, Pakistan, where he now lives, with stints in London and the United States. In addition to writing fiction, he is a prolific essayist on culture and politics for publications including The Guardian of London, Time magazine and The New York Review of Books. “I’m a political animal,” he told us via e-mail. “How the pack hunts, shares its food, tends its wounded — these things matter to me. So I write about them. Fiction and nonfiction are just two different ways of lying to try to get at truths. Fiction lies by fabricating what isn’t there. Non­fiction lies by omitting what is. Doing both is useful: it keeps me aware of sentences, a novelist’s obsession, and the power of the void that surrounds them, a preoccupation of journalists.”

headline: Sierra Leone, 10 Years Later
text: Former Liberian President Charles G. Taylor was convicted on Thursday by an international tribunal of 11 counts of planning, aiding and abetting war crimes committed in Sierra Leone. Mr. Taylor, who was found guilty of crimes against humanity and war crimes, including murder, rape, slavery and the use of child soldiers, is the first head of state to be convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials.

headline: The Conviction of Charles Taylor
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on what the conviction of Charles Taylor means for Sierra Leone and for current brutal dictators and warlords.

headline: TimesCast | Murdoch Apologizes

headline: Amazon’s Earnings Decline 35% but Top Forecasts
text: SEATTLE — Investors in many other companies might panic upon hearing of a 35 percent drop in net income. When Amazon.com reported those results on Thursday, its shares went up almost 15 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Homegrown Lineup Strolls Home With a Win
text: Considering who the Mets are and all the nuttiness they have seen, perhaps it was inevitable that on a day they fielded their first homegrown lineup in 41 years they would earn a three-game sweep of the Miami Marlins in a delightful, but entirely dumbfounding, way.

headline: Electric East London
text: From fashion and flora to designers and drinks, you can find it here.

headline: 36 Hours in East London
text: KNOWN for its cutting-edge bars, offbeat galleries and ethnic restaurants, East London is by far the city’s trendiest area (just ask Ralph Fiennes and Keira Knightley, who both live here), crowded with shoppers during the day and clubbers at night. Wear comfortable walking (and dancing) shoes to discover its neighborhoods east of the Tower of London, namely, Shoreditch, Bethnal Green, Hackney Wick and Dalston. You’ll find some of London’s best fashion, craft and design businesses, mostly in renovated historic buildings and warehouses off leafy squares and winding streets. Though the current crop of creative merchants echo the area’s 18th-century history as a center for silk weaving and furniture making, East London’s artists today hail from anywhere but the past.

headline: Former State Senator Is Sentenced to 7 Years in Vast Bribery Case
text: Carl Kruger, the once-powerful New York State senator from Brooklyn who resigned his office in disgrace and pleaded guilty to corruption charges in December, was sentenced to seven years in prison on Thursday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

headline: The Never-to-Be Bride
text: I MET Dan, my future husband, in college when I was 20. But we never married. In fact, we were never engaged. Not even close. I say he was my future husband only because he was that important to me.

headline: Earnest Sailors Drop Anchor Among the Enemy
text: One of the hallmarks of “Whale Wars,” the Animal Planet reality series about conservationists doing battle with Japanese whalers on the high seas, is the anonymity of the animal lovers’ faceless and mostly silent enemy: crouched on the decks of its ships, seen at a distance through the mist and spray.

headline: Exhibits From 2 Artists in Their 70s
text: Nothing rewards a provocateur quite like the art world, but not every enfant terrible turns éminence grise. Two artists who have made that transition, however, currently have work on view in New York.

headline: Theater Listings: April 27 — May 3
text: Theater

headline: In New Federal Program to Reward Teachers, Flawed Assumptions
text: A social studies and English teacher in Brooklyn had an early look at a $5 billion federal grant program called Project Respect, whose goal will be, as Education Secretary Arne Duncan put it, "to make teaching not only America's most important profession, but also America's most respected profession." But, the teacher writes, while the goal is good, some of the assumptions are wrong -- especially those having to do with assessing good teaching and effective leaders.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Sound of My Voice'
text: Zal Batmanglij, the director of "Sound of My Voice," narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Senate Passes Reauthorization of Domestic Violence Law
text: The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act and expand its reach to American Indians and gay, bisexual and transgender domestic abuse victims, after Republicans opted to sidestep an expected partisan brawl.

headline: Drawings of Continental Drift
text: At first glance “Storied Past: Four Centuries of French Drawings From the Blanton Museum of Art,” at the Grey Art Gallery, looks like a dreary affair: a gathering of little-known draftsmen, almost all of them beholden to the Academy. Give it time, though, and like a dull professorial type after a few gin and tonics it may surprise you with sudden flights of vivacity.

headline: Stop Fishing for Lunch Dates
text: People often e-mail me saying: “I’d like to have lunch. Please send me some dates when you are free.” This drives me nuts. It assumes that I want to have lunch with them, and puts the responsibility on me to find a date. I miss the old days when people said, “Let’s have lunch next Thursday,” which gave me an out if I wanted one, or the chance to suggest another day if I felt like it. Your thoughts? Susan, Grand Rapids

headline: Elbow Surgery Is Likely for Pelfrey
text: Mike Pelfrey is almost assuredly headed for Tommy John surgery in the wake of a magnetic resonance imaging test that revealed a partial tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow, a development that could end his career with the Mets.

headline: The Medal of Freedom: Civil Rights Activists, War Heroes, Thin Mints
text: The Presidential Medal of Freedom is the highest honor a grateful nation, or at least president, has to bestow on a civilian. And it is a big deal, even bigger than the annual pardoning of a Thanksgiving turkey or the Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn.

headline: Groups Seek Senate Review of Universal-EMI Deal
text: 6:34 p.m. | Updated Opponents of the Universal Music Group’s $1.9 billion bid for EMI’s record labels are asking the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues to examine the deal, raising the possibility of Senate hearings.

headline: A Small-Town Murder by Just the Nicest Guy
text: “Bernie,” Richard Linklater’s gaudily vibrant, at times morbidly funny true-crime story, takes place in the East Texas town of Carthage, which, at the time when sweet Bernie Tiede (Jack Black) murdered sour Mrs. Nugent (Shirley MacLaine), had a population of 6,500. To judge from the movie and the Texas Monthly article that inspired it, nearly everyone in Carthage loved Bernie, including the minister who after the shooting preached that Bernie “needs to be with God, and he needs to know that we are with him.” The preacher didn’t say that Bernie needed to be in heaven to be with God. In the movie, at least, he seems to suggest that Carthage would do just fine.

headline: Presidential Medals to Dylan, John Glenn and 11 Others
text: President Obama plans to award the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 13 people, including Bob Dylan, John Glenn, Toni Morrison and John Paul Stevens, the White House announced Thursday.
