text: SECAUCUS, N.J.

headline: Better Chanted Than Read
text: IT starts with a man’s voice: “Ocean,” he intones, stretching the final consonant. There’s an echo, another presence. A woman begins to talk-sing, her vocals growing high and furious, building to a wail; someone pants, more voices appear, everything is louder and more frenzied. A wild, sustained choral shriek. Then, six minutes after it began, the man again: “Ocean.”

headline: Beaumarchais Revamped With Shades Of Revolution
text: The Manhattan School of Music has put on some demanding operas, but nothing as challenging to produce as John Corigliano’s “Ghosts of Versailles,” with a libretto by the playwright William M. Hoffman, which opened on Wednesday night before a sold-out house.

headline: Lovebirds in a Predictable Pickle: Silly but So What?
text: At the start of “The Five-Year Engagement,” Tom (Jason Segel) is about to propose to his girlfriend, Violet (Emily Blunt). He has an elaborate surprise planned, and when it is ruined (by his clumsy eagerness and Violet’s persistent curiosity), he goes through with it anyway. The romance of the evening is in no way diminished by Violet’s knowledge of what’s coming, and something similar could be said about this movie, directed by Nicholas Stoller from a script he wrote with Mr. Segel.

headline: Saving Spain’s Honor: Atlético and Bilbao Reach Europa League Final
text: A day after Real Madrid joined Barcelona on the exit ramp out of European competition, two Spanish clubs salvaged a bit of prestige for La Liga by advancing to the Europa League final.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Le Moulin à Café
text: During school hours, Le Moulin à Café becomes a colonial outpost for families whose children attend the Lycée Français de New York, a Francophone private school in Yorkville.

headline: Sherlock in the Spotlight
text: “Sherlock” has raised the profile of its star, Benedict Cumberbatch, who has upcoming roles in “The Hobbit” and the sequel to “Star Trek.”

headline: By the Lycée, a Soupçon of Home
text: THE older children have been dropped off at school. Only a few little ones are left, quietly tucking into their pains au chocolat and cranberry twists. It’s 8:40 a.m. on a scruffy stretch of York Avenue between East 76th and East 77th Streets. Now, over porcelain mugs of coffee and plenty of hot milk, the talking can begin.

headline: Gardening Tools, for Sowing or Reaping
text: Mark K. Morrison, a landscape architect with homes in upstate New York and Connecticut, has surrounded himself with 10,000 gardening implements. Dating back to the 1500s, they range from unwieldy scythes and beet hoes to fragile glass sheaths for forcing cucumbers to grow straight.

headline: A Diplomat Whose Language Is Song
text: SOMETIMES it takes the efforts of a few highbrow arts organizations to bring cultures together through music. In the case of Arif Lohar, it also doesn’t hurt to have some help from Coke.

headline: New York Radio Rivals Kiss-FM and WBLS to Merge
text: In a stunning change for New York radio listeners, Kiss-FM and WBLS — longtime rivals in the R&B format — have become one.

headline: An Afterlife for a Sculptor
text: In the second half of the 1960s Richard Serra, Eva Hesse and Bruce Nauman, among others, were carving out the afterlife of Minimalism. Bill Bollinger, then in his 20s and now the subject of revelatory exhibitions at the SculptureCenter and at Algus Greenspon Gallery, was one of those others.

headline: Investor’s Sale of Its Stake in Hulu Could Value the Business at $2 Billion
text: One of the original owners of Hulu, Providence Equity Partners, is selling its stake, people with knowledge of the impending sale said on Thursday.

headline: Spare Times for April 27 — May 3
text: Around Town

headline: Habitats | Grand Concourse
text: José Stevenson’s Bronx apartment is filled with reflections of his Cherokee and Puerto Rican heritage, family heirlooms and Victoriana left behind by previous owners.

headline: His Style? Autobiographical
text: THE moment you enter José Stevenson’s apartment on the Grand Concourse, you see an image you don’t expect to find in this corner of the Bronx. In a moody painting that hangs in the foyer, a herd of hulking golden buffalo chomp happily on a seemingly endless plain.

headline: A New Neighborhood, Not Too Tame
text: WHEN the opportunity arose to relocate to New York from Toronto, Melinda Lehman and her husband, Terry Iwaskiw, barely hesitated.

headline: Movie Listings for April 27 — May 3
text: Movies

headline: Vivid Guides to Unfamiliar Landscapes
text: We hunger after the otherworldly. We crave magic and interstellar travel, the surreal and the mysterious. We want to savor fear and awe in the same breath, and the high priests of pop culture do their best to keep us sated, whether it’s Stephen King, the “Twilight” franchise or “Avatar” in 3-D.

headline: The Caucus Click: A Birthday Wish From the First Lady
text: Michelle Obama answered questions from children of White House employees participating in Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day, and wished Danielle Falcon a happy birthday.

headline: Vivid Guides to Unfamiliar Landscapes
text: Six new art books convey a sense of the otherworldly.

headline: Pop Listings for April 27 — May 3
text: Pop

headline: Intoxicated by Language, a Poet Is Destroyed by Life
text: “I have seen the Word made Flesh,” the poet Hart Crane wrote to his friend, the novelist and literary critic Waldo Frank, in a letter from April 1924. The object of his worship, Emil Opffer, was a sailor in the merchant marine who spent months at sea while Crane remained in New York, pining and jealous.

headline: Military News Roundup: Afghanistan, Drones, Panetta and Anti-Islamic Themes in Military Courses
text: Today’s edition of The Times has quite a few military-related items.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 27 — May 3
text: Jazz

headline: Dealing With Student Debt
text: FOR many recent college graduates, the dream of owning a home may have to be postponed awhile as they first grapple with repaying mounds of education loans.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for April 27 — May 3
text: Classical

headline: Useful Vocabulary for Building Watchers
text: THE Streetscapes column is not big on terminology, but some is necessary; instead of embarrassing yourself by saying “those grooves on the side of a column,” impress your dinner partner and use the real term, fluting.

headline: A Piece of the Great Outdoors for Sale
text: THE high-priced outdoor space available at Toll Brothers’ newest condominium along the Hoboken waterfront in no way resembles a rolling meadow, or even a plot of grass. Nevertheless, demand has been brisk for the space — rooftop concrete patios surrounded by lattice-topped fences, and offering views of Manhattan.

headline: Golf: Pros and Cons of Proximity
text: BEFORE Ridgeway Golf Club in White Plains closed two years ago, it wasn’t unusual for neighbors to have to cope with broken windows and other damage caused by golfers’ wildly off-the-mark shots. And, recalled Terence Guerriere, who lives nearby, even when nothing was damaged, such incidents often resulted in the arrival of a search party, breaching the privacy of residents barbecuing or sunning themselves on a weekend afternoon.

headline: Recycling a Country Club
text: IN the late 1940s, when Levitt & Sons, the builders of Levittown, started a more upscale subdivision of 668 homes in Roslyn Heights known as the Roslyn Country Club, it sweetened the appeal of a house or lot purchase with the promise of a neighborhood country club exclusively for residents’ use, setting dues at $100 a year.

headline: Q & A
text: Renovated, Except for the Heat

headline: Dance Listings for April 27 — May 3
text: Dance

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley Sexism, and Apple After Jobs
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

headline: In Gramercy, Better Timing for Irish Developer
text: RESIDENTS of the Kips Bay and Gramercy neighborhoods may have thought the ghostly glass building wrapped in scaffolding at the corner of 23rd Street and Second Avenue was another casualty of the global real estate crisis.

headline: Who Loses and Who Profits When Sex Is a Commodity?
text: In case you have forgotten, all women are prostitutes, and all men are johns. Strip away the trappings of upscale bourgeois life, and a wife — even an upscale professional wife — is a household slave, expected to cook, clean and take care of the children. Her husband might deign to make love to her after she cooks a fancy dinner for his boss. All it takes for her to keep the peace is some well-timed flirtatious role-playing. But he has to initiate the amorous reward. Sounds very 1970s, doesn’t it?

headline: Laying the Tracks Others Followed
text: The handsome show of Frank Stella’s early paintings at L&M Arts could not be better timed. Abstract art, especially of a Minimalist mien, is on the uptick right now, with a few too many young artists acting as if they have invented the wheel, especially where brushy or severely simplified monochromes are concerned.

headline: The $100 Million Question
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Bill Bollinger
text: A look at an exhibition of the artist’s work at the SculptureCenter.

headline: Pirating for the Troops
text: One of the world’s most prolific bootleggers of Hollywood DVDs is a hero to overseas soldiers.

headline: ‘Terracotta Warriors’
text: Photographs from a new exhibition at Discovery Times Square in New York City.

headline: Grading the Graders: Human vs. Robot
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sure Bets
text: ODDS are 3-to-1 that when Edvard Munch’s “Scream” comes up for sale at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, it will fetch $150 million to $200 million. And there’s a 3-to-2 chance that pastel will become the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction, breaking the current record of $106.5 million set two years ago at Christie’s for Picasso’s “Nude, Green Leaves and Bust.” As for who will buy “The Scream,” bets are 5-to-2 that it will be a Russian, 3-to-1 an Asian or European and 4-to-1 an American. That’s the thinking, anyway, from Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking chain, which has been analyzing the fate of what Sotheby’s is billing as the most recognizable image in art history after the “Mona Lisa.”

headline: Photo Replay: April 26
text: A view of the day in sports, with tennis in Germany, auto racing in Argentina and soccer in Spain.

headline: On the Block
text: A look at some of the artworks up for auction this spring.

headline: Spring Auctions
text: Several highly recognizable works up for sale at Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips de Pury over the next two weeks.

headline: A Murderer Tapping at His Chamber Door
text: Edgar Allan Poe died in Baltimore in October 1849, by most accounts in a state of dissipation and despair. “The Raven,” a new movie directed by James McTeigue (“V for Vendetta”; “Ninja Assassin”), differs from most accounts by imagining Poe in his final days as a heroic crime fighter, tracking down a diabolical serial killer with the tenacious ingenuity of the special agents on “Criminal Minds.”

headline: Life of a Salesman
text: Gonna make a record in the month of May* — well, actually, gonna sell a book publishing Monday. That means a couple of weeks of frantic promotion, starting with All Things Considered tomorrow, This Week and the 92nd Street Y on Sunday, and much much more.

headline: Mercedes’s Trash Talk at IHT Sports Summit
text: ISTANBUL — I was so disappointed when the Turkish Grand Prix was cut from the Formula One calendar this year that I wondered how I would get back to one of my favorite venues for a race: Istanbul. The answer came quickly when the International Herald Tribune decided to hold its inaugural Sports Business Summit in Istanbul.

headline: The Guru in the Basement Promises a Journey to ... Something
text: Nobody is gutted in “Sound of My Voice,” a smart, effectively unsettling movie about the need to believe and the hard, cruel arts of persuasion. But over time the men and women who meet in a mysterious house in an anonymous Los Angeles neighborhood — where they shed their clothes and cleanse their bodies in a ritual — are opened up bit by bit, wound by wound, until they’re sobbing and laughing, their insides smeared across the carpet.

headline: How to Apply for a Student Visa to Study in the United States
text: Martin Bennett, the EducationUSA outreach coordinator at the Institute of International Education, offers advice for international students on how to obtain a student visa.

headline: Machismo, Obtained via Machete
text: “Fight until our blood runs out! The heavenly home of our ancestors, here we come!” That battle cry prefaces a desperate, suicidal run across a fragile bridge by aboriginal warriors to confront the Japanese Army in the Taiwanese historical epic “Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale.” Its words embody the primitive philosophy of warfare glorified by this unabashedly nationalistic film.

headline: Secret Service Agent’s Plea in Colombia Proved True
text: WASHINGTON — In the hours after a Secret Service employee got into a dispute with a prostitute at a hotel in Colombia two weeks ago, high-ranking officials with the agency pored over hotel records.

headline: 3 Settings, 3 Countries and the World of Women Who Live by Their Bodies
text: “I picked up a client. He was 20 or 21 years old. After he was done with me, I had a one-legged man. After him came an old grandpa with a white beard. Right after the old man, I got another customer. He mishandled me, and I got very angry. I told him, ‘You may never come back to my room.’ More followed after that, about 10 clients all together.”

headline: For the Love of the Technology, the Bay Area Is Reinventing Baseball (Again)
text: A decade ago, as portrayed in the book and movie “Moneyball,” the Athletics put a new spin on the game of baseball through statistics and data. A new generation of baseball executives huddled around computers in Oakland and threw out century-old scouting traditions, relying instead on technology to select undervalued players in the 2002 Major League Baseball draft.

headline: Images of a Ballet Company Moving Through History
text: All the words in all the books about any art form are but suggestions of what they’re trying to describe. They’re useful, but you have to experience the stuff. And that’s the worthy pull of “Joffrey: Mavericks of American Dance”: visions of a company moving through history.

headline: His Wig May Be Askew, but This Singer Has Range
text: When Carletta Sue Kay takes the stage, it can take the unin-itiated by surprise. The singer is over six feet tall, with a figure more like a wrestler’s than an ingénue’s, and is typically a mess: wig askew, vintage dress often missing a sleeve or other homemade alterations, red lipstick unevenly applied.

headline: One Black Man’s Actions as a Piece of Civil Rights History
text: Early in Raymond De Felitta’s documentary of the 1960s-era South, “Booker’s Place: A Mississippi Story,” a couple of tales are quickly told about black men who were shot or beaten for their transgressions against whites: one for inadvertently brushing his mop against a woman’s foot, another for touching someone’s car. The anecdotes lay down the law as it stood shortly before the time Booker Wright, a black waiter, made the fateful decision to explain to a documentary crew for NBC News not only what he served white customers but also how he felt about their varied treatment of him.

headline: The N.F.L. Draft
text: The 2012 N.F.L. draft took place at Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

headline: The Netherlands: Budget Agreement Meets the European Union’s Targets
text: The Netherlands defied expectations of a prolonged budget crisis on Thursday, rolling out an agreement to meet European Union mandates less than a week after a dispute over austerity measures led to the collapse of Prime Minister Mark Rutte’s government. That collapse opened the door to elections in September that could help decide the future of the euro. Finance Minister Jan Kees de Jager said the budget deal brought the target for reducing the deficit next year to 3 percent of gross domestic product “into sight.” Parliament was expected to debate the measures late into the night Thursday, but with the backing of 77 votes in the 150-seat lower house, the budget put forth by Mr. Rutte, who will serve in a caretaker capacity until elections, appeared certain to go through essentially intact. NOS television, the Dutch state broadcaster, said the deal called for a lower mortgage-interest tax deduction, a freeze on public sector wages and increased “sin taxes,” among other things.

headline: Martial Arts Fighter Tackles the Russian Mob
text: Poor Jason Statham. Could we ask for a better action star? More graceful than Steven Seagal, more droll than Jet Li, more charming than Bruce Willis. And, as “Transporter 3” proved, more adept at sparring romantically than most. So how dispiriting to see him underserved once again, with a clattery vehicle like Boaz Yakin’s “Safe.”

headline: City Council Is Set to Encourage Greener Buildings With Zoning Changes
text: New York City is about to update its zoning regulations to catch up with the Bloomberg administration’s environmental image and to make it easier for buildings to insulate exterior walls, install solar panels and put gardens on rooftops.

headline: Four Young People, One Crime and a Night Gone Wrong
text: Dre (Evan Ross) is a smart, by-the-bootstraps high school senior, someone on his way out of the ’hood into the bigger world. So when his girlfriend begs him not to hang out with his delinquent buddies, you know that he will and that there will be trouble. Actually, you’ve already seen the trouble.

headline: Starbucks Sales in China Contribute to Earnings Rise
text: The Starbucks Corporation, the ubiquitous coffee company, grew strongly in the quarter that ended April 1, propelled by more traffic in its stores and big increases in sales of its products through channels like grocery and warehouse stores.

headline: An Oakland V.A. Official to Address Claim Delays
text: Douglas Bragg, the director of the Department of Veterans Affairs’s Oakland Regional Office, will appear next month before members of the California Congressional delegation to answer questions about the performance of his office, which handles all disability claims filed by veterans from Bakersfield to the Oregon border.

headline: Should Israel Act Alone for Peace?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trailing Toronto’s War Veteran Turned Bank Robber
text: From its opening shot of a quotation by the Argentine writer José Narosky — “In war, there are no unwounded soldiers” — “Citizen Gangster” announces its sympathies. Drawing on the exploits of Edwin Boyd, a Canadian World War II veteran who became that country’s most infamous bank robber, this unusually cerebral crime movie chooses psychic pain over public-enemy thrills.

headline: N.Y.U.’s Expansion Plan, as Seen by Its Leaders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tribeca: ‘War Witch’ and ‘Una Noche’ Take Top Prizes at Film Festival
text: “War Witch,” the director Kim Nguyen’s feature about a kidnapped African girl who becomes a child soldier, was named the best narrative feature at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival, and its star, Rachel Mwanza, was named best actress, the festival’s organizers announced at a ceremony on Thursday night.“Una Noche,” a film by Lucy Mulloy about Cuban teens who dream of fleeing Havana for Miami, won the best actor prize, which was split between two of its leads, Dariel Arrechada and Javier Nuñez Florián; Ms. Mulloy was also named best new narrative director for the film, which additionally was cited for best cinematography in a narrative feature film. (As was reported earlier this week, Mr. Nuñez and another star of the film, Anailín de la Rúa de la Torre, disappeared as they were traveling from Cuba to the festival.)

headline: A Visit to White House
text: To the Editor:

headline: Family of Robert G. Morvillo to Start a Law Firm in His Honor
text: Robert G. Morvillo, the prominent white-collar defense lawyer who died late last year, left behind a legacy of fierce advocacy on behalf of his powerful clients and a family of lawyers to carry the mantle.

headline: How to Evaluate Colleges
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Beaten Teenager Seeks Solace in Another Species
text: In defiance of its rather twee title, the documentary “Dolphin Boy” is admirably opposed to mystical pronouncements about the man-beast connection it so carefully records. More grounded in simple observation than in fanciful theories, this effortlessly engaging story of sudden tragedy and halting recovery wisely focuses on the facts and leaves the wonder to the audience.

headline: European Regulator Warns Silicon Valley About Privacy
text: The European data protection supervisor, Peter Hustinx, on Thursday urged technology companies to “innovate” in the area of consumer privacy, saying that lawmakers on the continent would press ahead on a contentious proposed law that would, in part, compel companies to pare down the personal data kept in their digital vaults.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Attorney General in Mexico Will Investigate Wal-Mart
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican government on Thursday stepped up its response to the bribery allegations that have been tied to Wal-Mart’s breakneck growth here, announcing that the federal attorney general’s office would begin an investigation into the company’s actions.

headline: Warlords Beware
text: It took a decade, but an international court on Thursday convicted the former Liberian president, Charles Taylor, for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Sierra Leone’s horrifying civil war. This is a historic victory for justice and accountability: the first time a former head of state has been convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials after World War II. Mr. Taylor, who will be sentenced in coming weeks, richly deserves this distinction.

headline: Underachievers Stumble Into Romantic Bliss
text: Celebrating aimless adults who prefer to sponge off the hard work of others is a dispiritingly persistent trend in American entertainment. In HBO’s much-yammered-about “Girls,” the lead character is stunned when her fed-up parents refuse to donate $1,100 a month to support her two-year quest for self-knowledge, and in “The Giant Mechanical Man,” underachieving paves the road to romantic bliss.

headline: Bands and Pop Singers Join Fight Against  Backpage.com Ads
text: More than a dozen prominent pop singers and rock bands have joined a campaign aimed at forcing The Village Voice to stop running ads on Backpage.com for escorts, strip-clubs and other “adult services,” a publicist for the campaign said. The list of bands who have signed a petition against the ads includes the former members of R.E.M and the members of the Roots, Alabama Shakes, the Civil Wars and Drive-By Truckers. Among the singers who have lent their support are Alicia Keys, Rosanne Cash and Talib Kweli.

headline: Running the World With Eyes Wide Open
text: Jesper Olsen, a 40-year-old from Denmark, runs the equivalent of a marathon most days. He eschews iPods and is on his 25th pair of running shoes as he strings the long runs together in his second run around the world. Call him a real-life Forrest Gump and he playfully rolls his eyes.

headline: Making a New Life in a Seamy New York
text: It’s almost a disappointment when anyone speaks in Andrew Dosunmu’s evocative debut feature, “Restless City,” which could nearly tell its simple story without words. Djbril (Sy Alassane), an aspiring singer and Canal Street peddler, may move through a gray-market immigrant world of pirated CDs and sketchy back rooms, but everyone and everywhere looks fashion-spread terrific, thanks to the serenely muted colors and elegant, wide-screen compositions by the cinematographer Bradford Young.

headline: After Quiet Years, British Regulator Gets Tough on Abuses
text: LONDON — Britain’s securities regulator once had a reputation for taking a light-touch approach to regulation.

headline: A Corporate Big Shot With a Sideline in Art Theft
text: “Headhunters” is the first screen adaptation of a book by Jo Nesbo, the Norwegian novelist best known for his crime series starring a loose-cannon detective. This relentless new film, which does not feature the detective Harry Hole, is ostensibly a stand-alone tale, unless you count the planned American remake. But its justifiably paranoid protagonist suffers enough punishing twists for two or three movies.

headline: In Democratic Primary, Taking On a Dallas Institution
text: It takes a lot of nerve to run in a Democratic primary against a 20-year incumbent, especially a Dallas institution like Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson.

headline: An Incomplete Justice
text: THE verdict delivered Thursday against Charles G. Taylor for crimes against humanity ends a saga that began on Christmas Eve 1989, when Mr. Taylor and a group of Libyan-trained followers invaded Liberia, igniting a regional conflagration that eventually engulfed parts of Sierra Leone, Guinea and Ivory Coast.

headline: In Congress, a Move to Look Into a Medical Debt Collector
text: A California representative is calling for an investigation into Accretive Health, one of the nation’s largest collectors of medical debt, for potentially violating a federal law that requires hospitals to provide emergency care regardless of citizenship, legal status or the ability to pay.

headline: Lousy but Not Lovable Bobcats
text: By every way you can measure, the Charlotte Bobcats are a spectacularly bad team. They spent the last part of their regular season compiling a staggering 23-game losing streak and clinching the N.B.A. record for worst winning percentage. They have lost to good teams by large margins and to mediocre teams by almost-as-large margins. After losing to the Knicks in their season finale, 104-84, on Thursday night, they have not won since March 17.

headline: At 92, a Bandit to Hollywood but a Hero to Soldiers
text: MASSAPEQUA, N.Y. — One of the world’s most prolific bootleggers of Hollywood DVDs loves his morning farina. He has spent eight years churning out hundreds of thousands of copies of “The Hangover,” “Gran Torino” and other first-run movies from his small Long Island apartment to ship overseas.

headline: S.&P. Cuts Its Rating on Spain, Citing Debt
text: Standard & Poor’s downgraded Spain’s credit rating on Thursday, saying that the country’s sovereign debt levels were too high and that its banks would need an infusion of aid as the country’s economy contracted.

headline: The Reading Renaissance
text: SEATTLE — Satan in Seattle, as the walking wounded of the book business describe Amazon.com, continues to expand from the shores of Lake Union here, with nearly a dozen new office buildings housing the global nerve center of earth’s largest online retailer.

headline: Out With the Old, in With the Inexperienced
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Small Screens, Big Dollars
text: THE annual spring upfronts, when television peddles its wares to Madison Avenue, has a new twist ahead of the 2012-13 season: Media companies that specialize in online video and other digital delights are adding themselves to the lineup of presentations by broadcast and cable TV outlets.

headline: How Many Terrorists in This Cell?
text: The young man sat at the defense table behind a great cloud of a beard, an unblinking stone, as his lawyer argued that he was not guilty. Just the victim of desperate criminals, who needed to sell someone to save their own miserable skins, so they ratted out their high school buddy.

headline: Hockey Loss Sets Off Slurs, and Boston Asks, ‘Again?’
text: BOSTON — The game-winning goal that Joel Ward of the Washington Capitals scored against the Boston Bruins in overtime on Wednesday did two things, both embarrassing to Boston. It knocked the reigning champion Bruins out of the N.H.L. playoffs, and it unleashed a flurry of Twitter slurs against Mr. Ward that summoned an old, familiar image of this city as a den of racist white sports fans.

headline: Conference Leaders Agree to Pursue 4-Team Playoff
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — College football is on the cusp of a major shift, but for now, the changing language of the game’s power brokers offers hope to those clamoring for a better way to decide a national champion.

headline: Testifying, Murdoch Cites a ‘Cover-Up’ in Phone Hacking
text: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch criticized many different people for many different things in a morning of scrappy and often blunt testimony before a judicial panel here on Thursday. But in the most explosive criticism of all, he unexpectedly accused at least one former employee of presiding over a “cover-up” of phone hacking and other dubious practices at The News of the World tabloid.

headline: Intrigue in Chongqing
text: St. Louis

headline: City Decides to Spare School of Second Chances
text: The schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, retreated on Thursday from a plan to shut down a last-chance high school for students who have dropped out or have failed at traditional schools.

headline: Is Our Adults Learning?
text: In 2009, we had a big debate about whether to pass a stimulus package. Many esteemed and/or Nobel Prize-winning economists like Joseph Stiglitz, Larry Summers and Christina Romer argued that it would help lift the economy out of recession. Many other esteemed and/or Nobel Prize-winning economists like Robert Barro, Edward Prescott and James Buchanan argued that positive effects would be small and the package wouldn’t be worth the long-term cost.

headline: Jaguars’ Owner Is Subject of Environmental Protest
text: When Shahid R. Khan bought the Jacksonville Jaguars late last year for $760 million, he was portrayed as an American success story: an immigrant who worked at an auto parts plant, later bought it and eventually became a billionaire.

headline: Woman, Fighter, Philosopher
text: I first met the renowned Yale professor Ruth Barcan Marcus in the ladies’ room at the Marlboro Music Festival during the summer of 1977. As a music major in Yale College I had taken only a few philosophy courses, and none with Marcus. But word of the arrival in 1973 of the formidable philosopher had reached even the musty practice rooms in the bowels of Harkness Hall; and I had seen her several times, from a safe distance, on campus. Perhaps because this initial encounter occurred on musical rather than philosophical terrain, I managed to ask the woman adjusting her collar in the mirror next to me whether she was Ruth Marcus, “the famous logician.” She laughed and said yes, and then asked what I planned to do with my Yale degree. I told her I wanted to go to graduate school in philosophy, but feared that a major in music, rather than philosophy, would be an obstacle. She replied, “I don’t see why that should stop you.”

headline: In China, a Fall From Grace May Aid a Rise to Power
text: BEIJING — When Xi Jinping, the vice president of China and its presumed next leader, returned from a crucial image-polishing tour of the United States in February, he faced an even more delicate matter at home.

headline: Now Off Case, Judge Weighs In on Dams
text: SEATTLE — A federal judge who spent a decade presiding over one of the most contentious environmental court fights in the Northwest — the fate of endangered salmon in the Columbia River Basin and four hydroelectric dams that interrupt their migration — has said in a recorded interview that the dams should be removed to help the fish.

headline: Gingrich Is Quitting the Race (Just Give Him a Little Time)
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Newt Gingrich arrived at the Penske Racing plant here on Thursday accompanied by a large security detail protecting him from a big threat — of rain.

headline: ESPN Radio Plans a Move to FM in New York
text: For 11 years, ESPN has built its New York radio outpost at 1050 AM, using local and national shows to challenge the power of the older, more established WFAN, which resides down the AM dial at 660.

headline: A Fallen Politician, Sympathetic Unto Himself
text: Save for the fact that he pitied himself far more than you could hope to match, Carl Kruger almost presented a sympathetic portrait of a man consumed with remorse.

headline: One Called Upon To Decide
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Not a bad way to work our way into the weekend puzzles. A fresh and crunchy Friday by Patrick Berry, with some lovely new entries, clues tightened up for an end-of-week solve, and enough wordplay to keep any solver happy. Life is good.

headline: If You Can’t Tell Your Cook From Your Mistress, What Do You Nibble?
text: Can I blame Mark Rylance?

headline: Sneaky Preacher, Without a Prayer
text: Say amen, somebody. Or, better yet, just whimper the word. We’ve finally come to the end of a hard-run overcrowded spring on Broadway. And here, to sound the final trumpet, is one last musical, a show that appropriately expresses how many a dedicated theatergoer must be feeling right now: plumb tuckered out.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 26, 2012

headline: Culture Warriors Don’t Win
text: Mitt Romney’s apparent nomination proves that Republican voters are more pragmatic and centrist than their reputation suggests. The Republican candidates this year fought a classic political battle. Rick Santorum, Newt Gingrich and Ron Paul campaigned as purists, echoing Henry Clay’s famous expression from 1844, “I’d rather be right than president.” The realist Romney updated the belief of nineteenth-century partisans that a candidate’s most important ability is what they called his “availability,” as in “his ability to avail” – and prevail.

headline: 3 Troopers Are Suspended Amid Sex Inquiry
text: Three New York state troopers were suspended on Thursday without pay amid an investigation into whether one of them had organized parties that might have involved prostitution, according to a statement by the State Police.

headline: Senate Votes to Reauthorize Domestic Violence Act
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act and expand its reach to American Indians and homosexuals, after Republicans opted to sidestep an expected partisan brawl.

headline: Opening the Broadcasters’ Books
text: Television stations have been making a lot more money from campaign ads since the Supreme Court helped lift the limits on contributions to political groups. The public, though, has been kept in the dark about how much these groups and the so-called super PACs are spending, and where they are spending it, because the stations don’t want to make it easy to find out how much they are being paid for those ads.

headline: Death of a Fairy Tale
text: This was the month the confidence fairy died.

headline: Student Loan Debate Becomes Election-Year Fight
text: WASHINGTON — The subject of interest rates on subsidized college loans, once reserved for the deep weeds of Congressional committees, has touched off a blazing battle between Democrats and Republicans at a volume usually reserved for debates over tax cuts or immigration.

headline: Defense Minister Adds to Israel’s Recent Mix of Messages on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — One day after Israeli newspapers reported that the nation’s top general had said economic and diplomatic pressures against Iran were beginning to succeed, his superior, Defense Minister Ehud Barak, said Thursday that the chances “appear low” that the Iranian government would bow to international pressure and halt its nuclear program.

headline: A Year in the Life of Social Security
text: The trustees of Social Security reported this week that absent reforms, the system will be able to pay full benefits until 2033 — versus 2036 in last year’s report — and three-fourths of benefits after that. One of the reasons for the grim new projection is the increase in oil prices, which the trustees assumed are here to stay and will exert a drag on the economy and worker pay for decades to come. Less pay means less tax revenue for the system.

headline: Robert Bork, Romney Standard-Bearer
text: Robert Bork has been among the most divisive figures in American law and a right-wing standard-bearer in Republican politics for nearly 40 years. In 1973, when he was solicitor general, he fired Archibald Cox as special prosecutor on the order of Richard Nixon to aid the Watergate cover-up. When Ronald Reagan nominated him to the Supreme Court in 1987, the Senate rejected him by a vote of 58 to 42, the largest margin in American history.

headline: Game 7 Worthy of Salute
text: Game 7 lived up to its billing Thursday night at a raucous Madison Square Garden. The Ottawa Senators desperately pressed for an equalizing goal in the third period. The Rangers frantically defended their goal, diving to block each shot. Henrik Lundqvist scrambled from post to post to make acrobatic saves. Each loose puck sparked pitched battles along the boards and behind the nets.

headline: Taylor’s Rule in Liberia
text: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and once a powerful warlord, was convicted of abetting rebels who committed war crimes in Sierra Leone in the 1990s.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Reduce Size of Force on Okinawa
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Japan have reached agreement on a long-simmering dispute that calls for the American military to reduce the number of Marines on Okinawa by 9,000 and begin returning land to the government there, senior officials announced on Thursday.

headline: Romney Uses ‘Cold War Prism,’ Biden Says in Foreign Policy Attack
text: Shifting the battle with Mitt Romney from jobs and taxes to the safer realm of foreign policy, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traveled to New York City on Thursday to praise President Obama as the man who got Osama bin Laden and to paint Mr. Romney as a cold war relic who would leave American troops stranded in Afghanistan.

headline: After Restful Final Game, Knicks Head to Miami

headline: With G.O.P.’s Ear, Rubio Pushes Dream Act Proposal
text: MIAMI — When Senator Marco Rubio first floated his compromise version of the Dream Act — the bill, now stalled, that would grant some students in the United States illegally a path to citizenship — the chances of reviving the politically charged issue in Congress seemed as dim as the chances of snuffing out attack ads on the campaign trail.

headline: U.S. Sees Positive Signs From China on Security Issues

headline: Pete Fornatale, a Pioneer of FM Rock, Dies at 66

He was 66.

headline: A (Free) Cultural Festival Known for Its Hip Quotient Opens in Hong Kong
text: Liberatum has been organizing cultural festivals around the globe for 10 years, and it’s finally launching its first one in Hong Kong. From Friday through Sunday, the festival will feature panels with the international icons Pharrell Williams and V.S. Naipaul alongside Hong Kong filmmakers, musicians and designers. The program also includes short films by Mike Figgis and Guy Bourdin, as well as a musical performance by the Hong Kong New Ensemble.

headline: Elise Testone Is Ousted From ‘Idol’ on Queen Week

headline: Georgia: One-Year Sentence in Killing
text: A white man who shot to death a 22-year-old black man who had sneaked into his home to party with the homeowner’s teenaged relative and her younger friend was sentenced to a year in a state detention center and nine years of probation on Thursday, said Hayward Altman, the district attorney for Georgia’s middle judicial circuit. Mr. Altman originally charged the man, Norman Neesmith, 62, with seven offenses, among them murder and false imprisonment. The charges were reduced in a plea bargain. The parents of the dead man, Justin Patterson, believed the shooting in January 2011 and the sentence were racially motivated. Mr. Altman said the case had elements of self-defense and was complicated by the fact that one of the girls was 14, although she told Mr. Patterson and his younger brother, who was also at the house that night, that she was 18.

headline: At a Bronx Vigil Nearly a Year After a Killing, a Man Is Shot Dead
text: Nearly a year ago, Michael Ikoli emerged from his apartment building on Webster Avenue in the Bronx and was shot dead. Wednesday would have been his 25th birthday, and a couple dozen friends gathered in front of his building to pay their respects. They lighted candles, dozens of them.

headline: Join Us to Talk About the N.F.L. Draft
text: So the first two picks of the N.F.L. draft went as expected and then the wheeling and dealing got started. On Monday at Noon Eastern time, Judy Battista and Mike Tanier, two of the Times’s football writers, will take stock of what happened over the next 220 selections during a Google Plus video hangout. And we would like to invite selected readers to join them in the discussion. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to let us know, and include a link to your Google-plus profile page. Please note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile, a video camera-enabled computer, and you will have to follow the Times in Google plus. If you cannot join us at that time, feel free to leave a question you would like answered and be sure to check back on The Fifth Down on Monday afternoon to watch a video of the hangout.

headline: The Sun Shines Today for New ‘Annie’ Star
text: Eleven-year-old actress Lilla Crawford will star as musical theater’s most famous orphan in this fall’s Broadway revival of “Annie,” the producers said on Friday. Ms. Crawford, a Los Angeles native, made her Broadway debut last year playing Debbie in the cast of “Billy Elliot” before it closed this winter. She was selected to play Annie after a nine-month star search that included 5,000 auditions across the United States and via online video.

headline: Markets Shrug Off a Disappointing G.D.P. Number
text: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index capped its best week in a month as retailers surged to a record and improving corporate earnings and consumer confidence tempered lower-than-forecast economic growth.

headline: A Humble Letter
text: Dear Diary:I started a long teaching career at Grover Cleveland High School in Queens, more than a little awed by the fact it was bigger than my hometown. At that time, the federal government made money available for field trips and, upon discovering none of my 9th or 10th graders had ever been on a field trip or even traveled much in the city, I set about planning to take them to what I considered its most beautiful place, the Cloisters.

headline: The Get | Mannin’s Monogram Pendant Necklace
text: There’s a lot of uncertainly surrounding Emily Blunt’s character, Violet, in the new romantic comedy “The Five-Year Engagement,” which opens in theaters today. What’s solid: the monogram necklace she wears in every scene, from her engagement to Tom (played by Jason Segel) to their wedding day. Designed by Suzanne Donegan, the Los Angeles-based jeweler behind the elegant and understated fine jewelry line Mannin, Blunt’s pretty gold pendant is as symbolic as it is stylish. (A newly affianced woman wearing a keepsake that bears what will soon be her maiden name’s initials? One doesn’t need a psychologist to connect those dots.) “The pendant has everlasting value,” Donegan says. “It feels good to wear, emotionally and physically.” Till death do us part.

headline: Looking for the English on London Menus
text: MOCK English food all you like. But the local food thing is almost as inbred in England as it is in France; it just sometimes hides behind poverty, war or a fatal attraction to (as they call it) America. Today there are literally dozens of restaurants featuring not only fish from the Channel, the North Atlantic and the North Sea, but local beef and pork. Meanwhile, there is lamb from Wales and Scotland, and produce from everywhere.

headline: What We’re Reading
