headline: My London, and Welcome to It
text: IF you’ve saved this article for your long-planned trip to London, and you’re now reading it for the third time, circling Heathrow, well, I’m sorry. You’re probably still up there because the queue at passport control has become mutinous. They’re snaking out onto the runways — grim, silently furious visitors, unable to use their phones, forbidden from showing anything but abject acquiescence to the blunt instrument that is the immigration officer at the distant desk.

headline: 11 Olympics, and Counting
text: GEORGE REED-DELLINGER watched his first Olympics on television in 1960 when he was 13. Sixteen years later he saw the Montreal Games live. “To be there in person, there’s nothing like it,” he said. “I’m getting goose bumps just thinking about it.”

headline: A ‘Buzz’ in Bermondsey
text: A 58,000-square-foot art space, a 95-story skyscraper and other attractions are sending a charge into this London neighborhood.

headline: Choice Tables, London
text: Mark Bittman went hunting for English cooking in London. Here’s a taste of what he found.

headline: School Aide Accused of Abuse Is Freed, but Investigation Continues
text: 1:54 p.m. | Updated  A teacher’s aide accused of molesting an 8-year-old girl was freed on Thursday night after the Manhattan district attorney’s office deferred prosecution of him, an official there said.

headline: At England’s Edge
text: Top-shelf art and a dramatic seaside setting lure visitors to remote St. Ives.

headline: Who Made That Mason Jar?
text: Before a New Jersey-born son of a Scottish farmer named John Landis Mason patented his jar in 1858, home-food preservation was a tricky affair. Modern heat-based canning, pioneered by a Frenchman in 1806, was too cumbersome for most home cooks, many of whom relied on cork-and-wax contraptions to seal food, often imperfectly, into vessels whose opaque walls rendered the contents invisible.

headline: Why Afghan Women Risk Death to Write Poetry
text: In a private house in a quiet university neighborhood of Kabul, Ogai Amail waited for the phone to ring. Through a plate-glass window, she watched the sinking sun turn the courtyard the color of eggplant. The electricity wasn’t working and the room was unheated, a few floor cushions the only furnishings. Amail tucked her bare feet underneath her and pulled up the collar of her puffy black coat. Her dark hair was tied in a ponytail, and her eyelids were coated in metallic blue powder. In the green glare of the mobile phone’s screen, her face looked wan and worried. When the phone finally bleeped, Amail shrieked with joy and put on the speakerphone. A teenage girl’s voice tumbled into the room. “I’m freezing,” the girl said. Her voice was husky with cold. To make this call, she’d sneaked out of her father’s mud house without her coat.

headline: So Long, Farewell
text: After reading The Ethicist, I started a feature in my high-school newspaper called The Moralist. But I feel conflicted offering advice that I myself would be unable to follow. I feel even worse when others comment on this contradiction. Under the assumption that nobody is perfect, how do you reconcile your human faults with the guidance you dispense in your column? LARRY MILSTEIN, SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Gabriel Kahane Is a One-Man Cultural Cuisinart
text: The concert was over, and Gabriel Kahane was standing in his dressing room at Carnegie Hall, dripping with sweat. He had soaked through the T-shirt he performed in — a deep V-neck with “Maybe I should call you when I get back from New York” written on it in a loopy script — and his mop of curly hair was matted down.

headline: After the Agony of Youth, the Ecstasy of Surfing
text: When I was 8, my parents divorced and my mother married a man whose career took us from Washington to Melbourne Beach, a town on the “Space Coast” of Central Florida, where I learned to surf.

headline: St. Ives, Where Art Meets the Ocean
text: SPRING colors glowed: robin’s-egg blues, daffodil yellows and succulent greens balanced by far-off reflections from the sand and surf. Whenever I stopped for directions on the road leading out of St. Ives, about five and a half hours from London, another broad Cornish accent encouraged me to continue farther up the hill, until I finally reached the gates of the Leach Pottery, the historic ceramics studio founded there in 1920.

headline: The Shark Jumper
text: What struck me most about your new memoir, “My Happy Days in Hollywood,” in which you recount creating shows like “The Odd Couple” and “Happy Days,” is that you still talk to your sister Penny. It sounds as if she made your life hell during “Laverne and Shirley.”  Yeah, that was my worst show experience. The ’70s were druggy years on a lot of shows. It was just a mess, but of course I still talk to her. I don’t think you can tell your family that you can’t come in the house. I’ve always tried to make people happy — the only one I totally didn’t was my sister. That’s one of the reasons I did “Beaches.” Women say things to each other, and the next day they go shopping. Men say things to each other, and they don’t talk for 30 years.

headline: My Son Went to Heaven, and All I Got Was a No. 1 Best Seller
text: At 3 years 10 months, Colton Burpo was a sunny child, a preacher’s son certain of his faith and his eternal fate. Then his appendix burst, and as doctors failed to figure out what was wrong with him, he lay in a hospital bed until his father, Todd, saw “the shadow of death” cross his face. “I recognized it instantly,” Todd, a pastor, recalls. With Colton’s face “covered in death,” Todd and his wife, Sonja, took the boy to another hospital, where he was wheeled into surgery. “He’s not in good shape,” the surgeon said. As Colton screamed for his father, Todd fled, locked himself in a room and railed at God.

headline: The Steinway Way
text: Inside the piano factory.

headline: The 4.15.12 Issue
text: The New York Times published a swell piece that, as such pieces must, made it clear that Caro is the most unusual and perhaps the best biographer of our age. If it is madness to spend nearly 40 years writing about L.B.J., then it is a special and useful madness. . . . “The Years of Lyndon Johnson” has become such an unusual quest that the obsession gains value independent of the finished product. Actually, that should be “published product,” not “finished.” Caro never finishes a book; he has it taken away from him. Eventually.

headline: Amid Shouts of Hecklers, Barclays’ Board Apologizes to Shareholders
text: 10:36 a.m. | Updated

headline: J. Crew Goes Hardcore
text: Surely somebody has noticed that the old 9:30 Club building in Washington, D.C., is soon to be a J. Crew store. Surely someone will claim this is somehow ‘‘ironic,’’ that the club that fostered the all-ages hardcore scene of Minor Threat, Government Issue and Fugazi will soon sell pairs of $140 Café Capri pants in geranium lace. I don’t see the big deal. But I worry about the smell.

headline: Parental Quandary: A Daughter Who Is Overweight, and Unaware
text: This week’s parental quandary comes from a father who’s intent on not becoming one of the parents Dr. Catherine Musemeche castigates for allowing their children’s weight and health to reach a point where gallbladder removal is the next obvious step. He wants to help his overweight 12-year-old daughter to change her lifestyle, and the numbers on the scale — but as far as he can tell, his daughter hasn’t noticed that she has a problem.

headline: An Introvert Steps Out
text: I awoke one January morning from uneasy dreams to find myself transformed. For seven blissful years I had spent my time reading, writing and researching a book about introversion. But the publication date had arrived, the idyll was over and my metamorphosis was complete. I was now that impossibly oxymoronic creature: the Public Introvert.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE COMPLETE POEMS,  by Philip Larkin. Edited by Archie Burnett. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $40.) The 90 pages of poems collected during Larkin’s lifetime, on which his reputation rests, are joined by others published and unpublished and by lengthy commentary.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE TRINITY SIX,  by Charles Cumming. (St. Martin’s Griffin, $14.99.) Cumming’s thriller posits a sixth double agent among the notorious spies from Trinity College, Cambridge, who infiltrated British intelligence and betrayed their country to the Soviet Union during the cold war. Convinced that the sixth spy’s death had been faked by MI6, Cumming’s hero, a rakish professor of Russian history, becomes enmeshed in a battle between Moscow and London.

headline: Unreconciled
text: Not shy of stepping straight into demanding terrain, Patrick Flanery sets his first novel, “Absolution,” in post-apartheid South Africa, where the horrific injustices of the past leak unavoidably forward. The end of apartheid may have put an end to state-sanctioned violence, but it signaled the beginning of an epidemic of a more personal kind of violence — a reactive, frustrated, untargeted revenge.

headline: Mythic Passions
text: To the long catalog of odd hybrids that inhabit Greek myth — the half-human, half-equine centaurs, the birdlike Harpies with their human faces, the man-eating Scylla with her doglike nether parts — we may now add Madeline Miller’s first novel, “The Song of Achilles.” In it, Miller has taken on an (appropriately) heroic task: to fashion a modern work of literature out of very ancient stories — specifically, the tale of the Greeks at Troy, one of the oldest and most seminal of all legends in the Western tradition. The idea of recasting the Greek classics began with the ancients themselves; Virgil’s “Aeneid” is, in many ways, both a rewriting of and a commentary on the Homeric epics. More recently, it has challenged ambitious writers like Mary Renault, whose 1958 novel “The King Must Die” brilliantly reimagined the Theseus legend as narrated by the hero himself, and David Malouf, whose terrific 2009 novel “Ransom” invents a moving episode toward the end of the “Iliad.” But in the case of Miller, who earned undergraduate and graduate degrees in classics at Brown, the epic reach exceeds her technical grasp. The result is a book that has the head of a young adult novel, the body of the “Iliad” and the hindquarters of Barbara Cartland.

headline: Social Networks of Disease
text: In “Partner to the Poor,” the medical anthropologist Paul Farmer writes that “the failure to contemplate social and economic aspects of epidemics stunts our understanding of them.” To this one might add: And hinders our ability to contain and defeat them. Craig Timberg, a journalist for The Washington Post, and Daniel Halperin, an epidemiologist and medical anthropologist at the University of North Carolina, have collaborated on “Tinderbox” precisely to explore these very aspects of the AIDS epidemic in Africa. They set out to identify why AIDS emerged when it did; why Africans were so disproportionally affected; and why some countries have succeeded in reducing infection rates while others have not.

headline: Mean Kids
text: Bully. Such a poisonous word for those of us who endured one. “Tormentor” feels more appropriate. What drives a person to torture another? To make life intolerable, until the bullied, dreading the thought of one more vicious homeroom encounter, can only wonder: Why is he doing it? When will it end? Will I make it through high school alive?

headline: The Dispossessed
text: When Thomas Bayly was a little boy, snuggled in his housekeeper’s lap, he asked her why she was called Hattie’s Mary. She told him it was her slave name and she’d chosen to keep it “as a way of always having her mother with her.” “Then he asked her what happened to her mother, and she answered that there are some questions you should never ask. You should never ask a prisoner what he did to get put in jail, never ask a widow whether she gets lonely in bed, and never ask a freed slave what happened to her family. Thomas was perhaps 4 when she gave him these answers, and he retained them until he could make sense of them, one by one.”

headline: Breaking Faith
text: From “God’s Controversy With New England,” Michael Wigglesworth’s 1662 call to repentance, to the latest campaign autobiography by a presidential aspirant, the jeremiad has been one of the most durable literary forms throughout American history. Typically, the author identifies some golden age, one just now dissolving in the rearview mirror; recounts the slippery path of declension; and then prescribes an amendment of ways in order to avert further disaster.

headline: The Secret of Our Non-success
text: Disappointing GDP number — we’re not growing fast enough to make any significant headway on reducing the output gap — but hey, no need for further Fed action.

headline: A Great Awakening
text: Secular Americans’ worst fears have come true: there is now scientific evidence that evangelical churches brainwash believers. They don’t merely teach that Adam and Eve actually existed and that gay marriage is an abomination. They change the way their members’ brains work. But T. M. Luhrmann, a psychological anthropologist at Stanford, argues that this is not as insidious as it sounds. On the contrary, mental conditioning has a noble lineage in the history of religion, and even (or especially) in this modern age, it can help humans flourish. “When God Talks Back” explains how rational people living in the 21st century can believe that God speaks to them — and why the rest of us should take them ­seriously.

headline: Playoff Preview: Eastern Conference
text: If the eight teams that qualified for postseason play out of the Eastern Conference seem familiar, that is because all eight also made it last season. The Indiana Pacers were the biggest movers, improving from No. 8 last season to No. 3 this season, but many of the story lines remain the same in a conference dominated by the Chicago Bulls and Miami Heat.

headline: Drawn Together
text: If one is at first glance tempted to dismiss Alison Bechdel’s “Are You My Mother?” as a glorified comic strip, one would be wildly and woefully misguided: it is as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs.

headline: Operation Anthropoid
text: The nameless narrator of “HHhH” has serious misgivings about the novel he is writing. Like Laurent Binet, the book’s French author, he has spent years examining the murder of the SS general Reinhard Heydrich in Prague in 1942 with a view to retelling the story as a thriller. But now he decides it is dishonest to invent descriptions, dialogue, thoughts and feelings on a subject as serious as this. The best he can do, he concludes, is to provide a running commentary on the truth (or otherwise) of what he is writing. “I just hope that, however bright and blinding the veneer of fiction that covers this fabulous story,” he writes, “you will still be able to see through it to the historical reality that lies behind.”

headline: Inside the List
text: SONGSTRESS: Carole King’s rock ’n’ roll memoir, “A Natural Woman,” is at No. 11 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. As famous singers go, King has always seemed exceedingly nice — more Janis Ian than Janis Joplin — and her book’s humble granola-and-chardonnay prose is about as earnest as you’d expect from the songwriter behind “You’ve Got a Friend.” But King’s best melodies often have a dark edge, and it’s detectable in her auto­biography too, especially in stories about her four failed marriages. One husband lost his mind to hallucinogens, and another beat her repeatedly before dying of a cocaine overdose. “In hindsight,” King writes, “I probably should have asked Rick these two questions: ‘Why are you living in a van?’ and ‘Are you by any chance psychotic?’ ” The music gossip’s not bad, either. In 1976 King and a boyfriend were watching “Taxi Driver” on the Upper East Side when King ran into Yoko Ono in the movie theater restroom. Ono invited the pair to spend the rest of the evening at the palatial apartment she shared with John Lennon — who had spurned King at their only previous meeting, 11 years earlier. Now she finally had a chance to ask him why. “It’s because I was intimidated,” he said. “No hard feelings, right?” This is Carole King we’re talking about: definitely, no hard feelings.

headline: Wells Fargo to Buy Prime Brokerage Firm
text: Wells Fargo took its first step into prime brokerage on Friday, agreeing to buy the midsize Merlin Securities.

headline: Agency Upgrades Investigation of 63,000 Ford Freestar Minivans for Rust Condition
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into corrosion on about 63,000 Ford Freestar minivans and its Mercury equivalent, the Monterey, from the 2004 model year. The agency suspects that the condition might prevent a third row of fold-down seats from being locked in the upright position.

headline: Some Favorite Urban Oases
text: In a post yesterday about the community-minded priorities, adjustments and sacrifices of oft-derided urbanites, I mentioned Central Park, but I didn’t really get into its greatness. And I won’t here, because I’ve neither the time nor the space. I’d need weeks, months, years. And I’d need hundreds of thousands of words, so infinite are the park’s glories and so big is my love for it. A blog post can’t accommodate that.

headline: Higher Bail in Shooting Is Rejected, for Now
text: A Florida judge on Friday rejected a prosecutor’s motion to increase bail for George Zimmerman, the man charged in the shooting of Trayvon Martin, after his lawyer disclosed that Mr. Zimmerman had received more than $200,000 from a legal defense Web site he established.

headline: The Temperature’s Rising (No Sweat)
text: CHET WALKER is standing before a room full of dancers, adroitly tossing a black baton from hand to hand. His disciples aren’t having such an easy time. “We’re having our first day with canes,” Melissa Spengler, Mr. Walker’s stage manager, whispers. “There may be some crashing.”

headline: London Underground | Mass Observation
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Crucial to Romney, Florida’s Latino Voters Are Wary of Him, Too
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — If Mitt Romney is to overcome his problem with Hispanic voters, he is going to have to start by changing a lot of minds in central Florida.

headline: Bribes Without Jail Time
text: As reported in a front-page article in The New York Times this week, the Wal-Mart Mexican bribery scheme has all the makings of a gripping criminal prosecution: millions of dollars in illegal payoffs to Mexican government officials and evidence of a cover-up scheme that went all the way to Wal-Mart headquarters in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: S.&P. Downgrades Nokia’s Bonds to Junk
text: 12:27 p.m. | Updated Adding Nokia‘s response and information on its earnings.

headline: Collect Call | Gray Foy and Joel Kaye’s Eight Rooms of Wonder
text: Two friends and collectors, compulsive accumulators both, live among eclectic treasures in their 57th Street apartment.

headline: With Prison Ministry, Colson Linked Religion and Reform
text: “Since the 1960s, prison reform has been seen as a leftist cause,” Robert Perkinson, a historian and the author of “Texas Tough: The Rise of America’s Prison Empire,” said this week. “But it used to be a Christian cause, and Colson played a big role in bringing prison reform back to Christian conservatism.”

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Despite the chill in the air, spring is surely here as perennial food markets bloom again for the season:— With its penchant for all things artisanal, the Hester Street Fair, at Essex and Hester Streets on the Lower East Side, reopens on Saturday, bringing together food vendors (from Luke’s Lobsters and Prohibition Bakery to Pies ‘n’ Thighs and Ample Hills Creamery), indie designers, yogis and more. The fair will continue through October on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.— Also making its debut for the year is the New Amsterdam Market, at the South Street Seaport on South Street near Peck Slip, on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. A bread pavilion featuring more than a dozen bakers, all of whom use local flour, helps kick off the season’s first market.— It’s opening weekend for the food vendors parked at the Red Hook ballfields, located near the corner of Bay and Clinton Streets in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Much of the Latin American fare is sold from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: The Service-Sector Mystery
text: The G.D.P. figure for the first quarter — growth at an annual rate of 2.2 percent — is disappointing, even if it could reflect cautious estimates that will be revised in coming months as more data comes in.

headline: Morning Walkabout: 4/27
text: Casino Company Gambles on Macau Galaxy Entertainment plans to spend more than $2 billion on the second phase of its resort in Macau, the world’s largest gambling destination. It is projected to open in 2015, making it the next casino to be completed there. (Reuters)

headline: Deals and More Deals
text: You do have to hand it to the N.F.L. It could have simply sat back on its laurels, gloating in its we’re-the-most-popular-league superiority, basking in the prime time television spotlight on its draft, which is really a non-event once held in a smoke-filled room in a basement somewhere. But somehow, against all entertainment odds, the league managed to produce something that turned into a cross between reality TV and “The Price is Right.”

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Nell Freudenberger discusses “The Newlyweds,” her new novel; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; T. M. Luhrmann talks about how evangelical Christians relate to God; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Friday Reading: Student Loan Debate Becomes Election-Year Fight
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Business Day Live | April 27, 2012
text: Who is held responsible under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act? Google's Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world and how equity research has evolved since the financial crisis.

headline: Business Day Live: Bribes Without Jail Time
text: Who is held responsible under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act? And, Google’s Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world and how equity research has evolved since the financial crisis.

headline: On Our Radar: A Hard Look at Exxon Mobil
text: In a review in The Times, Dwight Garner praises “Private Empire,” Steve Coll’s new book on Exxon Mobil, as “meticulous, multi-angled and valuable” as well as impartial, although he finds that it has “few peaks and valleys” emotionally. He says it is especially interesting on the subject of Exxon’s s relationship with the George W. Bush administration. [The New York Times]

headline: Playoff Preview: Western Conference
text: All that was old was new again, with the San Antonio Spurs leading the way in the Western Conference along with stalwart playoff teams like the Los Angeles Lakers and Dallas Mavericks while Chris Paul proved that he can make any team a contender. The traditionally stronger conference may lack the star power of the East, but it more than makes up for it in overall quality.

headline: A Consensus Begins to Emerge on Derivatives in Bankruptcy
text: Derivatives are contracts, but they are not treated like other contracts when one party enters an insolvency proceeding.

headline: Collect Call | Gray Foy and Joel Kaye’s Eight Rooms of Wonder
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Bob Dylan and Toni Morrison to Receive Presidential Medal of Freedom
text: Nearly 50 years after he sounded “Chimes of Freedom” on one of his earliest folk-rock albums, Bob Dylan, the mercurial pop troubadour, will be rewarded with a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian honor given by the United States, alongside such noteworthy figures as Toni Morrison, Madeleine Albright, John Glenn and John Paul Stevens.

headline: John Thain, ‘Grade A’ Dad
text: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch, did a less-than-ideal job parenting Merrill through its 2008 merger with Bank of America. (Remember the $35,000 “commode on legs?”)

headline: A Battered City, Through Local Lenses
text: AFTER decades of decline and neglect and the exodus of more than half of its population, Detroit now owns a cityscape that is often described as post-apocalyptic. Abandoned prewar skyscrapers, immense dilapidated factories, downtown streets devoid of people, entire neighborhoods nearly vacant and returning to brush: all provide epic vistas of blight, warning about the fickle nature of capitalism.

headline: Four Bowls of Pho
text: Diners who love pho (pronounced fuh) know the Vietnamese soup and noodle dish is all about the flavorful, meaty broth, served hot, hot, hot. But this week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman has found a way to capture the flavors of pho in a vegetarian broth. The recipe retains the traditional spices of pho without using meat. She writes:

headline: When Is a Bad Mother a Criminal?
text: From the Times Magazine: In Alabama, exposing a fetus to a “controlled substance, chemical substance or drug paraphernalia” is a crime. Amanda Kimbrough tested positive for methamphetamine after her son was born prematurely and was sentenced to 10 years in prison following his death. Reasonable response to a mother who uses while pregnant, or “pregnancy police” taken to the farthest extremes?

headline: For Runners, a Lift From Warren Buffett
text: Air Jordans have been around for decades for fans of the basketball legend. But for disciples of Warren E. Buffett’s value investing, there has never been a shoe that captures their hero – until now.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Technical Difficulties
text: After hours pouring glitter to create the yellow brick road on the backdrop, Helene Stapinski realizes: the set is so crowded, no one can even see it. That's just one of the problems encountered as P.S. 29's fifth-grade production of "The Wizard of Oz" heads toward opening night. The writer, a reluctant and then obsessive parent volunteer co-director, worries that the actors won't be able to follow stage directions. And clearly some of the parents can't follow directions, either.

headline: Who’s Paying for Those Ads?
text: Since the nation’s broadcasters refuse to fully disclose how much they’re making from campaign spending, the Federal Communications Commission has had to force them into accepting digital-age standards for transparency. The commission voted 2-to-1 this morning to require television stations to post information about campaign ads on a national database.

headline: Margaret & Tucker
text: In this user-generated video, Margaret and Tucker tell the story of how they met through a mutual friend and their first awkward date that they both agreed to put behind them.

headline: A Forlorn Birdbath, Right in City Hall’s Backyard
text: This one’s for the birds. The New York Times reported on Monday that standing water — in a puddle or even a birdbath — can subject the offending property owner to a fine of up to $2,000. It’s a violation of the New York City health code aimed at combating mosquitoes that carry West Nile virus.

headline: The South, the War and ‘Christian Slavery’
text: In the minds of many Southerners, the capture of New Orleans on April 25, 1862, by Union forces was more than simply a troubling military loss. It also raised the disturbing possibility that divine punishment was being inflicted on a spiritually wayward and sinful Confederacy.

headline: A Few Good Lawyers
text: BILIN, West Bank — Earlier this month, I finally watched “The Law in These Parts,” a documentary by the Israeli film director Ra’anan Alexandrowicz, at the 7th International Conference for Popular Resistance. The film describes the legal system that Israel has applied in the Palestinian Occupied Territories since 1967, and it does so exclusively through interviews with members of the Israeli military legal corps who wrote and implemented the system.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: If in Doubt, Send an Invitation Anyway

headline: Off the Charts: Working Off a Housing Oversupply
text: A major difference between the recovery from the 2007-9 recession and previous recoveries is that residential construction, usually a major contributor to recovery, has contributed very little. In part, that is because the homebuilding industry was a victim of past recessions but a major cause of the most recent one. Overbuilding, brought on by easy credit, left the economy vulnerable. Now, there are some signs that the overbuilding has been worked off.

headline: Lemon Poppy-Seed Pancakes With Greek Yogurt and Jam
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: Pancakes That Are Not So Flat (Artistically)
text: CHANCES are, if you have a reliable pancake recipe, you rarely stray.

headline: Engel Introduces Bill to Protect Student Privacy
text: 1:36 p.m. | Updated Federal legislation introduced Friday could curb efforts by universities and athletic departments to digitally track student athletes.

headline: Romney Campaign Tries to Paint Obama as Too Cool
text: Mitt Romney wants you to believe he will face one cool cat in November — a Ray-Ban-wearing, slow-news-jamming, smooth-as-silk singing Oval Office incumbent who regularly fills up stadiums with swooning students chanting his name: O-bam-a! O-bam-a!

headline: This Week’s Movies
text: The New York Times film critics on “The Five Year Engagement,” “Bernie,” and “The Pirates! Band of Misfits.”

headline: Steps to a Cakewalk Closing
text: THERE’S no lack of information on the Internet about real estate closings. But according to Sandy Gadow, the author of “The Complete Guide to Your Real Estate Closing” and a Sotheby’s broker who has taken part in thousands of closings, both buyers and sellers should know certain basic things to make a closing go well.

headline: Bang! You’re Closed
text: THE setting for the closing on an apartment in the East 50s was a lawyer’s office. Things seemed to be going well between the sellers until the wife found out the price her husband had received for the apartment. She clearly didn’t think it was enough. When he asked her to turn over her keys, she hurled them at him and hit him in the forehead, drawing blood.

headline: The Rail Hits the Fifth-Year Pole
text: It was April 8, 2008, when The Rail entered the world. The blog set out to provide an insightful look into the world of horse racing by seasoned reporters, grizzled handicappers and enthusiastic fans. Like proud parents, we were so thrilled with the adventure that was before us. We also had no idea what we had in store, which, in hindsight, was probably for the best. There were story lines galore, many heartwarming and some heartbreaking: Big Brown, Eight Belles, steroids, no steroids, Mine That Bird, Rachel Alexandra, Calvin Bo-Rail and Animal Kingdom to name a few.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Nell Freudenberger’s New Novel
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Mohsin Hamid reviews Nell Freudenberger’s latest novel, “The Newlyweds,” in which a Bangladeshi woman and American man agree to marry after meeting online. Mr. Hamid writes:

headline: A Flicker of Hope Appears in the Housing Market
text: THE boom in housing in the middle of the last decade created a huge oversupply of homes in the United States. But now that oversupply appears to be close to vanishing, at least in most parts of the country.

headline: Past Perfect
text: Restoration Hardware, which has forged a successful new identity with retro-chic furnishings, has also become a collector of vintage architecture. Having closed a substantial number of its mall stores in the last 18 months, the company has moved into the Hollywood Regency structure in Los Angeles that formerly housed Williams-Sonoma Home, and set up shop in a 1908 mercantile building in East Hampton, N.Y. Later this year, it will open a new retail space in Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood, restoring an elegant early-1860s building (right) that was constructed for the New England Museum of Natural History (and later housed the high-end retailers Bonwit Teller and Louis Boston). And more buildings will be added to the roster soon. Gary Friedman, Restoration Hardware’s chairman and co-C.E.O., explained that the gracious proportions of older buildings are more in line with the company’s identity: “We think of ourselves not as retailers but as curators.”

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: Still waiting for your Costume Institute Gala invitation to arrive in the mail? Don’t fret. This year, you can watch fashion’s royalty gather in front of your computer screen while it’s being  live streamed.

headline: Former Campaign Treasurer for Comptroller Is Indicted
text: A federal grand jury has indicted the former campaign treasurer for John C. Liu, the city comptroller, on charges that she helped funnel illegal campaign money to Mr. Liu by using fictitious donors and then impeded investigators’ efforts to gather information about the fund-raising, the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Friday.

headline: Lights. Camera. Invest! Putting Filmmaking in the Portfolio.
text: FOR most people, investing has not been fun these last few years. At best, it has been stressful.

headline: TimesCast | April 27, 2012
text: A blind activist escapes house arrest in China | Two former Virginia governors vie for a United States Senate seat | The space shuttle Enterprise arrives in New York.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Plan for Online Database of Political TV Ads
text: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a proposal to have local broadcasters publish information about political advertising sales on the Web in a government database.

headline: Video: This Week’s Movies, April 27
text: In today’s edition of “This Week’s Movies,” we hear critical takes on three films: Richard Linklater’s dark comedy “Bernie,” Peter Lord’s stop-motion animated “Pirates! Band of Misfits” and Nicholas Stoller’s romantic comedy “The Five-Year Engagement,” with Jason Segel and Emily Blunt. Do you have plans to go to one of these films this weekend, or do have thoughts on them? Let us know in the comments area below.

headline: A Tiger, Accused of Slurs, Is Arrested
text: Detroit Tigers outfielder Delmon Young was arrested outside a Manhattan hotel early Friday after an altercation in he screamed anti-Semitic epithets at a group of tourists and a panhandler, the police said.

headline: One in Two New College Graduates Is Jobless or Underemployed
text: One in two new college graduates is jobless or underemployed, The Associated Press reported this week.

headline: Robert Miles Parker, Artist and Preservationist, Dies at 72
text: Robert Miles Parker, an artist and preservationist whose pen-and-ink drawings of urban landscapes displayed a whimsical delight in storefronts, apartment buildings, houses and theaters, died on April 17 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a neighborhood where he could often be found working at a makeshift drawing board in a lawn chair on the sidewalk with a pet Norfolk terrier on a leash sitting patiently beside him. He was 72.

headline: At Pratt, Seeking a Sophisticated Eye
text: A few years ago, on a visit to the McQueen studios in London, I poked my head into a room of interns beavering away at rows of desks. They could have been accountants, I thought, poring over their Victorian ledgers. That scene could be duplicated across the fashion world, as new design-school graduates take their place in studios, and hope for the best. It’s exciting to land a job — a bonus if it’s with a halfway decent name — but hardly glamorous.

headline: Space Shuttle Enterprise Arrives in New York
text: Space Shuttle Enterprise arrived in New York, riding piggyback on a modified jumbo jet. Its trip included flyovers over parts of the city and landmarks before it landed at its temporary home, Kennedy Airport.

headline: 7 Series Reached New Ratings Lows on Thursday
text: On a night surely affected by sports events — guys on ice shooting pucks and other guys on stage reading out names of college football players — a live episode of NBC’s comedy “30 Rock” marginally improved the fortunes of the show, while “American Idol” solidified its position as it moves toward the end of another season.

headline: Letting Fliers Have a Voice in Mergers
text: Every time a company goes through bankruptcy court or gets involved in merger talks, it’s disappointing to see who does not have a seat at the negotiating table.

headline: Kurt Masur in Good Condition After Fall Off Podium
text: The conductor Kurt Masur, 84, is said to be in good condition in a Paris hospital after having fallen off the podium and into the audience last night while leading the Orchestre National de France at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées. The fall occurred during the second and final work on the program, Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. 6 (“Pathétique”), in the midst of the third movement, “Allegro molto vivace.” Mr. Masur’s assistant, Stefana Atlas, said that the fall resulted from an accident rather than his increasingly frail physical condition, which has led him to cancel some performances in recent months.

headline: Fair Share
text: At the I.C.F.F., the writer and designer Suzanne Trocmé curates British Bone, a selection of china produced by 1882LTD, including Max Lamb’s hand-carved tableware. Now in its second edition, WantedDesign again takes over the Terminal Stores building (28th Street at 11th Avenue), where it will host an exhibition of contemporary Brazilian design and a three-day workshop where design students will make their own light fixtures. In the garment district, the recently opened Moss Bureau (256 West 36th Street, 10th floor) will present “Midway,” a giant, zoetropic Ferris wheel and carousel by the artist and metalsmith Cathy McClure; “Mortal Stillness,” an exhibition of taxidermy by Kelly McCallum, assorted artist-made vessels and Jennifer Trask’s ivory, bone and gilded wood jewelry. And check out the new Standard Hotel East Village (25 Cooper Square), where the Sight Unseen founders (and T contributors), Monica Khemsurov and Jill Singer, will install the work of West Coast designers for the aptly named “Hotel California.” The British designer Tom Dixon will introduce his soon-to-be-available Etch Light Web at London Underground in the basement of the Bleecker Street Theater (45 Bleecker Street). Walk away with a Mirrorball or Jack Light, or order one for home delivery from Fab.com on special iPad stations. And finally, Jamie Gray will introduce the newest pieces of his MatterMade collection, including Meg Callahan’s digitally printed quilts at Matter (405 Broome Street) and at a “secret” location nearby. Happy hunting.

headline: Your Agenda for an American Airlines Customers’ Committee
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I call for the creation of a customers’ committee to represent the interest of frequent fliers on American Airlines. After all, everybody seems to get a seat at the table when an airline like American goes bankrupt or is the object of unwanted merger affection like the kind that US Airways is currently bestowing on it. So why shouldn’t customers try to get some leverage, too?

headline: George E. Doty Sr., Former Guardian of Goldman’s Finances, Is Dead at 94
text: George E. Doty Sr., a former partner at Goldman Sachs and longtime watcher of the investment bank’s finances, died on Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: In a Slump, Hopkins Lacrosse Faces Top-Ranked Loyola
text: The players on the Johns Hopkins men’s lacrosse team are ticked off and eager for another opportunity to showcase their talents and end all this losing business.

headline: Living In | Piermont, N.Y.
text: Piermont, a village draped down the Hudson River face of the Tallman Mountains, evokes a Mediterranean hillside, or maybe Sausalito, Calif.

headline: Jennifer Wu and Andy Woo
text: JENNIFER WU was moving so fast through life that potential suitors couldn’t keep up with her. Educated at Harvard and the New York University School of Law, she had been known to fly off to Africa or Europe on a moment’s notice, or scare up a party of 20 with a few phone calls.

headline: Boons and Banes of the Picturesque
text: DRAPED as it is down the Hudson River face of the Tallman Mountains, Piermont evokes a Mediterranean hillside, or maybe Sausalito, Calif. Either way, it presents a sharp contrast to many of its neighbors in Rockland County.

headline: Go Buy the 200th Issue of The Paris Review
text: This isn’t another in the “What I Learned From Reading …” series, but a companion plug for a couple of literary journals that are well worth spending your money on.

headline: Senate Candidates in Massachusetts Release Their Tax Returns
text: 2:41 p.m. | Updated BOSTON — The top two candidates in the Massachusetts Senate race, which has focused so far on who can best understand the needs of average voters, are much wealthier than most of those voters.

headline: Trailer: 'Don't Stop Believin''
text: A trailer for the documentary about Arnel Pineda and how his YouTube videos aided in getting him a gig as the lead singer of Journey.

headline: Babies on Parade
text: A timeline of celebrities and their babies in the news media.

headline: Investing With Your Heart, as Well as Your Head
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at an investment that doesn’t involve stocks or bonds or real estate. Instead, he talks to people who have invested in films.

headline: Radio As It Once Was
text: One day not long ago I was in my car, flipping through satellite radio stations on my way to work, when I suddenly heard a very unusual thing: Someone actually talking about the music he was playing. After a while I realized it was a voice from my teenage years – Dennis Elsas. one of a team of D.J.’s on New York’s WNEW FM in the 1960s and 1970s.

headline: The Baby Bump
text: JESSICA SIMPSON, the onetime pop star, had her first and last Top 10 hit more than a decade ago, with “I Wanna Love You Forever.” But that didn’t stop Elle magazine from putting her on its April cover (naked and pregnant, in an echo of the often-imitated 1991 Vanity Fair cover photo of Demi Moore) nor People magazine from splashing pictures of her baby shower over several pages in its April 2 issue.

headline: A Dinner Date That Presidents Wish They Could Skip
text: Just as they do every year, the famous officials, journalists and Hollywood stars will gather Saturday night at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner for an odd mix of celebrity and wonkdom.

headline: Marlins Park in Miami
text: The Miami Marlins’ colorful new stadium breaks from baseball’s now-familiar retro style into the 21st century.

headline: A Ballpark That May Be Louder Than the Fans
text: MIAMI — After 20 years of retro-style ballparks since the opening of Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, nearly all decked out with brick facades and calculated quirks that came to seem as predictable and interchangeable as the old doughnut-shaped arenas, Major League Baseball has its first unapologetic 21st-century stadium.

headline: Ahead of the Curve, Yet Again
text: INDIO, Calif.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $19,397,662.50
text: A full-floor penthouse at 100 11th Avenue that sold for $19,397,662.50 was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The penthouse, which has a 4,500-square-foot terrace, was also the last sponsor unit to sell in the building, which was designed by Jean Nouvel.

headline: Record Store Day Specials and Some Asian Vibes
text: Branford Marsalis Quartet

headline: Recordings Rich With Slavic Sounds
text: LIKE many singers from Slavic cultures, the Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky and the Polish baritone Mariusz Kwiecien have had some of their finest successes performing in Italian. This spring at the Metropolitan Opera Mr. Hvorostovsky has been stealing the show as Germont in Willy Decker’s production of Verdi’s “Traviata.” And after missing the first performances because of an injury, Mr. Kwiecien was impressive in the title role of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” in the Met’s new production in the fall. He followed up recently with an acclaimed turn as Belcore in Donizetti’s “Elisir d’Amore.”

headline: In Watch Industry, a Feud Over What Makes a Timepiece Swiss-Made
text: BASEL — Lest anyone doubt that the watches it makes are Swiss, Swiss Mountaineer emblazons Switzerland’s national flag on the dial of each timepiece. Does it matter that except for their Swiss movement, the watches’ components are made at a factory in Shenzhen, China? Or that Swiss Mountaineer is owned by a Hong Kong company called Golden Hawk?

headline: Fledgling Ballerinas, Just Learning to Fly
text: BESS KARGMAN wasn’t expecting anything life changing when she walked into the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts on her lunch break from an unpaid internship one April day three years ago. When banners advertising the New York City finals of the international ballet competition Youth America Grand Prix caught her eye, this aspiring documentary filmmaker in search of a subject popped into the theater and grabbed one of the last available seats.

headline: Eastern Conference Playoff Predictions
text: In the Western Conference, the second round of the playoffs will be played all over the map (distance from St. Louis to Los Angeles: 1,800 miles). But in the East, the matchups are among bitter rivals on Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor (distance from Newark to Philadelphia: 90 miles). Best advice to bystanders: stay off the trains on game days.

headline: Spain Is Still Awaiting the Payoff From Austerity
text: LONDON — Since the beginning of the debt crisis in Europe more than two years ago, defenders of the euro currency union have stuck to a basic argument: if the euro zone’s weaker economies would only keep pursuing policies of austerity, even as growth collapsed and job losses mounted, they would be rewarded by investors more willing to buy their bonds.

headline: ‘Ruggles: Complete Works,’ Reissued as a CD
text: Vocal soloists; John Kirkpatrick, pianist; Buffalo Philharmonic, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas; other ensembles. Other Minds OM 1020/21-2; two CDs.

headline: Obama Campaign Raises Money for Hillary Clinton
text: Four years ago, the Obama fund-raising machine worked to bury Hillary Rodham Clinton. Now his contributors are opening their wallets for her.

headline: How to Make Rhubarb Compote
text: Rhubarb compote is one of the best things to have on hand in your refrigerator. Melissa Clark shows how to make it.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: British Airways’ Menus  Try for a Retro Feel
text: In honor of the London Olympic and Paralympic Games, British Airways will be serving up special in-flight meals concocted by Michelin-starred chefs in its first-class cabins from July through September.

headline: Lindsey & Steven
text: Lindsey and Steven met in film school in 2003 but became friends in 2005 when they worked on a movie together. Their relationship deepened, thanks in part to a shared love of building bed forts.

headline: At Parris Island, Basic Training Pulls Lessons From Marines’ Real-World Lapses
text: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C. — The Marine Corps recruits sat cross-legged on the spotless floor of their barracks here, the blankets on their bunks pulled as tight as drumheads. Perched before them, catlike atop a pair of footlockers, Staff Sgt. Levar Woods launched into the day’s lesson.

headline: No Laughing Matter: ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’ Will Vie as New Play for Tonys
text: The eligibility committee for the Tony Awards on Friday denied a request by the producers of the Broadway comedy “One Man, Two Guvnors” to compete in the category of best play revival, where “One Man” would have faced less competition for a Tony nomination – and perhaps a stronger chance of winning – than in the category of best play. Instead “One Man,” which opened to excellent reviews this month, will compete for one of the four best-play nominations with other admired contenders like “Other Desert Cities,” “Clybourne Park,” “The Lyons,” “Peter and the Starcatcher,” and “Venus in Fur.”

headline: Space Shuttle Arrives in New York
text: The space shuttle enterprise was delivered to New York and given a grand entrance.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills 9 Near Damascus as Cease-Fire Erodes
text: A suicide bomber attacked a group of Syrian security service members near a mosque in a Damascus suburb on Friday, killing at least nine people and wounding dozens of others, said the state news media, which also reported at least two other bombings around the capital in the most recent signs of the erosion of the United Nations-monitored cease-fire.

headline: Treat Petite: A Different Sort of Soft-Serve
text: A successful trial run in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, led Rovshan Danilov, who is originally from Azerbaijan, and Arthur Simonyan, from Russia, to open a Manhattan shop selling soft-serve kefir. A fermented milk product popular in Eastern Europe, kefir (pronounced keh-FEAR) is now sold in many supermarkets here. It is similar to yogurt, but thinner, and contains several types of beneficial bacteria and yeast.

headline: April 29 — May 5
text: THE Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, whose “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia” shared the 2011 grand prize at Cannes, has become an auteur hero. But beyond Mr. Ceylan most American moviegoers probably have little experience with Turkish movies. That makes the 29-film series “THE SPACE BETWEEN: A PANORAMA OF CINEMA IN TURKEY” — presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center with the Moon and Stars Project of the American Turkish Society — all the more valuable. With movies from the late 1950s to the present, the series concentrates on socially engaged works rather than on the country’s commercial cinema.

headline: Breaking Down Knicks-Heat
text: In the summer of 2010, the New York Knicks and Miami Heat had similar ideas on constructing their rosters. Both teams freed up cap space in order to sign the league’s best free agents. The Heat achieved their goal, signing LeBron James and Chris Bosh, while retaining Dwayne Wade. As Miami grabbed three All Stars, New York was only able to land one, Amar’e Stoudemire.

headline: Dutch Plan to Restrict Marijuana Passes Hurdle
text: PARIS — The Dutch government’s plan to prohibit the purchase of marijuana by nonresidents cleared an important hurdle on Friday, when a court in The Hague dismissed a lawsuit brought by shop owners challenging the plan on the grounds that it was discriminatory.

headline: Healthcare: What Might Have Been
text: Long before the sexting scandal that ended his career, Rep. Anthony Weiner advised the president on how to pass healthcare reform. Robert Draper reports in his new book, “Do Not Ask What Good We Do,” that in September of 2009 Mr. Weiner told the president, “I think you’re looking at this entirely the wrong way. You need to simplify it. Just say that what we’re doing is gradually expanding Medicare.”

headline: Romania’s Government Collapses Amid Austerity Backlash
text: PARIS — Romania’s government fell Friday in a no-confidence vote just two months after taking office, the latest government in Europe to crumble amid disputes over unpopular austerity measures and declining growth rates.

headline: An Everyman Goes From YouTube to Journey
text: How many YouTube hits does it take to get to superstardom? For the musician and artist Arnel Pineda, it took only the right one. When Neal Schon, the guitarist for Journey, was looking for a new singer for the band, he searched on YouTube and found Mr. Pineda, a Filipino singer who was performing Journey songs with his group the Zoo Band. Mr. Schon asked to meet with Mr. Pineda and, eventually, Mr. Pineda, an artist who had logged so many hours impersonating the sounds of rock stars, became one. A new documentary playing this weekend at the Tribeca Film Festival, “Don’t Stop Believin': Everyman’s Journey” looks deeper into the unlikely story of Arnel Pineda and how he became the frontman for one of America’s most popular rock acts. It follows Mr. Pineda on the band’s 2008 tour and spends some time with him in more personal moments as well.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: The defense of Rajat K. Gupta got a boost from the disclosure of an insider inquiry targeting a Goldman banker in California. In China, big banks are starved for capital after a lending spree. And Andrew Ross Sorkin finds “tainted” executives sheltered on boards.

headline: House Passes Student Loan Bill Despite Veto Threat
text: WASHINGTON — Moments after an unusual fiery appeal from Speaker John A. Boehner, the House ignored a veto threat from President Obama and voted 215 to 195 on Friday to prevent a doubling of student loan rates.

headline: Homophobic? Maybe You’re Gay
text: WHY are political and religious figures who campaign against gay rights so often implicated in sexual encounters with same-sex partners?

headline: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the First Round of the N.F.L. Draft
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). Andrew Luck, Quarterback, Indianapolis Colts — Peyton Manning’s replacement brings size, accuracy and brains to offensive coordinator Bruce Arians’s quarterback-friendly offense, but without Pierre Garcon, Jacob Tamme and Dallas Clark he’ll have to make do with a declining Reggie Wayne and a fragile Austin Collie as his main weapons. Rookie quarterbacks always carry considerable risk, but his upside and talent will make him an attractive mid- to low-end QB2 that will be coming off of the fantasy boards in the middle rounds.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom colonial in Edgemont, N.Y., and a three-bedroom ranch in Metuchen, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Chelsea tri-level, a Boerum Hill house and a Washington Heights co-op.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Volume of ‘Batman: No Man’s Land’
text: New to the graphic books paperback best-seller list this week is Volume 2 of “Batman: No Man’s Land,” which appears at No. 7. The story was originally published in serialized form in 1999. Those days were hard times for Gotham City and the caped crusader: after an outbreak of disease, the city was leveled by an earthquake. The government had enough and gave the order to evacuate the city. Batman, his allies, his enemies and many residents stayed. The story, which wove through several monthly titles and was handled by several writers and artists, was compelling. The city became divided by rival factions and familiar faces were cast into different roles. (The Penguin, for example, became a supplier of goods on the black market, while the Huntress, who felt ostracized by Batman, took on a new guise.) Most superhero stories require a good helping of suspension of disbelief, and this one is no different. When “No Man’s Land” began, fans wondered why Batman’s heroic allies did not help him or the city. There’s an adventure that addresses that (in a Justice League story, they are shown protecting Gotham’s perimeter, but are asked by Batman to otherwise keep out), which I hope will be featured in a future volume.

headline: For Those Who Think ... (Yawn)
text: Toyota’s Camry remains mostly unchanged for 2012, offering the predictably soothing experience that has made it the best-selling car in America for 13 of the last 14 years.

headline: Spain’s King Has Surgery Amid Debate on His Reign
text: MADRID — In the latest twist in a drama now gripping Spain, King Juan Carlos underwent surgery for the second time on Thursday since fracturing his hip while elephant hunting in Botswana earlier this month.

headline: The Value of James Harden
text: While James Harden has received much attention this week for taking an elbow to the face from Metta World Peace, he actually deserves recognition for his impressive play this season.

headline: As Parents, Are Fathers the Second Sex?
text: Ten months ago, my wife and I had our first child, a boy. He was born in London, where we’ve been living for nearly four years.

headline: Nebraska Coach Makes Public Stand Against Gay Rights
text: While much of the sports world seems to be making an effort to be move away from its entrenched homophobia and be more inclusive of gays and lesbians — professional teams filming videos for the “It Gets Better” project and hockey’s new “You Can Play” initiative, for example — an assistant football coach at Nebraska believes that is going entirely in the wrong direction.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 27
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Satire of Kraft Sponsorship Is Sponsored by Kraft
text: The episode of the sitcom “30 Rock” that NBC broadcast live on Thursday night offered a fanciful tribute to live TV on the Peacock network. Not left out of that wacky history lesson were the sponsors, an integral part of television when it was live.

headline: Should Cyberbullying Be a Crime?
text: As schools prepare to put an anti-bullying curriculum in place to comply with the Dignity for All Students Act, legislation has been proposed in New York that would criminalize cyberbullying. Many experts say educational programs work best to teach children to respect each other, but one legislator says stricter penalties are necessary as more youths communicate through texts and the Internet.

headline: Passengers Tell American Airlines What They Want
text: In this week’s Your Money column, Ron Lieber argues that there’s a need for a committee to advocate for passengers when airlines restructure or merge. The issue has come up again as American Airlines makes its arguments on restructuring in bankruptcy court and US Airways signals that it hopes to merge with American.

headline: Tardec FED Bravo: A Deeper Shade of Army Green
text: By its own admission, the Army tends not to fret over the fuel efficiency of its terrestrial vehicle fleet. But at the Society of Automotive Engineers World Congress in Detroit this week, the armed forces played against type, unveiling a new concept vehicle, the FED Bravo.

text: AS far as asparagus is concerned, you could say I’m a fanatic: a rabid, obsessive-compulsive perfectionist.

headline: Federal Investigators Subpoena Union Documents
text: 5:02 p.m. | Updated Federal investigators have sent a subpoena to the National Basketball Players Association seeking documents about the business practices of the union, which have come under scrutiny because of claims of nepotism and conflicts of interest.

headline: After a Tumultuous Season, Anthony May Have More on the Line
text: It is hardly a strain to argue that the compelling first-round matchup between the Knicks and the Miami Heat is largely about the baggage strapped onto the backs of LeBron James and Company as they begin the 2012 postseason.

headline: Four Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Real Simple
text: Full disclosure: Real Simple is not a magazine that I usually buy or read. This is not because it’s not a good magazine (I’m not qualified to judge; see first sentence) but because it’s a magazine explicitly targeted at women. I am not generalizing here: the editor’s note from Kristin van Ogtrop (who, full disclosure Part 2, is the spouse of a Times Magazine staff member) includes a story about a husband buying his wife the wrong black cashmere turtleneck that concludes with: “The woman’s friends clucked sympathetically. Haven’t we all been there?” Personally, I have not been there.

headline: Seacrest’s Role at NBCUniversal Will Span News, Sports and Entertainment
text: Look for Ryan Seacrest to be appearing soon on NBC’s “Today” show and on the network’s coverage of special events like the Olympics.

headline: Vain Glorious | Virgin’s Code Red
text: Virgin Airlines recently unveiled a swank spa at its new Upper Class lounge at New York’s Kennedy Airport, the first Clubhouse spa outside of London. A blowout and a massage before you climb on board a night flight has great appeal — plane bed head is not a good look. The spa within the 10,000-square-foot clubhouse, designed by Slade Architecture, has its own Bumble and Bumble salon, and offers facials using Dr. Hauschka products.

headline: People’s Choice Returns With Apps and Adele
text: AS a car-buying choice, the Toyota Camry is like the “ask the audience” lifeline on “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?” The Camry, the best-selling car in America for 13 of the last 14 years, represents the wisdom of the crowd, a safe harbor for those who just aren’t that interested in cars.

text: April 27, 2012 — Chen Guangcheng, a blind lawyer known for taking on the case of thousands of women who had been forcibly sterilized, escapes from house arrest.

headline: The Few, the Proud, the Brutes: Special Ops for Jeep Wranglers
text: IN 1993, Dave Harriton decided to cut his Jeep in half to make it longer. Little did he know what the project would entail — or that it would stretch into an enterprise that supplies aftermarket equipment for Jeeps and modifies the off-road stalwarts for even more extreme use.

headline: P.S. 29 Parents Grill Officials Over Construction
text: For more than three hours in a packed auditorium at Public School 29 John M. Harrigan in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Thursday night, parents took representatives from the School Construction Authority to task for what they deemed “unacceptable behavior” involving a $7 million maintenance and upkeep project that began at the school at the end of February.

headline: Inserting the Brand-New Alongside the Old Familiar
text: New-music fans who object when musical organizations present contemporary works in special concerts, where they won’t intrude on the classics — the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series, or the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s Kaplan Penthouse concerts, for example — would have approved of the way the society presented John Harbison’s new Sonata No. 1 for Violin and Piano on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

text: A quirk in playoff scheduling has created a problem for some New York sports fans.

headline: Before Flying Car Can Take Off, There’s a Checklist
text: THE promise of an airplane parked in every driveway, for decades a fantasy of suburban commuters and a staple of men’s magazines, resurfaced this month in Manhattan. On display at the New York auto show was the Terrafugia Transition, an airplane with folding wings and a drive system that enabled it to be used on the road.

headline: Expect Some Delays
text: Flying cars like the Terrafugia Transition are ready to lift off, but they’ll need to clear some regulatory hurdles first.

headline: 50 Berlin Galleries Host Shows and Events
text: From Friday through Sunday, 50 galleries will open their doors to visitors from around the world as part of Gallery Weekend Berlin. With notable exhibitions and see-and-be-seen parties, the three-day event has emerged as one of the most important art happenings in Europe.

text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Threat of a Close Shave in Mozart’s Lecher’s Tale
text: Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” usually concludes these days with a moralizing sextet: after the rogue Giovanni has descended to hell, his fed-up servant Leporello, the women he wronged and the fiancées he enraged proclaim, “Questo è il fin di chi fa mal” (“Such is the end of the evildoer”). The sextet was usually omitted until the mid-20th century, and an artistic argument can certainly be made for its exclusion, since the opera ends on a note of heightened drama with Giovanni’s fiery death.

headline: Android Is Failing to Get Into Businesses as iPhone and iPad Do
text: Google’s Android is installed on more devices than any other mobile software system in the world. But beyond sheer quantity, it doesn’t seem to have much going for it among American businesses. Its prominence is eroding in the smartphone market here.

headline: If Carmen Had Made It to the Altar
text: So much bling, so little substance.

headline: A Critique of the Broken-Record Message of ‘Green Traditionalists’
text: Keith Kloor, building on a post on his blog, Collide-a-Scape, has an essay posted on Discover, titled “The Limits to Environmentalism,” that is well worth reading.

headline: Prosecutors Scrutinize Ex-Head of Dewey
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office is investigating accusations of wrongdoing at the troubled law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, the firm said on Friday.

headline: Untying the Knot, and Bonds, of Marriage
text: WHEN the performance artist Marina Abramovic separated from her longtime partner, Ulay, in 1988, they decided to honor the occasion with a ritual. She traveled to one end of the Great Wall of China, he to the other, and after a 90-day hike, they met in the middle, embraced and officially parted ways.

headline: Bill Skowron, Slugger in Yankee Golden Era, Dies at 81
text: Bill Skowron, the slugging first baseman who played on seven pennant-winning teams with the Yankees in the 1950s and early ’60s, died on Friday in Arlington Heights, Ill. He was 81.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wistful
text: The cascading blossoms remind me of what I saw in Paris last month: the elongated look of women in stripes.

headline: Woman With a Lens, Restored
text: DANCER, bride, runaway wife, radical filmmaker and pioneer — Shirley Clarke is one of the great undertold stories of American independent cinema. A woman working in a predominantly male world, a white director who turned her camera on black subjects, she was a Park Avenue rich girl who willed herself to become a dancer and a filmmaker, ran away to bohemia, hung out with the Beats and held to her own vision in triumph and defeat. She helped inspire a new film movement and made urgently vibrant work that blurs fiction and nonfiction, only to be marginalized, written out of histories and dismissed as a dilettante. She died in 1997 at 77 and is long overdue for a reappraisal.

headline: Door Between Galleries Lets in an Artist’s Vision
text: The big-money contemporary art world has grown so large that it often seems to have achieved nation-state status, while the galleries it comprises operate like feuding medieval principalities, constantly jousting for turf (Chelsea real estate), prestige (A-list artists) and money (from collectors’ pockets).

headline: More Answers About the Baby Hawks
text: Boo and Scout, the baby hawks in the Hawk Cam nest high above Washington Square Park, are now 17 and 18 days old and have morphed from round-headed, snow-white fuzz balls to slightly fearsome grayish creatures somewhat resembling fluff-covered dinosaurs. Now that they’re too big for mother hawk Rosie to sit on top of them, the pair are getting more air time on the Hawk Cam.

headline: Defying Expectations With Dark Lyrics and a Danceable Sound
text: Miike Snow, the Swedish band that started a three-night stand at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night, has given itself a tricky assignment: bringing angst and enigma into the artificial electronic paradise of electronic dance music. Its best-loved song, “Animal” — the crowd-pleasing finale on Tuesday — begins, “There was a time when my world was filled with darkness, darkness, darkness,” and doesn’t find much comfort from there.

headline: Video: Homemade Rhubarb Compote
text: In this week’s column, I mention a homemade rhubarb compote that I used as a topping for pancakes. I demonstrate the recipe in this video if you want a detailed look at how to make it, though it is simple as can be. Just cube 3/4 pound rhubarb and combine it with 3/4 cup sugar over low heat. When the rhubarb starts to soften, but before it falls apart (about 5 minutes), use a slotted spoon to transfer it to a bowl. Then, cook the liquid down in the pan until it thickens and turns syrupy (about 5 minutes longer). This condenses and intensifies the rhubarb flavor. Add the syrup to the bowl with the rhubarb and let cool. It will keep for at least a week in the fridge.

headline: Another Chapter in a Personal Myth That Keeps Growing Darker
text: By now, just about everyone in the contemporary dance world is familiar with the provocative, involved question behind “Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church,” the series Trajal Harrell  began in 2009: “What would have happened in 1963 if someone from the ball scene in Harlem had gone downtown to perform alongside the early postmoderns at Judson Church?”

headline: Signs of a Shift as ‘G.M.A.’ Again Leads ‘Today’ in Viewers
text: The early shift seems to be real: preliminary ratings this week indicate that ABC’s “Good Morning America” has won another week over NBC’s “Today” show, this time by a more substantial margin. The win came with Matt Lauer, the top morning anchor for “Today,” on the job.

headline: Asparagus, at Last
text: It finally feels like spring when local asparagus starts showing up in New York’s greenmarkets. And on a market visit the other day, fresh asparagus seemed to be popping out all over. There were tempting green spears in every size — fat, medium and pencil-thin, and even some purple-tinged varieties.

headline: Table Talk: The New Family Dinner
text: GROWING up in the ’70s, I sat down to a family dinner that was consistent with my parents’ child-rearing philosophy at the time, which my mother likes to call “benign neglect.” Over dinner, my father briefed my mother on the ins and outs of his day at the office, while my siblings and I zoned out or piped up or fought over why my older sister always got the corner seat. We sat down as a family to a good, healthy meal, but dinner was not what you would call child-centric — which was fine with us, and definitely fine with them.

headline: Tonys Committee Decides ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’ Isn’t a Revival
text: The eligibility committee for the Tony Awards on Friday denied a request by the producers of the Broadway comedy “One Man, Two Guvnors” to compete in the category of best play revival. “One Man” would have faced less competition for a Tony nomination — and perhaps a stronger chance of winning — as a revival than in the category of best play.

headline: Obama Trumpets Killing of Bin Laden, and Critics Pounce
text: WASHINGTON — Presidents running for re-election typically boast of programs they created, people they helped or laws they signed. They talk about rising test scores or falling deficits or expanding job rolls. President Obama is increasingly taking the unusual route of bragging about how he killed a man.

headline: A Winding Trip Reverberates in Cinema
text: AT one point in a lovely 1990 documentary about the French filmmaker Jacques Rivette he muses on the importance of curiosity and time to storytellers — or, in his modest phrase, “people who try to play with fiction.” Seated between his interlocutor, the critic Serge Daney, and the documentary’s director, Claire Denis, Mr. Rivette — a slight, thoughtful man who punctuates his answers with reflexive shrugs and bashful smiles — declares, “It seems that Scheherazade is our patron saint.”

headline: Teachers, Principals and Money Unresolved for 24 Turnaround Schools
text: Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott and his deputies told members of the Panel for Educational Policy Thursday night that the city will not require the 24 schools slated for turnaround to let go of half their teachers. Principals, he said, have been directed "to hire the best possible staff that they can. And if that means that they're hiring back more than 50 percent, then that is exactly what they should do." But that position could jeopardize federal funds.

headline: Reviewing the Toyota Camry
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the Toyota Camry, which received a refresh for the 2012 model year — though Toyota would argue its volume-leading sedan was “reinvented.”

headline: Deception Tells Its Tale, Again
text: WHO do you think you are?

headline: A State Looks at Itself in a New Mirror
text: DENVER — An East Coast visitor’s first reaction, provincially enough, has to be skepticism: does Colorado even have that much history?

headline: Secret Service Tightens Travel Rules for Its Staff
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks after the Secret Service opened an investigation into whether a dozen of its agents and employees had spent the night with prostitutes in Colombia, the agency announced on Friday that it had tightened its rules for staff members traveling in foreign countries.

headline: It Takes Two to Fight Over a Documentary
text: WHEN David Redmon and Ashley Sabin were first falling in love, they took a trip to Mexico. Not that kind of trip. They went to shoot a documentary about the squalid conditions of the workers who make Victoria’s Secret bags. The film never took shape, but the relationship flourished.

headline: Fans of Flight Welcome the Space Shuttle
text: When the space shuttle Enterprise touched down in New York City on Friday, 20 New York City high school students in crisp black military uniforms with red trim and gold buttons presented the national flag during “The Star-Spangled Banner.” It had to be the ultimate thrill for students who work on aircraft everyday.

headline: It’s April, It Rains. Deal (and Sing).
text: “The Happiest Sound in Town,” the title of Marilyn Maye’s new show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, is not a misnomer. A woman of seemingly inexhaustible vocal stamina, show-business smarts and innate good will and optimism, Ms. Maye, now 84, spreads a kind of joy that is the opposite of the forced cheer affected by many performers to camouflage insecurity.

headline: How to Interpret the Derby Contenders’ Final Preparations
text: The 20-horse field for this year’s Kentucky Derby is taking shape, and the stars are now either at Churchill Downs or will arrive in the next few days. Union Rags, who arrived at Churchill Downs on Thursday after training at Keeneland for a couple of weeks, performed a routine gallop Friday.

headline: Every Instrument Has the Spotlight
text: When Alan Gilbert commissioned the composer Marc Neikrug to write a piece for the New York Philharmonic, he couched the request simply: he wanted something that would show off the full orchestra. It could have been a symphony or a tone poem, but for Mr. Neikrug the solution was a concerto for orchestra: a score in the tradition of Bartok’s and Lutoslawski’s similarly titled works, in which every part of the ensemble would be treated equally. His goal, he said in a recent interview on YouTube, was to write music that would require the Philharmonic to “play ferociously difficult music like ferocious animals.”

headline: Classics With a Spirit of Improvisation
text: At first glance, the program that the pianist Richard Goode played at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening seemed dispiritingly constricted. The two composers whose works he performed, Schumann and Chopin, were born in the same year, 1810, and the works he chose were all composed within a decade, from 1838 to 1847.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 27
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a women’s bocce league in the Bronx, caretakers for the city’s historic homes and mourners at Levon Helm’s wake in Woodstock, N.Y.

headline: Classic Greek Flavors, With a Modern Twist
text: THE vivid blue and white color scheme, the airy dining room and even the typography on the sign at Kyma Greek Cuisine, a six-month-old restaurant in Somerville, primed my palate for the classics of that cuisine: succulent grilled meats and seafood, lemon, oregano, feta, ouzo, rich coffee.

headline: A Change in Name and Focus
text: The seven-year-old Long Island Merlot Alliance has changed its name to Merliance, after its collectively made wine, and expanded its program, now describing itself as a group of producers of “quality merlot and merlot-based blends.”

headline: Adventurous Choices for Nibblers and Grazers
text: THE small-plate restaurant trend shows no sign of waning. Such places are popular with good reason: diners looking for a light meal find the portions manageable, while those with big appetites enjoy trying a variety of dishes. One of the newest of the breed is the Phoenix, which opened in Seaford on Feb. 1 in a semicircular corner building that was previously a Pomodorino restaurant.

headline: Authentic Feasts, Tequila Included, for Any Fiesta
text: CONTRARY to popular belief, Cinco de Mayo is not Mexico’s independence day. It is, however, a fine occasion to salute that country’s culture and cuisine while getting a head start on summer. The three restaurants listed below serve authentic and innovative Mexican food in décors that contribute to a celebratory sense of fiesta all year long.

headline: A Nightingale Soaring Tranquilly Through Nocturnes

Then they eased into the first line, “Calmes dans le demi-jour” (“Calm at twilight”), from Fauré’s song “En Sourdine” (“Muted”), and as always with Ms. Piau, the calm seemed to permeate the very air.

headline: What’s in a Name? A Crucial Ingredient
text: SHORTLY before Burrata opened in February, with brown paper still covering the windows, stylish block letters fixed to its handsome facade announced the coming of a restaurant named Hearth (smaller letters below promised “wood-fired pizza”). With all systems ready to go, the owner, Chas Anderson, met with a cease-and-desist letter from a Manhattan restaurateur who already had rights to the name “Hearth” — hence the mellifluous last-minute christening.

headline: In Virginia, 2 Ex-Governors Vie for Senate and Balance of Power
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Seven months before Virginia voters elect their next United States senator, former Gov. Tim Kaine, the Democrats’ choice for the slot, was rallying a college crowd here, trying to impress upon them the magnitude of the decision to come.
