headline: Updates to an Art Form That Once Caused Outrage
text: The history of modern art is often described as a history of outrage. Take, for instance, this episode involving found objects: in 1913, the poet Guillaume Apollinaire published four reproductions of Pablo Picasso’s sculptural constructions, made of scavenged materials, in a small Parisian journal — upon which 34 of the journal’s 40 subscribers immediately canceled their subscriptions. Apparently, even those avant-garde consumers weren’t ready to accept such objects as art.

headline: City Crackdown on Hotels Affects Quaint B&B’s Too
text: The Eden House hotel in Washington Heights advertised free Wi-Fi and good subway access at bargain prices. The Loftstel in Brooklyn offered dorm-style beds for $25 a night, and three-bedrooms for just $195. In a city where a hotel room often costs a week’s pay, they seemed attractive options.

headline: Hollande and Sarkozy Trade Insults as Runoff Nears
text: PARIS — With accusations of fascism and lying, incompetence and imbecility, the French presidential campaign has been one of the nastiest in memory. One legislator from the governing party even compared the partner of the Socialist challenger to a Rottweiler.

headline: Desperately Seeking Quarterback Stoppers
text: When the Baltimore Ravens finally plucked outside linebacker Courtney Upshaw from the green room Friday night — he slid from an expected first-round selection to the third pick in the second — it continued this draft’s run on the people who chase after quarterbacks. And with the next pick, the Denver Broncos surprised analysts by taking defensive tackle Derek Wolfe, another pass rusher.

headline: Cars, Trains and Partisan Posturing
text: The transportation bill is vital, providing billions of dollars to states and communities to build and repair roads, ensure bridges are safe and improve mass transit for millions of commuters. It also sustains some 2.9 million jobs, many in the hard-pressed construction industry.

headline: A Theater Class Where All Are Able
text: MILLBURN, N.J. —   “I’m a little scared,” confessed one of the children in the black-box theater at the Paper Mill Playhouse here on a recent Friday.

headline: Bristol-Myers Subpoenaed in Inquiry Into Sales

headline: William Hammond and the End of the Medical Middle Ages
text: While other events of April 25, 1862, dominated the nation’s headlines — most notably the Confederate surrender of New Orleans — perhaps the most significant single event in the life of the average Union soldier was a presidential appointment that day that was hardly noticed outside Washington. Over the objection of Edwin Stanton, his secretary of war, President Lincoln named William Alexander Hammond as surgeon general of the Army.

headline: Chevron Misses Forecasts Despite Higher Oil Prices
text: Chevron missed first-quarter profit and sales estimates as falling production blunted the impact of surging oil prices. Net income rose 4.2 percent to $6.47 billion, or $3.27 a share, from $6.21 billion, or $3.09 a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 0.8 percent to $58.9 billion, 7.8 percent lower than the average of three analysts’ estimates compiled by Bloomberg. Stock in Chevron, which is based in San Ramon, Calif., fell 2 cents, or 0.02 percent, to $106.20 a share.

headline: Food Safety on Hold
text: While the first lady, Michelle Obama, champions the issue of healthy food, the rest of the administration does not seem to have gotten the message. There are now three important food issues on hold. And health and nutrition advocates worry that they are stalled for the election season, or longer, because of pushback from the food industry. Here is what needs to move along:

headline: Newly Engaged and Out to Splurge
text: The neighborhood remains scruffy, but gentrification is in full bloom at the NoMad Hotel, at Broadway and 28th Street, where the vibe is European louche-luxe and the restaurant is the province of Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, the chef and general manager who own the Michelin three-star Eleven Madison Park. At NoMad, patrons have multiple backdrops for dining, each offering its own enticements: the central Atrium, with its stone floor and glass ceiling, guarantees high visibility; the romantic Parlour, decorated with framed, pressed herbs, is comfortably intimate; the Fireplace room, for large parties, resembles an antique jewelry box. A seductively lighted duplex library adjacent to the bar encourages patrons to tuck away their iPhones, settle in with a book, sip a cocktail, converse and envision themselves to the manner born. Or inside a game of “Clue.”

headline: The Myth of Deterrence
text: One of the most frequently made claims about the death penalty is that it deters potential murderers. That was the claim when the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976. It is the claim today after a revival of research about the topic in the last decade.

headline: More Than a ‘Breath of Fresh Air’
text: Growing up in the Stanley M. Isaacs Houses on 92nd Street and First Avenue in Manhattan, Yvette Vasquez was never allowed to play outside. But around the projects there was mostly just asphalt littered with crack vials, recalled Ms. Vasquez, who is now 30. “There was nothing to look forward to,” she said, until she was 9, when the Fresh Air Fund sent her to spend two glorious weeks with a host family in St. Catharines, Ontario.

headline: United States Talks Fail as Pakistanis Seek Apology
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The first concentrated high-level talks aimed at breaking a five-month diplomatic deadlock between the United States and Pakistan ended in failure on Friday over Pakistani demands for an unconditional apology from the Obama administration for an airstrike. The White House, angered by the recent spectacular Taliban attacks in Afghanistan, refuses to apologize.

headline: A Year Older, but as Good as Ever

text: MIAMI — Since the Heat beat the Knicks on April 15, their Big Three has been reduced to the Big Two, then the Big One and now the Big Question Mark.

headline: Stuff Between Some Cake Layers
text: Administrivial Tournament/Will Shortz-Spotting Alert! If you live near Providence, Rhode Island and would like to enjoy some fresh puzzles constructed by the amazing minds of the Brown University Puzzle Club, constructors Natan Last, Aimee Lucido, Jonah Kagan, Joey Weissbrot, and Zoe Wheeler invite one and all to their Brown Annual Crossword Tournament, hosted by Will Shortz and being held tomorrow on campus in a building called LIST. The tournament runs from noon to 3:00 p.m., and the tournament puzzles will run at a later date here in The New York Times.

headline: No Less Irreverent at Age 68
text: “A lot of people come up to me and say, ‘Peel, I thought you were dead,’ ” said David Peel, who is not only alive but basically living the same life he led 40 years ago, when he was a muse for the Yippie and hippie movements in New York City.

headline: Persistence Has Yet to Pay Off in an Effort to Run a Newsstand
text: Mohammad Sikder, a baker turned cabby from Bangladesh who supports a family of six, had resolved to escape the stresses of a taxi driver’s life.

headline: Chandler’s Illness Could Be Knicks’ First Postseason Test
text: MIAMI — On the eve of the eve of their first playoff run together, the revived, reconstituted Knicks gathered around the dinner table to talk history, hopes and the Miami Heat. In this last leisurely moment Thursday night, the only concern was the empty chair where a 7-foot defensive sentinel should have been sitting.

headline: In Report, Details of Misconduct Accusations Against Former Finance Chief
text: A former Bloomberg official asked a real estate company to help her domestic partner find an apartment just weeks after her agency sharply reduced the firm’s tax burden, and she was romantically involved with two subordinates, according to the results of a city investigation released on Friday.

headline: Jogs, Shows and Lots of Caffeine
text: If his Sunday is not frenetic, Vin Cipolla, the constantly caffeinated president of the Municipal Art Society, feels as if something is missing — or it means he has retreated to his country house in Pound Ridge, N.Y., for fresh air and a daylong hike. But mostly, Mr. Cipolla, 55, sticks close to the cityscape he has focused on preserving and reinvigorating since leaving his position as president of the National Park Foundation in 2009. Marathon walks and Central Park jogs are Sunday habits. He lives near Columbus Circle with his wife, Celine McDonald, 55, a landscape painter, and the youngest of their four daughters, Gabriella, 23. Their second-youngest, Olivia, 26, has an apartment in the same building.

headline: For Goalie, Smooth Transition From Minors to Sport’s Biggest Stage
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — When the Washington Capitals’ season began, goaltender Braden Holtby was the odd man out. The team had signed the veteran Tomas Vokoun to battle Michal Neuvirth for the starting job. And despite an impressive finish to the 2010-11 season, Holtby found himself back with the Hershey Bears, the Capitals’ American Hockey League affiliate.

headline: With Support Off as Events Begin, Komen Works to Revive Its Image
text: Susan G. Komen for the Cure may have popularized the color pink as a universal symbol of breast cancer fund-raising. But these days, many of the breast cancer foundation’s local affiliates are singing the blues.

headline: Raid to Kill Bin Laden Helped United States, Panetta Says
text: WASHINGTON — Killing Osama bin Laden was not a “silver bullet” that destroyed Al Qaeda, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said on Friday, but he asserted that his death weakened the terrorist group and made the United States more safe.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Chesapeake Energy’s decision to end a controversial compensation plan for its chief executive and questions about aggressive debt-collection practices by Accretive Health were among the top stories this week.

headline: Turning Unused Acres Green
text: THE city of New York owns thousands of slivers of unused land, and about a year ago, a group of Brooklyn gardeners had an idea: identify all the vacant lots in the borough, then help neighborhood residents take them over. They built an online map, then a mobile app, with information about the plots, including the names and phone numbers of the agencies that owned them. They called themselves 596 Acres, after the total area of unused public land in Brooklyn, according to city data.

headline: Fewer Illegal Immigrants Stopped for Traffic Violations Will Face Deportation
text: Fewer illegal immigrants stopped by police for minor traffic violations would be held for deportation under changes announced Friday to a federal fingerprinting program, Department of Homeland Security officials said.

headline: On East 84th Street
text: Lillian Jacobs has lived on East 84th Street in Yorkville for 100 years. The area has maintained its charm and is home to many longtimers.

headline: A Lopsided Lacrosse Rivalry Receives a Jolt
text: BALTIMORE — The campuses of Loyola and Johns Hopkins sit a mile apart in this city’s northern end, linked by tree-lined Charles Street as well as a feverish enthusiasm for lacrosse.

headline: 100 Years of Staying Put
text: WHEN Lillian Jacobs was 2, in 1911 or ’12, her family moved from the Lower East Side into a tenement building on East 84th Street, just off York Avenue, then known as Avenue A. Her parents ran a candy store on the building’s ground floor, catering to the newly arrived immigrants from Germany, Hungary, Austria and Ireland.

headline: Giants Find Big-Play Potential and Smile With Pick
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When David Wilson met with the Giants during the scouting combine in Indianapolis, he wore a three-piece suit and congratulated team executives for winning the Super Bowl. A Giants official told Wilson, a running back, that he was one of the few prospects who had done so. It was a gesture that suited his personality.

headline: Wife of Ex-Aide Testifies About Work for Edwards
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Cheri Young, whose husband, Andrew, is the leading witness in the federal corruption trial against John Edwards, followed him onto the witness stand on Friday, recounting in a steely voice how much her husband had adored the former senator and vice-presidential nominee.

headline: Death of Spy, Zipped Into Bag, Spawns Theories and Inquest
text: LONDON — Britain, home to the MI6 spy agency that inspired the James Bond stories and the billion-dollar film franchise, has been wrestling this week with one of the country’s strangest real-life spy mysteries in a generation, one that has become known popularly as the case of the spy in the bag.

headline: A Different Intersection of Church and Politics
text: On Tuesday afternoon, on the steps of Federal Hall, in Lower Manhattan, where Occupy Wall Street protesters have been contained in recent weeks, Loren Hart, a conservatively dressed man of 33, sat reading a newspaper as he held a sign that gave quiet expression to pervasive grievances: “The economy is failing us. Our climate is worsening every day. Perhaps we should make some serious changes.” Mr. Hart arrived in New York from North Carolina in October to join the Occupy movement with the expectation that he would stay a few days, but he has felt unmotivated to leave.

headline: Bad News for Pelfrey Is Break for Young Pitcher
text: DENVER — The fall of one player represents an opportunity for another. As the Mets on Friday began to handle the immediate repercussions of Mike Pelfrey’s season-ending elbow injury, there was a familiar echo to the situation for Dillon Gee, a pitcher who benefited from a similar situation almost exactly a year ago.

This was five years ago, when Coples and his mother, Gail, walked into the football office at Hargrave Military Academy in Chatham, Va. The coach, Robert Prunty, apologized and said that his roster was full.

text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,934 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Young People’s Priorities
text: Judging by this week’s debate, you would think that student loans are young people’s only priority. They’re not. In fact, a cleverly designed survey released this week by Harvard University’s Institute of Politics asked respondents ages 18 to 29 to choose between pairings of issues to determine which ones they felt were more important. Among domestic issues, creating jobs almost always won, while combating climate change almost never did. Immigration is also a losing issue (except when paired with climate change), while access to affordable health care is a winner. I found the results so interesting that I wanted to share them. Enjoy.

headline: One Passed Ball by Tigers Erases Night of Control Problems From Nova
text: The temperature at Yankee Stadium was a baseball-unfriendly 47 degrees at game time Friday, with a chilly breeze starching the pennants. It was so frosty that even Justin Verlander, the Detroit Tigers right-handed ace, was not as precise and diabolical as usual.

headline: Uncertainty Hangs Over the Nets’ Brooklyn Lineup
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Four players and Coach Avery Johnson gave their parting words as members of the New Jersey Nets on Friday afternoon. Although the team will continue to practice a stone’s throw from the Meadowlands in the near future, they will be doing so as the Brooklyn Nets.

headline: Bin Laden’s Death Made U.S. Safe, Panetta Says, Recalling ‘Nail-Biting Moments’ of Raid
text: It has almost been one year since Osama bin Laden was killed in his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, by a United States Navy SEAL team. Ahead of the May anniversary, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta told reporters on Friday that bin Laden’s death was not a “silver bullet,” but that it, along with the killings of other Qaeda leaders, had “prevented them from having the command and control capability to be able to put together an attack similar to 9/11.”

headline: Enoch Williams, New York Councilman, Dies at 84
text: Enoch H. Williams, a former New York City councilman who used his leadership positions to pass a law banning smoking in most public spaces and to help stop the Giuliani administration from selling city-owned hospitals, but who also came under fire from gay rights groups, died on Tuesday at his home in Heathrow, Fla. He was 84.

headline: Joe Muranyi, Clarinetist for Louis Armstrong, Dies at 84
text: Joe Muranyi, a clarinetist whose mastery of pre-World War II jazz led to a four-year stint with Louis Armstrong’s last band — and to an improbable moment of pop stardom — died on April 20 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Devils’ Second-Round Schedule
text: The Devils’ series against the Philadelphia Flyers begins Sunday. Here is the second-round schedule:

headline: In a Single Half-Inning, the Mets Come Undone
text: DENVER — There was something cruel about the half-inning, how it stubbornly refused to end.

headline: Phoenix Wins Game 1 in Overtime
text: Ray Whitney scored 14 minutes 4 seconds into overtime as the host Phoenix Coyotes defeated the Nashville Predators, 4-3, in the opening game of their Western Conference semifinal series.

headline: Don’t Just Sit There
text: ONE lesson I’ve learned while writing about fitness is that few things impinge on an active life as much as writing about fitness — all that time spent hunched before a computer or puzzling over scientific journals, the countless hours of feckless, seated procrastination. While writing about the benefits of exercise, my muscles slackened. Fat seeped insidiously into my blood, liver and ventricles. Stupor infiltrated my brain.

headline: Refinery Venture Reflects Easing of India-Pakistan Relations
text: The billionaire Lakshmi N. Mittal and an Indian oil company are “formally opening a $4 billion refinery on the northern border with Pakistan,” as India and Pakistan seek to stimulate trade, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Police Clash With Malaysia Protesters Seeking Electoral Reforms
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The police fired tear gas and water cannons on Saturday at thousands of protesters here calling for free and fair elections, in one of the largest rallies in Malaysia in recent years.

headline: Energy Meeting Hopes to Bring Light to Millions of Homes
text: “Their work is not sexy and generates little controversy or media coverage,” but a group of energy and environment ministers from 22 countries and the European Union is claiming “substantial progress in spreading energy efficiency and more affordable energy around the globe,” John M. Broder writes in Green blog of The New York Times.

headline: Afghan Official Survives Attack by Insurgents
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — In an episode with worrisome significance for the security industry, two Taliban insurgents with pistols hidden in their shoes evaded an American-operated full-body scanner and nearly succeeded in assassinating the governor of Kandahar on Saturday.

headline: Stranded on a Not-So-Strange Land
text: For five years, Jiri Makovec, 35, a Czech photographer, stranded himself on an island.

headline: Following A Spirit Of Discovery
text: Since forming a dozen years ago the Wayne Shorter Quartet has held to a rigorously thorough standard of discovery, welcoming not only flashes of inspiration but also irresolute pauses, stubborn quandaries and heady longueurs.

headline: Remarks by Former Official Fuel Israeli Discord on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — The recently retired chief of Israel’s internal security agency accused the government of “misleading the public” about the likely effectiveness of an aerial strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, ratcheting up the criticism of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak from the country’s security establishment.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Approximately 152 senior police officers from the state have been transferred following a state cabinet decision. This announcement comes ahead of the bi-annual formality of shifting the government offices to the summer capital of Srinagar from the winter capital, Jammu. (Kashmir Live)

headline: The Horror of the Handshake
text: You could put together a good-sized mob of people who would probably rather step on John Terry’s hand than shake it. Start with Wayne Bridge. And Alexis Sánchez. And Tottenham’s defense. And nightclub bouncers. And Americans.

headline: Comparing Quinton Coples With Jason Pierre-Paul
text: Quinton Coples, the new Jets defensive end, has said that his game most resembles that of the Giants star Jason Pierre-Paul.

headline: A Conversation With: Actor Prosenjit Chatterjee
text: Dibakar Banerjee’s film “Shanghai,” scheduled for a June 8 release, brings Bengali actor Prosenjit Chatterjee back to Bollywood after a 20-year hiatus. “I needed a sexy leading man,” Mr. Banerjee, famous for his National Award-winning “Khosla Ka Ghosla” and “Oye Lucky! Lucky Oye!,” told a news conference in Kolkata on Monday.

headline: Giants Thrilled to Land Rueben Randle
text: The Giants seemed overjoyed Friday night to land L.S.U. receiver Rueben Randle. By the time the last pick of the second round rolled around, Randle was the highest player on their board — “by far,” the Giants said.  Why didn’t they trade up just to be sure they could grab him? General Manager Jerry Reese said the Giants hadn’t had great experiences with that strategy. So they waited — “We don’t panic” — and were rewarded. The Giants actually considered taking Randle at the end of the first round.

headline: Nine Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The New Yorker
text: Let’s first dispense with the question of whether I really read every one of the 55,000 words in this week’s New Yorker. All I can say is I tried. One of my favorite discoveries was a quote from Walt Frazier. As a girl growing up in New York City, I was obsessed with the Knicks guard. Back then you could write him a worshipful letter, care of the Garden, and get back a signed black-and-white photo. Once before a home game, my friend Paul and I saw him on the street after he got out of his Rolls. We asked him for his autograph — two adoring 12-year-olds offering up a couple of pieces of lined paper — and he told us he was only signing copies of a book about him that recently had been published, and then he turned away. I still loved him. But it was hard not to harbor a grudge. And then came all those years of his jangling play-by-play commentary. But I couldn’t help but feel a new sense of tenderness when he explained himself in Talk of the Town: “When I was a player, I rarely read anything, unless it was about me. Now I get The Times Arts & Leisure section, where they critique the plays: Riveting! Mesmerizing! Provocative! Profound! Dazzling! All these different words. I like the way they sound, so I write them down and use them.”

headline: For Northwestern Football Deonte Gibson Is a Burgeoning Star
text: Ask Northwestern football players about Deonte Gibson, and they will all say the same thing.

headline: At Google, a Moment to Pause
text: In the driven, intensely competitive atmosphere that is Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., a popular course teaches employees how to defuse emotions and tap their inner serenity and resilience.

headline: Euro Austerity, Continued
text: Martin Wolf does his own version of my austerity versus growth analysis; he uses a different measure of austerity and a different time period, but the results are basically the same. Martin’s graph, which would be unreadably small in this format, is here.

headline: A Shakespeare Olympiad in Dozens of Languages
text: The plays of William Shakespeare have such universal appeal that they have been performed in various languages worldwide. Now audiences can enjoy the Bard in multiple languages in one fell swoop. Globe to Globe, a festival from London’s Globe Theater, showcases 37 of Shakespeare’s plays performed in different languages by 37 international companies.

headline: Where The Productivity Went
text: Larry Mishel has a systematic breakdown of the reasons for worker income stagnation since 1973. He starts with the familiar divergence: productivity up 80 percent, the compensation (including benefits) of the median worker up only 11 percent. Where did the productivity go?

headline: Bombs Add to Soccer Festival Woes
text: LONDON — The decision to invite Ukraine to co-host Europe’s most important soccer tournament this year was a controversial one — and that was before four bomb explosions rocked the country’s third largest city on Friday.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Kentucky Derby Dreams’
text: In the winter of 2009, I went to Taylor Made Farm in Nicholasville, Ky., to chronicle a thoroughbred breeding farm. Thirty-five thousand thoroughbred foals were born in North America that year, about 400 of them at Taylor Made. I stayed with the farm’s 2009 foals, focusing on about a dozen of them, through the seasons of their young life until they were sold at the nation’s premiere yearling sales at Saratoga and Keeneland in 2010.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Translation and a Robot Weaver
text: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

headline: Protests in Malaysia
text: Police unleashed tear gas and chemical-laced water Saturday at thousands of demonstrators who staged one of Malaysia’s largest street rallies in years, demanding fair rules for national elections expected soon.

headline: Business Day Live | Chade-Meng Tan
text: April 27, 2012 - Google's Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world.

headline: Four Fiscal Charts
text: Here’s an exercise I did for my own edification — and to prepare for questions on book tour — but others may be interested in the results. I wanted a simple answer to the people who always insist that we must be having massive fiscal stimulus because we have a big budget deficit; my answer is that the deficit is a result of the depressed economy, but how do we show that without getting too much into the weeds?

headline: A Humbled Gap Tries a Fresh Coat of Pep
text: THIS can’t be a Gap: the mannequins look kind of happy.

text: EUROPE is hitting another rough patch. But this time, the troubles have barely rattled world financial markets. That’s a huge change.

headline: Refocused, After a Staggering Loss
text: I’VE always handled stress well. Any job would bore me if it didn’t have an element of stress. Part of my coping secret is that I compartmentalize. So when I’m at work, I’m 100 percent at work. When I’m mothering, I’m 100 percent Mommy.

headline: Hey, Not So Fast on European Austerity
text: EUROPEAN policy makers just don’t get it. To hear them talk, you’d think that Europe was on the right path. Troubled countries just need more of the same, they say — more fiscal austerity, more labor market flexibility, more price stability — and the European crisis will be licked.

headline: Chicken Scratches vs. Electronic Prescriptions
text: AS e-mail and texting have become our favored means of written communication, handwriting has almost disappeared. Penmanship is becoming a modern form of hieroglyphics, intelligible only to literary scholars.

headline: The Man Is a Coach. Period.
text: KENSINGTON, Conn. — The unofficial Chicago Bulls fan club of central Connecticut gathered around a 110-inch television one Thursday earlier this month. One family composed most of the club, four parents and two siblings who live here within half a mile of one another, the entire brood close by, always, except for one.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m sure that most of us have seen Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams puzzles, but if you are just tuning in, PandA puzzles are crossword-style puzzles whose clues are precisely what the title implies: they are usually all puns or anagrams. Some of them require putting words together, and I’ll talk about that in a bit.

headline: International Bird Rescue
text: In 1971, two oil tankers collided near the Golden Gate Bridge. The spill of 800,000 gallons of oil contaminated the coastline and wildlife, including countless aquatic birds. Volunteers who treated 7,000 of the oil-coated birds later created International Bird Rescue in Berkeley’s Aquatic Park. International Bird Rescue, which is now at the edge of the Suisun Marsh in Fairfield, gives baths, medical treatments and tender attention to scores of sick, injured or oil-coated birds at a state-of-the-art hospital. LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: In Oakland, Officials Say Police Used Illegal Tactics
text: Last week, as Oakland prepared for what organizers expect to be the largest Occupy Oakland protest since November, the city’s police department called a news conference to announce major reforms to its crowd-control policies.

text: As Brendan Shanahan approached his Midtown office building Thursday afternoon, a hockey fan was waiting for him. During Shanahan’s 20 years as an N.H.L. player, he embraced meeting fans. But Shanahan now wears a suit to work as the league’s disciplinarian, and people are rarely happy with him.

headline: Daring Circle, Now at Risk, Aided Activist’s Flight in China
text: BEIJING — For months, Chen Guangcheng, one of China’s best-known dissidents, played a cat-and-mouse game with the phalanx of guards encircling his home. He dug a tunnel to try to escape, a friend says, but was found out. And he sneaked out a video that alerted his supporters to the smothering confinement he said he and his wife endured at the hands of the men who kept them virtual prisoners in their rural farmhouse.

headline: White Sox Have First Base Covered
text: For decades, the premier positions for excellence through the decades were center field for the Yankees and left field for the Boston Red Sox. Maybe we should consider another: first base for the Chicago White Sox.

headline: Reveling in a Tech Life
text: I GREW up outside London and attended a private French school, the Lycée Français de Londres. My parents owned a printing company in London and would drop off my younger brother and me in the morning and pick us up after work. I attended that school from age 4 until I enrolled in the University of Oxford to study chemistry.

headline: A Beating in the Stands, Followed by One on the Field
text: Ty Cobb ruled the baseball world in the era before Babe Ruth. Fiery, profane and bearing a long list of grudges, Cobb often dominated games while turning almost everyone else into an adversary. He baited pitchers, argued with umpires and slid into bases with sharpened spikes; on and off the field, he was involved in numerous, often violent, incidents. Even his teammates disliked him.

headline: In the Philippines, Haunted by History
text: THE Philippines is haunted by its relationship with the United States. I remember the day, in 1991, when the Military Bases Agreement between the two countries was rescinded. The headlines yelled, finally: Freedom! But worrywarts held on to their beads. Clark Air Force Base and Subic Naval Base were America’s largest overseas outposts — powerful vestiges of colonial rule decades after the American occupation, which lasted from 1899 to 1946, had ended. In American history books those decades have fallen into an Orwellian memory hole: lost or abridged.

headline: For Jets, Harnessing Stephen Hill’s Speed
text: No, Matt Waldman of the Rookie Scouting Portfolio did not write a preview series on every single player who was drafted these past three days. But coincidentally in the past few months, his blog has featured several players who have been chosen by the Giants and the Jets. And coincidentally, Matt has helped the Fifth Down preview the draft. So here are some outtakes from his coverage of wide receiver Stephen Hill of Georgia Tech, chosen by the Jets with the 43rd pick after they surrendered two late-round picks to move up.

headline: A Universal Language of Sports-Talk Radio
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Before the big game that night, the radio caller wanted to talk about his team. He wanted to rant and to plead, to rationalize and to predict. He wanted, perhaps most of all, to complain.

headline: A World Title Match Without the Best Players
text: Viswanathan Anand and Boris Gelfand will have to forget their recent struggles when they begin their match for the world title in Moscow a week from Thursday.

headline: Base Serves as Home for Children Caught at Border
text: SAN ANTONIO — At lunchtime, teenage boys in red and blue T-shirts stood in line as they entered a hushed cafeteria for hamburgers and hot dogs. Just days earlier, many of them risked their lives crossing the border from Mexico into the United States, but now they were spending their time in spotless, orderly rooms, with police officers ensuring their safety, registered nurses monitoring their health and a host of board games, movies and outdoor activities keeping them entertained.

headline: If Peas Can Talk, Should We Eat Them?
text: Imagine a being capable of processing, remembering and sharing information — a being with potentialities proper to it and inhabiting a world of its own. Given this brief description, most of us will think of a human person, some will associate it with an animal, and virtually no one’s imagination will conjure up a plant.

headline: Griffin Will Help Introduce ‘a New Dimension’
text: Bill Polian was at the draft last week, wondering about the future of the N.F.L. Just a few months removed from his job as the president of the Indianapolis Colts, Polian is still familiar with the players who are entering the league, the ones he was scouting not long ago. He remembers the first time he saw in person Robert Griffin III, the second overall pick.

headline: He Is 56, and Short, but Stars at 3 Positions
text: Onstage at the Longacre Theater, Peter Scolari is in “Magic/Bird,” slipping in and out of characters, changing in and out of blazers, pullovers, warm-up suits and sneakers, and moving in and out of accents.

headline: For Sale Online: Yankees Cap (Used)
text: David Wells was in Detroit last Saturday, preparing for a broadcast the next day, when he watched the final inning of Philip Humber’s perfect game on television. As Humber wobbled against the leadoff man in the ninth inning, Wells rooted him on.

headline: Loyal Companion Helps a Veteran Regain Her Life After War Trauma
text: SAN DIEGO — The hovering aircraft was just a plain-vanilla traffic chopper, a benignly common species to Southern California skies. But its mere presence overhead was enough to make Tori Stitt stiffen.

headline: A New Pawn in China’s Two Tugs of War

headline: This Season, Celtics Are at Once Hobbling and Walking Tall
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — The Celtics played the first game of the lockout-shortened 2011-12 season, opening against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 25.

headline: Questions of Bias and Balance
text: Re “A Hard Look at the President” (April 22): I like your push for The Times to avoid bias in covering the presidential election. It strikes me as admirable even though, as a liberal, I naturally think that charges of bias against The Times are often overheated.

headline: The Post-Cash, Post-Credit-Card Economy
text: YOU walk into a cafe, order a macchiato, give your name to the barista and let him give you the once-over. That’s it. Payment made.

headline: Weapons of Peculiar Destruction
text: “The special actions of our revolutionary armed forces will start soon to meet the reckless challenge of the group of traitors,” the North Korean military command’s “special operation action group” said in a statement. ... “They will reduce all the ratlike groups and the bases for provocations to ashes in three or four minutes, in much shorter time, by unprecedented peculiar means and methods of our own style.”

headline: Thomas P. Campbell
text: Thomas P. Campbell is the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

headline: Dancap Leaves ‘Prince of Broadway’ Production
text: Dancap Productions has pulled out as lead producer of “Prince of Broadway,” the musical retrospective of the career of the Tony Award-winning producer and director Harold Prince, which is aiming to open on Broadway in November.

headline: A Romney Rambler Looks Back
text: ON Tuesday night, Mitt Romney stood at a lectern in New Hampshire, the state where he first announced his candidacy nearly 11 months ago, and unofficially assumed the mantle of the Republican Party.

headline: Terrorist Plots, Hatched by the F.B.I.
text: THE United States has been narrowly saved from lethal terrorist plots in recent years — or so it has seemed. A would-be suicide bomber was intercepted on his way to the Capitol; a scheme to bomb synagogues and shoot Stinger missiles at military aircraft was developed by men in Newburgh, N.Y.; and a fanciful idea to fly explosive-laden model planes into the Pentagon and the Capitol was hatched in Massachusetts.

headline: Warrior in Chief
text: THE president who won the Nobel Peace Prize less than nine months after his inauguration has turned out to be one of the most militarily aggressive American leaders in decades.

headline: Playoff Teams Have Strength in Reserve
text: Every good team needs strong play from its bench. With the playoffs set to begin, the following bench players were the most productive reserves, ordered by player efficiency rating, among those averaging 15 to 20 minutes a game. They may not be famous, but they are often pivotal to their teams’ chances of advancing.

headline: Needing to Get Faster, the Jets Act Quickly
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The two defining plays of the Jets’ disappointing 2011 season did more than produce anguish and heartbreak. They also informed the team’s strategy for this year’s draft.

headline: A Senator Fights Back
text: It is dangerous to challenge the funnel cloud of corporate and right-wing political advertising this year, but Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, has decided to fight back. She is running commercials that talk directly about the ads trying to prevent her re-election.

headline: Cozy Deal
text: Congress long ago shirked its responsibility to provide the Food and Drug Administration with sufficient money to do its job. So the companies that make drugs and medical devices — complaining that it took too long to win approval for their products — offered to pay “user fees” if the F.D.A. would hire more people to evaluate their applications. Critics charge that those cozy cash-fed agreements have given industry far too much influence over the regulatory process. Industry says that without the money, patients would have to wait far too long to get access to new treatments.

headline: Truth and Atonement in North Carolina
text: North Carolina is about to provide a bittersweet postscript to the sad and brutal history of eugenics in America. Of the 32 states that once had laws for compulsory sterilization of people deemed “feeble-minded,” “moronic” and otherwise undesirable as parents, none was more aggressive. In North Carolina, the power to recommend sterilization was extended beyond physicians to welfare workers charged with cutting the cost of the public dole.

headline: We Are All Nuns
text: CATHOLIC nuns are not the prissy traditionalists of caricature. No, nuns rock!

headline: The Torrent of Spring
text: Spring is the torrential season. On a bright, blue-skied day in April or May, it can feel as if you’re standing in a river of biological change, whether you’re in Central Park or out in the country. Everything seems to be regenerating — every species of plant, animal and insect — all of them cued to the new light and the new warmth. It’s as though we’re living in three kinds of time at once: geological time, which is too slow for us to grasp, human time, which is just right, and tulip time, which comes and goes in the blink of an eye.

headline: Bishops Play Church Queens as Pawns
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Words of the Prophets
text: Beirut, Lebanon

headline: The Human Cost of ‘Zero Tolerance’
text: There is no proof that the zero-tolerance policing adopted by New York and other cities in the 1990’s had anything to do with the decline in violent crime across the nation. Crime also dropped in jurisdictions that did not use the approach.

headline: The Imperiled Promise of College
text: FOR a long time and for a lot of us, “college” was more or less a synonym for success. We had only to go. We had only to graduate. And if we did, according to parents and high-school guidance counselors and everything we heard and everything we read, we could pretty much count on a career, just about depend on a decent income and more or less expect security. A diploma wasn’t a piece of paper. It was an amulet.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: When to Hold Recall Votes
text: Readers debate what misdeeds justify an official’s early exit.

headline: Incredible Shrinking Country
text: “THE Children of Men,” P. D. James’s 1992 novel, is set in a future where the world’s male population has become infertile, and an aging Britain is adapting to the human race’s gradual extinction. Women push dolls in baby carriages. Families baptize kittens. There are state-run “national porn shops” to stimulate the flagging male libido. Suicide flourishes. Immigrants are welcomed as guest laborers but expelled once they become too old to work. The last children born on earth — the so-called “Omegas” — have grown up to be bored, arrogant, antisocial and destructive.

headline: A First Round Filled With Close Games and Surprises
text: The unpredictability of the Stanley Cup playoffs was evident in the competitiveness of the opening round, which included a dethroning of the champion Boston Bruins.

headline: Amos Vogel, Champion of Films, Dies at 91
text: Amos Vogel, who exerted an influence on the history of film that few other non-filmmakers can claim, founding Cinema 16, which became the nation’s largest membership film society, and directing the first New York Film Festival, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 91.

headline: Marty and Nick Jr. Go to America
text: I PAID my first visit to America in 1958, at the age of 9, and I liked it so much that I stayed for almost a year. Before we embarked on the Queen Elizabeth, my brother Philip (age 10) and I took the wise precaution of changing our names. For me it was quite straightforward: I would be known, stateside, as Marty. Philip was more imaginative, adapting one of his middle names and coming up with Nick Jr. — while boldly ignoring the fact that there was no Nick Sr. My middle name, I later realized, would have been perfect just as it was: Louis (my parents were admirers of Louis Armstrong). Anyway, when the great liner approached the glittering immensity of New York, Nick Jr. and Marty were fully prepared.

headline: Unexceptionalism: A Primer
text: TO achieve unexceptionalism, the political ideal that would render the United States indistinguishable from the impoverished, traditionally undemocratic, brutal or catatonic countries of the world, do the following:

headline: Hello, Martians. Let Moby-Dick Explain
text: LAST night the Martians touched down in the backyard. They were oval and bright pink, with two antlike antennae topped by eyes fringed with sea-anemone lashes. They said they’d come to study America.

headline: Saudis Close Embassy in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia closed its embassy here on Saturday and recalled its ambassador, setting off a diplomatic crisis that seemed to catch Egypt’s military rulers off guard and left them struggling to repair a rift with a financial benefactor and a long-time ally.

headline: Infractions
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to go out on a limb and confess that this is the second pass I’m making at writing this post. I trashed the first draft, which is rare. And although she didn’t know it until now, I owe Tracy Gray an apology.

headline: Explaining a Slowdown in Health Care Spending
text: While the decline in the growth of national health care spending has largely been attributed to the recession, the changing behaviors of consumers and providers may also be a factor. As a share of the economy, health expenditures remained steady from 2009 to 2010.

headline: In Hopeful Sign, Health Spending Is Flattening Out
text: WASHINGTON — The growth of health spending has slowed substantially in the last few years, surprising experts and offering some fuel for optimism about the federal government’s long-term fiscal performance.

headline: How One Hospital Bent the Cost Curve
text: In an article in The Times on Sunday, I look at whether there is more than meets the eye in the slowdown in health care costs.

text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

Kreider, a rookie forward who was still on his parents’ cellphone plan when he joined the Rangers from Boston College three weeks ago, had just taken a perfect stretch pass from Derek Stepan and blasted a 43-foot slap shot past Washington goalie Braden Holtby.

headline: Just Like That, It All Goes Wrong for the Knicks
text: MIAMI — Tempers flared, jump shots faltered, a knee buckled, the mood darkened. And a Knicks postseason that had inspired so much promise turned quickly, shockingly gloomy Saturday afternoon.

headline: Pope Vs. Nuns

headline: Garcia’s Next Start in Question After Another Poor Showing

headline: One Killed and Dozens Hurt as Tent Collapses in St. Louis

headline: Data Harvesting at Google Not a Rogue Act, Report Finds

headline: China Blocking All Mention of Chen and His Daring Escape
text: HONG KONG — The improbable late-night escape of the blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng from house arrest in his rural village has thrilled anti-abortion campaigners and human rights groups, while humiliating the security forces who were charged with sealing off Mr. Chen and his family.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Why has the promise of India remained unfulfilled? Basharat Peer enumerates the many reasons for India’s recent failures and uncertain future in an article in Foreign Affairs magazine. The piece argues that while India’s elite and growing middle class have become increasingly vociferous at expounding their aspiration for India to become a great power, the country has little to show for it. Mr. Peer analyzes two popular books from last year – “Behind the Beautiful Forevers,” by Katherine Boo, and “The Beautiful and the Damned,” by Siddhartha Deb – to show how increasing inequity hampers the promise of India’s growing international influence.

headline: Years Roll By as Famed Tavern Struggles to Reopen

text: A smile creased General Manager Jerry Reese’s face Saturday when he began discussing Adrien Robinson, the Cincinnati tight end whom the Giants selected with the final pick in the fourth round, the 127th selection over all.

headline: We’re Doomed
text: Update: So you see what I mean. We have a terrible failure of demand — and Carly Fiorina thinks the key problem is excessive taxes on corporations (our effective rate is actually fairly low). Hey, if only we had low rates like Ireland, we could have 14.7 percent unemployment … oh well, never mind.

headline: New Model Needed for Race-Day Treatment, a Veterinarian Says
text: The white horse emerged late last year representing promise to restore a limping game; a new age of clean racing, race-day-medication-free racing; but the white horse hung coming down the lane. Too much Lasix, it seems; resulting in an inability to hold sway.

headline: Going to Heathrow? A Few Survival Tips
text: Heathrow Airport in London operates at 99 percent capacity, with 1,305 take-offs and landings each day – one every 45 seconds, except during the overnight ban. Since it can’t add capacity to ease demand during the Olympic Games in July, the airport authority aims to boost organization on the ground.

headline: Disruptions: With No Revenue, an Illusion of Value
text: The gears of Silicon Valley continue to mesh and turn because of money, not necessarily technological innovations. And there are certain things about that money machine that denizens of the Valley would rather keep quiet.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘The Kentucky Derby’
text: An excerpt from “The Kentucky Derby: How the Run for the Roses Became America’s Premier Sporting Event” regarding the controversial 1968 race.

headline: Obama Campaign Grapples With New Voter ID Laws
text: WASHINGTON — Field workers for President Obama’s campaign fanned out across the country over the weekend in an effort to confront a barrage of new voter identification laws that strategists say threaten the campaign’s hopes for registering new voters ahead of the November election.

headline: Romney Calls for Protecting Chinese Dissident
text: Mitt Romney weighed in on the looming diplomat crisis between the United States and China, calling on Sunday for the Obama administration to “take every measure” to protect a blind dissident and his family after his daring escape from house arrest last week.

headline: With a Steel Column, a Tower Will Reclaim the Manhattan Sky
text: If the winds are forgiving enough over Lower Manhattan — up where workers can see the whole outline of the island’s tip — a steel column will be hoisted into place Monday afternoon atop the exoskeleton of 1 World Trade Center and New York will have a new tallest building.

headline: Bill Clinton Deployed to Help Obama Raise Cash
text: WASHINGTON – Former President Bill Clinton is coming to the aid of President Obama on Sunday night in the first of a series of joint fund-raisers intended to tap his deep-pocketed network and marry two wings of a party that have lived together uneasily since their 2008 showdown.

headline: ‘The Avengers,’ a Week Away at Home, Leads Overseas
text: All of Hollywood’s action over the weekend was overseas, where Walt Disney Studios released “The Avengers” in 39 markets and took in $178.4 million. This superhero movie, which arrives in the United States next weekend (kicking off moviedom’s summer season), set records in 12 territories.

headline: Yankees Send Struggling Garcia to the Bullpen
text: The Yankees’ starting rotation has been a question mark all season with injuries and ineffectiveness forcing the team to overuse its bullpen and often play from behind. The team made a move to change things Sunday, demoting the struggling Freddy Garcia to the bullpen.

headline: Seven Killed as S.U.V. Plunges Into the Bronx Zoo
text: 10:27 p.m. | Updated  The revised version of this post is available here.

headline: New Taxicabs Are Green, Literally
text: Call it how you see it: Lime. Mint. Wasabi. Or perhaps you might prefer a nonedible comparison.

headline: The Coach, the Biographer and the Last Chapter
text: “This won’t be another book about X’s and O’s, will it?” Joe Paterno’s daughter Mary Kay asked.

headline: Protesters in Malaysia Accuse Police of Brutality
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Displaying bruises and scrapes, participants in a weekend protest said Sunday that the police used brutal tactics to shut down their rally for fair elections, prompting the organizers to demand an inquiry by the country’s Human Rights Commission.

headline: A Mysterious Woman With a Past, 300 Years of It
text: As much as Puccini’s “Tosca,” Verdi’s “Aida” or Berg’s “Lulu,” Janacek’s 1926 opera, “The Makropulos Case,” comes across as the stunning masterpiece it is only if a production has a soprano who can inhabit the lead role. Here that character is Emilia Marty, the mysterious prima donna at the center of this suspenseful thriller, set in Prague in 1922. On Friday night Karita Mattila sang Marty when the Metropolitan Opera brought back the sleekly modern and inspired 1996 production by Elijah Moshinsky, last seen in 2001.

headline: This Revolution Was British, Fired by Libidos
text: Faramerz Dabhoiwala has endured some awkward moments since his new book, “The Origins of Sex,” an ambitious history of sexuality in 18th-century Britain, was published to rave reviews in that country in January.

headline: A Symbiotic Relationship That Just Keeps Growing
text: With all the reports of financial struggles and labor clashes that have dogged the Philadelphia Orchestra this season, you can lose sight of the fact that on any given night this storied institution will probably prove anew that it remains one of the country’s premier ensembles. Certainly no other American orchestra has cemented as durable and fruitful a relationship with Simon Rattle, the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic and one of the world’s more provocative conductors.

headline: U.S. Drone Strike Underlines Clash of Interests in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An American drone strike killed three suspected militants in Pakistan’s tribal belt on Sunday, an official said, in the first such attack since the country’s Parliament demanded an end to those missions just over two weeks ago.

headline: Obesity-Linked Diabetes in Children Resists Treatment
text: Obesity and the form of diabetes linked to it are taking an even worse toll on America’s youths than medical experts had realized. As obesity rates in children have climbed, so has the incidence of Type 2 diabetes, and a new study adds another worry: the disease progresses more rapidly in children than in adults and is harder to treat.

headline: Theatrical on the Shell, Intricate at the Core
text: A brainy, adventurous Irish songwriter lives within the flamboyant theatricality of Julie Feeney, who’s playing a 10-night stand at the Irish Arts Center through May 6.

headline: April 30/ May 1 Media
text: According to my master schedule,

headline: Worth Watching: ‘African Men, Hollywood Stereotypes’
text: Thanks to a Facebook post by Cameron Sinclair, the executive director of Architecture for Humanity and co-editor of “Design Like You Give a Damn,”I found this fine effort to get beyond the Hollywood vision of the African man:

headline: In Crisis Over Dissident, U.S. Sends Official to Beijing
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration rushed to contain a growing diplomatic crisis between the United States and China, sending a senior diplomat to Beijing to discuss the fate of a blind dissident who fled house arrest last week.

headline: Diabetes in Obese Children Is Tough to Treat
text: The first large study of Type 2 diabetes in children has reached a troubling conclusion: Not only are more children developing the type of diabetes associated with obesity, but the disease develops more quickly and is less responsive to treatment, explains Denise Grady in today’s New York Times:

headline: A Nation’s Best and Worst, Forged in a Crucible
text: On Nov. 22, 1963, when he was told that John F. Kennedy was dead, and that he was now president, Lyndon B. Johnson later recalled, “I was a man in trouble, in a world that is never more than minutes away from catastrophe.”

headline: When Dancing the Senses, Sometimes No Explanation Is Required
text: “Perceptual Motion,” the new work presented by Battery Dance Company, is about the five senses. During its course, we’re clearly told this — in writing. Typed definitions and scientific descriptions of sight, hearing, touch, taste and smell appear on a screen at the beginning of each section; there’s a particular pleasure in finding that there’s no dumbing down in the way information is stated. Words like “somatosensory” and “mechanoreceptor” are part of the script, and at the matinee I attended on Friday at 3LD Art & Technology Center the audience responded with complete attention throughout because of the work’s serious intelligence.

headline: Top Prizes Awarded at Tribeca Film Festival
text: “War Witch,” the director Kim Nguyen’s feature about a kidnapped African girl who becomes a child soldier, was named the best narrative feature at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival, and its star, Rachel Mwanza, below, was named best actress, the festival’s organizers announced on Thursday night. “Una Noche,” a film by Lucy Mulloy about Cuban teenagers who dream of fleeing Havana for Miami, won the best-actor prize, which was split between two of its leads, Dariel Arrechada and Javier Núñez Florián; Ms. Mulloy was also named best new narrative director for the film, which additionally was cited for best cinematography in a narrative feature film. (Mr. Núñez and another star of the film, Anailín de la Rúa de la Torre, disappeared as they were traveling from Cuba to the festival.) “All In,” Daniel Burman’s film about the romantic life of a professional poker player, won for best screenplay, written by Mr. Burman and Sergio Dubcovsky, and “The World Before Her,” Nisha Pahuja’s film about competitors in the Miss India pageant, took best documentary feature. Two audience awards were announced on Saturday night: “Any Day Now,” the director Travis Fine’s feature inspired by a true story of a gay couple trying to adopt a teenager in Los Angeles during the 1970s, received the audience narrative award, and “Burn,” Tom Putnam and Brenna Sanchez’s film that follows the fire commissioner of Detroit, won the audience documentary award.

headline: Powerhouse Theater Summer Season
text: The playwright Itamar Moses (“Completeness”), the composer Michael Friedman (“Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson”) and the director Daniel Aukin (“4000 Miles”) will join together for a musical workshop based on Jonathan Lethem’s 2003 novel “The Fortress of Solitude” as part of the Powerhouse Theater’s coming summer season. Produced by New York Stage and Film and Vassar College, this year’s plays and musicals in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., begin on June 22. The schedule also will feature “Abigail/1702,” a new work by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”) that is set a decade after the events depicted in “The Crucible” by Arthur Miller, and “The Power of Duff,” a new play by Stephen Belber (“Dusk Rings a Bell”), in which a news anchor has a spiritual awakening on live television.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Joyce Theater has announced that its fall-winter season will include the return of Soledad Barrio and her company Noche Flamenca after a sold-out run at the theater last year. Running Sept. 18 through Jan. 27, the season will also feature a new piece from the choreographer Wen Wei Wang and performances by the dancers Crystal Pite and Russell Maliphant. ... A public memorial tribute to the theater producer and director Theodore Mann, who died in February at 87, will be at 1 p.m. on Tuesday at Circle in the Square Theater, of which he was a founder.

headline: Sabathia Controls Detroit as Rodriguez Moves Past Mays on R.B.I. List
text: Alex Rodriguez tied and later passed Willie Mays for eighth place on the career runs batted in list Sunday, but the story of the day for the Yankees was the continuation of C. C. Sabathia’s hot streak with Chris Stewart behind the plate.

headline: Turkish Writer Opens Museum Based on Novel
text: ISTANBUL — The first thing you see are the cigarette butts. There are thousands of them — 4,213 to be exact — mounted behind plexiglass on the ground floor of the Nobel laureate Orhan Pamuk’s new museum, named for and based on his 2008 novel, “The Museum of Innocence.”

headline: Where Nations Debate, Harmony of a Jazzy Kind
text: From its earliest days, when the pianist Jelly Roll Morton spoke of a “Spanish tinge,” jazz has been extraordinarily open to international influences. Now it’s official. Last fall Unesco — the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization — designated jazz a “universal music of freedom and creativity” and decreed that henceforth every April 30 is to be celebrated around the world as International Jazz Day.

headline: In Vast Jungle, U.S. Troops Aid in Search for Kony
text: OBO, Central African Republic — It has got to be one of the oddest matchups in United States military history.

headline: Ballet Star Gazes Down and Rises Up
text: On Saturday at the David H. Koch Theater a dozen or so of the foremost ballet dancers in the world performed. And yet the star of the evening — there was never any doubt about this — did not appear onstage until after all the dancing was over.

headline: Room at the Inn
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we get started with our solving week, Wordplay would like to extend congratulations to John Hammond, winner of the 2012 Brown University Crossword Tournament. Mr. Hammond finished the playoff puzzle in approximately 17.5 minutes. Stay tuned for some fun puzzles from this tournament, coming up starting tomorrow and appearing over the next week or two. Everybody, say congratulations to Mr. Hammond, pictured below with Will Shortz.

headline: Trial for U.S. Team for World Mind Sports Games
text: The trial to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games in August has reached the knockout stage in Schaumburg, Ill.

headline: Report Shows Quarterly Decline in Video Rental Revenue; Digital Streaming Increases
text: LOS ANGELES — Powerful shifts in viewing habits continued to distort the market for movies and television shows in home entertainment formats, as video rentals from stores and subscription services collapsed in the first quarter of 2012, according to a report from the Digital Entertainment Group. Digital revenue grew just enough to lift overall home entertainment spending in the United States by 2.47 percent, to $4.45 billion compared with $4.3 billion over the same period in 2011.

headline: Orhan Pamuk’s Novel Museum
text: Turkey’s best-known writer opened a museum in Istanbul.

headline: On Second Try, Flyers beat Devils in Game 1
text: PHILADELPHIA — Every series this postseason has been defined by unyielding defense and superb goaltending, every series except those played by the Philadelphia Flyers. They do not mind being the anomaly. They can deal with giving up a few goals as long as they score more.

headline: Bring Back Learning for Learning’s Sake
text: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks’ Lin Reports Soreness in Knee
text: MIAMI — Jeremy Lin’s left knee is sound, but it is not yet ready for the strain of playoff basketball and it may not be until the Knicks have run out of playoff games.

headline: Wal-Mart’s U.S. Expansion Plans Complicated by Bribery Scandal
text: In Los Angeles, a Wal-Mart building permit is getting a once-over. In New York, the City Council is investigating a possible land deal with the retailer’s developer in Brooklyn. A state senator in California is pushing for a formal audit of a proposed Wal-Mart in San Diego. And in Boston and its suburbs, residents are pressuring politicians to disclose whether they have received contributions from the company.

headline: Smoke-Free Residences
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Wait Out Rockies and Win on Davis’s Hit
text: DENVER — The Mets were forced to wait — for Jamie Moyer’s fastball to reach home plate, for their batters to capitalize in scoring situations, for their bullpen to preserve a lead — but after 4 hours 1 minute of baseball, their forbearance was finally rewarded.

headline: Insurers, Doctors and Patients
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spanish and English Mix in a Web Telenovela
text: If viewers are looking for telenovelas in Spanglish with a heavy dose of marketing, then Telemundo’s new Web series “Mia Mundo” will satisfy.

headline: Planting Native Species
text: To the Editor:

headline: Navigating a Tightrope With Amazon
text: Last Tuesday, Buzz Bissinger hopped the Amtrak train to Philadelphia from New York, where he had done a bit of publicity for “After Friday Night Lights,” a 12,000-word e-book that had been performing nicely since its release. But when he opened his laptop to check his ranking on Amazon, he found the book was no longer for sale there.

headline: Nespresso Coffee Develops a Taste for TV
text: NESPRESSO, a division of Nestlé that sells single-serve espresso machines and capsules of coffee worldwide, is introducing its first United States television advertising on Monday.

headline: Are Banks Making Too Much Money From Fees?
text: Do the fees banks charge customers need to be more closely regulated, or are they necessary for the health of the banks, and the economy?

text: Accounts

headline: Amid Rural Decay, Trees Take Root in Silos
text: EUDORA, Kan. — The sight is a familiar one along the dusty back roads of the Great Plains: an old roofless silo left to the elements along with decaying barns, chicken coops and stone homesteads.

headline: Makeup, and Feminist Guilt, at 13
text: My 8th grader began lobbying for makeup — again — shortly before she turned 13. The year before, she’d insisted that “everyone” in her 7th grade class wore makeup except three of them — her and two of her friends.

headline: After Derby Win With Long Shot, Hoping That History Will Repeat
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Penny Chenery, Lucien Laurin and Ron Turcotte found the Kentucky Derby winner’s circle in 1972 with a runner named Riva Ridge. They liked the place so much they decided to come back, and the big red horse named Secretariat provided their second consecutive victory in 1973.

headline: A Race Recast by YouTube and Twitter
text: MEXICO CITY — It sounds like the typical hardball, American-style campaign. The presidential candidate from the incumbent’s party calls the front-runner a “liar” in television and Internet advertisements. Supporters of the front-runner retaliate with a Web site and Twitter posts that say his top opponent “lies.” And the third-place candidate wraps the gaffes of both of them into a YouTube video cheekily titled “Excuses Not to Debate.”

headline: Start-Ups Look to the Crowd
text: When Eric Migicovsky, an engineer, wanted to develop a line of wristwatches that could display information from an iPhone — like caller ID and text messages — he went the traditional route of asking venture capitalists to finance his company.

headline: Richard Bellman, Lawyer Who Fought Discrimination, Dies at 74
text: Richard F. Bellman, a lawyer whose tenacity and legal ingenuity propelled him to victory in fights with local governments over racially discriminatory zoning, including in a landmark case against Mount Laurel, N.J., in 1975, died on April 18 on his way to work in Manhattan, where he also lived. He was 74.

headline: In Terrorists’ Testimony, a Rare, Intimate Look Into a Secretive World
text: There was a British man who nearly became the second shoe bomber and took his orders directly from Osama bin Laden.

headline: Hardly a Close Ally, Clinton Teams With Obama to Raise Cash and Votes
text: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Barack Obama wrested control of the Democratic Party after portraying Bill Clinton as a symbol of small-ball ambition and outdated politics. Now, as president, Mr. Obama is turning to his Democratic predecessor for help as Republicans breathe down his neck.

headline: Sudan Declares State of Emergency as Clashes Continue
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan declared a state of emergency on Sunday along much of its border with South Sudan as the momentum toward all-out war continues to build after weeks of clashes over disputed areas and oil.

headline: State Report Says Racing Association Knowingly Withheld Millions
text: The operator of the Saratoga, Aqueduct and Belmont racetracks knowingly withheld nearly $8.5 million that was due to bettors over a 15-month period, according to a new state report, and the Cuomo administration has asked the state inspector general to determine if executives broke civil or criminal laws.

headline: On Report Cards for City Schools, Invisible Line Between ‘A’ and ‘F’
text: Public School 30 and Public School 179 are about as alike as two schools can be. They are two blocks apart in the South Bronx. Both are 98 percent black and Latino. At P.S. 30, 97 percent of the children qualify for subsidized lunches; at P.S. 179, 93 percent.

headline: The Day After
text: THE one thing everyone knows about North Korea is that we know very little about North Korea, except that it is miserable, totalitarian, nuclear and erratic. It is the hermit kingdom, the dark side of the moon.

headline: Teetering, Dewey Ousts Ex-Head From Post
text: Dewey & LeBoeuf, the corporate law firm fighting for survival amid partner defections and heavy debt, ousted its former chairman from the firm’s management on Sunday and ended talks with a potential merger partner, according to an internal memo.

headline: Bulls Stay Positive After Losing Rose
text: DEERFIELD, Ill. — A day after Derrick Rose crumpled to the floor with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee, the Chicago Bulls were still dealing with the aftershocks of the news that they would have to continue their postseason without Rose, their star point guard and the league’s reigning most valuable player.

headline: Wasting Our Minds
text: In Spain, the unemployment rate among workers under 25 is more than 50 percent. In Ireland almost a third of the young are unemployed. Here in America, youth unemployment is “only” 16.5 percent, which is still terrible — but things could be worse.

headline: The C.I.A.’s Misuse of Secrecy
text: IN Yemen, Pakistan and elsewhere the C.I.A. has used drones to kill thousands of people — including several Americans. Officials have aggressively defended the controversial program, telling journalists that it is effective, lawful and closely supervised.

headline: What’s in a Name? (Part 1)
text: This is the first in a three-part series.

headline: The Civil War’s Rip Van Winkle
text: In 1860 Isaac Hayes went to find the North Pole; in 1862 he returned to a nation transformed.

headline: Final Farewells at a Legendary Radio Station
text: One worker went around collecting autographs on a T-shirt. Another solemnly handed thank-you notes sealed in stationery envelopes to some of the disc jockeys. Other employees smiled from behind the microphones, posing for cameras and cellphones.

headline: Scandal and Scrutiny Hem In Murdoch’s Empire
text: In the months after a phone-hacking scandal erupted in Britain last summer, Rupert Murdoch told people within News Corporation that he wanted to revisit his media company’s discontinued $12 billion bid for the pay television service British Sky Broadcasting.

headline: Lakers Open With a Familiar Thrashing of the Nuggets
text: LOS ANGELES — For the Denver Nuggets, at least, the road to the N.B.A. finals still runs through here.

headline: The Economy Downshifts
text: The slow start for the economy in 2012 — an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the first three months of the year — is evidence that the recovery is too weak to push joblessness much lower than its current 8.2 percent, and too fragile to withstand the kinds of budget cuts Congressional Republicans are proposing.

headline: Making Headway on a Plan to Lure Producers to China
text: LOS ANGELES — Bruno Wu, a Chinese media entrepreneur, is pushing ahead with his previously declared plan to expand the production of global films in China, despite a chill that ran through movie circles last week amid reports that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether American studios had made illegal payments to officials in China.

headline: United vs. City Reaches Far Beyond Manchester
text: MANCHESTER, England — Slanting rain and a vicious wind sent ripples and eddies across the puddles forming outside Manchester City’s Etihad Stadium on Sunday. Workers spilled out of two satellite television trucks, ferrying cables and cameras into the stadium to prepare for what could be the most anticipated match in Premier League history.

headline: U.N. Chief Will Ask West to Lift Myanmar Sanctions
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — When he addresses Myanmar’s Parliament on Monday, Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, plans to urge Western nations to lift or suspend their remaining sanctions against the country.

headline: When Rivals Concede, but Are in No Rush to Endorse
text: Mitt Romney has vanquished virtually all of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. Only RepresentativeRon Paul of Texas remains in the race; the rest, evenNewt Gingrich, have bowed to the reality that Mr. Romney will be the nominee.

headline: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
text: Photos from the production at the Classic Stage Company.

headline: For Some Parents, Leaving a Private School Is Harder Than Getting In
text: In February 2011, Nicole Smolowitz’s son was admitted to the Mandell School on the Upper West Side. She signed a contract and paid the $7,500 deposit.

headline: N.F.L. Draft More Closely Resembles Swap Meet, Only With Top-Quality Talent
text: No two N.F.L. drafts are alike.

headline: Foolish Mortals, Naughty Fairies: The Usual Mischief
text: A shower of rose petals descending on a carpet of black wood shavings provides one of the many visual allurements in the Classic Stage Company’s production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” The tilted mirrored wall rising at the back of the theater — like a humongous disco ball squashed flat — reflects the flurrying downfall back to the audience, amplifying the magical feeling of being caught up in the eye of a hot-pink hurricane.

headline: In China, Foreign Films Meet a Powerful Gatekeeper
text: LOS ANGELES — Any foreign movie knocking on China’s door must pass through powerful gatekeepers — the China Film Group and its chief executive, Han Sanping.

headline: Bigotry on the Ballot
text: North Carolina already has a law barring same-sex marriage, but the state’s Republican-controlled Legislature is not satisfied. It devised a measure to enshrine this obvious discrimination in the State Constitution and placed it on the ballot of the state’s May 8 primary election — a test of tolerance versus bigotry that ought to be watched closely nationwide.

headline: Knicks, in Rout, Beat Rangers for TV Viewers
text: New York sports viewers made a clear decision Saturday afternoon between playoff series that began at almost the same time. Game 1 of the first-round series between the Knicks and the Miami Heat and Game 1 of the Washington Capitals-Rangers Eastern Conference semifinals started a half-hour apart, and the N.B.A. game was the overwhelming favorite.

headline: After They Check the Box
text: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has reaffirmed and updated a 25-year-old ruling that bars companies from automatically denying employment to people based on arrest or conviction records. It is must reading for all employers.

headline: 2 Charged in Bronx Subway Stabbing
text: Two people have been charged with attempted murder in the stabbing of a 19-year-old man on a Bronx subway platform, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: 7 Relatives Die as S.U.V. Drops 60 Feet Off Bronx Highway
text: It could not have taken more than a few terrifying seconds from the moment the S.U.V.’s driver lost control on an elevated highway on Sunday to the moment it came to a violent rest about 60 feet below, in a nonpublic area of the Bronx Zoo. The vehicle’s seven occupants, spanning three generations of a Bronx family, were killed on impact, their bodies still inside.

headline: Don’t Bargain With Rail Safety
text: There are worrying signs that Congress is getting ready to retreat from the lesson learned in 2008 when 25 passengers were killed and more than 130 injured in a horrific California rail collision. In the aftermath of that tragedy, Congress did the right thing and passed a law requiring the installation by 2015 of automated control systems on the nation’s passenger lines that can stop a train if an engineer is dozing, incapacitated or just not paying attention. The engineer in the California disaster was found to be text-messaging at the controls when he blew past a red warning signal and collided head-on with a freight train.

headline: A Conversation With Paul Ryan
text: Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin may be the most influential policy maker in the Republican Party.

headline: Book Takes Aim at Murdochs
text: British newspapers were flooded last week with coverage of a judicial inquiry that spent several days relentlessly questioning Rupert Murdoch and his son James.
