text: April 29, 2012

headline: Ryan’s Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan strolls the halls of Capitol Hill with the anarchist band Rage Against the Machine pounding through his earbuds.

headline: Swiss Police Arrest Canadian Tied to Africa Fraud Inquiry
text: OTTAWA — The Swiss police have arrested a former senior executive of SNC-Lavalin, a Canadian construction company that did considerable business with the regime of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan dictator.

headline: Photo Replay: April 29
text: The images of the day include a title fight in boxing, a judo tournament and baseball action.

headline: Jordan the Owner Could Learn From Jordan the Player
text: From 1986, when he scored 63 points against Boston in a playoff game, until his final championship performance in 1998, Michael Jordan owned the N.B.A. spring. The period between April and June used to be called Jordan’s time.

headline: From Mediaite’s Founder, a Site for Blanket Coverage of Celebrity Chefs
text: As Dan Abrams interviewed editor candidates for his next Web site start-up, one of his questions must have stood out. “What’s your favorite celebrity chef feud?”

headline: Anthony Holds Key to All Hope for Knicks
text: MIAMI — To save the Knicks’ postseason, all Carmelo Anthony needs to do is score like himself, pass like Jeremy Lin, defend like Iman Shumpert and protect the rim like Tyson Chandler.

headline: Rangers Are Putting Up Obstacles for Ovechkin
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It may or may not wind up being a bulletin-board quotation, but Alex Ovechkin made a surprising assertion at the Washington Capitals’ practice on Sunday.

headline: On the Highest Floors, Food Comes to the Workers
text: New York, the most vertical of cities, has become a tad blasé about its skyscrapers, high-rise malls and multistory restaurant collections. At last, though, it has a fresh take on the perpendicular: the vertical food-truck court.

headline: When ‘Outdoor’ Ads Are Indoors
text: The industry that Madison Avenue usually refers to as “outdoor advertising,” or simply “outdoor,” is starting an effort to convince agencies and advertisers that it is more than outdoor.

headline: Accretive Denies Accusations of Pressuring Patients to Pay
text: Accretive Health, one of the nation’s largest collectors of medical bills, took issue on Sunday with a report by the Minnesota attorney general’s office that it puts bedside pressure on patients to pay their bills.

headline: Report Says Pepsi in Deals With IHOP and Applebee’s
text: The cola wars are heating up again.

headline: George Vujnovich is Dead at 96; Led War Rescue
text: George Vujnovich, an O.S.S. agent in World War II who oversaw the rescue of more than 500 downed Allied airmen from German-occupied Yugoslavia, his parents’ homeland, died Tuesday in Queens. He was 96.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for March, and the Chicago purchasing managers’ index for April (Monday); the I.S.M. manufacturing index for April and construction spending for March (Tuesday); the ADP employment report for April and factory orders for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, first-quarter productivity and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing report for April (Thursday); and unemployment figures for April (Friday).

headline: Staying Hopeful, No Matter the View
text: MISSION VIEJO, Calif. — After taking a penalty stroke for an errant drive, Jim Abbott studied his approach from about 110 yards to Arroyo Trabuco Golf Club’s short, yet challenging, par-4 sixth hole.

headline: A Radio Merger in New York Reflects a Shifting Industry
text: On its surface, the merger last week of WRKS and WBLS, longtime rivals in the R&B radio format in New York, was business as usual for the broadcast industry. Two struggling competitors combined operations, and a deep-pocketed third party — Disney — came along to lease the leftover frequency.

headline: Moscelyne Larkin, a Founder of Tulsa Ballet, Is Dead at 87
text: Moscelyne Larkin, one of five dancers termed the American Indian ballerinas of Oklahoma and a co-founder of the Tulsa Ballet, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Tulsa, Okla. She was 87.

headline: Finding the Limits of Empathy
text: In any struggle, failure to understand the opposition is a weakness and a point of vulnerability. This is especially true in politics. Both the Democratic and the Republican parties have repeatedly fallen into the trap of overestimating popular support for their own policies and failing to anticipate hostile reactions to them.

headline: Philippines Role May Expand as U.S. Adjusts Asia Strategy
text: FORT MAGSAYSAY, the Philippines — The squad from the United States Army’s 196th Infantry Brigade was moving quietly through the hills of Luzon Island when the staccato bursts of machine gun fire sent them into action.

headline: Making Progress Against Clutter
text: In a column last fall, I announced my intention to rid my home and myself of a half-century of accumulated “stuff” — everything from papers, books, clothing and shoes to packaging material and shopping bags. I’m happy to report significant progress.

headline: Word of the Day | epithet

headline: In Melodeeman, One Horse’s Rise and Fall
text: Melodeeman, a thoroughbred, raced for six years, through surgery, six owners and 47 races. He broke down and was euthanized on the track on Jan. 21, 2010.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Is This the End of Lockhart Gardner?
text: Where to begin? With the attempted sabotage of Lockhart Gardner, Kalinda’s troubled past and her rekindled friendship with Alicia, Jackie’s return and Peter’s bombshell, Sunday night’s Season 3 finale of “The Good Wife” left me feeling like the series had returned to its roots: a savory and satisfying blend of legal sagacity, emotional gravitas and humor.

headline: Lack of a U.S. Apology Is Sticking Point for Pakistan
text: HONG KONG — It was a difficult weekend in Pakistan. The body of a British Red Cross doctor was found, beheaded, dumped by the side of a road in Quetta. A C.I.A. drone strike killed three suspected militants in an old schoolhouse. And talks last week about a “reset” of the deeply troubled relationship with the United States went nowhere, partly because of Washington’s refusal to apologize for an earlier air attack that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers.

headline: Three Years of Kickstarter Projects
text: Almost 50,000 projects have sought financing on Kickstarter since the site began on April 28, 2009. About half successfully reached their fund-raising goals. Each dot represents how much a project raised by its deadline.

headline: One Horse, One Week of Injections
text: Coronado Heights, a 4-year-old thoroughbred who received a diagnosis of early degenerative joint disease, broke down and was euthanized on the track at Aqueduct on Feb. 25. Below, an illustration of the drugs and dosages given to Coronado Heights the week before he broke down.

headline: How the Data Was Analyzed
text: To assess how often horses break down or are injured, The New York Times bought official data covering more than 150,000 race results from 2009 through 2011. The data are compiled by trained “chart callers” and used to put together result charts that bettors use to evaluate horses. The Times searched the data for terms indicating that a horse encountered a physical problem: broke down, vanned off, injured, lame, euthanized, died, collapsed, bleeding or went wrong.

headline: Rise of the Racinos
text: As the popularity of horse racing has diminished, racetracks like Aqueduct in New York have turned to casinos for additional revenue.

headline: As Casinos Enter the Game, Horses Lose
text: Casinos opening at a growing number of racetracks have recalibrated the age-old economic equations of the horse-racing game.

headline: Big Purses, Sore Horses and Death
text: As he trained for his first race, at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, the 3-year-old thoroughbred Wes Vegas galloped on the track most mornings and had two timed workouts. But his handlers also prepared him in another way: In the month before the race, records show, he received 10 intravenous injections of potent drugs for pain, one the day before he ran; two injections of a drug for joint disease; corticosteroid injections in his two front ankles; a sedative; and an ulcer drug.

headline: Breakdown
text: The new economics of horse racing are making an always-dangerous game even more so, as lax oversight puts animal and rider at risk.

headline: Benzion Netanyahu, Hawkish Scholar, Dies at 102
text: Benzion Netanyahu, a scholar of Judaic history who lobbied in the United States for the creation of the Jewish state, wrote a revisionist account of the Spanish Inquisition and became a behind-the-scenes adviser to his son Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, died on Monday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 102.

headline: Ska Vengers Play Tihar

headline: Invisible President
text: MOSCOW — Dmitri Medvedev has entered his last week as president of Russia: on May 7, he will hand back the office to Vladimir Putin. Having served just one four-year term, he will be remembered as one of the country’s shortest-lived rulers. He will also be remembered as one of country’s shortest rulers. At no more than 5’3”, and with his propensity to ­­­wear huge Windsor knots, he often looks like a fourth-grader trying on daddy’s business suit.

headline: Eagles Looking Up; Umenyiora Unhappy
text: The Giants seemed pleased with themselves about their draft picks this past weekend, but managed to displease one of their current players. It’s not a new story. Osi Umenyiora has been unhappy with General Manager Jerry Reese for a while. Giants fans have to hope that Umenyiora can set aside contract distractions and play with abandon, as he did last season during the team’s Super Bowl run. But it seems too much to expect that he’ll be happy doing it.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Microsoft Buys Into the Nook, and Radio’s Shrinking Diversity
text: The e-book wars added a new alliance, the Microsoft-Barnes & Noble joint venture, DealBook reported on Monday. Microsoft has invested $300 million for a 17.6 percent stake in a new Barnes & Noble’s subsidiary composed of its Nook digital-book business and college-texts units; intriguingly, the deal values the subsidiary at $1.7 billion, much more than Barnes & Noble is worth by itself, as The Wall Street Journal noted. Also, as part of the deal, Microsoft has settled its patent dispute with Barnes & Noble, and there will be a Nook application included in the new Windows 8, which is scheduled to have a release preview in early June.

headline: Profile in Style | Misha Nonoo
text: A self-described magpie, the New York-based fashion designer found her aesthetic match in fellow Briton Alexander Gilkes (a co-founder of Paddle 8, an online art market). ‘‘We both have a knack for assembling clutter,’’ she says. The couple (who will wed in Venice in May) spend countless hours scouring antiques markets around the world for offbeat and interesting furnishings that act as an ‘‘Old World-y’’ counterpoint to their contemporary-art-filled apartment in downtown Manhattan. Nonoo’s favorite find is an 18th-century birthing table she bought in L’Isle Sur la Sorgue, in France. ‘‘It now serves a far less serious, but equally important, purpose as our drinks table,’’ she says with a laugh. The pair are consummate hosts who entertain often and effortlessly. According to Nonoo, the recipe for a good dinner party is simple. ‘‘We give our guests a good dose of grape, then it’s time for after-dinner games’’ — celebrity is a current favorite — ‘‘and an obligatory wearing of our collection of fancy-dress costumes and hats.’’ More…

headline: Edible Selby | Net Gains
text: Kirk Lombard, a Bay Area fisherman and self-described ‘‘fish nerd,’’ is not interested in marquee species. ‘‘I fish for the things nobody wants,’’ he says. Rock crab, surf smelt and monkeyface eel have long been his bread and butter, and he proudly holds the California record for the largest monkeyface ever caught (6.1 pounds). When the foraging trend took off — that is, when he started noticing ‘‘young people in tight pants pulling wild asparagus from cracks in sidewalks’’ — Lombard founded a company, Sea Forager, to show landlubbers how to find the city’s little-known sea creatures. He conducts sold-out tours to some of his secret fishing holes, where he demonstrates poke-poling, a method to retrieve the elusive monkeyface. ‘‘It’s great in gumbo,’’ Lombard says. More…

headline: ‘The Mexican’ Is Answering Questions

But in 2004, he assumed another persona: As the protagonist of the column ¡Ask a Mexican! he is fat, gold-toothed, and dons a sombrero to answer readers’ deepest questions about Mexican and Mexican-American life. (Examples: “Are there different kinds of Mexican food?” “Why do Mexicans paint murals on their cars?” “Is Mitt Romney part Mexican?”)

headline: Food Trucks Get Vertical
text: When it isn’t all that easy to get to the food in your workplace or neighborhood, there is an option: The food can come to you. And so, for the last few months, fancy-food trucks have been traveling up the freight elevator of the 19-story Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street in West Chelsea, to offer dining options five days a week to some 6,000 office workers and visitors.

headline: Borough Haul | Crossing Brooklyn Ferry Festival
text: If there are any doubts as to Brooklyn’s status as the coolest borough, Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, a three-day music and film festival named for a poem by the Brooklynite Walt Whitman and curated by the twin brothers Aaron and Bryce Dessner of the much-loved local band The National, should put them to rest. “The independent music scene in Brooklyn is the world capital of that culture,” Bryce says. “And it has a massive visual arts scene.” So when the Brooklyn Academy of Music approached the brothers about putting together a program of musicians and filmmakers who live in the borough, they jumped at the chance. Many of the names on the bill, like St Vincent and the Walkmen, are friends of the Dessners; others, like the Sierre Leone-born Janka Nabay, were chosen to represent Brooklyn’s musical diversity. But despite being organized by a pair of musicians, Crossing Brooklyn Ferry was initially conceived of as a film festival. “BAM is singular in its commitment to commissioning new work, and we wanted the festival to reflect that,” Bryce explains. “Plus it’s exciting for musicians to work with filmmakers, so we decided to commission new films and have scores written for them.” Among the filmmakers who will be screening work at BAM’s Rose Cinemas are Tunde Adebimpe of TV on the Radio, Jonas Mekas, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Poppy de Villeneuve, whose dreamy, black-and-white depiction of an afternoon on the bayou, “And So, We Begin Again,” an excerpt of which can be seen here, was hypnotically scored by Missy Mazzoli. “Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, the poem, talks about leaving Manhattan and islands,” de Villeneuve says. “I took that as a very literal starting point — I went to the Everglades and then the Ten Thousand Islands.”

headline: Romney Says He Would Have Ordered Bin Laden Killing
text: 3:04 p.m. | Updated PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  — Mitt Romney said on Monday that “even Jimmy Carter” would have given the order to kill Osama bin Laden in Pakistan a year ago, dismissing pointed questions by President Obama’s re-election campaign about whether Mr. Romney would have issued the same command the president did.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: The 2012 B2B Ace Awards, sponsored by the Business Marketing Association of New York, were presented on April 18. Digitas, part of the Publicis Groupe, won Best of Show for the “Small Business Saturday” campaign for American Express as well as the award for integrated marketing campaign with a budget of $1 million or more. The runner-up for Best of Show was the Corning Gorilla Glass campaign by Doremus, part of the Omnicom Group, which also won the award for a broadcast television campaign. The “B2B” in the name of the awards is for business-to-business.

headline: Brooklyn Basketball Will Be Black and White
text: eset with a long, checkered past, the Nets wasted no time embracing new traditions.

headline: Assumptions and Attitudes Don’t Survive Cancer
text: MALIGNANT Medical Ethicists Confront Cancer.

headline: A Ten-Volume Look at Jewish Culture
text: Yale University Press and the Posen Foundation are embarking on a 10-volume anthology that covers more than 3,000 years of Jewish cultural artifacts, texts and paintings. “This monumental project includes the best of Jewish culture in its historical and global entirety,” the editor in chief, James E. Young, a professor of English and Judaic Studies at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, said in a news release. “It will provide future generations with a working legacy by which to recover and comprehend Jewish culture and civilization.”

headline: Chandler Says He’ll Be in Knicks’ Lineup for Game 2
text: MIAMI – With bags under his eyes and hope in his voice, Tyson Chandler said he would be in the lineup Monday night to play the Miami Heat. Beyond that, even Chandler is not sure.

headline: Collective Intelligence 2012 Conference at MIT
text: The Collective Intelligence conference at MIT was the first-ever interdisciplinary research conference on the subject. It’s revealing that the event itself was a real exercise in collective intelligence.

headline: Ford Show Truck Is Drafted Into Service After Texas Tornadoes
text: As multiple tornadoes blistered the Dallas area on April 3, a custom-built Ford F-550 Super Duty pickup suddenly went from show truck to fully engaged fire department support vehicle.

headline: Sarkozy Threatens to Sue Over Accusations of Libyan Donations
text: As a close presidential race enters its final week in France, President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Monday that he would file suit against a muckraking French news site “before the end of the campaign” over articles claiming that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi illegally donated roughly $65 million to his 2007 presidential campaign.

headline: 3 Children Killed in Cross-Fire Between Taliban and U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three children were killed and three wounded in cross-fire on Monday when Taliban insurgents attacked a team of American soldiers in southern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

headline: Taking Aim at the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
text: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act has been at the center of a tug of war between business interests and federal authorities.

headline: Milken Panel Asks: Where Are the Deals?
text: LOS ANGELES — A Monday morning panel called “Outlook for M.&A.” at the Milken Institute Global Conference was, thankfully, slightly more interesting than its title would indicate.

headline: Just a Minute: Amy Chozick on News Corp
text: The scrutiny and scandal in Britain around News Corporation has affected its ability to expand and acquire. Amy Chozick discusses her article on the subject.

headline: Tortorella Is Finalist for Coach of the Year
text: John Tortorella was named a finalist for the Jack Adams Award given to the coach of the year, along with Ken Hitchcock of the St. Louis Blues and Paul MacLean of the Ottawa Senators.

headline: People Watching | Jesse Schlesinger
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Celtics’ Rondo Loses His Cool Against the Hawks
text: Yes, the Boston Celtics have survived the lockout-shortened, injury-marred regular season to get to the N.B.A. playoffs. But judging by Sunday’s 83-74 loss to the Hawks in Atlanta, a long postseason run may not be in the cards for the veteran-laden Celtics.

headline: Just a Minute: Chozick on Opportunity Cost of News Corporation’s Troubles
text: In just a minute, Amy Chozick discusses her article “Scandal and Scrutiny Hem In Murdoch’s Empire.”

headline: Watching the Hawks, With an Obscured View
text: We apologize that visibility of the red-tailed hawks’ nest has been significantly reduced. The once pristine view of Washington Square Park from the 12th floor of Bobst Library has been sullied by hawk excrement.

headline: Premier League: Manchester City (1) vs. Manchester United (0)
text: It seems like yesterday, make that a few weeks ago, when Manchester City Manager Roberto Mancini waved the blue flag and declared the race over in England’s Premier League. But now, with only two regular season games left, the Citizens find themselves in first place, on goal differential, after Monday’s 1-0 win against rival United in the Manchester derby at the Etihad Stadium.

headline: Spring’s False Start
text: Q. After a late-winter warm spell that was followed by early-spring cold, I noticed that the trees in my neighborhood did not fully blossom. Even crab apple blossoms perished in the cold. What can we expect by summer?

headline: E! Adds Scripted Series and Reality Shows to Lineup
text: The E! network announced an ambitious lineup of original programming Monday, including a new singing competition from one of the producers of “American Idol,” a relationship show with a Jonas brother (and his wife), and a weekly talk show with the comedian Whitney Cummings, which could raise questions about the future of her NBC sitcom.

headline: In Fight Over Obama Health Law, a Front in Minnesota
text: ST. PAUL — With zeal, excitement and a meticulous attention to detail, the administration of Gov. Mark Dayton is trying to expand health insurance coverage and remake Minnesota’s insurance market along the lines envisioned by President Obama.

headline: Peters and Jackman to Get Special Tonys
text: The Broadway darlings Bernadette Peters and Hugh Jackman will receive special Tony Awards at the June 10 awards ceremony, the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing announced on Monday. Ms. Peters, who appeared most recently on Broadway in “Follies,” will receive the Isabelle Stevenson Award for her volunteer work to benefit animal rescue groups and shelters. She has also worked on behalf of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, Standing Tall, and the Actors Fund of America.

headline: E.R. Doctors Face Quandary on Painkillers
text: Dr. Bruce Lobitz, an attending physician in the emergency department at Upstate Carolina Medical Center in Gaffney, S.C., sees about 10 patients a week complaining of toothaches. “The bane of our existence,” he calls them.

headline: Pro-Romney ‘Super PAC’ Scrubs Negative Ads
text: As Republicans rally to unify behind the presumptive nominee Mitt Romney, the campaign’s allies are working to heal old wounds from the bruising primary fight. In the latest example, the pro-Romney “super PAC” Restore Our Future has scrubbed its YouTube account of all negative ads against Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum.

headline: Cheese and Red Wine, Together Again
text: BACK in the old days, before the Internet or even electricity, red wine and cheese were thought to belong together as surely as pomp and circumstance. It was customary to serve the cheese course after the meal, to be consumed with the red that remained in the bottle after the roast had been finished. It seemed so obvious it did not warrant debate.

headline: Kickstarter Surprises Tech Startup
text: Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter for The New York Times, interviews one of the creators of the “Pebble” e-paper watch, a device that has received a massive following on Kickstarter.

headline: Farewell, Dr. Spock. Hello, Snooki.
text: For all too many of us, motherhood has the potential to be a salary and job killer. But as Jacob Bernstein so excellently reported in the Styles section on Sunday, it has turned into a savvy career move for an increasing number of C-level celebrities for whom, as he puts it, “motherhood pays.”

headline: TimesCast | Microsoft to Invest In Nook
text: April 30, 2012 - Microsoft invests in Barnes & Noble's Nook.

headline: Widow of Man Shot by C.I.A. Contractor in Pakistan Is Killed by Her Father
text: The widow of a man who died at the hands of a C.I.A. contractor in Pakistan last year was fatally shot by her father on Monday, according to police officers in the city of Lahore.

headline: TimesCast: Microsoft’s Deal Spurs E-Book Market
text: Michael J. de la Merced and Gregory Cowles discuss the impact of Microsoft’s $300 million investment in Barnes & Noble’s Nook unit.

headline: Cumulus, a Growing Radio Power, Sells 55 Scattered Stations
text: Cumulus Media, the nation’s second-largest broadcaster, has sold 55 stations and gained 10 others as part of an effort to move into larger, more closely clustered markets.

headline: Life Lessons, Taught the Hard Way
text: In her latest blog post about teaching at a South Bronx middle school, Laura Klein writes about visiting a student at an in-patient psychiatric facility. As a teacher, she writes, it's easy to take comfort in knowing that her expectations for troubled students provide "simplicity in a world that is chaotic and scary." But when an incident occurs, she writes, it reinforces that, "We don’t have the solutions, and even if we did, we don’t have the power to fix the things that are broken in their lives."

headline: Kreider Is Right Where He Wants to Be on 21st Birthday
text: Chris Kreider, the only player in N.H.L. history whose first two career goals have been playoff game-winners, turned 21 Monday.

headline: Radio Royalties Fight Heats Up Again
text: A bitter fight between radio and the record industry that has lasted decades is flaring up again.

headline: How Elite Colleges Still Feed Wall St.’s Recruiting Machine
text: Three and a half years have passed since the onset of the financial crisis, and the public hasn’t changed the way it talks about Wall Street and its future. Journalists, politicians and even the Occupy movement have shaped our discussion by analyzing — and often attacking — the bankers at the helm.

headline: In Suit, Protesters Say City Violated Their Constitutional Rights
text: 4:07 p.m. | Updated The City of New York, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and several large corporations have regularly violated the constitutional rights of Occupy Wall Street protesters who have sought to express their opinions at various demonstrations across the city, according to a wide-ranging federal lawsuit filed on Monday.

headline: TimesCast | Diplomatic Tensions in China
text: April 30, 2012 — The Obama administration tries to contain a growing diplomatic crisis with China.

headline: Let Them Go Golfing
text: Sometimes politicians make up things about their opponents – like when Republicans say President Obama hates liberty.

headline: Atlanta Brings Out the Weirdness in the Celtics
text: Rajon Rondo’s probable suspension for bumping into the referee Marc Davis on Sunday is merely the latest bizarre episode that happens to the Celtics when they venture to Atlanta to play the Hawks in the playoffs.

headline: Report Finds Pipeline Oversight Wanting
text: A report issued on Monday by the National Wildlife Federation asserts that federal laws regulating oil pipelines are inadequate in several crucial areas and that local regulations do not provide sufficient protection against safety and environmental risks.

headline: Agency Scandal Highlights Conference Contracts
text: Meeting and conference planners had plenty to say about the General Services Administration’s lavish 2010 conference in Las Vegas, where guests were served $5 mini-Monte Cristo sandwiches and shrimp that cost $4 apiece. But unlike members of Congress, they argued that the hors d’oeuvres were among the few things that were properly priced.

headline: Barnes & Noble’s Nook Unit Is Worth More Than Its Parent Company
text: Of all the details that stand out from Microsoft’s deal for an 18 percent stake in Barnes & Noble’s e-reader unit, perhaps the biggest one is this: the Nook division is now worth $1.7 billion.

headline: Open to Conversation, or a Helicopter Ride
text: I USED to hate business travel. For six years, I flew so much that I was in the top tier of mileage for all the major airlines. At one point, I was flying to Europe nearly every week for most of a year.

headline: Can Hair Make You A Better Pitcher?
text: “So much of the game of baseball is perception. If you’re going to be a closer, you don’t want to look like some clean-cut, nice guy.”

headline: Two-Person ‘Slowgirl’ Announces Its Cast
text: Zeljko Ivanek and Sarah Steele will star in “Slowgirl,” a new Lincoln Center Theater production written by Greg Pierce, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Capitals’ Holtby Is Not Rattled by Shaky Game 1
text: The Capitals may be playing a tighter brand of defense, but their late-season success can also be attributed to the strong play of their young goaltender Braden Holtby.

headline: Tony Nominations Coming Tuesday: Let the Combat Begin
text: The starting bell for Broadway’s biggest horse race rings at 8:30 a.m. Tuesday when nominations for the 2012 Tony Awards will be announced. By 8:35 a.m. the shrieking and moaning from armchair critics and show queens should be underway as well, about which productions and performers were robbed of Tony nominations and about which of the lucky ones were – how shall we put it? – undeserving.

headline: "Forward" Excerpt
text: An excerpt from the Obama campaign's "Forward" web video.

headline: The Sakura Matsuri Festival
text: Hosted by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the weekend-long festival celebrated traditional and contemporary Japanese culture.

headline: American’s Best Customers Want It to Stay Independent
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I proposed that American Airlines customers form a committee to try to influence the outcome of the airline’s bankruptcy and the outcome of any potential merger between the airline and US Airways or another carrier. Members of the FlyerTalk Web community are already pondering putting something like that together in the wake of the column — if you want to check it out and weigh in.

headline: Campaign Finance Watchdogs File Complaint Against Illinois Congressman
text: 4:46 p.m. | Updated  Two campaign finance watchdogs filed a complaint Monday against a Republican congressman who asked Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, for a $25,000 contribution to an anti-incumbent “super PAC” aiming to oust a veteran Republican from the House.

headline: Fur, Feathers, Ivory and Bone: The U.S. Military and Endangered Species Souvenirs
text: The links between conflict and contraband are as old as war, and have been the subject of extensive research. The reasons are easy to grasp, if sometimes hard to trace. Wars disrupt economies and can create acute shortages, often while encouraging lawlessness and the breakdown of borders and institutions. In these circumstances, smugglers are both in demand and can thrive.

headline: A Word Heard Often, Except at the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — The most versatile of the classic Anglo-Saxon swear words has, diligent research reveals, made just one appearance in oral arguments before the Supreme Court. The cursing, in 1971, probably won the case, which concerned the prosecution of a vulgar protest against the draft during the Vietnam War. By repeating the word in court, the protester’s lawyer showed that it could have a role in public discourse. Over the next two decades or so, the word was used in nine Supreme Court decisions, typically in quotations of something a criminal had said. Its last appearance was in 1993.

headline: Signs of Volcanoes In Mars Topography
text: A new study suggests that the Athabasca Valles, a group of valleys near the Martian equator, were not formed by ice, as some scientists have theorized.

headline: Masur Sidelined Through September With Broken Shoulder Blade
text: After falling from the podium during a concert in Paris on Thursday the conductor Kurt Masur, 84, has withdrawn from all his engagements through September.

headline: Five Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Spin
text: My first New York publishing job was an internship with Spin in the summer of 1987. It wasn’t glamorous. Most of my time was spent in a stockroom stuffing envelopes with T-shirts to be sent to new subscribers. (Perhaps a nonsubscribing friend or two of mine received a Spin T-shirt as well.) I can remember exactly two highlights that summer. First, John Leland, who was a terrific Spin columnist (and who now works here at The Times), took pity on my musical ignorance and gave me a couple of preview cassettes (cassettes!) that would change my worldview: “Sister,” by Sonic Youth, and “You’re Living All Over Me,” by Dinosaur Jr.

headline: One More Reason to Love Mussels: Curry-Laced Moules à la Marinière With Fresh Peas
text: “If you’re looking for a great, sustainable source of omega-3s, think about mussels.”

headline: Iran Denounces Florida Pastor Over Koran Burning
text: TEHRAN — A Koran burning conducted by Terry Jones, the controversial pastor from Florida, has angered Iranian politicians, with one calling for Jones’s execution.

headline: Principal Fined for Canceling Class So Son Could Be Tutored
text: A Queens school principal who had a math class watch a movie, “The Karate Kid,” so the teacher could tutor the principal’s college-age son has been fined $2,000 and reprimanded, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board announced on Monday.

headline: Is the Toyota Camry Unfairly Vilified?
text: Ezra Dyer’s review of the 2012 Toyota Camry, which appeared in Sunday’s Automobiles section, touched a nerve among some Wheels readers.

headline: Denial of Anthony Gives Knicks All Types of Problems
text: The Knicks’ playoff-opening catastrophe was marked by general failures more than any specific flaw, but much attention has rightly been paid to the Miami Heat’s denial defense against Carmelo Anthony. That strategic decision alone did not and could not have produced Game 1’s 33-point final margin, but the approach and its aftermath communicated plenty about the dynamics of both teams.

headline: Look of The Moment | Elizabeth Banks
text: The Look: Red State. A pleated peplum turns an exacting column dress into a look that’s anything but conservative.

headline: Coke Denies It Is in Talks to Buy Monster Beverage
text: 7:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: Quinn Quits Wage Rally After Bloomberg Is Insulted
text: Saying she would not tolerate name-calling in political debates, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, walked out of a rally on Monday after a participant derided New York’s mayor as “Pharaoh Bloomberg.”

headline: Abuse of Opiates Soars in Pregnant Women
text: The fast-growing abuse of prescription drugs has reached maternity wards in hospitals across the country, with the number of pregnant women addicted to opiate drugs — and the number of babies born experiencing withdrawal symptoms — rising sharply over the last decade.

headline: Delta Buys Refinery to Get Control of Fuel Costs
text: Delta Air Lines said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a refinery near Philadelphia from ConocoPhillips to offset the risk of higher jet fuel prices.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: Here are the highlights from the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, including the red carpet.

headline: Disregard These Predictions
text: John Boehner said last week that his party faces a “real challenge” in holding its Congressional majority. “I would say that there is a two-in-three chance that we win control of the House again,” he said on Fox News. Then he added, presumably for the benefit of those who struggle with math, “but there’s a one-in-three chance that we could lose.”

headline: Note to Self About China: Pick a Fight, Any Fight
text: Christopher Buckley’s satirical novels do not normally prompt cognitive dissonance. But there’s something jolting at work in his latest, “They Eat Puppies, Don’t They?” This book means to be funny, but it’s about China, currently one of the least funny places on earth. It’s not a period piece, but it is badly dated. Much of its charm is derived from a heroine who seems modeled on Ann Coulter. Much of its hilarity comes from contemplating how to kill off the Dalai Lama and what to do with his corpse.

headline: HBO Quickly Renews ‘Girls’ and ‘Veep’
text: HBO never hesitates when a show breaks through the clutter and starts making noise: this spring it has added two noisy comedies to its schedule, “Girls” and “Veep,” and on Monday it jumped to renew both of them for second seasons.

headline: Scraping a Little More Sky Downtown
text: A small steel tendril poked up atop 1 World Trade Center at 2:08 p.m. on Monday. About 17 minutes later, it was joined by another. Nineteen minutes after that, the first beam joined them, making a fencelike “H.” Shortly before 3 o’clock, the whole center of gravity on the skyline shifted from Midtown back down to Lower Manhattan — at least symbolically.

headline: Should Young Athletes Be Screened for Heart Risk?
text: Should high school athletes be screened for heart trouble before taking to the practice field?

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, Venezuela, Syria, and China.

headline: Groupon Reshuffles Board After Accounting Missteps
text: After a string of accounting missteps, Groupon is adding some financial muscle to its board.

headline: T Summer Design | Must Haves
text: On our design list this summer: a bar trolley, illustrative wallpaper, timely clocks. More…

headline: Kids Draw the News | Epic Brawl Depicted
text: Thanks to all the children who took us up on our first (and somewhat controversial) “Kids Draw the News” assignment: the big fight in the Tap Room of the New York Athletic Club. Behold their handiwork, in the slide show above.

headline: Seacrest Assembles TV Empire
text: Three months ago, when the news, sports and entertainment worlds converged on Indianapolis for the Super Bowl, Ryan Seacrest was at home in Hollywood — and feeling uncharacteristically jealous.

headline: Simple Device Helps Delay Birth to Lift Babies’ Chances of Survival
text: In wealthy countries, some very premature babies are saved in intensive care units. In poor countries, they often die or develop blindness, retardation, lung problems or cerebral palsy.

headline: What a Dearth of Small Donations May Mean for Romney
text: The fund-raising apparatus powering President Obama’s re-election effort has struggled to attract the big-money donors who contributed to Mr. Obama’s record fund-raising haul in 2008.

headline: In Birds’ Pursuit of Love, New Plant Life Blooms
text: Male bowerbirds cultivate plants, a new study reports, though their gardening work appears to be unintentional.

headline: Best-Case Scenario: Two Chances to Mate
text: Male orb-web spiders have an unenviable lot. Most of the time, their mates eat them immediately after copulating. Even if that doesn’t happen, males can mate at most twice in one lifetime.

headline: United States Tops ’50 Best Restaurants’ List With 8 Spots
text: The annual list of the 50 best restaurants in the world, compiled by Restaurant, a British magazine, and sponsored by S. Pellegrino and Acqua Panna, is out. The top three restaurants remain the same: Noma in Copenhagen and Can Roca and Mugaritz in Spain.

headline: Bob Smith, Inventor of Fog-Free Ski Goggles, Dies at 78
text: As an orthodontist, Bob Smith knew how to correct a problem. And as an avid skier who tackled the mountains near his home in Alta, Utah, he recognized something in 1964 that needed fixing: ski goggles.

headline: Piano Works Both Powerful and Poetic
text: PAUL LEWIS

headline: Reliving Days (and Lyrics) When No One Got Along
text: Twenty years ago Los Angeles was burning, a conflagration that began with a videotape. Four police officers who had been captured on camera beating Rodney King were acquitted on April 29, 1992, and for days the city seethed.

headline: Academia Occupied by Occupy
text: If surveys of Occupy Wall Street supporters conducted last fall still hold true, the crowds of protesters expected to turn out Tuesday for May Day events across the country will most likely skew male, young, white, college educated, underpaid, and thoroughly disgusted with the American political system.

headline: Dutch Troupe’s Long Road to the Joyce
text: In many ways, Roel Voorintholt and Ton Wiggers seem like an old married couple. The two men spend a great deal of each day together. They also live in the same house. They argue with withering humor over who will buy cigarettes. But Mr. Voorintholt and Mr. Wiggers aren’t a couple (well, at least not right now, but more on that later).

headline: Playing a Dogmatic Leader’s Power Games
text: On Friday evening Bloom! Dance Collective, a group of five dancer-choreographers with roots in Hungary, Italy and Spain, made its American debut at Abrons Arts Center. If the piece it presented, “City,” is an indication, this group isn’t coy when it comes to addressing social issues. Even though these artists, based in London and Budapest, welcome humor and convey a decidedly casual vibe, “City” is political dance. End of story.

headline: Clip: ‘First Position’
text: A scene from the documentary “First Position,” about young contestants in a ballet competition.

headline: Life in the Sea Found Its Fate in a Paroxysm of Extinction
text: It may never be as well known as the Cretaceous extinction, the one that killed off the dinosaurs. Yet the much earlier Permian extinction — 252 million years ago — was by far the most catastrophic of the planet’s five known paroxysms of species loss.

headline: Looking to Make a Profit on Lawsuits, Firms Invest in Them
text: When it comes to legal spats, companies often loathe having to spend millions of dollars on legal fees while waiting months for a case to drag through courts. But to Wall Street, lengthy litigation is a growing investment opportunity.

headline: An Underground Fossil Forest Offers Clues on Climate Change
text: In the clammy depths of a southern Illinois coal mine lies the largest fossil forest ever discovered, at least 50 times as extensive as the previous contender.

headline: Cuomo Forms Panel to Make 'Action Plan' for  Education
text: Richard D. Parsons, a New York businessman, was named chairman of a new state education commission by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: An Olympic Champion, a Symbol and an Awkward Partner With Fame
text: If all you know about Jesse Owens is Hitler, four gold medals and, oh yeah, didn’t he run against a horse?, then the “American Experience” documentary “Jesse Owens” (Tuesday night on PBS stations) will fill some gaps in brisk and entertaining fashion.

headline: As Brooklyn Rents Rise, She Stalks the $625 Apartment
text: If you live in New York and happen to have about $625 in your pocket, you could go out and buy yourself a plane ticket to Los Angeles, a 32-gigabyte iPad, or perhaps a shiny pair of Christian Louboutin pumps. Or you could make that your monthly rent in a city apartment, by sticking with Sophia Cosmadopoulos.

headline: Breathing Fire With Ballads
text: “Blown Away,” the new album by Carrie Underwood, the shiny but tough country star, starts out loud, sassy, rollicking and wise. “Good Girl” is the first song — a little Pat Benatar, a little Tanya Tucker — and it plays out like a sequel to Ms. Underwood’s 2006 smash “Before He Cheats,” except, instead of taking out her rightfully stoked dissatisfaction on her ex, she opts for unity and warns the next woman instead.

text: José Trivino leaned against his shiny, black Lincoln Town Car in Jamaica, Queens on Monday, gawking at a newspaper photo of the new “Boro Taxi.”

headline: Devils Seek Answers With Kovalchuk
text: NEWARK — One day after a playoff game in which he was virtually invisible, Ilya Kovalchuk, the Devils’ $100 million forward, was not available to speak with the news media Monday because he was visiting a therapist, a team spokesman said.

headline: High Turnover for Charter School Principals, Report Says
text: A report by charter school advocates found that teacher and principal attrition is a significant hurdle for the sector, which is young but growing quickly.

headline: Where China Is a Hot Topic, Even at Lunch

But although a dress code of business attire is unofficially enforced, DealBook has met many attendees who don’t work on Wall Street. (We particularly liked our conversation with the founder of a technology firm who had strong feelings about United States maritime laws.)

headline: With App, Groups Seek Better Way to Report Complaints of Profiling by Airport Security
text: WASHINGTON — Civil rights groups are going digital to combat what they say are instances of racial profiling by security screeners at the nation’s airports.

headline: Loyalists of Mali’s Overthrown Leader Appear to Be Attempting Countercoup
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Gunfire rang out over this West African capital Monday night as soldiers loyal to the president, who was deposed in a coup in March, appeared to be attempting a countercoup against the ruling military junta.

headline: Don’t Know Much About (Ancient) History
text: The things I do for book sales. I debated, sort of, Ron Paul on Bloomberg.Video here. I thought we might have a discussion of why the runaway inflation he and his allies keep predicting keeps not happening. But no, he insisted (if I understood him correctly) that currency debasement and price controls destroyed the Roman Empire. I responded that I am not a defender of the economic policies of the Emperor Diocletian.

headline: Yankees Have Unfamiliar Alignment in Outfield
text: The Yankees’ outfield has taken on a shape-shifting quality recently because of injuries to the starters at both corners. That showed in the lineup Monday night against Baltimore, which featured infielder Eduardo Nunez in left field and the defensively challenged Raul Ibanez right.

headline: Tigers’ Young Is Suspended for 7 Days After His Arrest
text: Delmon Young of the Detroit Tigers was suspended for seven days without pay by Major League Baseball on Monday, nearly four days after his arrest in Manhattan on a second-degree aggravated harassment charge.

headline: India: Crowded Ferry Capsizes
text: At least 35 people are dead and more than 160 are missing after a ferry carrying as many as 350 passengers capsized Monday on the swollen Brahmaputra River in eastern India during a severe storm, according to media reports and government officials. Other accounts in the Indian media put the death toll at more than 100. The accident occurred in the remote Indian state of Assam. The state police chief, J. N. Choudhury, told The Associated Press that about 150 people managed to swim to safety or were rescued. Ferry accidents happen with a grim frequency in eastern India and Bangladesh, where many people depend on boats to travel through the region.

headline: With Green Beret Tactics, Combating Gang Warfare
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — At first glance, the Brightwood neighborhood in this central New England city would seem to have little in common with war-torn villages in Iraq or Afghanistan.
